sense.s: The fourteenth letter of the alphabet; called SaAdN. It is one of the letters termed mahomuwsap [or nonvocal, i. e. pronounced with the breath only, without the voice]; and of the letters termed OasaliyRap, as also z and s, because proceeding from the tip of the tongue; (TA;) and is one of the letters termed musotaEoliyap, which are obstacles to UimaAlap: (M in art. Swd:) it is not conjoined with s, nor with z, [nor, as some say, with j, (see UijRaASN,)] in any Arabic word. (TA. [See also art. Swd.]) It is a radical, and a substitute; not an augmentative. (M in art. Swd.) It is sometimes substituted for s; and, as MF observes, what Ibn-Umm-Kásim says appears to mean that this substitution is allowable unrestrictedly; but Ibn-Málik, in the Tes-heel, makes it subject to conditions, saying that it is allowable accord. to a certain dial. when the s is followed by g or x or q or T, even when separated therefrom by a letter or by two letters: MF says that the dial. above mentioned is that of Benu-l-'Ambar, accord. to Sb and others; who give as exs. Sagiba for sagiba, and Saxira for saxira, and SaqabN for saqabN, and SaTaEa for saTaEa. (TA.)
[As a numeral, S denotes Ninety.]

1. SaYiba raOosuhu His head abounded with SuWaAb [or nits]; (S, M, K;) as also ASOb↓. (S, K.) SaYiba mina AlXRaraAbi, (M, K,) aor.
SaAa^a
, (K,) inf. n. SaOobN, (M,) He was, or became, satisfied, and filled, with drink: (M, K:) or SaYiba [alone] he drank much water. (S.)
4: see the preceding paragraph.
SuWobapN A granary, or granaries, (OanobaAr,) of wheat (TaEaAm). (K.)
And A place where dates are dried: so in the dial. of the people of El-Felj. (TA in art. HDr.)
SuWaAbN: see the next paragraph, in three places.

SuWaAbN, (S, K,) vulgarly pronounced SuwaAbap, without., (MF, TA,) A nit; i. e. an egg of a louse; (S, K;) and an egg of a flea; (K;) but accord. to some, not applied to the latter unless tropically: (MF, TA:) accord. to IDrst, a young louse: (TA:) or the eggs of the flea and of the louse; as also SuWaAbN↓: (M:) [or,] accord. to the S and K, SuWaAbN↓ and SiYobaAnN, (TA,) the latter of which is vulgarly pronounced SiybaAn, without C, (MF, TA,) are pls. of SuWaAbapN; but the former of them is a coll. gen. n., of which SuWaAbapN is the n. un.: (TA:) Yaakoob has erroneously asserted that one should not say SiYobaAnN. (M, TA.)
SuWaAbN↓ is also sometimes applied to (assumed tropical:) The small pieces of gold that are taken forth from the dust, or earth, of the mine. (IDrst, TA.) In the following verse, cited by IAar,

the poet means, [O my Lord,] cause me to find gold like SuWaAb [or nits], whole, or sound, not broken into minute parts; [for I see not the TayRaAr to stand in any stead; XayRaA being for XayoYFA;] by the TyRAr meaning the minutest pieces of gold that the wind blows away. (M, L, TA.)

And [the pl.] SiYobaAnN signifies [also] (assumed tropical:) Hoar-frost formed into grains like small pearls. (A'Obeyd, L, TA.) [And drops of fine rain are said to be likened to SiYobaAn: see Ham p. 796. See also SabiIRN (in art. Sbw), last sentence.]
miSoOabN A man who drinks much water: (S:) or who satisfies and fills himself with drink. (K.)

1. SaYika, aor.
SaAa^a
, (AZ, S, O, K,) inf. n. SaOakN, (AZ, S, O,) He (a man, AZ, S, O) sweated so that there arose from him a fetid odour, (AZ, S, O, K,) from cafar [app. as meaning stench of the arm-pit], or otherwise. (AZ, S, O.)
And, said of blood, It congealed. (O, K.)

And SaYika bihi It (a thing, TA) stuck, or clave, to him. (K, TA.) Hence, accord. to the 'Eyn, SaAka, used in this sense in a verse of El-Aashà: (TA:) or this belongs to art. Syk, (S and O in that art.,) agreeably with the opinion of ISd. (TA in that art.)

3. ZalRa yuSaAYikuniI munocu Alyawomi He has continued vying with me, or contending with me for superiority, or striving to surpass me, in strength, or power, or force, (yuXaAdRuniI,) all this day. (O, K, * TA.) [And so yuSaAyikuniI, mentioned in the TA in art. Swk; but app. belonging to art. Syk.]
SaYikN A strong man. (O, K.)

SaOokapN The odour, (K, TA,) i. e. altered odour, (TA,) of a piece of wood when it has become moist. (K, TA.) [And probably The altered colour and odour of rain-water trickling from trees: see what follows.]
SaAYikN, applied to rain trickling from trees, [app. a possessive epithet, meaning cuw SaOokapK,] Altered in colour and odour. (TA in art. Hlb.)

1. SaOaI, (S, M, K,) aor. yaSoYiI, (M,) like SaEaI aor. yaSoEiI, (S, [in one of my copies of the S yaSoEaI, which is wrong, or, accord. to the TA, both are correct, and in the K the pret. is said to be like saEaI, which implies that the aor. is like yasoEaI,]) inf. n. SaYiIRN (S, M, K) and SiYiIRN (Ks, M, K, TA) and SuYiIRN, (Ks, K, TA,) said of a young bird and the like, (S, K,) of a bird and of a young bird (M) and of a rat or mouse (S, M) and of a jerboa (S) and of a cat and of a dog (M) and of a pig and of an elephant, (S, M,) It uttered a cry, or sound; (S, M, K;) as also taSaMCaI↓: (M, K:) and accord. to Fr, one says also of the scorpion, taSiIoCu and taSoYiI. (S.) It is said in a prov., talodagu AlEaqorabu wataSoYiI or wataSiIoCu, (As, S, Meyd,) this latter verb being formed by transposition, (Meyd,) i. e. The scorpion stings while uttering a cry; (S, Meyd;) the w being a denotative of state: (As, S:) applied to him who does wrong in the guise of him who complains of wrongdoing. (Meyd.) And one says also, jaMCa bimaA SaOaI waSamata, (S, K,) and bimaA SaMCa waSamata (IAar, S, TA,) SaMCa being formed by tranposition from SaOaI, (S,) He brought what was vocal and what was mute; (S, K;) such as slaves and beasts, and clothes and silver; (As, TA;) or sheep or goats, and camels, and gold and silver; (IAar, TA;) meaning he brought much property: and this is likewise a prov. (S.)
4. OaSoOayotuhu I made it (i. e. a young bird &c.) to utter a cry, or sound. (M, K. [See 1.])
6: see the first paragraph above.

SaYiIRN, of the measure faEiylN, (TA, [originally an inf. n., written in a copy of the M SiYoIN, but the
former is evidently the right,]) The bitch: so called because of her cry. (TA.)

1. SabRa, (S, M, Msb, K, &, c.,) aor.
Sabuba
, inf. n. SabRN, (M, Msb,) He poured out, or forth (S, M, Msb, K) water (S, M, Msb) and the like. (M.) One says, Sababotu lifulaAnK maMCF fiI AlqadaHi liyaXorabahu [I poured out for such a one water into the drinkingcup that he might drink it]. (TA. [See also 8.])

Hence [(assumed tropical:) He paid down a price, or sum of money:] it is said in a trad., Uino OaHabRa Oaholuka Oano waAHidapF OaSabRa lahumo vamanaka SubRapF↓, meaning [(assumed tropical:) If thy family like that I should pay down to them thy price] at once, or at one time. (L, TA.)
And SabRa AlHabola fiI AlbiYori [(assumed tropical:) He lowered, or let down, the rope into the well] on the occasion of drawing water. (M in art. tl.)
And lamo yaSubRa raOosahu (assumed tropical:) He did not bend down his head: occurring in a trad. relating to prayer. (T, TA.)
And SubRa rijolaA fulaAnK fiI Alqayodi (tropical:) The legs of such a one were [put into the shackles, or] shackled. (Z, L, TA.)
And SabRa diroEahu (tropical:) He put on, or clad himself with, his coat of mail: (A, TA:) and SababotuhaA Ealayohi (tropical:) [I put it on him]. (A.)
And SabRa Ealayohi nafosahu (tropical:) [He threw himself upon him]. (A.)
And huwa yaSubRu UilaIRa Alxayora (tropical:) [He pours forth to me wealth]. (A, TA.)

And SabRa QllRehu Ealayohimo sawoTa EacaAbK (tropical:) [God poured upon them a portion, or a share, or vehemence, or severity, of punishment; or] God punished them. (A, * TA. [See also sawoTN.]) And SabRa QllRehu Ealayohi SaAEiqapF (tropical:) [God poured upon him a thunderbolt, or a destructive punishment, &c.]. (A, TA.) See also another ex. voce SabRN.
And SubRa, (K, TA,) in the pass. form, said of a man, and of a thing, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He, or it, was annihilated, caused to pass away, or done away with. (K, TA. [See also R. Q. 2.])
See also 7, with which it is syn. in the first of the senses assigned to the latter below.

[Hence, app.,] SabRa fiI AlwaAdiI (assumed tropical:) He descended into the valley. (M, K.) And qadamaAhu fiI baToni AinoSabRato↓ AlwaAdiI, occurring in a trad., means (assumed tropical:) His feet descended [into the interior, or bottom, of the valley]: (TA:) or AnoSabRato qadamaAhu fiI AlwaAdiI means (assumed tropical:) his feet rested in the valley; from AinoSabRa said of water. (Mgh.)

And SabRati AlHayRapu EalaI Almaloduwgi, (S, * TA,) or AnSbRt↓, (A,) (tropical:) [The serpent darted down upon the person bitten by it], said of the serpent when it has raised itself desiring to bite. (Ez-Zuhree, S, TA. *) And AlbaAziI EalaI AlSRayodi AnSbR↓ (tropical:) [The hawk, or falcon, stooped upon the prey, or quarry]. (A, TA.) And SabRa cuWaAlapu EalaI ganami fulaAnK (A, * TA) (tropical:) The wolf [rushed upon or] made havock among the sheep, or goats, of such a one. (TA.)

SabRa, (IAar, A, TA,) sec. pers. Sabibota, (S, M, * K,) aor. yaSabRu, (IAar, TA,) inf. n. SabaAbapN, (IAar, S, * M, A, K, * TA,) He (a man) was, or became, affected with excessive love, or with attachment, or admiring love, (IAar, S, TA,) and desire: (S:) or with desire: (M, A, K:) or with tenderness of desire, (S, M, A, K,) and ardour thereof: (S:) or with tenderness of love. (M, K.) One says, Sabibotu Uilayohi [I was, or became, affected with excessive love, &c., for him]. (M, A, * TA. *) And SabRa bihaA and UilayohaA He was, or became, affected with desire, or vehement desire, [&c.,] of, or for, her. (MA.)

Lh mentions, among what is said by the women of the Arabs of the desert on the occasion of fascinating by means of charms, faQSobabo Uilayohi SabRN↓, i. e. OariqN faOoraqo Uilayohi [as though meaning May he be sleepless by reason of love, and I will be sleepless for him: but I incline to think that the explanation has been corrupted by a copyist from raqRa faOariqRa Uilayohi, or lahu, meaning may he be tender-hearted to me, and I will be tenderhearted to him]. (M, L, TA.)
4. OaSabRuwA They (a company of men, TA) took their way down a declivity, or declivous place. (M, K, TA.)
5: see 7, in four places.
And see also what here follows.

6. taSaAbabotu AlmaMCa I drank what remained of the water (S, A, K) in a vessel: (S, A:) [or] you say, tSAbR AlSRubaAbapa and ASTbRhA↓ and tSbRbhA↓ [he drank what remained of the water, or of the milk, in a vessel]; (M, L;) all signifying the same. (L, TA.)

And [hence,] taSaAbRa fulaAnN AlmaEiyXapa baEoda fulAnK [lit. Such a one drank the remains of life after such a one], meaning (tropical:) such a one outlived such a one: (A, * TA:) and taSaAbabotuhumo OajomaEiyna UilRaA waAHidFA (tropical:) [I outlived them all except one]. (TA.) Esh-Shemmákh says, (M,) or ElAkhtal, (TA,)

(tropical:) [Verily the loss of a people whom I have outlived is more severe to me than abundant and long hair that has become altered in colour]: he means, the loss of those with whom I was in a state of ease and plenty is more severe to me than my hair's becoming white: (M:) Az says, he likens what remained of his life to the remains of beverage that he was sipping up. (TA.)

7. AnSbR It (water, S, M, and the like, M) poured out or forth, or became poured out or forth; (S, M, A, K;) as also SabRa↓, (M, Msb, K,) aor.
Sabiba
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. SabiybN; (Msb;) and tSbRb↓, (M, K,) which is of a form rarely occurring as that of a quasi-pass. of an unaugmented triliteral verb, being generally that of the quasi-pass. of a verb of the form faERala; (MF, TA;) [but this app. denotes its doing so repeatedly; and abundantly, like tadafRaqa, q. v.;] and ASTbR↓. (K.) One says, AlmaMCu yanoSabRu mina Aljabali, (TA,) and mn Aljbl yataSabRabu↓, (S, TA,) The water descends, little by little, from the mountain. (S, TA.) And AlEaraqu tSbRb↓ [The sweat flowed], and AldRamu [the blood]. (A.) And EaraqFA taSabRabotu↓ [which may be rendered I flowed with sweat] is a phrase of the Arabs, meaning tSbRb EaraqiI [my sweat flowed]: thus the act is literally ascribed to the speaker, and what is essentially the agent becomes a specificative: it is not allowable to say EaraqFA taSabRabotu; for, as it is not allowable to put the agent before the verb, so it is not allowable to put the specificative, when it is virtually the agent, before the verb. (IJ, M.)
One says also, AnSbR Alkuwzu [The mug had its contents poured out or forth]. (TA in art. dfq.)
See also 1, in three places.
AnSb AlnRaAsu EalaI AlmaMCi [generally implies descent, but] means (assumed tropical:) The people collected together, or assembled, at the water. (Msb.)
[And AnSbR is often said of a place, or the ground, &c., meaning (assumed tropical:) It sloped downwards.
Har (p. 125) uses the phrase tanoSabRu UilaI AllRahowi, meaning (as there expl.) (assumed tropical:) Thou inclinest to diversion, or sport..]

8. ASTbR AlmaMCa is expl. by Sb as signifying He took for himself the water; agreeably with general analogy: (M:) [but it is more properly rendered he poured out for himself the water:] one says, AiSoTababotu linafosiI maMCF mina Alqirobapi liOaXorabahu [I poured out for myself water from the skin that I might drink it]: and AiSoTababotu linafosiI qadaHFA [I poured out for myself a cup]. (TA.)
See also 6.
And see 7.
R. Q. 1. SaboSabahu (assumed tropical:) He annihilated it, caused it to pass away, or did away with it; (M, K; *) namely, a thing. (M.)
And (assumed tropical:) He dispersed it, or scattered it: (K:) he (a man) dispersed, or scattered, it, namely, an army, or property or wealth. (AA, K.)
R. Q. 2. taSaboSaba (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, annihilated, caused to pass away, or done away with; (S, M, K;) it passed, or went, away; said of a thing. (S, M. [See also SubRa.])
(assumed tropical:) It (the night, M, A, K, and the day, AZ, TA, and the heat, A) passed, or went, away, (AZ, M, A, K,) except a small portion, (AZ, M, TA,) or for the most part. (A. K.)
(assumed tropical:) It (what was in a water-skin, or milk-skin,) became little in quantity. (Fr, TA.)
(assumed tropical:) It (a company of men) became dispersed, or scattered. (M, TA.)
He (a man) was, or became, very bold, or daring, and very adverse, or repugnant, (M, * K, * TA,) EalayonaA [against us]. (TA.)
And, said of a day, It was, or became, intensely hot. (M, K, * TA.)

SabRN is an inf. n. [and is] used [as an epithet] in the sense of the measure faAEilN, or of the measure mafoEuwlN: (TA:) [thus it is used as an epithet] applied to water, [meaning Pouring out or forth, or poured out or forth,] like as are sakobN and gaworN: (S, TA: [see also SaAbRN and SabiybN:]) and hence, in 'Alee's description of Aboo-Bekr, when he died, kunota EalaI AlkaAfiriyna EacaAbFA SabRFA (assumed tropical:) [Thou wast, against, or upon, the unbelievers, a punishment pouring forth, or poured forth]. (TA.)

And [hence, app.,] one says, Darabahu DarobFA SabRFA, meaning (assumed tropical:) He smote him with the edge of the sword [as though with a smiting pouring down, or poured down]; as also
HadorF. (IAar, L, TA.)

One says also, Darabahu miAYipF faSabRFA, (TA,) or Oaxaca miAYapF faSabRFA, (A,) meaning, (tropical:) [He smote him with a hundred blows, or he took a hundred,] and less than that, i. e. faduwna celika, (TA,) contr. of faSaAEidFA; (A;) or and more [than that], or above [that], i. e. like faSaAEidFA, (A, TA,) i. e. maA fawoqa celika. (TA.)
And Ealayohi AlbalaMCu SubRa↓, mino SabRK, meaning (tropical:) [Trial, or affliction, was poured upon him] from above. (A, TA.)

Also, applied to a man, Affected with excessive love, or with attachment, or admiring love, (IAar, S, A, * TA,) and desire: (S:) or with desire: (M, A, * K:) or with tenderness of desire, (S, * M, A, * K,) and ardour thereof: (S: * [see SabRa:]) or with tenderness of love. (M, K.) One says, huwa SabRN bihaA (and UilayohaA (see SabRa)] He is affected with excessive love of her; &c.: (A:) fem. SabRapN: (M, K:) dual masc. SabRaAni, pl. masc. SabRuwna; dual. fem. SabRataAni, pl. fem. SabRaAtN: thus accord. to those who hold rajulN SabRN to be similar to rajulN fahimN and HacirN, originally SabibN: (TA:) [hence it appears that some hold SabRN to be originally an inf. n., and therefore use it as an epithet in its original form, without regard to gender or number: but] accord. to Sb, SabRN is [originally] of the measure faEilN, because you say Sabibotu SabaAbapF, like as you say qaniEotu qanaAEapF. (M.) See also 1, last sentence.
SubRN: see SubRapN.

Accord. to AO, it may also be pl. of SabuwbN↓ or of SaAbRN↓: but Az says that, accord. to others, it is not pl. of either of these two words; their pl. being SububN: (L, TA:) it is said in a trad., (S, L, TA,) respecting conflicts and factions, or seditions, (L, TA,) lataEuwdunRa fiyhaA OasaAwida SubRFA yaDoribu baEoDukumo riqaAba baEoDK: (S, L, TA:) here by OasaAwid are meant “ [great and noxious] serpents: ” (L, TA:) and SubRFA, accord. to Ez-Zuhree, is from AlSRabRu [“ the act of pouring out or forth ”]; for the serpent, he says, when it desires to bite, raises itself, and then darts down (lit. pours down) upon him that is bitten: (S, L, TA:) [as though the meaning were, Ye will be, therein, like great and noxious serpents, one portion of you smiting the necks of another portion:] Ez-Zuhree says that SubRFA is pl. of SabuwbN↓, and originally SububFA; like as rajulN SabRN is originally SabibN; and so says IAmb: but IAar is related to have said that OasaAwid means companies, pl. of sawaAdN; and SubRFA, pouring, one upon another, with slaughter: and some say that it is SubRaI, in measure like HubolaI; and it is said to be from SabaA, [for SabaA UilaI AldRunoyaA,] aor. yaSobuw, meaning “ he inclined to the things of the present world; ” and thus to be like guzRaI, pl. of gaAzK: [see SaAbK, in art. Sbw:] IAar used also to say that it is originally SubRaOF, with C, [pl. of SaAbiYN,] from SabaOF Ealayohi “ he came, or came forth, upon him unexpectedly. ” (L, TA.)
SubRapN A quantity of wheat or food, &c., that is poured out or forth (M, K) together, or collectedly; (M;) also (M, K) sometimes (M) termed SubRN↓. (M, K.) See also 1, near the beginning.

And A suforap [or piece of skin in which the traveller puts his food; or the thing upon which one eats]; (M, K;) so called because the food is poured into it, or upon it: (M:) or a thing like the suforap: (M, K:) and SunRapN, with n, signifies the same. (M.)
See also SubaAbapN, with which it is syn.
Also A company of men: (M, Msb, K:) [app. tropical; but it is said that] this is the primary meaning, and it is used in relation to camels, and sheep or goats, and the like, tropically. (TA.)

(tropical:) A detached number of horses, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) and of camels, (A, K,) and of sheep or goats, (A, Msb, K,) and of dirhems, or pieces of money: (A:) or from ten to forty: (A, K:) or from twenty to thirty and forty of camels and of sheep or goats: or less than a hundred (M, A, K) of camels: (M, K:) or of camels i. q. SiromapN: (S:) and from ten to forty of goats: (AZ, S:) or a flock of sheep or a herd of goats, as being likened to a company of men: (TA:) or from twenty to forty of sheep and of goats; or peculiarly of goats: or about fifty: or from sixty to seventy: and of camels about five or six: (IAth, TA:) and a collection of dirhems, or pieces of money, and of wheat, or food, &c.: and a piece of a thing: (Msb:) [or] a small quantity or portion of wealth or property. (M, K.)
And (assumed tropical:) A part, or portion, of the night: so in the saying, maDato SubRapN mina AllRayoli (assumed tropical:) [A part, or portion, of the night passed]. (S.)
SababN The descent, (taSawRub, M, L, TA, in the K erroneously written taSabRub, TA,) of a river, or rivulet, or channel of water, or of a road, down a declivity. (M, L, K, TA.)

And A declivity, declivous place, or ground sloping down; (M, A, K, TA;) and (TA) so SabiybN↓, of which the pl. is OaSobaAbN; (S, TA;) so too SabuwbN↓ and SubuwbN↓, with fet-h and with damm; (TA;) [i. e.] AlSRabuwbu↓ signifies that down which you descend, or have descended, (maA QnoSababota fiyhi,) and its pl. is SububN [like EumudN pl. of EamuwdN]; (M, TA;) [and so AlSRubuwbu↓;] or, as some say, AlSRabuwbu↓, with fet-h, is a name for the water, &c., that is poured out upon a man, like TahuwrN and gasuwlN; and SubuwbN↓, with damm, is pl. of SababN: but AZ mentions his having heard the Arabs apply SabuwbN↓ to a declivity, or declivous place; and says that its pl. is SububN: (TA:) and AlSRababu mina AlrRamoli signifies what has poured out or forth or down, of sand: (M, K: *) and the pl. of SababN is OaSobaAbN. (M, K.)
SubaAbN: see SubaAbapN.
SabuwbN [app. syn. with SaAbRN↓ as part. n. of the intrans. verb SabRa, signifying Pouring out or forth or down; or like the latter but having an intensive meaning]: see SubRN, in two places.
See also SababN, in four places.
SubuwbN: see SababN, in three places.
SabiybN [Poured out or forth: (see also SabRN, first sentence:) or, as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates,] water poured out or forth; syn. maMCN maSobuwbN↓. (M, K.)
And (M, K) some say (M) Blood: (S, M, K:) and sweat; (K;) as in the saying,

[Vehement midday-heats that draw forth the sweat]: (TA:) [or what is poured forth of sweat and of blood; for] one says, jaraI Sabiybu AlEaraqi and AldRami [What was poured forth, of the sweat and of the blood, ran, or flowed]. (A.)
And (M, K) some say (M) The expressed juice of Eanodam [or dragon's blood]. (M, K.)
And (M, K) some say (M) A certain red dye. (M, K.)

And (K) The juice of the leaves of sesame: (S, M, * K: *) A 'Obeyd (so in a copy of the S, or Aboo-'Obeydeh accord. to the TA,) says, it is the juice of the leaves of sesame, or of some other plant, which was described to me in Egypt, the colour of which juice is red tinged with blackness: and some say, it is the expressed juice of the leaves of the HinRaMC [q. v.]. (S, TA.)
And EuSofur [i. e. Safflower]: (K:) or purified EuSofur. (S.)
And A kind of tree [or plant] resembling sacaAb [or rue], (M, K,) with which the hair is dyed. (M.)
And Senna, (M, K,) with which beards are dyed, as with HinRaMC. (M.)
And A certain thing [or plant] resembling the wasomap [or wasimap, q. v.], (M, K, TA,) with which beards are dyed. (TA.)
Also Hoar-frost. (AA, K.) AA cites, as descriptive of the sky,
[And there is not in it aught save east wind and its hoar-frost]. (TA.)
And Good, or excellent, honey. (K.)
Also, (K,) or Sabiybu sayofK, (TA,) The extremity of a sword: (K, TA:) or the extremity next the siylaAn [q. v.] thereof: or, as some say, its sylAn absolutely. (TA.)
See also SababN.

SabaAbapN [is an inf. n., mentioned as such in the latter part of the first paragraph, and, when used as a simple subst.,] signifies [Excessive love, or attachment, or admiring love: (see its verb:) or] desire: (M, A, K:) or tenderness of desire, (S, M, A, K,) and ardour thereof: (S:) or tenderness of love. (M, K.)

SubaAbapN and SubRapN↓ A portion, (S, M, Msb, K,) or a small quantity, (Fr, A, and A 'Obeyd in explanation of the former,) of water, (Fr, S, M, Msb, K,) and of milk, (M, K,) or of wine, or beverage, (A 'Obeyd,) remaining (A 'Obeyd, S, M, Msb, K) in a vessel. (A 'Obeyd, S, M, Msb.)

My remaining portion of water in the vessel &c. satisfies thirst, though it is not water running [copiously] upon the surface of the earth, is a prov., applied to him who makes use of that which is bestowed though it be not much. (Meyd, TA. *) In the following verse, cited by IAar,

(tropical:) [During many a night have I guided in the right way young men infused with the remains of drowsiness that made them to bend their necks from side to side], SubaAb may be put for SubaAbap; or it may be pl. of the latter, [or rather a coll. gen. n. of which SubaAbap is the n. un.,] like as XaEiyrN is of XaEiyrapN: the poet uses this word metaphorically, in relation to drowsiness, like as he has used the word suquwA. (M, L, TA.) One says also lamo Oudoriko mina AlEayoXi UilRaA SubaAbapF and UilRaA SubaAbaAtK (tropical:) [I did not attain, or obtain, of life, save a small remainder and small remains]. (A, TA.)
SaAbRN: see SabuwbN: and see also SubRN.
SaboSabN, (M, K,) applied to a camel, (M,) Thick, or big, and strong; as also SubaASibN↓, (M, K, TA, in the CK SabaASib,) so applied; (M;) and SaboSaAbN↓, (K,) likewise so applied. (TA.)
SaboSaAbN: see what next precedes.

Also, applied to a [journey such as is termed] qarab, Hard, or severe: (M, TA:) and, applied to a [journey such as is termed] ximos, i. q. baSobaASN (As, S, K) and HaSoHaASN, i. e., in which is no delay, or intermission, nor any flagging. (As, TA.)
And AlSRaboSaAbu also signifies What remains of the thing: or what is poured out from it; (K, TA;) i. e., from the thing; by which is here said to be meant the water-skin or milk-skin. (TA.)
SubaASibN: see SaboSabN.
AlOaSabRu [app. a dial. var. of AlOaSamRu], an epithet applied to the month rajabN: (TA in art. Hrm:) see muHarRamN.

[maSabRN A place where water, or the like, pours out or forth, from a river into another river or into the sea &c., or from a tank or a gutter &c., and from high ground into a valley (see DaAjiEapN); and a sink, or sink-hole: pl. maSaAbRu (occurring in the S and K in art. rfq, &c.).]
[miSobaAbN, accord. to Reiske, signifies A ship: so says Freytag: but for this I find no authority.]
maSobuwbN: see SabiybN, first sentence.

1. SabaOa, (S, M, K,) aor.
SabaAa
, (M, K,) inf. n. SubuwoCN, (S, M, K, [in the last of which it is implied that this verb in all its senses except the last has SaboCN also for an inf. n., and likewise SabuWa as a syn. form, but this I do not find authorized by any other lexicon,]) said of the tush (S, M, K) of a camel (S, M) and of a cloven-hoofed animal and of a solid-hoofed animal, (M,) and said of a cloven hoof, (K, [but this, I doubt not, is a mistake, for in the place of SabaOa AlZRilofu wAlnRaAbu, the reading in the K, I find in the M SabaOa naAbu AlZRilofi waAlxufRi waAlHaAfiri, and the like in the L,]) It grew forth; (M, K;) or its point, or extremity, grew forth: (S:) and accord. to the K, it appears that ASbO↓ signifies the same; but this is not the case. (TA.) And SabaOat said of the vaniyRap [i. e. a central incisor] of a boy, It grew forth. (S.)

Also, said of a star, (M, K,) and of the moon, (M,) It rose; and so ASbO↓: (M, K:) or taSobaOa AlnRujuwmu the stars come forth from their places of rising: (AO, S:) or SabaOati AlnRujuwmu the stars appeared: (TA:) and AlnRajomu ASbO↓ the Pleiades [antonomastically called Alnjm] rose. (S.)

[Hence,] SabaOa, (S, M, K,) or SabaOa mino diynihi UilaI diynK Mxara, (AO, S, Msb, *) aor.
SabaAa
, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. SubuwoCN (S, M, K) and SaboCN; and SabuWa, (M, K,) aor.
SabuAa
, (TA,) inf. n. SubuwoCapN; (CK [but not in the TA nor in my MS. copy of the K];) (assumed tropical:) He departed from his religion to another religion; (S, M, Msb, K;) like as the stars come forth from their place of rising. (AO, S.) And SabaOa, (S,) or SabaOa fiI diynihi, aor.
SabaAa
, inf. n. SubuwoCN, (T, TA,) He was, or became, a SaAbiY [or Sabian]. (T, S, TA. [See SaAbiYN, below.])

And SabaOa Ealayohimo, (S, M,) aor.
SabaAa
, (S,) inf. n. SaboCN and SubuwoCN, He came forth upon them; (S, M;) as also ASbO↓: (M:) and accord. to IAar, SabaOa Ealayohi he came forth, or went forth, upon him, or against him: and he inclined against him with enmity: (TA:) or he came, or came forth, upon him unexpectedly: whence, he says, the word SubRFA in the saying of the Prophet, lataEuwduwnRa fiyhaA OasaAwida SubRFA, [which see in art. Sb,] the said word being of the measure fuERalFA, [originally SubRaOF,] and the C being suppressed: (L in art. Sb:) and OaSobaOahumo↓ signifies he came upon them suddenly, not having knowledge of their place. (K.)

One says also, SabaOa Ealayohimu AlEaduwRa, (M, * K,) aor.
SabaAa
, inf. n. SaboCN; (M;) as also SabaEa; (TA;) He guided to them (M, K) the enemy: (K:) mentioned by IAar, from AZ. (TA.)

And qudRima Uilayohi TaEaAmN famaA SabaOa walaA OaSobaOa↓ Food was presented to him, and he did not put (M, K *) his hand (M) or his finger (UiSobaEahu K) into it, or upon it: (M,) K: [see also SabaEa:]) mentioned by IAar. (M.) And SabaOa fiI AlTRaEaAmi, aor.
SabuAa
, He [app. a camel] put his head into the food: as also Sabaga. (O in art. Sbg.) And SabaOato fiyhaA raOosahaA [or fiyhi, She put her head into it]; like Sabagato. (TA in that art.)
4: see the preceding paragraph, in six places.

SaAbiYN [part. n. of SabaOa: and as such signifying] One who departs from his religion to another religion. (Msb.) The Arabs used to call the Prophet AlSRaAbiI [for AlSRaAbiYu], because he departed from the religion of Kureysh to El-Islám; and him who entered the religion of El-Islám, maSobuwRN, changing the C to w; and the Muslims [collectively], AlSRubaApN, as though pl. of AlSRaAbiIi, without C, like quDaApN and guzaApN pls. of qaADK and gaAzK. (TA.) And [the pl.] AlSRaAbiYuwna in the Kur [v. 73, &c.,] is said by Zj to mean Those who depart from one religion to another. (TA.)

Then this appellation, SaAbiYN, was applied to [Any individual of] a certain sect of the unbelievers, [the Sabians,] said to worship the stars secretly, and openly to profess themselves to belong to the Christians: they are called AlSRaAbiYapu and AlDRaAbiYuwna: and they assert that they are of the religion of Sábi the son of Sheyth [or Seth] the son of Adam: their appellation may also be pronounced AlSRaAbiyuwna, and thus Náfi' read it [in the Kur]: (Msb:) or the SaAbiYuwna are a certain class of the people who possess revealed scripture: (S:) or a people whose religion resembles that of the Christians, except that their kibleh is towards the place whence blows the [south, or southerly, wind called] januwb: (Lth, T, TA:) [or] whose kibleh is from (mino [or this may mean some point of]) the place whence blows the [north, or northerly, wind called] XamaAl at midday: (M, K:) or, accord. to some, their kibleh is the Kaabeh: (MF:) and they assert that they are of the religion of Noah, (Lth, T, M, K,) lyingly: (Lth, T, M:) in the R it is said that they are thus called in relation to Sábi the son of Lámak [or Lamech], the brother of Noah: Bd says, it is said that they are worshippers of the angels: and it is said that they are worshippers of the stars: and that their appellation is Arabic; from SabaOa “ he departed from a religion; ” or from SabaA “ he inclined, ” because of their inclining from truth to falsehood. (MF, TA.)

1. SabaHahu, (S, Mgh, TA,) aor.
SabaHa
, (Mgh, TA,) inf. n. SaboHN; (S, TA;) and SbRHhu↓, (K, TA,) inf. n. taSobiyHN; (TA;) He gave him to drink a morning-draught, or what is termed a SabuwH; (S, Mgh, K, TA;) [and] so SabaHahu SabuwHFA: (MA:) and the first [and second also] he handed to him a morning-draught of milk or of wine. (TA.) And SabaHa AlUibila, aor. and inf. n. as above, He watered the camels in the morning, between daybreak and sunrise. (TA.)

And both are said respecting a gaArap [meaning (assumed tropical:) He made a hostile, or predatory, incursion upon him in the morning; as though he made the gArp to be to him a morning-draught: see SaAbiHN]. (Ham p. 66.)

[And accord. to Reiske, as stated by Freytag, SabaHa signifies He drank in the early morning: but I think that Reiske may have assigned to it this meaning from his having found the pass. form of the verb, not distinguished as such, used in a case in which it might be supposed to signify thus.].
See also 2, in five places.
SabaHN as an inf. n. [of which the verb is SabiHa accord. to a general rule] signifies The being satiated, or having the thirst quenched, by a morning-draught, or what is termed a SabuwH. (L.)

And SabiHa, aor.
SabaHa
, inf. n. SabaHN [in the CK (erroneously) SaboH] and SuboHapN, [He, or it, was of the colour termed SuboHapN meaning as expl. below: or] it (hair) had whiteness naturally intermixed in it with redness; as also ASbAHR↓, (K, TA,) inf. n.
AiSbiyHaAHN. (TA.)

SabuHa, aor.
SabuHa
, inf. n. SabaAHapN, [q. v.,] He was, or became, beautiful, comely, pretty, or elegant; (S, A, K, TA;) as some say, peculiarly in the face: (TA:) or he was, or became, bright (Msb, TA) in the face. (Msb.)

2. SbRHhu, (S,) or SbRHhumo, (K,) inf. n. taSobiyHN, (TA,) He came to him, or to them, in the morning, in the time termed the SabaAH; (S, K;) as also [SabaHahu↓, or] SabaHahumo, aor.
SabaHa
: (K:) the teshdeed in the former does not imply muchness, or frequency: (S:) and SabRaHatohumu Alxayolu and SabaHatohumu↓ The horsemen came to them at daybreak, at the time termed the SuboH: (TA:) but Aboo-'Adnán says that there is a difference between SabRaHonaA and SabaHonaA↓; which is this: you say, SabRaHonaA balada kacaA [We came in the morning to such a town, or country], and SabRaHonaA fulaAnFA [We came in the morning to such a one], with teshdeed; and OaholahaA xayorFA SabaHonaA↓ or XarRFA [We came in the morning to its people, or inhabitants, with good or with evil, without teshdeed; as though we made the good or the evil to be a morning-draught, or putting the second of the nouns following the verb in the accus. case because of bi suppressed]: you say also, SbRHhu bikacaA; and you may also say, bkcA SabaHahu↓, as well as SabaHahu kacaA; He came to him in the morning with such a thing. (L.)

And SabRaHaka QllRehu bixayorK (S, * A, Msb) or biAlxayori (TA) (assumed tropical:) [May God visit thee in the morning with good, or good fortune, or happiness; or make thee to be in, or during, the morning attended with good, &c.; i. e. make thy morning good, or happy; or grant thee a good, or happy, morning]: a prayer for the person thus addressed, (Msb.)

And SabRaHotuhu I said to him Eimo SabaAHFA [expl. below, see SabaAHN]; (S;) and SabRaHahumo he said to them EimuwA SabaAHFA: (K:) or SabRaHotuhu means I said to him SabRaHaka QllRehu bixayorK [expl. above]. (Msb.)
See also 1, first sentence.
[Hence,] SabRaHotu Alqawoma AlmaMCa, inf. n. as above, I journeyed with the people, or party, by night until I brought them in the morning to the water. (K.)
SabRaHaniI fulaAnN AlHaqRa (tropical:) Such a one declared, or told clearly, to me the truth; syn. maHRaDaniyhi. (A, TA. [See SuboHN.])
taSobiyHN as a subst., see below.

4. ASbH He entered upon the time of morning termed SabaAH [which means both dawn and forenoon]: (S, * Msb: [in the former this meaning is indicated, but not expressed:]) or he entered upon the time of daybreak, or dawn, the time termed SuboH. (L, K.) By the following words of EshShemmákh,

is meant, [And the saying of the crier is,] The people, or party, have nearly entered upon the time of dawn: prosecute the night-journey: for the Arabs, when they have nearly arrived at a place which they desire to reach, say, qado balagonaAhu; and when travellers are near the time of daybreak, they say, OaSobaHonaA. (T, L.)

[Hence,] (tropical:) He awoke from sleep in the jawof [i. e. last third, or last sixth,] of the night. (A, TA.) [And simply (tropical:) He awoke: for] one says to the sleeper, OaSobiHo, meaning (tropical:) Awake thou from sleep. (A, TA.) And one says also, OaSobiHo yaA rajulu, meaning (tropical:) Become roused, O man, (A, K, * TA,) from thy heedlessness or inadvertence, (A, TA,) and see thy right course, (K, TA,) and what will rectify thy state. (TA.) And OaSobiHo layolu (tropical:) [Become morning, O night] a prov.: (Meyd, A, TA:) said in a distressing night, that is long by reason of evil. (Meyd. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 727.])
[Also He, or it, became in the morning in any particular state or condition: in this sense, and in that next following, an incomplete, i. e. a non-attributive, verb.]

And [hence, simply,] He, or it, became; syn. SaAra. (S, K.) One says, ASbH EaAlimFA He became knowing, or learned. (S, TA.) Thus, faOaSobaHuwA ZaAhiriyna, in the Kur lxi. last verse, means And they became victorious. (Bd.) And faOaSobaHa yuqalRibu kafRayohi, in the Kur xviii. 40, [And he became in a state, or condition, in which he turned over his hands; i. e.] and he became repentant, or grieved for what he had done. (A in art. qlb, and Bd.) And faOaSobaHuwA laA taraI UilRaA masaAkinahumo, in the Kur xlvi. 24, i. e. [And they became] in a condition such that, if thou wert present in their country, thou wouldst not see aught save their dwellingplaces; or, as Hamzeh and Ks read, laA yuraI UilRaA masaAkinuhumo [there was not to be seen aught save their dwelling-places]. (Bd.) [OaSobaHa yafoEalu kacaA is of frequent occurrence, meaning He became occupied, or engaged, in doing such a thing; he betook, set, or applied, himself to doing such a thing; set about, or commenced, doing such a thing; or began to do such a thing.]
[Also He performed the prayer of daybreak.] It is said in a trad., OaSobiHuwA biAlSRuboHi, meaning Perform ye the prayer of daybreak in the time of daybreak. (L.)
See also 8.
Also He acted gently. (TA in art. ArX: see an ex. in a verse cited voce maOorwuXN.)
UiSobaAHN He trimmed a lamp, or wick; or prepared it properly for use. (TA.)
See, again, 8.
as a subst., see SuboHN, in two places.
5. tSbRH He slept in the morning; or first part of day, before sunrise. (S, Msb, K.)
And He ate such food as is termed a SuboHap. (K, TA.) It is said in a trad., mano taSabRaHa bisaboEi tamaraAti EajowapK [He who eats as a SuboHap seven dates of the sort called Eajowap]. (TA.)
See also 8, in two places.
6. fulaAnN yataSaAbaHu yataHaAsanu [Such a one affects to be beautful, comely, pretty, or elegant: the latter verb is here added as an explicative of the former: see SabuHa]. (A, TA.)

8. ASTbH He drank a morning-draught, or what is termed a SabuwH; (S, K, TA;) [and] so ASbH↓. (Msb. [Thus in my copy of the Msb, but probably a mistranscription, for the former is the verb well known in this sense, and is not in that copy.]) It is said in a trad., maAlanaA SabiIRN yaSoTabiHu [We have not a child that drinks a morningdraught]; meaning we have not as much milk as a child may drink in the early morning, in consequence of the drought. (TA.)

And i. q. Oasoraja [as meaning He lighted a lamp or wick, or himself or another with a lamp &c.]; (K, TA;) and so ASbH↓ (A, TA) [in the former sense], as in the phrase ASbH miSobaAHFA [he lighted a lamp or wick]; (A;) and ASbH alone has this meaning, i. e. Oasoraja siraAjFA. (TA, from a trad.) [But it is used often in the latter sense:] one says, AlXRamoEu mimRaA yuSoTabaHu bihi Candles are of the things with which one lights [himself, or others]; syn. yusoraju: (S:) [and in like manner tSbRH↓; for] one says, huwa yataSabRaHu biAlXRumuwEi [He lights himself, or others, with candles]: (A:) [and in like manner also AstSbH↓; for] one says, AstSbH biAlmiSobaAHi (S, MA, Mgh, Msb, K *) He lighted [himself, or another,] with the lamp, or wick; (MA;) syn. Oasoraja; (S;) or Aisotasoraja: (K:) [hence it appears that ASTbH bihi and bh AstSbH↓ and bh tSbRH↓ may be aptly rendered he employed it as a means of light; and thus the second of these three verbs, is expl. in treatises on practical law:] one says also, biAldRuhoni AstSbH↓ [He employed oil as a means of light; or] he made the lamp, or wick, to give light by means of oil: (Mgh, Msb:) and it is said in a trad. respecting the several sorts of fat (XuHuwm) of carrion, bihaA AlnRaAsu yasotaSobiHu↓ The people [employ them as means of light; or] make their lamps, or wicks, to give light by means of them. (TA.)
10: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.
11: see 1, last sentence but one.

SuboHN (S, A, Msb, K, &c.) and SabaAHN↓ (Msb, K) and SabiyHapN↓ (Msb, * K) and UiSobaAHN↓ and muSobaHN↓ (K [or perhaps the last should be maSobaHN, q. v.]) Daybreak, or dawn; syn. fajorN; (S, A, Msb, K;) i. e. (so in the Msb, but in the K “ or ”) the beginning, or first part, of day: (Msb, K:) UiSobaAHN↓ is an inf. n. [inf. n. of OaSobaHa] used in the sense of SuboH, in the Kur vi. 96, (Jel,) and is similar to UibokaArN; (TA;) [and muSobaHN↓ is the n. of place and time from OaSobaHa:] the pl. of SuboHN is OaSobaAHN; (K;) and thus some read in the Kur vi. 96. (Bd.) See also OaSobaHu. One says, Oatayotuhu liSuboHi xaAmisapK and xAmsp liSiboHi↓, (S, K,) meaning [I came to him] in the morning (SabaAH) [of the last] of five days; (K;) i. e., of a fifth day; (TK;) [or rather, of a fifth night, as the last word is fem.;] like as one says, limuisoIi xAmsp. (S.)
AlSRuboHu is also used as meaning (assumed tropical:) The truth; and the clear, or plain, thing or case. (Ham p. 449.)
And OumRu SuboHK is one of the names of Mekkeh. (K, * TA.)
SiboHN: see the next preceding paragraph.
SabaHN: see SuboHapN.
Also The glistening of iron (K, TA) and of other things. (TA.)
SaboHapN: see the next paragraph, in three places.

Also A watering of camels in the morning, or first part of day, before sunrise: which is not esteemed by the Arabs wholesome: the time approved by them for watering is when the sun is near the meridian. (TA.)

SuboHapN The early part of the forenoon, after sunrise; syn. DuHFI; as also SaboHapN↓: (Msb:) or the period of one's entering upon the SabaAH [which means both dawn and forenoon]: so in the saying, laqiytuhu caAta SuboHapK [I met him when he was entering upon the dawn or forenoon]. (TA.)

And A sleep in the morning, or first part of day, before sunrise; as also SaboHapN↓; (S, * K;) or both signify a sleep in the DuHaI [expl. above]; (A;) but the latter is by some disapproved: such sleep is forbidden in a trad., because it is in a time for the commemoration of the praises of God and then for seeking gain. (TA.) One says, fulaAnN yanaAmu AlSRuboHapa and AlSRaboHapa↓ [Such a one sleeps in the first part of day, before sunrise]. (S.)
And Food with which one contents, or diverts, himself [so as to allay the craving of his stomach], in the morning or first part of day, before sunrise. (K.)
See also SabuwHN.

Also (Suh, K, TA,) and SabaHN↓, (Lth, S, TA,) [each said in one place in the K to be an inf. n. of which the verb is SabiHa,] Blackness inclining to redness: (K:) or intense redness in the hair: (Lth, TA:) or a colour inclining to that which is termed Suhobap: (K, TA:) or nearly the same as Suhobap: (Lth, * S, * TA:) or a colour inclining to that termed Xuhobap: (K, TA:) or whiteness that is not clear, or pure; so the former is expl. by Suh. (TA. [See also OaSabaHu.])

SaboHaAnu A man who has drunk a morningdraught, or what is termed a SabuwH; (TA;) or who has done so, and satisfied his thirst thereby: (Aboo-'Adnán, TA:) [in the S and K it is implied that it is syn. with muSoTabiHN, q. v.:] fem. SaboHaI. (S, TA.) Hence the prov., Oakocabu mina AlOaxiyci AlSRaboHaAni (Aboo-'Adnán, S, TA) More lying than the captive who had satisfied his thirst with a morning-draught: (Aboo-'Adnán, TA:) the person thus alluded to was a man who was among a people that gave him a morning-draught, after which he arose and quitted them, and was taken by another people, who said to him, “ Guide us to the place where thou wast; ” to which he replied, “ I have passed the night in the bare desert: ” but presently he sat down to make water, so they knew that he had passed the night with a people near by; and by his means they found their way to them, and exterminated them: (IAar, TA:) or the prov. is Oakocabu mina AlOaxidi AlSRaboHaAni More lying than the young unweaned camel that has satisfied its thirst with drinking [its mother's milk in the morning]; which [seems to be thirsty but] will not drink of its mother's milk when one desires it to do so: (IAar, Sh, TA:) or, accord. to Fr, than the young unweaned camel that is affected with indigestion, or heaviness of the stomach, from drinking much milk, and therefore craves for milk again. (Meyd. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov.: he seems to have followed a faulty text.])
Also the fem., SaboHaI, A she-camel that has been milked [app. in the morning]. (Meyd, in his Proverbs, under the letter S; and TA.)
See also SabiyHN.
SabaHaAnN A man who hastens to take the morning-draught, or what is termed the SabuwH. (K.)
SabaAHN: see SuboHN.

Also (Msb) Contr. of masaMCN, (S, A, Msb,) and so SabiyHapN↓, (S,) [and OuSobuwHapN↓ (as in a phrase following in this paragraph), and maSobaHN↓, (see this last word,)] i. e. Morning, or forenoon, counted from sunrise to noon: (Msb and TA in art. msw:) or, accord. to some, from midnight to noon: (TA in art. msw:) or, accord. to the Arabs, from the beginning of the latter half of the night to the time when the sun declines from the meridian; then commences the masaMC, extending to the end of the former half of the night; thus expl. by Th; so says El-Jawá- leekee. (Msb.) The Arabs say, when they regard a man, &c., as ominous of evil, SabaAHu QllRehi laA SabaAHuka [God's morning: not thy morning]: and if you will, you may say, SabaAHa QllRehi laA SabaAHaka. (Lh, TA.) And Eimo SabaAHFA, (S,) or EimuwA SabaAHFA, (K,) lit. imperative, but meaning a prayer, i. e. May thy life, or your life, be pleasant during the morning, (Har p. 32, and TA * in arts. nEm and wEm,) is a salutation of the people of the Time of Ignorance. (TA.) One says also, laqiytuhu SabaAHFA, and caA SabaAHK, (S,) or Oatayotuhu caA SabaAHK, (K,) which [i. e. cA SbAH] is only used adverbially, (Sb, S, K,) except in the dial. of Khath'am, (Sb, S,) meaning [I met him, or I came to him,] in a morning, [or] between daybreak and sunrise: (K:) the following verse (S, TA) by Anas Ibn-Nuheyk, of Khath'am, (TA,) or, as some say, by Iyás Ibn-Mudrikeh El-Hanafee, (so in a marg. note in a copy of the S,) presents an exception to the adverbial usage:

(S, TA:) the poet means, I determined to stay until the time of the SbAH [i. e. either dawn or forenoon]: for it is on account of some particular thing, i. e. some good quality, or some praiseworthy thing, that he is made a chief who becomes a chief: thus Ibn-Es-Seeráfee explains this verse. (TA.) And one says, Oatayotuhu caA SabuwHK↓, not used otherwise than adverbially, meaning the same as caA SabaAHK, expl. above; (K;) and caAta AlSRabuwHi↓ in the morning, or first part of day, before sunrise: (IAar, TA:) or caA SabuwHK↓ [properly means] in a time of drinking the [morning-draught called] SabuwH. (TA.) And yawomi kacaA Oatayotuhu SabiyHapa↓ [I came to him in the dawn, or in the morning, or forenoon, of such a day]: (A:) and OuSobuwHapa↓ kulRi yawomK [in the morning of every day]; and in like manner, OumosiyRapa kulRi yawomK. (S.) And Oatayotuhu SabaAHa masaMCa, (Sb, A, TA,) for SabaAHFA wamasaMCF, [I came to him morning and evening,] meaning every morning and evening: (Sharh esh-Shudhoor, p. 31:) the two nouns are thus constructed by some of the Arabs, after the manner of xamosapa EaXara: but some prefix the former noun to the other, putting the latter in the gen. case, except when the expression is used as a denotative of state, or adverbially: (TA:) [or, accord. to IHsh,] SabaAHa masaMCK is allowable as [an adverbial expression] meaning SabaAHa caA masaMCK [lit. in a morning having an evening, or in a forenoon having an afternoon]; and a similar instance occurs in the Kur, ch. lxxix. last verse. (Sharh esh-Shudhoor, ubi suprà.)

yawomu AlSRabaAHi means (tropical:) The day of the hostile, or predatory, incursion. (S, A, K.) The Arabs, when suddenly attacked in the morning by a troop of horsemen, cry aloud, yaA SabaAHaAho (assumed tropical:) [O! a hostile, or predatory, incursion!]; warning the whole tribe: (TA:) this is said by him who calls for aid: (JM:) for they generally made a hostile, or predatory, incursion in the morning: (TA, JM:) or, as some say, the two conflicting parties used, when night came, to abstain; and when day returned, they recommenced; so that the case is as though he who said thus meant, The time of the SabaAH [or morning] has come, therefore prepare yourselves for fighting. (JM.)
SubaAHN The XuElap [or lighted wick] of a qinodiyl [or lamp]. (K.) [See also miSobaAHN.]
And I. q. SabiyHN, q. v. (Ks, S, K.)

SabuwHN A morning draught; i. e. a draught, drink, or potation, that is drunk in the morning, or first part of day, before sunrise, (S, A, Msb, TA,) and afterwards, before noon; (TA;) contr. of gabuwqN: (S, A:) and whatever is eaten, or drunk, in the morning, or first part of day, before sunrise; contr. of gabuwqN: (TA:) [and particularly] milk that is drunk at that time: (AHeyth, L:) milk, or wine, that is drunk at that time: or what is drunk at that time hot: (L:) milk that is milked at that time: (K:) and XaraAb [i. e. beverage, or wine,] that people have, (K, TA,) and drink, (TA,) in the morning: (K, TA:) pl. SabaAYiHu. (TA.) OaEano SabuwHK turaqRiqu [Dost thou make a delicate allusion to a morningdraught?] is a prov., [the origin of which is expl. in art. rq, q. v.,] applied to him who speaks obscurely, not plainly; and to him who alludes ambiguously to some great thing or affair; and to him who by blandishing expressions makes a
thing incumbent on thee which is not really so. (TA.)
See also SabaAHN, in three places.
Accord. to Lth, it signifies [absolutely] Wine. (T, TA.)
And The quantity of milk of a camel that is drawn at dawn, or in the first part of day; and so SuboHapN↓. (TA.)
Also A she-camel that is milked at dawn, or in the forenoon, (Lh, AHeyth, K,) or in the morning, or first part of day, before sunrise; and so with p. (K.)

SabiyHN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and SubaAHN↓ (Ks, S, K) and SubRaAHN↓ and SaboHaAnu↓ (K) Beautiful, comely, (S, A, Mgh, K,) pretty, or elegant; (S, A, K;) as some say, peculiarly in the face; (TA;) or applied to the face: (A:) or bright (Msb, TA) in the face: (Msb:) the first is expl. by Lth as signifying fair of face: fem. SabiyHapN and SubaAHapN: and the pl. of SabiyHN and SubaAHN, and of their fems. here mentioned, is SibaAHN. (L. TA.)

SabaAHapN Beauty, comeliness, prettiness, or elegance; (S, A, K;) as some say, peculiarly in the face: (TA:) or brightness in the face: (Msb:) it is said that SabaAHap is in the face; waDaMCap, in the skin; jamaAl, in the nose; HalaAwap, in the eye; malaAHap, in the mouth; Zarof, in the tongue; raXaAqap, in the stature; labaAqap, in the qualities of the mind; and that the completion of beauty is in the hair. (L, TA.) [See 1, last sentence.]
SabiyHapN: see SuboHN: and SabaAHN, in two places.
SubaAHiIRN Intensely red blood: (K, TA:) from OaSobaHu signifying one “ whose hair is overspread with redness. ” (TA.)

OasinRapN SubaAHiyRapN Wide spear-heads. (K, TA. [In the CK the latter word is without teshdeed.]) ISd says, I know not the person or thing in relation whereto they are thus called. (TA.) [See also miSobaAHN.]
SubRaAHN: see SabiyHN.

SaAbiHN [Giving to drink a morning-draught, or what is termed a SabuwH: act. part. n. of 1, q. v.: see also Ham p. 66. And] One who waters his camels in the morning, between day-break and sunrise. (TA. [See SaboHapN.])
And (assumed tropical:) One who makes a hostile, or predatory, incursion upon a people in the morning; as though he made it to be to them a SabuwH. (Ham p. 66.)
AlHaqRu AlSRaAbiHu (tropical:) The plain, manifest, clear, truth. (K, * TA.)

OaSobaHu Of a black colour inclining to redness: (K:) or having redness intermixed in his black hair: (Sh, TA:) or whose hair, or beard, has a red hue overspreading it: (Aboo-Nasr, Sh, TA:) or having hair intensely red: (TA:) it is nearly the same as OaSohabu: (Lth, S:) and is an epithet applied to a man and to a lion: (S:) and to hair as meaning having whiteness naturally intermixed in it with redness; (K, TA;) of whatever kind it be: (TA:) fem. SaboHaMCu: (K:) and pl. SuboHN: (TA:) and hence [accord. to some] AlSRuboHu↓ meaning “ the dawn; ” for, as Az says, the colour of the true dawn inclines a little to redness. (TA.) [Hence, because of his colour,] AlOaSobaHu signifies The lion. (K.) In the phrase OusuwdN SuboHN, the epithet is added as a corroborative. (Z, TA.)
And the fem., SaboHaMCu signifies A female conspicuous, or clear, or fair, in the jabiyn [or side of the forehead]. (TA.)
OaSobaHiIRN A whip: (S, K:) and siyaATN OaSobaHiyRapN certain whips: (AO, S, TA:) so called in relation to cuw OaSobaHa, one of the Kings of El-Yemen, (AO, S, K, TA,) of Himyer. (TA.)
UiSobaAHN: see SuboHN, in two places.
It is said to signify also Darkness; contr. of SuboHN, which is its primary signification: and accord. to EshShereeshee, redness of the hair. (Har p. 284.)
OuSobuwHapN: see SabaAHN, in two places.

taSobiyHN The morning meal, that is eaten between daybreak and sunrise; syn. gadaMCN: (A, K:) a subst. of the measure tafoEiylN, (K, TA,) similar to taroEiybN &c.: pl. taSaAbiyHu. (A, TA.) One says, qarRaba UilaI AlDRuyuwfi taSaAbiyHahumo [He brought near to the guests, or put before them, their early morning-meals]. (A, TA.)

maSobaHN, (S, Msb, and some copies of the K,) formed from the unaugmented verb, (S, Msb,) and muSobaHN↓, (S, Msb, K,) formed from the augmented verb OaSobaHa, (S, Msb,) The place of entering upon the time of morning called SabaAH: and the time of entering upon the same: (S, Msb, K:) or the former signifies i. q. SabaAHN, and the time thereof, and the place thereof. (Marg. note in a copy of the S.) See also SabaAHN.
muSobaHN: see the next preceding paragraph: and see also SuboHN, in two places.
miSobaHN: see the paragraph here following, in four places.

miSobaAHN A lamp: or its lighted wick: syn. siraAjN: (S, K:) the latter is the proper meaning (L) [though not the more usual], and is the meaning intended in the Kur xxiv. 35, (Bd, L, Jel,) or a large, bright, or brilliant, siraAj: (Bd:) and miSobaHN↓ signifies a lamp: (L:) [the pl. of this is maSaAbiHu: and] the pl. of miSobaAHN is maSaAbiyHu. (Msb.) — maSaAbiyHu AlnRujuwmi means OaEolaAmu AlkawaAkibi [i. e. (assumed tropical:) The stars, or asterisms, that are signs of the way to travellers]. (L, TA.)

Also A large [drinking-vessel of the kind called] qadaH; (AHn, K;) and so miSobaHN↓: (K:) or maSaAbiyHu [the pl. of the former] signifies the [vessels called] OaqodaAH [pl. of qadaH] with which one drinks the morning-draught called SabuwH. (S.)

And A she-camel that remains in the morning in the place where she has lain down, (S, K, TA,) not going forth to pasture, (S, TA,) until the sun has risen high, (S, K, TA,) by reason of her strength (K, TA) and her fatness: (TA:) the quality thus described is approved: (As, S, TA:) and such a she-camel is also termed miSobaHN↓: pl. of the former as above. (TA.)
And A wide spear-head; (K, TA;) [app. of such as are termed OasinRapN SubaAHiyRapN;] as also miSobaHN↓. (TA.)
muSoTabiHN Drinking a morning-draught, or what is termed a SabuwH. (S, K. [See also SaboHaAnu, first sentence.])

1. Sabarahu, aor.
Sabira
, (S, M, A, K,) inf. n. SaborN, (M, K,) He confined him; held him in custody; detained, retained, restrained, or withheld, him, or it; (S, M, A, K;) Eanohu from it. (M, A, K.) [Accord. to a copy of the A, SbRrhu↓ signifies the same; but this may be a mistranscription. Hence,] Sabarotu nafosiI I restrained, or withheld, myself, or my soul; (S, Mgh;) EalaI kacaA [to endure such a thing]. (Mgh.) 'Antarah says, mentioning a battle in which he was engaged,

meaning Habasotu nafosFA SaAbirapF [i. e. And I restrained thereat a soul patient and ingenuous, that is firm when the soul of the coward yearns: the last word (for tataTalRaEu) I have here rendered on the supposition that the poet describes the soul of the coward as one that is yearning for home]. (S.) [And hence,] Sabara is also used intransitively: (Msb:) [or as a trans. verb of which the objective complement, namely, nafosahu, is understood:] you say, Sabara, aor. and inf. n. as above, (S, M, Msb, K,) He was, or became patient, or enduring; contr. of jaziEa: (M, K:) or he restrained, or withheld, himself, or his soul, from impatience: (S, Msb:) or he restrained, or withheld, himself, or his soul, from impatience, and his tongue from complaint, and his members from broil: or, accord. to Dhu-n-Noon, he shunned acts of opposition, and was calm in suffering the pangs of afflictions, and made a show of competence in a state of protracted poverty in places where the means of subsistence were found: or, as some say, he endured trial, or affliction, with good manners: or he was contented in trial, or affliction, without show of complaint: or he constrained himself to attempt things that he disliked: or, accord. to 'Amr Ibn-'Othmán, he maintained constancy with God, and received his trials with an unstraitened mind: or, accord. to El-Khowwás, he steadily adhered to the statutes of the Kur-án and the Sunneh: or, as some say, he was content to perish for gaining the approval of him whom he loved: or, accord. to El-Hareeree, he made no difference between a state of ease, comfort, and affluence, and a state of affliction; preserving calmness of mind in both states: (B:) and you also say AiSoTabara↓, (S, M, Msb, K,) and AiSRabara↓, (S, M, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, ASobarRa,])
changing the T into S, but not AiTRabara, for S is not to be incorporated into T; (S;) and likewise tSbRr↓; (M, K;) both syn. with Sabara; (M;) or tSbRr↓ signifies he constrained himself to be patient; (S, TA;) [or he took patience: and ASTbr↓, he acquired patience; and he was tried with patience: see SaAbirN.] One says, Sabara fulaAnN Einoda AlmuSiybapi Such a one was patient on the occasion of affliction. (S.) And Sabarotu EalaI maA Oakorahu [I was patient of, or I endured with patience, or bore with, what I dislike]. (A.) And Sabarotu EamRaA OuHibRu [I endured with patience the withholding of myself, or the being debarred, from what I love, or like; or I was patient of the loss, or want, of what I love, or like]: (A:) and Eanohu taSabRarotu↓ [I constrained myself to endure with patience the withholding myself, or the being debarred, from it, or him; or I constrained myself to be patient of the loss, or want, of it, or him]. (L, voce tajalRada.) And OafoDalu AlSRabori AltRaSabRuru↓ [The most excellent kind of patience is the constraint of oneself to be patient]: a saying of 'Omar. (IAar.) And badaniI laA yaSobiru EalaI Albarodi (tropical:) [My body will not be patient of cold, or will not endure patiently cold]. (A.) And SaborN signifies also The being bold or daring [in enduring, or attempting, a thing]. (TA.)

Also He made him, or it, firm, or fast; or bound, or tied, him, or it, firmly, or fast. (TA.) [Hence,] Sabarahu EalaI Alqatoli, inf. n. as above, He confined him, namely, a man, and other than man, [with bonds or otherwise,] (K, TA,) alive, (TA,) and shot, or cast, at him until he died: (K, TA:) or he set him up for slaughter: (M:) and you say also, qatalahu SaborFA; (S, M, Msb, K;) and Sabarahu; meaning he confined him (i. e. a man) to die, until he died; and in like manner you say ASbrhu↓; (S;) which latter signifies also he slew him in retaliation. (T in art. bwO.) And qutila SaborFA He (i. e. any living thing) was confined alive, and then shot at, or cast at, until he was put to death: (S:) or he (any living thing) was bound until he was put to death: (Msb:) or he (a man) was bound hand and foot, or held by another man, until he was beheaded: (Mgh:) or he was slain [deliberately,] not on the field of battle, nor in war or fight, nor by mistake: (A 'Obeyd:) and Subira he was confined, (A,) or held and confined, (B,) to be put to death. (A, B.) Saboru AlrRuwHi [signifies The confining the living, and shooting, or casting, at him until he dies; as is shown in the TA: but it] occurs in a trad., in which it is forbidden, as meaning the act of gelding, or castrating. (A, TA.)

Also, (S, Msb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Msb,) He confined him to make him swear, until he swore, or took an oath; as also ASbrhu↓: (S:) or he made him to swear a most energetic oath; (Msb;) as also Sabara yamiynahu, (A, Mgh,) which is a tropical phrase: (A:) and ASbrhu↓, (TA in art. blt,) or EalaI yamiynK ASbrhu↓, (TA in the present art.,) he (the judge, or governor,) constrained him to swear, or take an oath. (TA.) And Subira He was confined, or held in custody, in order that he might be made to swear, or take an oath. (A.) And Halafa SaborFA He swore, or took an oath, being confined, or held in custody, (S, M,) by the judge, or governor, (M,) in order that he might be made to do so. (S, M.) And Sabara yamiynFA He swore, or took an oath: (TA in art. blt:) and he compelled one to take an oath. (Mgh.)
See also 2.
Also He clave to him; namely, a man; syn. lazimahu. (M, K.)
Sabaraminohu: see 8.

Sabarotu, (S, [thus in my copies, without any complement,]) or Sabarotu bihi, (M, Msb, K,) aor.
Sabura
, inf. n. SaborN (S, M, Msb, K) and SabaArapN, (S, Msb, K,) I became responsible, or surety, for him, or it. (S, M, Msb, K.)
And AuSoburoniI Give thou to me a surety. (S, K.)

SabaruwA TaEaAmahumo, (so in the CK, [agreeably with an explanation of the pass. part. n. maSobuwrN, q. v.,]) or SabRaruwhu↓, (so in the M, and in my MS. copy of the K, [both probably correct,]) They collected their wheat together without measuring or weighing it; made it a Suborap [q. v.] (M, K.)

2. SbRrhu, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. taSobiyrN, (TA,) He urged him, or made him, to be patient, by a promise of reward: or he said to him, Be thou patient: and Sabarahu↓ he made him to be patient: (Msb:) or the former, he commanded him, or enjoined him, to be patient; as also ASbrhu↓: (M, K:) and the first, he required of him that he should be patient: (Sgh, TA:) and ASbrhu↓, he attributed to him (jaEala lahu) patience; (M, K;) as also ASTbrhu↓. (TA.)
See also 1, second sentence.
SbRrwA TaEaAmahumo: see 1, last sentence.
SbRr AlXRaIoCa, inf. n. as above, He heaped up the thing. (O.)

[SbRr also signifies He embalmed a dead body with Sabir, meaning accord. to Freytag myrrh; but for this I know not any authority: he mentions the verb as occurring in this sense in “ Hamak. Waked. ” p. 94, last line.
Also He ballasted a ship: used in this sense in the present day. See SaAbuwrapN.]

3. SAbrhu, (A, MA,) inf. n. muSaAbarapN (A, K) and SibaArN, (K,) [He vied with him in patience, or endurance; as shown in what follows: or] he acted patiently with him: (MA:) SaAbiruwA in the Kur iii. last verse means Vie ye in patience, or endurance: (Ksh, Bd, Jel: *) or in this instance, in the saying AiSobiruwA waSaAbiruwA waraAbiTuwA, the three verbs are progressive in meaning; the first meaning less than the second; and the second, less than the third: or the meaning is, [be ye patient] with yourselves, and [vie ye in patience] with your hearts in enduring trial with respect to God, and [remain ye steadfast] with your minds in desire for God: or [be ye patient] with respect to God, and [vie ye in patience] with God, and [remain ye steadfast] with God. (B, TA.) [See also 3 in art. rbT.]
4. ASbrhu: see 1, latter half, in four places:
and see 2, in two places.
[maA OaSobarahu How patient, or enduring, is he!]

maA OaSobarahumo EalaI QlnRaAri [in the Kur ii. 170] means How bold are they [to encounter the fire of Hell]! (K:) or how bold are they to do the deeds of the people of the fire [of Hell] | (TA:) or how much do they occupy themselves in doing the deeds of the people of the fire [of Hell]! (K:) this last explanation is in the Tekmileh. (TA.)
ASbrhu also signifies He (the judge, A, TA, or the Sultán, El-Ahmar, TA) retaliated for him. (El-Ahmar, A, TA. [See 8.])
ASbr [intrans.] It (a thing) was, or became, hard; syn. AiXotadRa. (A. [See SabarN.])
He fell into what is termed OumRu SabRuwrK, (K, TA,) i. e. a calamity: and he became in what is termed OumRu SabRaArK, i. e. a HarRap. (TA.)
He sat upon the Sabiyr, (K, TA,) i. e. the mountain. (TA.)
It (milk) was, or became, very sour, inclining to [the flavour of Sabir, i. e.] bitterness. (K.)
He ate the Sabiyrap, (IAar, K,) i. e. the thin, round cake of bread so called. (TA.)
And He stopped the head of a flask, or bottle, with a SibaAr, (K, TA,) i. e. a stopper. (TA.)
5: see 1, near the middle of the paragraph, in four places.
6. taSaAburN [relating to a number of persons] signifies The being patient, or enduring, one with another. (KL.) [You say, tSAbrwA They were patient, or enduring, one with another.]
And tSAbrwA EalaI fulaAnK They leagued together, and aided one another, against such a one. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA in art. Dfr.)
8. AiSoTabara, and its var. AiSRabara: see 1, former half in three places.
ASTbr minohu He retaliated by slaying him, or wounding him, or the like; (A, K;) and so minohu Sabara↓. (TA.)
[And accord. to Reiske, It was collected: (mentioned by Freytag:) app. as quasi-pass. of 1 in the last of the senses assigned to it above.]
ASTbrhu: see 2.
10. AstSbr It (a vapour, TA) became dense. (K, TA. [See SabiyrN.])
R. Q. 1: accord. to the S, Sanobara: see art. Snbr.
SaborN [inf. n. of 1, q. v.

Used as a simple subst.,] Patience, or endurance; contr. of jazaEN: (M, K:) or restraint of oneself, or of one's soul, from impatience. (S. [Several other explanations of this word are shown by explanations of the verb.])
Xahoru AlSRabori The month of fasting: (K:) fasting being called Sabor because it is self-restraint from food and beverage and sexual intercourse. (TA, from a trad.)
[qatalahu SaborFA, and qutila SaborFA: see 1.]

yamiynu AlSRabori The oath for which the judge, or governor, [in the CK AlHukomu is erroneously put for AlHakamu,] holds one in custody until he swears it: (M, K:) or the oath that is obligatory (K, TA) upon the swearer, (TA,) and which the swearer is compelled to take, (Mgh, K,) he being confined by the Sultán until he do so: (Mgh, * TA:) such an oath is also termed yamiynN maSobuwrapN↓: (Mgh:) [i. e.] the term maSobuwrapN is applied to an oath, (S, K, TA,) meaning one on account of which a man is confined, in order to make him swear it; (TA; [and this seems to be indicated by the context in the S and K;]) but the man being maSobuwr, and not the oath, the latter is thus
termed tropically. (TA.)
[Halafa SaborFA: see 1.]
See also SabirN.

SuborN (S, M, Msb, K) and SiborN↓ (M, Msb, K) The side of a thing: (S, M, K:) or a side rising above the rest of a thing: (Msb:) or its upper part, or top: (TA:) and the edge of a thing: (S, M, K:) and its thickness: formed by transposition from buSorN: (S:) pl. OFSobaArN, (S, M, Msb, K,) and pl. pl. OaSobaArapN. (Msb.) OaSobaArN signifies The sides of a vessel, (S,) and of a grave. (TA.) And you say, He filled the drinking-cup, (S, M, A, K,) and the measure, (A, TA,) UilaI OaSobaArihi, (S, M, A, K,) to its top, (S, M, K,) as also AlI OaSomaArihi; (S;) or to its uppermost parts; (TA;) or to its edges. (A.) And Oaxacahu biOaSobaArihi He took it altogether. (S, M, A, Msb, * K.) And laqiIa AlXRidRapa biOaSobaArihaA (assumed tropical:) He met with complete distress, or adversity. (As, S.) And in a trad., the tree called sidorapu AlmunotahaI is said to be Subora AljanRapi in the highest part of Paradise. (A, TA.)
Also the former, (S, M, K,) and SuburN↓, (M, K,) Land in which are pebbles, (S, M, K,) not rugged. (S, M.) Hence, OumRu SabRaArK↓, q. v. (S, M.)
See also SabiyrN, in two places.
SiborN: see SuborN:
and SabiyrN in two places:
and see also SabirN.
SabarN Ice; syn. HamadN: (A, Sgh, K:) and [its n. un.] with p, a piece thereof: (A, Sgh:) from OaSobara meaning AiXotadRa. (A.)

SabirN (S, M, Msb, K) and SaborN↓, which latter is allowable only in cases of necessity in poetry, (S, Msb, K,) or it is allowable in other cases, as also SiborN↓, agreeably with analogy, (Ibn-Es-Seed, Msb,) [Aloes;] a certain bitter medicine; (S, Mgh, Msb;) the expressed juice of a certain bitter tree; (M, K;) the expressed juice of a certain tree of which the leaves are like the sheaths of knives, long and thick, with a dusty and dull hue in their greenness, of rough appearance, from the midst of which there comes forth a stalk whereon is a yellow flower, vmd [but what this means I know not] in odour; (Lth, TA;) it grows like the green suwsan [or lily], save that the leaves of the Sbr are longer and broader and much thicker, and it contains very much juice; (AHn, M, O, TA;) it is crushed and thrown into the presses, then bruised with pieces of wood, and trodden with the feet until its expressed juice flows, when it is left until it thickens, then it is put into leathern bags, and exposed to the sun until it dries: (AHn, O:) the best sort is the suquToriIR [i. e. of the Island of Sukutrà]: and it is also known by the name of SabRaArapN↓ [a name now applied to the plant]: (TA:) the n. un. is SabirapN [and SaborapN and SiborapN]: and the pl. is SubuwrN. (M, TA.)
[Accord. to Freytag, it signifies also Myrrh: but for this I know not any authority.]
SuburN: see SuborN.
SaborapN: see SubaArapN:
and see SabaArRapN, in two places.
Also Urine, and dung of camels and other beasts, compacted together in a wateringtrough. (K.)

Oabuw Saborapa, (so in a copy of the M,) or Oabuw Subayorapa↓, (so in the K and TA,) A certain bird; (M, K;) red in the belly, black in the head and wings and tail, the rest of it being red; (M;) thus in the L; (TA;) or red in the belly, black in the back and head and tail; (K;) thus in the Tekmileh: (TA:) [but] AHát says, in “ the Book of Birds, ” Oabuw Subayorapa, which is [the same as] Oabuw Sabirapa↓, is [a bird] red in the belly, black in the head and wings and tail, the rest of it being red, of the colour of Sabir: and the pl. is SubayoraAtN and SabiraAtN. (O.)

SuborapN A quantity collected together, of wheat (&c.], without being measured or weighed, (S, * M, Msb, * K,) heaped up: (TA:) pl. SubarN. (S, Msb.) You say, AiXotarayotu AlXRaIoCa SuborapF I bought the thing without its being measured or weighed. (S, Msb.)
And Reaped grain collected together; or wheat collected together in the place where it is trodden out: (M, TA:) or when trodden out and thrashed. (Msb in art. kds.)
And Wheat sifted (M, K) with a thing resembling a saranod [or sirinod, which is a Pers. word, here app. meaning a kind of net]. (M.)
And Rough, or rugged, stones, collected together: pl. SibaArN. (M, K.) [See also SubaArapN.]
Oabuw Sabirapa: see SaborapN.
SabaArN: see SubaArapN, in two places.
SubaArN (M, K) and SubRaArN↓ (K) The fruit of a kind of tree, intensely acid, having a broad, red stone, brought from India, said to be (M) the tamarind, (M, K,) used as a medicine. (M.)
SibaArN A stopper [of a bottle]; syn. sadaAdN. (K. [See 4, last sentence.])
And The fruit of a certain acid tree. (K. [But in this sense it is probably a mistake for SubaArN, q. v.])
SabuwrN: see SaAbirN, in four places.
SabiyrN: see SaAbirN, in two places.
Also A surety. (S, M, Msb, K.) You say, huwa bihi SabiyrN He is a surety for him, or it. (TA.)

And Sabiyru qawomK The chief, head, director, conductor, or manager, of the affairs of a people, or party: (M, K:) he who is patient for, and with, a people, or party, in [the managing of] their affairs: (A:) pl. SubaraMCu. (M.)
[And accord. to Golius, A solitary man, having neither offspring nor brother: but app. a mistake for SunobuwrN, which is thus expl. in the S in this art.]

Also, (S, M, K,) and SubaArapN↓, (M,) A white cloud; (M, K;) and so SiborN↓ and SuborN↓, of which the pl. is OaSobaArN: (K:) or white clouds; (M, K;) as also OaSobaAnN, pl. of SiborN↓ and SuborN↓: (Fr, Yaakoob, S:) or white clouds that scarcely ever, or never, give rain: (S:) or clouds, (M, K,) or white clouds, (As, S,) that become disposed one above another (As, S, M, K) in the manner of steps: (As, S, M:) or a dense cloud that is above another cloud: (M, K:) or a stationary portion of cloud: (K:) or a portion of cloud which one sees as though it were maSobuwrap, i. e. detained; but this explanation is of weak authority: or, accord. to AHn, clouds remaining stationary a day and a night; as though detained: (M:) or clouds in which are blackness and whiteness: or, as some say, clouds slow in motion, by reason of their heaviness and the abundance of their water: (Ham p. 786:) the pl. of SabiyrN is the same as the sing., (M,) or it is SuburN. (S, M, K.)
And SabiyrN, A mountain: (O, K:) or AlSRabiyru is the name of a particular mountain. (TA.)
[And accord. to Freytag, as from the K, in which I do not find this meaning, A hill consisting of stones.]

Also SabiyrN, (K,) i. e. (TA) the Sabiyr of a xawaAn [or table, or thing upon which one eats], (M, A, TA,) A thin, round cake of bread, which is spread beneath the food that one eats: (M, A, K:) or (K, TA, but in the CK “ and ”) upon which the food to be eaten at a wedding-feast is ladled (K, TA) by the maker of the bread: (TA:) also called SabiyrapN↓. (K.)
SabaArapN: see the next paragraph:
and see SabaArRapN.

SubaArapN (S, M, K) and SabaArapN↓ and SibaArapN↓ (K) Stones: (S, M, K:) or smooth stones: (TA:) or SubaArapN signifies, (M,) or SabaArapN signifies also, (K,) a piece of stone, or portion of stones: or of iron. (M, K.) A poet says, (S,) namely, El-Aashà, (M,) or 'Amr Ibn-Milkat Et-Tá-ee, addressing 'Amr Ibn-Hind, who had a brother slain, (IB,)

L.foreign: mano muboligN EamorFA biOanRa AlmaroCa lamo yuxolaqo SubaAraho

sense.s: (so in the S; but in the M and TA this verse is given differently, with XayobaAna and OanRa in the places of EamorFA and biOanRa; and it is said in the M that accord. to one relation the last word is SiyaAraho, [with I,] which, it is added, is like SubaArah in meaning;) [i. e. Who will tell 'Amr, or Sheybán, that man was not created stones?] but IB says that the last word is correctly SibaAraho, with kesr to the S; and the poet means, man is not stone, that he should patiently endure the like of this: (TA:) [J says,] accord. to one relation, the last word is SabaAraho, with fet-h, which is pl. of SabaArN↓, the SabaArN being affixed to denote its being a pl. pl., for SaborapN is pl. of ↓signifying strong, or hard, stones: [and he adds,] El-Aashà says,

(S:) but IB says that SabaArN and SabaArapN are not pls. of SaborapN; for faEaAlN is not a pl. form, but fiEaAlN, with kesr, like HijaArN and jibaAlN: (TA:) [and it is said that] the verse from which this is cited is not by El-Aashà, and is correctly and completely as follows:

by AlSyAr being meant the Sanoj, (TS, K, TA,) the stringed instrument thus called: (TS, TA:)
accord. to the reading given in the S, the verse means, As though the croaking of the frogs in it, a little before daybreak, were the sounds of falling stones: and this is correct. (TA.)
See also SabiyrN.
SibaArapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
rajulN SabuwrapN: see maSobuwrN.
SabiyrapN: see SabiyrN, last sentence.
Oabuw Subayorapa: see SaborapN.

SabaArRapN, [respecting the form of which see HamaArRapN,] (S, M, K,) and SabaArapN↓, without teshdeed, (Lh, M, K,) and SaborapN↓, (K,) The intenseness of the cold (S, M, K) of winter: (S, M:) and [in an absolute sense] intenseness of cold: (TA:) and SaborapN↓ signifies also the middle of winter; (K;) and so SawobarapN↓. (TA.)
SabRaArN: see SaAbirN, in two places.

OumRu SabRaArK (S, M, A, K) and OumRu SabRuwrK↓, (K,) or the former only is meant in the K as having the first of the significations here following, (TA,) A stony tract, of which the stones are black and worn and crumbling, as though burned with fire; syn. HarRapN; (T, S, M, A, &c.;) for which HarR is erroneously put in copies of the K: (TA:) from SuborN↓, q. v.; (S, M;) or from SubaArapN: or, accord. to some, such as is level, abounding with stones, and difficult to walk upon: (M:) or the former is [the tract called] HarRapu layolaI, and [that called] HarRapu AlnRaAri: (ElFezáree:) or it has the first of the above-mentioned significations, and signifies also a [mountain, or hill, such as is termed] haDobap: (ISk:) or smooth rock upon which nothing makes an impression: but the latter, accord. to Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee, signifies a haDobap without a pass. (ISh.)

Also OumRu SabRaArK (M, K) and OFmRu SabRuwrK↓ (S, M, K) A calamity, or misfortune: and a severe war: (M, K:) or the latter, a distressing case. (S.) One says, waqaEuwA fiI OumRi SabRaArK (M) and OumRi SabRuwrK↓ (S, M) They fell into a calamity, &c.: (M:) or the latter, they fell into a distressing case: (S:) or into a perplexing and distressing case, from which they could not escape, like the haDobap, above mentioned, without a pass: (Aboo-'Amr EshSheybánee:) but in some of the copies of the “ Alfádh ” [of ISk], OumRi SayRuwrK, as though derived from SiyaArapN, signifying “ stones. ” (TA.)
SubRaArN: see SubaArN.
OumRu SabRuwrK: see SabRaArN, in three places.
SabRaArapN Rugged ground, rising above the adjacent part or parts, and hard, (K, TA,) in which is no herbage, and which produces none: or i. q. OumRu SabRaAri. (TA.)
See also SabirN.

SaAbirN and SabuwrN↓, (M, K,) the latter of which is also applied to a female, without p, (M,) and SabiyrN↓ (M, K) and SabRaArN↓, (M,) are epithets from Sabara “ he was patient, or enduring: ” (M, K:) the five following epithets are said to denote different degrees of patience: SaAbirN is the most general of them [in signification, meaning simply Patient, or enduring]: muSoTabirN↓ signifies acquiring patience; and tried with patience: mutaSabRirN↓, constraining himself to be patient: SabuwrN↓, having great patience; [or very patient;] whose patience is greater than that of others; [as also SabiyrN↓; or this signifies rendered patient, from Sabarahu;] denoting quality, or manner: and SabRaArN↓, having an intense degree of patience; [or having very great patience;] denoting measure, and quantity: the pl. of SabuwrN↓ is SuburN. (TA.) As an epithet applied to God, (Aboo-Is-hák [i. e. Zj],) AlSRabuwru↓ signifies The Clement, or Forbearing, who does not hastily avenge Himself upon the disobedient, but forgives, or defers: (Aboo-Is-hák, K:) [it may be well rendered The Long-suffering:] it is an intensive epithet. (TA.) One says also, huwa SaAbirN EalaI Albarodi (tropical:) [He is a patient endurer of cold]. (A.)
SanobarN; &c.: see art. Snbr.
SawobarapN: see SabaArRapN.
SaAbuwrapN Ballast of a ship; the weight that is put in the bottom of a ship. (TA.)

OaSobaru [More, and most, patient or enduring]. OaSobaru mino HimaArK [More patient than an ass] is a prov. (Meyd.) And one says, huwa OaSobaru EalaI AlDRarobi mina AlOaroDi (tropical:) [He is more patient of beating than the ground]. (A.) [The fem.] SuboraI is applied to a she-camel by Honeyf El-Hanátim [as meaning Surpassingly patient or enduring]. (IAar, TA in art. bhI.)

OaSobirapN Sheep or goats, and camels, that return in the evening and morning to their owners, not remaining away from them: (M, K: *) [a pl. having no sing.: (K:) [ISd says,] I have not heard any sing. of it. (M.)
maSobuwrN [pass. part. n. of 1, q. v. Confined, &c.

] Confined [with bonds or otherwise], (K,) or set up, (M,) to be put to death: (M, K:) and rajulN SabuwrapN↓ a man confined, (K,) or set up, (M,) to be put to death; (M, K;) i. q. maSobuwrN liloqatoli: (Th, M, K:) and maSobuwrapN, applied to a beast (bahiymapN, A), confined [or bound] to be put to death [and in that state killed by arrows or the like]; i. q. maHobuwsapN EalaI Almawoti: such is forbidden to be eaten. (S, A.)
maSobuwrapN applied to an oath: see SaborN.
Also Made into a Suborap, like a Suborap of wheat; so gathered or collected together. (TA.)
muSoTabirN: see SaAbirN. [mSTyr is expl. by Reiske as signifying Collecta caro ( ὄγκοσ τῆσ σαρκός): mentioned by Freytag: if so, it is app. muSoTabirN: see its verb.]
mutaSabRirN: see SaAbirN.

1. SabaEa bihi, aor.
SabaEa
, (AZ, S, K,) inf. n. SaboEN, (AZ, S,) He pointed at him, or towards him, with his finger, (biUiSobaEihi,) disparagingly: (AZ, S, K:) or, as some say, he meant some evil thing to him when he (the latter) was inadvertent, not knowing. (TA.)

And SabaEa fulaAnFA EalaI fulaAnK He directed such a one to such a one by pointing, or indication: (S, K:) because, when one directs a man to a way, or road, or to a thing that is latent, or obscure, he points towards it with the finger.
