(TA.) One says, maA SabaEaka EalayonaA What directed thee to us? (TA.) And SabaEa bayona Alqawomi He directed others to the people, or party. (TA.) Of one who magnifies himself, or acts proudly, in his government, or administration, one says, SabaEahu AlXRayoTaAnu (assumed tropical:) [app. meaning The Devil has directed him]: and Oadorakatohu OaSaAbiEu AlXRayoTaAni [The fingers of the Devil have reached him]. (TA. [See the pass. part. n. below.])

And one says, qurRiba Uilayohi TaEaAmN famaA SabaEa fiyhi i. e. [Food was presented, or offered, to him, or was placed, or put, before him, and] he did not put his finger into it. (TA.) [See also SabaOa, near the end.]
And SabaEa AldRajaAjapa, (O, K,) inf. n. as above. (TA,) He inserted his finger into the hen in order that he might know if she were [near] laying an egg or not: (O, K:) mentioned by Z. (TA.)

And SabaEa AlUinaMCa He put his finger upon the vessel so that what was in another vessel flowed upon it [into the former vessel]: (A'Obeyd, S, O, K:) or, as some say, he put together his two fingers, [or two of his fingers,] then discharged, or let flow, what was in the vessel, of wine, or beverage, into a thing with a narrow head [or mouth]: or, accord. to Az, he discharged, or let flow, what was in the vessel, of wine, or beverage, between the extremities of [either of] his two thumbs and fore fingers, in order that it might not become scattered, and pour forth copiously. (TA.)
And SabaEahu, inf. n. as above, He hit, or hurt, his finger. (TA.)
SabaEa EalaI Alqawomi, inf. n. as above, meaning He came forth upon the people, or party, is said to be originally SabaOa, with C. (TA.)

4. ASbE, followed by EalaI, is said by Freytag, as on the authority of Meyd, to signify He (a pastor) fed and managed well his cattle: but this is perhaps taken from a mistranscription of the saying, mentioned by Meyd, lilrRaAEiI EalaI maAXiyatahi UiSobaEN, q. v. infrà.]
SaboEN (tropical:) Self-magnification, or pride; (O, K, TA;) such as is consummate; (TA;) and haughtiness, or insolence, or vain glory; (O, TA;) and muSobaEapN↓ signifies the same. (O, K, TA.)
SuboEN i. q. SuboHN [q. v.]: the E being substituted for the H. (MF on the letter E.)

UiSobaEN and OuSobaEN and OuSobuEN and UiSobiEN and OaSobiEN (S, O, Msb, K) and UiSobuEN and OaSobaEN (O, Msb, K) and OaSobuEN and OuSobiEN, the C being thus trebly vowelled, and the b likewise (Msb, K) with every one of the vowellings of the C, (K,) and OuSobuwEN↓ also, (Msb, K,) of all which forms the
first is the [only] one commonly known and the one approved by persons of chaste speech, (Msb,) all mentioned by Kr, (K,) and by Lh also on the authority of Yoo, (TA,) A finger: and a toe: (MA, KL, &c.:) of the fem. gender, (Msb,) or fem. and masc., (S, O, Msb, K, *) but generally fem.: (O, Msb, K: *) pl. (of ASbE, MA) OaSaAbiEu and (of ASbwE, MA) OaSaAbiyEu. (MA, K.)

One says, bihimo tuvonaI AlOaSaAbiEu [With the mention of them the fingers are bent]; meaning that they are reckoned as the best, [or among the best,] for the best are not many. (M, on a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. vnI.) [See also two similar exs. in the first paragraph of art. Hnw and HnI.]

And lilrRaAEiI EalaI maAXiyatihi UiSobaEN (tropical:) [The pastor has a finger pointing at his cattle, or camels or sheep or goats]; meaning, [has upon his cattle] an impress of a good state or condition; (S, K, * TA;) i. e. they are pointed at with the fingers because of their goodliness and fatness and good tending. (TA.) [See also a verse cited voce SulobN.] And similar to this saying is the prov., Ealayohi mina QllRehi taEaAlaI UiSobaEN HasanN, meaning (assumed tropical:) [Upon him is, from God, (acknowledged be his absolute supremacy,)] an impress of a good state or condition. (Meyd.) And one says also, UinRahu laHasanu AlUiSobaEi fiI maAlihi, meaning (assumed tropical:) Verily he is good in respect of the impress upon his cattle [indicative of their state or condition]. (IAar, TA.)
And fulaAnN mugilRu AlUiSobaEi (tropical:) Such a one is unfaithful, treacherous, or perfidious. (O, K, * TA. *)
And lahu UiSobaEN fiI hecaA AlOamori (tropical:) [He has a finger in this affair]. (TA.)

The Prophet said qalobu AlmuWomini bayona UiSobaEayoni mino OaSaAbiEi QllRehi yuqalRibuhu kayofa XaMCa (tropical:) [The heart of the believer is between two of the fingers of God: He turneth it about as He pleaseth]. (O.)

And a man says, in respect of a difficult affair, when he has been made to have recourse to a strong man, able to bear his burden, UinRahu yaOotiI Ealayohi biUiSobiEK waAHidapK (assumed tropical:) [Verily he will make an end of it with one finger]: and UinRahu yakofiyhi biSugoraI OaSaAbiEihi (assumed tropical:) [Verily the smallest of his fingers will suffice him for its accomplishment; the b thus prefixed to the agent being redundant, as in kafaI biQllRehi XahiydFA and many other instances]. (O.)
Oabuw AlUiSobaEi is one of the surnames of The Devil. (TA. [See SabaEahu AlXRiyoTaAnu, above.])
[UiSobaEN signifies also (assumed tropical:) A prong, as resembling a finger: so in the S and K in art. Hfr, and in other instances.]

OaSaAbiEu AlfatayaAti, (O, TS, K,) in the “ Minháj ” of Ibn-Jezleh ASAbE AlftyAn, [app. a mistranscription,] and in the I, ASAbE AlbunayRaAti, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) [Common clinopodium, or wild basil,] the sweet-smelling plant called in Pers. AlfaranojamuXok, (AHn, O, K,) which grows abundantly in the southern parts of Arabia, and is not depastured by any animal. (AHn, O.)

OaSaAbiEu AlEacaAraI (assumed tropical:) A species of grapes, (AHn, O, K,) black, (AHn, O,) long, like the acorn, likened to the dyed fingers of virgins; (AHn, O, K; *) the bunch thereof is about a cubit [in length], compact [so I render mutadaAxis, supposing it to be similar to dxys applied to herbage &c.,] in the grapes; its raisins are good; and it grows in the Saráh (AlsRaraAp). (AHn, O.)

OaSaAbiEu huromusa (assumed tropical:) The flowers (fuqRaAH) of the suwranojaAn [or Hermodactylus (the Iris of Linn.?) now applied to meadow-saffron, a species of colchicum]; (O, K;) the potency of which is like that of the swrnjAn [itself]. (TA.)

OaSaAbiEu firoEawna (assumed tropical:) [Certain things] resembling the maraAwiyd [or maraAwid with which kuHol is applied], of the length of the finger, (K, TA,) red; (TA;) brought from the Sea of El-Hijáz; of proved efficacy for the speedy consolidation of wounds. (K.)

OaSaAbiEu SuforN (assumed tropical:) The root (OaSol) of a certain plant of which the form is like the hand, (O, K,) variegated with yellowness and whiteness, hard, and having a little sweetness; and there is a species thereof yellow, with a dust-colour, but without whiteness: (O, TA:) so says Ibn-Jezleh: (TA:) it is beneficial as a remedy for madness, or diabolical possession, and for poisons, (K, TA,) and the sting, or bite, of venomous, or noxious, reptiles, or the like, and it acts as a dissolvent of thick excrescences. (TA.)
As a measure, UiSobaEN signifies [A digit; i. e. a finger's breadth;] the width of six moderate-sized barley-corns; (Msb voce jariybN;) the forth part of the qaboDap. (Mgh and Msb ibid.)
OuSobuwEN: see UiSobaEN, first sentence.
maSobaEapN: see SaboEN.
maSobuwEN (tropical:) Self-magnifying, or proud. (IAar, O, K, TA.)

1. Sabagahu aor.
Sabuga
and
Sabaga
(S, O, Msb, K, the former not in the copy of the K used by SM) and
Sabiga
, (Fr, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. SabogN (S, O, Msb, K) and SibagN (As, O, K) and SibagapN, (AHn, TA,) [of which last, SibogapN (q. v.), also said to be an inf. n., is perhaps a contraction, or, as is said in the Ksh ii. 132, it means a mode, or manner, of Sabog,] He dyed it, or coloured it; (K TA;) namely, a garment, or piece of cloth; (S, O, Msb, TA;) and white, or hoary, hair, and the like. (TA.) [It is said that] the primary meaning of AlSRabogu in the language of the Arabs is The altering [a thing]: and hence Subiga AlvRawobu, meaning The garment, or piece of cloth, was altered in colour to blackness or redness or yellowness [&c.]. (TA.)

[Hence,] Sabaga AllRuqomapa, aor.
Sabuga
, inf. n. SabogN, (assumed tropical:) He moistened the mouthful with oil or grease [or any kind of Sibog i. e. sauce & c.]; and he dipped it, or immersed it; and in like manner any other thing. (TA.) [Thus] one says, Sabaga yadahu biAlmaMCi (As, O, K) and fiI AlmaMCi (TA) (tropical:) He dipped, or immersed, his hand, or arm, in the water. (As, O, K, TA.) And Sabagati AlnRaAqapu maXaAfirahaA fiI AlmaMCi (As, O) or biAlmaMCi (TA) (assumed tropical:) The she-camel dipped her lips in the water. (As, O, TA.)

[Hence also,] the term SabogN is used by the Christians as meaning (assumed tropical:) The dipping, or immersing, of their children, [i. e. baptizing them,] in water. (Az, S, * TA.) One says, Sabaga waladahu fiI AlnRaSoraAniyRapi, inf. n. [SabogN (as shown in the next preceding sentence) and] SibogapN, (assumed tropical:) He introduced his child into the Christian communion, it is said, by dipping, or immersing, him in the water of baptism. (TA.) And Sabaga waladahu fiI AlyahuwdiyRapi (assumed tropical:) He introduced his child into the Jewish communion [probably by baptism combined with circumcision: but see SibogapN, an explanation of which seems to indicated that circumcision alone is meant in this case]. (TA.)
And yaSobuguwna AlHadiyva (assumed tropical:) They colour and alter information, or discourse. (O.)

And Sabaguwhu fiI Eayonihi (assumed tropical:) They altered him in his estimation; and informed him that he had become altered from the state in which he was. (TA.) And it is said that SabaguwniI fiI Eayonika and SabaguwniI Einodaka mean They pointed me out to thee as one who would accomplish what thou desiredst of me; from the saying of the Arabs, Sabagotu AlrRajula biEayoniI and biyadiI I pointed at the man with my eye and with my hand: (O, K: *) but Az says that this is a mistake; that the Arabs when they mean thus say SabaEotu, with the unpointed E. (O.)

One says also, Sabaga yadahu biAlEilomi, (Msb,) or bifanRK mina AlEilomi, and biAlEamali, (TA,) (tropical:) He laboured in science, [or in a species of science or knowledge, and in work,] and became notable therein [or thereby]. (Msb.)
Sabaga DaroEuhaA, inf. n. SubuwgN, (tropical:) Her udder became full, and goodly in colour: (O, K, TA:) said of a camel. (O, TA.)

And Sabagato EaDalatuhu, (O, K,) aor.
Sabuga
, (O, TA,) inf. n. SubuwgN, (TA,) said of a man, (O,) His EDlp [or muscle] became long: (O, K:) like sabagato. (O, TA.) And Sabaga AlvRawobu, inf. n. SubuwgN, The garment, or piece of cloth, was long and ample: a dial. var. of sabaga. (TA.)

And Sabaga fiI AlTRaEaAmi, aor.
Sabuga
, He [app. a camel] put his head into the food: as also SabaOa. (O.) And Sabagati AlUibilu fiI AlrRiEoIi [The camels put their heads into the pasture, or herbage]. (O, TA.) And Sabagato fiyhaA raOosahaA [or fiyhi, She put her head into it]; like SabaOato. (TA.)
2. SbRgt viyaAbahaA She (a woman) dyed her garments much. (O.)

SbRgt AlrRuTabapu, (S, A, TA,) or Albusorapu, (O, L, TA,) inf. n. taSobiygN, (L, TA,) i. q. canRabat (tropical:) [i. e. The ripening date, or the full-grown unripe date, began to ripen, or showed ripening, or became speckled by reason of ripening, or ripened, at the part next the base and stalk]: (S, O, L, TA:) or became coloured. (A, TA.) And AlnRaxolapu ASbgt↓ (tropical:) The palm-tree showed ripening in its dates; (O, K, TA;) as also SbRgt, inf. n. as above: (K:) or, accord. to Az, tSbyg in relation to the palm-tree [itself] is not known. (TA.)

And SbRgt AlnRaAqapu, (Az, O, K,) inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) The she-camel cast her young one when its hair had grown; as also ASbgt↓: (O, K:) but sbREt, with s, which means the same, is more commonly used. (Az, O, TA.)
4: see 2, in two places.

OaSobaga QllRehu Ealayohi AlnRiEama
is a dial. var. of OasobagahaA, (O, K, *) meaning God rendered benefits, or boons, complete, full, or ample, to him. (O.)

5. tSbRg fiI AldRiyni is from AlSRibogapu, (Lh, O, K,) and means (assumed tropical:) He became settled, or established, in religion: (TK:) and so tSbRg SibogapF HasanapF; expl. by Z as meaning (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, in a good state [in respect of religion]. (TA.)
8. ASTbg bikacaA It was, or became, dyed, or coloured, with such a thing. (TA. [There said to be tropical; but this I doubt.])

And ASTbg biAlSRibogi, (S, * O, K,) or biAlxalRi, (El-Fárábee, Mgh, Msb,) and the like, and, as some say, mina AlxalRi, (Msb,) or fiI AlxalRi, (Mgh, [so in my copy, but app. a mistranscription]) (tropical:) He made use of what is termed Sibog [or sauce, & c.], (O, K, TA,) or vinegar, (TA,) to render his bread savoury; (O, K, TA;) AlSRibog including olive-oil, as well as vinegar, and similar seasonings. (TA.) One may not say, ASTbg Alxuboza bixalRK. (Mgh, Msb.)
ASTbg also signifies (assumed tropical:) He made, or prepared, what is termed Sibog [i. e. sauce, & c.]. (TA.)

SbogN (AZ, As, S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and SibogapN↓ (S, O, Msb, K) and SibagN↓, (O, K,) or this is an inf. n., differing from SibogN, (AZ, As, L,) and SibaAgN↓, (Mgh, O, Msb, K,) as some say, (O,) or this last is a pl. of the first, (O, * Msb,) [or] the pl. of SibogN is OaSobaAgN, (S,) A dye; (AZ, As, S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) used for colouring clothes [& c.]: (TA:) the pl. of SibaAgN↓ is OaSobigapN; and OaSaAbiygu is a pl. pl. [i. e. pl. of OaSobaAgN]. (TA.)

[Hence, app.,] one says of a girl, or young woman, when one first takes her as a concubine, or when he first has her conducted to him as a bridge, (AZ, O,) or when one first marries her, (K,) UinRahaA laHadiyvapu AlSibogi (assumed tropical:) [Verily she is one newly taken as a concubine, or a bride: app. alluding to the recent application of the dye of the hinnà]. (AZ, O, K.) And one says also, maA Oaxacotuhu biSibogi AlvRamani, (AZ, O,) or maA Oaxacahu biSibogi vamanihi, (K,) i. e. [I did not, or he did not, take it, or acquire it,] for its proper price, [app. meaning its cost-price, or prime-cost,] but for a high [or raised] price. (AZ, O, K. *)

SibogN also signifies, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, TA,) and so does SibaAgN↓, (Mgh, TA,) or the latter is pl. of the former, (S, O, TA,) (tropical:) A seasoning, or condiment, for bread, to render it savoury; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, TA;) particularly (Msb) such as is fluid, (Mgh in art. Adm, and Msb,) as vinegar, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) and olive-oil, (Mgh, TA,) and the like, (Msb, TA,) [i. e. any sauce,] in which the bread is dipped: (Msb:) so called because the bread is dipped in it, (Mgh, TA,) and coloured thereby: (Mgh:) the pl. of SibaAgN↓ is OaSobigapN: one says, kavurati AlOaSobigapu EalaI AlmaAYidapi (tropical:) (tropical:) The sauces, or fluid seasonings, were abundant upon the table.] (TA.) SibogN is used in this sense, but not explained, in the K. (TA.) Hence, in the Kur [xxiii. 20], waSibogK liloMkiliyna (assumed tropical:) [And a sauce for those that eat]; (S, O, Msb, TA;) where it means, accord. to Fr, olive-oil; but accord. to Zj, the olive [itself]; and Az prefers the latter explanation: (TA:) some read waSibaAgK↓. (Bd.)
SabagN, in a horse, The having the whole of the fetlock white, without its whiteness conjoining with that of what is termed AltRaHojiyl [q. v.]. (TA.)
SibagN: see SibogN, first sentence.
SubogapN, in a sheep or goat, or in a ewe, (assumed tropical:) Whiteness of the extremity of the tail; the quality denoted by the epithet SabogaMCu. (TA.)
Also (assumed tropical:) A date that has become partly ripe, i. e. ripe in a part thereof. (O, K.)
SibogapN: see SibogN, first sentence.

It also means (assumed tropical:) Religion, syn. diyn, (AA, O, K,) and milRap; (K;) and the religious law, syn. XariyEap; (TA;) and anything whereby one advances himself in the favour of God: (AA, TA:) [thus,] in the Kur [ii. 132], (O, TA,) Sibogapa QllRehi means the religion of God, syn. fiTorapa QllRehi, (O, Msb, K,) or diyna QllRehi, (S, Msb,) which is the meaning of fiTorapa QllRehi; (Msb;) the religion of God, with an adaptation to which mankind are created; because its effect appears in him who has it like the dye in the garment; (Bd, Jel;) or because it intermingles in the heart like the dye in the garment; (Bd;) and it is said to be from the Christians' Sabog [or Sabogap i. e. baptism] of their children in a sort of water that they have; (S; [and the like is said in the O, and Ksh, & c.;]) Sbgp being in this instance in the accus. case as an objective complement; (Msb;) for the meaning is “ follow ye the religion of God; ” (O, Msb;) or “ we will follow the religion of God: ” (O:) or it means that which God has prescribed to Mohammad; i. e. circumcision: (O, K:) or Sbgp is in this instance an inf. n., (Ksh, Bd, Jel,) signifying a mode, or manner of, Sabog [i. e. of baptism], (Ksh,) relating to the baptism of the Christians, (Ksh, Bd,) a corroborative of the saying MmanRaA [in verse 130], as such put in the accusative case, (Ksh, Bd, Jel,) by reason of a verb understood, (Jel,) the meaning being SabaganaA QllRehu Sibogatahu [God hath baptized us with his baptism]; (Ksh, Bd, Jel; *) [so that Sibogapa QllRehi signifies the baptism of God, and may here be rendered We have received the baptism of God;;] the Muslims being hereby commanded to say to the Christians, “ Say ye, God hath baptized us (SabaganaA) with the faith, with a baptism (Sabogap) not like ours [i. e. not like our Christian baptism], and purified us with a purifying not like ours; ” or the Muslims being hereby commanded to say [of themselves], “ God hath baptized us (SabaganaA) with the faith, as a baptism (SibogapF), and we have not been baptized with your baptism (lamo nuSobago Sibogatakumo). ” (Ksh.)
SibogiIRN a rel. n. from SibogN. (Msb.)
[A seller of dyes. (Golius, on the authority of Meyd.)]
SibaAgN: see SibogN, in five places.
SabiygN i. q. maSobuwgN↓ [i. e. Dyed]; applied to a garment, or piece of cloth: and also used as a pl., applied to garments, or pieces of cloth. (L, TA.) [See also muSabRagN.]
SibaAgapN The craft, or art, of the dyer. (O.)
SabRaAgN A dyer (O, L, K) of garments. (O, K.)

And [hence,] (tropical:) A liar: (K:) one who colours and alters information, or discourse. (O, K. *) The Prophet is related to have said, Oakocabu AlnRaAsi AlSRabRaAguwna waAlSRawRaAguwna or mino Oakocabi AlnRaAsi Alx [Which may mean The most lying of men, or of the most lying of men, are the dyers and the goldsmiths; or (assumed tropical:) those who colour, and those who transform, information, or discourse]: El-Khat- tábee says, the meaning is, that the persons who practise the two crafts to which these words relate make many promises as to returning the goods, and often break their promises; wherefore they are said to be of the most lying of men; not that every one of them is one who lies: but he adds that it has been said to mean the moulding and colouring of speech with falsehood. (O.)
naAqapN SaAbigN, (O, K,) without p, (O,) A she-camel having her udder full, and goodly in colour. (O, K.)
And UibilN SaAbigapN fiI AlrRiEoIi [meaning Camels putting their heads into the pasture], with p. (O. [See 1, last sentence but one.])

OaSobagu (assumed tropical:) A horse white in the forelock, (AO, S, Mgh, O, K,) all of it: (AO, Mgh: [see also OasoEafu:]) or white in the extremities of his tail: (S, O:) or white in the extremities of the ear: (K:) when the whiteness is in his tail, he is termed OaXoEal: or, accord. to AO, it signifies also white in the whole of the tail, including its extremities. (TA.) And (tropical:) A bird white in the tail: (S, O, K, TA:) or, accord. to the book entitled “ Ghareeb el-Hamám ” by El-Hasan Ibn-' Abd-Allah ElIsbahánee El-Kátib, white in the whole of the head; but used in the former sense by the keepers of pigeons. (TA.) And [the fem.] SabogaMCu (assumed tropical:) A sheep or goat (XaAp, S, O, K) or a ewe (AZ, TA) white in the extremity of its tail, (AZ, S, O, K, TA,) the rest of it (i. e. of the animal) being black. (TA.)
Also (assumed tropical:) A species of weak birds. (TA.)
Also, (applied to a man, O,) (tropical:) One who voids his excrement (O, K, TA) in his clothes (K, TA) when he is beaten (O, K, TA) and when he is frightened: mentioned by Z. (TA.)

And SabogaMCu, (assumed tropical:) A certain tree, or plant, (Xajarap,) like the vumaAm [which is applied to several species of panic grass], having a white fruit, growing in sands: (K:) [but this seems to have been taken from three different explanations, here following:] accord. to Aboo-Ziyád, a certain tree, or plant, that grows in the sands, resembling the DaEap [which is applied to a species of the vumaAm], which is one of the abodes of the gazelles in the hot season, lurking-places being excavated by them at its roots: accord. to another, of the Arabs of the desert, it is like the vumaAm, but the DaEap is larger in the leaves, and of a brighter green: accord. to
Aboo-Nasr, a certain tree, or plant, having a white fruit. (O.) And, (O, K,) as some say, (O,) (assumed tropical:) A bunch of herbage, of which, when it comes up, the upper portions are green on the side next the sun, and white on the side next the shade. (O, K.)

Also (i. e. OaSobag) The greatest of torrents. (Ibn-' Abbád, O, K.) [In this sense, though used as a subst., it seems to be, as in other senses, imperfectly decl., being originally an epithet: if not originally an epithet, it might, accord. to some authorities, be perfectly decl.]
muSobigN [without p] (tropical:) A palm-tree (naxolapN) showing ripening in its dates. (O, TA.)
[maSobagapN A dye-house: so in the language of the present day.]

muSabRigN Dyed much. (O.) In the phrase viyaAbN muSabRagapN, [it is said that] the epithet is with teshdeed lilokavorapi [which means to denote muchness, and also to denote application to many objects, so that it may be rendered either Garments much dyed, or simply dyed garments]. (S.)
muSabRigN, like musabRigN, which is the more commonly used, [each without p,] applied to a she-camel, (assumed tropical:) Casting her young one when its hair has grown. (Az, TA.)
maSobuwgN: see SabiygN.

1. Sabana, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
Sabina
, (S Msb, K,) inf. n. SabonN, (S,) He turned away a gift, (As, S, K, TA,) or an act of kindness or beneficence, (As, S, TA,) from his neighbours, and his acquaintances, to others; and in like manner, kabana and xaDana; (As, TA;) or he withheld it; EanRRA [from us]: (As, S, K:) and Sabana AlkaOosa, (M, Msb,) aor. as above, (Msb,) he (the cupbearer) turned away the cup of wine, (M, Msb,) mimRino huwa OaHaqRu bihaA [from him who was more, or most, entitled to it], (M,) or Eanohu [from him]. (Msb.) 'Amr Ibn-Kulthoom says,
[Thou hast turned away the cup of wine from us, O Umm-' Amr; when the proper course of the cup of wine was towards the right]. (S. [See EM p. 184.])
And He (a man) hid a thing in his hand, (M, TA,) such as a dirhem & c., without its being known. (TA.)

And Sabana AlkaEobayoni, (S, K,) or AlqidoHayoni, aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) He placed evenly, or suitably, in his hand, (S, M, K,) the pair of play-bones, or dice, (S, K,) or the pair of gaming-arrows, (M,) and then cast them: (S, M, K:) said of a player at a game of hazard. (S, K.) To him who does so one says, Oajilo walaA taSobino [Shuffle thou, and do not pack]. (S.)
2. SbRn, from SaAbuwn, He soaped a thing; or washed it with soap: so in the language of the present day.]
7: see what next follows.

8. ASTbn and AnSbn↓ (K, TA) and Saboyana↓ (so in my MS. copy of the K) or Sayobana↓ (so in the CK, but neither of these is in the TA,) He, or it, turned away or back, or became turned away or back. (K.)
Q. Q. 1. Saboyana or Sayobana: see what next precedes.
SabonaMCu The hand of a player at a game of hazard inclined for acting treacherously to a companion. (IAar, K.)

SaAbuwnN a word of well-known meaning, (S, M, K,) [Soap;] a compound with which clothes [&c.] are washed: the best of which is made of pure olive-oil and clear potash and good jiyr [meaning lime], well cooked [i. e. boiled], and dried, and cut into particular shapes: the magoribiIR sort is not cut, nor well cooked [or boiled], but is like cooked starch: (TA:) it is hot and dry; and produces a pleasurable sensation in the body; (K;) but the washing the head with it hastens hoariness: (TA: [in which many other supposed properties of it are mentioned:]) IDrd says the word is not of the language of the Arabs: (TA:) [Fei, in the Msb, fancifully derives it from Sabana AlkaOosa, because it removes filths and impurities:] MF says that it is one of the words common to all languages, Arabic and Persian and Turkish and others [as Greek &c.]. (TA.)
[Hence,] SuAbuwnu Alhumuwmi is a term for (assumed tropical:) Wine. (TA voce tiroyaAqN, q. v.)
[SaAbuwniIRN Of, or relating to, soap; saponaceous.
And A maker, or seller, of soap: mentioned in the K and TA only as a surname.]

1. SabaA, (S, M, K,) aor. yaSobuw, inf. n. SabowapN, (S,) or SabowN, (M, K,) and SubuwRN (S, M, K) and SibFA [also written SibFI, in the CK (erroneously) SabFI,] and SabaMCN, (M, K,) [app., in its primary acceptation, He was a youth, or boy, or child; agreeably with an explanation of a phrase in what follows, and with explanations of SibFA and SabaMCN which will be found below:

and hence,] He was, or became, youthfully ignorant, or foolish, or silly: (M, K:) [and, as seems to be indicated in the TA, he indulged in amorous dalliance; a sense in which the verb, more especially with SibFA (q. v. infrà) for its inf. n., is very frequently used:] or he inclined to ignorant, or foolish, or silly, and youthful, conduct; and in like manner tSAbI↓; from AlSRibaA, which is from AlXRawoq [i. e. “ desire ”]: (S: [see an ex. of the inf. n. of the latter verb in a verse cited voce XaAba, in art. Xyb:]) or SibFA and SabaMCN, as inf. ns., signify the inclining the heart to any one; and have other significations expl. in what follows: and taSaAbK↓ signifies the manifesting passionate love, and desire: (KL:) [but SibFA and SabaMCN are often used in different senses: thus Et-Tebreezee says that] in the following hemistich of a poem by Dureyd Ibn-Es-Simmeh,

L.foreign: SabaA maA SabaA HatRaI EalaA AlXRayobu raOosahu

sense.s: the first SbA may be from AlSRibaI [or AlSRibaA], and the second SbA from AlSRabaMCu signifying AlfataMCu; so that the meaning may be, He engaged in play, or sport, and AlSRibaI [or amorous dalliance, &c.], as long as he was a youth, [until hoariness came upon his head;] or the meaning may be, he engaged in AlSRibiI as long as he engaged therein, &c. (Ham p. 380.) And SabiIa, (S, M, K,) [aor. yaSobaI,] inf. n. SabaMCN, (S,) or SibFA, (M,) [or both, as will appear from what follows,] signifies He played, or sported, with the SiboyaAn [i. e. youths, or boys, or children]: (S:) or he acted in the manner of the SiboyaAn: (M, K: *) or both SibFA and SabaMCN, as inf. ns., signify the acting as a youth, or boy, or child; and the playing, or sporting, with youths, or boys, or children: (KL:) and tSbRI↓ and tSAbI↓, said of an old man, signify he acted in a youthful, boyish, or childish, manner. (TA.)

SabaA, inf. n. SubuwRN and SabowapN, also signifies He inclined. (Msb.) You say, SabaA UilayohaA He inclined to her, namely, a woman; as also SabiIa: and in like manner, Sabato Uilayohi and Sabiyato [She inclined to him]. (M. [See also SubRN, in art. Sb.]) And SabaA Uilayohi, (M,) or UilayohaA, (K,) inf. n. SabowapN (M, K) and SubowapN (K) and SubuwRN; (M, K;) and SabiIa; (K;) He yearned towards, longed for, or desired, (M, K,) him, (M,) or her: (K.)
[Hence, app.,] Sabati AlnRaxolapu, (M, K,) aor. taSobuw, (M,) The [female] palm-tree inclined, or leaned, towards the male palm-tree that was distant from it. (M.)
And Sabati AlrRaAEiyapu, (M, K,) aor. taSobuw, (M,) inf. n. SubuwRN, The pasturing beast inclined its head and put it upon the pasturage. (M, K.) [See also 2.]
Sabato, (S, M, K,) aor. taSobuw, (S, M,) inf. n. SubuwRN (S, M, K) and SabFA, (M, K,) in [some of] the copies of the K SabaAC, (TA,) said of the wind called AlSRabaA, (S, M, K,) It blew. (K.)
And SubiIa Alqawomu, (M, K,) like EuniIa, (K,) The people, or party, were blown upon by the wind called AlSRabaA. (M, K.)
2. SbRI raOosahu, inf. n. taSobiyapN, He inclined his head towards the ground. (TA.) [See also 1, near the end.]

3. SAbI rumoHahu, (T, S, *, M, K, TA,) inf. n. muSaAbaApN, (TA,) He inclined his spear, (M, K,) or he lowered the head of his spear towards the ground, (T, TA,) [or, as the context in the S seems to indicate, he inverted his spear,] to pierce, or thrust, (T, M, K,) with it. (M, TA.)

SAbI AlsRayofa He put the sword into its gimod [which generally means its scabbard] (S, M, K,) or into its qiraAb [which generally means its case for enclosing it together with its scabbard,] (TA,) reversed, or inverted: (S, M, K, TA:) or, accord. to the A, SAbI sayofahu, and sikRiynahu, means he put his sword, and his knife, into its qiraAb not in the right manner: and one says to one who hands a knife, SaAbi sikRiynaka i. e. Reverse thy
knife, putting the handle towards me. (TA.)
SAbI binaMCahu He made his building to incline, or lean. (K.)
SAbI maXaAfirahu He (a camel) inverted his lips on the occasion of drinking. (K.)
SAbI AlXRayoxa He, or it, overturned the old man; and made him to incline. (TA.)

SAbI Albayota, (M, K,) i. e. Albayota mina AlXRiEori, (TA,) He recited the verse not rightly, or not regularly. (M, K, TA. [In the CK, SAbAhu Albayota.]) And SAbI AlkalaAma He made the speech, or language, to deviate from its proper course, or tenour. (M, K.)
SaAbayonaA Eani AlHamoDi is a phrase mentioned by AZ as meaning We turned away from the [plants called] HmD. (TA.)

And one says, AljawaAriI yuSaAbiyna fiI AlsRitori, meaning yTlEn [i. e. yaTRaliEona, but I think that fiI is a mistranscription for min, and that the meaning is, The girls, or young women, look from within the curtain]. (TA.)
4. OaSobato She (a woman) had a child such as is termed SabiIR [i. e. a boy, or a young male child]; (S, M;) and a child, male or female. (S.)

OaSobatohu She (a woman, M, K, or a girl, or young woman, S) excited his desire, and invited him, (M, K,) or made him to incline, (S,) to ignorant, or foolish, or silly, and youthful, conduct, (S, M, K,) so that he yearned towards her; as also taSabRatohu↓. (M, K.) And taSabRaAhaA↓ He invited her to the like thereof. (M.) And tSbRAhA↓ also signifies He deceived, or beguiled, her, and captivated her heart; (M, K; [see also another rendering in an explanation of a verse cited voce UiSaArN;]) as also tSAbAhA↓. (K.) And ASbI Eirosa fulaAnK He endeavoured to cause the wife of such a one to incline [to him]. (TA.)
OaSobawoA They entered upon [a time in which blew] the wind called AlSRabaA. (M, K.)
5: see 1, latter half:
and see also 4, in three places.
6: see 1, in three places:
and see also 4.
10. AstSbI, as stated by Freytag, is expl. by Reiske as signifying Pueriliter se et proterve gessit:
and by Jac. Schultens as signifying Pro puero habuit. But the usage of this verb in any sense is app. post-classical.]

SabFA [is of the fem. gender, and] is a subst. and an epithet, [so that one says riyHN SabFA, as well as SabFA alone and riyHu AlSRabaA,] (M, TA,) [and signifies The east wind: or an easterly wind:] the wind that blows from the place of sunrise: (Msb:) or the wind of which the mean place whence it blows is the place where the sun rises when the night and day are equal; the opposite wind of which is the dabuwr: (S:) or the wind that faces the House [of God, i. e. the Kaabeh; app. meaning that blows from the point opposite to the corner, of the Kaabeh, that is between the Black Stone and the door]; as though yearning towards the House: (M, TA:) or, accord. to IAar, (M,) the wind of which the place whence it blows extends from the place of rising of AlvRurayRaA [or the Pleiades] to [the place of] banaAt naEoX [meaning the tail of Ursa Major]: (M, K:) [it is often commended by poets as a gentle and pleasant gale, like the Zephyr with us:] the dual is SabawaAni and SabayaAni: (Lh, M, K:) and pl. SabawaAtN and OaSobaMCN. (M, K.)

SibFA [also written SibFI] and SabaMCN↓, the former with kesr and the short alif, and the latter with fet-h and the long alif, (S, Msb,) [both mentioned before as inf. ns.,] Youth, or boyhood; the state of the SabiIR [q. v.]: (S:) or childhood. (Msb.) One says, kaAna celika fiI SibaAhu and SabaAYihi [That was in his youth or boyhood: or in his childhood]. (Msb.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. XfE.]

And the former [or each, as is shown in the first sentence of this art.,] has also a signification derived from AlXRawoqu [or “ desire; ” i. e., each signifies also An inclining to ignorant, or foolish, or silly, and youthful, conduct; and amorous dalliance]: (S:) and SabowapN↓ signifies [the same, as is also shown in the first sentence of this art., or, like SibFA and SabaMCN,] the ignorance, or foolishness, or silliness, of youth; (Lth, M, K;) and amorous dalliance. (Lth, TA.) [See an ex. of the first in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. AdI; and another in a verse cited voce EaAraDa.]
SabowapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
SabaMCN: see SabFA.

SabiIRN A youth, boy, or male child; syn. gulaAmN: (S:) or a young male child; (Mgh, Msb;) before he is called gulaAm: (Mgh:) or one that has not yet been weaned, (M, K,) so called from the time of his birth: (M:) and SaAbK↓ signifies the same as SabiIRN; these two words being like qaAdirN and qadiyrN: (TA:) the pl. of the former is SiboyapN [a pl. of pauc., in which the w is changed into I because of the kesreh before it, like as is said in the M respecting another of the pls.,] (S, M, Msb, K, but not in the CK,) and SibowapN (M, K, TA, in the CK SabowapN,) and SuboyapN (M, K) and SaboyapN, (K, TA, but not in the CK,) [or rather the last two are quasi-pl. ns.,] and OaSobK [another pl. of pauc.] (K) and OaSobiyapN [also a pl. of pauc.], (M, K,) but this last is said by J to have been unused, because the usage of SiboyapN rendered it needless, (TA,) and SiboyaAnN, (S, M, Msb, K, but not in the CK,) in which the w is changed into I because of the kesreh before it, (M,) and SuboyaAnN, (M, K,) as some say, preserving the I notwithstanding the dammeh, (M,) and SibowaAnN (M, K, but not in the CK,) and SubowaAnN: (M, K:) and [ISd says,] accord. to Sb, the dim. of SiboyapN is OuSayobiyapN↓, and that of OaSobiyapN is SubayRapN↓, each irreg.; but in my opinion, SubayRapN is the dim. of SiboyapN, and OuSayobiyapN is that of OaSobiyapN: (M:) [J says,] OuSayobiyapN occurs in poetry as being the dim. of OaSobiyapN. (S.) SabiyRapN↓ signifies A young woman, girl, or female child; (S, TA;) and so too, [sometimes,] SabiIRN: (TA:) and the pl. is SabaAyaA. (S TA.)

OumRu AlSRiboyaAni is a term applied to The flatus, or flatulence, (AlrRiyHu,) that is incident to children. (TA in art. Am.) [Golius, in that art., explains it as meaning Larva, terriculamentum puerorum; on the authority of Meyd.: and also as meaning Epilepsy; on the authority of Ibn-Beytár.]
SabiIRN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The pupil of the eye: (M, K:) but Kr ascribes this meaning to the vulgar. (M.)

And (tropical:) The extremity of each of the jaw-bones: (K, TA:) i. e. (TA) AlSRabiyRaAni signifies the two extremities of the two jaw-bones (S, M, TA) of the camel and of other animals: or, as some say, the two edges curving outwards from the middle of the two jaw-bones: (M, TA:) or, accord. to the A, the thin portions of the two extremities thereof: and it is [said to be] tropical. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) A bone below the lobe, or lobule, of each of the two ears: (K:) or, as some say, the head of the bone that is below the lobe, or lobule, of each of the two ears by the space of about three fingers put together. (M.)

And (tropical:) The edge (HadR) of the sword: (M, K, TA:) or the ridge thereof, (M, TA, in the copies of the K Oawo gayorihi is erroneously put for Oawo Eayoruhu, TA,) which rises in [i. e. along] its middle; (M, K, TA;) and likewise of a spear-head: (M, TA:) or, accord. to the A, that part of a sword below, or exclusive of, (duwna,) its Zubap [q. v.]. (TA.)

And (assumed tropical:) The head of the human foot; (M, A, TA; in the copies of the K raOosu Alqawomi is erroneously put for raOosu Alqadami; TA;) i. e. the part [thereof] between its HimaArap [q. v.] and the toes. (A, TA.) And AlSRabiyRaAni signifies also (assumed tropical:) The two sides of the [camel's saddle called] raHol. (M.)

It is also said that SiboyaAnu Aljaliydi signifies (tropical:) The grains of hoar-frost that resemble pearls: and SiboyaAnu AlmaTari (tropical:) the small drops of rain: but accord. to the author of the “ Khasáïl, ” it is SiYobaAn [pl. of SuWaAbapN, q. v.], with C and then b. (TA.)
SabiyRapN fem. of SabiIRN, q. v.
SubayRapN: see SabiIRN, former half.
SaAbK: see SabiIRN, first sentence.
Also i. q. SaAHibu SabowapK [i. e. One who indulges in youthful folly, and amorous dalliance]. (TA.)

Kureysh, (M,) or the Jews, (TA,) used to call the Companions of the Prophet SubaApN. (M, TA. [See SaAbiYN, in art. SbO.]) And Náfi' read [in the Kur ii. 59 and xxii. 17] AlSRaAbiyna instead of AlSRaAbiYiyna; (TA;) and [in v. 73] AlSRaAbiyuwna instead of AlSRaAbiYuwna. (TA voce SaAbiYN.)
SubRaI, a pl. of SaAbK, is expl. as meaning Those who incline to conflicts and factions, seditions, or the like, and love to be foremost therein. (TA. [See SubRN, in art. Sb.])

AlSRaAbiyapu The oblique wind (AlnRukayobaMCu, dim. of AlnRakobaMCu,) that blows in a direction between that of the east or easterly wind (AlSRabaA) and that of the
north or northerly wind (AlXRamaAl): (S, K:) it is very cold, (S and TA voce nakobaMCu,) and very boisterous, and unattended by rain or by any good. (TA ibid.)
OuSayobiyapN: see SabiIRN.

muSobK, (Ks, Az, M,) or muSobiyapN, (S, A,) or both, (K,) applied to a woman, (Ks, Az, S, M, A, K,) and the former also applied to a man, (Er-Rághib, TA,) Having Siboyap [i. e. children, or young children, or young unweaned children], (S, Er-Rághib, A, *) or having a child such as is termed SabiIR. (M, K.)
Hence the latter is metaphorically applied by El-Hareeree to (tropical:) Wine of which the sealed cover has been broken. (Har p. 450.)
[See also the verb, 4.]
maSobuwRN: see SaAbiYN, in art. SbO.
muSaAbiyapN A calamity, or misfortune. (K.)

1. SaHRa, (S, A, MA, Msb, K,) aor.
SaHiHa
(MA, Msb, K) and
SaHaHa
, (MA,) inf. n. SiHRapN (S, * A, * MA, Msb, * MF, TA) and SuHRN, (S, * K, * MF, TA,) two forms of the inf. n. of which there are some other exs., as qilRapN and qulRN, and cilRapN and culRN, (MF, TA,) and SaHaAHN also, (K, * TA, * TK,) [like salaAmN &c.,] He was, or became, healthy, or sound; (MA;) or restored to health, or soundness, mino EilRatihi [from his disease]; (S, A;) as also AstSHR↓: (S:) or his disease departed. (K, TK.) And (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, [or proved,] sound, valid, (MA,) [substantial, real, sure, certain,] true, right, (MA, Msb,) correct, just or proper, whole or entire, (MA,) or [unmarred, or unimpaired,] free from every imperfection or defect or fault or blemish, (L, K, TA,) and from everything that would occasion doubt or suspicion or evil opinion: (L, TA:) and (tropical:) it was, or became, suitable to the case, or event. (Msb.) You say, SaHRato XahaAdatuhu (tropical:) [His testimony was sound, valid, &c.]. (A, TA.) And SaHRa qawoluhu (tropical:) [His saying was, or proved, true]. (A, TA.) And SaHRa Einoda AlqaADiI HaqRuhu (tropical:) [His right, or due, or just claim, was, or became, established, substantiated, made good, or verified, in the estimation of the judge; like vabata]. (A, TA.) And SaHRa lahu Ealayohi kacaA (tropical:) [Such a thing became established, or verified, as due to him from him; like vabata]. (A, TA.) And SaHRa AlEaqodu (tropical:) The contract became established by its execution. (Msb,) And SaHRati AlSRalaApu, as used by the lawyers, (tropical:) The prayer [was suitable to the ordinance thereof, so that it] annulled the obligation of performing it after the appointed time. (Msb, * and Dict. of Techn. Terms of the Mussalmans pp. 815-816. [This meaning is expressed in the former by the phrase OasoqaTati AlqaDaMCa; which is fully expl. in the latter work, with other conventional meanings of SiHRapN, all reducible to explanations given above.]

SaHRa AlXRaIoCa [if not a mistranscription for OaSaHRa or SaHRaHa] signifies (assumed tropical:) He made the thing SaHiyH [i. e. sound, valid, &c.]. (L, TA. [In the latter app. taken from the former.])

2. SHRHhu, [inf. n. taSoHiyHN,] He rendered him healthy, sound, or free from disease; (S, A, MA, TA;) said of God; (S, TA;) and (A, TA) so ASHRhu↓. (A, K, TA.) One says, QllRehu badanaka OaSaHRa↓, and SaHRaHa jisomaka, May God render thy body healthy, sound, or free from disease. (A.)

And (assumed tropical:) He rendered it sound, valid, (MA,) [substantial, real, sure, certain,] true, right, (MA, Msb,) just or proper, whole or entire, (MA,) [or free from every imperfection or defect or fault or blemish, and from everything that would occasion doubt or suspicion or evil opinion: see 1.] You say, SaHRaHotu AlkitaAba, and AlHisaAba, (assumed tropical:) I corrected the book, or writing, and the reckoning; rectified what was wrong thereof. (L, TA.) And SHRH baraMCatahu [He verified his being free from a thing; clear, quit, or guiltless, of it; or irresponsible for it]. (Mgh in art. brO.)
4. ASHRhu: see 2, in two places.
Also He found him to be SaHiyH [or healthy, sound, or free from disease]; namely, a man. (L, TA.)

And ASHR He had his family and his cattle in a healthy, or sound, state; (L, K;) whether he himself were in health or sick: (L:) or, said of a people, or party, they had their cattle in a healthy, or sound, state, after they had been affected by a plague, or murrain, or distemper. (S, L.)
5. tSHRH bihi [He was rendered healthy, or sound, by it]. (O and TA voce XayoEapN, q. v.)
10: see 1, first sentence.
One says also, OanaA OasotaSiHRu maA taquwlu (tropical:) [I hold to be true, right, or just, what thou sayest]. (TA.)
R. Q. 1. SaHoSaHa It (a thing, or an affair,) was, or became, distinct, apparent, or manifest; (K;) like HaSoHaSa. (TA.)
SuHRN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

SiHRapN (S, A, MA, O, K) and SuHRN↓ (S, * O, K) and SaHaAHN↓ (O, K) [all app. inf. ns., of SaHRa, q. v.; and used as simple substs. meaning] Health, or soundness of body; (S, A, MA, O;) contr. of suqomN or saqamN: (S, A, O:) or departure of disease: (K:) SiHRapN is said to be in the body and in religion; like as are [its contrs.] maraDN and suqomN: (Aboo-Is-hák, TA in art. mrD:) in the body, it is a natural state or condition, wherewith the actions [and functions] of the body have the natural course: and it is metaphorically used in relation to [other things, including] attributes, or ideal things: (Msb:) and signifies [a sound, valid, substantial, real, sure, certain, true, right, correct, just or proper, whole or entire, state or condition; as is indicated in the first paragraph of this art.; or] freedom from every imperfection or defect or fault or blemish, (L, K, TA,) and from everything that would occasion doubt or suspicion or evil opinion. (L, TA.) One says, OawoSaI fiI SiHRatihi waXiHRatihi. (K in art. XH, q. v.) And wasuqomihi kaAna celika fiI SuHRihi↓ [That was in his state of health, or soundness, and his illness, or sickness]. (AO, S.) And mina maA Oaqoraba AlSRaHaAHa↓ AlsRaqaAmi [How little removed is health, or soundness, from illness, or sickness!]. (O.)
SaHaAHN: see SiHRapN, in two places:
and see SaHiyHN, in four places.
SaHaAHu AlTRariyqi means (assumed tropical:) The hard part of the road, that has not been rendered soft, or plain, (K, TA,) nor smooth, or easy to walk or ride upon. (TA.)
SuHaAHN: see the next paragraph.

SaHiyHN (S, A, MA, Msb, K, KL) and SaHaAHN↓ (S, A, Msb, K) Healthy, sound, or free from disease; (S, A, MA, K, KL;) and so SaHiyHu Aljasadi, applied to a man: (Msb:) and (assumed tropical:) sound, valid, (MA, KL,) [substantial, real, sure, certain,] true, right, (MA, KL, and Msb in explanation of the former word,) correct, just or proper, whole or entire, (MA, KL,) or [unmarred, or unimpaired,] free from every imperfection or defect or fault or blemish, (L, K, TA,) and from everything that would occasion doubt or suspicion or evil opinion: (L, TA:) [and (assumed tropical:) suitable to the case, or event: (see 1:)] fem. SaHiyHapN, applied to a woman [and to other things]: (TA:) pl. SaHaAHN, (A, Msb, K,) a pl. of SaHiyHN, (Msb,) and applied to men [and other things], (A, K, TA,) and of SaHiyHapN, and applied to women, (TA,) and OaSiHRaMCu, (A, Msb, K,) a pl. of SaHiyHN, (Msb,) and applied to men, (A, K,) and OaSiHRapN, likewise applied to men, (A,) and SaHaAYiHu, (K,) a pl. of SaHiyHapN, and applied to women. (TA.) SaHiyHu AlOadiymi means [lit. Sound of skin; or] not [having the skin] cut; as also SaHaAHu↓ AlOadiymi: (S:) [but each has a tropical signification; for] one says, fulaAnN SaHiyHu AlOadiymi (Ham p. 628) meaning (tropical:) [Such a one is sound] in respect of origin, and of honour, or reputation. (Har p. 135.) And dirohamN SaHiyHN means A dirhem free from defect; as also SaHaAHN↓; and SuHaAHN↓, [which I find as syn. with SaHiyHN in my copy of the K,] with damm, is allowable, like TuwaAlN as syn. with TawiylN. (L, TA.) And it is said in a trad., yuqaAsimu Qbonu Mdama Oahola AlnRaAri qisomapF SaHaAHFA↓ i. e. The son of Adam, meaning Kábeel [or Cain], who slew his brother Hábeel [or Abel], will make a right division with the people of Hell, so that half of it shall be for him, and half for them. (L, TA.)

SaHoSaHN (S, L, Msb, K) and SaHoSaAHN↓ and SaHoSaHaAnN↓ (S, L, K) A place, (S, Msb,) or ground, or land, (L, K,) that is plain, or even,
(S, L, Msb, K,) destitute of herbage: pl. of the first SaHaASiHu: (L:) and the first signifies a tract of land destitute of herbage, plain, or even, and containing small pebbles: (L:) or a smooth tract of land: (R, MF:) and OaroDN SaHaASiHu and SaHoSaHaAnN↓ a land destitute of everything, containing no trees, nor any depressed resting-place for water, said by AM to be seldom found except in the rising ground of a valley, or in a mountain near to such rising ground, and not so plain as what is termed SaHoraMC. (L.)

[Hence, app., (see art. trh,)] turRahaAtN SaHaASiHu, and turRahaAtu SaHaASiHa, [the latter preferred by J, as he says in the S,] (tropical:) What is vain, or false; (S, K, TA;) like trRhAt basaAbis: (S:) or [rather] vain, false, untrue things, that have no foundation. (TA.)
SuHoSuHN and SuHoSuwHN↓ One who pursues, or investigates, minute things, and retains them in his memory (yuHoSiyhaA), and knows them. (K.)
SaHoSaAHN: see SaHoSaHN.
SuHoSuwHN: see SuHoSuHN.
SaHoSaHaAnN: see SaHoSaHN, in two places.

muSiHRN A man having his family and his cattle in a healthy, or sound, state; whether he himself be in health or sick: (L:) or having his cattle in a healthy, or sound, state, after their having been affected by a plague, or murrain, or distemper: pl. muSiHRuwna. (S, L.) It is said in a trad., laA yuwridanRa cuw EaAhapK EalaI muSiHRK (S, L) i. e. One whose camels are affected by a murrain, or distemper, shall by no means bring them to water immediately after one whose camels are in a healthy, or sound, state, so as to water the former beasts with the latter: a prohibition apparently given for fear that the latter beasts should become diseased like the former, and it should be supposed that the disease had passed by contagion, which ought not to be imagined. (L. [See also mumoriDN.])

maSaHRapN A cause of one's being rendered healthy, or sound in body. (L, K.) So in the saying, AlSRawomu maSaHRapN [Fasting is a cause of one's being rendered healthy]. (L, K.) One says also, AlsRafaru maSaHRapN [Travel is a cause of one's becoming healthy]. (S, A.) And OaroDN maSaHRapN A land free from plagues, or any common, or epidemic, diseases; in which maladies are not common or frequent. (TA.)

muSaHoSiHN True, sincere, or honest, in love, or affection. (K.) And it is also said to signify Counselling, or admonishing, or one who counsels or admonishes, faithfully, or sincerely: so in a verse of Meleeh El-Hudhalee; as though used by poetic license for muSaHRiHN. (L.)
And (tropical:) One who does, or says, vain, or false, things. (A, K.)

1. SaHibahu, aor.
SaHaba
, inf. n. SuHobapN (S, A, Msb, K, &c.) and SaHaAbapN (S, A, K) and SiHaAbapN, (K,) He associated, kept company, or consorted, with him; (A, K;) [he accompanied him;] he was, or became, his companion, associate, comrade, fellow, friend, or fellow-traveller: (MA:) and SAHbhu↓ signifies the same. (TA. [See this latter verb below.])

[Hence] one says, SaHibaka QllRehu and SaAHabaka↓, (A, TA,) [inf. n. of the former (in the TA inadvertently said to be of the latter) SiHaAbapN, (said in the TA to be with kesr,) or SaHaAbapN, and, as will be shown by what follows, SuHobapN also,] (tropical:) May God guard, keep, protect, or defend, thee; may God be thy guardian, keeper, &c.: (TA in explanation of the former:) and OaHosana QllRehu SaHaAbataka (A, and Ham p. 443) or SiHaAbataka (TA) (tropical:) [May God make the guarding, &c., of thee to be good]. And (TA) [in like manner,] fulaAnFA ASHb↓ signifies (assumed tropical:) He guarded, kept, or protected, such a one; as also ASTHbhu↓: and he defended such a one; syn. manaEahu: (K, TA:) one says, biSuHobapK AallRehumRa OaSoHibonaA↓ waOaqolibonaA bicimRapK (assumed tropical:) O God, guard us with thy guarding in our journey, and make us to return with thy safeguard to our country, or land, &c.; occurring in a trad.: (TA:) and walaA humo minRaA yuSoHabuwna↓, (A, TA,) in the Kur [xxi. 44], (TA,) means (tropical:) Nor shall they (i. e. the unbelievers, TA) be defended from us, (A, TA,) as expl. by Zj; (TA;) and preserved in safety: (A:) or, accord. to Katádeh, nor shall they be attended by good from us: or, as some say, it is from the phrase SaHibaka QllRehu meaning as expl. above. (TA.)
See also 4, last sentence but one.

SaHaba, aor.
SaHaba
, (K,) inf. n. SaHobN, (TK,) He skinned a slaughtered animal. (K.)
3. SAHbhu, (MA,) inf. n. duSaAHabapN, (KL,) i. q. SaHibahu; (TA;) He associated, kept company, or consorted, with him. (MA, KL.) See 1, first and second sentences.
And see the next paragraph, last sentence but one.

4. OaSoHabotuhu qulaAnFA [I made such a one to be a companion, or an associate, to him]. (A.) And OaSoHabotuhu AlXRaIoCa (tropical:) I made the thing to be [as it were] a companion to him; (S, K, TA;) and so AstSHbthu↓; as in the saying, AstSHbth AlkitaAba wagayorahu (tropical:) I made the book, or writing, &c., to be [as it were] his companion. (S, * TA.)
And ASHbhu (tropical:) He did to him that which caused him to be a companion, or an associate, to him. (A, TA.)
And (tropical:) He left upon it, namely, a skin, its hair, (S, A,) or its wool; not subjecting it to the process termed EaTonN. (S.)
See also 1, in three places.

ASHb, intrans., He (a man) became one having a companion, or an associate: (K, TA: [in the latter said to be tropical; but, I think, without reason:]) and he was, or became, one having companions, or associates. (TA.)

And [hence,] (tropical:) He (a man) had a son who had attained to manhood (S, A, TA) and so become like him: (TA;) i. e. he was alone, and became one having a companion; (A;) or as though his son became his companion. (TA.)

And (tropical:) He (a camel, and a horse or similar beast, S, TA, or an animal, and a man to a man, A, TA *) became tractable, submissive, or obsequious, after being refractory, or incompliant; (S, A, TA;) [and so SaAHaba↓, as is implied by an explanation of its part. n. muSaAHibN; and AstSHb↓, for] hence, (A,) one says also, AisotaSoEaba tumRa QsotaSoHaba (tropical:) [He was refractory, or incompliant: then he became tractable, submissive, or obsequious]: (A, TA:) and accord. to A 'Obeyd, one says, SaHibotu↓ AlrRajula, from AlSRuHobapu, and OaSoHabotu [app. ASHbt lahu], meaning (assumed tropical:) I became tractable, submissive, or obsequious, to the man. (TA.)
And, said of water, (tropical:) It became overspread with [the green substance termed] TuHolub. (S, A. *)

5. yataSaHRabu minRaA (assumed tropical:) He is ashamed, or bashful, with respect to us; or shy of us; (K, TA;) i. e. he is ashamed to sit with us, or shy of sitting with us. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.) And fulaAnN maA yataSaHRabu mino XaIoCK (tropical:) Such a one does not guard himself against anything, and is not ashamed to do it, or shy of doing it, does not shun it, or avoid it. (A.)
6: see the next paragraph, in two places.

8. ASTHbwA, (S, A, K,) originally AStHbwA, (S,) They associated, kept company, or consorted, one with another; (S, A, K;) as also tSAHbwA↓: (A:) and in like manner ASTHbA and tSAHbA↓ said of two men. (TA.)
ASTHbhu: see 1.

10. AstSHbhu He desired him, or demanded him, as a companion, an associate, a comrade, or a friend: (MA:) or he invited him to associate, keep company, or consort, with him: and he clave to him: (A, K:) [he chose him, or took him, as a companion, &c.: and] he had him with him. (MA.)

[Hence,] one says, AisotaSoHabotu kitaAbFA liI (tropical:) [I made a book a companion to me; or I made a book belonging to me my companion]. (A, L, TA.) And AisotaSoHabotu AlkitaAba wagayorahu (assumed tropical:) I carried the book &c. with me. (Msb.) And one says of anything, AstSHbhu as meaning (assumed tropical:) It clave, adhered, or held-fast, to it; namely, another thing; (IF, S, Msb, TA;) or coalesced, or united, with it. (S, TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce raAmikN.]
See also 4, second sentence:
and see the last sentence but one of the same paragraph.
SaHobN: see SaAHibN.
SuHobapN an inf. n. of SaHibahu [q. v.]. (S, A, Msb, K, &c.)

[As a simple subst., Companionship. Hence, lahu SuHobapN, often occurring in biographies as meaning He had companionship with the Prophet; i. e. he was one of the Companions of the Prophet. And xarajotu SuHobapa AlrRasuwli, frequently occurring in trads., meaning I went forth in the companionship of the Apostle, or in company with the Apostle. Hence also] one says, Hamalotu AlkitaAba SuHobatiI (assumed tropical:) [I carried the book with me]. (Msb.) SuHobapu AlsRafiynapi [The companionship of the ship] is a post-classical phrase, denoting, by way of comparison, that which has no permanence. (Har p. 258.)
See also SaAHibN, of which it is a quasipl. n.
SaHaAbapN an inf. n. of SaHibahu [q. v.]. (S, A, K.)

See also SaAHibN, of which it is a quasi-pl. n. [AlSRaHaAbapu is commonly applied to The Companions of the Prophet:] SaHaAbiIRN↓ [is the n. un., meaning a Companion of the Prophet; and] is conventionally applied to one who saw Mohammad, and whose companionship with him was long, even if he have not related anything from him; or, as some say, even if his companionship with him was not long. (KT.)
SaHaAbiIRN: see the next preceding paragraph.

SaAHibN A companion, an associate, a comrade, a fellow, or a friend; (A, MA, KL, TA;) a fellow-traveller: (MA:) [an accomplice: (assumed tropical:) an accompanier, or attendant, as applied to a thing:] and (tropical:) a lord, or master; a possessor, an owner, an occupant, a haver, or a proprietor; of anything: (A, TA:) it is not trans. like the verb, therefore you may not say, zayodN SaAHibN EamorFA; (TA;) [i. e.] it is not used as an act. part. n., but as a subst., like waAlidN; (Ham p. 32:) the pl., (S, Msb,) or term applied to a pl. number, (A, K, TA,) is SaHobN↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) a pl. like rakobN of raAkibN, (S,) or [rather] a quasi-pl. n., (TA,) and OaSoHaAbN, [the most common of all,] (A, Msb,) a pl. like OaXohaAdN of XaAhidN, (TA,) or pl. of SaHobN, like OaforaAxN of faroxN, (S,) and OaSaAHiybu, (S, K,) pl. of OaSoHaAbN, (S,) and SuHobaAnN, (S, K,) a pl. like XubRaAnN of XaAbRN, (S,) and SiHaAbN, (S, A, K,) a pl. like jiyaAEN of jaAYiEN, (S,) and SiHaAbapN, (A, K,) in which the p may be regarded, agreeably with analogy, as an affix to the pl. SiHaAbN characteristic of the fem. gender, (TA,) and SaHaAbapN↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) which is more common than SiHaAbapN, (TA,) but the only instance of faEaAlapN as the pl. measure of a word of the measure faAEilN, (L, TA,) or originally an inf. n., (S,) or not so, but a quasi-pl. n., though written like the inf. n. [that is said to be its original], (from a marginal note in a copy of the S,) and SuHobapN↓, (S, A,) a pl. like furohapN of faArihN, (S, TA,) or [rather] a quasi-pl. n.: (TA:) the fem. is SaAHibapN, and its pl. is SawaAHibu and SawaAHibaAtN, (Mgh, Msb,) the latter mentioned by AAF on the authority of Abu-l- Hasan: (TA:) hence, in a trad. of 'Áïsheh, OanotunRa SawaAHibu yuwsufa [Ye are the female companions, or the mistresses, of Joseph; meaning, enticers to lewdness]; or, as some relate it, SawaAHibaAtu yuwsufa: (Mgh:) the dim. of SaAHibN is SuwayoHibN↓ (A) [and that of SaAHibahN is SuwayoHibapN↓]. yaASaAHi for yaASaAHibiI [O my companion, &c.,] is the only allowable instance of such curtailing of a prefixed noun, related as heard from the Arabs. (S, TA.) One says, fulaAnN SaAHibu SidoqK [Such a one is a good companion, &c.]. (A, * TA.) [And SaAHibu jayoXi The commander of an army. And SaAHibu Albariydi and SaAHibu AlXRuroTapi &c.: see arts. brd and XrT &c. And AlSRaAHibu, alone, in post-classical times applied to The Wezeer, when an officer of the pen: see De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., ii. 59.] And SaAHibu Alyamiyni [The companion of the right hand] and SaAHibu AlXRimaAli [The companion of the left hand]; appellations of each man's recording angels, who write down his good and evil actions. (A trad. thus commencing in the Jámi' es-Sagheer.) And SaAHibu AlSRuwri (assumed tropical:) The angel who is the possessor of the horn. (Idem.) [And SaAHibu bayotK (assumed tropical:) The owner, or master, of a house or tent.] And OaSoHaAbu AljanRapi (assumed tropical:) [The inmates, or occupants, of Paradise]: (Kur ii. 76, &c.:) and OaSoHaAbu AlnRaAri (assumed tropical:) [The inmates, &c., of the fire of Hell]. (Kur ii. 37, &c.) And SaAHibu sijonK (assumed tropical:) An inmate of a prison. (Bd and Jel in xii. 39.) And SaAHibu AlSRafRi waAljumoEapi (assumed tropical:) He who keeps to praying in the first rank and to the prayer of Friday. (El-Munáwee on a trad. thus commencing in the Jámi' es-Sagheer.) And OaSojaAbu AlXRaAfiEiIRi (tropical:) The followers of the persuasion of EshSháfi'ee: and in like manner one says of the followers of other persuasions. (Msb.) [And SaAHibu kitaAbK (assumed tropical:) The author of a book.] And SaAHibu EilomK wamaAlK (tropical:) A possessor of science and of wealth. (A, TA.) And SaAHibu witorK (assumed tropical:) [One who has a claim for blood-revenge: see an ex. in a verse cited voce darRaAkN]. (Keys Ibn-Rifá'ah, TA in art. drk.) [And SaAHibu OamorK wanahoIK (assumed tropical:) One who possesses authority to command and to forbid. And SaAHibu OamorK also signifies (assumed tropical:) The author of an affair or event or action; the doer of a thing; the manager, or disposer, thereof: and one who keeps, or adheres, to a thing. And SaAHibu dayonK (assumed tropical:) A debtor.] And one says, xaraja waSaAHibaAhu AlsRayofu waAlrRumoHu (tropical:) [He went forth, the sword and the spear being his companions]. (A, TA.)
SuwayoHibN and suwayoHibapN dims. of SaAHibN and SaAHibapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
OaSoHabu i. q. OaSoHaru, (S, K,) Of a colour inclining to redness: applied to an ass [app. to a wild ass]. (S, TA.)
muSoHabN [properly Made to have a companion.
And hence,] (assumed tropical:) A man possessed by a jinnee or demon; a demoniac; or insane. (K, * TA.)
See also muSoHibN.

And (tropical:) A skin, or hide, (A, K,) or a [skin such as is termed] ziqR, (S,) having its hair remaining upon it, (S, A, K,) or its wool, or its fur; (K;) and maSoHuwbN↓ signifies the same. (A.) Hence, qirobapN muSoHabapN (K, TA) (tropical:) A water-skin that has somewhat of its wool [or hair] remaining upon it, and that has not been subjected to the process termed EaTonN. (TA.)
And (tropical:) A branch, or stick, that has not been stripped of its bark, or peel. (TA.)
muSoHibN [properly Having a companion.
And hence,] A man having a son that has attained to manhood, and become like him. (K, * TA.)
And (tropical:) One who talks to himself; and so, sometimes, muSoHabN↓. (K, TA.)
And (tropical:) Tractable, submissive, or obsequious, after being refractory, or incompliant; (K;) as also muSaAHibN↓, (A, K,) and musotaSoHibN↓. (TA. [See also the next paragraph.])
And (assumed tropical:) Going straight on, or right on, without delay. (K.)
huwa miSoHaAbN lanaA bimaA nuHibRu (assumed tropical:) He is [very] submissive, or compliant, to us in that which we like. (K.) [See also muSoHibN.]
maSoHuwbN [Associated with, or accompanied].

[Hence,] one says [to a person departing], AimoDi maSoHuwbFA (tropical:) Go thou, kept in safety, preserved from harm; and [so] muSaAHabFA↓: (A, TA:) and [in like manner,] in bidding farewell, muEaAfFA muSaAHabFA↓ (tropical:) [Be thou kept in safety or health, preserved from harm]: and a poet says,
(assumed tropical:) [And my companion is preserved, or defended, from the causes of evil]. (TA.)
See also muSoHabN.
muSaAHabN: see maSoHuwbN, in two places.
muSaAHibN: see muSoHibN.
muSoTaHabN: see maSoHuwbN.
musotaSoHibN: see muSoHibN.

1. SaHarahu, aor.
SaHara
, (S, K,) inf. n. SaHorN, (S, TA,) namely, milk, He made it to become what is termed SaHiyrap: (S, TA:) or he cooked it, (K, TA,) and then gave it to a sick person to drink. (TA.)
SaHaratohu AlXRamosu The sun pained his brain: (K:) it is like Saharatohu; (A;) or, as some say, melted him. (TA.)

SaHara, aor.
SaHara
, inf. n. SaHiyrN and SuHaArN, He (an ass) uttered a sound [or braying] more vehement than the neighing of horses. (TA.)
[Golius explains SaHara as meaning It spread out wide, said of a place, on the authority of J: but the verb is ASHr, q. v.; and the authority is not J.]

3: [SiHaArN is an inf. n. of SaAHara, a verb not mentioned: hence,] Oaboraza lahu maA fiI nafosihi mina AlOamori SiHaAraA (assumed tropical:) [He showed to him what was in his mind, of the thing, or affair, openly]: a saying like jaAharahu bihi jihaArFA. (K, * TA. [See also 4.])

4. ASHr, (S, A, Mgh, K,) or ASHr AlSRaHoraMCa, (Msb, [but I think that this is a mistake for ASHr UilaI AlSRaHoraMCi,]) inf. n. UiSoHaArN, (Msb,) He went forth to the SHrMC [or desert, &c.], (S, A, Mgh,) or into the SHrMC: (Msb, K:) tSHRr [in this sense] has not been heard. (Mgh.)

Hence, in a trad., the saying of Umm-Selemeh to 'Áïsheh, sakRana QllRehu EuqayoraAki falaA tuSoHiriyhaA [app. meaning, accord. to explanations of it in the TA in art. Eqr, God hath made thy dwelling and estate, or, as Z explains it, thy person (nafosaki), to be quietly settled, therefore do not thou remove it forth to the desert]; i. e. laA tuboriziyhaA UilaI AlSRaHoraMCi; the verb, accord. to IAth, being made trans. by
the suppression of the prep.; [i. e. tuSoHiriyhaA being for tuSoHiriI bihaA;] for it is [properly] intrans. (TA. [See also the next sentence but one, in which the verb is tropically made trans.])
OaSoHiro liEaduwRika means (assumed tropical:) Be thou in a state of clearness [or certainty] with respect to the case of thy enemy: (JM, TA:) occurring in a trad. of 'Alee. (TA.)

One says also, OaSoHara biAlOamori and OaSoHarahu (tropical:) He revealed, or made manifest, the affair, or case: and laA tuSoHiro Oamoraka (tropical:) [Reveal not thy affair, or case]: and OaSoHirohu bimaA fiI qalobika (tropical:) [Reveal to him what is in thy mind]. (A, TA.)
ASHr said of a place, It was, or became, wide, or spacious; (O, K, TA;) i. e. it became like the SaHoraMC. (TA.)
Said of a man, He was, or became, blind of one eye. (K.)

11. ASHArR It (a plant) dried up; or became yellow; or dried up and became yellow: (S:) or became of a dingy red colour, and then dried up and became yellow: (TA:) and (TA) it (a plant, K, or an ear of corn, TA) became red: or its first parts became white. (K, TA.)
SiHorN an imitative sequent to SiforN [q. v.]. (Kh, Ham p. 354.)
SaHarN: see SuHorapN.

laqiytupu SaHorapa baHorapa, in which the two nouns are imperfectly decl., (S, L,) being regarded as one, (L,) and SaHorapF baHorapF, (K in art. bHr,) and buHorapa SuHorapa↓, with damm, (O,) and SuHorapF buHorapF, (MF in art. bHr,) and SaHorapF baHorapF naHorapF, (O, K,) and SaHorapa baHorapa naHorapa, (K, [but this last is implicitly disallowed in the O, and expressly by MF in art. bHr,]) and with damm also in all these words, [i. e. SuHorap &c.,] (K,) I met him openly, or in open view, nothing intervening to conceal him. (S, L, K. [See also baHorapN; and see SaroHapN.]) And one says likewise, Oaxobarahu biAlOamori SHrp bHrp [He acquainted him with the affair, or case, openly]. (TA.)

SuHorapN (S, K, in the CK, SuHarapN [which is a mistake,]) and SaHarN↓ (K [in some copies of the K SaHorN, which, as observed in the TA, is wrong,]) A colour in which is [the kind of red termed] XuqorapN: (S:) or a colour nearly the same as [the kind of red termed] SubohapN: (K:) or the latter, (TA, [and app. the former also,]) a dust-colour with a slight redness, (in the K, in Humorap xafiyRap, the latter of these two words is a mistake for xafiyfap, TA,) inclining to a little whiteness: (K, TA:) or the former, redness inclining to dustcolour: (TA:) or dust-colour with redness: (A:) and [redness of the kind termed] Xuqorap in the head: (As, TA:) and both words, a colour in which is whiteness and redness: (TA:) and whiteness overspreading blackness; like suHorapN and saHarN: (TA in art. sHr:) and the latter, accord. to Sgh, whiteness. (TA.)
Also, both words, The quality of a SaHoraMC [q. v.]. (ISh.)
And the former, A clear space in a [stony tract such as is called] HarRap, (S, K,) consisting of soft and clean soil with stones in it: (TA:) pl. SuHarN; (S, K;) the only pl. (TA.)
See also SaHorap.

SaHoraMCu, imperfectly decl., (S, K,) though not an epithet; (S;) or it is an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates; (TA;) and is imperfectly decl. because it is of the fem. gender, (S,) and because the letter characteristic of the fem. gender [namely the long A] is inseparable from it, (S, K,) A desert; a waste; syn. barRiyRapN: (S, Msb:) or a tract of land like the back of a beast, bare, or destitute of herbage, without trees and without hills and without mountains; smooth [throughout]: (ISh:) or a plain, or level tract of land, with smoothness and ruggedness, (A, K,) less [rugged] than what is termed qufR: (K:) or a spacious tract of ground in which is no herbage: (M, A, K:) or the most plain and even of land, whether it have produced herbage or not, not having any mountain or hill near it; as also jahaAdN: (ISh, TA in art. jhd:) you say SaHoraMCu waAsiEapN [a wide desert &c.]; (S;) but you do not say SaHoraMCapN, adding one fem. sign after another: (S, Msb:) the pls. are SaHaAriIRu (S, Msb, K) and SaHaArK (S, M, Msb) [in the K, SaHaAriI, which, without the art. Al, and except when it is prefixed to another noun, and in a case of pausing, is a manifest mistake, as is shown in every complete treatise on inflection,] and SaHaAraI (S, Msb, K) and SaHoraAwaAtN: (S, K:) the first of which four pls. occurs in poetry, and is the original form of the second: for when you form the pl. of SaHoraMCu, [which is originally SaHoraAA,] you introduce an A between the H and the r, and give kesr to the r as in all similar cases: then the first A which is after the r [in SHrAA] is changed into I, because of the kesreh preceding it; and the second A, which is the characteristic of the fem. gender, is also changed into I, and incorporated into the former: then they reject the first I, and change the second into A, [though still writing it I,] and say SaHaAraI, with fet-h to the r, that the A may not be elided in the case of tenween, [which the word would have if the r were with kesr]; and this they do to distinguish between the I that is changed from the A which is a characteristic of the fem. gender and the I that is changed from the A which is not a characteristic of the fem. gender as the A of maromFI when they say maraAmK: some of the Arabs, however, do not reject the first I [in SaHaAriIRu], but reject the second I, and say AlSRaHaAriI, with kesr to the r, and hecihi SaHaArK, like as you say jawaArK (S. [In the Ham, p. 54, SuHarN is mentioned as a pl. of SaHoraMCu; but I think it doubtful.])
SuHaArN The sweat of horses: (O, K:) or the fever of horses. (K.) [
See also 1.]
SaHuwrN: see OaSoHaru.
SaHiyrN A certain uttering of the voice of the ass, (A, K,) of a vehement kind, (A,) more vehement than the neighing of horses: an inf. n. (TA. [See 1.])

SaHiyrapN Milk into which heated stones are thrown, so that it boils, after which some clarified butter is poured upon it, and it is drunk; and sometimes some flour is sprinkled upon it, and then it is supped: or, accord. to Abu-l-Gheyth, it is called SaxiyrapN, from AlSRaxoru; like fahiyrapN, from Alfihoru: (S:) or fresh milk into which heated stones are thrown, or which is put in the cooking-pot and made to boil in it once, until it burns; and sometimes flour is put into it, and sometimes clarified butter: (TA:) or fresh milk which is made to boil, after which some clarified butter is poured upon it, (K,) and it is drunk: (TA:) or fresh milk which is heated until it burns: (A:) or pure milk of camels, or of sheep, or of goats, which, when they want soup, and have not flour, it not being found in their land, they cook, and then give to drink to a sick person, hot. (TA.)
vawobN SuHaAriIRN A kind of garment, so called in relation to SuHaAr, a town of El-Yemen: or, as some say, of the colour termed SuHorap, like OaSoHaru↓. (TA, from a trad.)
SuHayoraMCu A certain sort of milk: (K:) so says Kr, without particularizing it. (TA.)

OaSoHaru Of the colour termed SuHorap: (S, K:) or similar to OaSobaHN: (As:) a man of a red colour inclining to dust-colour: (TA:) or having a colour such as is termed Xuqorap upon his head: (As:) and an ass in which is a red colour: (S:) or of a dust-colour with redness: (A:) or in which is whiteness and redness; (TA;) and so SaHuwrN↓ applied to a she-ass; or this signifies wont to kick with her hind leg: (K, TA:) fem. SaHoraMCu: (S, TA:) and pl. SuHorN. (TA.) See also SuHaAriIRN.
AlOaSoHaru and AlmuSoHiru↓ The lion. (Sgh, K.)
AlmuSoHiru: see what next precedes.
muSaAHirN One who fights with his adversary in the desert (AlSRaHoraMC), and does not act deceitfully with him. (S.)

2. taSoHiyfN signifies (primarily, Msb) The making a mistake (S, O, Msb, K, TA) in a SaHiyfap, (S, O, K, TA,) by reason of the ambiguity, or dubiousness, of the letters: a postclassical term: (TA:) or the reading a thing in a manner at variance with what the writer intended, or at variance with the conventional usage thereof: (Mgh:) a secondary signification is the altering a word, or an expression, in such a manner that the meaning intended by the application [thereof] becomes altered: (Msb:) or it consists in the altering of a diacritical point [or points]; as in AlnfI for AlnqI, or vice versâ: (KT, after AltRaHoriyfu:) one says, SHRf AllRafoZa He altered the word, or expression, [in such a manner that the meaning intended by the application thereof became altered, or] so that it became dubious [to the reader]. (Msb.) [See also taHoriyf, in the first paragraph of art. Hrf.]

4. OuSoHifa It had SuHuf [i. e. written pieces of
paper or of skin] (S, O, K, TA) collected in it, (S, O,) or put in it (K, TA) between two boards. (TA.)

5. tSHRf, said of a word, or an expression, It became altered [so as to have a meaning different from that intended by the application thereof, (see 2,) or] so as to be dubious. (Msb.) One says, tSHRf Ealayohi lafoZu kacaA [Such a word, or such an expression, became altered so as to be dubious to him]. (O, K. *)

SaHofapN [A sort of bowl;] a vessel like the qaSoEapN, (S, ISd, O, Msb, K, * TA,) expanded, wide, (ISd, TA,) or a large, expanded qaSoEap, (Mgh,) or, accord. to Z, an oblong qaSoEap, (Msb,) that satisfies the hunger of five [men] (Ks, S, ISd, Mgh, O, TA) and the like of them: (ISd, TA:) Ks says, (S, O,) the largest sort of qaSoEap is the jafonap; next to which is the qaSoEap [properly so called], (S, O, K,) which satisfies the hunger of ten [men]; (S, O;) then, the SaHofap, (S, O, K,) which satisfies the hunger of five; (S, O;) then, the miYokalap, (S, O, K,) which satisfies two men, and three; (S, O;) and then, the SuHayofap↓, (S, O, K,) which satisfies one man: (S, O:) the pl. of SaHofapN is SiHaAfN. (S, O, Mgh, Msb.) It is said in a prov., Aisotaforaga fulaAnN maA fiI SaHofatihi Such a one chose for himself, as his share, [or exhausted, all of] what was in his SHfp. (TA.)

SaHafiIRN One who makes mistakes in reading the SaHiyfap [or writing, or written piece of paper or of skin]; incorrectly termed by the vulgar SuHufiIRN, with two dammehs; (O, K;) [for the formation of a rel. n. from a pl. of this kind (i. e. from SuHufN) is not allowable,] though the pl. is not restored to the sing. in forming the rel. n. in the case of proper names, such as OanomaAriIRN &c., nor in the case of words that are used in a manner like that of proper names, such as OanoSaAriIN &c.: (O:) or a learner, or one who acquires knowledge, (Mgh, Msb,) from the SaHiyfap, (Mgh,) inferior [in rank] to the maXaAyixi [pl. of XayoxN]: (Msb:) a rel. n. from SaHiyfapN; (Mgh, Msb;) like HanafiIRN and bajaliIRN from Haniyfapu and bajiylapu: (Msb:) and muSaHRifN↓ signifies the same as SaHafiIRN [in the former of these senses]. (TA.)
SiHaAfN Small places that are made for water to collect and remain therein (manaAqiEu SigaArN tutRaxacu lilomaMCi): pl. SuHufN. (Esh-Sheybánee, O, K.)

SaHiyfN [appears from what here follows, to be syn. with SaHiyfapN↓, or rather it is a coll. gen. n. of which the latter is the n. un.:] (tropical:) The surface of the ground or earth; (O, K, TA;) as being likened to the thing [i. e. paper or skin] that is written upon. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph.

SaHiyfapN A written piece of paper (MA, Mgh, Msb) or of skin; (Msb;) a writing, or thing written; a book, or volume; a letter, i. e. an epistle; syn. kitaAbN; (S, O, K;) [syn. with kitaAbN in all of these senses; in the last of them in an anecdote related in Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 721-2, and in Har p. 119, q. v.;] and a [portion of a book, such as is termed] kurRaAsap; and a register; [for] in the UinoqaAE [a title of several books, it is said that] the kurRaAsap and muSoHaf↓ and SaHiyfap and kitaAb and dafotar are one: (MA:) pl. SuHufN (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and SuHofN, a contraction of the former, (TA,) and SaHaAYifu, (S, O, Msb, K,) like safaAYinu pl. of safiynapN; (Lth, O;) the first of these pls. anomalous, (Lth, Sb, O, K,) the sing. being likened to qaDiytN (Sb, O, TA) and qaliybN (Sb, TA) and ragiyfN, (O,) of which the pls. are quDubN (Sb, O, TA) and qulubN (Sb, TA) and rugufN: (O:) [or SaHiyfN may be its original, as well as regular, sing.:] see the next preceding paragraph. SuHufi Uiborehiyma wamuwsaI, in the Kur [lxxxvii. last verse], means [In the books of Abraham and Moses; i. e.] the books revealed to Abraham and Moses. (O.) [SaHiyfapN also means The record of the actions of anyone, that is kept in heaven: (see raqRN:) one says, SaHiyfanuhu sawodaMCu, meaning (assumed tropical:) The record of his actions is black; a phrase often used in the present day, in speaking of a bad man.] Mohammad [the Hanafee Imám] speaks of SuHuf not written upon; saying, faUino kaAnati AlsRariqapu SuHufFA layosa fiyhaA kitaAbN [And if the stolen property be papers, or books, not having any writing upon them]. (Mgh. [See, again, raqRN.])
SaHiyfapN signifies also A plank, board, or leaf, of a door; like SaHaAYifu [from which it is perhaps formed by transposition, or it may be tropical in this sense]: pl. SaHiyfN. (MA.)

Also (tropical:) The external skin, or scarf-skin, of the face: (O, TA:) or as some say, the part thereof that fronts one: pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] SaHiyfN↓; or this may be used, in a verse in which it occurs, for SaHiyfap. (TA.)
One says also SaHaAYifu mino XaHomK [meaning (assumed tropical:) Layers of fat]. (A in art. nyr.)
SuHayofapN: see SaHofapN.
SaHRaAfN [A bookseller;] a seller of SuHuf: or [a bookbinder;] a maker [meaning binder] of SuHuf. (TA.)
maSoHafN: see what next follows.

muSoHafN (Th, S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and miSoHafN↓ (Th, S, O, Msb, K) and maSoHafN↓; (Th, O, K;) the first of which is the original, (Fr, S, O, Msb,) being from OuSoHifa meaning as expl. above, and one of certain words that are pronounced by [some of] the Arabs with kesr to the m instead of damm because the latter is deemed by them difficult of utterance, of which words are also mixodaEN and miTorafN and migozalN and mijosadN, (Fr, S, O,) or, accord. to AZ, Temeem pronounce the m with kesr, and Keys pronounce it with damm, [as do most persons in the instance of mSHf in the present day,] and Th says that maSoHafN, with fet-h, is correct and chaste; (O;) [A book, or volume, consisting of] a collection of SuHuf, (S, Mgh, O, K, TA,) written upon, and put between two boards: (TA:) [generally applied in the present day to a copy of the Kur-án:] and also signifying a [portion of a book, such as is termed] kurRaAsap: but the former is the primary [and more common] signification: (Mgh:) pl. maSaAHifu. (KL.) See also SaHiyfapN.
miSoHafN: see the next preceding paragraph.
muSaHRifN: see SaHafiIRN.

1. SaHila, aor.
SaHala
, inf. n. SaHalN, He was, or became, hoarse, rough, harsh, or gruff, in voice; said of a man: (S, O:) [and] SaHila Sawotuhu, aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) His voice was, or became, hoarse, rough, harsh, or gruff: or sharp, together with hoarseness, roughness, &c.: or SaHalN signifies a roughness, (xuXuwnapN, K,) or a rattling, (HaXorajapN, Lh, TA,) in the chest: and a cracking in the voice, without a right tenour thereof: (Lh, K, TA:) one says, fiI Sawotihi SaHalN In his voice is a hoarseness [&c.]: (S, O:) and SaHila Haloquhu His fauces became hoarse [&c.]: (IB, TA:) but accord. to IAth and others, it is not Arabic [in origin]. (TA.) See also SahalN.
SaHolN [app. a mistake for SaHalN]: see SaHalN.
SaHilN, (K,) or SaHilu AlSRawoti, (S, O,) Hoarse, rough, harsh, or gruff, [&c.,] in voice; as also OaSoHalu↓. (S, O, K.) And SawotN SaHilN [A voice that is hoarse, &c.]. (TA, from a trad.)
OaSoHalu: see the next preceding paragraph.
8. ASTHm i. q. ASTxm, q. v.

11. ASoHaAmRa, (K,) inf. n. AiSoHiymaAmN, (TA,) said of a plant, or herbage, It became intensely green: and it became yellow, (K, TA,) and altered in colour; or, as J says, [in the S,] ASHAmRt Albaqolapu the herb, or leguminous plant, became yellow: (TA:) thus it has two contr. meanings: or it (i. e. a plant, or herbage,) became intermixed with yellowness in its dark greenness. (AHn, K.) And ASHAmRt AlOaroDu The land became altered [for the worse] in its herbage, and its rain departed: (K:) or, as some say, the land became altered in the colour of its seed-produce, for the reaping: and in like manner, ASHAmR AlHabRN the grain became thus altered. (TA.) And ASHAmR AlzRaroEu The seed-produce was smitten by cold: or began to dry up. (K.)
SuHomapN Blackness inclining to yellowness: or a dust-colour inclining a little to blackness: or redness in whiteness: (K:) or, as some say, yellowness in whiteness. (TA.)

OaSoHamu Of the colour termed SuHomapN: (K:) i. e. black inclining to yellowness: (S, K:) &c.: (K:) or, accord. to AA, intensely black: (TA:) fem.
SaHomaMCu. (K.)
The latter, applied to a fayofaMC [or smooth, or waterless, desert], (Sh, K,) or to a balodap [or district, &c.], (S,) signifies Dusty. (Sh, S, K.)
