And (tropical:) The hair that hangs down upon the place above-mentioned. (S, O, Msb, K.) One says SudogN muEaqorabN (tropical:) [A curled lock of hair hanging down upon the temple]. (S, O, TA.)
SadagN Crookedness, and bending, or inclining. (TA. [See 1, near the end.])
SudugN: see SudogN.
SadaAgN A mark made with a hot iron upon the Sudog [or temple, of a camel], (S, O, K, TA,) or, as in the A, upon the even part of the Sudog, lengthwise. (TA.)

SadiygN an epithet applied to a child (S, K) In the stage extending to his completion of seven days: (S:) or that is seven days old: (Mgh, O, K:) because his temple becomes firm (yaXotadRu Sudoguhu) only to this period, (so in the O, [and the like is said in the Mgh,]) or because his temples are not bound (laA yuXadRu SudogaAhu) save for seven days: (so in the TA:) or it may be an instance of faEiylN in the sense of mafoEuwlN from Sadagahu Eani AlXRaIoCi meaning “ he turned him away, or back, from the thing. ” (O.)
And [hence, perhaps,] Weak. (S, O, K.)

AlOaSodagaAni [The two temporal arteries;] two veins beneath the SudogaAni [or two temples], (O, K,) which, as is said by As, are always pulsing, in everyone in the world: a word having no sing., like as they say of AlmicorawaAni. (O.)
miSodagN: see what next follows.

miSodagapN A pillow, or cushion; (S, O, K;) because placed beneath the Sudog [or temple]; also pronounced misodagapN; and sometimes they said mizodagapN; (S, O;) and [miSodagN↓ and] misodagN and mizodagN signify the same. (TA in art. sdg.)
maSodRagN, and its fem.: see what follows.
maSoduwgN, A camel marked with the mark termed SidaAg; as also muSadRagN↓: (K, * TA:) or the former is applied in this sense to a camel, and muSadRagapN↓ in like manner to camels. (ISh, O, TA.)

1. Sadafa EanRiI, (S, O,) or Eanohu, (Msb, K,) aor.
Sadifa
, (O, K,) He turned away from, avoided, shunned, and left, (S, O, Msb, K,) me, (S, O,) or him, or it; (Msb, K;) so the verb signifies in the Kur vi. 158 [and a similar instance occurs in verse 46 of the same chap.]; (O;) and so Eanohu tSdRf↓: (O, * K:) and (so in the K [but more properly “ or ”]) Sadafa, (A'Obeyd, M, O, K,) aor.
Sadifa
(M, K) and
Sadufa
, (K,) inf. n. SadofN and SuduwfN, (M, O, K, TA, [SadafFA in the CK is a mistake,]) he turned away, (A'Obeyd, M, O, K, TA,) or became turned away, or back, (O, K, TA,) and declined, (K, TA,) Eanohu from it, (M, O,) namely, a thing; (O;) said of a man. (K.) And Sadafato, said of a woman, She turned away her face. (Msb.)
See also 4.

SadafN is an inf. n. (S, M, O, Msb) of which the verb is Sadifa, (M, Msb,) and from which is derived the epithet OaSodafu↓ applied to a horse, or to a camel: (S, M, O:) it signifies, in relation to a horse, The having the thighs near together, and the hoofs far apart, with a twisting of the pasterns (S, O, K:) or a crookedness in the fore legs: (M:) or an inclining in the hoof towards the off side: (ISk, S, M, Mgh, O, K:) or an inclining of the foot (As, S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K) of the fore leg or of the kind leg (As, S, M, O, Msb) of the camel, towards the off side; (As, S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) if towards the near side, the epithet applied to him is Oaqofadu, (As, S, O, K,) and the verb is qafida, inf. n. qafadN: (TA:) or an inclining in the qadam [or human foot]; As says, I know not whether from the right or from the left: or an approaching of one of the knees towards the other; thus, peculiarly, in the horse: or a nearness together of [the two tendons called] the EujaAyataAni, and a wideness apart of the hoofs, with a twisting of the pasterns; one of the natural faults of horses: (M:) (Mtr says,] as meaning a twisting in the neck, I have not found it. (Mgh.)

3. SAdfhu, (S, O, K, TA,) inf. n. muSaAdafapN, (M, TA,) He found him; or lighted on him; syn. wajadahu; (S, O, K, TA;) namely, another man; (S, O;) and laqiyahu [which may also be rendered he met with him; or encountered him]; (O, K, TA;) and waAfaqahu [which signifies the same]. (M, * TA, and S and K in art. wfq.) One says, SaAdafotu fulaAnFA bimawoDiEi kacaA I found, or met with, such a one in such a place; syn. waAfaqotuhu. (TA in art. wfq.) And SaAdafota Oamoraka muwaAfiqFA liUiraAdatika [Thou foundest thine affair, or thy case, suitable to thy wish; i. e., foundest it to be so: thus, in this instance, and in many others, like its syns. wajadota and laqiyta, the verb has two objective complements]. (S * and K * and TA in art. wfq.)
And muSaAdafapN signifies also The being opposite, one to another; or the facing one another; or the matching one another; syn. muHaAcaApN. (TA.)

4. ASdfhu He, or it, turned him away, (S, M, O, K,) or back; or caused him to return, go back, or revert; (K, TA;) Eanohu from it; (M;) and Sadafahu↓, (O, K,) inf. n. SadofN, (O,) signifies the same; (O, K;) the latter verb being trans. as well as intrans., but when trans. having only one inf. n., that mentioned above. (O.) One says, OaSodafaniI Eanohu kacaA wakacaA Such and such things turned me away from it. (S, O.)
5. tSdRf: see 1, first sentence.
Also I. q. taEarRaDa: (TA:) in the saying of Muleyh ElHudhalee,

[app. describing a she-camel, or a number of camels, meaning And when her, or their, burdens were, or became, adjusted, or firm or steady, and she, or they, went alternately to the right and left, (see the phrase taEarRaDati AlUibilu AlmadaArija, in art. ErD,) in the high places of ascent, cold in the
entrances thereof, because of their height], Skr says, taSadRafato means taEarRaDato. (M, TA.)
6. taSaAdafaA, said of two sides of a mountain, They met together, and faced each other. (TA.)
SadafN inf. n. of Sadifa [q. v.]. (M, Msb.)

Also Anything high, or lofty, (As, S, M, O, K,) such as a wall and a mountain, (M,) or such as a wall and the like; (K;) like what is termed hadafN: (As, S, O:) and the side of a mountain: (M:) or SadafN and hadafN both signify any building or structure, that is high, or lofty, and great; (A'Obeyd, TA;) accord. to Az, likened to the Sadaf of a mountain, which is the side that faces one, thereof: (TA:) and SadafN and SudufN↓ (S, M, O, K) and SudafN↓ and SadufN↓, (O, K,) accord. to different readings of a passage in the Kur, (S, M, O, K,) [xviii. 95,] in which the dual occurs, (S, M, O,) signify the place of ending, or breaking off, (S, O, K,) of a mountain, (K,) or of a lofty mountain: (S, O:) or the side of a mountain: (K:) or the part between two mountains: (M:) or, as used in this instance, (K, TA,) in the verse of the Kur, (TA,) AlSRadafaAni, (M, K,) as also AlSRudufaAni↓, (M,) means two mountains (M, L, K) meeting together, (M, L, TA,) in the copies of the K, mutalaAziqaAni [i. e. cleaving together], but the correct reading is mutalaAqiyaAni, as in the L [and M], (TA,) between Ya-jooj and Ma-jooj: (M, L, K, TA:) and AlSRudufaAni↓, (M, K,) with damm to the d (M,) i. e. with two dammehs, especially, (K,) or this as well as AlSRadafaAni, (TA,) means the two sides of the XiEob [app. here meaning ravine, or gap, between two mountains], or of the valley: (M, K, TA:) so says IDrd: (M, TA:) both signify the two sides of the mountain when they [meet together, and] face each other, so called litaSaAdufihimaA, i. e. because of their meeting together, and facing each other, having between them a [road such as is termed] fajR, or a XiEob [expl. above], or a valley. (TA.)

Also [The mother-of-pearl shell; or oyster-shell; and any shell of a mollusk: and, by an extension of its primary application, the oyster itself; and any shell-fish, or testaceous mollusk of the water, and likewise of the land:] the cover of the pearl; (K;) or this is called Sadafu AldRurRapi, (S, O,) or Sadafu AldRurRi; (Msb;) a kind of cover created in the sea, composed of [what are termed] SadafataAni [i. e. a pair of shell-valves], which are opened from [i. e. so as to disclose] a kind of flesh in which is life, called the maHaArap [i. e. oyster], and in the like thereof are found pearls; (Lth, TA;) i. q. maHaArN [which means oyster-shells, and also oysters themselves, and both of these may be here meant, as both are correct meanings of SadafN]: (M:) n. un. with p: (S, M, O, Msb, K:) [in the Msb it is also said that AlSRadafapu signifies the maHaArap, which is the maHomil of the pilgrims; but I think that this is a mistake, caused by understanding maHaArap here in a wrong sense; for I find no other authority for assigning this meaning to AlSRadafapu:] pl. OaSodaAfN. (O, K.) [See an ex. of the pl. voce HalazuwnN.]
[Hence,] AlSRadafapu signifies also, (M, TA,) or Sadafapu AlOucuni, (O,) The maHaArap [or concha, i. e. the external, deep, and wide, cavity, around the hole,] of the ear. (M, O, TA.)

[And hence, also,] AlSRadafataAni signifies The two small hollows, or sockets, in each of which is set the head of one of the two thing-bones, and in each of which is a ligament (EaSabapN [app. that called ligamentum teres, forming a tie]) to that head. (M, TA.) [And in like manner, The two sockets in the scapula, in each of which turns the head of one of the two upper arm-bones: (see HaAriqapN:) or these, it seems, are called by some AlSRadafaAni; for it is said that] AlSRadafu signifies the part of the scapula which is the place of the waAbilap. (O, K.)
And SadafN also signifies (tropical:) Flesh, (O,) or a piece of flesh, (K, TA,) growing in a wound of the head, next the skull, resembling the cartilages. (O, K.)
And in the Tekmileh it is said that [the pl.] OaSodaAfN signifies Waves of the sea. (TA.)
See also SudafN.
SadufN: see SadafN, second sentence.
SudafN: see SadafN, second sentence.
Also, i. e. like SuradN, (O, K,) or SadafN↓, (so in a copy of the M,) A species of animal of prey: (M, O, K: *) or, as some say, a bird. (M, O, K.)
SudufN: see SadafN, in three places.

SadafiIRN A camel of a certain sort, (M, K, *) of excellent quality, (K,) [ISd says,] so called, (M, K,) I think, in relation to a tribe of Arabs of El-Yemen, (M,) or in relation to a sub-tribe (baTon) of Kindeh, (K,) called AlSRadifu. (M, K.) [See also SarafiIRN.]
[Also a rel. n. from SadafN; Testaceous.]

SaduwfN A woman who turns away her face (Lh, M, Msb) from her husband: (Lh, M:) or a woman who turns her face towards one and then turns away: (S, O, K:) or a woman who desires not kisses: (M:) or having a stinking mouth, (Lh, Ibn-'Abbád, M, O, K,) as an epithet applied to a female, (Lh, M,) or to a male: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) applied in this last sense to a man because he turns away his face whenever any one speaks to him. (TA.)
And A she-camel that will not come to the watering-trough until it is left to her unoccupied: like SaruwmN. (TA in art. Srm. [See also what next follows.])
SawaAdifu [pl. of SaAdifapN] Camels that come to others at the drinking-trough, and wait at their rumps until the drinkers have gone away, that they may go in. (S, O. [See also what next precedes.])
OaSodafu: see SadafN, in the first paragraph.
muSadRafN meaning One often attacked by diseases is a word used by the vulgar. (TA.)
maSoduwfN Veiled, or concealed; covered; or protected; syn. masotuwrN. (TA.)

1. Sadaqa, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) aor.
Saduqa
, (M, TA,) inf. n. SidoqN (S, * M, O, * Msb, K, TA) and SadoqN, (M, K,) the former of which is the more chaste, (TA,) or the latter is an inf. n. and the former is a simple subst., (K,) and taSodaAqN (M) and maSoduwqapN, (O, K, TA,) which is one of the [few] inf. ns. of the measure mafoEuwlapN, (O, TA,) [or a fem. pass. part. n. used as an inf. n. like as is said of its contr. makocuwbapN,] he spoke, said, uttered, or told, truth, or truly, or veraciously; contr. of kacaba: (Msb: [and in like manner it is said in the S and M and O and K that SidoqN is the contr. of kacibN:]) Er-Rághib says that SidoqN and kacibN are primarily in what is said, whether relating to the past or to the future, and [in the latter case] whether it be a promise or other than a promise; and only in what is said in the way of information: but sometimes they are in other modes of speech, such as asking a question, and commanding, and supplicating; as when one says, “ Is Zeyd in the house? ” for this implies information of his being ignorant of the state of Zeyd; and when one says, “ Make me to share with thee, or to be equal with thee, ” for this implies his requiring to be made to share with the other, or to be made equal with him; and when one says, “ Do not thou hurt me, ” for this implies that the other is hurting him: SidoqN, he says, is [by implication] the agreeing of what is said with what is conceived in the mind and with the thing told of, together; otherwise it is not complete Sidoq, but may be described either as Sidoq or sometimes as Sidoq and sometimes as kacib according to two different points of view; as when one says without believing it, “ Mohammad is the Apostle of God, ” for this may be termed Sidoq because what is told is such, and it may be termed kacib because it is at variance with what the speaker conceives in his mind. (TA.) One says, Sadaqa fiI AlHadiyvi [He spoke truth in the information, or narration]. (S, O, K.) And Sadaqahu i. e. He told him, or informed him, with truth, or veracity, (AHeyth, * M, Msb, *) fiI Alqawoli [in the saying]; for it is trans. as well as intrans. (Msb.) And Sadaqahu AlHadiyva (S, O, K, in the CK [erroneously] SadRaqa fulAnFA AlHadiyva) He told him with truth, or veracity, the information, or narration; for it is sometimes doubly trans. (TA.) And SadaqaniI sinRa bakorihi [He hath told me truly the age, or as to the age, of his youthful camel; or SadaqaniI sinRu bakorihi the age of his youthful camel has spoken truly to me]: (S, O, K:) a prov., (S, O,) expl. in art. bkr [q. v.]. (K.) And fulaAnN laA yaSoduqu Oavaruhu and Oavarahu, meaning Such a one, when asked, will not tell truly whence he comes. (M.) And Sadaqato yamiynuhu His oath was, or proved, true. (Msb in art. bt.) Sadaqotu QllReha HadiyvFA Uino lamo OafoEalo kacaA is an oath of the Arabs, meaning laA Sadaqotu Alx [May I not utter truly to God a saying, i. e. may I not speak truth to God, if I do not such a thing]. (AHeyth, O, K.) One says also, Sadaqahu AlnRaSiyHapa, and AlUixaMCa, He rendered to him truly, or sincerely, good advice, and brotherly affection. (M.) And Sada quwhumu AlqitaAla (S, M, K, * TA) [They gave them battle earnestly,
not with a false show of bravery; as is implied in the S, and M, and K; i. e.] they advanced against them boldly in fight: (M, TA:) and in like manner, SadaquwA fiI AlqitaAli they advanced boldly in fight: or, accord. to Er-Rághib, the former means they gave them battle so as to fulfil their duty: and hence, in the Kur [xxxiii. 23], rijaAlN SadaquwA maA EaAhaduwA QllReha Ealayohi, Men who fulfilled the covenant that they had made with God. (TA.) And Sadaqa AllRiqaMCa, inf. n. SidoqN, He was firm, or steady, in encounter, or conflict. (M, TA.) And Sadaqa ZanRiI My opinion was, or proved, true, or correct, like as one says [in the contrary case], kacaba: (Er-Rághib, TA:) whence, in the Kur [xxxiv. 19], walaqado Sadaqa Ealayohimo Uiboliysu ZanRahu, meaning fiI ZanRihi [i. e. And assuredly Iblees was, or proved to be, correct in his opinion that he had formed against them]: but some read SadRaqa↓, meaning, as Fr says, HaqRaqa [i. e. Iblees proved, or found, to be true, his opinion &c.]. (TA.) And Sadaqatohu nafosuhu His soul [told him truth; meaning,] diverted him, or hindered him, or held him back, from an undertaking, causing him to imagine himself unable to prosecute it. (TA in art. kcb.) And Sadaqa AlSRuboHu [The dawn shone clearly]. (S in art. sqT.) [And one says of a word or the like, yaSoduqu EalaI kacaA, meaning It applies correctly to such a thing.]
Sadaqa AlwaHoXiIRu: see 2, near the end.

2. SdRqhu, (S, M, O, &c.,) inf. n. taSodiyqN, contr. of kacRabahu. (O, * K.) [This explanation implies several meanings here following.] He attributed, or ascribed, to him truth, veracity, or the speaking truth. (Msb.) And He said to him, “ Thou hast spoken truth. ” (Msb.) He accepted, or admitted, [or assented to, or believed,] what he said: (M:) you say, SdRqhu fiI Hadiyvihi [He accepted, &c., what he said in his information, or narration]: (S:) and you say SdRq bilisaAnihi [He assented to the truth of what was said with his tongue]; as well as biqalobihi [with his heart, or mind]. (T in art. Aamn.) He held him to be a speaker of truth. (MA.) [He found him to be a speaker of truth. He, or it, proved him to be a speaker of truth; verified him; or confirmed the truth of what he said: see an ex. in a verse cited voce bayonN.] He found it (an opinion) to be true, or veritable. (Ksh and Bd and Jel, in xxxiv. 19.) He verified it; confirmed its truth; or proved it to be true, or veritable; i. e. an opinion [&c.]; syn. HaqRaqahu: (Ksh and Bd, ibid.:) one says, SadRaqa Alxabara Alxuboru [The trial, proof, or test, verified the information]. (S in art. xbr.) See 1, near the end. In the saying in the Kur [xxxix. 34], waQlRaciI jaMCa biAlSRidoqi waSadRaqa bihi, [which seems to be best rendered But he who hath brought the truth and he who hath accepted it as the truth, (see kacRaba biAlOamori,)] 'Alee the son of Aboo-Tálib is related to have said that by AlcI jMC bAlSdq is meant Mohammad; and by AlcI SdRq bh, Aboo-Bekr: or, as some say, Gabriel and Mohammad [are meant by the former and the latter respectively]: or by the former, Mohammad; and by the latter, [every one of] the believers: (M:) accord. to Er-Rághib, by wSdRq bh is meant and hath found, or proved, to be true (HaqRaqa) that which he hath brought by word, by that which he hath aimed at (bimaA taHarRaAhu) by deed. (TA.)
SdRq is also said to signify He said, “ This thing is the truth; ” like HaqRaqa. (TA in art. Hq.)
And this verb also denotes AlmubaAlagapu fiI AlSRidoqi: thus in the saying,
[My opinions respecting them were, or proved to be, very true or correct]. (Ksh, in xxxiv. 19.)
SdRq AlwaHoXiIRu, (O, K, TA,) or Sadaqa↓, (so in a copy of the M,) (tropical:) The wild animal ran without looking aside, when charged upon, or attacked: (M, O, K, TA:) mentioned by IDrd. (O, TA.)
SadRaqahumo He exacted from them the poor-rate. (TA. [See SadaqapN.])
See also 5.

3. SaAdaqotuhu, (M,) inf. n. muSaAdaqapN (S, M, O, K) and SidaAqN, (M, O, K,) the latter like kitaAbN, (TA, [in the CK erroneously written SadAq,]) I acted, or associated, with him as a friend, or as a true, or sincere, friend. (S, * M, O, * K. *) [See also 6.]

4. ASdq AlmaroOapa He named for the woman a SadaAq [or dowry]: (S, M, * O, K:) or he gave her her SadaAq: (M, * Msb:) or he appointed her, or assigned her, a SadaAq, on taking her as his wife: (TA:) and he married her, or took her as his wife, on the condition of his giving her a SadaAq. (Msb.) And sometimes this verb is doubly trans.; whence, in a trad., maA caA tuSodiquhaA faqaAla UizaAriI [It was said, “ What is it that thou meanest for her, or givest her, as her dowry? ” and he said, “ My waist-wrapper ”]. (Mgh.)

5. tSdRq Ealayohi He gave him (i. e. the poor, Mgh, Msb) what is termed Sadaqap, (M, Mgh, Msb,) meaning [an alms, or] what is given for the sake of God, (M,) or what is given with the desire of obtaining a recompense from God: (M, * Mgh:) and Elyh SadRaqa↓ signifies the same; (M, TA;) and in this sense SdRq is [said by some to be] used in the Kur lxxv. 31. (TA.) Hence, in the Kur [xii. 88], wataSadRaqo EalayonaA: (TA:) or this means (assumed tropical:) And do thou confer a favour upon us by giving that which is [not like the mean merchandise that we have brought, but of middling quality,] between good and bad. (M.) One says, taSadRaqotu bikacaA, meaning I gave such a thing as a Sadaqap. (Msb.) See an ex. voce XiqRN. The saying, in a trad., UinRa QllReha taSadRaqa Ealayokumo bivuluvi OamowaAlikumo, meaning (tropical:) [Verily God] hath conferred a favour [upon you by giving you a third of your possessions to bequeath to whom ye will], if correct, is tropical. (Mgh.)

It is said by Ibn-Es-Seed, on the authority of AZ and IJ, and mentioned by IAmb, that tSdRq signifies also He asked, or begged, for what is termed Sadaqap [or alms]: but Fr and As and others disallow the beggar's being called mutaSadRiq: (Az, TA:) IKt says that the verb is improperly used in this sense by the vulgar: (Msb:) [and accord. to J and Sgh,] one says, mararotu birajulK yasoOalu, and one should not say yataSadRaqu. (S, O.)

6. taSaAduqN signifies The acting, or associating, as friends, or as true, or sincere, friends, one with another. (K. [See also 3.]) And I. q. SidoqN: (TA:) [or rather mutual Sidoq; contr. of takaAcubN:] one says, taSaAdaqaA fiI AlHadiyvi and fiI AlmawadRapi (S, O, TA) They were true, or sincere, each to the other, in information, or narration, and in love, or affection; contr. of takaAcabaA. (O, TA.)
SadoqN is an inf. n. of Sadaqa [q. v.]: (M, K:)

and is used as an epithet, applied to a man &c.: (S, M, O, K, TA:) [and] SidoqN↓ [also, if not a mistranscription for SadoqN,] is an inf. n. used as an epithet, applied to a man and to a woman: (so in a copy of the M and in the TA:) [it is said that] the former signifies Hard, (S, M, O, Msb,) applied to a spear, (S, M, O,) and to other things: (M:) or even, or straight; (S, O;) or it signifies thus also, applied to a spear, and to a sword: (M:) or hard and even or straight, applied to a spear, (K, TA,) and to a man, (K,) or to the latter as meaning hard: or, as IB says, on the authority of IDrst, it is not from hardness, but means combining those qualities that are commended; and it is applied to a spear as meaning long and pliant and hard, and the like; and to a man, and to a woman likewise [without p, but see what follows], as meaning true in hardness and strength and goodness; for, IDrst says, if it meant hard, one would say HajarN SadoqN and HadiydN SadoqN, which one does not: (TA:) and, applied to anything, (O, K, TA,) it means complete, or perfect, (Kh, O, K, TA,) thus applied to a man, (TA,) such as is commended; (O;) fem. with p, (O, K, TA,) applied to a woman: (O:) the pl. is SudoqN, applied to a company of men, (S, O, K,) and SuduqN (K) and Sadoquwna, so applied, and SadoqaAtN applied to women: (O, K:) and Ru-beh says, describing asses,

meaning [Rounded, as though pared, in the ears,] penetrating in the eyes; (O, TA;) which is [said to be] tropical. (TA.) SadoqN signifies also Firm, or steady, in encounter, or conflict: (M:) or one says Sadoqu AllRiqaMCi, applying this epithet to a man, (S, O, K, TA,) meaning thus: (TA:) and Sadoqu AlnRaZari [firm, or steady, in look]. (S, O, K, TA. [Said in the TA to be tropical.])

SidoqN is an inf. n. of Sadaqa [q. v.]: (M, K, &c.:) or a simple subst., (K,) signifying [Truth; veracity; or] agreement of what is said with what is conceived in the mind and with the thing told of, together; otherwise it is not complete Sidoq, as expl. above in the first paragraph of this art. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

It is also syn. with XidRapN [meaning Hardness; firmness, compactness, or soundness; strength, power, or force; vigour, robustness, sturdiness, or hardiness; and courage, bravery, or firmness of heart]: (K, TA: [in the latter of which it is said to be tropical; but this is
evidently not the case accord. to the O, in which it is said that it radically denotes quwRapN (i. e. strength, force, &c.,) in a saying &c.: in the K it is implied by the context that it is syn. with XidRap when used as the complement of a prefixed n. in instances mentioned in what here follows: but Sgh says, more correctly,]) a noun signifying anything to which goodness is attributed is prefixed to Sidoq, governing it in the gen. case; so that one says (O) rajulu SidoqK (Sb, M, O, K) [A man of good nature or disposition or character &c.], contr. of rajulu sawoCK; (Sb, M;) and Sadiyqu SidoqK [a friend of good nature &c.]; (O, K;) and likewise AimoraOapu SidoqK [a woman of good nature &c.]; (K;) and in like manner also HimaAru SidoqK [an ass of a good kind]; (Sb, M, K;) and vawobu SidoqK [a garment, or piece of cloth, of good quality]. (Sb, M.) The saying in the Kur [x. 93], (O,) walaqado bawRaOonaA baniI AisoraAYiyla mubawRaOa SidoqK means And verily we assigned to the Children of Israel a good place of abode. (O, K.)
See also SadoqN.
SadoqapN: see SadaAqN; each in two places.
SudoqapN: see SadaAqN; each in two places.

SadaqapN [An alms; i. e.] a gift (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K) to the poor (S, O, Msb) for the sake of God, (M, K,) or to obtain a recompense from God; (M, * Mgh, K; *) a portion which a man gives forth from his property by way of propitiation, [to obtain the favour of God,] like zakaApN, except that the former is primarily applied to such as as is supererogatory, and the latter to such as is obligatory: but it is said to be applied to such as is obligatory [i. e. to the zakaAp, q. v., meaning the poor-rate, which is the portion, or amount, of property, that is given therefrom, as the due of God, by its possessor, to the poor, according to a fixed rate,] when the person who does so aims at conformity with the truth in his deed: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [in this latter sense, which is indicated in the S and O &c., and more plainly in the M, it is very frequently used:] and thus it is used in the Kur ix. 104, and in like manner its pl. in ix. 60: (Er-Rághib, TA:) the pl. is SadaqaAtN. (S, M, O, Msb.) It is said in a trad., laA Sadaqapa fiI AlUibili AljaArRapi [There is no poorrate in the case of working camels], because they are the riding-camels of the people; for the poorrate is in the case of pasturing camels, exclusively of the working. (S in art. jr.)
See also SadaAqN.
SaduqapN: see SadaAqN, in two places.
SuduqapN: see the next paragraph.

SadaAqN and SidaAqN↓, (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) the former of which is the most common of the dial. vars. here mentioned, (Msb,) [but] the latter is [said to be] more chaste than the former, (Mgh,) and SaduqapN↓, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) of the dial. of El-Hijáz, (Msb,) and SudoqapN↓, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) of the dial. of Temeem, (Msb,) and SadoqapN↓ (M, O, Msb, K) and SuduqapN↓ (M, O, K) and SadaqapN↓, (M, K,) The mahor (S, M, Mgh, O, K) of a woman; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) [i. e. a dowry; nuptial gift; or gift that is given to, or for, a bride:] the pl. of SdAq is SuduqN, (M, Mgh, Msb,) a pl. of mult., (M,) or SudoqN, (O,) or both, (K,) and OaSodiqapN, a pl. of pauc., (M,) or this is accordant to analogy, but has not been heard; (Mgh;) the pl. of SaduqapN↓ is SaduqaAtN; (S, Msb, K;) the pl. of SudoqapN↓ is SudoqaAtN and SudaqaAtN and SuduqaAtN, (O, * Msb, K,) which last is the worst; (K;) and the pl. of SadoqapN↓ is SudaqN, (Msb,) or SadoqaAtN [by rule SadaqaAtN]. (O.)
SidaAqN: see the next preceding paragraph.

SaduwqN Having the quality of speaking, saying, uttering, or telling, truth, or truly, or veraciously, in a high, or an eminent, degree; very, or eminently, true or veracious: (Msb:) pl. SuduqN and SudoqN. (K.) See also OaSodaqu.

SadiyqN A friend: (O, K:) or a true, or sincere, friend: (S, M, Msb, TA:) applied likewise to a female, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) as also SadiyqapN, (S, M, Msb, K,) the former anomalous, the latter regular; (MF;) and to a pl. number, (S, M, O, K,) as in the Kur xxvi. 101 (M) [and in several other instances, of which see one in a verse cited voce rawiIRN]: its proper pl. is OaSodiqaMCu (S, M, O, K) and SudaqaMCu and SudoqaAnN, (M, K,) the last on the authority of Fr, (TA,) and OaSaAdiqu, (M, O, K,) which is a pl. pl., (K,) said by IDrd to be anomalous, unless it be a pl. pl.: (O:) and the dim. is SudayRiqN↓; one says, huwa SudayRiqiI, meaning He is the most special, or most distinguished, of my friends, or of my true, or sincere, friends. (S, O, K.)

SadaAqapN Love, or affection: (K:) or truth, or sincerity, of love or affection: (TA:) or friendship, or friendliness; (S, M;) or true, or sincere, friendship or friendliness: (S, M, Msb:) or true firmness of heart in love or affection; an attribute of a human being only. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
SudayRiqN dim. of SadiyqN, q. v. (S, O, K.)

SidRiyqN One who speaks, says, utters, or tells, truth, or truly, or veraciously, much, or often: (Mgh, O, K:) [or rather having the quality of speaking, saying, uttering, or telling, truth, or truly, or veraciously, in a very high, or very eminent, degree; for] it has a more intensive signification than SaduwqN [q. v.]: (TA:) or i. q. muSadRiqN [which may have the latter of the two meanings expl. above, or may mean one who accepts, or admits, the truth of what is said, or who verifies, &c.: or muSadRiq in a high, or an eminent, degree; for it is added that] the fem. as used in the Kur v. 79 means superlative in AlSRidoq and AltRaSodiyq; as a possessive epithet, i. e. caAtu taSodiyqK: (M:) or it signifies daAYimu AltRaSodiyqi [i. e. always muSadRiq in one or another or all of the senses assigned to this word above: it may be correctly rendered eminently, or always, veracious: and eminently, or always, accepting, or confirming, the truth]: and it may mean one who verifies his saying by deed, or act: (S:) it is said in the “ Mufradát ” [of Er-Rághib] that it has the first of the meanings expl. in this paragraph: or rather means, one who never lies: or rather, one by whom lying cannot be practised because of his habitual veracity: or rather, one who is true in his saying and his belief, and who confirms his truth by his deed, or acting. (TA.)
SaAdiqN Speaking, saying, uttering, or telling, truth, or truly, or veraciously; true in respect of speech &c., or veracious. (Msb, TA.)
SidoqN SaAdiqN is a phrase like XiEorN XaAEirN, meaning Eminent, and exalted, veracity. (M, TA. *)

And HamolapN SaAdiqapN [A charge, or an assault, made with earnestness, not with a false show of bravery,] is like the saying [in the contr. case] HamolapN kaAcibapN. (M, TA: * said in the latter to be tropical.) See also maSodaq, in two places.
One says also tamorN SaAdiqu AlHalaAwapi, meaning Very sweet dates. (IDrd, O.)
And barodN SaAdiqN Vehement, or intense, cold. (TA voce baHotN &c.)

AlSRayodaqu The small star cleaving to the middle one of [those called] banaAtu naEoXK AlkuboraI [which compose the tail of Ursa Major]; (Kr, M, TA;) [i. e. the star called AlsRuhaA, q. v.; for] it is said that the first of bnAt nEX AlkbrI, that is at the extremity thereof, is named AlqaAYidu; and the second is AlEanaAqu, and by the side of it is a small star named AlsRuhaA and AlSRayodaqu; and the third is AlHawaru: (O:) or, accord. to AA, (O, TA,) the pole-star (AlquTobu). (O, K, TA. [But this is strange; and the more so as it is added in the K that it is expl. in art. qwd; for the explanation in that art. (though not free from obvious mistakes) identifies AlSRayodaqu with AlsRuhaA.])

And, (K,) accord. to Sh, (O, TA,) it signifies AlOamiynu [The trusted, trusted in, or confided in, &c.]. (O, K. [But it is added in the O that Sh cites a verse of Umeiyeh Ibn-Abi- s-Salt in which AlOamiynu is applied as an epithet to the star called AlSaydq.])
And, (K,) accord. to some, as AA says, (O,) it signifies The king. (O, K.)
faEalahu fiI gibRi SaAdiqapK [in the CK faEalahu gibRa SAdiqapK] means He did it after the affair, or case, had become manifest to him. (IDrd, O, K, TA.)
SunoduwqN, mentioned in this art. in the S and Msb: see art. Sndq.

OaSodaqu [More, and most, true or veracious]. One says OaSodaqu mino qaTaApK [More veracious than a katáh]; because the bird thus called cries qaTaA qaTaA; [thus telling where it is to be found;] its name being imitative of its cry: (Meyd, and TA in art. qTw:) hence it is called by the Arabs AlSRaduwqu↓: the saying is a prov. (Meyd.)

cuw maSodaqK, (JK, S, M, O,) with fet-h, (S,) or cuw miSodaqK↓ like minobar, (K,) applied to a man, (JK, M,) [i. e.] applied to a courageous man, (S, O, K,) means AlHamolapi SaAdiqu↓ [Earnest, not
making a false show of bravery, in the charge, or assault]; (JK, S, M, O, K;) or courageous [in the charge, or assault]: (JK:) maSaAdiqu, occurring in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, may be for cawuw maSaAdiqa; or it may be an anomalous pl. of SidoqN [used as an epithet], like malaAmiHu and maXaAbihu [pls. of lamoHapN and XabahN]. (M.) Also, (S, M, O, K,) applied to a horse, (M,) [i. e.] applied to a fleet and excellent horse, (S, O,) in like manner, (M,) meaning AljaroIi SaAdiqu↓ [Earnest in running]; (S, O, K;) as though fulfilling his promise of running: (S, O: [said in the TA to be tropical:]) Khufáf Ibn-Nudbeh says,

L.foreign: UicaA maA QsotaHamRato OaroDuhu mino samaAYihi

sense.s: meaning When his hoofs are wetted with the sweat of his upper parts, he runs, being left to himself, not beaten nor chidden, and a fulfiller of his promise to do his utmost. (S, O.) And sometimes it is applied to an opinion, in like manner [as meaning True, or sincere]. (M.)
maSodaqN also signifies Hardness. (Th, M.)

Also i. q. HadRN [as meaning The edge of a sword]: (TA:) [in a copy of the M written jidR, which I think an evident mistake; for it is added,] and it is said to have this meaning in a verse of Dureyd Ibn-Es- Simmeh [relating to a sword]. (M, TA.)
miSodaq: see the next preceding paragraph.
muSadRaqN A man from whom the poor-rate (Sadaqap) of his cattle is exacted. (TA.)
muSadRiqN One who accepts, admits, assents to, or believes, another in his information, or narration. (S, TA.)

Also The exactor, or collector, (S, M, O, Msb, K, TA,) of the SadaqaAt, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) i. e. (TA) of the Huquwq [or dues, meaning poor-rates], (M, TA,) of the cattle, (Msb,) or of the sheep or goats, (S, M, O, TA,) and of the camels, (M, O, TA,) for the persons to whom pertain the shares [thereof]. (TA.)
muSRadRiqN: see mutaSadRiqN.

miSodaAqN A thing that confirms, or proves, the truth of a thing: (S, K:) [and] a verbal evidence of the truth, or veracity, of a man. (Har p. 106.) One says, hecaA miSodaAqu hecaA This is what confirms, or proves, the truth of this. (S.) And XaIoCN layosa lahu miSodaAqN [A thing having nothing to verify it]. (IAar, TA in art. brq.)

maSoduwqapN [see 1, near the beginning]. One says layosa liHamolatihi maSoduwqapN [meaning There is no earnestness attributable to his charge, or assault]; like as one says [in the contr. case], lys lahaA makocuwbapN. (M.)

mutaSadRiqN One who gives what is termed Sadaqap [meaning alms]: (S, O, Msb, K:) accord. to Kh, it means thus, and also one who asks [alms]; (O, TA;) and IAmb says the like; but Az says that the skilful of the grammarians disallow this; and thus say Fr and As and others: (TA:) [J, also, and Sgh and Fei, say that] it has only the former meaning: (S, O, Msb:) it is also pronounced muSRadRiqN↓, by substitution [of S for t] and incorporation [of one S into the other]; (S, * O, * Msb, K; *) and this pronunciation of the pl. both masc. and fem. occurs in the Kur lvii. 17, (S, O, K,) where Ibn-Ketheer and Aboo-Bekr, differing from others, read without teshdeed to the S. (O.)

SayodalN Stones [i. e. pieces of ore] of silver: mentioned by IB on the authority of IDrst: and he says that HijaArapu AlEaqaAqiyri [meaning drugs resembling pieces of stone, such as pieces of gum &c.,] are likened thereto. (TA.)
SayodalapN [The trade of the SayodalaAniIR;] the sale of EiTaArap [i. e. drugs and perfumes]. (K, * TA.)

SayodalaAniIRN (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) a word of wellknown meaning: (M:) A seller of medicines (Mgh, Msb, TA) and of drugs (TA) and of perfumes: (K, TA:) a rel. n. from SayodalaAnu, the name of a town or place, (K,) or from SayodalN meaning as expl. above; (IB, TA;) or a Pers. word arabicized: (M:) and SayodanaAniIRN signifies the same, (S, Msb, K, [in the CK, erroneously, SanodanaAniIRN,]) and so SanodalaAniIRN: (K in this art., and O and K in art. Sndl:) the pl. of the first is SayaAdilapN. (M, Mgh, Msb, K.)
Also A king: and so SayodanaAniIRN. (M in art. Sdn.)

1. Sadamahu, (S, M, K,) aor.
Sadima
, (M, K,) inf. n. SadomN, (S, M, Mgh, K,) He dashed himself, i. e. his body, (S, Mgh, TA,) against him, (S, TA,) or against it, (S, Mgh, TA,) i. e., a thing: (Mgh:) or he struck it, or knocked it, [or struck or knocked against it,] namely, a hard thing with the like thereof. (M, K.) Hence the saying, Alkalobu UicaA qatala AlSRayoda SadomFA laA yuWokalu [i. e. When the dog kills the game by dashing himself against it, it shall not be eaten]. (Mgh.) [See also 3.]

And Sadamahu, aor. as above, (Msb,) and so the inf. n., (Mgh, Msb, K,) He pushed, thrust, or repelled, him, or it. (Mgh, Msb, K, TA.) One says, Sadamotu AlXRarRa biAlXRarRi [I repelled evil with evil]. (TA.)
And Sadamatohu HumayRaA AlkaOosi i. e. (tropical:) [The intoxicating influence of the cup of wine] smote him [or attacked him] in his head. (TA.)
And Sadamahumo OamorN, (M, TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (tropical:) An event befell them. (M, K, * TA.)
And Sadamahu biAlqawoli (assumed tropical:) He silenced him by speech. (Msb.)

3. SAdmhu, (S, K, TA,) inf. n. muSaAdamapN, (TA,) He, or it, dashed against him, or it, being dashed against by him, or it: (S, * PS:) or struck, or knocked, him, or it, being struck, or knocked, by him, or it: (K, * PS:) or pushed, thrust, or repelled, him, or it, being pushed, &c., by him, or it; (K, * TA;) syn. daAfaEahu: (TA, and Ham p. 313:) and i. q. saAkRahu [i. e. he struck him, or it; or struck him, or it, vehemently, with a broad thing, or with anything; or slapped him with his hand; being struck, &c., by him]: (Ham ibid.:) [but, like as daAfaEahu often signifies the same as dafaEahu, so accord. to Fei,] SaAdamahu AlHimaAru means Sadamahu [i. e. The ass dashed against him; &c.]. (Msb in art. Xtm.)

6. taSaAdamaA, (S, Mgh,) said of two men running, (Mgh,) and AiSoTadamaA↓, (S, Mgh, K, K,) said of two horsemen, (Mgh,) and of two stallion [camels], (TA,) They dashed themselves together, each against the other: (S, * TA, PS:) or they struck, or knocked, [against] each other; they collided; (K, * TA;) each of them struck with himself the other: (Mgh:) or both verbs, said of two horsemen, they smote each other, each of them with his weight and his sharpness or vigorousness or valiantness: (Msb:) [or they pushed, thrust, or repelled, each other: (see 1:)] and tSAdmwA they pushed, pressed, crowded, or thronged, together; or dashed, one against another; (M, K, TA; but in the M, only the inf. n. is mentioned;) like two ships in the sea. (TA.)
8: see the next preceding paragraph.
SidomN The rugged portion of a [stony tract such as is termed] HarRap; as also SidomapN↓. (ISh, TA.)

SadomapN A single shock, or collision: (KL:) a single impulsion, push, or thrust: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) a vehement befalling of an event. (KL.) It is said in a trad., AlSRaboru Einoda AlSRadomapi AlOuwlaI (S, Msb, TA) i. e. (assumed tropical:) [Patience is to be exercised] at the first [shock, or] assault, or attack, of the calamity: (TA:) meaning that patience is the last thing in the case of every misfortune, (S, Msb,) but it is [most] commended, (S,) or is most rewarded, (Msb,) on the occasion of the sharpness, or vehemence, thereof. (S, Msb.) And one says, Oatayotu EalaI AlOamorayoni SadomapF waAHidapF [I made an end of the two affairs at one dash, or at one stroke]. (TA.)
And A baldness in the side of the forehead; syn. nazoEapN. (K.)
See also AlSRadimataAni, in two places.
SidomapN: see SidomN.

AlSRadimataAni (AZ, S, M, K) and AlSRadomataAni↓ (K) The jabiynaAni [or two parts whereof each is termed jabiyn, above the temple, on either side of the forehead]: (K:) or the two sides (AZ, S, M, K) of the jabiyn (AZ, S, K) or of the jabiynaAni: (M:) or, accord. to AA, as is stated in a marginal note in a copy of the S, the correct meaning is the two sides of the forehead. (TA.)
And AlSdmtAn [i. e. AlSRadimataAni or AlSRadomataAni↓] signifies also The two sides of the valley: as though, by reason of their confronting, they struck each other. (TA.)
SudaAmN: see what next follows.

SidaAmN, (S, K,) or SudaAmN↓, (M,) asserted by Az to be with damm, (TA,) or the latter is vulgar, (S,) not allowable, (K,) though agreeable with analogy, (S, K,) being like SudaAEN and zukaAmN and duwaArN and other terms for diseases, (TA,) A
certain disease in the heads of horses or similar beasts: (S, M, K:) or, accord. to ISh, a certain disease that attacks camels, in consequence of which their bellies become affected with acidity, and they relinquish the water, though thirsty, for some days, until they recover or die. (TA.)
OaSodamu Bald in the sides of the forehead. (K.)
miSodamN A man vehement in war, and courageous; or a warrior; or known, experienced warrior; syn. miHorabN. (M.)
UibilN muSadRamapN: see what follows.
jamalN maSoduwmN A camel affected with [the disease termed] SidaAm: and UibilN muSadRamapN↓ [camels affected therewith]. (TA.)
SayodanN A firm, strong, or compact, building. (M.)
And A firm, strong, or compact, garment, or piece of cloth: (M:) or a [garment of the kind called] kisaMC that is stout, or strong, or that is thick, or compact, in texture. (K.)
And A king; (S, M, K;) because of the firmness of his rule, or his state, or condition; as also SayodanaAniIRN↓ and SayodalaAniIRN. (M.)
And A fox; (S, M, K;) as also SayodanaAniIRN↓: (K:) or AlSRayodanu is one of the names thereof. (TA.)
And The hyena. (K.)
See also SayodanaAniIRN.
Also A species of fly, that makes a buzzing sound over the herbage. (IKh, TA.)
And, as also SayodalN, Stones [i. e. pieces of ore] of silver: to which are likened what are termed HijaArapN AlEaqaAqiyri. (IDrst, TA. [See SayodalN; and see also SayodaAnN, below.])
SayodaAnN Pieces of silver, (M, TA,) when struck from the stone [or ore] thereof: (TA:) n. un. with p. (M, TA.) [See also SayodanN, above, last signification. And see SayodaAnN in art. Syd.]

And Stone cooking-pots: (M, TA:) in this sense [likewise] a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p. (IB and L in art. Syd, in which it is mentioned in the S and L and K.) [See, again, SayodaAnN, and also SayodaMCu, in art. Syd.]
And Small pebbles: (IAar, M, TA:) or so SayodaAnu AlHaSaI. (L in art. Syd.)
SayodaAnapN [as a n. un.: see SayodaAnN, above.
Also] Rugged, hard ground, in which is fine stone. (M, TA.)
See also two other significations (mentioned here in the TA) in art. Syd.

SayodanaAniIRN A certain creeping thing, (daAbRapN, M,) or a small creeping thing, (duwayobRapN, S, K,) that makes for itself a habitation in the ground, (S, M, K,) within the ground, (M,) and conceals it; (S, M, K;) i. e. covers it over; (M;) so says A 'Obeyd; (S;) also called SayodanN↓: (S, K:) accord. to IKh, a certain small creeping thing (dwybRp) that collects pieces of stick, or wood, from the plants: accord. to IAar, a certain creeping thing (daAbRapN) having many legs, so many that they cannot be counted, which are short and long. (TA.)
See also SayodanN, in two places.

Also i. q. SayodalaAniIRN (S, Mgh, K, TA) as meaning A seller of medicines, (Mgh,) or of perfumes: so called as being likened to the small creeping thing mentioned above: or from SayodanN in a sense expl. above as syn. with SayodalN. (TA.)
1. SadowN as an inf. n. of which the verb is SadaA: see 2 in art. SdI, in two places.
SadowN as a subst. A certain liquid poison which is applied upon arrow-heads, or spear-heads, or the like, resembling the blood of the [serpent called] Oasowad. (M, TA.)
1. SadiIa, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. yaSodaI, (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. SadFI, He thirsted: (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) or he thirsted vehemently. (M.)
SadaA, inf. n. SadowN: see 2, in two places.

2. taSodiyapN signifies The clapping with the hands; syn. taSofiyqN; (S, K;) accord. to Er-Rághib, as being like the echo (AlSRadaI), inasmuch as there is no profit in it; (TA;) or it is from AlSRadRu, because they [who practised it in their worship] used to turn away (kaAnuwA yaSudRuwna) from El-Islám; (K;) [see more in the second paragraph of art. Sd;] and SadowN [an inf. n. of which the verb is SadaA↓] signifies the same; (K;) and so taSadRK↓, of which AHeyth cites as an ex. the saying of Hassán

[Their prayer is the clapping with the hands, and whistling: like the saying in the Kur viii. 35]: (TA:) one says of a man, SdRI, (M,) or SdRI biyadayohi, (TA,) meaning He clapped with his hands; (M, TA;) [said to be] originally SadRada; (M;) and biyadayohi SadaA↓, inf. n. SadowN [mentioned above], meaning the same. (TK.)
also muSadRiyapN.

3. SAdAhu, (K,) inf. n. muSaAdaApN, (S,) He imitated him, or it; syn. EaAraDahu: (S, * K:) and he, or it, corresponded, and was equal, to him, or it. (TA.) In the Kur xxxviii. 1, some read SaAdi, with kesr, as an imperative from AlmuSaAdaApu (Bd, TA) as meaning AlmuEaAraDapu; and hence AlSRadaI [i. e. the echo], because it imitates (yuEaAriDu) the first sound: so that the meaning is, Imitate thou (EaAriD) the Kur-án by thy works. (Bd.)

[And] i. q. dabRarahu [i. e. He considered, or forecast, its issues, or results; did, performed, or executed, it with thought, or consideration; or managed, conducted, ordered, or regulated, it]; relating to an affair: (M:) [or] AlmuSaAdaApu signifies the turning about, or revolving, the opinion, or idea, [that one forms] respecting the management (tadobiyr) of a thing, and the doing of it: (Ham p. 35:) [or,] accord. to As, the minding a thing attentively, carefully, or solicitously: a man who had assisted his she-camel in her bringing forth said, bitRu OuSaAdiyhaA Tuwla layoliI [I passed all my night minding her attentively, carefully, or solicitously]; because he disliked binding her fore shank to her arm, as it would distress her; or leaving her, as she might go away at random and the wolf might devour her young one: and in like manner one says of the pastor, yuSaAdiI Uibilahu [He minds attentively, &c., his camels]; when they thirst before the completion of their usual period of being kept from drinking, he restricts them to journeying by night so as to arrive at water on the morrow. (TA.)

And He soothed, coaxed, wheedled, or cajoled, him; or deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him; or strove, endeavoured, or desired, to do so: syn. daAraAhu, (S, M, K, TA,) and daAjaAhu, and saAtarahu, (S, K, TA,) all of which have one meaning, (TA,) [though the last implies concealing enmity,] and laAyanahu. (M.) mano SaAdaAka faqado SaAdaka [He who soothes thee, or coaxes thee, surely ensnares thee] is a saying mentioned in the A. (TA.)
4. ASdI It (a mountain) returned an echo. (S, * K.)
And He (a man, TA) died; (K, TA;) as though [meaning] his echo ceased; the | having a privative effect. (TA.)

5. AltRaSadRiI, accord. to Er-Rághib, signifies The corresponding to a thing like as does the echo returning from the mountain. (TA.) [But accord. to others,] tSdRI lahu is originally taSadRada; (Az and L in art. Sd;) and signifies taEarRaDa, (S, M, K,) and taDarRaEa. (M.) [See 5 in art. Sd; where the usages of this verb, except in the senses mentioned and indicated here below, are fully explained.]
It signifies also The feigning oneself unmindful, negligent, inattentive, inadvertent, inconsiderate, or heedless, not being really so. (TA.)
And The diverting oneself. (TA.)
See also 2.

SadFI [sometimes written SadFA] An echo; i. e. AlSRadaI signifies what the mountain returns to him who utters a sound, or voice, or cry, therein; (K;) or the sound of the mountain and the like that responds to one; (M;) or what responds to one with the like of his voice, or cry, in the mountains &c. (S.) One says, SamRa SadaAhu (tropical:) [His echo became dumb, or may his echo become dumb]; (S, TA;) meaning he perished, or may he perish: (S and K and TA in art. Sm:) and OaSamRa QllRehu SadaAhu (tropical:) [May God make his echo to return no sound]; (S, K, TA;) meaning may God destroy him: (S, K, and TA in art. Sm:) for when a man dies, the SdI hears not from him anything, that it should respond to him. (S. [See also another explanation of this saying in what follows.])
And A sound, voice, or cry, (M, TA,) in an absolute sense. (TA.)

Also The part of the head, (M,) or the part of the brain, (TA,) which is the place [or seat] of hearing. (M, TA.) And therefore one says, OaSamRa QllRehu SadaAhu [May God render deaf the part of his brain which is the seat of hearing]. (TA.)

And The brain, (M, K, TA,) itself. (TA.) And The [entire] contents (lit. the stuffing, HaXow,) of the head; (M, K, TA;) also called the haAmap. (TA.) One says, SadaEa QllRehu SadaAhu [May God crack his brain, or the contents of his head]. (M.)

And A bird that cries in the
haAmap [or head] of the slain when his blood has not been avenged by retaliation: (M:) or a bird that comes forth (M, K) from his head, (mino raOosihi, M,) or from the head of the slain, (K,) when he, or it, has become consumed, or decayed, (M, K,) also called the haAmap; (M;) accord. to the assertion of the people of the Time of Ignorance; (M, K;) mentioned by A 'Obeyd; and some of them used to say that the bones of the dead became a haAmap, which flew: pl. OaSodaMCN: (TA:) and [this may be meant by the saying that it signifies] the male of the buwm (S, M, K, TA) and haAm: pl. OaSodaMCN: (M:) they used to say that when a man was slain and his blood was not avenged by retaliation, there came forth from his head a bird like the buwmap, i. e. the haAmap, the male being called the SdI; and it cried upon his grave, AisoquwniI AisoquwniI [Give ye me to drink, give ye me to drink, meaning, of the blood of the slayer]; and if the slayer was slain, it abstained from its crying: (TA:) and [it is said that] it signifies also the body [itself] of a human being after his death; (M, K;) or the remains of the dead in his grave, i. e. his juvRap [or corpse]. (Jm, TA.)

And, (K,) accord. to El- 'Adebbes, (S,) [A cricket;] a certain flying thing, that creaks by night, and hops, (S, K,) and flies, thought by the [common] people to be the junodab, but it is only the SdI, the jndb being smaller than the SdI. (S. [See also AlSRarRaAru.])
And A certain fish, black, long, (K, TA,) and bulky: n. un. SadaApN. (TA.)
And [A man] small, or slender, in person; (AA, M, K, TA;) and so SadaOo, with C, as mentioned by Az. (TA. [See also SadoEN and SadaEN.])

And Knowing in respect of what is conducive to the good of cattle: (K:) or SadaI maAlK means thus: (M:) or gentle in the management of cattle; like UizaMCu maAlK: so in the Jm: (TA:) or, as some particularly say, of camels: (M, TA:) [i. e.] you say, UinRahu laSadaI UibilK, meaning Verily he is knowing in respect of camels, and of what is conducive to their good. (S.)

Also Thirst: (S, M, K:) or vehement thirst: (M:) [see the first paragraph, in which it is mentioned as an inf. n.:] it is said that thirst does not become vehement but the brain dries, and therefore the skin of the forehead of him who dies of thirst cracks. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph.
And The act of the mutaSadRiI, (M, K, TA,) i. e., [as is indicated in the M,] of him who raises his head and breast, looking towards, or regarding, a thing; and so SadaApN↓. (TA.)

SadK and SaAdK↓ and SadoyaAnu↓ (S, M, Msb, K) and SadFI↓ [which last is an inf. n. used as an epithet] (M) Thirsting: (S, M, Msb, K:) or thirsting vehemently: (M:) fem. [of the first] SadiyapN (Msb) and [of the second] SaAdiyapN (Msb, K) and [of the third] SadoyaA↓: (S, M, Msb, K:) and the pl. of SaAdiyapN is SawaAdK. (Ham p. 329.)
SadaApN: see SadFI, last sentence.
SadoyaAnu; and its fem., SadoyaA: see SadK.
SaAdK (fem. with p, and pl. of the latter SawaAdK): see SadK.

As pl. of SaAdiyapN, (M,) SawaAdK signifies [also] Tall palm-trees: (S, K:) and sometimes, such as drink not water: (S:) or palm-trees that drink water: [thus in a copy of the M:] and some say, such as are tall thereof, and of other trees. (M.)
kaOosN muSodaApN [A cup of wine] having much water: contr. of muEoraqapN, this meaning “ having little water. ” (M.)
miSodaMCN A man who thirsts much. (M.)

muSadRiyapN The woman who faces, or decorates, (tuSadRiI↓, [which I thus render conjecturally, finding nothing to indicate its meaning except what here follows,]) the wisaAdap [i. e. pillow, or cushion,] with AlOaranodaj, meaning black lines, upon the leather [that forms its covering]. (TA.)

1. SarRa, (S, A, TA,) aor.
Sarira
, (S, TA,) inf. n. SariyrN, said of the junodab [which is app. a species of locust], and of a writing-reed, and of a door, (S, A, TA,) or of a dog-tooth, (nAb, so in a copy of the S in the place of bAb in other copies as in the A and TA,) It made a sound, or noise; (S, A, TA;) or a prolonged sound or noise; [meaning it creaked; or made a creaking, or grating, sound;] and so anything that makes a similar prolonged sound: and [in like manner] AiSoTarRat↓ said of a mast (saAriyap), it creaked, or made a creaking sound: (TA:) but when there is a lightness, or slightness, and reiteration, of the sound, they use the reduplicative form, SaroSara↓, inf. n. SaroSarapN, (S, * TA,) signifying he (the bird called OaxoTab, S, A, TA, and the hawk, or falcon, S, M, TA, or other bird, or flying thing, M) uttered his [reiterated quavering] cry; (S, M, A, TA;) as though they imitated prolongation in the cry of the junodab [and the like], and reiteration in the cry of the OaxoTab [and the like thereof]. (S, TA.) SarRa Aljunodabu is a prov., expl. in art. jdb [q. v.]. (TA in that art.)
Also He (a sparrow) [chirped, or] uttered a cry, or cries. (TA.)

SarRa, aor.
Sarira
, inf. n. SarRN and SariyrN; and SaroSara↓; He cried, called out, or raised a cry or clamour, (M, K,) with vehemence, (K,) or with the utmost vehemence: (M:) and [in like manner] one says, jaMCa yaSoTarRu↓ He came [making a clamour, or] in clamour. (TA.)
And SarRa SimaAxuhu, inf. n. SariyrN, His ear-hole sounded, (M, K,) or tingled, or rang, (A,) by reason of thirst. (M, A, K.) And SarRati AlOucunu The ear tingled, or rang. (ISk, A.)
And SarRa, aor. as above, He thirsted [app. so as to hear a ringing in his ears]. (IAar.)
SarRN [as inf. n. of SarRa] also signifies The act of binding [a captive, &c.: see the pass. part. n., maSoruwrN]. (Mgh.)

You say, SarRa, [aor.
Sarura
,] (S, M, A,) inf. n. SarRN, (M, TA,) He tied up a purse, (S, M, * TA,) and money in a purse. (A.)

And SarRaAlnRaAqapa (S, M, K) and biAlnRaAqapi, (M, K,) or SarRa AlnRaAqapa biAlSRiraAri, (Msb,) aor.
Sarura
, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. SarRN; (M, K;) [and app. SarRarahaA↓; (see the pass. part. n., voce maSoruwrN;)] He bound the SiraAr [q. v.] upon the she-camel; (S;) [i. e.] he bound the she-camel's udder with the SiraAri: (M, Msb, K, * TA:) and SarRa AlOaTobaMCa biAlSRiraAri [He bound the teats with the SrAr]. (A.) [See a verse of ElKumeyt cited voce rijolN: and see also what there follows it.]
[Hence,] SarRahaA means also (assumed tropical:) He left off milking her [i. e. the camel]. (Msb.)
And tuSarRu, [aor. of SurRat,] said of a leathern bucket (dalow) that has become flaccid, It is tied, and has a loop-shaped handle affixed within it, having another such opposite to it. (K, * TA.)

And one says, SarRa EalaIRa AlTRariyqa qalaA Oajidu masolakFA (tropical:) [He closed, or has closed, against me the road, or way, so that I find not any passage]. (A.) And SurRato EalaIRa hecihi Albalodapu falaA Oajidu minohaA maxolaSFA (tropical:) [This town has become closed against me so that I find not any way of escape from it]. (A.)

And SarRa Oucunayohi, [aor.
Sarura
, inf. n. SarRN,] He (a horse) contracted his ears to his head: (ISk, S:) or pointed and raised his ears; which a horse does only when he exerts himself and hastens in his pace: (TA:) or he (an ass) straightened and erected his ears to listen; as also OaSarRahumaA↓: (A:) and OaSarRa↓ used intransitively, (ISk, S,) without the mention of the ears, (A,) signifies the same as SarRa Oucunayohi: (ISk, S, A:) and SarRa biOucunihi and SarRa Oucunahu, aor. and inf. n. as above; and bihaA OaSarRa↓; he (a horse, and an ass,) straightened and erected his ear to listen; (M, K;) as also SarRarahaA↓. (TA.)
[The inf. n.] SarRN signifies also The act of confining, withholding, hindering, or preventing. (TA.)
And SurRa (tropical:) He had an iron collar put upon his neck, or round his neck and hands together. (A.)

And SarRa, aor.
Sarura
, He collected together a thing, or things, (IAar,) or anything. (TA.) And kalaAmFA SarRara↓ (assumed tropical:) He collected something to be said in his bosom, or mind. (L and TA, from a trad.) And AlmaAla SaroSara↓, inf. n. SaroSarapN, He collected together the property, or the camels or the like, and put back what had become scattered of the extreme portions thereof. (T, TA.)
And SurRa It (a plant, or herbage,) became smitten by cold, or by intense cold. (M, K.)
2: see 1, in three places.
SarRarato said of a she-camel, She preceded. (Aboo-Leylà, M, K.)
3. SArRhu EalaI AlXRaIoCi He compelled him against his will to do the thing. (S, K.)
4: see 1, latter part, in three places.

ASrR Ealayohi, (S, TA,) inf. n. UiSoraArN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He persevered, or persisted, in it; or kept to it perseveringly. (S, TA.) You say, ASrR EalaI fiEolihi (assumed tropical:) He persevered, or persisted, in doing it. (Msb.) And ASrR EalaI AlcRanobi (tropical:) He persevered, or persisted, in the crime, sin, or act of disobedience. (M, TA.) The verb is used in this sense when its object is evil, or crime, or the like. (TA.)

And (assumed tropical:) He
determined, resolved, or decided, upon it. (M, Mgh, K.) You say, ASrR EalaI fiEolihi (assumed tropical:) He determined, resolved, or decided, upon going on in doing it, and not turning back. (TA.)

ASrR yaEoduw (assumed tropical:) He hastened (M, K) somewhat (M) in running: (M, K: [in the CK, for OaSarRa yaEoduw OasoraEa, is put AaSarRa baEuda waAasoraEa:]) accord. to A 'Obeyd, the verb in this sense is OaDarRa; but Et-Toosee asserts that this is a mistranscription. (M.)

ASrRAlsRunobulu The ears of corn became such as are termed Sarar [q. v.]: (M, K:) [or] accord. to ISh, one says, ASrR AlzRaroEu, inf. n. UiSoraArN, meaning The seed-produce [i. e. corn] put forth the extremities of its awn, before its ears had become developed. (TA.)
8: see 1, former half, in two places.
ASTrR said of a solid hoof, It was, or became, narrow, or contracted, (S, TA,) in an unseemly manner, or immoderately. (TA.)
R. Q. 1. SaroSara, inf. n. SaroSarapN: see 1, former half, in two places:
and the same paragraph, last sentence but one.
SarRN A leathern bucket (dalow) that, in consequence of its having become flaccid, is tied, and has a loop-shaped handle affixed within it, having another such opposite to it. (K, * TA.)
See also SariyrapN.

SirRN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and SirRapN↓ (M, A, K) Cold: (Th, M, A, Msb, K:) or intense cold; (Zj, M, A, K;) as also SaroSarN↓: (Ham p. 719:) or cold that smites the herbage and the seed-produce of the field: (S:) in the Kur iii. 113, the first of these words has the first of the meanings expl. above: (IAmb:) or the second meaning: (Zj:) or signifies noise and commotion: or, accord. to I 'Ab, fire. (IAmb.)

And riyHN SirRN (M, A, K) and SaroSarN↓ (S, M, A, K) A wind intensely cold: (S, M, A, K:) or very intensely cold: (T in explanation of the latter:) or vehemently loud: (M, A, K:) of SaroSarN↓ some say that it is originally SarRarN, from SirRN meaning “ cold; ” the incipient letter being repeated, and put in the place of the medial r: others, that it is from Sariyru AlbaAbi [ “ the creaking of the door ”], and from SarRapN meaning “ vociferation, or clamour. ” (ISk.)
And SirRN is the name of A certain bird, like the sparrow (K, TA) in size, (TA,) of a yellow colour: (K, TA:) so called because of its cry: or, as some say, the sparrow (EuSofuwr) itself. (TA.)

SarRapN Vociferation, or clamour: (S, M, A, TA:) so in the Kur li. 29: (TA:) or the most vehement vociferation or clamour or crying (Zj, M, K *) of a man and of a bird &c. (Zj, M.) [In the K, this meaning is erroneously assigned to SirRapN.]
And Vehemence of grief or anxiety (S, M, K) and of war (M, K) and of heat, (K,) or of the hot season, (M,) &c.: (S, M:) and vehemence of the heat of summer. (S, A.)
And A contraction, or much contraction, and sternness, or moroseness, of the face, (K, TA,) by reason of dislike, or hatred. (TA.)
Also A company, a collection, or an assemblage. (S, M, K.) So in the following words of Imra-el-Keys:

(S, M) i. e. Those of them that remained behind, in a herd, not dispersed: (EM p. 48: [see the entire verse voce duwnN:]) or fI SrRp here means in [the midst of] clamour: (S:) or in vehemence of grief or anxiety. (S, M.)

Also i. q. EaTofapN (M, K) [i. e.] A certain bead (xarazapN) by which women fascinate men so as to withhold them from other women. (Lh, M, K, TA. [This is evidently what is meant by EaTofap, but is given in the M and K as a signification distinct therefrom.])
See also muSarRaApN.

SurRapN A purse (XarajN, M, K, in the CK XarojN,) for money; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) as also maSarRN↓, with fet-h, (TA,) or miSarRN↓: (so in a copy of the A:) pl. of the first, SurazN. (Msb.) Hence the prov., AifotaHo Suraraka taEolamo Eujaraka, meaning (assumed tropical:) Return to thyself, [or lay open the recesses of thy mind,] and thou wilt know [thy vices, or faults, or] thy good from thy evil. (Meyd. [See also SuradN, last explanation.])
SirRapN: see SirRN.

SararN Ears of corn (sunobul) after the culm is produced, (M, K, [in the CK, yuqaSRabu is put in the place of yuqaSRibu,]) before they become apparent: (M:) or ears of corn while the farina has not come forth into them: n. un. with p: (AHn, M, K:) or, accord. to ISh, corn when the leaves become twisted, and the extremity of the ears becomes dry, or tough, though the farina have not come forth into them. (TA.) [See 4, last sentence.]
SaraArN: see SaruwrapN, in two places.

SiraArN The thing with which a she-camel's udder is bound: (M, K:) the string which is tied over the she-camel's udder and over the [piece of wood called] tawodiyap, in order that her young one may not suck her; (S;) and in order that it may not make any impression upon her, they smear her teats with fresh [dung of the kind called] baEar: (TA:) or a piece of rag which is bound upon the she-camel's teats, in order that her young one may not such her: (Msb:) pl. OaSirRapN. (M, A, K.) It is a custom of the Arabs to bind the SrAr upon the udders of their milch camels when they send them to pasture by themselves; and when they return in the evening, they loose the ASrRp, and milk. (IAth.)
[Hence,] jaEalotu duwna fulaAnK SiraArFA (tropical:) I put an obstruction, or obstacle, in the way of such a one. (A.)
Also Elevated places over which the water does not come. (S.)
SaruwrN: see SaruwrapN.
SaraArapN: see the next paragraph, in three places.

SaruwrapN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and SaAruwrapN↓ (S, M, Msb, K) and SaruwrN↓ and SaAruwrN↓ (M, K) and SaraArapN↓ (S, M, K) and SaruwriIRN↓ (S, M, Msb, K) and SaAruwriIRN↓ (M) or SaAruwraMCu↓, (Sgh, K,) the last like EaAXuwraMCu, mentioned on the authority of Ks, (TA,) A man who has not performed the pilgrimage to Mekkeh: (S, M, A, Msb, K:) so called from SarRN, signifying the “ act of confining, withholding, hindering, or preventing; ” (TA;) or because the person so called refrains from expending of his property in pilgrimage: (Msb:) you say also, AimoraOapN SaruwrapN a woman who has not performed the pilgrimage to Mekkeh: (S, Msb:) pl. SaraArN↓ and SaraArapN↓: (K:) [or, rather, the former is a coll. gen. n., of which SaraArapN is the n. of un.; and the latter is a quasi-pl. n., like SaHaAbapN, as well as n. un. of SaraArN:] Fr cites, from certain of the Arabs, SaraArN↓ as used collectively; and one of the number is termed SaraArapN↓: (S:) each of the forms ending with the relative I receives the dual and pl. and fem. inflections: and accord. to IAar, the forms preceding those receive also the dual and pl. inflections: (M, * TA:) and some say that SawaAriyru is pl. of SaAruwrapN↓: (TA:) or SaAruwrapN↓ and SaAruwrN↓, (M,) or SaruwrapN, (Lh, S, M, A, Msb,) as occurring in the poetry of En-Nábighah, (Yaakoob, S,) not used without p, (Lh, M,) or all the sing. forms above mentioned, (K,) signify one who has not married: (M, A, K:) or who has not had intercourse with women: as though he had determined (OaSarRa) upon relinquishing them: (Yaakoob, S, Msb: *) applied in like manner to a woman, and to a plurality of persons: (M, K:) the p in SaruwrapN applied to a man and to a woman is not to denote the fem. gender, but to give the utmost intensiveness to the signification. (IJ, M.)

It is said in a trad., laA Saruwrapa fiI AlUisolaAmi, (S, M,) meaning, accord. to A 'Obeyd, There is no abstinence from intercourse with women in El-Islám: (M, TA:) i. e., no one should say, I will not marry: (TA:) thus he makes Srwrp a noun signifying an accident: but it is better known as an epithet: (M:) and IAth says that the meaning is, he who slays another in the Haram [or sacred territory of Mekkeh] shall be slain: his saying, “ I am a Srwrp; I have not performed the pilgrimage, and I know not the sacredness of the Haram; ” shall not be accepted of him: for in the Time of Ignorance, the Kaabeh was a place of refuge. (TA.)
daraAhimu SariyrapN i. q. maSoruwrapN [i. e. Dirhems, or pieces of money, tied up in a purse]: (K:) termed in the present day SarRN↓. (TA.)
See also SaArRapN.

SaraAriIRN A sailor: (S, M, K:) like SaArK: (S:) pl. SaraAriyRuwna: (S, M, K:) it has no broken pl.: (M:) or SarRAriIR should be [without tenween, imperfectly decl., and] mentioned in art. SrI; for it is pl. of SurRaMCN, which is pl. of SaArK, which J has mentioned in art. SrI: AHát used to say that SurRaMCN is a sing., like HusRaAnN; but without sufficient authority: and J has regarded SaraAriIR as a sing. in consequence of his finding it to have the same construction as a sing, in verses of Arabs;
whence he imagined the I in it to be the relative I, as is shown by his mentioning the word in this place. (IB.)
SaruwriIRN: see SaruwrapN.
SurRaI: see SirRaI:
and see also art. SrI.
SurRiI: see the next paragraph.

hiIa minRiI SirRaI, said of an oath, (S,) or huwa minRiI, SirRaI, (M, K,) and OaSirRaI↓, and SirRiI↓, and OaSirRiI↓, (Yaakoob, S, M, K,) and SurRaI↓ and SurRiI↓, (K, TA,) or SurRiIRN↓ and SirRiIRN↓, (as in a copy of the M,) It is a determination, or resolution, from me; (S, M, K;) a serious assertion; not a jest. (S, K.) Aboo-Semmál El-Asadee, his she-camel having strayed, said, “ I swear to Thee, [O God,] that, if Thou restore her not to me, I will not serve Thee: ” (S:) or, “ O God, if Thou restore her not to me, I will not say a prayer to Thee: ” (TA:) and he found her, her nose-rein having caught to a thorntree (Eawosajap); and he took her, and said, Ealima rabRiI OanRahaA minRiI SirRaI My Lord knew that it was a determination, or resolution, or serious assertion, from me: (S:) or a confirmed determination: (ISk:) it is derived from OaSorarotu EalaI AlXRaIoCi “ I persevered, or persisted, in the thing: ” (S:) [or “ I determined, or resolved, upon the thing: ”] AHeyth says, SirRiI↓, i. e., Determine thou, or resolve thou; as though he addressed himself; from OaSarRa EalaI fiEolihi “ he determined, or resolved, upon going on in doing it, and not turning back: ” it is also said that OaSirRI↓ is changed into OaSirRaI↓, like as they say biOabiI Oanota and biOabaA Oanota: and in like manner, SirRiI↓ is changed into SirRaI; the A in OaSirRiI being elided: not that they are two dial. vars., Sararotu EalaI AlXRaIoCi and OaSorarotu: and Fr. says that SirRaI and OaSirRaI↓ are originally imperatives; and that, when they desired to change them [i. e. the imperatives] into nouns, they changed the I into | [written I after fet-h]: and in like manner, [changing verbs into nouns,] they say, nuhiIa Eano qiylK waqaAlK; &c. (TA.) Accord. to AZ, one says, UinRahaA minRiI laOaSirRaI↓ meaning Verily, it is a truth, or reality, from me; and Aboo-Málik says the same of OaSirRiI↓. (TA.)
SirRiI: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

SarRiIRN and SirRIRN↓ A dirhem, (S, M, A, K,) and a deenár, (A,) that sounds, (S, M, K,) or rings, (A,) when struck: (S, M, A, K; in some copies of the last of which, in the place of UicaA nuqira, is put AcA nuqida: TA:) accord. to some, used only in negative phrases: (IAar, M:) thus used in the phrase, maA lifulaAnK SarRiIRN, [expl. as] meaning Such a one has not a dirhem nor a deenár: (IAar, A: *) and so used, as meaning a dirhem, by Khálid Ibn-Jembeh; who does not assign to it a dual nor a pl. (TA.)
SurRiIRN: see SirRI.
SirRiIRN: see SarRiIR:
and see also SirRaI.

AlSRarRaAru, (Msb,) or SarRaAru AllRayoli, (S, K,) or both, (Mgh in art. xTb,) and AlSRaroSaru↓, (M and L in art. jd,) The judojud; [a cricket, which is called the SarRaAr in the present day]; (S, M, Mgh, L;) a certain thing that creaks (yaSirRu); (Msb;) a small flying thing; (K;) it is larger than the junodab, and is called by some of the Arabs AlSRadaI: (S, Mgh:) A 'Obeyd says that this last term signifies a certain flying thing that creaks (yaSirRu) by night, and hops, and flies, thought by the [common] people to be the junodab, and found in the deserts. (Msb.)
SurRaAnN Such as grow in hard ground (jalad [in the CK, erroneously, jilod]) of the trees termed Xajaru AlEiloki, (K, TA,) and of other trees. (TA.)
SaroSarN: see SirRN, in three places.
and see AlSRarRaAru.

Also A certain insect (duwayobRapN), (M, K, TA,) beneath the ground, that creaks (taSirRu) in the days of the [season called] rabiyE; (TA;) and so SuroSurN↓ and SuroSuwrN↓. (M, K, TA.) [Accord. to Forskål, (Descr. Animal., p. xxii.,) SrSr, pronounced “ sursur, ” is applied to an insect which he terms Blatta Aegyptiaca.]
And The cock: (K, TA: [written by Golius and Freytag SiroSirN:]) so called because of his cry. (TA.)
See also SuroSuwrN.
SuroSurN: see SaroSarN:
and see also SuroSuwrN.
SaroSaraAnN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

SaroSaraAniIRN sing. of SaroSaraAniyRaAtN, (S, Msb,) which signifies Camels between the baxaAtiIR [or Bactrian (in the CK, erroneously, najAtiI)] and the Arabian: (S, M, Msb, K:) or such as are called fawaAlij: (S, M, K:) and SaroSaraAnN↓ [if not a mistranscription] signifies the same. (TA.) [See also SuroSuwrN.]
And SaroSaraAniIRN (S, M, K) and SaroSaraAnN↓ (M, K) A species of fish, (S,) a certain smooth fish, (M, K,) of the sea. (S, M.)
SuroSuwrN Large camels; (S, M, K;) as also SuroSurN↓ and SaroSarN↓. (TA.)
And A camel of the species called buxotiIR [i. e. Bactrian]: (M, K:) [see also SaroSaraAniIRN:] or its offspring; as also surosuwrN: (M:) or an excellent stallion-camel. (IAar.)
See also SaroSarN.
Also A ship, or boat: [or a long, or great, ship or boat:] and so quroquwrN. (TA.)
AlSRaraASirapu The Nabathæans of Syria. (S, K.)
rajulN SaArRN bayona Eayonayohi A man contracted in the part between the eyes, like him who is grieving, or mourning. (TA.)
And SaArRN signifies Trees (Xajar) tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, not without shade (K, TA) in their lower parts, by reason of their perplexedness. (TA.)

SaArRapN A want; a thing wanted; an object of want; or a needful, or requisite, thing: (S, M, K:) pl. SawaArRu. (TA.) One says, liI qibala fulaAnK SaArRapN [I have a want to be supplied to me on the part of such a one]. (A 'Obeyd, S.)

Also Thirst: (S, K:) pl. SaraAYiru, (K,) which is extr., (TA,) and SawaArRu: (K:) or the latter is pl. of SArRp in the sense first expl. above; as A 'Obeyd says; and this is meant in the K: (TA:) AA says that its pl. in the latter sense is SaraAYiru; and he cites the following words of Dhu-r-Rummeh:

[And the wild asses turned back, retreating quickly, not having quenched their thirst]: but fault has been found with AA for this; and it is said that SaraAYiru is pl. of SariyrapN↓, [which is not expl.,] and that the pl. of SArRp is SawaArRu. (S.) One says, qaSaEa AlHimaAru SaArRatahu, meaning The ass drank water until he quenched his thirst. (S.)
SaAruwrN: see SaruwrapN, in two places.
SaAruwrN: see SaruwrapN, in three places.
SaAruwraMCu: see SaruwrapN.
SaAruwriIRN: see SaruwrapN.
SuwayorRapN Narrow in disposition and in mind or judgment or opinion. (Sgh, K.)
HajarN OaSarRu A hard stone: (Tekmileh, TA:) and SaxorapN SarRaMCu a hard rock: (M, K:) or a smooth rock. (L.)
OaSirRaI: see SirRaI, in four places.
OaSirRiI: see SirRaI, in three places.
maSarRN or miSarRN: see SurRapN.
maSarRataA Albawoli waAlgaAYiTi [The two sphincters that serve as repressers of the urine and dung]. (K in art. Asr.)
muSirRapN A she-camel that does not yield her milk copiously. (M, K.)

muSarRaApN That has been left unmilked for some days, in order that the milk may collect in her udder, or until it has collected in her udder; (M, K;) as also SarRapN↓; applied to a ewe, or she-goat: or the former is from SarRaI, aor. yuSarRiI, (K,) inf. n. taSoriyapN, and therefore should be mentioned in art. SrI [q. v.]. (TA.)
muSarRarapN: see the next paragraph.
maSoruwrN Bound, as a captive. (Mgh.)
And maSoruwrapN and muSarRarapN↓ A she-camel having her udder bound with the SiraAr. (IAth, TA.)
And maSoruwrN applied to a solid hoof, Contracted: or narrow: (M, K:) or narrow and contracted: (S:) and muSoTarRN↓ signifies the same; (M, K;) or narrow in an unseemly manner, or immoderately. (TA.)
Also (tropical:) A man having an iron collar put upon his neck, or round his neck and hands together. (A.)

maSaArR [app. an irregular pl. of maSiyrN, and therefore without tenween,] The OamoEaMC [or guts, bowels, or intestines, into which the food passes from the stomach]. (M, K.) One says, Xariba HatRaI malaOa maSaArRahu, meaning [He drank until he filled] his OamoEaMC: mentioned by AHn on the authority of IAar, with no more explanation than this. (M.)
muSoTarRN: see maSoruwrN.
One says also AimoraOapN muSoTarRapu AlHaqowayoni [meaning (tropical:) A woman narrow in the flanks]. (A.)
See also muSoTaridN, in art. Srd.

1. Saraba He made the sour milk termed Sarob: (K, * TA:) [or] Saraba AllRabana, (M, TA,) aor.
Sariba
, (M,) or
Saruba
, (TA,) inf. n. SarobN, he made the milk to become what is termed Sarob: and he milked some of the milk upon other milk, and left it to become sour: (M, TA:) or Saraba AllRabana fiI AlwaTobi he collected the milk in the skin, portion after portion, and left it to become sour; as also AiSoTarabahu↓: (S:) or you say, Saraba AllRabana fiI AlsRiqaMCi and AlsRamona fiI AlnRiHoIi [he collected, portion after portion, and left, the milk in the skin called siqaMC and the clarified butter in the skin called niHoI]. (M, TA.)
[Hence,] Sarabotu AllRabana fiI AlDRaroEi (assumed tropical:) I caused the milk to collect in the udder, not drawing it forth. (Kt, TA.)

And Saraba (assumed tropical:) He kept in, or retained, and collected, [his] urine: (K, TA:) or withheld it long: and accord. to some, particularly said of a stallion-camel: (TA:) [or] Saraba bawolahu, (S, M,) aor.
Saruba
and
Sariba
, inf. n. SarobN, (M,) (assumed tropical:) he kept in, or retained, and collected, his urine: (S, M:) accord. to some, particularly said of a stallion-camel. (M.)

And Saraba AlSRabiIRu [caA baTonihi being app. understood] (assumed tropical:) The boy remained some days without discharging his excrement, or ordure: (M, TA:) and Saraba baTonu AlSRabiIRi, inf. n. SarobN, (assumed tropical:) the boy's belly became constipated (Eaqada), that he might become fat: (M:) [or] Saraba AlSRabiIRu liyasomana (assumed tropical:) the boy's excrement, or ordure, (cuw baTonihi,) became confined, so that he remained a day without discharging it, when he was about to become fat. (S.) [In the copies of the K, Saraba is expl. as signifying Eaqada baTona AlSRabiIRi liyasomana, to which, written without the syll. signs, the TA assigns the last of the meanings above; therefore, I doubt not, the right reading is baTonu, agreeably with the explanation of Saraba baTonu AlSRabiIRi in the M, given above: otherwise, the meaning must be (assumed tropical:) He, or it, caused the boy's belly to become bound, or constipated, that he might become fat.]

Sariba, aor.
Saraba
, (K, TA,) inf. n. SarabN, (TK,) said of milk, (TA,) It became collected (K, TA) in the udder. (TA.)
Sarabati AlOaroDu The land produced herbs, or trees, such as are termed Sarab [a coll. gen. n. of which the n. un. is SarabapN, q. v.]. (M, K. * [The meaning is indicated in both by the context.])
Saraba also signifies He cut, or cut off; (K, TA;) i. q. Sarama; like as one says Darobapa laAzibK and laAzimK. (TA.)
And i. q. kasaba [He gained, acquired, or earned; &c.]. (K.)
2. taSoriybN The drinking of sour milk, (O, K, TA,) such as is called Sarob. (TA.)
And The eating of gum, (O, K, TA,) i. e., what is called Sarob. (TA.)
4. ASrb He (a man, TA) gave. (O, K.) One says, ASrb Uilayohi maAlFA He (a man) gave to him property. (TK.)
8: see 1, first sentence.
ASTrb SarobapF He provided, or took, for himself some milk, either fresh or sour, in a skin, for a journey. (M, TA.)
11. ASoraAbRa [said by MF to be written by ISd AiSoraOabRa↓] It was, or became, smooth, (M, O, K, TA,) and clear; (TA;) said of a thing, (M, K, TA,) or of milk. (O.)
Q. Q. 4. AiSoraOabRa: see what next precedes.

SarobN and SarabN↓ (S, M, &c.) Sour milk (M, Mgh, K) that has been collected in a skin: (M, K:) or very sour milk: (S, Msb:) or milk that has been collected in a skin for some days so that it has become very sour: (As, M:) n. un. SarobapN↓ and SarabapN↓: (M, TA:) SiraAbN, occurring in some of the Expositions of the Jámi' es-Sagheer, is a mistranscription; or it may be a pl. of SarobN accord. to the analogy of HabolN and HibaAlN, and ramolN and rimaAlN. (Mgh.) One says, tazowiI jaMCanaA baSarobapK↓ Alwajoha [He brought us some sour milk, or very sour milk, that had been collected in a skin, making the face to contract in wrinkles]. (S.) [SM here adds,] Az says that AlSRaromu is like AlSRarobu, and is better known. (TA. [But this evidently relates to the signification of “ the act of cutting, ” or “ cutting off; ” not to AlSRarobu as applied to milk.])
Also, (K,) or the former word, (M,) Milk that is provided in a skin for a journey, (M, K,) whether fresh or sour. (M.)

And both words, (M, K, TA,) or SarabN↓ [only], (S, Msb,) Gum: (Msb:) or red gum: (T, S, M, L, TA: in the K, AlSRibogu AlOaHomaru is erroneously put for AlSRamogu AlOaHomaru: TA:) some say (M) it is the gum of the TaloH (S, M) and of the EurofuT, peculiarly; the pieces of which are red, as though they were ingots [of gold], and they are broken with stones: (M:) the n. un. is SarabapN↓: (S, M: [SarobapN as a n. un. in this sense I do not find mentioned:]) and sometimes it [i. e. SarobN or SarabN] has SiraAbN for pl.: (M:) sometimes, (S,) what is called SarabapN↓ is a thing like the head of the cat [in size], within which is a thing [or substance] like dibos [or honey of dates], (S, K,) and like glue, (S,) which is sucked and eaten. (S, K.)
SirobN A few tents (buyuwt [in the O, erroneously, butuwt]) of the weak sort of the Arabs of the desert: (IAar, O, * K, TA:) and so SiromN. (O.)
SarabN: see SarobN, in two places.
Also Red honey. (TA in art. Drb.)
See also SarabapN.
SarobapN: see SarobN, in two places.
Hence, (tropical:) The water [by which is meant the seminal fluid] that collects in the back [of a man]; as being likened to the [sour] milk that is collected in a skin. (M, TA.)
SarabapN: see SarobN, in three places.

Also A herb, (M, K,) and tree, (M,) that becomes green, and puts forth leaves, when dry, or that has grown, or become somewhat restored to a good state, after having been eaten [or depastured], (yatajabRaru, so in the M, [in the K yataxayRaru, which, as is remarked in the TK, is a mistake,]) after men [have fed their cattle therefrom]: pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] SarabN↓. (M.)
