SarobaI, (S, K,) accord. to Sa'eed Ibn-El-Museiyib, (TA,) The [she-camel called] baHiyrap, (S, K,) whose milk was forbidden [by the pagan Arabs] for the sake of the idols (AlTRawaAgiyt), no man milking her [for himself]: (TA:) thus called, (S, K, TA,) it is said, (TA,) because they used not to milk her save for the guest, so that her milk became collected [and retained] (S, K, TA) in her udder: (S, TA:) Kt says, it is from Sarabotu AllRabana fiI AlDRaroEi [expl. above]; or, as some say, from [AlSRarobu as signifying] “ the act of cutting, ” or “ cutting off; ” and this seems to be the more correct of the two explanations: accord. to IAar, it signifies a she-camel having the ear slit, like the baHiyrap, or cut off: and its pl., he says, is SurobN. (TA.)
SiraAbN See-produce, or corn, which has been sown after that which has been carried off to the place where it is trodden in the autumn. (O, K.)

SariybN Milk that has been made what is termed Sarob; as also maSoruwbN↓: (M, TA:) or sour milk: (A, K, TA:) pl. SurobN. (K.) So in the saying AlDRariyba laA AlSRariyba, i. e. [Give me] the thick [milk], from a number of milch camels, that has been mixed together; not the sour. (A, TA.)
SaraAbapN Clearness, and smoothness: thus in the phrase SaraAbapu HanoZalK in a verse of Imra-el-Keys; as some relate it: (M, TA:) as others relate it, SaraAyap, (M,) or SalaAyap. (TA.)
miSorabN A vessel in which milk is collected, portion after portion, and left to become sour: (S, K: *) and so mikoraSN and miqoraEN: pl. maSaAribu. (TA.)
maSoruwbN: see SariybN.
muSarRabapN (assumed tropical:) A she-camel that is kept from being milked, in order that she may become fat. (L in art. SfH, from the T.)

2. SrRj, inf. n. taSoriyjN, He plastered with
SaAruwj a watering-trough or tank (K, * TA) &c.: and sometimes they said XrRq. (TA.)

SaAruwjN Quick lime (nuwrap), and the mixtures thereof; (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) with which are plastered watering-troughs, or tanks, and baths, &c.: (M, TA:) a Pers. word, (S, TA,) originally JaAruw, (TA,) arabicized, (S, M, Msb, K,) as is every word in which occur both S and j, (S, Msb,) or SamajN is an exception to this rule: (TA in art. Swbj:) sometimes it is called XaAruwqN. (TA.)

1. SaruHa, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
SaruHa
, (K,) inf. n. SaraAHapN and SuruwHapN, (S, O, Msb,) [both strangely said in the K, to be substs.,] It was, or became, pure, sheer, free from admixture, unmingled, unmixed, genuine, or clear; (S, O, Msb, K;) said of a thing (S, O, Msb) of any kind of which the meaning is predicable, (S, O,) [and particularly] said of one's race, or genealogy. (K.)
SaraHa: see 2, in two places.
2. SarRaHato She (a camel) yielded pure, or clear, milk. (TA in art. Hlb.)

[Hence, probably,] taSoriyHN signifies The speaking clearly, plainly, explicitly, directly, or without ambiguity or equivocation; contr. of taEoriyDN. (S, A, K.) You say, SrRH bimaA fiI nafosihi, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) and bimaA Einodahu, (A,) He made apparent, manifest, or plain, or he manifested, exposed, or revealed, (S, A, L, K,) what was in his mind, (S, L, K,) and what he had; (A;) as also bihi SArH↓; (L, K;) and bh SaraHa↓: (TA:) or he declared, or made clear, what was in his mind, so as to express the intended meaning according to the first [or most obvious] interpretation; or he made it free from expressions susceptible of tropical meanings and a secondary [or remote] interpretation. (Msb.) And SrRH AlXRaIoCa, (TA,) inf. n. taSoriyHN; (K, TA;) and SaraHahu↓, (TA,) inf. n. SaroHN; (K, TA;) and ASrHhu↓, (TA,) inf. n. UiSoraAHN; (K, TA;) He made the thing apparent, manifest, clear, or plain. (K, TA.)

This verb is also intrans. (K.) One says, SrRHt Alxamoru, (S, A, Msb,) inf. n. taSoriyHN, (S, K,) The wine became free from froth; (S, A, Msb, K;) [it became clear] after fermenting and frothing. (S.) And SrRH AlnRahaAru The day became free from clouds, and sunny: (A:) or SrRH Alyawomu the day became free from mists and clouds. (Msb.) And SrRHt kaHolu The year of drought, or sterility, became one of unmixed severity; (S, Meyd, L, K;) and in like manner, SrRHt AlsRanapu: (L:) or the former means the sky became clear of clouds. (S in art. kHl, and Meyd.) And SrRH, (S, Msb, TA,) inf. n. as above, (K, TA,) said of an affair, (K, TA,) or, as in a copy of the K, [and in the S and Msb,] said of the truth, (TA,) It became apparent, manifest, exposed, or revealed; (S, Msb, K, TA;) and so AnSrH↓, (S, K, TA,) said of the truth. (S, TA.) Hence the prov. Einoda AltRaSoriyHi turiyHu, meaning On the appearing of the truth thou findest rest; (Meyd, TA;) no doubt remaining in thy mind. (Meyd.) And SarRaHa AlHaqRN Eano maHoDihi, (S, Meyd, A, Msb,) another prov., meaning (tropical:) The truth, or affair, became revealed, or manifest, (S, Meyd, Msb,) after its being concealed: (Meyd, Msb:) or, as AA says, falsity became detected, or exposed, and the truth became apparent and known. (Meyd. [See also zubodN.]) And SarRaHato bijilocaAna, another prov., (Meyd, L,) meaning It (the affair, or case,) became apparent, or manifest, to thee, in Jildhán; which last word is variously written, [see Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 730, and Har p. 106,] a place in Et-Táïf, soft and even, like the palm of the hand, containing no covert in which one may conceal himself; the t in SrRHt denoting the qiSRap or xuTRap: (Meyd:) i. e. the man made apparent, or revealed, the utmost of what he desired, or meant. (L.)
See also a trad. cited in art. SwH, conj. 2.
SrRH said of an archer or the like means [He made his arrow, or missile, to go clear of the butt or mark; or] he shot, or cast, and missed (K, TA) the butt [or mark]. (TA.)
3. SArH bihi: see 2.

[SArHhu, inf. n. muSaAraHapN and SiraAHN, He confronted him, or faced him.] One says, Xatamahu muSaAraHapF, and SiraAHFA, (S, K,) and SuraAHFA↓, (K,) which last is a subst. [used as an inf. n., i. e. a quasi-inf. n.], (S, K,) He reviled him confronting him, or face to face, or to his face. (S, K.) And laqiytuhu muSaAraHapF, (A, TA,) and SiraAHFA, and SuraAHFA↓, (TA,) I met him face to face. (A, TA.)
4: see 2.
5. tSrRH AlzRabadu Eani Alxamori The froth became cleared away from the wine. (TA.)
7: see 2.

SaroHN A qaSor [i. e. palace, or pavilion, &c.]: (Zj, S, A, K:) and (as some say, TA) any lofty building: (S, A, K, TA:) or a single house or chamber, built apart, or detached, large, and lofty: (Msb, TA:) pl. SuruwHN. (S, A.)
SaraHN: see SariyH.

SaroHapN The court, or open area, of a house; i. e. a spacious vacant part or portion thereof, in which is no building; its EaroSap, (S, TA,) or its saAHap [which means the same]: (A, Msb, TA:) pl. SaraHaAtN. (Msb.)

And A tract of ground that is hard and elevated (S, L) and even: or a tract that is even, and open to view, of ground, and of a place where camels or other animals are confined, or where dates are dried, and of a house or dwelling: or a tract that is even, and of goodly appearance, though not open to view: Aboo-Aslam asserts it to mean a [desert tract such as is called] SaHoraMC. (L.)

[Hence, app.,] one says, xaraja lahumo SaroHapa baroHapa, (so accord. to the TA as from the K,) or SaroHapa baroHapK, (O, and so in my MS. copy of the K,) or SaroHapF baroHapF, (so in the CK,) He went forth openly, or into the field [of battle], to them: (O, K:) and OinRa xuruwja SaroHapK baroHapK lakaviyrN, (so accord. to the TA as from the K,) or SaroHapa baroHapK, (O, and so in the CK,) or SaroHapa baroHapa, (so in my MS. copy of the K,) [accord. to SM,] with fet-h in the end of each [app. in the former phrase], and with tenween in each [app. in the latter phrase], (TA,) [i. e. Verily the going forth openly, or into the field of battle, is frequent. See also SaHorap, and baHorap.]
SuroHaAnN: see SariyHN.
SaraAHN: see SariyHN.
SuraAHN: see SariyHN, in six places.
Also Thin milk, containing much water, so that in some parts of it one sees a tawniness and xuDorap [here app. meaning a blackish hue]. (L.)
See also 3, in two places.
SiraAHN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

SariyHN Anything pure, sheer, free from admixture, unmingled, unmixed, genuine, or clear; (S, A, Msb, K, TA;) as also SaraHN↓, (S, K,) which is by some restricted by the [additional] epithet white, (TA,) and SuraAHN↓, (L, K,) and SiraAHN↓, which is [said to be] more chaste [though much less usual] than SuraAHN, (L,) and SaraAHN↓, (K,) and SumaAriHN↓, (S, K,) in which last the m is augmentative, or, as is related on the authority of AA, it is SumaAdiHN, with d, but [J says] I do not think this to have been retained in the memory [as transmitted from the Arabs of classical times]. (S.) You say labanN SariyHN Milk of which the froth has gone, (S, A, L,) or free from froth, (T, L,) and clear: (T, A, L:) or just drawn. (TA in art. zhr.) And bawolN SariyHN Urine free from froth. (T, L.) And xamorN SuraAHN↓, (L,) and SuraAHiyapN↓, (L, K,) without teshdeed, (K,) Pure wine, (L, K,) without admixture. (TA.) And kaOosN SuraAHN↓ A cup of wine without admixture. (S, A, Msb, K.) And jaMCa banuw tamiymK SariyHapF The sons of Temeem came unmixed with any others. (S.) And rajulN SariyHN, (T, S, L, K, *) and EarabiIRN SariyHN, (A, Msb,) A man, (T, S, L,) and an Arab, (A, Msb,) of pure, or unmixed, race or genealogy; pl. SuraHaMCu: (T, S, A, L, Msb, K:) and farasN SariyHN a horse of pure race; (T, TA;) pl. SaraAYiHu, (T, K, TA,) in this case as distinguished from the former. (T, TA.) And nasabN SariyHN Pure, or unmixed, race or genealogy. (A.) And kalimapN SuraAHN↓ and SuraAHiyapN↓ [A word, an expression, or a sentence,] that is pure, genuine, or clear. (K.) And kacibN SuraAHN↓ and SiraAHN↓, the latter with kesr, and SuraAHiyapN↓ and SuraAHiIRN↓ (TA) and SuroHaAnN↓ with damm, (Lh, TA,) (assumed tropical:) A pure, sheer, or unmixed, lie, (Lh, TA,) manifest, and known
to men. (TA.) And qawolN SariyHN (assumed tropical:) A saying [that is explicit, plain, or clear,] not requiring anything to be conceived in the mind, nor any interpretation. (Msb.) And XarRN SuraAHN↓ (tropical:) [Pure unmixed, evil, or mischief]. (A, TA.) And SariyHu AlnRuSoHi (assumed tropical:) Pure, or sincere, in admonition, or counsel. (L, TA.)
SaraAHapN: inf. ns. of SaruHa [q. v.]. (S, O, Msb.)
SuruwHapN: inf. ns. of SaruHa [q. v.]. (S, O, Msb.)
SuraAHiyapN: see SariyHN, in three places.
[Hence the saying,] OataAhu biAlOamori SuraAHiyapF [app. He stated to him the affair, or case,] clearly, or without admixture. (L, TA.)
SuraAHiIRN: see SariyHN.
SariyHiIRN an epithet applied to a horse, in relation to a certain stallion named SariyHN, (S, TA,) or AlSRariyHu, (TA,) that begat a generous breed. (S, TA.)
SuraAHiyRapN A vessel for wine: (K:) [in Pers. SuraAHiI:] but IDrd doubts its correctness. (TA.)
SurRaAHN A certain flying thing, resembling the [species of locust called] junodab, which is eaten. (K.)
SumaAriHN: see SariyHN.

yawomN muSarRiHN, (S, K,) like muHadRivN [in measure], (K,) [in one of my two copies of the S muSarRaHN also, and in the other copy the latter only,] A day free from clouds: (S, K:) occurring in the poetry of Et-Tirimmáh. (S.)
miSoraAHN A she-camel that does not yield frothy milk; (T, K; [in the CK, lA taroEaI is put for lA turagRiI;]) that yields pure milk, with little froth. (M, TA.)

1. SaroxapN, (L, K,) an inf. n. of Saraxa, (S,) signifies The calling or calling out, or crying or crying out, vehemently; [or screaming;] (L, K;) on an occasion of fright, or alarm, or of some affliction, or evil accident: (L:) one says, Saraxa, inf. n. SaroxapN; and ASTrx↓; [He called or called out, &c.;] both meaning the same. (S.) And SuraAxN is also an inf. n. of Saraxa, (A, Mgh, Msb,) and signifies The raising the voice, calling or calling out, crying or crying out: (S, A, L, K:) or doing so vehemently: (L, K:) and the calling, or crying, for aid, or succour; (A;) which last meaning is said to be tropical, but conventionally regarded as proper; (MF;) as also SariyxN, (S, TA,) which is likewise an inf. n. of Saraxa: (A, Mgh:) one says, Saraxa, aor.
Saruxa
(A, MA, Mgh, L, Msb) and
Saraxa
, (MA,) inf. n. SuraAxN (A, MA, Mgh, L, Msb) and SariyxN, (A, Mgh,) He raised his voice, called or called out, cried or cried out: (A, MA, L, Msb:) or did so vehemently: (Mgh, L, Msb: *) and he called, or cried, for aid, or succour, (A, Mgh, L, Msb,) saying, waA gawovaAho [Alas, a crying for aid!] and waA SaroxataAho [Alas, a crying of alarm!]; (L;) and AstSrx↓ signifies the same: (AHát, L:) and ASTrxwA↓ is syn. with tSArxwA↓; (S, TA;) meaning SaraxuwA; as also AstSrxwA↓; (TA;) or [rather] meaning They called or called out, &c., (SaraxuwA,) one to another. (TK.) kaAnato kaSaroxapi AlHubolaI [It was like the vehement crying-out, or the screaming, of the pregnant woman] is a prov., said of a thing that comes upon one suddenly, when he is not aware. (T.)

4. ASrx He aided, or succoured, another; in answer to a call, or cry; (S, A, Mgh, Msb;) as also AstSrx↓: (AHát, L:) the | in the former verb is said to have a privative effect, so that OaSoraxotuhu signifies I made his crying, or vehement crying, &c., to cease: (TA:) and SaArixapN↓ has the signification of the inf. n. of this verb, as an inf. n. [or rather quasi-inf. n.] of the measure faAEilapN; (K;) and SariyxN↓ also may have this signification in the Kur xxxvi. 43, as is said in the Ksh [and by Bd]. (TA.)

5. tSrRx He made an effort to call or call out, to cry or cry out, or to do so vehemently; [or, to scream;] (S, A, K;) or he made an effort in calling or calling out, &c., (PS,) in calling or calling out, &c., vehemently, and in crying for aid or succour. (KL.) One says, AltRaSarRuxu bihi HumoqN, (S,) meaning AltRaSarRuxu biAlEuTaAsi [i. e. The making an effort to call or call out, &c., or in calling or calling out, &c., in sneezing, is stupidity]. (S, TA.)

6. tSArxwA They called or called out, cried or cried out, or did so vehemently, one to another; (A;) [and so, accord. to a copy of the A, AstSrxwA↓; and app. ASTrxwA↓, as seems to be indicated in the L and K;] see 1.
8: see 1, in two places: and see also 6.
10. AstSrxhu He called, or cried, to him for aid, or succour. (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb.)
And He incited him, urged him, or induced him, to call or call out, to cry or cry out, [app. for aid, or succour,] or to do so vehemently. (L, TA.)

[Hence,] AusotuSorixa AlUinosaAnu There came to the man a voice, or cry, informing him of an event on account of which his aid was invoked, or announcing to him a death. (IAth, TA.) AisotiSoraAxu AlHaIRi means The tribe's being invoked for aid to perform what is requisite for the dead: and hence the trad. of Ibn-'Omar, faQsotuSorixa EalaI QmoraOatihi, not biQmoraOatihi, meaning, And he was called to aid in furnishing for the grave, and burying, the corpse of his wife: or it may mean, was informed that his wife was at the point of death. (Mgh.)
See also 1, in two places; and 6:
and see 4.
SaroxapN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S.)
Hence, (TA,) The call to prayer. (K, TA.)
SuraAxN an inf. n. of Saraxa [q. v.]. (A, &c.)
SariyxN an inf. n. of Saraxa [q. v.]: (A, Mgh:) see also 4.
See also SaArixN, in four places.
AlSRarRaAxu [He who calls or calls out, or cries or cries out, or does so vehemently, or screams, &c., much, or often.
And hence,] The peacock. (IAar, K.)

SaArixN Calling or calling out, or crying or crying out, or doing so vehemently; [or screaming;] as also SariyxN↓. (A, Msb.) And Calling, or crying, for aid, or succour; (S, Msb, K;) and so SariyxN↓; (S, K;) and musotaSorixN↓. (S.)

Also, and SariyxN↓, (AHeyth, S, A, K,) or the latter [only] of these, (T, Msb,) and muSorixN↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) and SaArixapN↓, (Lth, TA,) Aiding, or succouring; or an aider, or a succourer: (Lth, T, S, A, Msb, K:) Az says that he had not heard SaArixN in this sense on the authority of any except As; but that all men agree that it has the second of the senses given above, and that muSorixN↓ has the last of those senses. (TA.) OamapN EabodN Sariyxuhu↓, meaning [A male slave] whose aider [is a female slave], is a prov. applied in the case of a mean man who is aided by one meaner than he. (Meyd.) And it is said in the Kur [xiv. 27], maA OanaA bimuSorixikumo wamaA Oanotumo bimuSorixiIRa↓ I am not your aiders, nor are ye my aiders. (TA.)
AlSRaArixu is an appellation of The cock; (K, TA;) because he cries much in the night: and it is said by some to be tropical. (TA.)
And SaArixN signifies also A voice, or cry, informing a man of an event on account of which his aid is invoked, or announcing to him a death. (IAth, TA.)
SaArixapN The voice, or cry, of the calling for aid, or succour. (K.) Hence the saying, samiEotu SaArixapa Alqawomi [I heard the cry of the people, or party, calling for aid, or succour]. (TA.)
See also 4.
And see SaArixN.
muSorixN: see SaArixN, in three places.
musotaSorixN: see SaArixN.

1. Sarida, aor.
Sarada
, inf. n. SaradN, He, or it, was, or became, cold: or intensely cold. (M, L. [See SarodN.]) One says, Saridotu Alyawoma SaradFA XadiydFA [I was, or became, to day, very cold; or very intensely cold]. (A.) And Sarida yawomunaA [Our day was, or became, very cold; or very intensely cold]. (A.)
And Sarida, aor. as above, (S, K,) and so the inf. n., (S,) He (a man) was quickly sensible of cold. (S, K.)
And Sarida said of milk, It became in a state of decomposition, by reason of cold. (TA.)
And, said of a skin, (O, K,) inf. n. as above, (O, TA,) It emitted its butter in clots: (O, K:) of the doing of which it is cured with hot water. (O, TA.)

Sarida Eani AlXRaIoCi,
inf. n. as above, means (assumed tropical:) He abstained, refrained, or desisted, from the thing; [as though he became cold with respect to it;] he left, relinquished, or forsook, it: (M:) and Sarida qalobiI Eani AlXRaIoCi (tropical:) My heart refrained from the thing; left, relinquished, or forsook, it: (S, A, O, K:) like as one says, OaSobaHa qalobiI SaridFA↓: (TA:) the [lizard called] DabR is spoken of as saying,
[(assumed tropical:) My heart has become cold, or indifferent, (meaning disposed to abstinence,) not desirous of coming to drink]. (O.)

Sarida, (M, L, K,) or Sarida Eani AlrRamiyRapi, (S,) or mina AlrRamiyRapi, (A,) said of an arrow, (S, M, A, K,) and of a spear, (M, L,) aor. as above, (L,) and so the inf. n., (M, A, L,) It passed through, or transpierced, or a part of it passed through, (S, M,) the animal at which it was shot [or thrown], by reason of its sharpness; expl. by nafaca HidRapF: (S:) or it penetrated so that its extremity passed through; expl. by nafaca HadRuhu; (L, K;) or xarajato XabaApu HadRihi; and so Sarada, aor.
Saruda
. (A. [See SaAridN: and see an ex. in a verse cited voce buqoyaA.])

And Sarida, (K,) inf. n. SaradN and SarodN, (M, L,) [the latter inf. n. suggesting that one says also Sarada,] said of an arrow, (M, K,) and of a spear and the like, (M,) It missed the object of aim: thus having two contr. significations: (M, L, K:) and ASrd↓ also has the latter of these two significations. (L.)

Sarida said of a horse, aor.
Sarada
, [inf. n. SaradN,] (tropical:) He became galled in the place of the saddle: (K, TA:) [or he had a white place, or white places, on his back, produced by galls, or by hair growing in the places of galls: (see SaridN and SuradN:)] and, said of a camel, he had white fur growing in the place of a gall produced by the saddle, after its healing. (AO.)
See also 4.

2. taSoriydN, (S, M, K,) in the giving to drink, (S, K,) is The giving to drink less than satisfies thirst. (S, * M, K. *) One says, SrRdhu He gave him to drink less than satisfied his thirst. (M.) And SarRadotu AlXRaAriba Eani AlmaMCi I stopped short the drinker from drinking the water. (A.) And saqaI saqoyFA gayora taSoriydK [He gave to drink a quantity not less than satisfied thirst]. (A.) And SrRd AlsRaqoIa He stopped short the giving to drink before satisfying thirst. (A.) And SrRd Xurobahu He cut short, or put a stop to, his drinking. (TA.) And SrRd XaraAbahu He made his beverage to be little in quantity. (A.) And accord. to the T, taSoriydN signifies The drinking less than satisfies thirst. (TA.)

Also, (S, K,) in giving, (S,) (tropical:) The making to be little, or small, in quantity or number. (S, K, TA.) One says, SrRd AlEaTaMCa (tropical:) He made the gift to be little, or small, (M, A, TA,) lahu to him. (A, TA.) And it is said in a trad., [app. relating to a particular class of persons,] lano yadoxula AljanRapa UilRaA taSoriydFA, meaning qaliylFA [i. e. (assumed tropical:) They will not enter Paradise save in small number]. (TA.)
[Also, app., An arrow's hitting the object of aim: see its part. n. muSarRidN.]
And The act of scattering, or dispersing. (El- Kálee, TA.)
And SrRd said of barley and of wheat, It put forth its awn, but not its ears, though almost doing the latter. (El-Hejeree, M.)

4. ASrd AlsRahoma, (S, M, L, K,) and AlrRumoHa; (M;) and Saradahu↓; (M, L, K;) He made the arrow, and the spear, or a part thereof, to pass through (S, M) the animal at which it was shot [or thrown]: (S:) or to penetrate so that its extremity passed through. (M, L, K.) [See Sarida and SaAridN.]
See also 1, latter part.

7. AinoSiraAdN is said to mean The experiencing of cold. (Meyd. [Mentioned by him, with the expression of a doubt as to the true meaning, and as only occurring, to his knowledge, in a prov., which see in Freytag's “ Arab. Prov. ” i. 357: but OakaAmK, there, should be UikaAmK.])

SarodN (S, M, L, K) and SaradN↓, (M, L,) the former a simple subst. and the latter an inf. n., (Lth,) and SariydN↓, (TA,) Cold, or coldness: (S, M, L, K:) or intense cold: (M, L:) SarodN is a Pers. word, [originally sarod,] arabicized: (S, K:) or, accord. to a number of authors, it is an Arabic word adopted by the Persians. (MF.) One says yawomu SarodK and SaradK↓ [A day of cold: or of intense cold]. (A.)
For the former, see also SaridN, in two places.
Also, the former, A high place in mountains; (AA, L, K;) being the coldest part. (AA, L.)

SarodN signifies also Pure, unmixed, unadulterated, or genuine; (S, M, L, K;) applied to beverage, (L,) such as is termed nabiyc, (S, L,) and to wine, (L,) and to anything. (M, K.) One says kacibN SarodN (assumed tropical:) An unmixed lie. (S, L.) And OuHibRuhu HubRFA SarodFA I love him with a pure, genuine, or sincere, love. (AZ, S, L.)

[Hence,] jayoXN SarodN (assumed tropical:) An army composed only of the sons of one father or ancestor: (L:) or an army altogether consisting of sons of one's paternal uncle [meaning of one's relations]: (AO:) or, (M, A, L, K,) and jayoXN SaridN↓ (M, A, L) and SaradN↓, (K,) (assumed tropical:) A great army; (K;) (tropical:) an army that appears, from the slowness of its motion, by reason of its great number, to be inanimate. (M, A, L.)
See also SuradN, near the end.
SaradN: see SarodN, in three places:
and see SuradN, near the end.

yawomN SaridN An intensely-cold day; and layolapN SaridapN an intensely-cold night: (M, L:) [or] yawomN SarodN↓ a cold day: (S:) and riyaAHN SawaAridu. [pl. of riyHN↓ SaAridapN↓] cold winds. (Ham p. 596.) And OaroDN SarodN↓ A cold land: pl. SuruwdN: (M:) the latter (i. e. the pl.) contr. of juruwmN. (S.) And rajulN SaridN A cold, or an intensely-cold, man: and qawomN SarodaI↓ a cold, or an intensely-cold, company of men. (M, L.) See also miSoraAdN.
SaridN applied to milk, In a state of decomposition, (O, K, TA,) by reason of cold. (TA.)
SaridN Eano XaIoCK (assumed tropical:) Abstaining, refraining, or desisting, from a thing; [as though cold with respect to it;] leaving, relinquishing, or forsaking, it. (M.) See 1.
See also SarodN.
And see SaAridN

SaridN applied to a horse, (tropical:) Galled in the place of the saddle: (K, TA:) or, (L,) as also muSarRadN↓, (A, TA,) having a white place, or white places, on his back, produced by galls, (L, TA,) or having on his back white places, termed SirodaAn, [pl. of SuradN,] produced by hair growing in the places of galls. (A.) [And app. applied in a similar sense to a camel: see Sarida.]

SuradN A certain bird, (S, M, K,) above the size of the sparrow, (M,) having a large head, (K,) which preys upon sparrows: (T, K:) a certain bird, black and white, or party-coloured, (OaboqaEu,) with a white belly: (A:) a certain bird of the crow-kind, also called AlwaAqiI: (Msb:) the Arabs used to regard its cry, (L, Msb,) and the bird itself, (L,) as of evil omen, (L, Msb,) and used to kill it; and they are forbidden to kill it, in order to dispel the idea of a thing's being of evil omen: (Msb:) there are two species thereof; one species is called by the people of El-'Irák AlEaqoEaqu [a name now applied to the magpie, corvus pica]; the other species, called AlSRuradu AlhamohaAmu, [so in the L, but in my copy of the Msb AlhyAm,] is the wild sort, which is found in Nejd, upon the trees called EiDaAh; it is never seen but upon the ground, [so in the L, but in my copy of the Msb, it is never seen upon the ground,] springing from tree to tree: (Sukeyn En-Numeyree, L, Msb:) when chased, and hard pressed, it is overtaken, and utters a cry like that of the hawk: it preys upon sparrows: (Msb:) it is described by AHát as a bird black and white, or party-coloured, (OaboqaEu,) with a white belly, and a back of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour (OaxoDar), [or, as is said in the L, half white and half black, found in trees,] large in the head and beak, having a talon with which it preys upon sparrows and other small birds, as large as the point of a spear: (Mgh, Msb:) some add to this that it is called AlmujawRafu, because of the whiteness of its belly; and AlOaxoTabu, because of the dark, or ashy, dust-colour of its back; and AlOaxoyalu [a name now applied to the green woodpecker, picus viridis], because of its diversity of colour; that it is never seen but upon a branch (fiI XuEobapK, and so in the L,) or a tree, (Mgh, Msb,) and can scarcely ever, or never, be taken, (Msb,) or can never be taken: (Mgh, L:) it is regarded as of evil omen: (Mgh:) Sgh says that it is called sumayoTN, [perhaps a mistranscription for XumayoTN, because black and white,] in the dim. form: (Msb:) [it is said that] it was the first bird that fasted for the sake of God: (K:) the pl. is SirodaAnN: (S, M, Msb, K:) and the female is called SuradapN. (Msb.)

Also (tropical:) A white place, (S, M, L, K,) produced by galls, (S, L, K,) or by the saddle; (M;) or SuradapN signifies a white place produced by hair growing in the place of a gall; likened to the colour of the bird thus called: (A:) pl. SirodaAnN. (M, A.) And (assumed tropical:) A white place on the hump of a camel: (M:) or white fur growing in the place of a gall produced by the saddle, after its healing: (AO:) pl. as above.
(AO, M.)

And (assumed tropical:) A certain vein (As, M) beneath the tongue, (As,) or in the lower part of the tongue, (M,) of the horse. (As, M.) And AlSRuradaAni (assumed tropical:) Two veins, (Lth, Ks, S, M, L, K,) of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour, (OaxoDaraAni, Lth, Ks, M, L,) in the lower part of the tongue, by means of which the tongue moves about, (Lth, Ks, L,) or penetrating within (yasotaboTinaAni) the tongue: (S, M, K:) or two veins, on the right and left of the tongue: (L:) or, as some say, two bones, which erect (yuqiymaAni) the tongue. (M.) Yezeed Ibn-Es- Sa'ik in his saying
means caribaAni [i. e. caribaA AllRisaAni, for caribN lisaAnuhumaA, as though he said lahu lisaAnN caribN He has a long, or an unbridled, tongue; the phrase that he uses being pleonastic]. (S.)
Also, (M, L,) or SarodN↓, (so in the K,) and SaradN↓, which is the more known, (TA,) A nail in a spear-head, (M, L, K,) by means of which the shaft is fastened to it. (L, K. *)
Accord. to Sh, fatRaHa Suradahu means He opened his mind, so as to reveal his secrets. (TA. [But this is perhaps a mistranscription, for ftH Surarahu: see SurRapN.])
SarodaI [pl. of SaridN; and, agreeably with analogy, of SariydN]: see SaridN, and SurRaAdN.
SariydN: see SarodN.
Also Hoar-frost, or rime; syn. jaliydN. (TA.)
See also SurRaAdN.

SariydapN [app. a subst.; for if it were an epithet, having the meaning of a pass. part. n. of the fem. gender, it should by rule be without p;] A female animal, (M,) or a ewe, (K,) injured, (M, K,) and emaciated, (M,) by cold: pl. SaraAYidu: (M, K:) on the authority of IAar. (Kudot;.)

SurRaAdN Cold and humid clouds in which is no water: (As:) or cold and humid clouds which the wind carries away; as also SurRayodN↓ and SariydN↓: (M:) or thin clouds in which is no water; (S, K;) as also SurRayodN↓ (K) and SarodaI↓. (L, TA.)
SurRayodN: see what next precedes, in two places.
SaAridN: see its fem., with p, voce SaridN.

Also, (S, A, L, K,) and miSoraAdN↓, (S, L, K,) and SaridN↓, (A,) An arrow that has passed, or of which a part has passed, through the animal at which it has been shot; syn. naAficN: (S, L, K:) or of which the extremity only has passed through: when part of the arrow has passed through, it is termed naAficN; and when the whole has passed through, maAriqN. (A.) And nabolN SawaAridu Arrows of which the extremities have passed through the animals at which they have been shot. (A.)
OaSoradu More [and most] cold; or more [and most] affected by cold:
and More [and most] transpiercing. (Meyd, in explanations of provs. commencing with this word. [See Freytag's “ Arab. Prov. ” pp. 743-4.])
muSoradN: see what next follows.
muSoridN, (Ktr, L,) or muSoradN↓, (so accord. to the K, [the former agreeable with its verb, the latter app. a mistake,]) An arrow missing the object of aim. (Ktr, L, K.) [See also muSarRidN.]
muSarRadN Beverage, (S,) or drink, (A,) made little in quantity. (S, A.)
And Given little to drink: or (assumed tropical:) given a small gift. (S.)
See also SaridN.
muSarRidN An arrow hitting the object of aim. (Ktr, L.) [See also muSoridN.]
miSoraAdN A wind (riyHN) cold; or intensely cold: or accompanied by cold and humid clouds. (IAar, M.)
Also, and SaridN↓, (T, S, M, K,) A man quickly sensible of cold; (S;) weak in enduring cold; (K;) impatient of cold. (T, M.)
And the former, Strong in enduring cold. (K.)
And A land without trees, and without anything (K, TA) of herbage. (TA.)
See also SaAridN.
muSoTaridN A man vehemently angered or enraged: (K:) and so muSoTarRN, without d. (TA.)
SuraATN A long sword: a dial. var. of suraATN [q. v.]. (K.)

SiraATN A road, or way; as also siraATN, (S, K,) which is the original; (TA;) and ziraATN: (S:) [see the second of these three words:] Akh says that the people of El-Hijáz make it fem., and Temeem make it masc. (S and Msb voce zuqaAqN, q. v.)

AlSRiraATu, also written with s, is likewise [The name of] a bridge extended over the midst of Hell, (K, TA,) sharper than a sword, and thinner than a hair, over which the creatures will pass, the people of Paradise passing over it with their works, some like the blinding lightning, and some like the wind sent forth, and some like coursers, and some running, and some walking, and some dragging themselves along; and a crier will cry, from the lower parts of the empyrean, “ Lower your eyes until Fátimeh, the daughter of Mohammad, (may God bless and save him, and may God be well pleased with her and her two sons,) pass over; ” and the fire will say to the believer, “ Pass thou over, O believer, for thy light hath extinguished my flame; ” and thereupon, the feet of the people of the fire will slip. (TA.)
maSoraTN and miSoraTN: see masoraTN.

1. SaraEahu, aor.
SaraEa
, inf. n. SaroEN (S, O, * Msb, K) and SiroEN, (S, O, * K,) the former inf. n. of the dial. of Temeem and the latter of Keys, (S, O,) and maSoraEN, which is also a n. of place, [and, accord. to rule, of time also,] (S, O, K,) said of a man, (S, Msb,) He threw him down, or prostrated him, on the ground; (O, L, K, TA;) namely, a man. (T, TA.) And SaraEatohu is also said of a beast, [the pronoun referring to the rider,] meaning It threw him down. (TA in art. qmS.) Hence the saying, AlmaniyRapu taSoraEu AlHayawaAna (tropical:) [Death prostrates the animal]. (TA.) And mavalu AlmuWomini kaAlxaAmapi mina AlzRaroEi taSoraEuhaA AlrRiyHu marRapF fataEodiluhaA OuxoraI i. e. [The similitude of the believer is as the fresh, or juicy, plant of seedproduce,] which the wind bends at one time, throwing it from side to side, [and straightens at another.] (TA, from a trad.) And SuriEa AlXRajaru The trees were cut and thrown down. (TA.)
See also 3.
[Hence also,] SuriEa He was affected with the disease termed SaroE [expl. below]. (Msb.) And He (a man) was affected with diabolical possession, or madness; inf. n. SaroEN. (TA.)
See also 2, in two places.
2. SrREhu, [inf. n. taSoriyEN,] He threw him down or prostrated him, on the ground, vehemently; namely, a man. (K.)
SrRE AlbaAba, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He made the door-way to have what are termed miSoraAEaAni [i. e. a pair of folding doors]; as also SaraEahu↓. (K, TA.)

And [hence,] SrRE AlXRiEora (tropical:) He made the poetry to have what are termed miSoraAEaAni; as also SaraEahu↓: (K, TA:) or AltRaSoriyEu fiI AlXRiEori, (S,) or taSoriyEu Albayoti mina AlXRiEori, (TA,) is the making the first miSoraAE [meaning hemistich] to rhyme [like the second]; (S;) [i. e.] the making the last foot of the first hemistich like the last of the second [in rhyme]: (TA:) derived from the miSoraAE of the door-way. (S, TA.)

3: SaAraEotuhu faSaraEotuhu↓, (S, Msb, TA,) inf. n. of the former muSaAraEapN and SiraAEN, (Msb, TA,) I wrestled with him, each of us endeavouring to throw down the other, [and I overcame him in doing so, or and I threw him down.] (TA.)

5. tSrRE lahu (tropical:) He became lowly, humble, or abased, and abashed, to him; as also tDrRE: (Az, TS, TA:) or (tropical:) he lowered, humbled, or abased, himself to him: one says, maA zilotu OataSarRaEu lahu and Uilayohi (tropical:) [I ceased not to lower, humble, or abase, myself to him] HatRaI OajaAbaniI [until he answered me, or gave me his assent]. (Z, TA.)
6. tSArEwA They wrestled, one with another, endeavouring to throw down one another; and [ASTrEwA↓ signifies the same; or] ASTrEA↓ they two wrestled, each endeavouring to throw down the other. (TA.)
7. AnSrE [He, or it, became thrown down, or prostrated, on the ground]. (Occurring in the K in art. jOv.)
8: see 6, in two places.
SaroEN an inf. n. of 1. (S, Msb, K.)

Also, [as a subst., Epilepsy, or falling sickness: and sometimes, app., ecstatic catalepsy; a sort of trance into which a person falls:] a certain disease, (S, O, Msb, K,) well known, (S, O,) resembling madness, or diabolical possession, (Msb,) accord.
to the Ra-ees [Ibn-Seenà, whom we call “ Avicenna ”], (TA,) preventing, but not completely, the vital organs from performing their actions [or functions]; the cause of which is an obstruction that occurs in one or more of the venters (buTuwn) of the brain and in the ducts of the OaEoSaAb [here meaning nerves] by which the members are moved, [arising] from an abundant thick or viscous xiloT [or humour], whereby the ruwH [by which is here meant, as in many other instances, the vital spirit, or nervous fluid,] is prevented from pervading them in the natural manner, and consequently the members become [spasmodically] contracted. (K, TA.)

Also A sort, or species: and a state, condition, or manner of being: syn. DarobN and fanRN: (S, K:) of a thing: (K:) and so SiroEN↓: and likewise DaroEN and DiroEN: (TA:) [See also SaroEapN:] pl. [of mult.] SuruwEN (S, K) and [of pauc.] OaSoruEN. (K.) One says, huwa cuw SaroEayoni, meaning cuw lawonayoni [i. e. He, or it, has two sorts, or species: or two distinctive qualities or properties]. (Ibn-'Abbád, Z, O, K.) And tarakotuhumo SaroEayoni I left them changing from state to state. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) And liloOamori SaroEaAni, meaning TarafaAni [i. e. There are two ways of performing the affair, either of which may be chosen]. (TA.)
See also SiroEN, in three places.
SaroEaAni Two camels of which one comes to the water when the other returns from it, by reason of their [the camels'] multitude. (S, O, K.)

And [hence, perhaps,] AlSRaroEaAni signifies The night and the day; (K;) [and] so AlSRiroEaAni↓, with kesr, like AlSRirofaAni: (TA in art. Srf:) or the forenoon and the afternoon; from the first part of day to midday and from midday to sunset; each of these being termed SaroEN: (S, O, K:) or the morning, between daybreak and sunrise, and the evening, between sunset and nightfall; as also AlEaSoraAni; (S and K in explanation of AlOaboradaAni;) and some assert that it is formed by transposition from AlEaSoraAni: (TA:) or the two extremities of the day. (A, TA.) And one says, Oatayotuhu SaroEaIi AlnRahaAri I came to him in the morning and evening; or between daybreak and sunrise and between sunset and nightfall. (S, O, K.) And laqiytuhu SaroEaIi AlnRahaAri I met him at the two extremities of the day. (A, TA.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says,

meaning As though I were one, i. e. a camel, yearning towards his place of abode, which an evening and a morning, in evening a binding of the fore shank to the arm and in the morning a shackling of the legs, turn [or keep] away from a settled abiding-place: or, as Aboo-'Alee relates it, raAYiHapN, [as a partial substitute for SaroEaAni,] meaning, an evening, when there is a binding of the fore shank to the arm, and a morning, when there is a shackling of the legs; for they bind the camel's fore shank to his arm in the evening when he is lying down, and they shackle his legs in the morning so that he may pasture [but not stray]: another reading is SaroEaAhu [his morning and evening]. (TA.)
One says also, huwa SaroEu kacaA i. e. HicaMCahu [app. meaning It is over against, or corresponding to, such a thing]. (O, K.)
SiroEN an inf. n. of 1. (S, K.)
And i. q. muSaAriEN. (K.) See the latter in two places.
See also SaroEN, former half.

[Also Either of two opposite conditions in which one is or stands &c. in respect of an affair or case.] One says, Talabotu mino fulaAnK HaAjapF faQnoSarafotu wamaA OadoriI EalaI OaIRi SiroEaIo Oamorihi huwa [I sought, or demanded, of such a one, an object of want, and then turned away, and I know not in which of the two opposite conditions he was in respect of his affair, or case]; i. e., his affair, or case, did not become apparent, or clear, or known, to me. (S, O, K. *) And a poet says,

L.foreign: faruHotu wamaA wadRaEotu layolaI wamaA darato

sense.s: [And I went, and bade not farewell to Leylà, and she knew not in which of the two opposite conditions in respect of her affair, or case, I was going]; i. e., whether I went from her presence retaining attachment, or forsaking; (S, TA;) or, as Z says, in a condition of success or of disappointment. (TA.)
See also SaroEN, in the middle of the paragraph.

Also A like; a similar person or thing; and so SaroEN↓. (O, K.) One says, humaA SiroEaAni (S, O) and SaroEaAni↓ (O) They two are likes: (S, O:) and so XiroEaAni, &c. (S.) And hecaA SiroEuhu and SaroEuhu↓ This is the like of him, or it: and so DiroEuhu and DaroEuhu, &c. (IAar, TA.)
And A strand of a rope: (O, K:) and so DiroEN: (O:) pl. SuruwEN (O, K) and DuruwEN. (O.)
SaroEapN A single act of throwing down, or prostrating, on the ground; or a single suffering of prostration. (K, TA.) See also SiroEapN.

And A state, or condition: (O, K:) so in the saying, huwa yafoEaluhu fiI kulRi SiroEapK [He does it in every state, or condition]: (O:) [see also SaroEN:] or, accord. to the “ Mufradát ” [of Er-Rághib], the state, or condition, of him who is thrown down, or prostrated. (TA.)
SuroEapN One who is often thrown down, or prostrated, by men. (K.)

SiroEapN A mode, or manner, of throwing down, or prostrating; or of being thrown down, or prostrated: (S, * K, TA:) a word similar to rikobapN and jilosapN. (S.) Hence, (K,) one says, suwoCu AlAisotimosaAki xayorN mino Husoni AlSRiroEapi [The bad manner of holding fast upon one's beast is better than the good manner of being thrown down, or prostrated]: (S, K:) i. e., when one holds fast, though he ride not well, it is better than one's being thrown down, or prostrated, in a manner that does not hurt him; because he who holds fast sometimes overtakes, but he who is thrown down will not attain: (TA:) a prov.: or, as some relate it, Husoni AlSRaroEapi↓, which means the good manner of the single suffering of prostration. (K, * TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 623.])

SuraEapN One who throws down, or prostrates, others; (S, O, K;) as also SirRiyEN↓ and SurRaAEapN↓: (K:) or one who throws down, or prostrates, his antagonists much, or often; (TA;) and so SirRiyEN↓, (S, O,) and SurRaAEapN↓, with damm and teshdeed, mentioned by Ks: (O:) or SirRiyEN↓ signifies one who throws down, or prostrates, vehemently, though he be not well known for doing so; as also SarRaAEN↓ and SariyEN↓, the latter like OamiyrN [in measure, but this I think doubtful, probably added from finding SirRiyEN mistranscribed]: or SirRiyEN↓, accord. to the T, one whose occupation, whereby he is known, is the throwing down, or prostrating, others [as a wrestler]. (TA.) It is said in a trad. that the Prophet asked, Whom do ye reckon the SuraEap among you? they said, Him whom men will not throw down: and he said, He is not such, but is (assumed tropical:) he who governs himself on the occasion of anger: or, as some relate it, (assumed tropical:) the forbearing on the occasion of anger, (O, TA. *)
SaruwEN One who wrestles much with others, endeavouring to throw them down: (T, K, TA:) pl. SuruEN. (K.)
SariyEN i. q. maSoruwEN↓ [meaning Thrown down, or prostrated, on the ground]: pl. SaroEaI. (O, K.)
[And i. q. maSoruwEN↓ meaning (as the latter is expl. in the Msb) Affected with the disease termed SaroEN, q. v.]
And [i. q. maSoruwEN↓ meaning] Affected with diabolical possession, or madness. (TA.)
One says also, baAta SariyEa AlkaOosi (tropical:) [He passed the night prostrated by the influence of the wine-cup]. (TA.)

And raOayotu Xajarahumo SaroEaI and muSarRaEaAtK↓ (tropical:) I saw their trees cut down [and laid prostrate]. (TA.) And nabaAtN SariyEN (tropical:) A plant, or plants, or herbage, growing upon the surface of the earth, not erect. (TA.) And guSonN SariyEN (tropical:) A branch falling down to the ground: (TA:) or a branch broken down and fallen to the ground: (Msb:) and [in like manner] one says guSonN maSoruwEN↓; and maSaAriEu is said to occur in a verse of Lebeed as pl. of the latter word, the reg. pl. of which is maSaAriyEu: but in that verse some read muSarRaE↓ [which has a similar meaning. (TA. [See EM p. 157.])
SariyEN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Slain: from the same word as applied to a branch and expl. above: pl. SaroEaI. (Msb.)

And (tropical:) A twig, or rod, drooping, or hanging down, to the ground, falling upon it, but with its base upon the tree, so that it remains falling in the shade, the sun not reaching it, and therefore becomes more soft, or supple, than the branch [from which it depends], and more sweet in odour; and it is used for rubbing and cleaning the teeth [i. e. masaAwiyk are made of it]: pl. SuruEN: (K, TA: [the pl. is thus in the L; but in some copies of the K SuroEN:]) or, accord. to the T, the
sing. signifies a twig, or rod, that falls from the tree called baXaAm [q. v.]; and the pl. is SuroEaAnN: the former pl. occurs in a trad., in which it is said that the Prophet was pleased to rub and clean his teeth with SuruE. (TA.)
Also (tropical:) A bow from which nothing has been pared off: or of which the wood has dried upon the tree; (S, O, K, TA:) or this [latter] is only called SariyfN. (TA.)
And (tropical:) A whip, in like manner, (S, O, K, TA,) from which nothing has been pared off. (TA.)
See also SuraEapN.
SaraAEapN The quality of throwing down, or prostrating, vehemently. (TA.)
SarRaAEN: see SuraEapN.
SirRiyEN: see SuraEapN, in four places.
SurRaAEapN: see SuraEapN, in two places.
[SaAriEN act. part. n. of 1: pl. SaAriEuwna and SaraEapN. Hence,] qawomN SaraEapN A people, or party, who throw down, or prostrate, those with whom they wrestle. (TA.)
maSoraEN A place [and accord. to rule a time also] of throwing down, or prostrating, on the ground: (S, O, K:) [pl. maSaAriEu.]
[And (assumed tropical:) A place of slaughter: for] maSaAriEu Alqawomi signifies the places of slaughter of the people, or party. (TA.)
Also an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, O, K.)
miSoraEN: see miSoraAEN.

muSarRaEN [pass. part. n. of 2, q. v.]. One says, mararotu biqatolaI muSarRaEiyna [I passed by slain persons thrown down, or prostrated, on the ground]: with teshdeed because relating to many objects. (S.)
See also SariyEN, in two places.

miSoraAEN Either half [i. e. leaf] of a door [meaning of a folding door]: (MA, * Msb, KL: *) either one of what are termed the miSoraAEaAni of a door or door-way: (S, Msb:) miSoraAEaA baAbK means two doors that are set up, meeting together, the place of entrance thereof being in the middle of them [i. e. between them]: (T, O, K, TA:) [and in like manner, miSoraAEaA sitorK (occurring in the S in art. sjf) means the two separate halves, that hang side by side, so as to meet together, of a curtain; like the two leaves of a folding-door:] and the miSoraAE of a door [or curtain] is also called its miSoraE↓: (TA:) the pl. of miSoraAEN is maSaAriyEu. (MA.)

Hence, the miSoraAE in poetry; (S;) A hemistich: (MA, KL:) [this is the general meaning: in a more restricted sense,] miSoraAEaAni in poetry means a single verse [i. e. a pair of hemistichs] having two rhymes: (T, O, * K, * TA:) [using it in the latter sense, i. e. as meaning a verse of which the former hemistich rhymes with the latter, which is app. the primary signification,] Aboo-Is-hák says, the miSoraAEaAni are the two doors of the ode, like the mSrAEAn of the house, or chamber, or tent: and he says that the derivation of the word is from AlSRaroEaAni meaning “ the two extremities of the day. ” (TA.)
maSoruwEN: see SariyEN, in four places; where it is stated that maSaAriEu is said to occur as a pl. thereof; the reg. pl. being maSaAriyEu.

muSaAriEN One who wrestles with another, endeavouring to throw him down; as also SiroEN↓: you say, humaA SiroEaAni↓ i. e. They are two persons wrestling together, each endeavouring to throw down the other. (K, * TA.)

AlSRarofu signifies The turning, or sending, or putting, a thing away, or back, from its way, or course; the causing it to turn away, or back; therefrom; the averting it, or repelling it therefrom: (M:) or the shifting a thing from one state, or condition, to another; (Bd in vi. 105;) and so AltRaSoriyfu↓. (TA.) You say, Sarafahu, (M, K,) or Sarafahu Eano wajohihi, (Msb, TA,) i. e. Eano sananihi, (TA in art. wjh,) aor.
Sarifa
, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. SarofN, (M, Msb,) He turned, sent, or put, him, or it, away, or back, &c., (M, K,) from his, or its, way, or course. (M.) And nafosahu Eani SArf↓ AlXRaIoCi, meaning SarafahaA Eanohu [He turned himself away, or back, from the thing]. (M.) And Sarafotu AlrRajula EanRiI [I turned the man away, or back, or I averted him, or repelled him, from me]. (S.) And Sarafa AlSRiboyaAna He dismissed the boys, or sent them away, syn. qalabahumo, (S, K,) from the school: (K:) or Sarafotu AlSRabiIRa I let the boy go his way; and in like manner, AlOajiyra the hired man. (Msb.) And Sarafa QllRehu Eanoka AlOacaI [May God avert from thee harm]. (S.) And ASTrf↓ wajohahu (K in art. sfw and sfI) [meaning Sarafahu i. e.] He turned away his face. (TK in that art.) Sarafa QllRehu quluwbahumo, in the Kur [ix. 128], means God hath made them to err in requital of that which they have done: (M, TA:) or God hath turned them away, or may God turn them away, from belief. (Bd.) And saOaSorifu Eano MyaAtiI, in the Kur [vii. 143], means [in like manner] I will requite by causing to err from the direction of my signs. (O, TA.) [And one says also, Sarafahu UilaI kacaA He turned him (i. e. another man, or the like, as in the Kur xlvi. 28), or it (for ex. his mind or intention), to such a thing.]
[Hence,] Sarafa Alkalimapa, (TA,) inf. n. SarofN, (O,) He declined, or inflected, the word [i. e. the noun] with tenween. (O, TA.) See also 2.

[Hence, also,] AlSRarofu means The exchanging, or giving in exchange, gold for silver [and the reverse]: because it is turned (yuSorafu) thereby from one metal to another. (M.) You say Sarafa AldRaraAhima He exchanged, or gave in exchange, the dirhems for [other] dirhems or for deenárs. (Mgh.) And Sarafotu AlcRahaba biAldRaraAhimi I exchanged, or gave in exchange, the gold for dirhems: (Msb:) and AldRaraAhima biAldRanaAniyri [the dirhems for deenárs]. (S.)

It is said in a trad. respecting AlXRufoEap [or the right of pre-emption], UicaA Surifati AlTRuruwqu falaA XufoEapa i. e. When the roads thereof are made distinct [app. by their being turned in different directions, from the house, or piece of land, in question, to the possessions of different proprietors, there is no right of pre-emption]: (TA:) the inf. n. of the verb in this case is SarofN. (TA.)

You say also, Sarafotu AlmaAla I expended the property; (Msb;) [and so SrRftuhu↓; for] AltRaSoriyfu, (M,) or taSoriyfu AldRaraAhimi, (O,) fiI AlbiyaAEaAti, (M, O, K, *) means the expending of money [in the purchase of articles of merchandise]. (M, O, K. *)

And Sarafotu AlkalaAma I embellished the speech [app. by distorting it, or otherwise altering it]; and SarRafotuhu↓ has a similar, but intensive, meaning: (Msb:) or Sarofu AlHadiyvi means the embellishing of discourse, or speech, (A 'Obeyd, S, M, O, K,) by adding in it, (A 'Obeyd, S,) or and adding in it; (M, O, K;) and in like manner Sarofu AlkalaAmi: (K: [of which see another explanation voce SarofN:]) and is [said to be] from AlSRarofu in pieces of money, meaning “ the superiority of one over another in value. ” (O, K.)
Sarafa liOaholihi [as though meaning Sarafa nafosahu liOaholihi]: see 8.
[See also SarofN, below.]

Sarafa AlXRaraAba, (M, O, K,) inf. n. SuruwfN, (M, TA,) He did not mix the beverage, or wine; (M, O, K, TA;) as also SrRfhu↓, and ASrfhu↓; the last mentioned by Th. (M, TA.) And Sarafa Alxamora, (K, TA,) aor.
Sarifa
, inf. n. SarofN, (TA,) [or perhaps this should be SuruwfN, as in the next preceding sentence,] He drank the wine unmixed; (K, TA;) [and so SarRafahaA↓; for] taSoriyfu Alxamori, (S, O,) or AltRaSoriyfu fiI Alxamori, (K,) signifies the drinking of wine unmixed. (S, O, K. [Freytag has erroneously expl. Sarafa as meaning simply He drank wine.])

Sarafati Albakorapu, (S, O, K,) aor.
Sarifa
, (S, O,) inf. n. SariyfN, (S, M, O, K,) The sheave of the pulley caused a sound to be heard on the occasion of the drawing of water: (S, M, * O, K:) and the Sariyf of the door, and of the tush of the camel, is like that of the sheave of the pulley; (S, O;) [i. e.] the Sariyf of the door, (M, K,) and of the writingreed (M, Msb) and the like, (M,) is a creaking, or grating; (M, Msb, * K;) and so that of the tush of the camel: (K: [wnAbu AlbaEiyri in the CK is a mistake for wnAbi AlbEyr:]) one says of a man, and of a camel, Sarafa binaAbihi, (M, TA,) and Sarafa naAbahu, (TA,) aor.
Sarifa
, inf. n. SariyfN, He grated his canine tooth [against its opposite] so as to cause a sound to be heard: (M, TA:) the Sariyf of the stallioncamel is [indicative of] his threatening: (M:) or that of the canine tooth of the she-camel denotes her weariness; and that of the canine tooth of the he-camel, his lust: (IKh, TA:) or the Sariyf of the stallion is from briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness; and that of the female, from fatigue. (As, TA.) [But]

Sarafato, (IAar, S, M, O, K,) aor.
Sarifa
, (S, M, O,) inf. n. SuruwfN (S, M, O, K) and SiraAfN, (Lth, Lh, IAar, S, M, O, K,) said of a bitch, (S, O, K,) or of any female having a cloven hoof and of any having a claw, (Lh, M,) or of a ewe or she-goat and of bitch and of a cow, (Lth, TA,) or of any female animal of prey, but
mostly of a bitch, (IAar, TA,) signifies She lusted for the male: (Lth, Lh, IAar, S, M, O, K:) and the epithet applied to such an animal is SaArifN↓. (Lh, IAar, S, M, O, K.)

2. AltRaSoriyfu [in its primary acceptation is like AlSRarofu in the primary acceptation of the latter, but generally relates to several objects, or is used in an intensive sense]: see 1, first sentence: it signifies The turning of the winds (Lth, O, K, TA) from one state or condition, to another; (O, TA;) or from one direction, or course, or way, to another; (Lth, O, K, TA;) and so of the torrents, and of the horse, and of affairs, and of the verses of the Kur-án; (Lth, TA;) the making of the winds to very, or differ; and so of the clouds; (M;) the changing of the winds to south and north [&c.] and hot and cold [&c.]; (Jel in ii. 159, and xlv. 4;) or the making of the winds to be south and north, and east and west, and to be of various sorts in their kinds: (TA:) or taSoriyfu AlMyaAti signifies [the varying, or diversifying, of the verses of the Kur-án, by repeating them in different forms; or] the making of the verses of the Kur-án distinct [in their meanings by repeating and varying them, as expl. by many of the expositors in the instances occurring in vi. 46 and 65 and 105, and xlvi. 26]. (O, K.)

It signifies also The deriving one word from another [by modification of the form for the purpose of modifying the meaning; including what we term the declining of nouns (like AlSRarofu) and the conjugating of verbs]. (O, K.) [The science of AltRaSoriyf in language is commonly termed Eilomu AlSRarofi↓.]
In relation to property, or money, see 1, near the middle of the paragraph.
And in relation to speech, see 1, near the middle of the paragraph.
One says also, SrRf AlXRaIoCa, (M,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) meaning He employed the thing in other [i. e. more] than one way; as though he turned it from one way to another way. (M, TA.)

And [hence,] SarRafotuhu fiI AlOamori, (K,) or fiI OamoriI, speaking of a man, (S, O,) i. q. qalRabotuhu [meaning I employed him to act in whatsoever way he pleased, according to his own judgment or discretion or free will, or I made him a free agent, in the disposal, or management, of the affair, or my affair: or (assumed tropical:) I made him, or employed him, to practise versatility, or to use art or artifice or cunning, in the affair, or in my affair; for the quasi-pass., tSrRf, is said to be from AlSRarofu as signifying AlHiylapu, and is expl. as syn. with AiHotaAla: but the former meaning is the more common: and it is also used as meaning simply I employed him in the managing of the affair, or my affair]. (K.)
[Hence also, SrRf Alfarasa He exercised the horse.]
SrRf AlXRaraAba: and SrRf Alxamora: see 1, latter half.
3: see 1, third sentence.

The inf. n. muSaArafapN signifies also (assumed tropical:) The dealing, or buying and selling, with any one biSarofK [app. meaning with art or artifice or cunning, or it may perhaps mean in the exchanging of money: see SayorafiIRN], (KL.)
4. ASrf AlXRaraAba: see 1, latter half.
5. tSrRf [quasi-pass. of 2: thus,] said of a man's face, It turned about; or was, or became, turned about; syn. tqlRb. (Jel in ii. 139.)
And It (a thing) was, or became, employed in other [i. e. more] than one way; as though it were turned from one way to another way. (M.)

[Hence,] tSrRf fiI AlOamori, (K,) or fiI OamoriI, (S,) quasi-pass. of SarRafotuhu fiyhi, (S, * O, K,) thus syn. with tqlRb [meaning He acted in whatsoever way he pleased, according to his own judgment or discretion or free will, or as a free agent, in the disposal, or management, of the affair, or my affair; or he was, or became, employed to do so]: (K:) or it is from AlSRarofu as signifying AlHiylapu; (S, M, TA;) i. e. it means (tropical:) [he practised versatility, or] he used art or artifice or cunning, in the affair, or in my affair; syn. AiHotaAla. (TA [and in like manner Bd in xxv. 20: but the former meaning is the more common: see also 8].) [It is also used as meaning simply He employed himself, or was employed, in the managing of the affair, or my affair; because the management of affairs generally requires the practice of versatility, or the use of art or artifice or cunning.]
[Hence also, said of a horse, He was exercised.]

7. AnSrf, (S, M, O, K,) inf. n. AinoSiraAfN, (O,) and munoSarafN is also sometimes an inf. n. thereof as well as a n. of place, (S,) quasi-pass. of Sarafahu, (S, M,) said of a thing, (M,) or of a man; (S;) as such signifying It [or he] turned, or went, away, or back, from its [or his] way, or course; or was, or became, turned, or sent, or put, away, or back, therefrom; or averted, or repelled, therefrom: (M:) [or shifted from one state, or condition, to another: (see 1, first sentence:)] or i. q. AinokafRa; so in the copies of the K; but [this is an inadequate explanation;] the right [or better] explanation is AnokafaOa [i. e. he, or it, reverted, or returned; or was, or became, turned away or back]; agreeably with what is said in the O. (TA.) vumRa QnoSarafuwA in the Kur [ix. 128] means Then they return, or go back, from the place in which they have listened: or then they turn away from doing aught of that which they have heard. (M.)
[Accord. to Golius, it signifies also It ran in a small stream; or the like; for he explains it as meaning “ manavit: ” but for this he names no authority.
Said of a noun, it means It was inflected, or declined, with tenween.]

8. ASTrf (tropical:) He sought, sought after, or sought to gain, sustenance or the like, (M, TA,) and used art or artifice or cunning [in so doing]; (M;) for his family, or household; (M, TA;) as also Sarafa↓, aor.
Sarifa
; you say, Sarafa liOaholihi [as though meaning Sarafa nafosahu liOaholihi] and ASTrf: (M:) or he used art or artifice or cunning (tSrRf) in the seeking of gain: (O, K, TA:) or [meaning thus] you say, ASTrf fiI Talabi Alkasobi. (S.)
It is also trans.: you say, ASTrf wajohahu: see 1, first quarter.
And ASTrf AldRaraAhima He procured the dirhems in exchange for [other] dirhems or for deenars. (Mgh.)
10. AisotaSorafotu QllReha AlmakaAriha (S, O, K) I begged God to avert from me the things, or events, that are objects of dislike or hatred. (O, K.)
SarofN [as an inf. n.: see 1].

Used as a subst., The evil accidents, mishaps, or calamities, of time, or fortune; [thus expl. as having a pl. signification;] Sarofu AldRahori meaning HadavaAnuhu, (S, M, O, K,) and nawaAYibuhu, (S, O, K,) or HawaAdivuhu; (Msb;) because it [i. e. time, or fortune,] turns things from their way, or course: (M:) [but it seems to be more properly rendered the shifting of fortune, or its shifting about; and to be an inf. n. sometimes used as a simple subst., and therefore having a pl., for] its pl. is SuruwfN. (M, Msb.) In the phrase qado XaHaTato Sarofu nawaAhaA, in a verse of Sakhr-el-Ghei, [ISd says,] he has made it fem. because of its dependance upon AlnRawaI [which is fem.; as though the meaning were The afflictions that are the consequence of the course taken by her in her journey have exceeded the bounds of moderation]: (M:) [or it is here made fem. because having the signification of a broken pl., which is fem.:] or the meaning is, qado baEudato taSarRufu wajohihaA AlRaciI Oaxacato fiyhi [i. e. the shiftingabout of her course that she has taken has become far-extending; Sarof being thus used as an inf. n.; for the Arabs sometimes make the inf. n. fem., saying OawojaEatoniI Darobuka as well as OawojaEaniI Darobuka; (see EM p. 157;) and this I think the most preferable explanation]. (Skr in his Expos. of the Poems of the Hudhalees, p. 14 of the vol. edited by Kosegarten.)
Also Repentance. (S, M, O, Msb, K.) [See a phrase below, in which this and other meanings are assigned to it.]

And (tropical:) Art, artifice, or cunning. (Yoo, S, M, O, K, TA.) Hence, in the Kur [xxv. 20], famaM yasotaTiyEuwna SarofFA walaA naSorFA (tropical:) [And they are not able to put in practice art or artifice or cunning, nor aid]: (S, TA:) or this means and they are not able to avert, or repel, from themselves punishment, (O, K, TA,) nor to aid themselves. (O, TA.)

And Excellence, or superiority, of a dirhem, (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) and of a deenár, (M,) over another, (S, M, &c.,) in goodness, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or in value; (M, Mgh, O, K;) as in the saying, bayona AldRirohamayoni SarofN [Between the two dirhems is a difference of excellence], because of the [superior] goodness of the silver of one of them: (S:) and in like manner, of speech; (O, K;) as in the saying fulaAnN laA yaEorifu Sarofa AlkalaAmi Such a one knows not the excellence of speech over other speech: (O:) and [in like manner] one says, lihecaA EalaI hecaA SarofN There is, or pertains, to this, an excess, and an excellence, over this; for when one is judged to excel, it, or he, is turned aside from its, or his, likes, or fellows. (O, K. *)

And The night; and the day: (K:) [because of their interchanging:] AlSRarofaAni signifies the night and the day; (S, O, K;) as also AlSRirofaAni↓; (K;) the latter accord. to Ibn-'Abbád; (O;) like AlSRiroEaAni, with kesr also [as well as with fet-h]. (TA.)

In the saying (S, M, O, Msb) of the Arabs, (M,) or of the Prophet, (O, Msb,) in a certain trad., (K,) laA yuqobalu minohu SarofN walaA EadolN
[Neither Sarof nor Eadol shall be accepted from him], (S, M, * O, Msb, *) by Sarof is meant repentance; (S, M, O, Msb, K;) and by Eadol, ransom: (M, Msb, K:) or by the former, art, or artifice, or cunning; (Yoo, S, M, O, K;) and by the latter, ransom: (M:) or by the former, acquisition of gain; and by the latter, ransom: (K:) or by the former, a supererogatory act; (A'Obeyd, M, O, K;) and by the latter, an obligatory act: (A'Obeyd, M, K:) or vice versâ: (K:) or by the former, weight; and by the latter, measure: (M, O, K:) or by the former, deviation; and by the latter, a right, or direct, course: (IAar, M:) or by the former, maA yutaSarRafu fiyhi [app. meaning an evasive artifice]; and by the latter, a like: (Th, M:) or by the former, value, or price; and by the latter, a like; the saying originally relating to the bloodwit (AldRiyap): one says, lamo yaqobaluwA minohumo SarofFA walaA EadolFA, i. e. They did not accept from them a bloodwit, nor did they slay one man for him, of their people, who had been slain; but they required from them more than that; for the Arabs used [often] to slay two men, and three, for one man; when they slew a man for a man, that was AlEadol with them; and when they took a bloodwit, having turned from the blood to another thing, that was Sarof, i. e. the value, or price, was Sarof: then the saying was applied in relation to anything, so as to be proverbially used in the case of him who was to render more than was incumbent on him: it has also been said that by Sarof is meant [in the saying cited above] something additional, or in excess; but this is nought. (M.)
SirofN: see its dual in the next preceding paragraph, near the middle.

Also Pure, unmixed, or free from admixture; (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) applied to wine, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) or beverage, as meaning unmixed, (S, M, O, Msb,) and so maSoruwfN↓, (O, K,) and to other things, (K,) to blood, and to phlegm, (TA,) and to anything (M, Msb) as meaning free from turbid foulnesses: (Mgh, * Msb:) and SariyfN↓ likewise signifies anything having in it no admixture. (TA.)

And A certain dye, (Msb,) a red dye, (S, O, K,) with which the thongs, or straps, of sandals are dyed, (S, O,) or with which the hide is dyed: (Msb:) or a certain red thing with which the hide is tanned (yudobagu [perhaps a mistranscription for yuSobagu]). (So in a copy of the M.)

AlSRarofapu One of the Mansions of the Moon; [the Twelfth Mansion;] a single very bright star, [ β of Leo,] (S, O, K, and Kzw in his Descr. of the Mansions of the Moon,) by which are some small evanescent stars; (Kzw;) over against, (bitiloqaMC, so in my copies of the S,) or following, (O, K and Kzw ubi suprà,) AlzRuborap; (S, O, K, Kzw;) [i. e.] it is a single star behind the xaraAtaAni of the Lion; (M;) it is on the hinder part of the tail (canab) of the Lion; [wherefore it is called by our astronomers Deneb;] and is also called the qunob, which means the sheath of the penis, of the Lion: (Kzw in his Descr. of Leo: [in the S and O, erroneously, “ the qalob of the Lion: ”]) [it rose aurorally, in Central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, on the 8th of Sept., O. S.; and set aurorally on the 9th of March:] Ibn-Kunáseh says, (M,) it is called AlSRarofapu because of the turning away of the cold (S, M, O, K) from the heat, (M,) and the coming of the heat, (S, O,) accord. to the [O and] K at its rising, but [as] IB says, correctly because of the turning away of the heat [at its rising], and the coming of the cold: (TA:) [i. e., correctly,] it is thus called because of the turning away of the cold at its setting in the early mornings, and the turning away of the heat at its rising from beneath the rays of the sun in the early mornings: (Kzw in his Descr. of Leo:) when it rises before the dawn, that is the beginning of autumn; and when it sets with the rising of the dawn, that is the beginning of spring. (M.) [Hence,] AlSRarofapu is [called] naAbu AldRahori AlRaciI yufotarRu, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) or naAbu AldRahori AlRaciI yafotarRu Eanohu [The dog-tooth of time, or fortune, which it shows smiling]: for when AlSrfp rises, [a mistake for “ sets, aurorally, ”] the blossoms come forth and the herbage attains its full height: (M and K in art. fr:) in the T it is said that AlSRarofap is called by the Arabs naAbu AldRahori [the dog-tooth of time, or fortune,] liOanRahu yafotarRu Eani Albarodi waEani AlHarRi fiI AlHaAlatayoni [i. e. because it smiles revealing (the advent of) the cold and (that of) the heat, in its two states (of auroral rising and setting)]. (TA.)

SarofapN also signifies A certain kind of bead (xarazapN); (Lh, S, M, O, K;) mentioned among those by means of which men are captivated, or fascinated, or restrained by women from other women; (S, O, K; *) or by means of which men are conciliated, so as to be turned thereby from their ways of acting or conduct or the like. (Lh, M.)
And A bow having upon it a black mark or spot (XaAmapN sawodaMCu), the arrows of which, when they are shot, will not hit the object of aim. (O, K.)
And one says, Halabotu AlnRaAqapa SarofapF, meaning I milked the she-camel in the early morning, between dawn and sunrise, and then left her until the like time of the morrow. (O, K. *)
AlSRarafaAnu Death; (M, K;) a name of death. (IAar, O.)
And SarafaAnN signifies Lead; syn. raSaASN: (S, Msb, K:) or raSaASN qaloEiIRN [q. v.]: (M:) and (K) accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, (O,) copper; syn. nuHaAsN. (O, K.)

And A sort of dates; (S, M, O, Msb;) a heavy sort of dates: (K:) n. un. with p: (M:) AHn says, (M, O,) on the authority of certain of the Arabs, (O,) that the SarafaAnap is a red date, like the baroniyRap, (M, O, Msb,) but (M, O) hard to be chewed, (M, O, K,) tough, (M, O,) and the heaviest of all dates: (M, O, Msb:) persons having households and slaves and hired men provide it, because of its satisfying quality, (O, K, [but for ljrMtihaA in the O, referring to the n. un., and lijazaAtihaA in copies of the K, and ljizAyatihA in the CK, I read lijazaAYihaA, which is evidently the right reading, and agrees with what here follows,]) and its standing in great stead: (O, K:) or it is the [sort of dates called] SayoHaAniIR [q. v.]: (K:) AHn says, En-Nowshajánee told me that the SarafaAnap is [called] AlSRayoHaAniyRapu in El- Hijáz, and in like manner its palm-tree. (O.) SarafaAnapN riboEiyRaho tuSoramu biAlSRayofi watuWokalu biAlXRatiyRaho is one of their proverbs [expl. in art. rbE]. (AHn, O, K.)
SarafiIRN A camel of a certain excellent sort; (M, O, K;) a rel. n.: (O, K:) or it is correctly with d; (O, * K;) i. e. SadafiIRN [q. v.]: (O:) some say that it is with d; and this is the right. (M.)
SaruwfN A she-camel that makes a grating, or creaking, sound with her tushes, or canine teeth. (S, O, K.)
SariyfN inf. n. of 1 in the senses expl. in the last sentence but one of the first paragraph [q. v.]. (S, M, &c.)
See also SirofN.
Applied to milk, (S, M, O, K,) Just milked; (K;) brought away from the udder while hot, (S, M, O,) when milked. (S, O.)

Also Dry saEaf [or palmbranches]: n. un. with p: (AHn, M:) [i. e.] SariyfapN↓ signifies a dry saEafap. (K.) And AHn says, (M, O,) in one place, (M,) AlSRariyfu signifies, (M, O, K,) as some assert, (O,) What has become dry, of trees; (M, O, K;) like AlDRariyEu; (M;) called in Pers. HucoxuwX, (so in copies of the K, in the CK xudoxuwX, and in the O AlxacoxuwaX, [all app. mistranscriptions, for I find nothing like them in Pers. except partially, i. e. xuwX meaning “ dry, ” like xuXok,]) and also called [in Arabic] Alqafolapu [the tree that has become dry]. (O.) [See also SariyEN, with the unpointed S.]
Also Silver: so in a verse cited voce Uino (page 107, third col.): (ISk, S, O:) or pure silver. (K.)
See also the next paragraph.
SariyfapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Also A thin, round cake of bread; syn. ruqaAqapN: pl. SurufN and SiraAfN and [coll. gen. n.] SariyfN↓. (K.)

xamorN SariyfiyRapN Wine of Sariyfuwnu, (S, O, K,) a place, (S, O,) i. e. a town, (O,) in El-' Irák, (S, O,) in the Sawád of El-' Irák near 'Okbarà, (O, TA;) not, as it is implied in the K, from another of the same name in Wásit: (TA:) or, as some say, wine just taken from the danR [or jar]; like [as one says] labanN SariyfN. (O, K.)
SarRaAfN: see SayorafiIRN:
and see also SaArifN.
SirRiyfN: see the next paragraph.

SaArifN [act. part. n. of 1: as such having, among other meanings, the meaning of Grating, or creaking; or making a grating, or creaking, sound: and so SarRaAfN↓, but properly in an intensive sense; for] the dual of SarRaAfN is used by the poet Aboo-Khirásh as meaning two thongs of a sandal that make a creaking sound: (M:) [and SirRiyfN↓ likewise means making a creaking sound with the teeth: so accord. to Freytag, from Jereer.] One says, maA fiI famihi SaArifapN, meaning He has not in his mouth a canine tooth [lit. a
grater or creaker; for sinRN SaArifapN a tooth that makes a grating, or creaking, sound]. (M.)
See also 1, last sentence.
SaArifapN: pl. SawaArifu: see taSaAriyfu, below.

SayorafN One who practices art or artifice or cunning, in the disposal, or management, of affairs; (S, M, O, K;) as also SayorafiIRN↓; (S, O, K;) which latter is applied by the poet Suweyd Ibn-Abee-Káhil El-Yeshkuree [in the like sense] as an epithet to a tongue, in his saying,
[And a cunning, sharp tongue, like the edge of the sword, what it touches it cuts]. (S, O.)
See also what next follows.

SayorafiIRN i. q. SarRaAfN↓, (S, M, O, Msb,) or SarRaAfu daraAhima, (K,) and so SayorafN↓, (M, Msb, K,) i. e. A money-changer; (M, Msb, TA;) except that SarRaAfN has an intensive signification [app. as meaning a skilful money-changer, and hence it is often used in the present day as meaning a banker]: (Msb:) all are applied to him who knows and distinguishes the relative excellence, or superiority, of pieces of money: (Mgh:) these appellations are from AlmuSaArafapu, (S, O,) or from AltRaSarRufu, (M,) or from SarofN meaning “ excellence, ” or “ superiority, ” of one dirhem [or deenár] over another, (Mgh, and Msb on the authority of IF in relation to the first,) because such as excels, or is superior, is turned aside from the deficient: (Mgh:) the pl. is SayaArifapN (S, M, O, K) and SayaArifu (M) and SayaAriyfu, this last occurring in poetry, (S, M, O, K,) by poetic license, for the sake of the measure. (S, O.)
See also SayorafN.
taSaAriyfu AlOumuwri [and SawaArifuhaA pl. of SaArifapN↓] The varieties, or vicissitudes, of affairs or events. (M, TA.)

maSorifN A place of turning away or back: [see also munoSarafN:] hence, in the Kur [xviii. 51], walamo yajiduwA EanohaA maSorifFA, (TA,) meaning [And they shall not find] a place to which to turn away, or back, from it: (Bd, Jel:) or, a turning away, or back, from it: (Bd:) pl. maSaArifu. (TA.)
maSoruwfN [pass. part. n. of 1: see its verb:
and] see munoSarifN:
see also SirofN.
mutaSarRafN i. q. mutaqalRabN [as meaning Place, or scope, or room, for free action]. (A, voce sarobN [q. v.]; and so in the Fáïk.)
mutaSarRifN is an epithet applied to a verb [as meaning That is perfectly inflected], opposed to jaAmidN [q. v.]. (TA, voce qado.)
[ZarofN mutaSarRifN and TarofN gayoru mutaSarRifK signify the same, respectively, as ZarofN mutamakRinN and ZarofN gayoru mutamakRinK: see art. mkn.
wakiylN mutaSarRifN, means A factor, an agent, or a deputy, who acts according to his own free will in the disposal, or management, of an affair.]
munoSarafN is a n. of place, [meaning A place of turning away or back, like maSorifN,] as well as an inf. n. [of 7]. (S.)

munoSarifN and gayoru munoSarifK denote the two different sorts of nouns, (O, K,) meaning, respectively, [like maSoruwfN↓ and gayoru maSoruwfK,] Inflected, or declined, with tenween, and not so inflected or declined. (O, TA.)

1. Saramahu, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
Sarima
, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. SaromN (S, M, Msb, K) and SuromN, (M, K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (M, Msb,) He cut it, syn. qaTaEahu, (S, M, Mgh, Msb,) in any manner: [i. e. it signifies also he cut it through; or he cut it off, or severed it; for thus the meaning of qaTaEahu is generally explained:] (M:) or it signifies [only] he cut it (qaTaEahu) so as to separate it: (M, K:) namely, a thing, (S,) such as a rope, and a raceme of dates. (TA.) One says, Surimato Oucunuhu i. q. Sulimato [i. e. His ear was cut off, entirely]. (TA.) And Sarama AlnRaxola, (S, M, Msb, K,) and AlXRajara, (M, K,) and AlzRaroEa, aor. as above, inf. n. SaromN, (M,) He cut off the fruit, or produce, of the palm-trees, (S, M, Msb, * K,) and the trees, (M, K,) and the corn, or the like; (M;) as also ASTrmhu↓. (S, M, K.)

[Hence,] Saramahu, (S, M, MA, K,) [aor. as above,] inf. n. SaromN (S, MA,) or SuromN, (M, MA,) or the latter is a simple subst., (S,) (assumed tropical:) He cut him (i. e. another man); meaning he ceased to speak to him, or to associate with him; he cut him off from friendly, or loving, communion or intercourse; forsook him, or abandoned him; syn. qaTaEa kalaAmahu; (S, M, K;) and hajarahu: (A and Mgh and K in art. hjr:) or he cut himself off, or separated himself, from him, namely, his friend; he cut off [or withdrew] his friendship from him. (MA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce OabRa.] And Sarama waSolahu, aor. as above, inf. n. SaromN and SuromN, (assumed tropical:) [He cut, or severed, his bond of union,] as indicative of resemblance [to the act of cutting, or severing, properly thus termed]. (M.)
And Sarama Oamorahu (assumed tropical:) [He decided his affair]. (O voce DahoyaOa, q. v. [See also SaArimN, and SariymapN.])

Sarama is also intrans., as syn. with AnSrm, q. v. (M, K.) And [hence] one says, Oadobarati AldRunoyaA biSaromK i. e. (assumed tropical:) [Worldly good departed] by becoming cut off, or by ceasing, and coming to an end. (TA.)
One says also, Sarama EinodanaA XahorFA, meaning (assumed tropical:) He stopped, stayed, or tarried, with us a month: (K, TA:) mentioned by El-Mufad- dal, on the authority of his father. (TA.)

Sarama, (Msb,) [aor.
Saruma
,] inf. n. SaraAmapN and SuruwmapN, (M,) It (a sword) was, or became, sharp, (M, Msb,) and did not bend. (M.)

And [hence,] Saruma inf. n. SaraAmapN, said of a man, (S, M, Msb, K, TA,) as being likened to a sword, (TA,) (tropical:) He was, or became, courageous; (Msb;) or hardy, strong, or sturdy, (S, TA,) or sharp, penetrating, or vigorous and effective, (M, K, TA,) and courageous. (S, M, K, TA.)

2. SrRmhu [He cut it; cut it through; or cut it off, or severed it; namely, a number of things considered collectively; or a single thing much, or in several places]: (M:) taSoriymu AlHibaAli signifies taqoTiyEuhaA [i. e. the severing of the ropes]: the verb being with teshdeed to denote muchness [of the action], or multiplicity [of the objects]. (S, TA.) [Hence, taSoriymu AlOaTobaMCi The cutting off of the teats of camels: a phrase mentioned in the TA.]

3. SArmhu, (MA,) inf. n. muSaAramapN, (KL, TA,) (assumed tropical:) He effected a disunion with him: (MA:) or he cut him off from himself, being in like manner cut off by him: (KL:) or he cut him off from friendly, or loving, communion or intercourse, being so cut off by him: forsook him, or abandoned him, being forsaken, or abandoned, by him: cut him, i. e. ceased to speak to him, being in like manner cut by him: for AlmuSaAramapu signifies AlmuhaAjarapu and qaToEu AlkalaAmi. (TA.)
4. ASrm AlnRaxolu The palm-trees attained, or were near, to the time, or season, for the cutting off of their fruit. (S, M, Msb, K, TA.)

And [hence perhaps,] ASrm said of a man, (S, K, TA,) inf. n. UiSoraAmN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, poor, (S, K,) having a numerous family, or household: (K:) or in a evil condition, though having in him intelligence (tamaAsuk): [it is said that] the original meaning is he had a Siromap, i. e. portion, of property remaining to him. (TA.)

5. tSrRm quasi-pass. of SarRamahu; (M;) i. q. tqTRE [i. e. It became cut; cut through; or cut off, or severed; said of number of things considered collectively; or of a single thing as meaning it became cut, &c., much, or in many places, or into many pieces]. (S, K.)
See also 7, in three places.
Also (assumed tropical:) He affected hardiness, strength, sturdiness, and endurance, or patience; or constrained himself to behave with hardiness, &c. (S, K.)

6. tSArmwA (assumed tropical:) They cut, forsook, or abandoned, one another; (MA;) they separated themselves, one from another; (KL, in which only the inf. n. is mentioned;) they severed the bond of union, or communion, that was between them; disunited, or dissociated, themselves, one from another; syn. taqaATaEuwA. (S, * MA, in the former of which only the inf. n. is mentioned.)
7. AnSrm It became cut; cut through; or cut off, or severed; (S, M, K, TA;) quasi-pass. of Saramahu; (M, TA;) said of a rope [&c.]; and so Sarama↓. (M, K, TA.)

[Hence,] AnSrm mina AlnRaAsi [or Eani AlnRaAsi] (assumed tropical:) He separated himself from mankind; said of the wolf and of the crow [&c.]. (ISk, S, M. *) And AnSrm AllRayolu (assumed tropical:) The night went away, or departed; as also tSrRm↓: (Msb:) and AnSrm AlXRitaMCu (assumed tropical:) The winter ended; and tSrRmt↓ AlsRanapu (assumed tropical:) The year ended: (TA:) and AlqitaAlu tSrRm↓ (assumed tropical:) The fighting ended, or ceased. (Mgh.)
8. ASTrmhu: see 1, third sentence.
SaromN Skin: [or leather:] (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) a Pers. word (S, Msb) arabicized, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) originally jarom [correctly Jarom]. (Mgh, Msb, TA.)

SuromN is an inf. n. like SaromN, (M, K,) or a simple subst.: (M, Msb:) [see the first paragraph, in three places: in one of its senses, there expl.,] it is syn. with hijoraAnN and qaTiyEapN: (TA:) and SariymapN↓ [likewise] signifies (assumed tropical:) Separation from a friend: pl. SuramN. (MA. [This pl. is app. there mentioned as of SariymapN; but it is more probably of SuromN.])
Suromu AldRiyki: see daliykN.

SiromN Tents (OaboyaAtN), (S, M,) of men, (S,) collected together, (S, M,) separate from [those of other] men: (M:) or i. q. SirobN, (O in art. Srb,) which means a few tents (buyuwt [in the O, erroneously, butuwt]) of the weak sort of the Arabs of the desert: (IAar, O, * K, TA; all in art. Srb:) and hence, (M,) a company (M, Msb, K, TA) of men, (Msb, TA,) not many; or simply a company (TA) alighting and abiding with their camels by the side of the water: (Msb, TA:) pl. OaSoraAmN [a pl. of pauc.] (S, M, Msb, K) and OaSaArimu, (S,) or OaSaAriymu, (M,) or both, (K,) but accord. to IB the latter of these two is the right, [being a pl. pl., i. e. pl. of OaSoraAmN,] (TA,) and SuromaAnN, (Sb, M, K,) with damm. (K.)

And i. q. DarobN. (K. [So, app., in all the copies; accord. to the TK as meaning A sort, or species: but I think it most probable that this is a mistranscription for SirobN, with which, as has been stated above, SiromN is syn. accord. to the O.])
