Also i. q. xufRN munoEalN (M) or xufRN munaERalN (K) [i. e. A soled boot: that xufR here means a boot, not a camel's foot, is indicated by its being immediately added by SM that] SarRaAmN↓ signifies A seller thereof. (TA.)

SaromapN [an epithet applied to a man, but used as a subst., and therefore having for its pl. SaramaAtN]. One says, huwa SaromapN mina AlSRaramaAti, [the last word said to be thus (muHarRakap) in the TA, but in the CK (in which as well as in my MS. copy of the K mn is omitted) written AlSRaromAti,] meaning (tropical:) He is [a person] slow to revert from his anger. (K, TA.)
Also, [if not a mistranscription for Siromap↓,] A portion of silver, melted, and cleared of its dross, and poured forth into a mould. (TA.)

Siromap A herd, or detached number, of camels, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) consisting of about thirty: (S:) or from twenty to thirty: (M, K:) or from thirty to five and forty: (M:) or to fifty, and forty; (K;) if amounting to sixty, termed SidoEap: (TA: [but see this latter word:]) or from ten to forty: (M, Msb, K:) or from ten to some number between that and twenty: (M, K:) or more than a cawod [which is at least two or three] up to thirty: (T voce UibilN:) or about forty: (Ham p. 753:) or less than a hajomap, which is a hundred or nearly a hundred: (Id. p. 637:) pl. SiramN. (S, * M, * Msb.)
A portion of property. (TA.)
And A detached portion of clouds: (S, M, Msb, K:) pl. as above. (S, M.)
See also SariymapN.
And see SaromapN.

SaraAmN and SiraAmN↓ The cutting off of the fruit of palm-trees: (S, * Msb, and L voce jadaAdN:) and (L voce jacaAdN) the time, or season, thereof: (S, L:) or the time, or season, of the ripening of the fruit of palm-trees. (M, K.)
SaraAmi: see the next paragraph, in two places.
SuraAmN: see SaArimN.

Also The last milk [remaining in the udder] after what is termed AltRagoriyz [which is variously explained (see 2 in art. grz), in the CK and in one of my copies of the S erroneously written AltRagoziyr,] which a man draws when in need of it. (S, K. *) Bishr says,

[Now deliver thou to Benoo-Saad a message, and to their chief, that the last milk in the udder has been drawn]: (S:) the last two words [the latter of which is written in the CK SarAmi↓] are a prov., meaning (assumed tropical:) the excuse has reached its uttermost: (S, K:) thus says AO: (S:) IB says that SuraAmu in the saying of Bishr means the she-camel that is termed AlSRaromaMCu↓, that has no milk; [i.e. that the phrase means the she-camel that has now no milk has been milked;] and that he makes it a proper name; and that he [also] means thereby the latter of the two senses here following. (TA.)

AlSRuraAmu is also one of the names for War, or battle; (As, S, K; *) and so SaraAmi↓, [indecl.,] like qaTaAmi: (K:) and one of the names for calamity, or misfortune. (As, S, K. * [See also SayoramN.])
SiraAmN: see SaraAmN.
Sometimes it is applied to signify Palm-trees themselves; because the fruit is cut off: so in a trad. (TA.)
SaruwmN: see SaArimN, in two places.
Also a she-camel that will not come to the watering-trough to drink until it is left to her unoccupied; (K, TA;) cutting herself off from the other camels. (TA.)

SariymN i. q. maSoruwmN↓, (M, Msb,) Cut; cut through; or cut off, or severed: (S, Msb, K:) and having the fruit cut off; syn. majoduwdN; (S, K;) applied to palm-trees (naxol). (M.) And the former, A heap (kudos) of corn or the like that has been cut, or of which the produce has been cut off; syn. maSoruwmN↓. (M, TA.) And Whose ear has been cut off entirely (AalRaciI Surimato Oucunuhu): pl. SuromN. (TA. [See also the fem., with p, voce baHiyrapN, where the pl. is said to be SurumN.])

[Applied to the lungs, it means properly Burst asunder. Hence the saying,] jaMCa Sariyma saHarK, [so in copies of the K, accord. the TA siHor, but correctly either saHarK or saHorK q. v., in the CK bACa and Sariymu, which last word is obviously wrong,] meaning (tropical:) He came disappointed of attaining what he desired, or sought, and in a state of despair. (K, TA.) And huwa Saraymu sHrK EalaI hecaA AlOamori [i. e. Sariymu saHorK or saHarK] (tropical:) He is wearied and eager for this thing, or affair. (TA.)
Also (assumed tropical:) An affair decided, determined, or resolved, upon. (M, TA.)
Used as a subst., see SariymapN, in two places.

Also (assumed tropical:) The daybreak, or dawn; (S, M, K;) because cut off from the night; (M;) as also SariymapN↓: (S:) and the night; (ISk, M, K;) because cut off from the day; (M;) or the dark night: (S:) thus having two contr. meanings: (S, K:) and a portion thereof; (Th, M, K;) i. e., of the night; (TA;) as also SariymapN↓: (M, K:) and SariymaA AllRayoli the first and last parts, or beginning and end, of the night. (TA.) The phrase in the Kur [lxviii. 20] faOaSobaHatN kaQlSRariymi means [And it became in the morning] burnt up and black like the night: (S, M, Bd, TA:) or like the dark night, being burnt up: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or like the black night: (Katádeh, TA:) or like the day, by its whiteness from excessive dryness: (Bd:) or like that garden of which the fruits have been cut off: (Bd, TA: *) or like the sands [that are termed Sariym (see SariymapN)]: (Bd:) or the meaning of Srym in this instance is that which here next follows. (TA.)
Black land, that does not give growth to anything. (K.)
And A piece of wood, or stick, which is placed across upon the mouth of a kid, (M, K,) or of a young weaned camel, and then tied to his head, (M,) in order that he may not such. (M, K.)
See also SaArimN.

SaraAmapN (tropical:) A man (TA) who follows his own opinion, cutting himself off from consultation with others: (M, TA:) or who acts with penetrative energy, or vigorousness and effectiveness, in the performing of his affairs: an inf. n. used as an epithet. (TA.)
SuraAmapN What is cut off [of the fruit] of palmtrees. (Lh, M.)
SariymapN Land (OaroD) of which the seed-produce has been reaped: (S, K:) of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN. (TA.)

And A portion, (S, M, K,) or large portion, (TA,) detached from the main aggregate, of sand; (S, M, K;) as also SariymN↓: (M, K:) [or the latter is a coll. gen. n., being used in a pl. sense:] one says OafoEaI SariymapK (S) or SariymK↓ (K) [A viper of a detached sand-heap or of detached sand-heaps]; like as one says HayRapu xalRK. (S in art. xl.)
And A group, or an assemblage, (S,) or a detached number, (M,) of the trees called gaDFA, and salam, (S, M,) and OaroTFI, and of palm-trees; and likewise SiromapN↓, of OaroTFI, and of samur. (M.)
See also SariymN, in two places.

Also (assumed tropical:) Decision, or determination, (S, M, K TA,) EalaI XaIoCK [to do a thing]: (S, TA:) and the deciding of an affair, (M, K, TA,) and the firm, or sound, execution thereof: (TA:) or an object of want upon accomplishment of which one has decided,
or determined; as also EaziymapN: (AHeyth, TA:) pl. SaraAYimu. (TA.) One says, huwa maADi AlSRariymapi and AlSRaraAYimi [He is effective of decision &c. and of decisions &c.]. (TA.)
See also SuromN.
SurayomapN A detached number [or a small detached number, for it is app. dim. of SiromapN,] of camels. (TA.)
SarRaAmN: see SaArimN.
Also A preparer, or seller, of Sarom, (MA,) whence it is derived, (Mgh,) i. e. skin, or leather: (MA:) or it signifies as expl. voce SiromN, last sentence. (TA.)

SaArimN Cutting; cutting through; or cutting off, or severing; and Sb says that SariymN↓ is used in the same sense, like as Dariyb in the phrase Dariybu qidaAHK is used in the sense of DaArib. (M.) Uino kunotumo SaArimiyna, in the Kur [lxviii. 22], means If ye be deciding, or determining, upon the cutting off of the fruit of the palm-trees. (TA.)

And (assumed tropical:) A man cutting, or severing, his bond of union; or one who cuts, or severs, that bond; and so [but in an intensive sense] SarRaAmN↓ and SaruwmN↓; (M;) or this last signifies, (M, K,) as also SuraAmN↓, (K,) having strength to cut, or sever, (M, K,) the bond of his union. (M.)
Also, applied to a sword, (S, M, Msb, K,) and [in an intensive sense] SaruwmN↓, (M, K,) Sharp, (S, M, Msb, K,) and not bending: (M:) pl. of the former SawaArimu. (TA.)

And the former, (S, M, K, TA,) applied to a man, (S, M, TA,) as being likened to a sword, (TA,) (tropical:) Hardy, strong, or sturdy, (S, TA,) or sharp, penetrating, or vigorous and effective, (M, K, TA,) and courageous. (S, M, K, TA.)
And AlSRaArimu (tropical:) The lion. (K, TA.)
SayoramN A calamity (K, TA) that extirpates everything. (TA. [See also SuraAmN, last sentence.])
Also Firm, or sound, of judgment. (K.)

And i. q. wajobapN, (S, M, K,) like SayolamN, (TA,) i. e. An eating once in the day: (M, K, * TA: *) or, accord. to Yaakoob, an eating at the time [of morning] called AlDRuHaI (M, TA) [and not again] to the like time of the morrow: (TA:) one says, fulaAnN yaOokulu AlSRayorama (S, M, * K *) i. e. [Such a one eats] once (K, TA) in the day: but AHát says, I asked El-Asma'ee respecting the bazomap and the Sayoram, and he said, I know it not: this is the language of the devil. (TA.)
OaSoramu A man having the extremity of his ear cut off. (Mgh.)
See also muSorimN.

Also [the fem.] SaromaMCu A she-camel having little milk; (M, K;) because her abundance of milk has become cut off: (M:) pl. SuromN. (K.) See also SuraAmN. [In the Ham, p. 230, it is implied that it signifies A she-camel such as is termed muSarRamapN↓ as meaning whose OaxolaAf (or teats) have been cut off: for it is there said that the poet 'Orweh has applied the term SaromaMC to (assumed tropical:) a cooking-pot, likening it to the she-camel termed muSarRamapN meaning as expl. above.]
Also, (S, K,) or falaApN SaromaMCu, (M,) A desert in which is no water. (S, M, K. [See also one of the explanations of the dual, here following.])

AlOaSoramaAni signifies The wolf and the crow; (ISk, S, M, K;) because of their separating themselves (ISk, S, M) from mankind: (ISk, S:) and the [bird called] Surad and the crow: and the night and the day; (K, TA;) because each is cut off from the other. (TA.) El-Marrár says,

[Upon a waterless desert, in which are its wolf and crow, and in which the skilful guide of the desert is burned by the sun]. (ISk, S, M.) And tarakotuhu biwaHoXi AlOaSoramayoni is a saying mentioned by Lh, but not expl. by him: (M, TA:) ISd says, (TA,) in my opinion it means, [I left him in] the desert, or waterless desert: (M, TA:) or, accord. to Z, in a desert, or waterless desert, in which was nothing but the wolf and the crow. (TA.)
maSorimN A narrow place, that quickly flows with water: (K, TA:) so called because the flow of water is quickly cut off from it. (TA.)
muSorimN A possessor of a Siromap of camels. (TA.)

And [hence], as also OaSoramu↓, (M, K,) Having little property: (M:) or poor, [and] having a numerous household, or family. (K.) One says, kalaON tiyjaEu minohu kabidu AlmuSorimi [Herbage by reason of which the liver of him who has little property is pained]; i. e., abundant, so that when he who has little property sees it, he grieves that he has not many camels which he may pasture upon it. (M.)
miSoramN The curved knife of the parer of spindles. (S, MA, K.)

muSarRamapN A she-camel whose [fore or kind] pair of teats have been cut off, (S, M, K,) in order that the UiHoliyl [or orifice through which the milk passes forth from the udder of each teat] may dry up and the milk not issue, for the purpose of giving greater strength to her: and (AA used to say, S) this is sometimes in consequence of the stoppage of the milk, something having happened to the udder, for which it is cauterized, and her milk stops, (S, K,) no milk ever issuing from the udder: (S:) see also SaromaMCu, voce OaSoramu: or muSarRamapu AlOaTobaMCi means a she-camel treated (Euwlijato) so that her milk has stopped. (Mgh.)
maSoruwmN: see SariymN, first and second sentences.

1. SariIa, (S, M, Msb,) aor.
SaraIa
, (Msb,) inf. n. SarFI, (M, Msb,) said of water, It remained, or stagnated, long: or it remained long, and became altered [for the worse]: (S, Msb:) or, said of water and of milk, it remained so that its flavour became altered [for the worse]: (M:) or, said of milk, it remained undrawn from the udder, so that its flavour became bad, or corrupt. (TA.) And SariIa AldRamoEu The tears collected [in the eye] and did not run. (TA.)

[Hence,] Sariyati AlnRaAqapu, (Fr, M, Msb, TA,) aor. as above, (Msb,) and so the inf. n.; (M, Msb, TA;) but Ibn-Buzurj says Sarat, aor.
SariIa
; (TA;) The she-camel's milk became collected in her udder; (M, Msb, TA;) as also OaSorat↓. (M, TA.)
And SariIa fiI yadihi, (S, M, IKtt, TA,) with kesr; (S, TA;) or SaraI fiI yadihi;) (thus accord. to the K;) He (a man) remained in his hand, as a pledge, (S, M, K, TA,) held in custody. (S, K, TA.)

And SirIi [thus written without any syll. sign, app. SriI,] i. q. AinoqaTaEa [It, or he, became cut off, cut short, or stopped; &c.: quasi-pass. of SaraAhu in one of the senses of the latter]: from IAar. (TA.)

SaraAhu, (IKtt, Msb, TA,) aor.
SariIa
, (Msb,) inf. n. SaroIN, (IKtt, Msb, TA,) He confined it, namely, water, in a resting-place or a vessel; and in like manner, milk, and tears: (IKtt, TA:) or he collected it, namely, water, and it remained long and became altered [for the worse], or remained or stagnated long; and in like manner, but in an intensive sense, SrRAhu↓. (Msb.) One says also of cows [and the like], taSoriI AllRabana fiI DuruwEihinRa They confine and collect the milk in their udders. (TA.) And [of a man] one says, SaraI AlmaMCa fiI Zahorihi zamaAnFA He retained the mAC [i. e. sperma] in his back a long time, (S, M, K, *) by abstaining from sexual intercourse. (M, K.)

[Hence,] SarayotuhaA, (M, Msb,) aor.
SariIa
, inf. n. SaroIN; (Msb;) and SarRayotuhaA↓, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. taSoriyapN, (S, Msb,) but the latter verb has an intensive meaning; (Msb;) and OaSorayotuhaA↓; (M;) namely, a ewe or she-goat, (S,) or a she-camel, (M, Msb,) and any other milch animal, (M,) I caused the milk to collect in her udder, (S, M, Msb,) by abstaining from milking her for some days. (S, M.)

Also, i. e. SaraAhu, (M, K,) aor.
SariIa
, (K,) inf. n. SaroIN, (M,) i. q. qaTaEahu [He cut it off, cut it short, or stopped it; &c.]; (M, K;) namely, a thing. (M.) You say, SaraI bawolahu, inf. n. as above, meaning qaTaEahu [He, or it, cut short, or stopped, his urine]. (S.) And Sarayotu AlmaMCa [app. I cut short, or stopped, the drawing of the water; for it is expl. as said] UicaA Qsotaqayota vumRa qaTaEota. (S.) And maA yaSoriyka minRiI OaIo EabodiI, occurring in a trad., means What cuts short (yaqoTaEu) thine asking of Me [O my servant]? (TA.)
And i. q. dafaEahu [He repelled it]. (M, K.) One says, SaraI QllRehu Eanohu XarRahu i. e. dafaEa [God repelled, or may God repel, from him his, or its, evil, or mischief]. (S.)
And i. q. manaEahu [He prevented it, &c.]. (S, M, K.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says,

L.foreign: hawaAhunRa Uino lamo yaSorihi QllRehu qaAtiluho

sense.s:
[And they bade farewell to one affected with desire, whose heart they had smitten; the love of them, if God had not prevented it, had been his slayer]. (S. [But this verse may be well rendered as an ex. of SaraAhu in the sense next following, which is also a meaning of manaEahu: in the M, it is
cited as an ex. of SaraAhu in the sense of dafaEahu.])
Said of God, (M,) He protected, defended, guarded, or preserved, him: (M, K:) or (M) He saved him (M, K) from destruction, or perdition: (K:) or (M) He sufficed him: (M, K:) or He aided him. (TA.)

SaraI bayonahumo, (K,) or SaraI maA bayonahumo, (S, M,) He decided [between them, or the case between them]; (S, K;) namely, persons who had applied to him as a judge: (S:) or he rectified, or adjusted, the case between them. (M.)

SaraI also signifies EaTafa [He bent, or inclined]: (K, TA:) [app. intrans., or trans. by means of bi, for] a poet uses the phrase Sarayona biAlOaEonaAqi [They bent, or inclined, with the necks]. (TA.) [But it is said in the TK that SaraAhu means EaTafahu He bent, or inclined, it.] Accord. to Ibn-Buzurj, Sarati AlnRaAqapu EunuqahaA means The she-camel raised her neck by reason of the heaviness of the burden. (TA.)
Also He preceded, or went before; syn. taqadRama. (IAar, K.) [Accord. to the TK, one says SaraI Alqawoma, meaning taqadRamahumo He preceded, or went before, the people, or party.]

And [the contr., i. e.] He receded, or retreated; or became, or remained, or lagged, behind; syn. taOaxRara. (IAar, K.) [Accord. to the TK, one says SaraI Eanohumo, meaning He receded, or retreated, from them; &c.].
Also He, or it, was, or became, high; syn. EalaA. (IAar, K.)
And the contr., i. e. He, or it, was, or became, low; syn. safula. (IAar, K.)
2: see 1, former half, in two places.
4: see 1, former half, in two places.

ASrI also signifies He sold a ewe or she-goat, (K, TA,) or a she-camel, (TA,) whose milk had been caused to collect in her udder in consequence of her not having been milked for some days; such as is termed muSarRaApN. (K, TA.)
8. AiSodaraAhu i. q. AizodaraAhu [the d in each being substituted for t]: see the latter, in art. zrI.

SarFI, (S, M, Msb, K,) an inf. n. used as an epithet, (Msb,) and SirFI↓, (S, M, K,) [and Freytag adds SurFI↓, as from the K, in which I do not find it,] Water remaining, or stagnating, long, accord. to Fr; (S;) or that has remained, or stagnated, long: (Msb:) or water remaining long, (K,) or that has remained long, and become altered [for the worse], (S, M, Msb,) accord. to AA. (S.) And the first, (M, K,) an inf. n. used as an epithet, (TA,) Milk that has remained (M, K) long (K) so that its flavour has become altered [for the worse]; (M, K;) as also SarK↓, which is in like manner applied to water: (M:) or milk left [long] in the udder of the camel, not drawn, so that it becomes salt and windy: (IAar, TA:) or milk drawn in the night from a camel abounding therewith, having a bad and burning flavour. (Az, TA.) And, (M, K,) some say, (M,) [used as a subst.,] A portion remaining (M, K) of milk (M) in the udder, (Ham p. 661,) and of water. (TA.) And Tears (damoEN) that have become collected: and the sing. [or epithet applied to a single tear (damoEapN)] is SaraApN. (M.) And nuTofapN SaraApN [Sperma of a man] altered [for the worse]: and long retained by him in his back. (M. [This is also mentioned in the S, app. in the latter of these senses; the meaning being there only indicated by the context.])
For the fem., SaraApN, see also muSarRaApN.
SurFI: see SarFI, first sentence:
and see also muSarRaApN.
SrFI: see SarFI, first sentence.

In relation to a she-camel it is Her being pregnant twelve months, and bringing forth, and then yielding her biestings, or having her biestings milked: mentioned by Az. (TA. [But what is meant by this is, to me, doubtful; for sometimes an inf. n., and sometimes and epithet, and sometimes a subst., is expl. in this manner.])
SarKi [part. n. of SariIa]: see SarFI.
Also A she-camel whose milk has collected in her udder. (Msb.) [See also muSarRaApN.]
SaroyapN Milk collected [in the udder]: a poet says,

L.foreign: wakulRu ciI SaroyapK laA budRa maHoluwbu

sense.s: [And whatever udder has milk must be milked]. (TA.)
SaroyaMCu: see muSarRaApN.
SaroyaAnu, applied to a man and to a beast, Whose maMC [i. e. sperma] has collected in his back. (TA.)
Also The [bird called] yamaAmap [n. un. of yamaAmN, q. v.]: and the [bird called] samaAmap [n. un. of samaAmN, q. v.]. (TA.)

SaraMCN Colocynths (S, M, K, in the CK [erroneously] SirACN [expressly said in the TA to be with fet-h and medd,]) when they become yellow; (S, M;) as also SaraAyaAtN: (so in one of my copies of the S [in which it is shown to be correct by an ex. in a verse of Suleyk there cited: in the M and TA SaraAyaA, which I think a mistranscription]: in the other of my copies of the S omitted:) one thereof is termed SaraAyapN↓. (S, M, K. *) [In the M and K, SaraMCN is termed pl. of SaraAyapN; but it is properly speaking a coll. gen. n., originally SaraAIN.]
SaraAyapN↓ also signifies The water in which colocynths have been steeped. (M, K.)
SariIRN One who acts with boldness towards the wife of his father: (K, TA:) such was Ibn-Mukbil. (TA.)
SaraAyapN: see SaraMCN, in two places.
SurRaI: see muSarRaApN, below.
SaArK [act. part. n. of SaraI: as such signifying] Guarding or preserving [&c.], or a guarder or preserver [&c.]. (TA.)
[Hence,] A sailor: (S, M, K:) because he guards, or preserves, the ship: (TA:) pl. SurRaMCN (S, M, K) and (M, K) pl. pl. (M) SaraAriIRu and SaraAriyRuwna. (M, K. [But see SaraAriIRN in art. Sr.])

Also [said to signify] The transverse piece of wood in the middle of the ship: (M, K:) [but] IAth says that it is the daqal [i. e. mast] of the ship, which is set up in the middle thereof, and upon which is the XiraAE [or sail: it is now commonly called SaAriyapN↓ and saAriyapN: both of which are also sometimes applied to a column]: pl. SawaArK. (TA.)
SaAriyapN A well (rakiyRapN) of which the water is old, altered for the worse, and overspread with [the green substance termed] EaromaD: (K, * TA:) mentioned by Az. (TA.)
See also SaArK, last sentence.

muSarRaApN A ewe, or she-goat, whose milk has been caused to collect in her udder by her not having been milked for some days; (S, K;) as also SurRaI↓, like rubRaI; (so in copies of the K; [but this, if correct, should be mentioned in art. Sr, in which the former is also mentioned; accord. to the TA, however, it seems to be SurFI↓, without teshdeed, for it is there said to be like rubI;]) both likewise applied to a she-camel, and to a cow; (TA;) and SaraApN↓ signifies the same, (K,) applied to a she-camel and to a ewe or she-goat; (TA;) and so, applied to a she-camel, SaroyaMCu↓, of which the pl. is SaraAyaA, (M, K,) an irreg. pl. (M.) [See also SarK.]
Aboo-'Alee, in the Bári', makes it syn. with maSoruwrapN; and so says the Imám EshSháfi'ee; as though originally muSarRarapN: but Suh, in the R, disallows this. (TA.)
OaSaATibu is the pl., and OuSayoTibN is the dim., of UiSoTabolN, q. v. (TA in art. ASTbl.)
OuSoTubRapN [i. q. OusoTubRapN, q. v.;] Tow; i. e. what falls from flax in the process of combing. (M, K.)
mSTb [app. a mistranscription for miSoTabapN↓ or maSoTabapN, like masoTabapN, q. v.,] A blacksmith's anvil: so in the T, on the authority of IAar. (TA.)

miSoTabapN (so in copies of the K) [and maSoTabapN, like masoTabapN], or miSoTabRapN, (so accord. to the TA, with teshdeed to the b, [but the word is of frequent occurrence and commonly written without tesh-deed,]) A place where people assemble, (AHeyth, TA,) like a dukRaAn, [i. e. a kind of wide bench, of stone or brick &c., generally built against a wall,] for the purpose of sitting upon it: (AHeyth, K, TA:) Az heard an Arab of the desert, of the tribe of Fezárah, apply this word to a square, flat-topped pile of earth, raised for the purpose of passing the night upon it: (TA:) also, [sometimes, app. in late ages,] a hospice for strangers; or a place in which the poor and the beggars assemble: (MA, and Har p. 375:) not [originally, or properly,] an Arabic word: (Har ubi suprà:) [see more in art. sTb, for it is a dial. var. of masoTabapN,] of the dial. of Baghdád: (MA:) [the pl. is maSaATibu.]
See also the next preceding paragraph.

1. SaEuba, (S, A, MA, Msb, K,) aor.
SaEuba
, (A, K,) inf. n. SuEuwbapN; (S, MA, Msb, K;) and AstSEb↓;
(S, A, MA, Msb, K;) and ASEb↓, (IAar, K,) inf. n. UiSoEaAbN; (IAar, TA;) It (a thing, Msb, or an affair, or event, S, MA, Msb, K) was, or became, SaEob, (S, A, &c.,) i. e. difficult, hard, hard to be done or accomplished, hard to be borne or endured, or distressing. (A, MA, K.) One says, Ealayohi AlOamoru AstSEb↓, (S, MA, Msb,) like SaEuba, (S, Msb,) The affair, or event, was, or became, difficult, &c., to him. (MA.)
2. SERbhu, (K,) inf. n. taSoEiybN; (TA;) [and] ASEbhu↓, (A,) inf. n. UiSoEaAbN; (KL;) and tSERbhu↓; (K;) He made, or rendered, it SaEob, (A, K,) i. e. difficult, hard, &c. (A, K, KL.)
4. ASEb: see 1.

Said of a camel, He was, or became, SaEob [meaning refractory, or untractable]: (K, TA:) [and in like manner one says AstSEb↓: (see its contr. AstSHb:) and tSERb↓, which is also said of a man:] and ASEb said of a camel, he was unridden, (A, TA,) and untouched by a rope. (A.)
Also, said of a man, His camel was, or became, refractory, or untractable. (L, TA.)
ASEbhu: see 2.
Also He left him (i. e. a camel) unridden, (S, K, TA,) and untouched by a rope, so that he became refractory, or untractable. (S, K.) [See muSoEabN].

And He found it (i. e. an affair, or event, S, Msb, or a thing, K) to be SaEob [i. e. difficult, hard, &c.]; (S, Msb, K;) as also AstSEbhu↓: (Msb, K:) or both signify he saw it, or held it, to be so. (TA.) [See an ex. of the former in a verse cited voce rayovN.]
5. tSERb, intrans.: see 4.
tSERbhu: see 2.
10. AstSEb, intrans.: see 1, in two places:
and see also 4.
AstSEbhu: see 4.

SaEobN Difficult, hard, hard to be done or accomplished, hard to be borne or endured, or distressing; (A, MA, K;) contr. of saholN; (Mgh, TA;) as also SuEobuwbN↓: (T, O, K, TA:) pl. of the former SiEaAbN; (Msb;) and of ↓the latter, SaEaAbiybu. (T, TA.) One says OamorN SaEobN A difficult, hard, or distressing, affair or event. (A.) And EaqabapN SaEobapN (thus in the A, but in the Msb and TA without any syll. signs,) [A mountainroad] difficult, hard, or distressing: (TA:) pl. EiqaAbN SiEaAbN (A, Msb *) and SaEobaAtN with sukoon [to the E because the word is an epithet; for if it were a subst., it would be SaEabaAtN]. (Msb.) [Or EuqobapN SaEobapN may perhaps be meant in the TA, i. e. A difficult, hard, or distressing, stage of a journey.]

Also Refractory, untractable, incompliant, obstinate, or stubborn; (K, * TA;) contr. of caluwlN; (S, A, TA;) applied to a camel, (S, A,) or to a beast; (TA;) [and to a man;] fem. SaEobapN, (S, TA,) which is applied to a woman: (S:) and the pl. of this is SiEaAbN, [as of the masc.,] (TA,) and SaEobaAtN, applied to women, with sukoon [to the E because the word is an epithet]. (S, TA.) rakiba AlnRaAsu AlSRaEobapa waAlcRaluwla, occurring in a trad. of I'Ab, [lit. The people rode the refractory and the tractable she-camel,] means (assumed tropical:) the people entered upon difficult and easy affairs; i. e. they cared not for things, nor were cautious respecting what they said and did. (L, TA.)
[Hence,] AlSRaEobu The lion; (O, K;) because of his untractableness. (TA.)
SuEobuwbN: see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence, in two places.
SaAEibN Land containing stones such as fill the hand, and other stones, which is tilled, or cultivated. (K, TA.)

muSoEabN A stallion [of camels]: (S, K:) and a camel, (S, A,) or a stallion [of camels], (ISk, TA,) left unridden, and untouched by a rope, (ISk, S, A, TA,) so as to become refractory, or untractable: (S:) or an unbroken camel, upon whose back nothing is allowed to be put: (L, TA:) pl. maSaAEibu and maSaAEiybu. (ISk, TA.)

It is also applied as an epithet to a man, (A, Msb, TA,) meaning masawRadN [i. e. (assumed tropical:) Made a chief or lord &c.]: (TA:) pl. maSaAEibu. (A, Msb.) One says, fulaAnN muSoEabN mina AlmaSaAEibi (tropical:) [Such a man is one of those who have been made chiefs or lords &c.]; like as one says, qaromN mina Alquruwmi. (A.)
muSoEibN A man whose camel is refractory, or untractable: occurring in a trad. (L, TA.)

SaEotarN I. q. saEotarN [q. v.]: (K, and S and Msb in art. sEtr:) it grows in the country of the Arabs, and is of two kinds, suholiIRN [i. e. of the plain] and jabaliIRN [i. e. of the mountain]: (AHn, TA:) when strewn in a place, it drives away venomous or noxious reptiles and the like, (K,) such as serpents and scorpions. (TA.)

1. SaEida fiI AlsRulRami, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
SaEada
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. SuEuwdN (S, Msb, K) and SaEadN and SuEudN; (Ham p. 407;) and tSERd↓, (A,) or AiSRaERada, (L,) inf. n. AiSRaERudN; (K;) and tSAEd↓, (A,) or AiSRaAEada, (L,) inf. n. AiSRaAEudN; (K;) and ASTEd↓; (K;) He ascended, or went up, the ladder, or stair: (L, Msb, K:) and so the verb is used of ascending a thing similar to a ladder, or stair: but in a case of this kind one should not say ASEd. (L.) And SaEida AlsRaToHa and UilaI AlsRaToHi (A, Msb) He ascended, or ascended to, the flat house-top. (Msb.) And SaEida AlmakaAna, and fiI AlmakaAni, and ASEd↓, and SERd↓, He ascended the place, or upon the place. (L.) And fiI SERd↓ Aljabali, (S, A, Msb, K,) and EalaI Aljabali, inf. n. taSoEiydN; (S, K;) and SaEida fiyhi, a form rarely used, (Msb,) disallowed by AZ, (S, TA,) and said by him to have been unknown, (S,) or unheard, (K,) but he afterwards authorized it, and it is also authorized by IAar and ISk, (TA,) and SaEida Aljabala; (S in art. dxl; [for SaEida fiI Aljabali, see daxalotu Albayota;]) and fiyhi tSERd↓, (MF, from a trad.,) and AiSRaERada fiyhi, (AZ,) inf. n. AiSRiERaAdN; (TA; [app. a mistranscription for AiSRaERudN; or AiSRaERada may be a mistranscription for AiSRaEada↓, a var. of AiSoTaEada, and its inf. n. is AiSRiEaAdN;]) He ascended the mountain. (Msb, K.) And fiI AlOaroDi SERd↓ He ascended the land. (AZ, TA.) One says, TaAla fiI AlOaroDi taSowiybiI wataSoEiydiI↓ [Long have continued my descending, or going down, and my ascending, or going up, in the land]. (A. [There immediately following SaERada fiI Aljabali, expl. above: see also rakabN muSaERidN.])
See also 4, last sentence.
2. SERd, inf. n. taSoEiydN, as intrans.: see above, in four places.
And see also 4, in four places.

SERdhu He made him, or caused him, to ascend, or mount; syn. EalRaAhu; (K and TA in art. Elw;) and raqRaAhu; (TA in art. rqI;) [and so ASEdhu↓; and AstSEdhu↓; like as one says in the contr. sense nazRalahu and Oanozalahu and Aisotanozalahu.] You say, SERdhu jabalFA and daAbRapN [He made him to ascend, or mount, a mountain and a beast]. (TA in art. Elw.) And fiI Aljabali yuSoEiduwnahaA↓ is said with reference to wild bulls or cows [as meaning They make them to ascend upon the mountain]. (S and TA in art. slE.)

[Hence,] one says also, SaERada fiIRa AlnRaZara waSawRabahu, meaning (assumed tropical:) He looked at me from head to foot, contemplating me. (L, from a trad. [And a similar phrase occurs in Har p. 640.])

[SERdhu, inf. n. taSoEiydN, (the latter as used in the K voce kaAfuwrN,) also signifies (assumed tropical:) He sublimated it: often occurring in medical books, and used in this sense in the present day.]
And taSoEiydN signifies also The act of liquifying, melting, or dissolving. (K.)
See also 4, last sentence.
4. ASEd fiI AlmakaAni: see 1.

[Hence,] ASEd fiI AlOaroDi He went through the land towards a land higher than the other [from which he came]: (A, TA:) taken from the saying of Lth, that ASEd, inf. n. UiSoEaAdN, signifies He went towards a declivity, or a river, or a valley, higher than the other [from which he came]. (TA.) And ASEd fiI AlbilaAdi He went up, or upwards, through the countries, or lands. (AA, Msb.) And ASEd mino baladi kacaA UilaI baladi kacaA He journeyed [upwards] from such a region, or town, to such another region, or town; from one that was lower to one that was higher. (Msb.) [And hence,] ASEd, inf. n. UiSoEaAdN, He journeyed, or went, towards Nejd, and El-Hijáz, and El-Yemen: [or towards a higher region:] and AinoHadara signifies “ he journeyed, or went, towards El-'Irák, and Syria, and 'Omán: ” (ISk, on the authority of 'Omárah:) or the former, he journeyed, or went, towards the Kibleh: and the latter, “ he journeyed, or went, towards El-'Irák: ” (Aboo- Sakhr, T:) or the former, he came to Mekkeh; (K;) but this is a defective explanation: (TA:) and muSoEadN, also, is used as an inf. n. of this verb; and munoHadarN, as an inf. n. of AnHdr: (T, TA:) or ASEd, inf. n. UiSoEaAdN, he commenced a journey, or went forth; as from Mekkeh, and from ElKoofeh to Khurásán, and the like: (Fr:) or he
commenced a journey, or the like, in any direction: and AnHdr signifies “ he returned, from any town or country. ” (Ibn-'Arafeh.) And ASEd fiI AlOaroDi, (Akh, S, K,) or fI AlbilaAdi, (Akh accord. to the T,) He went away, and journeyed, through the land, (Akh, S, K,) or through the countries, (Akh, T,) in any direction. (L.) And ASEdt AlsRafiynapu, inf. n. UiSoEaAdN; (L;) or SERdt↓; (A;) The ship spread her sail, and was borne along by the wind, (A, L,) upwards [app. meaning up a river or the like]. (L.)

ASEd fiI AlwaAdiI; (Akh, S, L, K;) and fiyhi SERd↓, inf. n. taSoEiydN; (Akh, S, Msb, K;) and AiSRaERada↓, (Lth,) but this last is disapproved by Az; (TA;) He descended, or went down, into the valley, (Akh, S, L, Msb, K,) from the part whence the torrent comes; not going to the bottom of the valley: and in like manner, ASEd fiI AlOaroDi He descended, or went down, into the land: (L:) and fiI Aljabali SERd↓ He descended the mountain; as well as he ascended it. (IB, L.) Akh cites the following words of 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Hemmám Es-Saloolee,

(S, L,) as meaning I descending, or going down, at one time, through the countries, and [another time] ascending, or going up: this, says IB, is what induced Akh to explain SERd as he has done; but it presents no proof, because UiforaAEN has two contr. significations, that of UiSoEaAdN and that of AinoHidaArN: and accord. to AZ, by OuSaERidu the poet means I ascending, or going up, to high places; and by OuforiEu, the contrary. (L.)
ASEd also signifies He advanced towards another. (L.)
And He went far; syn. OaboEada. (Ham p. 22.)
And ASEd fiI AlEadowi He exerted himself vehemently in running. (L.)
ASEd as trans.: see 2, in two places.
ASEdt She (a camel) became such as is termed SaEuwd [q. v.]. (S, L, K.)
And OaSoEadotu AlnRaAqapa, (S, L, K,) and SaEadotuhaA↓, [probably imperfectly transcribed for SaERadotuhaA↓,] (L,) I made the she-camel to be, or became, such as is termed SaEuwd. (IAar, S, L, K.)
5. tSERd, and its var. AiSRaERada: see 1, in two places:
and see also 4.
tSERd AlnRafasu The breath passed forth with difficulty. (L.)

tSERdhu (S, A, K) and tSAEdhu↓ (A, K) It (a thing, S, K, or an affair, A) was, or became, difficult, or distressing, to him; it distressed, or afflicted, him: (A'Obeyd, S, A, K:) from SaEuwdN as signifying “ a mountain-road difficult of ascent: ” (A' Obeyd:) or from AlSRaEuwdN as the name of “ a certain mountain in Hell. ” (TA.)
6. tSAEd, and its var. AiSRaAEada: see 1:
and see also 5.
8. ASTEd, and its var. AiSRaEada: see 1, in two places.
10. AstSEdhu: see 2.
AstSEd Albariyra He plucked or gathered, the fruit of the OaraAk to eat. (TA in art. br.)
SuEodN: see SuEudN.
SaEadN: see SaEuwdN, in two places.

EacaAbN SaEadN A vehement, severe, rigorous, or grievous, punishment; (S, A, K;) i. e. cuw SaEadK: (TA:) or a distressing, or an afflicting, punishment, (Bd and Jel in lxxii. 17,) that shall overcome the sufferer thereof, the latter word being an inf. n. used as an epithet. (TA.)

SuEudN an inf. n. of SaEida [q. v.]. (Ham p. 407.) [Hence,] cahaba AlsRahomu SuEudFA [The arrow went upwards]. (A.) And hecaA AlnRabaAtu yanomiI SuEudFA This plant increases in height. (S.) And tanafRasa SuEudFA: see SuEadaMCu. And mino SuEodK↓ [used by poetic license for mn SuEudK], said of a thing falling, i. e. From above; from a higher place. (Ham p. 349.)
Also a pl. of SaEuwdN: and of SaEiydN. (S, L, K.)
SuEudN, thus, with two dammehs, is also the name of A certain tree from which pitch is melted forth. (L.)
SaEodapN A high, or an elevated, piece of land or ground; contr. of haboTapN. (Mgh in art. hbT.) And SaEodapu is said to be a proper name for The earth. (Ham p.22.)

And A she-ass: (L, K:) or a long-backed she-ass: (L:) or long [in the back], applied to a she-ass as an epithet, and therefore the pl. is SaEodaAtN, with the E quiescent. (Ham p. 385.) And banaAtu SaEodapa Wild asses: (S, K:) said to be so called from SaEodapu meaning as expl. above; and if this be correct, it is like the appellation banaAtu AlbarRi: (Ham p. 22:) or as being likened to the women [or rather woman (as will be shown in what follows)] termed SEdp; and in like manner, OawolaAdu SaEodapa: (Har p. 471:) the rel. n. [applied to a single wild ass] is SaAEidiIRN↓, (S, L, K,) irregularly formed: thus in the saying of Aboo-Dhu-eyb,
[And he shot, and made a far-flying arrow to reach a wild ass in the flank, and the ribs enclosed it]. (S, L.)

And A spear, or spear-shaft; syn. qanaApN: (L:) a spear-shaft (qanaApN) straight by its growth, (S, L, K,) not requiring to be straightened: (S, L:) and a kind of OalRap [or broad-headed dart], which is smaller than a Harobap: (L:) or [simply] an OalRap: (K, TA:) [in the CK Aelap: and] in some copies of the K Oakamap, which is a mistranscription: (TA:) pl. SiEaAdN and SaEadaAtN; (L;) the latter with fet-h to the E because it is a subst. (Ham p. 385.) One says, taTaAEanuwA biAlSRiEaAdi i. e. [They thrust, or pierced, one another] with the spears. (A.)

[Hence,] jaAriyapN SaEodapN (tropical:) A girl, or young woman, straight in figure, (A, L,) like a spear, or spear-shaft: (L:) pl. jawaArK SaEodaAtN, the latter word with the E quiescent, (A, L,) because it is an epithet. (L.)
SuEodapN: see SaEiydN, last sentence but one.
SaEodaMCu: see SaEuwdN, in two places.

SuEadaMCu A sigh, or sighing; a breathing with an expression of pain, grief, or sorrow: or with difficulty: (L:) a long breathing: (K:) or a prolonged breathing: (S:) or a loud breathing: (A:) accord. to some, a breathing emitted upwards. (L.) You say, tanafRasa AlSRuEadaMCa, (L,) or tnfRs SuEadaMCa, (A,) and tnfRs SuEudFA↓, (L,) He sighed; uttered a sigh or sighing; or breathed with an expression of pain, grief, or sorrow: (L:) [or uttered a prolonged breathing:] or breathed loudly. (A.)

[Hence,] fulaAnN yatobaEu SuEadaMCahu, (A,) or yatatabRaEu SuEudaMCahu, (L, [in which the noun is evidently mistranscribed,]) (tropical:) Such a one raises his head, and does not stoop it, by reason of pride: (A:) or does not raise his head nor stoop it. (L. [The former explanation seems to be the right.])
See also SaEuwdN, in four places.
SuEodudN: see the next paragraph.

SaEuwdN An acclivity; contr. of habuwTN, (S, L, K,) or of HaduwrN; (Msb;) and SaEadN↓ is [syn. therewith, being] contr. of SababN: (L:) pl. SaEaAYidu and SuEudN. (S, K.) An ascending road: of the fem. gender: pl. [of pauc.] OaSoEidapN and [of mult.] SuEudN. (L.) A mountain-road difficult of ascent; (S, A, L, K;) as also SaEuwdaMCu↓, (L, K,) and SuEadaMCu↓: (L in art. kOd:) a difficult place of ascent. (L in that art.) [Hence,] AlSRaEuwdu A certain mountain in Hell, (L, K, MF,) consisting of fire, which the unbeliever will ascend during a period of seventy years, after which he will fall down it, and thus he will do for ever: (MF:) it is of one live coal; the unbeliever will be compelled to ascend it, and will be beaten with maqaAmiE [pl. of miqomaEapN, q. v.]; and whenever he puts his leg upon it, it will dissolve as high as the lower part of his hip, and will then become replaced whole and sound. (L.)

[Hence also,] (tropical:) Difficulty, grievousness, distress, affliction, or trouble; (A, L, Msb;) as also SaEadN↓ (L) and SaEodaMCu↓, (K,) or SuEadaMCu↓, (L,) and SuEodudN↓. (K.) You say, Oarohaqotuhu SaEuwdFA (tropical:) I made him, or constrained him, to do a difficult, grievous, distressing, afflicting, or troublesome, thing: (A:) or I imposed upon him such a punishment. (L.) And lilsRiyaAdapi SaEodaMCu↓ [or SuEadaMCu↓? (see above)] (tropical:) There is a difficult, or distressing, ascent to lordship, or mastery. (A.) And OakamapN caAtu SuEadaMCa↓ (assumed tropical:) A hill difficult to ascend. (L.)

Also A she-camel that brings forth a young one imperfectly formed, (As, S, K,) after six or seven months, (As,) and is made to take an affection to the young one of the preceding year, (As, S,) or and takes an affection to the young one of the preceding year: (K:) or a she-camel whose young one dies, and which returns to her former young one, and yields it milk: when she does this, her milk is the sweeter: (Lth:) or a she-camel that brings forth her young one after its hair has grown, and then takes an affection to her former young one, or to the young one of another: pl. SaEaAYidu and SuEudN; but this latter pl. is disapproved by Sb. (L.)

SaEiydN High, or elevated, land or ground: or high, or elevated, land or ground, above such as is low, or depressed: or even land or ground:
(L:) or even land or ground, without any trees: (Lth, L:) or a [desert such as is termed] SaHoraMC: (A:) or the surface of the earth; (Th, Zj, S, A, Msb, K;) whether it be dust or earth, or otherwise: Zj says, I know not any difference of opinion among the lexicologists on this point: (Msb:) [such is said to be its meaning in the Kur iv. 46 and v. 9; and therefore in performing the act termed AltRayamRam,] a man should strike his hands upon the surface of the earth, and not care whether there be in chat place dust or not: (Zj:) [hence] one says, TaAra Siytuka fiI Alqariybi waAlbaEiydi wabalaga munotahaI AlSRaEiydi [Thy fame has flown through the near and the distant regions, and reached the extremity of the surface of the earth]: (A:) or SaEiydN signifies the earth, or ground, itself; (IAar, A, L;) as in the saying Ealayoka biAlSRaEiydi, meaning Sit thou upon the earth, or ground: (A:) or good earth or land: or earth, or land, not mixed with sand nor with salt soil: (L:) or dust, or earth, (Fr, S, L, Msb, K,) such as is pure, upon the surface of the ground or that has come forth from within it; thus accord. to Az in the Kur iv. 46 and v. 9, in the opinion of most of the learned: (Msb:) or only earth containing dust; not applied to a coarse, nor to a fine, baToHaMC; nor to a coarse kaviyb; although it be mixed with dust: (Esh-Sháfi'ee, L:) pl. SuEudN and SuEudaAtN, (S, L, K,) the latter a pl. pl. (Msb, TA.)
And A wide, or an ample, place. (L.)

And A road, (L, Msb, K,) whether wide or narrow: (L:) pls. as above (L, Msb) and SuEodaAnN. (L.) It is said in a trad., UiyRaAkumo waAlquEuwda biAlSRuEudaAti UilRaAmano OadRaI HaqRahaA, i. e. Beware ye of sitting in, or by, the roads, save he who performs the duty relating thereto: [respecting which duty see TariyqN:] SuEudaAt is here the pl. of SuEudN, which is pl. of SaEiydN: or, as some say, it is pl. of SuEodapN↓, which signifies A court, or an open space, before the door of a house, and the place through which men pass in front of it. (L.)
Also A grave. (AA, Mtr, L, K.)
UinRahaA lafiI SaEiydapi baAzilayohaA (tropical:) Verily she (a camel) is near to cutting her two teeth called the baAzilaAni. (L, TA.)
SaEuwdaMCu: see SaEuwdN.
SuEaAdiyRapN, applied to a she-camel, Tall, or long; syn. TawiylapN. (K.)
SaERaAdN EalaI AljibaAli One who climbs the mountains much or often. (TA in art. rqI.)
SaAEidN [Ascending, &c.].
[Hence,] EunuqN SaAEidN (tropical:) A tall neck. (A, L.)
And XarafN SaAEidN (tropical:) [High nobility]. (A.)

[Hence also,] one says, balaga kacaA faSaAEidFA (tropical:) It reached such an amount and upwards: (K, TA:) and Oaxacotuhu bidirohamK faSaAEidFA (tropical:) I got it for a dirhem and upwards; an elliptical phrase, for Oaxacotuhu bidirohamK fazaAda AlvRamanu SaAEidFA I got it for a dirhem and the price increased upwards, or cahaba SaAEidFA went upwards: you may not say waSaAEidFA, because you do not mean to tell that the dirhem with something more made the price, as when you say bidirohamK waziyaAdapK; but you mention the lowest price that you offered, and mean that you then offered more and more. (Sb, L.) And qaraOa faAtiHapa AlkitaAbi faSaAEidFA (assumed tropical:) He read the opening chapter of the Book [i. e. of the Kur-án] and more is a phrase of the same kind. (L.)
SaAEidiIRN rel. n. of SaEodapu, q. v.

maSoEadN [A place of ascent: pl. maSaAEidu]. One says rutobapN baEiydapu AlmaSoEadi and AlmaSaAEidi (tropical:) [meaning A station, or post of honour, to which the ascent and ascents (lit. the place and places of ascent) is, and are, distant]. (A.)
muSaERadN A high mountain. (L.) And rakabN muSaERadN, or muSaERidN↓, A high, or prominent, pubes. (L.)
Also Beverage, or wine, (K,) and vinegar, (TA,) prepared with pains by means of fire, or well boiled, (Euwlija biAlnRaAri, K, TA,) until it becomes altered in flavour and colour. (TA.)
muSaERidN: see the next preceding paragraph.
miSoEaAdN The [rope called] HaAbuwl, [made in the form of a hoop,] by means of which a man ascends palm-trees. (K, * TA.)
[And A scaling-ladder.
And, accord. to Freytag, A chain with which the feet of captives are shackled, to prevent their taking wide steps:
and A chain upon the feet of women, serving as an ornament: in relation to which he refers to Schröder de vestitu mulierum Hebr. p. 123.]

1. SaEira, aor.
SaEara
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. SaEarN; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) and tSERr↓; (A, K;) He had a wryness, or distortion, in the cheek, (S,) or in the face, (A, K,) or in either side [thereof], (K,) or in the neck, (Lth, A, Mgh, Msb,) by reason of pride, (A,) with a turning of the face on one side: (Lth, Mgh, Msb:) [see also 5:] or he (a camel) had a disorder by reason of which he twisted his neck, (K,) and distorted it. (TA.) You say, fiI Eunuqihi waxadRihi SaEarN In his neck, and in his cheek, is a wryness, or distortion, arising from pride. (A.) And laOuqiymanRa SaEaraka [I will assuredly straighten thy wryness, or distortion, of the neck, or cheek]. (A.) And OaSaAba AlbaEiyra SaEarN A disease which made him to twist his neck befell the camel. (Mgh, TA.)
[See also SaEarN below.]
Also SaEira, (TK,) inf. n. SaEarN, (K, TK,) He (a man, TK) ate SaEaAriyr [pl. of SuEoruwrN, q. v.], (K, * TK,) i. e., gum. (TA.)
2. SERrhu He caused him to have a wryness, or distortion, in the neck, and a turning of the face on one side, by something smiting or befalling him. (Msb.)

SERr xadRahu, (inf. n. taSoEiyrN, K,) and SAErhu↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) and ASErhu↓, (K,) He turned away his cheek (S, A, Msb) from the people, (Msb,) by reason of pride (S, A, Msb) and dislike; (S, Msb;) he turned away his cheek from looking towards the people, by reason of contempt arising from pride. (K.) It is said in the Kur [xxxi. 17], walaA tuSaERiro xadRaka lilnRaAsi, (Mgh, TA,) and accord. to one reading, laA tuSaAEiro↓, (TA,) meaning, And turn thou not away from people through pride. (Fr, Aboo-Is-hák, Mgh.) [See also 5.]
3: and 4: see 2; the former in two places.
5. tSERr and tSAEr↓ He distorted his cheek by reason of pride. (Sgh, TA.) See also 1.
6: see what next precedes.
9. ASErRt AlUibilu The camels went a vehement pace: or became dispersed. (TA.)
R. Q. 1. SaEorarahu, (S, K,) inf. n. SaEorarapN, (TA,) He made it round: (S, K:) he rolled it. (TA.) [See muSaEorarN.]
R. Q. 2. taSaEorara It became round: (S, K:) it rolled. (TA.)

R. Q. 3. AiSoEanorara, and AiSoEarRara, (K,) in which latter the n is incorporated into the r, (TA,) He (being beaten or struck) writhed, (TA,) and turned round by reason of pain, in his place, and became contracted. (K, TA.)
SaEarN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.].

The saying fiI AlSRaEari AldRiyapu is expl. as meaning In [the case of] the distorting of the face [the whole bloodwit shall be exacted: as though the verb of which SaEarN is the inf. n. were trans.; but this is obviously a loose rendering]. (Mgh.)
SaEarN also signifies Pride: (Mgh:) or the being proud. (TA.)
And Smallness of the head: (K:) or the being small, said of a man's head: (K, * TA:) one says, SaEira raOosuhu, inf. n. SaEarN, meaning his head was small. (TK.)

SuEoruwrN (S, K, & c.) and SuEurRurN↓ (Sgh, K) Long, slender, twisted gum: (K:) or a piece of gum having a long and twisted form: (AZ, S:) and [gum of the kind called] lavFI that has become concrete: (K:) or this is the signification of SaEaAriyru, (S, K,) which is the pl. [of SErwr], (TA,) accord. to AA: (S:) or the pl. signifies concrete gum resembling fingers: and SErwr is said to signify a piece of gum: accord. to Aboo-Nasr, it is like a read-pen, and twisting like a horn: and AHn says that SuEoruwrapN, with p, signifies a small round piece of gum: (TA:) and the fruit, (K,) or any fruit, (TA,) of a tree that is like (that of, TA) the Oabohal, and like pepper, and what resembles this, of such as are hard: (K, TA:) or such they term SaEaAriyru: (TA:) or gum in general: pl. SaEaAriyru. (K.)

Also, (K,) or SuEoruwrN [only], (TA,) (assumed tropical:) A certain substance, yellow, [in the CK ASgr is put for ASfr,] thick, tough with [somewhat of] softness and moisture, that comes forth from the teat: (K:) so called by way of comparison: (TA:) or what is first milked, of biestings: (K:) or milk that is gummy (muSomigN), in biestings, before it becomes clear. (TA.)
SuEoruwrapN The little ball which is rolled along by the [kind of beetle called] juEal. (K, TA.)
SaEaAriyru (assumed tropical:) Long fingers. (TA.)
SuEurRurN: see the next preceding paragraph.

SaERaArN Proud, or haughty: because he declines with his cheek, and turns away his face from people: occurring in a trad.: or the word as there used is SaqRaArN, or DafRaAzN, accord. to different relaters. (TA.)
SayoEariIRN applied to a camel's hump, Great, or large, (K, TA,) and round. (TA.)
And OaHomaru SayoEariIRN Intensely red. (K.)
SayoEariyRapN Obliquity in going or march or course: (S, K:) from SaEarN [inf. n. of SaEira]. (S.)

Also A mark made with a hot iron upon the neck of a camel: (S:) or of a she-camel (K) only: (TA:) a mark of the people of El-Yemen, only made upon she-camels: (Tedhkireh of Aboo-'Alee:) not upon a camel whether male or female, (K,) as it is said to be by A'Obeyd [and J]. (TA.) J was led into error by a verse of El-Museiyab (K) Ibn 'Alas; wherein he uses the phrase binaAjK Ealayohi AlSRayoEariyRapu [With a swift he-camel marked with the SyEryRp]; (TA;) on hearing which, Tarafeh (K) Ibn-El-'Abd (TA) said, qadi Qsotanowaqa Aljamalu [The male camel has assumed the characteristic of the female camel]. (K, TA.) El-Bedr El-Karáfee urges that the term baEiyr, used by J, includes the female; and that the masc. epithet [naAjK] is used [by the poet] because the male is the more honourable, being more hardy, and stronger than the female: but this demands consideration. (TA.)

OaSoEaru Having a wryness, or distortion, in the cheek, (S,) or in the face, (A, K,) or in either side [thereof], (K,) or in the neck, (A, Msb,) by reason of pride, (A,) with a turning of the face on one side: (Msb:) or a camel having a disorder by reason of which he twists his neck, (K,) and distorts it: (TA:) sometimes the being so is natural (S, A, Msb, K) in a man (S, Msb) and in an ostrich; (S, A, Mgh;) and sometimes it is accidental: (Msb:) pl. SuEorN. (TA.)

It occurs in a trad. as signifying Such as withdraws himself [from others, through pride]; syn. caAhibN binafosihi: (S, TA: [thought by Ibr D to be a mistake for zaAhK binafosihi: but this seems to me improbable:]) or such as turns away his face, by reason of pride: (IAth:) and in another trad. as signifying such as turns away from the truth, and is faulty. (TA.)

muSoEarRN, (S,) in the K muSoEarN, said to be like mukoramN, but the former is the right, as is shown by the ex. below, (TA,) applied to a night-journey to water, Hard, or severe. (S, K.) A poet says,
[And they had performed a hard night-journey to water]. (S, TA.)
muSaEorarN [Made round: and simply, round]. A rájiz says,
[Black, like the round grains of pepper]. (S.)

1. SaEaTahu, aor.
SaEaTa
and
SaEuTa
, (K,) inf. n. SaEoTN and SuEuwTN, (TA,) a dial. var. of saEaTahu; and so is ASEThu↓ of AsEThu. (K, * TA.) See art. sET.
4: see what here precedes.
SaEuwTN i. q. saEuwTN, q. v. (Lh, K.)

1. SaEaqatohumu AlsRamaMCu, (S, O, K,) aor.
SaEaqa
, (K,) inf. n. SaAEiqapN, (O, K,) The sky smote them with what is termed SaAEiqap [i. e. a thunderbolt]. (S, O, K.) [And SaqaEatohum signifies the same.]

SaEiqa is quasi-pass. of the verb in the phrase above; (Z, TA in art. srf;) signifying He was smitten by a SaAEiqap; (TA in art. SqE;) as also SaqiEa; (K and TA in that art.;) and so SuEiqa and SuqiEa. (O in that art.)

And SaEiqa, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
SaEaqa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. SaEaqN, (Msb,) or SaEoqapN, (S, O,) or both, and SaEoqN, (K,) and taSoEaAqN, (S, O, K,) He (a man, S, O) swooned, or became insensible, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) and lost his reason, (TA,) in consequence of a sound that he heard, (Msb, TA,) such as the vehement sound of the fall of a wall or the like or of a part of a mountain; (TA;) as also SuEiqa. (Msb, TA. *)

And SaEiqa, aor.
SaEaqa
, inf. n. SaEoqN and taSoEaAqN, He (a man) died. (TA.) faSaEiqa mano fiI AlsRamewaAti wamano fiI AlOaroDi, in the Kur [xxxix. 68], means And those in the heavens and those upon the earth shall die: (S, TA:) or shall fall down dead, or in a swoon: (Bd:) or shall lose their reason. (TA.)
And SaEiqati AlrRakiyRapu, inf. n. SaEaqN, The well fell in ruins, or to pieces; or collapsed. (TA.)

SuEaAqN [as an inf. n.] signifies The sounding of thunder: and SaEiqa, aor.
SaEaqa
, inf. n. SuEaAqN, is said of a bull, meaning He bellowed, or lowed: (TA:) and likewise of a man [app. as meaning he bel-lowed, or roared]. (ISk, TA in art. Am.)
4. OaSoEaqatohu AlSRaAEiqapu The SAEqp [or thunderbolt] smote him. (TA.)
And ASEqhu He, or it, caused him to swoon, or become insensible. (S.)
And He, or it, killed, or slew, him. (TA.)
SaEoqN: see the next paragraph.

SaEaqN is an inf. n. of SaEiqa [q. v.]: (Msb, K:) and primarily signifies A swooning, or becoming insensible, in consequence of a vehement sound that one hears; and sometimes, such that one dies in consequence thereof:
afterwards often used as meaning Death. (TA.)
[Also] Vehemence of sound or voice: (O, K:) and vehemence of braying of an ass; used in this sense by Rubeh; (O, * TA;) and said by Az to be originally SaEoqN↓. (TA.)
SaEiqN Expecting, or looking for, a SaAEiqap [or thunderbolt]. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

Also Swooning, or becoming insensible; (K, TA;) and so maSoEuwqN↓; or the latter signifies dying suddenly: and the former, swooning, or becoming insensible, and losing his reason, in consequence of a sound that he has heard, such as the vehement sound of the fall of a wall or the like or of a part of a mountain. (TA.)
And Dying, or dead. (TA.)
Also, (K, TA,) or SaEiqu AlSRawoti, (S, O,) Vehement in voice, (S, O, K, TA,) and in braying; (TA;) applied to an ass. (S, O, TA.)
SaEoqapN: see SaAEiqapN.
Also The sound proceeding from a SaAEiqap [or thunderbolt]. (TA.)
AlSRaEoqapu AlOuwlaI means The first blast [of the horn on the day of resurrection]. (Msb.)
And SaEoqapN also signifies A death. (TA.)
SaAEiqN A camel meagre in his marrow. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O.)

SaAEiqapN [A thunderbolt; i. e.] a thing descending from the thunder, that smites not anything but it alters it and burns it: (Msb:) or fire that falls from the sky, (AZ, S, O, K,) in vehement thunder: (AZ, S, O:) or fire that God sends with vehement thunder: (TA:) or the scourge (mixoraAq) that is in the hand of [the angel who is] the driver of the clouds, and that comes not upon anything but it burns it: (O, K:) or a vehement sound from a thundering with which falls a piece of fire: or the sound of thunder: (TA:) Wahb Ibn-Munebbih, being asked respecting it, whether it were a tangible thing or fire or what else, answered that he thought no one knew it except God: (O, TA:) accord. to some, (TA,) it signifies also the cry, or vehement cry, or shout, [that is an efficient] of punishment: (S, O, K:) and death; (O, K;) so accord. to Katádeh (O, TA) and Mukátil: (TA:) or a cause of death: (Zj, TA:) and any destructive punishment: (O, K:) and SaEoqapN↓ and SaAqiEapN are dial. vars. thereof: (TA:) the pl. is SawaAEiqu. (O, Msb, TA.)
maSoEuwqN: see SaEiqN.

1. SaEila, aor.
SaEala
, (K,) inf. n. SaEalN, (TA,) He, or it, was, or became, such as is termed SaEolN and OaSoEalu meaning as expl. below; as also ASEAlR↓. (K, TA.) One says, AlnRaxolapu ASEAlRt↓ meaning The palm-tree was, or became, slender in the head. (IDrd, O, TA.)
11: see the preceding paragraph, in two places.

SaEolN Small in the head; applied to a man, (As, S, O,) and to an ostrich; (S, O;) as also OaSoEalu↓; (O;) and SaEolaMCu↓ applied to a woman: (S:) or small in the head and long and slender in the neck; applied to a man: (Sh, TA:) or SaEolN and its fem. SaEolapN, and OaSoEalu↓ and its fem. SaEolaMCu↓, such as is slender in the head and neck, of mankind, and of ostriches, and [in like manner] of palm-trees: (K, * TA:) or, accord. to As, only the first is applied to a man, and its fem. (with p) to a woman: but IB says that others mention SaEolaMCu↓ as applied to a woman; and accord. to this, one applies OaSoEalu↓ to a man. (TA.) And naxolapN SaEolapN A palm-tree that is crooked, and bare in the lower parts of its branches: (S, O,
K:) or a tall palm-tree; which is disapproved, because often when it is tall it becomes crooked. (IB, TA.) And HimaArN SaEolN An ass that has lost his soft hair, (S, K,) or his abundant and long hair, (O,) or both. (TA.) And SaEolN signifies also Tall, or long: (K:) applied by El-'Ajjáj to a mast of a ship as meaning tall, and having its upper part even, or uniform, with its middle; not as meaning slender in the head. (TA.)
Also, [used as a subst.,] A male ostrich; because small in the head: and with p, a female ostrich. (TA.)
SaEalN Slenderness. (S, O.)
SaEolapN, (O, TA,) or SaEalapN↓, which is preferred by Sh, (O,) Smallness of the head: (O, TA:) or slenderness, and lightness of the body. (TA.)
SaEalapN: see what next precedes.
OaSoEalu, and its fem. SaEolaMCu: see SaEolN, in six places.
Q. 1. SaEolakahu, (O, K,) inf. n. SaEolakapN, (TA,) He rendered him poor, or needy. (O, K.)

SElk AlvRariydapa He made the vrydp [or mess of crumbled bread moistened with broth] to hare a head: or he raised its head. (K.) And SElk Oasofala AlsRanaAmi He stretched up the lower part of the camel's hump so as to make its upper part of a rounded form. (Sh, O.)
And SElk Albaqolu AlUibila The herbs, or leguminous plants, fattened the camels. (Sh, O, K.)
Q. 2. taSaEolaka He was, or became, poor, or needy. (S, * O, * K.) And He made a show of poverty. (KL.) [He affected to be such as is termed SuEoluwk.]

tSElkt AlUibilu The camels cast, or shed, their fur, (S, K, TA,) and, some add, became bare. (TA.) Accord. to Sh, The camels became slender in their legs in consequence of fatness [of the body; app. meaning that their legs became slender in comparison with their bodies]. (TA.) And accord. to As, tSElk said of a horse, He became slender, and shed his abundant and long hair. (TA.)

SuEoluwkN Poor, or needy; (S, O, K, TA;) [a poor man;] and ISd adds, having no property; and Az adds, and having no reliance [upon any person or thing]: (TA:) and a thief, or robber: (KL:) pl. SaEaAliyku. (S, O.) SaEaAliyku AlEarabi means cuWobaAnuhaA [i. e., as expl. voce ciYobN, The thieves, or sharpers, and paupers, of the Arabs; or the paupers of the Arabs who practise thieving: because they act like wolves]. (S, O.) 'Orweh Ibn-El-Ward was called Eurowapu AlSRaEaAliyki because he used to collect the poor in a HaZiyrap [i. e. an enclosure for cattle] and sustain them by means of the plunder that he took. (S, O, K.)

muSaEolaku AlrRaOosi A man round in the head: (O, K, TA:) or, as some say, small in the head. (TA.) And maSaEolakN applied to a camel's hump, Such as is as though one rounded its upper part, and stretched up its lower part with the hand so as to make it assume that rounded form. (Sh, O.)

1. SaEaA, aor.
SaEawa
, He, or it, was slender; and was small: (IAar, K:) from SaEowN, here following. (TA.)

SaEowN A small EuSofuwr [or bird of the sparrowkind], (K, TA,) red in the head; (TA;) fem. with p: (K:) or small EaSaAfiyr [or birds of the sparrow-kind], the heads of which are red; n. un. with p: (Msb:) or SaEowapN signifies a certain bird; and its pl. is SaEowN and SiEaMCN: (S:) or the pl. (of SaEowapN, Msb) is SiEaMCN (Msb, K) and SaEawaAtN, (K, in the CK SEowAtN,) and the pl. of SaEowN is OaSoEaMCN: some say that SaEowN is originally waSoEN. (TA.)
Hence, (TA,) naAqapN SaEowapN A she-camel small in the head. (K.)
And the pl. OaSoEaMCN signifies OuSuwlN [pl. of OaSolN, q. v.]. (TA.)

1. Sagura, aor.
Sagura
; (S, Msb, K;) and Sagira, aor.
Sagara
; (K;) inf. n. SigarN, (S, Msb, K,) of the former, (S, Msb, TA,) and SagaArapN, (K,) also of the former, (TA,) and SagarN and SugoraAnN, (IAar, K,) which are both of the latter; (TA; [but Ibr D thinks that there is no reason for this assertion with respect to SgrAn;]) [He or] it (S, Msb) was, or became, small, or little; SigarN being the contr. of kibarN, (S,) or of EiZamN, as also SagaArapN [&c.]: (M, K:) or SigarN is in body, or corporeal substance, (fiI Aljiromi,) [and in years, or age; and Sagura, with this inf. n., said of a human being, signifies he was a child, or in the state of childhood, not having attained to puberty;] and SagaArapN is in estimation or rank or dignity (fiI Alqadori). (M, K.)

Also Sagura, inf. n. SigarN and SagaArN and SagaArapN and SugoraAnN and SugorN (K) and SagarN, (TA,) He was content with vileness, baseness, abasement, or ignominy, (K,) and tyranny, or injury: (TA:) or SagarN is inf. n. of Sagira, aor.
Sagara
, signifying he was, or became, vile, base, or ignominious; (S, * Msb;) and so SugorN and SagaArN: (Mgh:) or SagaArN signifies the being small, or little, in estimation or rank or dignity: (TA:) and you say, Sagura fiI Euyuwni AlnRaAsi, with damm, meaning, [he became small, or little, in the eyes of men; i. e.,] he lost his reverence, or reverend dignity. (Msb.) [See also 6.] One says also, huwa yaSoguru Eano kacaA He, or it, is smaller than, or too small for, such a thing; syn. yaqilRu. (TA in art. ql.) And Sagurato Eani Alwaladi [She was too young to bear offspring]. (S in art. jl, &c.)

maA SagaraniI UilRaA bisanapK, aor.
Sagura
, means maA Sagura EanRiI [i. e. He was not younger than I, save by a year]. (IAar, K.)
And Sagurati AlXRamosu The sun inclined to setting. (Th, K.)
2. SgRrhu, (inf. n. taSogiyrN, TA,) He made him, or it, small, or little; as also ASfrhu↓. (S, K.) You say, Alqirobapa ASgr↓ He sewed the water-skin [so as to make it] small. (S, K.)

SgRrhu fiI Euyuwni AlnRaAsi He, or it, rendered him [small, or little, i. e.,] contemptible, vile, base, or ignominious, [in the eyes of men:] (A:) and [in like manner] he, or it, rendered him vile, base, or ignominious, (TA,) or content with vileness, baseness, abasement, or ignominy. (K.)
SagRarotu XaOonahu (TA in art. gmz) and mino XaOonihi (S and TA in the same art.) [I lessened his rank, or dignity].

SgRr AlAisoma, inf. n. taSogiyrN, He changed the noun into the diminutive form. (Msb.) This is done for several purposes: to denote the smallness of the thing signified, in itself; as in the instance of duwaborapN [“ a small, or little, house ”]: to denote its smallness in the eye of the speaker, when it is not small in itself; as in the saying cahabati AldRaraAhimu UilRaA durayohimFA [“ the dirhems went, except a small dirhem ”]: to denote nearness; as in the instance of qubayola AlSRuboHi [“ a little before daybreak ”]: to denote affection and benevolence; as in the expression yaA bunaIRa [“ O my little (meaning dear) son ”]: to denote the greatness of the thing signified; as in the phrase sunayRapN HamoraMCu [“ a very severe year ”]: to denote praise; as when a man is described as kunayofN muliYa EilomFA [“ a little pastor's-bag filled with knowledge ”]: to denote blame; as in the expression yaA fuwayosiqu [“ O thou little transgressor ”]. (L, TA.) [The inf. n., taSogiyrN, is also applied to A diminutive noun itself; as also AisomN muSagRarN.]
See also 10.
4: see 2, in two places.
ASgrt AlOaroDu The land produced small plants or herbage, (K,) not tall. (TA.)

AirotabaEuwA liyuSogiruwA [They remained in the spring-pasture] in order that they might rear the younger ones: (O, K: expl. in the former by liyuwalRid AlOaSaAgira [correctly liyuwalRiduwA]: in the CK and my MS. copy of the K, by liyuwliduwA AlOaSaAgira [which is a manifest mistake].)
OaSogarati AlnRaAqapu waOakobarato (tropical:) The she-camel uttered her yearning cry to, or for, her young one, in a low tone, and loudly. (A.)
6. tSAgr He became small; he shrank, or became contracted; (O * and TA in art. DOl;) by reason of abasement, (TA ibid.,) or from fear. (Ham p. 658.)

He became vile, base, ignominious, abject, or contemptible; (K, * TA;) came to nought. (TA.) And tSAgrt Uilayohi nafosuhu He (lit. his soul or his own self) became of little importance, by being vile, base, or ignominious, to himself, or in his own estimation; (A, Msb;) he became vile, base, ignominious, abject, or contemptible, to himself, or in his own estimation. (S, * K, * TA.)
And [He affected, or feigned, abjectness; contr. of takaAbara: or] he exhibited abjectness. (KL.)
10. AstSgrhu He counted, accounted, reckoned, or esteemed, him, or it, small, or little: or vile, base, or ignominious: syn. EadRahu SagiyrFA: (S, K:) or young: as also SagRarahu↓. (TA.)

SugorN (S, Msb) and SagaArN↓, with fet-h, (S, [and
so in the Kur vi. 124,]) or SugaArN↓, with damm, (Msb, [but perhaps there is an omission in my copy of the Msb after this word,]) and SagarN↓, (S,) Vileness, baseness, abasement, or ignominiousness: (S, Msb:) so the second word signifies in the Kur vi. 124: (TA:) and tyranny, or oppression, or injury. (S.) One says, qumo EalaI Sugorika, and Sagarika↓, [Rise thou, notwithstanding thy vileness, or ignominiousness]. (S.) [See also 1, of which it is an inf. n.]
SagarN: see SugorN, in two places. [And see 1, of which it is an inf. n.]

fulaAnN Sigoratuhumo Such a one is the least, or youngest, of them: (K, * TA:) and fulaAnN Sigorapu Oabawayohi, and Sigorapu waladi Oabawayohi, Such a one is the least, or youngest, of the children of his parents: opposed to kiborap. (TA.) And OanaA mina AlSRigorapi I am of the little-ones, or of the young: (K:) said by an Arab child when he is forbidden to play. (TA.)
SugoraAnN: see SagiyrN.
SagaArN: see SugorN.
SugaArN: see SagiyrN:
and SugorN.

SagiyrN Small, or little; (S, K;) [in body, or corporeal substance: and in estimation or rank or dignity; as is implied in the K: and in years, or age; a youngling; a young one of any female; and of a tree and the like: applied to a human being, a child; i. e., one who has not attained to puberty: opposed to kabiyrN:] as also SugaArN↓ (S, K) and SugoraAnN↓ (K) and OaSogaru↓: (Msb in art. kbr:) fem. with p: (Msb:) pl. masc. SigaArN and SugaraMCu, (a form used in poetry, S,) and maSoguwarMCu↓, (S, K,) or the last is [correctly speaking] a quasi-pl. n.: (TA:) and pl. fem. SigaArN, but not SagaAYiru when used as an epithet: (Msb:) the dim. of SagiyrN is SugayRirN↓ and SugayRiyrN↓, (Sb, K,) the latter anomalous. (TA.) You say, huwa SagiyrN fiI Alqadori; and fiI AlEilomi; [He is small, or little, in rank, or dignity; as also Sagiyru AlXRaOoni; and in knowledge.] (A.) And jaMCa AlnRaAsu Sagiyruhumo wakabiyruhumo The people came: [the small in rank or dignity, of them, and the great therein, of them: or] those of no rank or dignity, and those of rank or dignity. (Msb.) [See also SaAgirN.]

SagiyrapN, [a subst. from SagiyrN, made such by the affix p,] applied to a sin, [signifying A small or little, sin,] has for its pl. SagiyraAtN and [more commonly] SagaAYiru; being, when thus applied, a subst. (Msb.) [See muHaqRaraAtN.]
SugayRirN and SugayRiyrN dims. of SagiyrN, q. v.

SaAgirN In a state of vileness, abasement, ignominiousness, abjectness or contempt: (Msb:) or content with vileness, abasement, or ignominy, (K,) and tyranny, or injury. (S, A, TA.) [See also SagiyrN.]

OaSogaru [Smaller, or less; and smallest, or least; in body, or corporeal substance; and in estimation or rank or dignity; and in years, or age]: (S, Msb, K:) fem. SugoraI: (S, Msb:) pl. masc. OaSaAgiru (Sb, S, K) and OaSaAgirapN, (M, K,) though the sing. is not of the nouns which regularly add p to the pl., and it is added in this case because the sing. resembles in form qaXoEamN, of which qaXaAEimapN is a pl., (ISd,) and OaSogaruwna: (Sb, S:) and pl. fem. SugarN (Sb, S, Msb) and SugorayaAtN: (Msb:) but Sb says, you do not say nisowapN SugarN, nor qawomN OaSaAgiru, except with the article Al: and he adds, we have heard the Arabs says, AlOaSaAgiru [perhaps miswritten for AlOaSaAgirapu]; and if you please, you may say AlOaSogaruwna. (S.)

AlOaSogaraAni [lit. The two less, or least, things,] means (assumed tropical:) the heart and the tongue. (K.) It is said in a prov., AlmaroCu biOaSogarayohi, meaning, (assumed tropical:) The man obtains power over things, and manages them thoroughly, by means of his heart and his tongue. (ISk, TA. [See Har p. 446.])
See also SagiyrN.
OaroDN muSogirapN Land having small plants or herbage, not grown tall. (ISk, S, K. *)
muSagRarapN: see maSofuwrN, in art. Sfr.
maSoguwrapN: see maSofuwrN, in art. Sfr.
maSoguwraMCu: see SagiyrN.

1. SagaA, aor. yaSoguw; (S, Msb, K;) and [SagaI, aor.] yaSogiI, (S, TA, and so in some copies of the K,) or yaSogaI; (Msb, and so in some copies of the K, and in the M, but it is said in the TA that it is correctly yaSogiI, with kesr, as in the S;) inf. n. SuguwRN; (S, Msb, K;) and SagiIa, aor. yaSogaI, inf. n. SagFA and SugiIRN; (S, Msb, K;) He, or it inclined, (S, Msb, K, TA,) UilaI AlXRaIoCi [to the thing], (TA,) or UilaI kacaA [to such a thing]: (Msb:) or they signify [sometimes, for the meaning expl. above is unquestionably correct, and is that which is predominant,] he (a man, TA) had an inclining of his Hanak [here app. meaning the mouth or the part below the mouth]; (K, TA;) or of one of his lips; thus correctly, as in the M and A; Xidoqayohi in [some of] the copies of the K [and XiqRayohi in others] being a mistake for Xafatayohi. (TA.) You say, Sagato Uilayohi Oucunuhu His ear inclined to him, or it. (TA.) And hence, in the Kur [lxvi. 4], faqado Sagato quluwbukumaA [For the hearts of you two have inclined to that which is not right]. (Msb.) And Sagati AlnRujuwmu, (S, Msb,) and AlXRamosu, (K,) The stars, and the sun, inclined to setting. (S, Msb, K.) And SagaA AlrRajulu The man inclined, or leaned, on one side: or bent, or bowed, himself upon his bow. (TA.) And SagiIa, EalaI Alqawomi inf. n. SagFA, [as though meaning He inclined to set himself against the people or party,] is said of one when his love, or affection, is with such as are not of the said people, or party. (TA.)

And SagiIa, aor. yaSogaI, (K, TA,) inf. n. SagFA agreeably with the S and M, accord. to the copies of the K, erroneously, SagoIN, (TA,) and SugiIRN, (K, TA,) He inclined and gave ear, or hearkened, or listened. (K. [See also the next paragraph.])
4. ASgI AlUinaMCa He inclined the vessel: (S, Msb, K:) or he turned the vessel upon its side, in order that what was in it might collect together. (M, TA.)

[Hence,] OuSogiIa UinaMCu fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) Such a one perished, or died. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And OaSogaI UinaMCahu (assumed tropical:) [I. q. ASgI HaqRahu expl. in what follows: (see also muSogFI:) or] he detracted from his reputation; spoke evil of him; or slandered him. (Z, TA.) ASgI HaqRahu, (A, TA,) or AlXRaIoCa, (K,) means (tropical:) He diminished to him, impaired to him, or defrauded him of a portion of, (Z, K, TA,) his right or due, (Z, TA,) or the thing. (K.)

You say also, OaSogayotu raOosiI, and samoEiI, I inclined my head, and my ear. (Msb.) And ASgI Uilayohi, (S, K,) or ASgI Uilayohi samoEahu, (M, TA,) He inclined his ear to him. (S, M, K.) And ASgI, alone, He gave ear, hearkened, or listened. (K. [See also 1, last explanation.]) And OaSogati AlnRaAqapu The she-camel inclined her head towards the raHol [or saddle], (S, K, TA,) in some copies of the S UilaI AlrRajuli [towards the man], (TA,) as though she were listening to a thing: (S, K:) this she does when the saddle is bound upon her. (S.)

SagFA an inf. n. of SagiIa [q. v.]: and also [used as] a simple subst. [meaning Inclination]. (TA.) One says, OaqaAma SagaAhu [He rectified] his inclination. (TA.) And maEaka Sagowuhu↓ and Sigowuhu↓, and SagaAhu, i. e. His inclination [is with thee, meaning, is agreeable with thine]. (AZ, S, K.) In [some of] the copies of the K Sagowuhu and Sigowuhu are written SagowapN and SigowapN, which would lead the inadvertent to imagine these two words to be syn. with the word there next preceding, namely, SagowaMCu as an epithet applied to the sun. (TA.)

SagowN: see the next preceding paragraph. [hecaA Qbonu Sagowika, or Sigowika↓, is a phrase similar to hcA Abn Uinosika, meaning This is thy chosen, or special, friend or companion: but perhaps postclassical.]
SigowN: see SagFA and SagowN.
Also The interior of a ladle:
and the side of a well:
and the part that is folded, or turned over, of the sides of a dalow [or leathern bucket]: K, TA:) so in the M: and its pl. in these senses is OaSogaMCN. (TA.)
SagowapN: see SagowaMCu, voce OaSogaI.
[SaAgK part. n. of SagaA: fem. SaAgiyapN: and pl. SawaAgK.]

SaAgiyatuka means Those who incline to thee, (K, TA,) and come to thee, (TA,) in their cases of need: (K, TA:) or whoever, of thy family, come to thee as guests: (TA:) or those who incline to thee, of thy companions and relations: (Har p. 207:) ISd thinks it to be made fem. because meaning a jamaAEap. (TA.) OakorimuwA fulaAnFA fiI SaAgiyatihi means [Honour ye such a one in respect of] those who incline to him, and who
come to him seeking to obtain what he has. (S.)
And AlSRawaAgiI means The stars that have inclined to setting. (TA.)
OaSogaI, applied to a man, (TA,) Having an inclining of the Hanak; (K, TA;) or of one of the lips: (K, * TA: [see 1:]) fem. SagowaMCu. (TA.)

And the fem., applied to a qaTaAp [or bird of the species termed qaTFA], Having an inclining of its beak, and of one of its mandibles: and one says SagowaMCu SagowapN↓ to give intensiveness to the meaning; like as one says layolN laAYilN. (TA.)
Also, i. e. the fem., applied to the sun, Inclining to setting. (K.)

maSogFI [A place of inclining, or to which to incline]. It is said in a prov., AlSRabiIRu OaEolamu bimaSogaI xadRihi [The child best knows the place of inclining of his cheek]: i. e. he best knows to whom he should betake himself, or whither it will profit him [to go]. (TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 715.])
muSogFI Inclined. (Ham p. 260.)

One says, fulaAnN muSogFI UinaAWuhu, meaning (assumed tropical:) Such a one is abridged, or defrauded, of a portion of his right, or due: (S, and Ham pp. 259-60:) because when the vessel is inclined, what it will hold becomes deficient. (Ham.)

1. SafRa, (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) aor.
Safufa
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. SafRN, (O, Msb, K, TA,) He set, or placed, or stationed, (S, M, Mgh, O, K,) a company of men, (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) in war (S, O, K) &c., (O, K,) and a military force, (TA,) and also [in a similar sense] a thing, (Msb,) in a rank, or row, or line: (S, M, Mgh, O, K:) and likewise SfRf↓, (TA,) inf. n. taSofiyfN; (IDrd, O, K, TA;) but this has an intensive signification. (IDrd, O, TA.)

One says also of a she-camel, taSufRu yadayohaA Einoda AlHalabi [She sets her fore legs evenly, side by side, not putting one of them in advance of the other, as if about to go onward, on the occasion of being milked]. (S, M, O, K.) [See also Safana, said of a man: and see SaAna in art. Swn.]) And [in like manner] one says, SafRati AlUibilu qawaAYimahaA [The camels set their legs in an even row]. (S, O.)

And of a she-camel one says also, taSufRu OaqodaAHFA mino labanihaA UicaA Hulibato [as though meaning She yields a row of bowls of her milk when she is milked], because of the abundance of her milk. (S, O, K *.) And taSufRu bayona miHolabayoni Oawo valaAvapK, (S, O,) or simply taSufRu, (M,) She combines two milking-vessels, or three, at one milking; (S, * M, O; *) AlSRafRu meaning her being milked into two milking-vessels, or three, (S, O, K,) so as to combine them. (S, O. [In the CK, Oano taHoluba is a mistake for Oano tuHolaba.]) And a rájiz, cited by AZ, says, referring to a she-camel,

[She is milked into three milking-vessels at one milking]. (S, O.) One says also SafRahaA, i. e. HalabahaA SafRFA [app. meaning He milked her into two bowls, or three, at one milking; or into two bowls; the pronoun referring to a she-camel]. (M. [One or the other of these two meanings appears to be indicated by what there precedes this.])

SufRa EalaI Aljamori liyanoXawiIa (S, K) is said of flesh-meat (S) [app. meaning It was laid, cut into a strip, or into strips, upon the live coals to broil]; and fiI AlXRamosi liyajifRa [in like manner, in the sun to dry]: (K:) for one says of him who has prepared flesh-meat cut into strips, or oblong pieces, and dried in the sun, SafRa AllRaHoma; and [in like manner] one says also, SafRahu EalaI AlnRaAri liyanoXawiIa: (Msb:) or SafRa AllRaHoma, aor.
Safufa
, inf. n. SafRu, means he cut the flesh-meat into broad slices: (M:) and accord. to ISh, AltRaSofiyfu↓ is like AltRaXoriyHu, i. e. the cutting a piece of flesh-meat thin, so that it is translucent: (TA in the present art:) or AltSfyf is a kind of taXoriyH; i. e. the cutting a piece of flesh-meat thin, so that it is translucent by reason of its thinness, and then throwing it upon the live coals. (TA in art. XrH.) [See SafiyfN.]
See also 8, in three places.

SafRa said of a bird, (M, O, Msb, K,) aor.
Safufa
, (M, Msb,) inf. n. SafRN, (Msb, K,) It extended its wings in a line, (M,) or it expanded its wings, (O, Msb, K,) in the sky, and did not move them, (M,) or and struck [an evident mistake for and did not strike] with them its sides like the pigeon: (Msb:) such as do so are not to be eaten; (Msb, K;) as the vulture and the hawk: (Msb:) it is said in a trad., yuWokalu maA dafRa walaA yuWokalu maA SafRa. (O, K, TA. See art. df.)

Safafotu lilsRaroji, (S,) or Safafotu lilsRaroji SufRapF, (O,) or Safafotu AlsRaroja, (K, and so in one place in the O,) and OaSofafotuhu↓, (O, K,) but this latter verb is of weak authority, (O,) (tropical:) I put to the horse's saddle a SufRap [q. v.]: S, O, K, TA:) [and] SafRa AldRaAbRapa, and SafRa lahaA, He made for the beast a SufRap. (M.)
2: see above, first sentence:
and also in the latter half of the paragraph.
3. SaAfRuwhumo (S, MA, O,K) fiI AlqitaAli (S, O, K) They fought them in rank; they drew themselves out in a rank against them [in fight]. (MA.)
[And app. one says also SaAfRahu meaning He had the SufRap of his house over against, or facing, his (another's) SufRap. See huwa muSaAfRiI, below.]
4: see 1, last sentence.
6: see 8.

One says also tSAfRwA Ealayohi They collected themselves together in a rank, or row, or line, against him. (M, TA.) And tSAfRwA EalaI AlmaMCi They collected themselves together at the water; as also tDAfRwA Ealayohi: like as one says tSwRk fiI xuroYihi and tDwRk, and SalaASilu AlmaMCi and DalaADiluhu. (Lh, TA.)

8. ASTfRwA They stood in, (S, Mgh, O, K,) or became, (M,) [or set, placed, or stationed, themselves in,] a rank, or row, or line; (S, M, Mgh, Msb; *) or ranks, or rows, or lines; (O, K;) as also tSAfRwA↓; (M, O, * K; * [AltRaSaAfRu being expl. in the O and K by AltRasaATuru; in the CK, erroneously, AltRaXATuru;]) and so SafRuwA↓, (M, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
Safufa
, (M, Mgh,) inf. n. SafRN and SafRaI, but [ISd says] this latter inf. n. I have not heard except in a phrase mentioned in what follows. (M.) Hence the saying, AlnRisaMCu xalofa AlrRijaAli walaA taSufRu↓ taSufRu maEahumo [The women shall stand in a rank behind the men in the mosque, and shall not stand in a rank with them]. (Mgh.) And hence the saying of a woman of the desert to her sons, UicaA laqiytumu AlEaduwRa fadagaraI walaA SafRaI↓ i. e. [When ye meet the enemy, rush upon them without consideration, and] do not set yourselves in a rank. (M. [See also 1, in art. dgr.])
R. Q. 1. SafoSafa He journeyed, (saAra, O, and so in copies of the K,) or became, (SaAra, so in the CK,) alone in a SafoSaf, or level tract of land. (O, K.)
And He pastured upon the trees called SafoSaAf. (O, K.)
