And SafoSafapN [as an inf. n., or as a simple subst.,] signifies The crying or cry, (Sawot,) of the sparrow, which is called SufoSuf (O, K) in some one or more of the dialects. (O.)

SafRN A rank, row, or line [of things]; (KL, PS;) or an even Sador [i. e. front, or fore part,] of any things: (M:) and a company of men standing in a rank, or row, or line: (O, K:) pl. SufuwfN; (S, M, O, Msb, K;) and the sing. may also be used in the sense of the pl.; it may be used either thus in the sense of the pl. or as a sing. in the Kur xviii. 46. (O.) Hence, in a trad., sawRuwA Sufuwfakumo [Make even your ranks] in prayer. (O, TA.)

Also A station of Sufuwf [or ranks of men]. (M. [See also maSafRN.]) And hence, (M,) as used in the Kur xx. 67, i. q. muSalRFI [i. e. A place of prayer, or a place of prayer on the occasion of the Eiyd, or festival]; (Az, M, O;) because the people stand there in ranks: (M:) i. e. a place where people assemble for their Eiyd: (Az, O:) or, in that instance, SafRFA may mean muSoTafRiyna [i. e. standing in ranks], (Az, M, O,) as a denotative of state. (M.)
And A pair of bowls (qadaHaAni) [app., as seems to be indicated, that are filled at one milking of a camel]; because they are put together. (M.)
Also A certain medicament with which the teeth are whitened. (O.)

SufRapN An appertenance of a house, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K, [in none of which is it explained,]) or of a building, like a wide bahuw [here used in a postclassical sense, as meaning a kind of vestibule, or portico, for shade and shelter, open in front], with a long roof or ceiling; (Lth, TA;) the TurRap of a building [app. meaning what is above described]; (M;) i. q. saqiyfapN: (S and Msb and K in art. sqf:) [see safiyfapN; and see also sudRapN:] and i. q. ZulRapN [i. e. a roof, or covering, for shade and shelter, over the door of a house; or extending from a house to another house opposite; like sudRapN and saqiyfapN]: (M:) [for the meaning assigned to it by Golius as from the S, and by Freytag as from the K and S, (“ scamnum discubitorium, fere ex lapidibus structum, ”) I find no authority in any Arabic work: in Egypt, it is applied to a shelf of marble or of common stone, about four
feet high, supported by two or more arches, or by a single arch, figured and described in the Introduction to my work on the Modern Egyptians; this being app. so called because resembling in form, though not in size, a porch:] the pl. is SufafN (S, O, Msb, K) and SifaAfN and SufRaAtN. (Mgh.) Oaholu AlSRufRapi [The people of the SufRap] was an appellation applied to certain persons who were the guests of El-Islám, [i. e. supported by the charity of the Muslims,] (O, K, TA,) consisting of poor refugees, and houseless men, (TA,) who passed the night in the SufRap of the mosque of the Prophet [in El-Medeeneh], which was a covered place, an appertenance of the mosque, (O, K, TA,) roofed over with palm-sticks; (Har p. 379; [where see more;]) thither they resorted for lodging; and sometimes they were few, and sometimes they were many: [SM says,] I have drawn up a list of their names, in a tract, to the number of ninety-two, (TA in the present art.,) or ninetythree. (TA voce OawofaADN.) [ISd says,] EacaAbu yawomi AlSRufRapi [The punishment of the day of the SufRap] is the same as EacaAbu yawomi AlZRulRapi [mentioned in the Kur xxvi. 189]: (M, TA:) Lth says that the former was a day on which a certain people disobeyed their apostle, wherefore God sent upon them heat and clouds which overspread them, so that they perished: and Az says that it is not the same as that mentioned in the Kur, and that he knew not what is meant by EcAb ywm AlSfRp: (O, (TA:) it seems, however, that both mean the same, as AlSRufRapu and AlZRulRapu are one in meaning. (TA.)

Also (tropical:) An appertenance of the saroj [or horse's saddle]; (S, M, IAth, Mgh, O, K, TA;) like the miyvarap [q. v. in art. wvr] of the raHol [or camel's saddle]; (IAth, L, TA; *) the thing with which it is covered, between the qarabuwsaAni, which are its fore part and its hinder part: (Mgh:) or, (M, TA,) as also of the raHol, (M,) the thing that comprises within it (taDumRu) the [two pieces of wood called the] EaroquwataAni and the [two pads, or stuffed things, called the] bidaAdaAni, above them and beneath them: (M, TA:) pl. SufafN (S, M, O, K) and SifaAfN, the latter mentioned by Sb. (M.)
Also (tropical:) A long period (zamaAnN) of time. (O, K, TA.) So in the saying, EiXonaA SufRapN mina AldRahori (tropical:) [We lived, or have lived, a long period of time]. (O, TA.)

And (assumed tropical:) The quantity of grain that is put upon the palm of the hand: occurring in a trad. of Abu-d-Dardà, in the saying, OaSobaHotu laA Oamolku SufRapF walaA lufRapF [I became so that I possessed not the quantity of grain that might be put on the palm of the hand, nor a morsel of food]; AllRufRapu meaning AllRuqomapu. (TA.)
SafafN A thing that a man wears beneath the coat of mail (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K) in the day of battle. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

SafuwfN A she-camel that yields a row of bowls of her milk (taSufRu OaqodaAHFA mino labanihaA S, O, K) when she is milked, (S, O,) because of the abundance of her milk: (S, O, K:) or for which two vessels are set side by side (yuSafRu), and which fills them: (Ham p. 535:) or that sets her fore legs evenly, side by side, (taSufRu yadayohaA, [see 1,]) on the occasion of being milked. (S, M, O, K.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce SuwfN. And see also DafuwfN.]

SafiyfN Flesh-meat (S, M) such as has been laid, cut into a strip, or into strips, (SufRa, S, K, and the like in the M and O, or XuriHa waSufRa, Mgh,) upon the live coals (S, Mgh, O, K) to broil (S, Mgh, K) or to become thoroughly cooked, (O,) or upon the pebbles, and then roasted, or broiled, (M,) or in the sun, to dry: (O, K:) or flesh-meat cut into strips, or oblong pieces, and dried in the sun, (M, * Mgh, Msb,) or, as Lth says, and in like manner Ks, spread in the sun [to dry]: (Mgh:) or flesh-meat cut into broad slices: (M:) or, accord. to Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, flesh-meat cut into slices, not in the manner of qadiyd, but made broad, like cakes of bread [which are generally about a span, or somewhat less, in width, round and flat]: (TA:) [or cut thin so as to be translucent: (see 1, latter half:)] or flesh-meat made to boil once, and then taken up [from the fire]. (M.)
AlSRufRiyRapu The SuwfiyRap: so called in relation to those called Oaholu AlSRufRapi. (TA. (See art. Swf.])

SaAfRN [originally SaAfifN, act. part. n. of SafRa, q. v.]. SaAfRapN and [its pl.] SawaAfRu are epithets applied to camels [as meaning Setting their legs in an even row], from SafRato qawaAYimahaA: (S, O:) [or] SawaAfRa (in the Kur xxii. 37, O, K) means maSofuwfapF [i. e. set in a row], (M, O, K, TA,) to be slaughtered; (M, TA;) of the measure fawaAEil in the sense of the measure mafaAEil [thus in the O, and also (probably copied therefrom) in the copies of the K; but correctly mafaAEiyl]: or it means muSoTafRapF [i. e. standing in a row]: (O, K:) or, as related by I 'Ab, it is SawaAfina. (TA.) In the phrase waQlSRaAfRaAti SafRFA in the Kur [xxxvii. 1], by AlSRaAfRaAt are meant The angels standing in ranks in Heaven, glorifying God. (M, O, K.)
Applied to a bird, it means Expanding its wings and not moving [or flapping] them [in its flight]: opposed to daAfRN. (M and TA in art. df.)

SafoSafN A level, or an even, tract of land or ground: (S, O, Msb, K:) thus expl. by AA, and by Mujáhid, as used in the Kur xx. 106: by others as meaning smooth: accord. to Fr, having in it no herbage: and accord. to IAar, bald: pl. SafaASifu: (TA:) or OaroDN SafoSafN signifies a smooth, and level, or even, land; and so, accord. to IJ, [the fem.] SafoSafapN. (M.) Also, (M,) or SafoSafapN [app. as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant], (TA,) A desert, or waterless desert; syn. falaApN; (M, TA;) from IDrd. (TA.)
And The Harof [i. e. ridge, or brow, or ledge,] of a mountain. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
SufoSufN The sparrow, (IDrd, O, K,) in some one or more of the dialects. (IDrd, O.)
SafoSafapN [fem. of SafoSafN, q. v.
Also] i. q. sikobaAjapN [n. un. of sikbaAjN, q. v., i. e., A mess of the kind of food thus called]; (AA, O, K;) as also SafoSaAfapN↓, (O, K,) which is of the dial. of Thakeef. (O.)
And A certain insect (duwayobRap, Lth, M, O), by the Persians (AlEajam) called the siysak [i. e. weevil]: (Lth, O:) a word adventitious to the Arabic language. (Lth, M, O.)

SafoSaAfN The tree called xilaAf: (S, M, O, K:) [accord. to modern usage, the latter is the salix Aegyptia of Linn.: (Forskål's Flora Aegypt. Arab., p. lxxvi., and Delile's Floræ Aegpyt. Illustr., no 934:) and the SfSAf accord. to Forskål, ibid., is the salix Babylonica; or this is called SafoSaAf ruwmiIR: (Delile, no. 932:) and another species of salix is called in Egypt SafoSaAf baladiIR: (Forskål, ibid; and Delile, no. 933:)] or so in the dial. of Syria: (M, Msb:) or a kind of tree of which the xilaAf is a species: (K in art. xlf:) n. un. with p. (M, O, K.)
SafoSaAfapN: see SafoSafapN.
Also n. un. of SafoSaAfN [q. v.]. (M, O, K.)
maSafRN A station, (S, Msb,) or place where ranks are drawn up, (O, K,) in war, or battle: (S, O, Msb:) pl. maSaAfRN. (S, O, Msb, K.)
huwa muSaAfRiI He is the person whose SufRap [of his house] is over against, or facing, my SufRap. (IDrd, O, K.)

1. SafaHa Eanohu, (Mgh, Msb, K, *) aor.
SafaHa
, (K,) inf. n. SafoHN, (TA,) properly signifying He turned towards [or from] him, or it, the SafoHap [i. e. side] of his face, (Mgh,) means he turned away from, (Mgh, Msb, K, *) and left, (Msb, K,) him, or it, (Mgh, Msb,) i. e. [a man, or] an affair. (Msb.) And Darabotu Eanohu SafoHFA I turned away from him and left him; (S, TA;) i. e. a man: (TA:) SafoHFA being here an inf. n., and therefore in the accus. case, as in the phrase qaEadotu juluwsFA; or it is in the accus. case as an adv. n., and the meaning is I turned away from him aside. (Har p. 434. [See also, in art. Drb, a similar phrase in the Kur xliii. 4, cited here in the TA, and in Har ubi suprà.])

And SafaHa Eanohu, (S, A, K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) means [also] He turned away from his crime, sin, fault, or offence: (S, A, TA:) or he forgave him. (K, TA.) And SafaHotu Eano canobi fulaAnK I turned away from the crime, sin, &c., of such a one, and did not punish him for it: (TA:) or SafaHotu Eani AlcRanobi, aor. and inf. n. as above, I forgave the crime, sin, &c. (Msb.)
And SafaHato, (K, TA,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. SufuwHN, said of a she-camel, (K, TA,) and of a ewe, or she-goat, (TA,) [She ceased to yield her milk;] her milk went away. (K, TA.)
SafaHa as a trans. verb: see 5, in five places.
And see 2.

Also, aor.
SafaHa
, inf. n. SafoHN, He (a dog) spread forth, or stretched out, his fore legs: a rájiz says,
[As the spreading forth of his fore legs, to, or for, a bone; I mean a dog]; klbA being put in the accus. case as an explicative: or he here uses an inversion; meaning SafoHa kalobK ciraAEayohi. (L.)

And SafaHahu, (S,) or SafaHahu biAlsRayofi; (K;) and ASfHhu↓, (S,) or ASfHhu bAlsyf; (TA;) He struck him with the side, or flat, of the sword, (biEuroDihi, TA, or biEaroDihi, S, K,) [i. e. with its SafoH, or SufoH, or SafoHap,] not with its edge. (TA.)

And SafaHahu, (S, IAth, K, TA,) aor.
SafaHa
, inf. n. SafoHN; (TA;) and ASfHhu↓, (S, K, TA,) inf. n. UiSofaAHN; (TA;) He turned him back, or sent him away; namely, a person asking, or begging; (S, K, TA;) he refused his request: (IAth, TA:) and SafaHahu Eano HaAjatihi and EanohaA ASfHhu↓ He refused him the thing that he wanted. (TA.)
And SafaHahu also signifies He gave to him. (IAth, TA.) [Thus it has two contr. meanings.]
Also He gave him to drink any kind of beverage (K, TA) and at any time. (TA.)
And SafaHa AlUibila EalaI AlHawoDi He made the camels to pass by the wateringtrough; [app. watering them;] syn. OamarRahaA Ealayohi. (S, K.)

2. SfRH, (K,) inf. n. taSofiyHN, (S,) He made a thing wide, or broad; (S, K;) as also SafaHa↓; (K;) [and ASfH↓;] see muSofaHN. One says of a sword, SufRiHa, inf. n. as above, It was made broad, or wide, and lengthened out, in the forging. (IAar, S, TA.)

taSofiyHN is also syn. with taSofiyqN, (S, Msb, K,) meaning The clapping with the hands. (S, IAth, TA.) One says, SafRaH biyadayohi and SafRaqa [He clapped with his hands]; (A, TA;) he struck one of his hands upon the other: (Mgh:) or he struck with the outer side of the right hand upon the inner side of the left hand. (O in art. Sfq.) [Golius gives SafaHa in this sense, erroneously, as from the S; and Freytag, this form as well as SfRH.] And it is said in a trad., AltRasobiyHu lilrRijaAli waAltRaSofiyHu lilnRisaMCi, or, as some relate it, AltRaSofiyqu instead of AltSfyH, [The saying suboHaAna QllRehi is for men, and the clapping with the hands is for women;] (S, Mgh, * TA;) i. e., when the Imám is inadvertent, the person whom he leads should, if a man, rouse him by saying sbHAn AllReh; and if a woman, should clap with her hands, instead of speaking. (IAth, TA.)

3. muSaAfaHapN signifies The taking by the hand; (S, A, K;) as also taSaAfuHN↓; (A;) or the latter has a like meaning: (S, K: *) or the former signifies [the joining hands; i. e.] the putting the hand [of one] in the hand [of another] in meeting and saluting: (Ham p. 802:) or the making the palm of the hand to cleave to [that of] the hand [of another], and turning face to face. (L.) You say, SaAfaHahu biyadihi He took him by his hand. (A.) And SaAfaHotuhu, inf. n. as above [and SifaAHN], I applied my hand to his hand; (Msb;) or I put the palm of my hand upon the palm of his hand. (TA.)

And laqiyahu SifaAHFA He met him turning towards him the SafoH [or side] of his face: (TA:) or he met him face to face; i. q. SiqaAbFA: (TA in art. Sqb:) [and] he met him suddenly, or unexpectedly. (Ham p. 802.)
4. ASfHhu: see 1, latter part, in three places:
and see also 2.
Also He inverted it, or reversed it, (Ibn-Buzurj, K,) namely, a sword; like SaAbaAhu [q. v.]. (Ibn-Buzurj.)

5. tSfRHhu He examined its SafaHaAt [or sides]; i. e. a thing's: (S:) or he considered it carefully, or attentively, and examined its SafaHaAt. (A, Mgh.) And taSafRaHotu AlkitaAba I turned over, or examined, the SafaHaAt, meaning pages, of the book; as also SafaHotuhu↓, inf. n. SafoHN: (Msb:) and waraqa AlmuSoHafi SafaHotu↓ I examined the leaves of the muSoHaf [i. e. volume, or book, or copy of the Kur-án,] one by one. (O, K.) And tSfRH Alqawoma, (Lth, A,) and SafaHahumo↓, (Lth, O, Msb, K,) He looked at the people, seeking for a particular man: (Lth:) or he examined the states, or conditions, of the people, and looked among them, to ascertain whether such a one was to be seen: (A; in explanation of the former:) or he made the people to pass before him, and examined them, one by one: (O, K; in explanation of the latter:) or he beheld [or looked at] the SafaHaAt [or sides] of the faces of the people. (Msb.) And tSfRH wujuwha Alqawomi He examined carefully, or attentively, the faces of the people, looking at their (the people's) external appearances and forms, and seeking to make himself acquainted with their cases: and he looked at the faces of the people, seeking to know them; as also SafaHahaA↓. (Lth, TA.) And tSfRH AlOamora, (A, TA,) and tSfRH fiI AlOamori, (K, TA,) and AlOamora SafaHa↓, (TA,) and SafaHa fiI AlOamori, (K, TA,) He looked into the affair, or case. (K, TA.)
6. taSaAfaHaA They took each the other's hand. (TK.) See also 3.
Hence, taSaAfuHu AlOajofaAni (assumed tropical:) The closing together of the eyelids. (Har p. 364.)
10. AstSfHhu danobahu He asked him, or begged him, to forgive his crime, sin, fault, or offence. (L, TA.)

SafoHN, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) of a thing, (S, A, Mgh,) or of anything; (Msb;) and SafoHapN↓, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) of a thing, (Mgh,) or of anything; (S, A, Msb;) The side; or lateral, or outward, part or portion; syn. of the former naAHiyapN; (S, A;) or of the same, (K,) or of the latter, (S, A,) or of each, (Mgh, Msb,) jaAnibN: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) and both signify also the face, or surface, or front, of a thing: (Mgh:) pl. [of the former SifaAHN, as below, and] of the latter SafaHaAtN. (Msb.) SafoHaA AlXRaIoCi signifies The two sides of the thing; syn. jaAnibaAhu. (TA.) And SafoHu AlUinosaAni The side of the human being; (S, O, K; *) as also SafoHatuhu↓. (O.) And hence, baEiyrihi SalRaI UilaI SafoHapi↓ [He prayed towards the side of his camel]. (Mgh.) And SafoHN and SufoHN↓ signify The EuroD [i. e. side] (S, O, and K accord. to the TA, but in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K EaroD, [which in this instance I think a mistake,]) of the face: (S, O, K:) and so of a sword; (K, TA; [in the former of which, in art. ErD, the EuroD of a sword is said to be its SafoH;]) or the EaroD [i. e. breadth, or width,] (S, O, Msb, and so accord. to the CK and my MS. copy of the K,) of a sword; (S, O, Msb, K;) i. e. contr. of Tuwl; (Msb;) [but it may be well rendered its side, or its flat, and so SafoHapN↓, for SM says that] SafoHataA AlsRayofi signifies the two faces, or surfaces, of the sword: (TA:) one says, naZara Uilayohi biSafoHi wajohihi (S, A) and biSufoHi↓ wjhh (S) [He looked towards him with the side of his face turned towards him] and biSafoHatihi↓ [which means the same]: (A:) but accord. to AO, one says, AlsRayofi Darabahu biSufoHi↓ [He struck him with the side, or flat, of the sword], and the vulgar say biSafoHi Alsyf, with fet-h: (S:) the pl. [of SafoHN] is SifaAHN (K, TA) and [that of SufoHN↓ is] OaSofaAHN. (TA.) AlrRajuli SafoHapN↓ signifies The side (EuroD) of the breast of the man. (L.) And one says, janobihi Darabahu EalaI SafoHapi↓ [He struck him on the surface, or flat part, of his side; and so ElI SafoHi jnbh; but the former is the more common]. (A.) And AlsRayofi jalaA SafoHataI↓ [He polished the two sides, or surfaces, of the sword]. (A.) And Alwaraqapi kataba fiI SafoHataIi↓ [He wrote upon the two sides, or faces, of the piece of paper]. (A.) AlkitaAbi SafaHaAtu↓ signifies The pages, or faces of the leaves, of the book. (Msb.) And SafoHu AlkafRi The face [i. e. palm] of the hand. (L.) And SafoHaA Alkatifi The two parts of the scapula that slope down from the Eayor [or spine thereof]: pl. SifaAHN. (L.) And SafoHu Aljabali The part of the mountain where the side thereof rests upon the ground; (S, K;) its safoH [q. v.]: (JM:) pl. SifaAHN. (S.)
SufoHN: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.
SafaHN Excessive width in the forehead. (IAar, K.)
SafoHapN: see SafoHN, in ten places.

[Hence,] OabodaI lahu SafoHatahu (tropical:) i. q. kaAXafahu [which is used alone as meaning kaAXafahu biAlEadaAwapi He showed open enmity, or hostility, with him]: (A, TA:) or he showed, or revealed, to him his deed [or crime] which he was concealing. (TA in art. bdw, from a trad. [which shows it to be used in an evil sense].)

SifaAHN, which is disapproved in horses, is [A quality] like what is termed masoHap [app. meaning a flatness, or an evenness,] in the side (EuroD) of
the cheek, by reason of which its width is excessive. (O, K.)
[It is also an inf. n. of 3, q. v.]

SafuwHN One who has the quality of turning away from the crimes, sins, faults, or offences, of others, and of forgiving; [or rather wont to turn away &c.;] as also SafRaAHN↓: (TA:) AlSRafuwHu, (K, TA,) as an epithet applied to God, (TA,) means the Very Forgiving; or He who forgives much. (K, TA.)
And Generous; (K;) because the generous man forgives those who act injuriously towards him. (TA.)
And A woman who turns away from one; who forsakes one's society: as though not giving aught but her side. (K.)

SafiyHN: see SafiyHapN, in four places. [It is properly a coll. gen. n.: as such signifying Any kind of thing made flat and broad or wide: as, for instance, plate, or expanded metal: n. un. with p, meaning a piece thereof.]
[Hence, as it is supposed to be an expanded solid substance,] AlSRafiyHu, (K,) or AlSRafiyHu AlOaEolaI, (TA,) is one of the names of Heaven. (K, TA.)

SafiyHapN A wide, or broad, stone; (T, S;) as also SafiyHN↓ (T) and SufRaAHN↓: (S:) or [SafiyHN↓ and] SufRaAHN↓ and SafaAYiHu [which last is pl. of SafiyHapN] signify wide, or broad, stones, which are put over graves: (A:) or SafaAYiHu and SufRaAHN↓ signify wide, or broad, and thin, stones; (K, TA;) one of which is called SafiyHapN and SufRaAHapN↓: (TA:) and anything wide, or broad, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) such as a stone, (TA,) and a plank, or board, (Mgh, TA,) and the like, (TA,) is termed SafiyHapN (Mgh, Msb, TA) and SufRaAHapN↓: (TA:) whence one says, AiXotaraI daArFA fiyhaA SafaAYiHu mino cahaba wafiDRapK [He purchased a house in which were plates of gold and of silver]. (Mgh.) The pl. SafaAYiHu signifies also [particularly] The planks, boards, or leaves, (OalowaAH,) of a door. (S, K.) And Wide, or broad, swords; (A, K;) one such sword being termed SafiyHapN: (S:) or this latter signifies [simply] a sword; and SafiyHN↓, swords. (Ham p. 323.) And The qabaAYil [or principal bones, namely, the frontal, occipital, and two parietal, bones,] of the head; (K;) a single one of these being termed SafiyHapN. (TA.) And SafiyHapN, (S,) or SafiyHN↓, (K,) or each of these, (TA,) signifies The face, or surface, of anything wide, or broad. (S, K, TA.) And SafiyHapu Alwajohi The exterior skin, cuticle, or scarf-skin, of the face. (S.)
SafRaAHN: see SafuwHN.
SufRaAHN; and its n. un., with p: see SafiyHapN, in five places.

Also (tropical:) Camels whose humps have become large, (K, TA,) so that the hump of the she-camel occupies the whole of her back: n. un. with p: (TA:) pl. SufRaAHaAtN and SafaAfiyHu: (K:) likened to wide, or broad, stones or similar things, because of their hardness. (TA.)

SaAfiHN A she-camel, (K,) and a ewe, or she-goat, (TA,) [ceasing to yield her milk;] whose milk is going away: (K, TA:) or a she-camel that has lost her young one, and whose milk has gone. (IAar, TA.)
gayora muqoniEK raOosahu walaA SaAfiHK bixadRihi, occurring in a trad., means [Not lifting up, or elevating, his head,] nor putting forth his cheek, nor inclining on one side. (L.)
OaSofaHu A man excessively wide in the forehead: from SafaHN. (K.)

muSofaHN Wide, or broad; (S, K;) as also muSafRaHN↓, (K,) which latter is the more common; both applied in this sense to a sword, and to anything; and maSofuwHN↓ signifies the same. (TA.) One says, wajohu hecaA AlsRayofi muSofaHN The face of this sword is wide, or broad; from OaSofaHotuhu↓. (S.) And Darabahu biAlsRayofi muSofaHFA, (S, A, K,) and maSofuwHFA↓, (IAar, TA,) and muSofiHFA↓, (A, [this last relating to the agent,]) He struck him with the breadth, or width, [or flat,] of the sword; (S, A, K;) not with its edge: (A:) and Drbh bAlsyf gayora muSofaHK He struck him with the sword not with its breadth, but with its edge. (TA.) And rajulN AlrRaOosi muSafRaHu↓ A man wide, or broad, in respect of the head; (S, TA;) and so muSofaHu AlrRaOosi. (TA.)

Also Having the two sides of his head depressed, and the side of the forehead prominent, (K, TA,) and the occiput also prominent and conspicuous: (TA:) or having the fore and hind parts of the head projecting. (AZ, Mgh.)
And A head compressed in the parts next the temples, so as to be long between the forehead and the back of the neck. (K.)
A nose straight in the bone; (K, TA;) having the bone even with the forehead. (TA.)
And A smooth, or soft, or smooth and soft, and beautiful, face. (Lh, K.)

Applied to a sword, (TA,) Inclined, or bent: (S, K, TA:) and inverted, or reversed: (Ibn-Buzurj, K, TA:) that is turned upon its edge when one strikes with it: and that is inclined, or bent, when one desires to sheath it. (TA.)

It is said in a trad., qalobu AlmuWomini muSofaHN EalaI AlHaqRi, meaning (assumed tropical:) The heart of the believer is inclined to the truth; (S, L;) as though its side (SafoHuhu i. e. jaAnibuhu) were placed upon it. (L.) And muSofaHN applied to a heart signifies also (assumed tropical:) Turned away from the truth: (TA:) [or] so applied, in which are combined faith and hypocrisy: (K, TA:) or, accord. to Khálid, that falls short of its duty; in which is latent rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; and which is not sincere in its religion: (Sh, TA:) or it means double-faced; one who meets the unbelievers with one face, and the believers with another face; SafoHN signifying the “ face, ” of anything. (IAth, TA.)
And AlmuSofaHu is a name of The sixth of the arrows used in the game called Almayosir; (S, K;) as also Almusobilu. (S.)
muSofiHN biAlsRayofi Striking with the side of the sword, not with the edge; (TA;) striking with the face of the sword. (O.) See also muSofaHN.
muSafRaHN: see muSofaHN, in two places.

[Hence,] muSafRaHapN signifies A sword; as also muSafRiHapN↓: (K: [but see what follows:]) accord. to IAar, muSafRaHaAtN [its pl. (K)] signifies swords; because they are made broad, or wide, and lengthened out, in the forging: (S:) or, as some say, it signifies broad, or wide, swords. (TA. [See also SafiyHapN.]) Lebeed says, describing clouds,

[As though there were swords, or broad swords, upon their summits, and wailing women having upon them the pieces of rag which such women hold in wailing and with which they make signs]: (S, TA:) Az says that he likens the lightning, in the darkness of the clouds, to broad swords: (TA:) and IAar says that mSfRHAt here means swords: but as some relate the verse, the word is muSafRiHaAt↓ [meaning women clapping their hands]; as though he likened the clouds' discovering themselves when the lightning shone from them, and they opened, and then met together after the lightning's becoming extinct, to the clapping of women's hands: (S: in some copies of which, Algayov is put for Algayom:) or, accord. to this reading, he likens the sound of the thunder to women's clapping of their hands. (TA.)
Also A she-camel (T, L) that is kept from being milked, in order that she may become fat. (T, L, K.)
muSafRiHapN, and its pl.: see muSafRaHN.
maSofuwHN: see muSofaHN, in two places.
muSaAfiHN One who commits adultery, or fornication, with any woman, whether she be free or a slave. (K.)

1. Safadahu, (S, M, A, Mgh, K,) aor.
Safida
, (S, M, Mgh, K,) inf. n. SafodN (S, M, Mgh) and SufuwdN; (M;) He bound him, bound him fast or made him fast, (S, M, A, Mgh, K,) shackled him, or fettered him, in iron &c., (M,) or with iron, (A,) or with a [collar of iron put upon the neck or around the neck and hands together, such as is called] gulR; (L;) and SfRdhu↓, (M, K,) inf. n. taSofiydN, (S,) signifies the same; (S, M, K;) and so ASfdhu↓, (K,) or this last has a different signification from the two other verbs mentioned above, as expl. below. (L.)
2: see above.
[Hence,] one says, SafRadotuhu, bikalaAmiI, inf. n. taSofiydN I overcame him by my speech. (A, TA.)

4. ASfdhu, (S, M, A, L,) inf. n. UiSofaAdN, (S,) He gave him; (S, M, A, L;) gave him freely, or gratuitously; (L;) property, or a slave: (S:) it is doubly trans. (M.) One says, Uino OafadotaniI HarofFA faqado OaSofadotaniI OalofFO [If thou teach me a word, verily thou givest me what is worth a thousand dirhems]. (A, TA.)
See also 1.
SafodN: see the next paragraph, in three places.

SafadN A bond; (S, K, TA;) as also SafodN↓: (TA:) or, (M, A,) as also SafodN↓, (M,) i. q. SifaAdN↓, (M, A,) which signifies a rope, (M,) or a thong, (S, K,) or a shackle, or fetter, (S, A, K,) or a [collar of iron which is put upon the neck or around the neck and hands together, such as is called] gulR, (S, M, A,) with which one is made fast, (M,) or with which a captive is made fast: (S, A, K:) pl. OaSofaAdN, [expl. in the S and A and K as signifying shackles, or fetters,] the only known pl., though of the form of a pl. of pauc. (M.)

Also A gift; (S, M, A, K;) [said to be] so called because he upon whom it is conferred is bound thereby; (Ksh and Bd in xxxviii. 37;) and so SafodN↓: (M:) pl. as above. (L.) One says, AlSRafadu SafadN The gift is a shackle, or fetter. (A.)
And i. q. vanaMCN [which generally means Praise, eulogy, or commendation; but is said by some to mean also the contr.]. (M.)
SifaAdN: see the next preceding paragraph.
nahiIa Eano SalaApi AlSRaAfidi The praying of him who puts his feet together as though they were fettered is forbidden. (L, from a trad.)
UiSofidN is used by a poet for UiSofinoTN [q. v.]. (M.)

1. Safara aor.
Safira
, inf. n. SafiyrN, (S, M, K,) with which SufaArN↓ is syn. in a phrase mentioned below; (S;) and SfRr↓, (M, K,) inf. n. taSofiyrN; (TA;) He, or it, (a bird, a vulture, S, and a serpent, or the Oasowad, or OaEoraj, or Aibon qitorap, or OaSalap, M,) whistled; syn. mkaA; (S;) made, or uttered, a certain sound, (M, Msb, * K,) without the utterance of letters. (Msb.) [It is mostly said of a bird: see an ex. voce jawRN.] One says [also], Safara fiI AlSRafRaArapi [He whistled in the whistle]. (M, K.) And Safara biAloHimaAri, and SfRr↓, He called the ass to water [by whistling; for to do thus is the common custom of the Arabs]. (M, K.) And Fr mentions the phrase, kaAna fiI kalaAmihi SafaArN↓, meaning SafiyrN [i. e. There was in his speech a whistling]. (S.)

Safira, aor.
Safara
, inf. n. SafarN (S, M, A, K, &c.) and SufuwrN; (M, K;) and accord. to the T, Safara, aor.
Safura
, inf. n. SufuwrapN; (TA;) It, or he, was, or became, empty, void, or vacant; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) namely, a house or tent; (S;) or a vessel, (S, M, &c.,) mina AlTRaEaAmi waAlXRaraAbi [of food and beverage]; and a skin, mina AllRabani [of milk]; (TA;) and a hand; (A;) and a thing; (S, M;) and accord. to ISk, Safira, aor
Safara
, inf. n. SafiyrN, is said of a man. (TA.) [See also 4, last sentence but one.] One says, naEuwcu biAllRehi mino qaraEi AlfinaMCi waSafari AlUinaMCi (S, M, A) [We seek preservation by God from the yard's becoming void of cattle, and the vessel's becoming empty;] meaning, from the perishing of the cattle. (S.) And Safirato wiTaAbuhu, (M, A, K, [in the CK, erroneously, waToAatuhu,]) and Safira UinaAWuhu, (A,) [lit. His milk-skins, and his vessel, became empty;] meaning (tropical:) he died; (M, K;) he perished. (A. [See also other explanations in art. wTb.])
Sufira, (M, K,) inf. n. SaforN, (K,) He had what is termed SufaAr, i. e. yellow water in his belly. (M, K.)
2: see above, in two places.
and see 4.
Also SfRrhu, (S, M, K,) inf. n. taSofiyrN, (K,) He made it yellow: (S:) he dyed it yellow; (M, K;) namely, a garment, or piece of cloth. (M.)

4. ASfrhu He emptied it; or made it void, or vacant; namely, a house or tent [&c.]; (M, K;) as also SfRrhu↓, (K,) inf. n. taSofiyrN. (TA.) The Arabs say, maA OaSogayotu laka UinaMCF walaA OaSofarotu laka finaMCF [I have not overturned a vessel belonging to thee, nor have I emptied a yard belonging to thee]; meaning I have not taken thy camels nor thy property, so that thy vessel should be overturned and thou shouldst find no milk to milk into it, and so that thy yard should be empty, plundered, no camel or sheep or goat lying in it: it is said in excusing oneself. (M.)
[Accord. to Freytag, ASfr signifies also It (a house) was, or became, empty, or void, of (mino) household-goods: so that it is syn. with Safira: and this is probably correct: for
] OaSofara, (S, K,) also, (K,) signifies He was, or became, poor; (S, K;) said of a man. (S.)

5. tSfRr AlmaAlu The cattle became in good condition, the vehement heat of summer having departed from them: [or,] accord. to Sgh, tSfRrt AlUibilu signifies The camels became fat in the [season called the] SafariyRap. (TA.)

9. ASfrR It become OaSofar [i. e. yellow: and also black]: (S, M, K:) and so ASfArR↓: (S, K:) or the former signifies it was so constantly: and the latter, it was so transiently. (Az, TA. [See 9 in art. Hmr.])
11: see the next preceding paragraph.
SaforN: see SiforN.
SuforN: see SiforN.

Also, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) and SiforN↓ accord. to AO, (S, M, Msb, *) who allowed no other form, but the former is the better, (M,) [Brass;] the metal of which vessels are made; (S;) i. q. nuHaAsN [which means both copper and brass]; (A, Msb;) or a sort of nuHaAs; or nuHaAs made yellow; (M;) or the best sort of nuHaAs; (Msb;) or an excellent sort thereof: (TA:) n. un. SuforapN↓. (M.)

And Gold: (M, A, K: [see also AlSRaforaMCu, voce OaSofaru:]) or deenars; either because they are yellow (SuforN [pl. of OaSofaru]), or thus called because resembling the Sufor of which vessels are made. (M.)
And Women's ornaments. (A.)

UinRahu lafiI Suforihi, (S, O, TA, [thus in an old and very excellent copy of the S, in another copy of which I find, as in Freytag's Lex., SuforapK↓,]) and Siforihi↓, (TA,) [app. means He is in that state in which he requires to be rubbed with saffron; for it] is said of him who is affected by madness, when he is in the days in which his reason fails; because they used to rub him with somewhat of saffron. (S, O, L.)

SiforN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and SuforN↓ and SufurN↓ and SafirN↓ (M, K) and SaforN↓ (M) and OaSofaru↓ (Msb) Empty, void, or vacant; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) applied to a house or tent, (S, Msb,) and to a vessel, (M, A,) and to a hand: (A:) each of the first three is used alike as masc. and fem. and sing. [and dual] and pl.: (M:) [and so, app., is the last but one:] and each has also for its pl. OaSofaArN. (M, K.) One says bayotN SiforN mina AlmataAEi A house, or tent, or chamber, empty, or void, of furniture and utensils. (S.) And [applying the pl. form of the epithet to a sing. subst.,] UinaMCN OaSofaArN An empty vessel; (M, K;) like as one says buromapN OaEoXaArN; on the authority of IAar: (M:) and [applying the sing form of the epithet to a pl. subst.,] MniyapN SiforN empty vessels. (M, K.) And rajulN Siforu Alyadayoni A man empty-handed. (S, Msb.) And SiforN mina Alxayori (assumed tropical:) Void of good. (TA.) And it is said, in a trad., of Umm-Zara, that she was SiforN ridaAWuhaA meaning (assumed tropical:) Lank in her belly; as though her rdAC, which is a garment that falls upon the belly and there ends, were empty. (TA.) And huwa SiforN SiHorN It is [utterly] empty; SHr being an imitative sequent. (Kh, Ham p. 354.)

SiforN in arithmetical notation, in the Indian method, is A circle [or the character h, denoting nought, or zero; whence our term “ cipher: ” when nought is thus denoted, five is denoted by a character resembling our B: but more commonly, in the present day, nought is denoted by a round dot; and five, by h]. (L, TA.)
See also SuforN, in two places.
SafarN [an inf. n. of Safira, q. v.:
and hence,] Hunger: and SaforapN↓ [the inf. n. un.] a hungering once. (M, K.)
Also A certain disease in the belly, which renders the face yellow: (M, K:) or a collecting of water in the belly. (Kt.) [See also SufaArN.]

Also A kind of serpent, (S, M, K,) in the belly, (S, K,) which sticks to the ribs, and bites them, (M, K,) or, as the Arabs assert, which bites a man when he is hungry, its bite occasioning the stinging which a man feels when he is hungry: (S:) used alike as sing. and pl.; or one is termed SafarapN: (M:) and it is said to be what is meant by the word in a trad., in which it is disacknowledged: (S, TA:) or a certain reptile (daAbRap) which bites the ribs and their cartilages: (M, K:) or a certain serpent in the belly, which attacks beasts and men, and which, accord. to the Arabs [of the time of Ignorance], passes from one to another more than the mange or scab; (Ru-beh:) the Prophet, however, denied its doing so: it is said also that it oppresses and hurts a man when he is hungry: (A'Obeyd:) this is the explanation approved by Az: (TA:) or, as also SufaArN↓, worms in the belly, (M, K, TA,) and in the cartilages of the ribs, which cause a man to become very yellow, and sometimes kill him. (TA.) You say, EaDRa EalaI Xurosuwfihi AlSRafaru, meaning, (tropical:) He was hungry. (A.)

Accord. to some, (M,) in the trad. above referred to, SafarN signifies The postponing of [the month] El-Moharram, transferring it to Safar: (A'Obeyd, M, K:) [see nasiIoCN:] or it there means the disease called by this name, because they asserted it to be transitive. (K.)

Also The intellect, or understanding; or the heart, or mind; syn. ruwEN: (M, K: [in the CK rawoE:]) the inmost part (lubR) of the heart. (M, K.) Hence the saying, (TA,) laA yalotaATu hecaA biSafariI This will not adhere to me, [or to my mind,] nor will my soul accept it: (S, TA:) said of that which one does not love. (A.)
Also A contract, compact, or covenant: or suretiship, or responsibility: syn. EaqodN. (M, L, K. [In some copies of the K, fqd.])

Also (S, M, Msb, K) and sometimes [Safaru,] imperfectly decl., (K,) but all make it perfectly decl. except AO, who makes it imperfectly decl. because it is determinate [or a proper name] and similar in meaning to saAEapN, which is fem., meaning that all nouns signifying times are saAEaAt, (Th, M,) and, accord. to some, AlSRafaru, (Msb,) [The second month of the Arabian calendar;] the month that is [the next] after ElMoharram (AlmuHarRamu): (S, M, K:) so called because in it they used to procure their provision of corn from the places [in which it was collected, their granaries having then become empty (Sifor); agreeably with the opinion of my learned friend Mons. Fulgence Fresnel, that it was so called from the scarcity of provisions in the season in which it fell when it was first named; for it then fell in winter: see the latter of the two tables in p. 1254; and see also nasiIoCN]: or because Mekkeh was then empty, its people having gone forth to travel: or, accord. to Ru-beh, because the Arabs in it made predatory expeditions, and left those whom they met empty: (M:) or because they then made predatory expeditions, and left the houses of the people empty: (Msb in art. jmd:) pl. OaSofaArN, (S, M, Msb, K,) and, as some say, SafaraAtN. (Msb.)
AlSRafaraAni The two months of El-Moharram and Safar; (M;) two months of the year, whereof one was called by the Muslims El-Moharram. (IDrd, M, Msb, K.)
SafirN: see SiforN, first sentence.
SufurN: see SiforN, first sentence.
SaforapN: see SafarN, [of which it is the n. un.,] first sentence.
SuforapN [Yellowness;] a certain colour, (S, M, Msb,) well known, (M, K,) less intense than red, (Msb,) found in animals and in some other things, and, accord. to IAar, in water. (M.)
Also Blackness. (M, K.)
See also SuforN, in two places.
Suforapu, imperfectly decl., is a proper name for The she-goat. (Sgh, K.)

SafariIRN (S, M, K) and SafariyRapN↓ (K) The increase, or offspring, (nitaAj,) of sheep or goats (S, M, K [in the CK, Aw is erroneously put for w before this explanation]) after that called qayoZiIRN: (S, TA:) or at the period of the [auroral] rising of Suheyl [or Canopus, which, in Central Arabia, at the commencement of the era of the Flight, was about the 4th of August, O. S.; here erroneously said in the M to be in the beginning of winter]: (M, K:) or ↓the latter word signifies [as above, and also the period itself above mentioned: or] the period from the rising of Suheyl to the setting of AlcRiraAE [the Seventh Mansion of the Moon, which, in the part and age above mentioned, was about the 3rd of January, O. S.], when the cold is intense; and then breeding is approved: (M:) or the period from the rising of Suheyl to the rising of AlsRimaAk [the Fourteenth Mansion of the Moon, which, in the part and age above mentioned, was about the 4th of October, O. S.], commencing with forty nights of varying, or alternating, heat and cold, called AlmuEotadilaAtu: (AZ:) the first increase [of sheep and goats] is the SaqaEiIR, which is when the sun smites (taSoqaEu) the heads of the young ones; and some of the Arabs call it the XamosiIR, and the qayoZiIR: then is the SafariIR, after the SaqaEiIR; and that is when the fruit of the palm-tree is cut off: then, the XatawiIR, which is in the [season called] rabiyE: then, the dafaYiIR, which is when the sun becomes warm: then, the SayfiIR: then, the qayoZiIR: then, the xarafiIR, in the end of the [season called] qayoZ: (Aboo-Nasr:) or SafariyRapN signifies, (M, K,) and so SafariIRN, (K,) the [period of the] departure of the heat and the coming of the cold: (AHn, M, K:) or the period between the departure of the summer and the coming of the winter: (Aboo-Sa'eed:) or the first of the seasons; [app. meaning the autumnal season, called Alxariyf, which was the first of the four, and of the six, seasons; or perhaps the first of the seasons of rain, commonly called AlwasomiIR;] and it may be a month: (AHn, M, K:) or the latter, (M,) or both, (TA,) the beginning of the year. (M, TA.) [Hence,] OayRaAmu AlSRafariyRapi↓ Twenty days of, or from, (mino,) the latter part of the summer, or hot season. (TA voce HulRabN.)
Also the former, (S,) or ↓both, (TA,) The rain that comes in the beginning of autumn: (S:) or from the period of the rising of Suheyl to that of the setting of AlcRiraAE [expl. above]. (TA.)

Also the latter, (S, M,) or ↓both, (K,) A plant that grows in the beginning of the autumn: (S, M, K:) so called, accord. to AHn, because the beasts become yellow when they pasture upon that which is green; their arm-pits and similar parts, and their lips and fur, becoming yellow; but [ISd says,] I have not found this to be known. (M.)

SuforiyRapN A sort of dates of El-Yemen, which are dried in the state in which they are termed busor, (AHn, M, K,) being then yellow; and when they become dry, and are rubbed with the hand, they crumble, and sawiyq is sweetened with them, and they surpass sugar; (AHn, M;) [or] they supply the place of sugar in sawiyq. (K.)

AlSRuforiyRapu, (S, M, K,) and, (K,) or as some say, (S, M,) AlSRiforiyRapu↓, (M, K,) A sect of the xawaArij, (S,) a party of the HaruwriyRap; (M, K;) so called in relation to Sufrah (Suforapu [which is the name of a place in El-Yemámeh]): (M:) or in relation to Ziyád Ibn-El-Asfar, (S, K,) their head, or chief; (S;) or to 'Abd-Allah (S, M, K) Ibn-Es-Saffár, (S,) or Ibn-Saffár, (K,) or Ibn-Safár, (so in a copy of the M,) in which case it is extr. in form; (M;) or on account of the yellowness of their complexions; or because of their being void of religion; (K;) accord. to which last derivation, it is AlSRiforiyRapu↓, with kesr; and As holds this to be the right opinion. (TA.)
And the former (AlSRuforiyRapu) The mahaAlibap, (M, K,) who were celebrated for bounty and generosity; (TA;) so called in relation to Aboo-Sufrah, (M, K,) who was [surnamed] Abu-l-Mohelleb. (M.)
AlSRiforiyRapu: see the next preceding paragraph in two places.
SafariyRapN: see SafariIRN, in five places.
SiforiytN is the sing. of SafaAriytu, (S,) which signifies Poor men: (S, K:) the t is augmentative. (S.)

SafaArN, (S, M,) with fet-h, (S,) or SufaArN↓, like guraAbN, (K,) What is dry, of [the species of barleygrass called] buhomaI: (S, M, K:) app. because of its yellowness: (M:) it has prickles that cling to the lips of the horses. (TA in art. Xfh.)
And the former, accord. to ISk, A certain plant. (TA.)
SufaArN: see 1, in two places.

Also A certain disease, in consequence of which one becomes yellow: (A:) the yellow water that collects in the belly; (M, K;) i. q. siqoIN: (M:) or a collecting of yellow water in the belly, which is cured by cutting the naAYiT, a vein in the Sulobi [i. e. backbone, or back]. (S.)
See also SafarN.
And see SafaArN.
Also A yellowness that takes place in wheat before the grain has become full. (A, TA.)
And Remains of straw and of other fodder, at the roots of the teeth of beasts; as also SifaArN↓. (M, K.)

And The tick, or ticks: (M, K:) and, (K,) or as some say, (M,) an insect, or animalcule, (duwayobRapN,) that is found in the solid hoofs, and in the toes, or soles, of camels, (M, K,) in the hinder parts thereof. (M.)
SifaArN: see the next preceding paragraph.
SafiyrN inf. n. of Safara [q. v.]. (S, M, K.)
[In the present day it signifies also The sapphire.]
SufaArapN What has withered, (M, K,) and become altered to yellow, (M,) of plants, or herbage. (M, K.)
SafiyrapN A dam (DafiyrapN) between two tracts of land. (Sgh, K.)
SufaAraI A species of bird, that whistles (yaSofiru). (M. [See also what next follows.])

SufaAriyRapN A certain bird; (IAar, S;) as also SufaAriyapN, without teshdeed; (S;) the bird called tubaXRirN, (S in art. bXr,) or tubuXRirN: (K in that art.:) [Golius (who writes the word SafaAriyRapN) adds, “ ut puto, quæ in Syria SufayorA dicitur, flava, duplo major passere, nam et passer luteus, ut reddit Meid. ”:] i. q. SaEowapN. (IAar.) [See also AlOaSoqaEu.]
SufuwriyRapN, accord. to the K, A kind of nabaAt [i. e. plant]: but in the Tekmileh, a kind of viyaAb [i. e. garments, or cloths]; pl. of vawob; and it bears the mark of correctness. (TA.)
SafRaArN: see SaAfirN
Also A fabricator of Sufor [or brass]. (M, K.)
SufRaArN, with damm, The entire quill of a feather. (AA, O.)
SafRaArapN [A whistle: so in the present day: and also a fife:] a hollow thing (M, K) of copper, (K,) in which a boy whistles (M, K) to pigeons, (K,) or to an ass, that he may drink. (TS, L, K.)
[Hence,] AlSRafRaArapu The anus; syn. AlAisotu; (M, K;) in the dial. of the Sawád. (TA.)
SaAfirN Whistling; or a whistler. (TA.)

And hence, (TA,) A thief; (K;) as also SafRaArN↓: [or this signifies a frequent, or habitual, whistler:] the thief being so called because he whistles in fear of his being suspected: whence, as some explain it, the saying Oajobanu mino SaAfirK [More cowardly than a thief]: (TA:) a prov.: accord. to AO, it means in this instance one who whistles to a woman for the purpose of fornication or adultery; because he fears lest he should be seen: or

accord. to A'Obeyd, Any bird that whistles; for birds of prey do not whistle, but only ignoble birds, that are preyed upon: (Meyd:) [or] any bird that does not prey: (M, K:) and any bird having a cry: and a certain cowardly bird: (K:) [accord. to Dmr, as stated by Freytag, it is a bird of the passerine kind; also called SaAfiriyRapN↓:] accord. to Mohammad Ibn- Habeeb, (Meyd,) a certain bird that suspends itself from trees, hanging down its head, whistling all the night in fear lest it should sleep and be taken; and so in the prov. above mentioned: (Meyd, A: *) or, accord. to IAar, it means bihi maSofuwrN↓ [whistled to]: i. e., when he is whistled to, he flees: and by bihi AlmaSofuwru↓ is meant the bird called AltnwRT [i. e. AltRanawRuTu or AltRunawRiTu &c.], the cowardice of which induces it to weave for itself a nest like a purse, suspended from a tree, narrow in the mouth and wide in the lower part, in which it protects itself, fearing lest a bird of prey should light upon it: (Meyd: [see also art. nwT:]) or any coward. (TA.)
SaAfiriyRapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
OaSofaru [a comparative and superlative epithet form Safara]. One says OaSofaru mino bulobulK [A greater whistler, or warbler, than the blbl]. (S.)
See also SiforN.

[Also More, and most, empty, void, or vacant.] It is said in a trad., OaSofaru Albuyuwti mina Alxayori Albayotu AlSRiforu mino kitaAbi QllRehi [That one of houses which is the most void of good is the house that is destitute of the Book of God]. (S.)

Also [Yellow;] of the colour termed SuforapN: (S, M, K:) fem. SaforaMCu: (Msb, &c.:) pl. SuforN. (TA.) And Black (A'Obeyd, S, K) is sometimes thus termed: (S:) applied to a camel, as in the Kur lxxvii. 33, because a black camel always has an intermixture of yellow: (TA:) or, applied to a camel, of a colour whereof the ground is black, with some yellow hairs coming through. (M.) Applied to a horse, Of the colour termed in Pers. zarodaho [a kind of sorrel], (S,) but not unless having a yellow [or sorrel] tail and mane. (As, S.)

banuw AlOaSofari The Greeks (AlrRuwmu): (S, A:) or their kings: because the sons of El-Asfar the son of Room the son of 'Eesoo (or 'Eysoon, TA, [i. e. Esau,]) the son of Is-hák [or Isaac] (K) the son of Ibráheem [or Abraham]: (TA:) or El-Asfar was a surname of Room: (TA:) or they were so called because their first ancestor, (A, IAth,) Room the son of 'Eysoon, (IAth,) was of a yellow complexion: (A, IAth:) or because they were conquered by an army of Abyssinians by whom their women had yellow children: (K:) [or] they are the modern Muscovites. (TA.)

AlOaSofaraAni Gold and saffron; (S, M, K;) which are said to destroy women: (TA:) or the plant called waros and saffron: (S, K:) or the plant called waros and gold: (M:) or saffron and raisins. (ISk, Sgh, K.)

And AlSRaforaMCu Gold. (M, K. [See also SuforN.]) Hence the saying of 'Alee, yaA SaforaMCu QSofarRiI wayaA bayoDaMCu QboyaDRiI wagurRiI gayoriI O gold, [be yellow,] and O silver, [be white, and beguile other than me:] and one says also, maA lifulaAnK SaforaMCu walaA bayoDaMCu [There is not belonging to such a one gold nor silver]. (TA.)

Also A kind of bile, (M, K,) well-known; (K;) [the yellow bile; one of the four humours of the body; of which the others are the black bile (AlsRawodaMCu), the blood (AldRamu), and the phlegm (Albalogamu):] so called because of its colour. (M.)
And The bow that is made of [the tree called] naboE. (S, * K, * TA.)
And The female locust that is devoid of eggs. (M, K.)

And A certain plant, (S, M, K,) of the plain or soft tracts, and of the sands, (M, K,) and sometimes growing in hard level ground: (M:) or a certain herb, that spreads upon the ground, (AHn, M,) the leaves of which are like those of the xasR [or lettuce], (AHn, M, K,) and which the camels eat vehemently: (AHn, M:) it is of the kind called cukuwr. (Aboo-Nasr, M.)
muSofarN: see its fem., with p, voce maSofuwrN.
muSofirN A poor man. (S.)
muSafRarN; and its fem., with p: see maSofuwrN.

huwa maSafRiru Qsotihi is from AlSRafiyru, [see Safara,] not from AlSRuforapu, (S,) and means He is a SarRaAT; (S, K;) as though denoting cowardice: (TA:) or it is from SafRara “ he dyed yellow; ” (M;) and was applied to Aboo-Jahl; (M, TA;) meaning that he dyed his Aisot with saffron, and was addicted to [the enormity termed] Oubonap: this, accord. to Sgh, is the correct explanation; and he adds that it is said of a luxurious man, whom experience and afflictions have not rendered firm, or sound, in judgment. (TA.)

AlmuSafRirapu is an appellation applied to Those whose sign [meaning the colour of their ensign] is Suforap; (M, K;) [i. e. whose ensign is yellow;] and is similar to AlmuHamRirapu and AlmubayRiDapu. (M.)
maSofuwrN: see SaAfirN, in two places.
Also Hungry; and so muSafRarN↓. (K.)

Of the maSofuwrap, (TA,) and muSofarap↓, (Mgh, TA,) or muSafRarap↓, (Mgh,) which one is forbidden to offer in sacrifice, (Mgh, TA,) it is said that the first is Such as has the ear entirely cut off; because its ear-hole is destitute of the ear: and the second, the lean, or emaciated; because devoid of fatness; or, accord. to Kt, the first and second have the latter meaning, as though destitute of fat and flesh: (TA:) or the second and third have the latter meaning; or the former meaning: (Mgh:) but accord. to the relation of Sh, what is thus forbidden is termed AlmaSoguwrapu, with g, having the former of the meanings expl. above; which IAth disapproves: (TA in art. Sgr:) or AlmuSagRarapu. (Mgh in that art.)
Also Having the disease termed SufaAr: (A, TA:) or one from whose belly comes forth yellow water. (TA.)

SiforidN A certain bird, (S, M, K,) of a cowardly nature, (K,) larger than the sparrow, (M,) that frequents houses, and is the most cowardly of birds; (Lth;) it is afraid of the [little bird called] SaEowap; (IAar;) and is by the vulgar (S) called Oabuw AlmaliyHi. (S, K. [Accord. to Golius, the nightingale: but this I think a mistake.]) Oajobanu mino SiforidK [More cowardly than a sifrid] is a prov., (S, Meyd,) asserted by AO to be postclassical. (Meyd. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 372.])
UiSofanoTN a dial. var. of UisofanoTN, q. v. (As, K.)

1. SafaEahu, aor.
SafaEa
, (O, Msb, K,) inf. n. SafoEN, (S, * O, Msb, TA,) accord. to Lth, (O, TA,) He struck him with his fist, not vehemently, on the back of his neck: (O, K, TA:) or, (O, K,) accord. to Az (O, Msb, TA) and others, (Msb,) he struck him [i. e. slapped him] with his expanded hand (O, Msb, K, TA) on the back of his neck, or on his body; not with the fist: (O, Msb, TA:) or it is post-classical: (S, K:) [but Fei says,] the assertion that it is post-classical is not to be regarded: (Msb:) Az adds, IDrd says that it is from SawofaEapN↓, (O, TA,) which signifies the top, or uppermost part, of the [cap called] kumRap, and of the turban: (O, K, TA:) or this is a mistranscription, and is correctly with q: (K, TA:) [Sgh says,] this which Az mentions, [as] on the authority of IDrd, I have not found in the Jm; and it is correctly with q. (O.)
SafoEapN A single act of striking [or slapping] with the expanded hand upon the back of the neck, or upon the body. (Msb.)
SafoEaAnu or SafoEaAnN (accord. to different copies of the S and K) A man who is struck [or slapped] in the manner expl. above in the first paragraph; (S, Msb, K;) as also maSofaEaAniIRN↓. (O, K.)
SawofaEapN: see the first paragraph of this art.
maSofaEaAniIRN: see SafoEaAnu.

1. SafoqN [inf. n. of Safaqa] signifies The striking [a thing] so as to cause a sound to be heard in consequence thereof; (S, O, K;) as also taSofiyqN [inf. n. of SfRq↓, but this has an intensive signification]: (S:) and taSofaAqN is [also] an inf. n. of Safaqa, like Safoq in the phrase Safoqu AlkafRi EalaI AlOuxoraI [the striking of the hand upon the other hand], but denoting muchness of the action. (Sb, M, TA.) [Hence several meanings of both of these verbs, here following.]

Safaqa raOosahu, and Eayonahu, (M,) and Safaqahu EalaI raOosihi, (Msb,) aor.
Safiqa
, inf. n. SafoqN, (M, Msb,) He struck his head, and his eye, (M,) and he struck him on his head with the hand. (Msb.) And Safaqahu biAlsRayofi, (O, K,) inf. n. SafoqN, (O,) He struck him with the sword. (O, K.) And Safaqa bihi AlOaroDa [lit. He smote the ground with him; meaning he flung him upon the ground]. (L, TA.)
Safaqa bijanaAHayohi, (M, K,) aor. as above, (M,) [inf. n. SafoqN,] said of a bird, He beat [his sides, or the air,] with his wings; (M, L, K; *) as also SifRq↓, (M, K,) inf. n. taSofiyqN. (TA.)

Safaqatohu AlrRiyHu, and SfRqthu↓, The wind smote it so as to cause a sound to be heard: (S:) or the latter signifies [simply] the wind smote it, or beat it: (Ham p. 719:) [or the wind beat upon it; namely, a sail &c.: (see XiraAEN:)] [and] both signify the wind shifted it to the right and left, and turned it back: (TA: [in the CK, AltRatoliybu is erroneously put for AltRaqoliybu as an explanation of AltRaSofiyqu:]) and AlrRiyHu AlmaMCa SfRqt↓ The wind beat the water so that it made it clear: (M:) and Safaqati AlrRiyHu AlOaXojaAra, (K,) aor. as above, inf. n. SafoqN, (O,) The wind put the trees in motion, or into a state of commotion, (O, K,) and shook them: (O, TA:) and AlrRiyHu SfRqt↓ AlsRaHaAba The wind smote the clouds, [for Saramatohu in my original, an obvious mistranscription, I read Darabatohu,] and blew in different directions upon them. (TA.)
Safaqa AlEuwda, (inf. n. SafoqN, TA,) He put in motion [by striking them] the chords of the lute. (S, O, K.)

Safaqa yadahu biAlbayoEapi and Safaqa EalaI yadihi, inf. n. SafoqN (M, K) and SafoqapN, (K,) [or the latter, which see below, is a simple subst.,] He struck his hand upon his [another's] hand by way of ratifying the sale, or the covenant; (M, K;) and so Safaqa lahu AlbayoEa, aor.
Safiqa
, (K,) inf. n. SafoqN: (TA:) or Safaqotu lahu biAlbayoEi and biAlbayoEapi, inf. n. SafoqN, I struck my hand upon his hand [by way of ratifying the sale and the covenant]. (S, O, Msb.) [See also safaqa. And see an ex. in a verse cited voce radaAdN.]

SafoqN (S, O, K) as inf. n. of Safaqotuhu, (S, O,) also signifies The shutting, or closing [a thing]; and the turning, or sending, or putting, [a thing] back, or away; (S, O, K;) as also UiSofaAqN↓. (K.) You say, Safaqa Eayonahu He shut, or closed, his eye. (S, O, K.) And Safaqa AlbaAba, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) aor.
Safiqa
, (M,) inf. n. SafoqN, (M, Msb,) He shut or closed, the door; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also ASfqhu↓: (S, O:) or both signify he locked the door: (M, K:) and in like manner safaqahu [and Asfqhu]. (TA.) And He opened the door: (ADk, O, Msb, K:) thus having two contr. significations. (Msb.) And Safaqa maAXiyatahu, inf. n. SafoqN, He turned, or sent, his cattle back, or away. (M, TA.) And Safaqahumo Eano kacaA He turned them [i. e. men] back, or away, from such a thing. (TA.) And one says, maA zaAluwA yaSofiquwnaniI They ceased not to turn me about in an affair: [meaning that] they endeavoured to induce him to do it. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)
Safaqahumo mino baladK UilaI baladK They expelled them from town to town, or from country to country, forcibly and ignominiously. (TA.)
Safaqa AlXRaraAba: see 2.

Safaqa AlqadaHa, (O, K,) inf. n. SafoqN, (O, TA,) He filled the drinking-vessel; as also ASfqhu↓; (O, K;) and SfRqhu↓: (O:) or AlkaOosa SfRq↓, and ASfqhA↓, he filled the drinking-cup, or wine-cup: (Lh, M:) and AlHawoDa ASfqnA↓ We collected the water in the watering-trough. (TA.)
And SafaqahaA, inf. n. SafoqN, He compressed her; syn. jaAmaEahaA. (TA.)
And SafoqN signifies also The collecting together [a thing or things]. (TA.)
Safaqa AlrRajulu, (M, K,) inf. n. SafoqN, (M,) The man went away. (M, K.)
mina Safaqato EalayonaA SaAfiqapN↓ AlnRaAsi A company of men alighted at our abode. (IDrd, M, * O, K. *)

Safaqato, (IDrd, O, K,) inf. n. SafoqN, (TA,) said of a she-camel, Her womb closed against the passage of her fœtus, (Oarotajato raHimuhaA Eano waladihaA, [or Ourotijato i. e. became closed, the syll. signs of this word in the O being doubtful, in the CK erroneously written Artaxato,]) so that the fœtus died. (IDrd, O, K, TA.)

Safuqa, aor.
Safuqa
, (M, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. SafaAqapN, said of a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) It was strong, stout, or firm; (M;) thick, substantial, close, or compact, in texture: (O, Msb, K:) and so safuqa. (T, S, &c., in art. sfq.)
And, said of a face, (S, O, K, TA,) (tropical:) It was impudent; or had little shame. (O, K, TA.)
2: see 1, former half, in five places.

AltRaSofiyqu biAlyadi means The making a sound with the hand [by clapping]: (S:) one says, SfRq biyadayohi [He clapped with his hands; or clapped his hands]: (O, Msb:) and AlnRisaMCu yuSafRiqona EalaI AlmayRiti [The women clap their hands in lamenting over the dead: thus they often do in the present day, over the corpse and over the grave]: (TA:) AltRaSofiyqu is syn. with AltRaSofiyHu: (As, O:) or (O) the former signifies the striking with the palm of one hand upon that of the other; (O, K;) but the latter is better expl. as the striking with the outer side of the right hand upon the inner side of the left hand. (O.) [See also 2 in art. SfH.]
SfRq Alqirobapa, (M, TA,) inf. n. tSofiyqN, (TA,) He poured water into the skin, (M, TA,) and shook it about, (TA,) the skin being new, so that the water came forth yellow. (M.)
See also 1, latter half, in two places.
SfRq AlXRaraAba He mixed the wine, or beverage. (M.)

And, (M,) inf. n. as above; (S, O, K;) and Safaqahu↓, (M,) inf. n. SafoqN; (K;) and ASfqhu↓, (M,) inf. n. UiSofaAqN; (K;) He transferred the wine, or beverage, from one vessel to another, (S, M, O, K,) or from one jar to another, (As, TA,) it being mixed, (K,) in order that it might become clear. (M, K.)

taSofiyqu AlUibili means The removing of camels from a place which they have depastured to a place in which is pasture: (S, O, K: *) thus in the saying of the rájiz (Aboo-Mohammad El-Fak'asee, O) cited in the first paragraph of art. zl: (S, O:) or AltRaSofiyq in that instance, accord. to IAar, is from SfRq Alqawomu fiI AlbilaAdi The people, or party, went far in the country in search of pasture: (M:) [or] SfRq, said of a man, (Ibn- 'Abbád, O,) inf. n. as above, (K,) means He went away; and he went round about. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.)
And AltRaSofiyqu signifies also The forming a determined intention or purpose, and then reversing it. (TA.)
3. SAfq Einoda Safoqapi AlbayoEi [He struck his hand upon that of another in token of the ratification of the sale]. (T in art. dw. [See also 6.])

SAfqt said of a she-camel, She lay, or slept, upon one side one time and upon the other side another time: from SafoqN meaning jaAnibN. (M. [And the same is indicated in the O.]) And fulaAnN yuSaAfiqu bayona janobayohi Such a one turns over upon this Safoq [or side] one time and upon the other another. (O.) And baAta fulaAnN yuSaAfiqu [Such a one passed the night turning over from side to side]. (Z, TA.)

[Accord. to the K, said of a she-camel, She was taken with the pains of parturition; i. q. maxaDato: but this is app. a mistake; for it seems to have been taken from the saying in the O, (one of the principal sources of the K,) UicaA maxaDati AlnRaAqapu SaAfaqato, which evidently means When the she-camel is taken with the pains of parturition, she turns over from side to side; as is there indicated by the context both before and after.]
SAfq bayona qamiySayoni, (M,) or byn vawobayoni, (K,) He wore two shirts, (M,) or two garments, (K,) one of them over the other. (M, K.)
4: see 1, latter half, in five places:
and see also 2.

OaSofaquwA Ealayohi i. q. tabaAyaEuwA Ealayohi [i. e. They made a covenant, or compact, respecting it, or to do it, as though by striking their hands together], namely, the thing, or affair: (TA in art. byE: [see Safaqa yadahu biAlbayoEapi; and see also 3, and 6, and SafoqapN:]) they combined consentaneously, or agreed together, respecting it, or to do it, namely, the thing, or affair; syn. OaTobaquwA Ealayohi, (S, O, K,) or AijotamaEuwA Ealayohi. (M.) And OaSofaquwA EalayonaA [They combined, or collected themselves together, against us]. (M, from a verse of Zuheyr.) OaSofaqato lahu
nisowaAnu makRapa occurs in a trad. as meaning The women of Mekkeh collected themselves together to him: or, as some relate it, AinoSafaqato↓. (TA.) And one says, OaSofaquwA lahu meaning HaXaduwA [i. e. They collected themselves together to him; or they combined to treat him with courtesy and honour]. (M.)
ASfq lahumo He brought them as much food as would satisfy their hunger: (O, K:) said in relation to the entertainment of guests. (O.)

OaSofaqato yaduhu bikacaA, (S, O,) or yadiI, (K,) His hand, or my hand, lighted on, met with, or encountered, such a thing; syn. SaAdafatohu and waAfaqatohu. (S, O, K.) En-Nemir Ibn-Towlab says, (S, O, TA,) describing a jazRaAr [or slaughterer of camels], (TA,)
[Until, or until when, the share was divided, and his hand lighted on the skin of her udder and her young one]. (S, O, TA: but in the S, TuriHa is put in the place of qusima.)
OaSofaqa Alqawomu The people, or party, were, or became, in a state of commotion, or tumult; syn. AiDoTarabuwA. (M, TA. [See also 8.])
OuSofiqa liI It was appointed, or ordained, for me; or prepared for me. (TA.)
ASfq Alganama He milked the sheep, or goats, but once in the day; (S, M, O, TA;) and so with s: (TA in art. sfq:) or AlUiSofaAqu signifies the milking once in the day and night. (TA.)
ASfq AlvRawoba He wove the garment (M, TA) strongly, stoutly, firmly, (M,) thickly, substantially, closely, or compactly. (TA.)

5. tSfRq He (a man) turned over and over; (M;) he moved repeatedly to and fro, syn. taradRada, (M, O, K,) from side to side. (M.) And tSfRqt She (a camel) turned herself over, upside down (lit. back for belly), (O, K, TA,) when taken with the pains of parturition. (TA.)
tSfRq liloOamori He addressed, or applied, or directed, himself, or his regard, or attention, or mind, to the affair; syn. taEarRaDa lahu. (Sh, O, K.)

6. tSAfqwA (S, M, O) They struck their hands upon the hands of others (O) Einoda AlbayoEapi [on the occasion of the ratifying of a sale, or covenant]: (S, O:) or they [struck a bargain;] bought and sold; or made a covenant, or compact; one with another. (M, TA.)
7. AnSfq It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) was beaten by the wind, so that it moved to and fro. (M. TA.) [See also 8.]
It (a door) became shut, or closed: and so with s: (TA in art. sfq:) [or it shut again of itself:] said of a door which, when opened, will not remain open. (TA in art. dlq.)
He (a man, TA) turned, or became turned or sent or put, back, or away: (S, O, K, TA:) he [or it] returned. (TA.)
And AnSfqwA They collected themselves together: the contr. of the next preceding signification. (TA.) See also 4.
And one says, AnSfqwA EalayonaA yamiynFA waXimaAlFA They came upon us on the right and left. (M, TA.)

8. ASTfqt AlOaXojaAru The trees became shaken, or agitated, by the wind. (S, O, K, TA.) And ASTfq AlEuwdu The lute had its chords put in motion, (S, O, K, TA,) so that they responded, one to another. (TA.)
ASTfq AlMfaAqu biAlbayaADi The tracts of the horizon flickered with whiteness, and the light thereof spread. (TA.)
And ASTfq Almajolisu biAlqawomi The sitting-place became a scene of commotion, or tumult, with the people, or party. (TA. [See also 4, latter part.])
SafoqN: see SafoqapN.

Also A side; a lateral part or portion; (S, M, O, K;) and so SufoqN↓, (S, O, K,) and SafaqN↓; (M, O, K;) syn. naAHiyapN, (S, M, O, K,) and jaAnibN. (M, TA.) Of a mountain, (S, O, K,) it signifies in like manner, (O,) its SafoH, (S, O, K,) and its naAHiyap: (S:) [both of which signify as above: or by the former may be meant what here follows:] or its face, (M, K,) in the upper part thereof, above the HaDiyD [or low ground at, or by, the base, or foot]: (M:) pl. SufuwqN. (S, O.) [In like manner also,] SafoqaA AlEunuqi signifies The two sides of the neck. (M, K.) And SafoqaA Alfarasi The two cheeks of the horse. (M, K.)
Also A place. (K.)
See also SifoqN.
And see SafaqN, in two places.
SufoqN: see the next preceding paragraph.

SifoqN, with kesr, The miSoraAE [i. e. either half, or leaf,] of a door [meaning of a folding door]: (K:) [or, accord. to the O, it is SafoqN↓, for it is there said that SafoqaA AlbaAbi means miSoraAEaAhu; but SM follows the reading in the K without remarking upon the difference in the O; and adds,] and one says, baAbu daArihi SifoqN waAHidN [meaning The door of his house is one leaf; i. e.] when it does not consist of what are termed miSoraAEaAni. (TA.)
SafoqN: see SafoqN.

Also Water that is poured into a new skin, and shaken in it, and in consequence becomes yellow; (S, O, K;) or yellow water that comes forth from a new skin upon which water has been poured; (M;) and so SafoqN↓. (M, K.) Hence, (TA,) one says, waradonaA maMCF kaOanRahu SafaqN [We came for the purpose of drinking to water as though it were the yellow water that comes forth from a new skin]. (S, O.)
And A new skin upon [or into] which water is poured, in consequence whereof yellow water comes forth from it. (M.)
Also, accord. to AHn, (M,) or so SafoqN↓, (K,) The odour, and savour, of dibaAg [or tan]. (M, K.)
And The former, accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, The last of dibaAg [or tan]: (O, TA:) in the K, Mxiru AldRimaAgi is erroneously put for Mxr AldRibaAg. (TA.)

SafoqapN A striking of the hand [of one person] upon the hand [of another] in [ratifying] a sale or purchase and a covenant: (Mgh:) and SafoqN↓ is [used in the same sense, being an inf. n. and also] a subst. from the verb in the phrase Safaqa yadahu biAlbayoEapi [expl. in the first paragraph of this art.]; (M, K;) as also SifiqRaI↓, like zimijRaI, (K,) or SifaqRaI↓, (so in a copy of the M,) which is mentioned by Sb, (M, TA,) and of which Seer says that it may be from Safoqu AlkafRi EalaI AlOuxoraI. (TA. [See 1, first sentence.])

Hence it is used to signify The contract itself that is made in the case of a sale, (Mgh, Msb,) and the covenant that one makes: (Mgh:) or an agreement respecting a thing: (M, TA:) Az says that it relates to the seller and the buyer. (Msb.) [And it is sometimes with s in the place of S.] One says, rabiHato Safoqatuka i. e. [May] thy purchase [bring profit]. (S, O.) And baAraka QllRehu laka fiI Safoqapi yamiynika i. e. [May God bless thee in] the contract [(lit. the striking) of thy right hand]. (Msb.) And SafoqapN raAbiHapN, and SafoqapN xaAsirapN, (S, O, K,) A sale or bargain [bringing gain, and a sale or bargain occasioning loss]. (K.) And UinRahu lamubaAraku AlSRafoqapi [Verily he is blessed in respect of bargaining]; meaning that he buys not anything without gaining in it. (TA.) And qadi QXotarayotu Alyawoma SafoqapF SaAliHapF [I have purchased to-day a good purchase]. (TA.) And AlbayoEu SafoqapN Oawo xiyaArN Selling is decisive or with the option of returning. (Mgh.) And it is said in a trad. (of Ibn-Mes'ood, TA), SafoqataAni fiI SafoqapK ribFA i. e. Two bargains in a [single] bargain [are an unlawful gain]: this is of two kinds: one is the seller's saying to the buyer, “ I sell to thee such a thing for a hundred dirhems on the condition of thy buying of me this garment, or piece of cloth, for such a sum: ” the other kind is his saying, “ I sell to thee this garment, or piece of cloth, for twenty dirhems on the condition of thy selling to me thy commodity for ten dirhems. ” (O.) And it is said in another trad., UinRa Oakobara AlkabaAYiri Oano tuqaAtila Oahola Safoqatika i. e. [Verily the greatest of great sins is] thy fighting those with whom thou hast made a covenant: because each of the two persons making a covenant puts his hand in the hand of the other, like as is done by each of two persons selling and buying. (TA.)
SifiqRaI or SifaqRaI: see the next preceding paragraph.

SifaAqN The inferior [or inner] skin, that is beneath the skin upon which is the hair: (S, O, K:) a thin skin beneath the upper skin and above the flesh: (IAth, TA:) or the SifaAq of the belly is the skin, (M,) the inner skin, (TA,) that is next to the sawaAd, (M, TA,) the sawaAd of the belly, (TA,) [i. e. the liver,] and which is the part where the farrier perforates the beast (banoqubu mina AldRaAbRapi) [at the navel, in order that a yellow fluid may issue forth]: (M, TA:) or the SafaAq is the part around the navel, where the farrier performs the operation above mentioned: (AA, TA:) or the skin which, when the masok [or hide] is stripped off, remains cleaving to the belly, and the rending of which occasions a [rupture termed] fatoq; so says As, in the “ Book of the Horse: ” (TA:) or what is between the jilod [or outer skin] and the muSoraAn [or intestines into which the food passes from the stomach]; (ISh, O, K;) com-
prising all of what are termed the maraAqR of the belly, beneath the jilod thereof, to the sawaAd of the belly [i. e. the liver]; the maraAqR of the belly being all that has not a bone curving over it: (ISh, O:) or the skin of the whole of the belly: (O, K:) the pl. is SufuqN, only. (M, TA.)

SafuwqN An abominable acclivity or ascending road or mountain-road difficult of ascent: pl. SafaAYiqu and SufuqN. (M, K.) And A mountain, (K,) or an obstacle, or elevated portion, of mountains, (O,) such as is inaccessible. (O, K.) And A smooth, high rock: pl. SufuqN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
Also, applied to a bow, Pliant. (Fr, O, K.)

[In the TA, in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb describing a bow, to which it seems to be there applied as an epithet, it is expl. as signifying rAjEp; but I think that this is a mistranscription for raAjifapN, meaning Quivering.
Freytag has assigned to it three explanations which belong to SifaAqN.]

SafiyqN, applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) strong, stout, or firm; (M;) thick, substantial, close, or compact, in texture: (Mgh, O, Msb, K:) and safiyqN is a dial. var. thereof. (TA.)
Also (assumed tropical:) Hardy, strong, sturdy, enduring, or patient. (M.)
And applied to a face (S, O, K, TA) as meaning (tropical:) Impudent; or having little shame. (O, K, TA.) And rajulN Safiyqu Alwajohi (assumed tropical:) A man having no shame. (Har p. 368.)
SafiyqapN: see SaAfiqapN.
SafaAYiqu Travelling-camels (rikaAbN) coming and going. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)
See also SaAfiqapN.
SafRaAqN A cock that beats with his wings when crowing. (TA.)

It occurs in a trad., followed by OafRaAq in apposition, and is said by As to mean AalRaciI yaSofiqu EalaI OamorK EaZiymK [app. One who goes away on some great affair]: but in the opinion of Az, it means one who makes many journeys, and who employs himself, or uses art or artifice or cunning, in affairs of traffic; thus nearly agreeing in meaning with OfRaAqN. (O: the latter meaning only is assigned to it in the K.)
SaAfiqapN A company (IDrd, M, O, K) of men [alighting at one's abode]. (IDrd, M, O.) See 1, near the end.

Also A calamity, or misfortune: (M, TA:) pl. SawaAfiqu: (M:) this pl. and SafaAYiqu↓, (O, K, TA,) which latter may be pl. of SafiyqapN↓, (TA,) signify accidents, or evil accidents, (O, K, TA,) and varieties, or vicissitudes, of events. (O, TA.)
OaSofaqu A garment, or piece of cloth, more [strong, stout, firm,] thick, substantial, close, or compact, in texture, than another. (Mgh.)

OaSofaqaAniyRapN [written in one place with fet-h, and in another with kesr, to the f,] i. q. xawalN [A man's slaves, or servants, and other dependents; or slaves, and cattle, or camels &c.;] in the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)
maSofaqN A place of passage; a way, road, or path; syn. masolakN. (O, TA.)

muSafRaqN [pass. part. n. of 2, q. v.]. One says, laka EinodiI wudRN muSafRaqN wanuSoHN murawRaqN (tropical:) [I have, for thee, an affection defecated like wine that has been transferred from one vessel to another and left to settle, and a benevolence purified like clarified wine]. (TA.)
Also A full [or filled] drinking-vessel. (Fr, TA.)
muSaAfiqN A camel lying, or sleeping, upon one side one time and upon the other side another time. (O, K.)
And muSaAfiqN bayona vawobayoni Wearing two garments, one of them over the other. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

1. Safana, aor.
Safina
, inf. n. SufuwnN, said of a horse, He stood upon three legs and the extremity of the hoof of the fourth leg; (AZ, * S, K, TA;) [thus expl.] without restriction to a fore leg or a hind leg: (TA:) or he stood upon three legs, and turned back the extremity of the fore part of the fourth hoof, that of his fore leg: (M, TA:) [or he stood upon three legs, and otherwise: (see SaAfinN:)] accord. to Fr, the poems of the Arabs indicate that SufuwnN signifies peculiarly, or specially, [or simply,] the act of standing, or standing still. (TA.)

Also, (M, Msb, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M, Msb,) said of a man, (K,) or Safana qadamayohi, (TA, from a trad.,) meaning SafRa qadamayohi [He set his feet evenly, side by side], (M, Msb, K, TA,) standing, (Msb,) and praying. (TA.) [Or, said of a man standing in prayer, it signifies, or in this case it signifies also, He put his feet close together: or he turned one of his feet backward, like as the horse turns one hoof when standing upon three legs: see, again, SaAfinN.]

Safana AlHaXiyXa (M, TA) waAlwaraqa, aor.
Safina
, (M,) inf. n. SafonN, said of a bird, or flying thing, It compacted the dry herbage (M, TA) and the leaves, [to make a habitation,] for its young ones, (M,) or around its place of entrance [into its habitation]; (TA;) and SfRnhu↓ signifies the same: (M:) taSofiynN↓ as the act of the hornet and the like is the compacting for itself, or for its young ones, a habitation (K, TA) of dry herbage and of leaves: so says Lth. (TA.)
And Safana viyaAbahu He collected together his clothes (JM, TA) fiI sarojihi [upon his saddle], (TA,) or fiI AlsRaroji wanaHowihi [upon the saddle and the like thereof]. (JM.)

Safana bihi AlOaroDa, (K, TA,) aor.
Safina
, inf. n. SafonN, (TA,) He flung him, or it, upon the ground. (K, TA.)

And Safanahu, aor.
Safina
, inf. n. SafonN, He rent, or slit, his Safan, i. e. scrotum. (M.)
2. SfRn, and its inf. n.: see 1, in two places.
3. muSaAfanapN The standing confronting a people, or party. (TA.)

[Also The dividing of water among a people, or party, in the manner described in the next paragraph:] one says, SaAfana AlmaMCa bayona Alqawomi faOaEoTaAniI SafonapF↓ i. e. maqolapF [for juroEapa maqolapK, the meaning being He divided the water in that manner among the people, or party, and gave me a gulp as much as would cover a pebble in the bottom of a vessel]. (TA.)

6. tSAfnwA AlmaMCa, (AA, S, M, K,) said of people in a journey and having little water, (M,) They divided the water among themselves (AA, S, M, K) by shares, (S, K,) by means of the pebble, (AA, S, M,) which they threw into the vessel to pour the water into it, (AA,) giving to each of them as much as would cover the pebble. (AA, S.) See also 6 in art. HcI.

SafonN [if not a mistake for SufonN, q. v.,] signifies The [round piece of skin, or leather, in which food is put, and upon which people eat; commonly called] suforap; as also SafonapN↓: (K:) the latter is expl. by AA and IAar as a suforap that is gathered together by a [running] string [near the edge, by means of which it is converted into a bag, agreeably with a modern custom]. (TA.)
And The [bursa faucium, or faucial bag, of the camel; commonly called] XiqoXiqap; as also SafonapN↓: (K:) so expl. by AA. (TA.)
See also SafanN.

SufonN A thing like the suforap [described in the next preceding paragraph], and between the Eayobap and the qirobap, in which are [put] goods or utensils or the like: or it is of skin, or leather, (M,) [i. e.] a receptacle of skin, or leather, (S, in which it is expressly said to be with damm,) like the suforap, (S, M,) pertaining to the people of the desert, in which they put their travelling-provisions, and (M) with which (S, M) sometimes (M) water is drawn, (S, M,) like [as is done with] the dalow: (M:) occurring in a verse of Sakhr El-Hudhalee [cited in art. xD]: (S:) or a thing like the [small bucket, or small drinking-vessel, of skin or leather, called] rakowap, (Fr, Mgh, K,) in which the ablution termed wuDuwoC is performed: (Fr, K:) or it signifies, (Mgh,) or signifies also, (K,) accord. to AA, (S,) a [pouch such as is called] xariyTap, pertaining to the pastor, in which are [put] his food, and his zinaAd [for producing fire], (S, Mgh, K,) and his other utensils or apparatus, (K,) or what other things he requires; (S, Mgh;) and sometimes water is drawn with it, like [as is done with] the dalow; (TA;) as also SafonapN↓: (K:) or, accord. to A'Obeyd, SafonapN↓ signifies a thing like the Eayobap, in which are [put] a man's goods or utensils, and his [other] apparatus; and when the p is elided, it is pronounced with damm [i. e. SufonN]: (TA:) or SafonapN↓, (TA,) or SuqonapN↓, (so in a copy of the M,) signifies a small dalow [or leathern bucket], having a single Haloqap [or ring]; and when it is large, it is called SufonN: and the pl. is OaSofunN. (M, TA.)
And (assumed tropical:) Water [app. considered as contained in the vessel thus called]: so expl. as used in the saying of Aboo-Du-ád,
[I poured into his drinking-trough water that he might drink it]. (TA.)
See also what next follows.

SafanN The scrotum (S, M, Msb, K) of a man; (S, Msb;) as also SufonN↓, (M,) or SafonN↓, (K,)
and SafonapN↓ and SufonapN↓: (M:) pl. OaSofaAnN (S, M, Msb) and SufonaAnN. (Msb.)
And (tropical:) The envelope of the ear of corn: (K, TA:) so called by way of comparison [to the scrotum]. (TA.)

And The habitation that is compacted (M, * K, TA) by a bird, or flying thing, (M,) or by the hornet and the like, (K, TA,) of dry herbage and of leaves, (M, TA,) for its young ones, (M, K, TA,) or for itself. (K, TA.)
SafonapN: see SafonN, in two places:
and SufonN, in three places:
and SafanN:
and see also 3.
SufonapN: see SufonN, latter part:
and SafanN.

SaAfinN A horse standing upon three legs and the extremity of the hoof of the fourth leg: (A'Obeyd, * S, TA:) or standing upon three legs, and turning back the extremity of the fore part of the fourth hoof, that of his fore leg: (M, TA:) or standing upon three legs, and otherwise: thus, says Fr, I have found the Arabs use the word: (TA: [see 1, first sentence:]) pl. SufuwnN (M, TA) and SawaAfinu and [the pl. of SaAfinapN is] SaAfinaAtN. (TA.) SaAfinaAtN occurs in the Kur xxxviii. 30. (M, TA.)
