And in the same, xxii. 37, I'Ab and Ibn-Mes-'ood used to read SawaAfina [instead of SawaAfRa]; the former explaining it as meaning Having the shank of one fore leg tied up to the arm; for thus is done with the camel when he is slaughtered: the latter, as meaning standing, or standing still. (TA.)

And applied to a man, it means SaAfRN qadamayohi [setting his feet evenly, side by side], (A'Obeyd, M, TA, and the like is said in the S and Msb,) standing. (A'Obeyd, Msb, TA.) It is said in a trad., (S, M, Msb, TA,) referring to the Prophet mentioned as praying, (S, M,) qumonaA xalofahu SufuwnFA [app. meaning We stood behind him setting our feet evenly, side by side; for so the context seems to indicate]. (S, M, Msb, K.) [But] in another trad., Salewpu AlSRaAfini is said to be forbidden; meaning [The praying] of him who puts his feet close together: or, as some say, of him who turns back his foot [i. e. one of his feet] like as the horse turns his hoof [i. e. one of his hoofs, when standing upon three legs]. (TA.)

AlSRaAfinu signifies [The saphena, or crural vein; so in the present day; i. e.] the vein of the saAq: (S: [see Oaboharu, and see also AlnRasaA:]) or a vein lying deep in the arm (AlcRiraAE) [and] amid the sinews of the [fore] shank of a beast: or the SaAfinaAni are two veins penetrating into the interior of the two shanks: or two veins in the legs: or two branches [of veins] in the two thighs: and the SAfn is [strangely said to be] a vein in the interior of the back bone, extending lengthwise, uniting with the niyaAT [q. v.] of the heart, also called the OakoHal. (M.)

1. SafaA, (S, M, Msb,) aor. yaSofuw, (S, Msb,) inf. n. SafaMCN (S, M, Msb, K *) and SufuwRN (M, Msb, K *) and SafowN (K, * TK) and SafowapNe and SifowapN, (MA,) said of wine, or beverage, (S,) or of water, (TK,) or of a thing, (M,) It was, or became, clear, limpid, or pure; contr. of kadira; (S, M, K; *) or free from Alkadar [i. e. turbidness, thickness, or muddiness]; (Msb;) or free from admixture. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And, said of the air, or atmosphere, It was, or became, cloudless; free from any particle of cloud. (M, K.) [And it is also said, tropically, of life; and of the mind, or heart; and of love, or affection; &c.]
Safato, (AA, S, M, K,) aor. taSofuw; (AA, S;) and Safuwto; (M, K;) said of a she-camel, (AA, S, M, K,) and of a ewe, or she-goat, (AA, S,) She abounded with milk. (AA, S, M, K.)

SafaA AlXRaIoCa He took the clear, or pure, part, or portion, of the thing; (M, TA;) as also Safowahu AstSfI↓; (M;) and AstSfAhu↓ [alone] signifies the same; (K, TA;) as also ASTfAhu↓; (Er-Rághib, TA;) or he took the best, or choice, part, or portion, of it. (TA.) You say, Safawotu Alqidora I took the clear, or pure, part, or portion, [of the contents] of the cooking-pot. (S.)

2. SfRAhu, inf. n. taSofiyapN, He cleared, or clarified, it, namely, wine, or beverage, (S, TA,) by means of the raAwuwq [or miSofaAp]. (TA.) And He removed from it the floating particles, or motes, or the like, that had fallen into it; (TA;) or so SfRAhu mina AlqacaI. (Msb.)
And SfRI Earamatahu, inf. n. as above, He winnowed his heap of trodden-out corn, or grain. (TA.)

3. SAfAhu, (S, M, K, TA,) inf. n. muSaAfaApN, (TA,) (tropical:) He regarded him, or acted towards him, with reciprocal purity of mind, or sincerity; or with reciprocal purity, or sincerity, of love, or affection; syn. xaAlaSahu; (S in art. xlS;) he rendered him true, or sincere, brotherly affection; (M, K, TA;) as also ASfAhu↓; (K;) or AlwudRa ASfAhu↓, (S, Msb,) or AlmawadRapa, (TA,) he rendered him pure, or sincere, love or affection; (S, Msb, TA;) and [in like manner] one says also SAfAhu AlUixaMCa. (TA.)
4. ASfAhu AlXRaIoCa He made the thing to be his, or he assigned, or appropriated, to him the thing, purely, absolutely, or exclusively. (TA.)
See also 3 in two places.

And ASfAhu (S, Msb, K, TA) biAlXRaIoCi (S) or bikacaA (K, TA) (tropical:) He chose him in preference to others (S, Msb, K, TA) for, or to give him, the thing or such a thing; (S, K, TA;) and he distinguished him particularly, peculiarly, or specially, i. e. above, or from, or exclusively of, others, by the thing or by such a thing. (TA.)
And ASfI EiyaAlahu biXaIoCK qaliylK (assumed tropical:) He contented, or satisfied, his family, or household, with something little, or scanty. (TA.)

ASfI AlOamiyru daAra fulaAnK means (assumed tropical:) The prince, or governor, took what was in the house of such a one: (S, * TA:) and maAlahu AstSfI↓ (tropical:) He took all his property. (S, K, TA.)

ASfI, intrans., (tropical:) He was, or became, destitute, or devoid, mina AlmaAli [of property], and mina AlOadabi [of good education, good breeding, or polite accomplishments, &c.]: (S, K, TA:) as though clear thereof. (TA.)
And (tropical:) He (a man, TA) became exhausted of his sperma by women: (Az, K, TA:) or he ceased from sexual intercourse. (IKtt, TA.)
And ASft said of a hen, (assumed tropical:) She ceased to lay eggs: (S, M, K, TA:) as though she became clear. (TA.)
Hence, (TA,) ASfI said of a poet, (tropical:) He ceased to utter poetry, or to poetize. (S, M, A, K, * TA.)
ASfI Alqawomu The people had abundance of milk in their camels, and in their sheep or goats. (TA.)
ASfI said of a digger, He reached stone (SafFA, M, TA, i. e. HajarFA, TA), so that he was repelled [thereby], (M, TA,) or prevented from digging [further]. (TA.)
5. tSfRI [It became cleared, or clarified]. (K in art. nTb.)
6. taSaAfayonaA We regarded one another, or acted reciprocally, with purity, or sincerity, [of mind, or] of love, or affection; syn. taxaAlaSonaA. (S. [See also 3.])
8. ASTfAhu: see 1, last sentence but one.

Also He took it clear, limpid, or pure; (M, TA;) and so [accord. to SM, which, however, I think doubtful,] AstSfAhu↓, which is expl. in the K as signifying he reckoned it clear, limpid, or pure; though the former meaning is assigned in the M to ASTfAhu only. (TA.)

And He chose, made choice of, selected, elected, or preferred, it, (S, M, K,) namely, a thing; (M;) as also AstSfAhu↓. (M, K.) And AiSoTafayotu kacaA EalaI kacaA I chose such a thing in preference to such a thing. (TA.) But AiSoTifaMCu QllRehi EibaAdahu [sometimes means God's creating his servants pure; for it] is sometimes by his bringing them into existence clear from the admixture that is found in others: and sometimes it is by his choice and judgment. (TA.)
10: see 1, last sentence but one, in two places:
see also 8, in two places:
and see 4.

SafFA Stones: or smooth stones: and one thereof is termed SafaApN: [i. e. the former word is a coll. gen. n., and the latter is its n. un.:] the two words being like HaSFI and HaSaApN: (Msb:) or SafaApN signifies a smooth rock: (S:) or a hard and smooth stone, large, and such as does not give growth to anything: (M, K:) and the pl. of this is SafFA [improperly thus termed a pl.] (S, M, K) and SafawaAtN, (M, K,) and (S, M, K) that of SafFA, (M, K, *) not of SafaApN, (M,) OaSofaMCN and SufiIRN (S, M, K) and SifiIRN: (M, K:) or SafFA signifies stones that are broad and smooth: (ISk, TA:) and [accord. to F,] SafowaMCu↓ signifies the same as SafaApN, as also SafowaAnapN [in the CK erroneously written SafowaAp], of which the pl. is SafowaAnN↓ and SafawaAnN↓, (K,) which last is said by El-Háfidh to be a mistaken pronunciation of SafowaAnN; (TA;) [but correctly,] SafowaMCu↓ [which is a quasi-pl. n.] and SafowaAnN↓ [a coll. gen. n.] (As, T, S, M, TA) of which the sing. or n. un. is SafowaAnapN (S, M, TA) signify the same as SafFA, (As, T, M, TA,) or stones, (S,) or soft, smooth stones; (TA;) or SafowaAnN↓ is used as a pl. and as a sing.; as a pl. meaning smooth stones, one of which is termed SafowaAnapN; and as a sing., stone, or a stone: (Msb:) the dual of SafFA is SafawaAni. (ISk, TA.) maA tanodaI SafaAtuhu is a prov., (S,) applied to the niggardly, like maA yabiDRu Hajaruhu, (S, in art. bD,) meaning (assumed tropical:) No good is obtained from him. (TA in that art.) And one says also, qaraEa SafaAtahu, meaning (assumed tropical:) He im-
pugned his character; blamed, or censured, him; or spoke against him. (Mgh in art. gmz.)
AlSRafaA A certain place in Mekkeh (S, Msb) may be masc. or fem., as meaning either the makaAn or the buqoEap. (Msb.)
[binotu SafFA, accord. to Reiske, as stated by Freytag, signifies The echo.]
SafowN Clearness, limpidness, or purity; contr. of kadarN; (M, K;) like [the inf. ns.] SafaMCN and SufuwRN [&c. when used as simple substs.: see 1, first sentence]. (K.) See also SafaMCN, below.

Also, and SafowapN↓ and SifowapN↓ and SufowapN↓, (S, M, Msb, K,) but only with fet-h when without p, (AO, S,) The clear, or pure, part, or portion, of a thing; (S, M, Msb, K;) the best, or choice, part, or portion; (TA;) and so SafiIRN↓, (K, * TA,) of a thing. (K, TA.) One says AlmaMCi Safowapu↓, (T, TA,) and AlmaAli, (AO, T, S, TA,) and AlMxaMCi, (T, TA,) and Sifowatuhu↓, (AO, T, S, TA,) and Sufowatuhu↓, (AO, S,) [i. e. The clear, or pure, part, or portion, or the best, or choice, of water, and of property, and of brothers,] but only Safowu AlUihaAlapi [the clear, or pure, part, or portion, or the best, or choice, of the grease, or melted fat, &c.]. (T, TA.) And Mohammad is said to be QllRehi mino xaloqihi Safowapu↓ and muSoTafaAhu↓ [i. e. God's choice one, or elect, or favourite, of his creatures]: (S:) and [in like manner] Adam is said to be QllRehi SafiIRu↓ i. e. the chosen one, or elect, of God. (TA.)
SafaApN as meaning SaAfiyapN: see SaAfK.
Also n. un. of SafFA [q. v.].
SafowapN: see SafowN, in three places.
SufowapN: see SafowN, in two places.
SifowapN: see SafowN, in two places.
One says also, fiI AlUinaMCi SifowapN mino maMCK, or xamorK, i. e. [In the vessel is] a small quantity [of water, or of wine]. (M.)
SafowaMCu: see SafFA, in two places.

yawomN SafowaAnu, (S, M, K,) and SaAfK↓, (M, K,) A day in which the sun is clear, and which is very cold: (S:) or a cold day, (K,) or a very cold day, (M,) without clouds and without thickness [of the air]. (M, K.)

SafowaAnu is also a name of The second of the days of cold: (K, TA:) so called because the sky therein is clear of clouds: [as a proper name,] it is determinate, and imperfectly decl. (TA. [See also SufayRapu.])
SafowaAnN [as a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is with p; and said to be used as a sing. and as a pl.]: see SafFA, in three places.
SafawaAnN: see SafFA.
SafaMCN an inf. n. of SafaA. (S, M, &c. [See 1, first sentence.])

[It is often used by moderns as meaning (assumed tropical:) Serenity of life, and of the mind; freedom from trouble; comfort; content; complacency; happiness, joy, or pleasure: and so, sometimes, SafowN↓.]
Also (tropical:) [Reciprocal purity or sincerity of mind, or of love or affection, or of brotherly affection; or pure, or sincere, reciprocal love &c.;] a subst, from SaAfaAhu. (TA.)
SafiIRN: see SaAfK.

Also (tropical:) A friend who regards one, or behaves towards one, with reciprocal purity or sincerity of love or affection, or of brotherly affection: (S, * M, * K, TA:) pl. OaSofiyaMCu. (TA.) One says, fulaAnN SafiIRu fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) [Such a man is the friend &c. of such a man]: and fulaAnapu SafiIRu fulaAnK and SafiyRatuhu (assumed tropical:) [Such a woman is the friend, &c. of such a man]. (Ham p. 430.)
See also SafowN, in two places.

Also (tropical:) The portion, of the spoil, which the chief, or commander, chooses for himself before the division; (S, Msb, K, TA;) and so SafiyRapN↓, of which the pl. is SafaAyaA: (S, Msb:) or, accord. to As, SafaAyaA is pl. of SafiIRN, which signifies the portion which the chief chooses for himself, exclusively of his companions, such as the horse, and that which cannot be divided among the army: or, as AO says, the portion which the chief chose for himself, after [taking] the fourth part, such as the she-camel, and the horse, and the sword, and the girl or young woman; and thus it continued to be in the case of El-Islám, but the fourth became reduced to the fifth. (Msb.)

Also, applied to a she-camel, (S, M, K,) and to a ewe, or she-goat, (S,) Abounding with milk; (S, M, K;) or so SafiyRapN↓: (Z, TA:) or the former, a she-camel whose milk lasts throughout the year: (IAar, TA in art. Xkr:) pl. of the former, (Sb, S, M, K,) or of the latter, (Z, TA,) as above: (Sb, S, M, Z, K:) Sb says that it is not pluralized with A and t because the sing. is without p. (M.)
And A palm-tree (naxolapN) abounding with fruit; (M, K;) or so SafiyRapN↓: (Z, TA:) pl. of the former, (TA,) or of the latter, as above. (Z, TA.)
SafiyRapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.
SufayRapu a name of The first of the days of cold: (K, TA:) so called because the sky therein is clear of clouds. (TA. [See also SafowaAnu.])

SaAfK Clear, limpid, or pure; free from kadar [or turbidness, &c.]; (Msb;) and so SafiIRN↓, applied to anything. (M.) Applied to pasturage, the former word may mean Clear of dried-up leaves or similar rubbish: or it may be formed by transposition from SaAYifN, meaning “ of the [season called] Sayof, ” and so belonging to art. Syf. (M. [See also SaAfK in another sense as formed by transposition from SaAYifN, voce SaAfN, in art. Swf.]) In the phrase AllRawoni SafaApu↓ applied by the poet Kutheiyir-'Azzeh to honey (janaApu AlnRaHoli), and expl. as meaning Clear in respect of colour, [ISd says,] I think that SfAp is originally Safiyap, as a possessive epithet. (M.) [SaAfK is also applied to a sword, and the like, as meaning Bright, or free from rust.] And in the Kur xxii. 37, [instead of the common reading SawaAfRa, pl. of SaAfRN and SaAfRapN,] some read SawaAfiIa, [pl. of SaAfiyapN, as well as of SaAfK applied to irrational animals,] as meaning that the animals there mentioned are [to be regarded as] things purely [or exclusively] belonging to God. (TA.)
See also SafowaAnu.
Also A certain fish, which [it is said] chews the cud; pl. SawaAfK. (TA.)
SaAfiyapN [fem. of SaAfK, q. v.

And also, as a subst.,] (tropical:) One of what are termed SawaAfiI AlUimaAmi, which means the towns, or villages, of those who have rebelled against him, which the Imám [or Khaleefeh] chooses for himself [as his peculiar property]: (A, TA:) or, as in the T, AlSRawaAfiI signifies what the Sultán appropriates exclusively to those persons whom he specially favours: or, as some say, it means the possessions and lands which their owners have abandoned, or of which the owners have died leaving no heirs thereof. (TA.)

miSofaApN i. q. raAwuwqN; (S, MA, K, TA;) i. e. A strainer; (MA; [thus accord. to modern usage;]) a clarifier; i. e. a thing from which clearing, or clarifying, is effected; called by the vulgar mSfyRap [i. e. miSofayRap, and also miSofaAyap]: pl. maSaAfK. (TA.)
EasalN muSafRFI [Clarified honey; or] honey cleared of the floating particles, or motes, or the like, that had fallen into it. (TA.)
muSoTafFI: see SafowN, last sentence.

1. Saqiba, (S, K,) aor.
Saqaba
, (K,) inf. n. SaqabN, (M, A, K,) [like saqiba,] He, or it, was, or became, near. (S, M, * A, * K.) You say, Saqibato daAruhu, (S, A,) with kesr [to the q], (S,) inf. n. as above, (S, * A,) His house was near; (S, A;) and (A) so daAruhu OaSoqabato↓, (M, A, K, TA,) and Oasoqabato. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., (S, A,) AljaAru OaHaqRu biSaqabihi, (S, A, K,) i. e. [The neighbour has a better, or the best, claim to pre-emption by reason of his being near: see, with respect to this explanation, and other explanations also, what is said of another reading, bisaqabihi, voce saqiba: or has a better, or the best, claim] to close connection, and nearness; meaning pre-emption: (IAmb, O, TA:) or, to what is next to him, and near to him: (A, K, TA:) accord. to some, the meaning is the partner: (O, TA:) or the partner who has not divided with his copartner; this, says Az, being shown to be the meaning by another trad.: (Msb in art. jwr:) or the neighbour whose dwelling is adjoining. (O, TA.)
Also He, or it, was, or became, distant, or remote: thus it has two contr. significations. (K.)
Saqabahu, (K,) inf. n. SaqobN, (M,) He collected it, or gathered it together. (M, K.)
And Saqabahu He raised it; namely, a building, &c. (M, O, K.)

And Saqabahu, (K,) or Saqaba qafaAhu, (M, TA,) He struck (M, K, TA) him, or it, (K,) or the back of his neck, with his Saqob, (M, TA,) i. e. (TA) with his fist. (K, TA.) [The inf. n.] SaqobN signifies The striking anything solid and dry or tough. (S, TA.)
Saqaba, (K, TA,) or SqRb↓, (so in a copy of the M,) said of a bird, It uttered a cry or cries: (M, K:) from Kr. (M, TA.)
2: see what immediately precedes.

3. SAqbhu He drew near to him: and he faced
him, or met him face to face: (A:) or SaAqabahumo, inf. n. muSaAqabapN and SiqaAbN, he faced them, or met them face to face: (K:) or SaAqabonaAhumo, inf. ns. as above, we drew near to them: and laqiytuhu muSaAqabapF and SiqaAbFA I met him face to face. (M.)
4. OaSoqabato daAruhu: see 1, second sentence.
ASqbhu He made him, or it, to be near. (S, K.) And ASqb QllRehu daArahu May God make his house to be near. (A.) [And so with s.]
And one says, OaSoqabaka AlSRayodu The game, or object of the chase, has become near to thee, so that thou art able to shoot, or cast, at it. (K.)

SaqobN The young one of a camel: (M, L, K:) and so saqobN [q. v.]: (M:) but the latter is the more chaste, and some have rejected the former word: (MF:) pl. SiqaAbN and SuqobaAnN (M, K) [and app. SuquwbN also, like suquwbN,] and [pl. of pauc.] OaSoqubN. (TA.)

And Anything [i. e. any animal] tall, together with plumpness, or with fatness, softness, thinness of the skin, and plumpness; (S, M, K;) and so with s; (M;) as also SaqabN↓. (TA.) Applied to a branch, Juicy, thick, and long. (TA.)
And A tent-pole: (M, K:) or the middle tent-pole, which is the longest: (S, M, K:) and so with s: (M:) pl. SuquwbN. (S, M, K.) [See also this pl. below.]
And The fist: so in the phrase Darabahu biSaqobihi [expl. above]. (TA.)

SaqabN [is an inf. n., of Saqiba, as mentioned above: and, used as a simple subst.,] signifies Vicinity, or nearness. (M, A, &c.) Thus in the phrase huwa Saqabaka [lit. He is in thy vicinity; meaning he is near thee]; mentioned by Sb among instances of adv. nouns which he classes apart because of their strangeness. (M.) And one says also, daAriI mino daArihi biSaqabK [lit. My house is in a situation of nearness with respect to his house:] meaning, near [his house]. (TA.)

It [is also used as an epithet, and as such] signifies Near: (M, K:) you say makaAnN SaqabN, and saqabN [q. v. voce saAqibN], A near place; (M;) and makaAnN SaAqibN↓ and saAqibN: (A in art. sqb:) and daAruhu SaqabN minRiI [His house is near me]. (A in the present art.)
See also SaqobN.
SuquwbN a pl. of SaqobN [q. v.]. (S, M, K.)
Also The kind legs of camels; a dial. var. of suquwbN: (IAar, M:) the s is changed into S app. because the latter is more agreeable with q. (M.)
SaAqibN: see SaqabN.

SayoqabaAniIRN A seller of perfumes [&c.: for the Arab dealer in perfumes sells a great variety of things, such as drugs, many articles of grocery, and the like]: (O, K:) so called because he collects [somewhat] of everything. (TA.)
OaSoqabu [More, and most, near]. One says, hecaA OaSoqabu mino hecaA This is nearer than this: (M: [and the like is said in the A and TA:]) and so Oasoqabu. (M, TA. *)
huwa muSaAqibiI He is my neighbour: (TA in the present art.:) he is one whose house, or tent, adjoins mine. (TA in art. jwr.)

1. Saqara, (S, M, K,) aor.
Saqura
, (M,) inf. n. SaqorN, (S, M,) He broke, (S, K,) or struck, (M,) stones, (S,) or a stone, (M, K,) with a SaAquwr [q. v.]. (S, M, K.)
Saqarahu biAlEaSaA, (M, K,) inf. n. as above, (M,) He struck him, or beat him, (M, K,) on his head, (M,) with the staff, or stick. (M, K.)

Suqira bihi AlOaroDu He was thrown, or cast, upon the ground; lit. the ground was struck with him. (O, K. [In some copies of the K, Sqr in this instance and the verb explaining it (Drb) are in the act. form, and AlArD is therefore in the accus. case.])

Saqara AlnRaAra, (M, K,) inf. n. as above; (M;) and SqRrhA↓, (M, K,) inf. n. taSoqiyrN; (TA;) He lighted, or kindled, the fire; or made it to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame. (M, K.)

Saqaratohu AlXRamosu, (S, M, A,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) (tropical:) The sun hurt him by its heat: (A:) or pained his brain: (S:) or fell vehemently, with fierce heat, upon him, or upon his head: or was hot upon him. (M, TA.) [See also 1 in art. sqr.]
SaqaraniI bikalaAmihi (tropical:) [app. He cursed me, and calumniated me]. (A. [These meanings seem to be there indicated by the context.])
Saqara AllRabanu The milk was, or became, intensely sour; as also ASqrR↓, inf. n. AiSoqiraArN; (K;) and Samoqara↓, (K in art. Smqr,) and AiSomaqarRa↓. (K in that art and in the present art. also.)
[See also SaqorN, below, last explanation but one.]
2. SqRr AlnRaAra: see 1.
SqRr AltRamora, (M,) or AlrRuTaba, inf. n. taSoqiyrN, (As, TA,) He poured Saqar [q. v.], (M,) or dibos, [which is the same,] (As,) upon the dates, (M,) or upon the fresh ripe dates. (As.)

4. ASqrt AlXRamosu (tropical:) The sun was, or became, burning, or fiercely burning; syn. AitRaqadat; (M, K;) as also AiSomaqarRat↓, (L and K in art. Smqr,) in which the m is augmentative: (L in that art.:) the former is from AStqrt said of fire. (M.)
5. tSqRrt AlnRaAru: see 8.
tSqRr [He hawked;] he hunted with the Saqor. (A, K.)
And He tarried, stayed, or waited, (K, TA,) in a place. (TA.)
8. AStqrt AlnRaAru ASTqrt The fire became lighted or kindle; burned, burned up, burned brightly or fiercely, blazed, or flamed; (M, K;) as also tSqRrt↓. (K.)
9. ASqrR: see 1, last explanation.
Q. Q. 1. Samoqara: see 1, last explanation.
Q. Q. 1: Sawoqara He (a bird) uttered the cry termed Sawoqariyr [q. v.]: (K:) reiterated his cry. (TA.)
Q. Q. 4. AiSomaqarRa: see 1, last explanation:
and see also 4.

SaqorN [The hawk;] the bird with which one hunts, or catches, game; (S;) whatever preys, or hunts or catches game, of the birds called buziAp [pl. of baAzK] and XawaAhiyn [pl. of XaAhiyn]; (M, A, K;) a kind of bird including the baAziI and the XaAhiyn and the zurRaq and the yuWoyuW and the baAXaq: (AHát, TA in art. bXq:) [like our term “ saker, ” and the French “ sacre, ” &c.:] pl. [of pauc.] OaSoqurN (M, K) and [of mult.] SuquwrN and SuquwrapN (M, A, K) and SiqaArN and SiqaArapN and SuqurN; (M, K;) the last of which is said by Th to be pl. of SuquwrN, which is pl. of SaqorN, but [ISd says] I hold it to be pl. of SaqorN: the fem. is SaqorapN↓. (M.)
[And accord. to Reiske, as mentioned by Freytag, A liberal man: perhaps a noble man, as likened to a hawk.]

Also, (S, K,) and SaqorapN↓, (S, M, K,) Vehemence of the stroke of the sun, (S, M, K,) and fierceness of its heat: (M:) or the vehemence of its stroke upon the head: (M:) pl. [of the latter] SaqaraAtN. (S, A.)

Also the former, Sour milk; (K;) [and] so SaqorapN↓: (A:) or milk rendered sour by a stroke of the sun: (Sh:) or milk sour in the utmost degree: (As:) or very sour milk; as also SaqorapN↓: (S:) or this latter is milk that has curdled, and of which the thick part has become separate, and the whey become clear, and that has become sour, so as to be a good kind of sauce. (L.) One says, tazowiI Alwajoha jaMCanaA biSaqorapK↓ [He brought us some sour milk, or very sour milk, &c., such as contracts the face, or makes it to wrinkle: like as one says biSarobapK]. (S, A, L.)

Also, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) and SaqorapN↓, (M,) [The exuded, or expressed, juice called] dibos; (S, K;) in the dial. of the people of El-Medeeneh: (S:) or the dibos of dates; (M;) or of fresh ripe dates, (Mgh, Msb,) before it is cooked; i. e. what flows from them, like honey, and what, when it is cooked, is called rubR: (Msb:) or the honey of fresh ripe dates and of raisins; as also SaqarN↓: (K:) or the honey of fresh ripe dates when it has become dry, or tough: or what exudes from grapes, and from raisins, and from dates, without their being pressed; (M;) as also SaqarN↓: (TA:) or, in the dial. of the Bahránees, [or people of El-Bahreyn,] the crude dibos, resembling honey, which flows from baskets of dates when they [i. e. the dates] are deposited and congested, in an uncovered chamber, [so I render bayot muSarRaH, but the meaning of the epithet is not clear,] with green earthen pots beneath them. (AM, TA.)
And the former, (SaqorN,) (assumed tropical:) Water that has become altered for the worse in taste and colour. (K, O, TA. [See also muSaqRarN and SaqarapN.])

Saqoro also signifies A daAYirap [or feather, i. e. portion of the hair naturally curled or frizzled in a spiral manner or otherwise,] behind the place of the liver (AO, K, TA) of a horse or similar beast, (K, TA,) on the right and on the left, (TA,) or in the back of a horse: (AO, TA:) there are two such feathers, (AO, K, TA,) which are the limit of the back. (AO, TA.)

Also, [probably as an inf. n., of which the verb is Saqara,] The acting the part, or performing the office, of a pimp to
[men's] wives, or women under covert. (IAar, M, O, K. [In the CK, AlHarami is erroneously put for AlHurami.]) Hence the epithet SaqRaAr, [as some explain it,] occurring in a trad. [which see below]. (TA.)
And A cursing of such as is not deserving [thereof]: pl. SuquwrN and SiqaArN. (K.)
Saqaru a name of Hell; a dial. var. of saqaru [q. v.]. (K.)
SaqarN Fallen leaves of the [kind of trees called] EiDaAh, and [particularly] of the EurofuT, (M, K,) and of the salam, and of the TaloH, and of the samur: not so called until they fall. (M.)
See also SaqorN, in two places.
ruTabN Saqri, (S,) or SaqirN maqirN, (M, K,) in which the latter word is an imitative sequent, (K,) Fresh ripe dates containing Saqor: (M, K:) [melliferous:] or proper for dibos [or Saqor]. (S.)
AimoraOapN SaqirapN A woman sharp, or acute, of mind, (cakiyRapN, [in the CK, erroneously, zakiyRapN,]) strongsighted. (Sgh, K.)

jaMCa biAlSRuqari waAlbuqari, (A, K, TA,) and biAlSRuqaAraI↓ waAlbuqaAraI, (K, TA,) (tropical:) He came with lies, and excitements of dissension: (A, TA:) or with sheer lying: (K:) or with sheer, and excessive, or abominable, lying: (TA:) each being a name for that which is unknown: (K, TA:) and in like manner one says jMC biAlXRuqari waAlbuqari, and biAlXRuqaAraI waAlbuqaAraI; mentioned by IDrd, in the Jm; and by Meyd, in the Collection of Proverbs. (TA in art. bqr.) [See also Har p. 399.]
SaqorapN: see SaqorN, in six places.

SaqarapN (assumed tropical:) Water remaining in a watering-trough in which dogs and foxes void their urine, (O, K, TA,) altered for the worse in taste and colour. (TA. [See also SaqorN and muSaqRarN.])

SuqorapN (assumed tropical:) A colour, of a bird, in which the xuDorap [or dark, or ashy, dust-colour] thereof, or the blackness thereof, is mixed with redness or yel-lowness; as being likened to [the colour of] Saqorap [or Saqor], i. e. dibos: a bird of that colour is termed muSaqRarN↓: so in the book entitled “ Ghareeb el- Hamám, ” by Hoseyn Ibn-'Abd-Allah el-Kátib El-Isbahánee. (TA.)

SaquwrN, (so in a copy of the M in two instances, and so in the O in one instance,) or SaqRuwrN↓, (so in the O in another instance, and so accord. to the K, in which latter it is expressly likened to tanRuwrN,) A wittol, or tame cuckold; syn. dayRuwvN: (M, K:) or one who acts the part of a pimp to his own wives, or women under covert; as also SaqRaArN↓: (O:) the former epithet occurring in a trad. (M, O.)
SuqaAraI: see jaMCa biAlSRuqari waAlbuqari, above.
SaqRaArN [A falconer, or rearer of hawks. (Golius, from Meyd: and so in the present day.)
And] i. q. dabRaAsN [A seller of dibos, or Saqor]. (O, K.)

Also (assumed tropical:) One who is in the habit of cursing (M, O, K) those who are not deserving [of being cursed]: (M, O, K:) and (assumed tropical:) a calumniator: and (assumed tropical:) an unbeliever. (M, O, K.) The Prophet, being asked the meaning of SaqRaArN, (M, TA,) or of saqRaArapN, (T, TA,) or of SaqRaAruwna, (O,) occurring in a trad., said (assumed tropical:) Young people who shall be in the end of time, whose mutual greeting will be mutual cursing. (T, M, O, TA.) See also SaquwrN.
SaqRuwrN: see SaquwrN.
SaAqirN, applied to a Saqor [or hawk] Sharp-sighted. (K.)
SawoqarN: see SaAquwrN.
SaAqirapN A calamity, (M, K,) or a vehement calamity, (O,) befalling. (M, K.)

SaAquwrN [A pickaxe;] a large faOos (AA, S, M, K) with one slender head, with which stones are broken; (AA, S, M;) i. q. miEowalN; (AA, S, A;) and SawoqarN↓ signifies the same; (M, K;) [but] this latter is expl. by IDrd as meaning a thick faOos with which stones are broken. (TA.)
And (assumed tropical:) The tongue. (M, K.)
See also what next follows.
SaAquwrapN The inner side of the cranium, over the brain, (M, K, TA,) as though it were the bottom of a bowl: in the T said to be termed SaAquwrN↓. (TA.)
And SaAquwrapu, (M,) and AlSRaAquwrapu, (M, K,) a name of (assumed tropical:) The Third Heaven. (M, K.)
SawoqariyrN A cry of a bird, (M, K,) with a reiteration, (M,) resembling the sound of this word. (M, K.)
OaSoqaru in the following saying, (M,) hecaA AltRamoru OaSoqaru mino hecaA These dates have more Saqor than these, (AHn, M, K,) has no verb. (M.)
muSoqarRN Milk that is sour and disagreeable: (Ibn-Buzurj, TA:) and muSomaqirRN↓ signifies milk intensely sour. (TA in art. Smqr.)

ruTabN muSaqRarN Fresh ripe dates, (A,) or fresh ripe dates that have become dry, (S,) upon which is poured dibos (S, A) of ripe dates, (A,) in order that they may become soft: and sometimes it occurs with s; for they often change S into s when there is in the word q or T or g or x; as in buSaAqN and SiraATN and SudogN and SamaAxN: (S:) or excellent fresh ripe dates, picked from the raceme, which are put into [earthen vessels of the kind called] basaAtiyq [pl. of busotuwqapN (in the TA erroneously written basaAtiyn)], and upon which Saqor is poured: they remain moist and good all the year. (AHn, L.)
And maMCN muSaqRarN (assumed tropical:) Water altered for the worse [in colour, as though Saqor, i. e. dibos had been mixed with it]. (M. [See also SaqorN and SaqarapN.])
And TaAYirN muSaqRarN (assumed tropical:) A bird of the colour termed, SuqorapN, q. v. (TA.)
muSaqRirN One who hunts with hawks. (A, * TA.)
muSomaqirRN A day intensely hot: the two m in this word are augmentative. (TA.)
See also muSoqarRN.

1. SaqaEahu, (S, Mgh, O, K,) aor.
SaqaEa
, (O, Mgh, K,) inf. n. SaqoEN, (O,) He struck him, or beat him: (K:) or he struck [or slapped] him with his expanded hand: (TA:) [like SafaEahu:] or, (S, Mgh, O, K,) as also SawoqaEahu↓, (O, K,) he struck him (S, Mgh, O, K) upon his head, (O, K,) or upon his SawoqaEap, (S, O,) [i. e.] upon the top of his head: (Mgh:) this last is the primary signification: and hence, metaphorically, he struck him, or beat him, in an unrestricted sense: (Mgh, * O, TA:) and he struck it, namely, a dry, or tough, and solid thing, with a similar thing; as, for instance, a stone with a stone, and the like: or, as some say, he struck it, namely, anything dry, or tough. (TA.) It is said in a trad., respecting Munkidh, SuqiEa MmRapF i. e. He was struck on the top of his head: (O:) or he had his head broken so that the wound reached the membrane over his brain. (TA.)
One says also, SaqaEa bihi AlOaroDa (O, K) He threw him down, or prostrated him, on the ground; (K;) [lit.] he smote the ground with him. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

And SaqaEatohu AlSRaAqiEapu i. q. SaEaqatohu AlSRaAEiqapu, (S, O, K,) The thunderbolt smote him. (TA.) And SuqiEa He was smitten by a thunderbolt; i. q. SuEiqa; of the dial. of Temeem: (O:) and so SaqiEa; (K, TA;) like SaEiqa. (TA.)
And SaqaEahu bikaIRK He branded him, or marked him by cauterizing, upon his head, [or his SawoqaEap,] or his face. (O, K.)

And SaqaEa AlvRariydapa, aor. and inf. n. as above, He ate the vrydp [or mess of crumbled bread with broth] from its SawoqaEap [or top, or upper part, or hollow made therein]. (TA. [See also Q. Q. 1.])

SaqoEN also signifies The raising of the voice: (O, TA:) and the uttering it by consecutive emissions. (TA.) You say, SaqaEa biSawotihi He raised his voice. (TA.) And hence, (TA,) SaqaEa said of a cock, (S, O, K,) aor.
SaqaEa
, (O,) inf. n. SaqoEN and SuqaAEN (IDrd, O, K) and SaqiyEN, (K,) He [crowed, or] uttered a cry: (IDrd, S, O, K:) and so saqaEa. (S.)
And, accord. to IAar, The being eloquent in speech, and lighting upon the [proper] meanings. (TA.)
SaqaEa biDaroTapK, said of an ass, He emitted a sounding wind from the anus, in a moist and dispersed state. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
SaqaEa Albayota He attached to the tent the rope called SiqaAE [q. v.]. (Az, O, TA.)

And SaqaEa, (S, O, K,) said of a man, (K,) He went away, (S, O, K, TA,) fiI kulRi AlnRawaAHiI [in all directions]: (TA:) one says, maA OadoriI Oayona SaqaEa, (S, O, TA, [but in the second, laA is put in the place of maA,]) and baqaEa, (TA,) meaning I know not whither he went away: (O, TA:) and the verb is seldom used in this sense without the particle of negation. (TA.) Or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (O,) or so SaqiEa, (S, TA,) like fariHa, not SaqaEa, (TA,) He deviated from the way, (S, O, K, TA,) and alighted, or descended and abode, alone, by himself: (TA:) or he deviated from the way of goodness and generosity. (IF, O, K, TA.) And SaqoEN signifies The going astray; losing one's way; or becoming lost; and perishing;
or dying. (TA. [But I think that this is probably a mistranscription for SaqaEN, inf. n. of SaqiEa.]) You say also, SaqiEa fulaAnN naHowa kacaA Such a one repaired towards such a thing. (TA.)

And SaqiEati AlbiYoru, aor.
SaqaEa
, (A'Obeyd, S,) inf. n. SaqaEN, The well collapsed; or broke down. (A'Obeyd, S, K. *)

SaqiEato, (TA,) inf. n. SaqaEN, (O, K, TA,) said of horses, and of birds, &c., They became white (O, K, TA) in the [SawoqaEap, or] uppermost part of the head, (TA,) or in the middle of the head. (O, K.)
And [the inf. n.] SaqaEN, in relation to the head, signifies The being bald: or, as some say, the going away of the hair. (TA.)
SuqiEati AlOaroDu The earth, or ground, became overspread with the SaqiyE [i. e. hoarfrost, or rime]; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also OuSoqiEat↓; each with damm. (IDrd, K.)
2. SqRE lahu, inf. n. taSoqiyEN, He swore to him respecting a thing: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) and so bqRE lh, inf. n. taboqiyEN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)
4. ASqE He (a man, O, TA) entered upon [a time, or a tract, of] SaqiyE [i. e. hoar-frost, or rime]. (IDrd, O, K, TA.)

And ASqE AlSRaqiyEu AlOaroDa, (K, TA,) and AlXRajara, (O, TA,) The SqyE [or hoar-frost] fell, or lighted, upon the earth, or ground, (K, * TA,) and the trees. (O, TA.) And OuSoqiEati AlOaroDu: see 1, last sentence. And OuSoqiEa AlnRaAsu The men, or people, became overspread with the SaqiyE. (TA.)
Q. Q. 1. SawoqaEahu: see 1, first sentence.
SawoqaEa AlvRariydapa He spread evenly the vrydp [or mess of crumbled bread moistened with broth]. (TA.)

SuqoEN A district, quarter, or tract, syn. naAHiyapN, (S, O, Msb, K,) of a country: (Msb:) and a place, region, quarter, tract, or point, towards which a person, or thing, goes, tends, or is directed; syn. jihapN: and a place of alighting, or of descending and stopping or sojourning or abiding or lodging or settling; or a place of abode or settlement; syn. maHalRapN: (Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] OaSoqaAEN, (O, TA,) and pl. pl. OaSaAqiEu: (TA:) and SuqogN is a dial. var. thereof. (IJ, TA; and K in art. Sqg.) One says, fulaAnN mino Oaholi hecaA AlSRuqoEi i. e. mino hecihi AlnRaAHiyapi [Such a one is of the people of this district, &c.]. (S, O.) And huwa fiI SuqoEi baniI fulaAnK He is in the naAHiyap [or district, &c.], and the maHalRap [or place of alighting, &c.], of the sons of such a one. (Msb.) See also miSoqaEN.
Also A part, or portion, of the surrounding and inferior sides of a well: pl. OaSoqaAEN: but the more approved word is with s. (TA.)
SaqaEN inf. n. of SaqiEa. (S, &c.)
Also An affection like gamRN, [i. e.] that takes away the breath, (yaOoxucu biAlnRafasi, S, O, K, [in the CK, bAlnRafosi,]) by reason of the vehemence of the heat. (S, O, K.)
SaqiEN [Smitten by a thunderbolt: (see its verb, SaqiEa:) or] smitten as by a thunderbolt from the enemy: so accord. to some: (O, TA:) 'Ows Ibn-Hajar says,

(S, * O, TA, but in the TA OaAabaA) [which may be rendered O Aboo-Duleyjeh, who is for a solitary tribe, smitten as though by a thunderbolt from the enemies, in Showwál (which was, in the time of the poet, a cold month)?]: or, accord. to IAar, the meaning here is, in a state of retirement, remote from the enemies; (S, * O;) for when the winter pressed severely upon the man, he used to retire to a distance, lest a guest should alight at his abode; the enemies being the strange guests; and by saying fI XwRAl, he means that the cold was in Showwál: (O, TA:) or SaqiEN means absent and remote, so that one knows not where he is: or that has gone away, and alighted alone, or by himself: (TA:) [pl. SaqoEaI:] see an ex. voce daqiEN.

OaroDN SaqiEapN, (TA,) and maSoquwEapN↓, Earth, or ground, overspread with the SaqiyE [i. e. hoarfrost, or rime]: (S, Msb, TA:) and in like manner, XajarN SaqiEN, and muSoqaEN↓, trees overspread with the SaqiyE. (TA.)
SaqoEapN Intenseness of cold; from AlSRaqiyEu [meaning “ hoar-frost, ” or “ rime ”]. (TA.)
SuqoEapN A whiteness in the middle of the head of a horse and of a bird &c.; (S, O, K;) or in the middle of the head of a black sheep or goat, accord. to Abu-l-Wázi'. (TA.)
SaqoEaAn Stupid, dull, or wanting in intelligence: but this is a vulgar word. (TA.)

SaqaEiIRN The first increase, or offspring, (nitaAj,) [of sheep, or goats,] when the sun smites (taSoqaEu) the heads of the lambs or kids: (Aboo-Nasr, O, K: [in the CK, Albuhomi is erroneously put for Albahomi:]) and some of the Arabs call it the XamosiIR, and the qayoZiIR: then is the SafariIR, after the SaqaEiIR: (Aboo-Nasr, TA:) it is also expl. as signifying such as is brought forth in the [period called] SafariyRap: (TA: [but see SafariIRN:]) and, (O, K,) accord. to AZ, (O,) the young camel that is brought forth in [the time of] the SaqiyE [i. e. hoar-frost, or rime]; which is of the best of the increase [of camels]. (O, K.)

SiqaAEN A piece of rag with which a woman protects her ximaAr [or muffler] from the oil [in her hair], (S, O, K, TA,) putting it on her head; (TA;) as also SawoqaEapN↓: (K:) or this latter signifies a thing by which the head is protected, such as a turban and a ximaAr and a ridaMC. (TA.)
And The [woman's face-veil termed] buroquE (S, O, K) is sometimes thus called. (S, O.)

And A thing with which a she-camel's nose is bound, (S, O, K, TA,) as expl. in art. drj [voce durojapN], (S,) when they desire her to affect her young one or the young one of another: or, accord. to A'Obeyd, a piece of rag with which her eyes are bound; that with which her nose is bound, [or stopped, (see 1 in art. ZOr)] when she is made to affect a young one not her own, being termed gimaAmapN. (TA. [But see durojapN.])
And A mark made with a hot iron upon the qacaAl [or back of the head] of a camel. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
And An iron thing that is in the place of [the kind of curb called] the Hakamap of the bit. (O, K.)
And A thing that is next to the head of the horse, beneath (duwna) the larger buroquE. (TA.)

The SiqaAE of a tent (xibaMC) is A rope that is extended from its top, and pulled tight, the two ends of which are tied to two pegs, or stakes, stuck into the ground, when the wind is violent and it is feared that the tent may be thrown down. (O, TA.)
SaqiyEN The jaliyd [i. e. hoar-frost, or rime,] that nips, or blasts, (lit. burns, [see OaHoraqa,]) the plants, or herbage; (Msb;) what falls from the sky in the night, resembling snow. (S, O, K.)
Also A species of zunobuwr [or hornet]: (O, K:) so says AHát, as having been heard by him from a man of Et-Táïf. (O.)
SaAqiEN [Deviating from the truth; as is indicated in the TA: and hence,] a liar: (TA:) one says, Saho SaAqiEu i. e. Be silent, O liar. (Yoo, O, K.)
SaAqiEapN i. q. SaAEiqapN [i. e. A thunderbolt]: (Fr, S, O, K:) of the dial. of Temeem: pl. SawaAqiEu. (TA.) [See also SaAEiqapN.]

SawoqaEapN The place of the whiteness termed SuqoEap in the head of a horse and of a bird &c.: (S:) or the middle of the head [in an absolute sense]: (O, K:) or the top, or uppermost part, [of the head, or] of the [cap called] kumRap, and of the turban. (O, K, TA: all in art. SfE. [See 1 in that art., where this last meaning is assigned to SawofaEapN.])
And A turban [itself]: (O, K:) and any other thing that protects the head: (TA;) accord. to IDrd, a piece of rag which a woman puts upon her head as a protection. (O. See SiqaAEN, first sentence.)
A piece of rag which is tied upon the top of the [kind of women's camel-vehicle called] huwodaj, and which the wind blows about. (TA.)
The head [or top] of the [woman's face-veil called] buroquE. (IAar, TA in this art. and voce XibaAmN [q. v.].)
The hollow (waqobap) [that is made in the upper part of a dish] of variyd [or crumbled bread moistened with broth]: (S, O, K, TA:) or the top, or upper part, of variyd. (TA.)
Also The place of a battle in which is much smiting. (IDrd, O, K.)

OaSoqaEu, applied to a horse, and a bird, &c., Having a whiteness in the middle of the head: (S, O, K:) or a horse white in the top of his head: (Mgh:) fem. SaqoEaMCu, (S, O, K,) applied to an eagle (EuqaAb), (S, O, TA,) and to a female ostrich [&c.]. (TA.)

AlOaSoqaEu A certain bird, resembling the EuSofuwr [or sparrow], in the feathers and head of which is a whiteness, found near water; mentioned [in the K] in art. sqE [as with s in the place of S]: (TA:) accord. to Ktr, (O, TA,)
the bird called AlSRufaAriyapu [q. v.]: (O, K, TA:) you may form its pl. after the manner of substs. [i. e. saying OaSaAqiEu], because it is an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates; or after the manner of the epithet [i. e. saying SuqoEN]. (TA.)

Accord. to AHát, AlSRaqoEaMCu signifies A [bird such as is termed] duxRalap [q. v.], of a dingy colour, small, with a yellow head, short in the zimikRaI [or tail] and the legs and the neck: (TA:) or, accord. to him, the SaqoEaMC with a yellowness is a duxRalap of a dingy yellow colour, small, short in the zimikRaI and the legs and the neck: and all duxRal are with the Arabs of the [birds termed] EaSaAfiyr and HumRar: but the SaqoEaMC with a blackness is a duxRalap of a dingy reddish colour, black in the head, and short in the zimikRaI and the neck. (O.)
AlOaSoqaEu also signifies The forelock of a horse: or the white forelock thereof. (TA.)
And AlSRaqoEaMCu, The sun. (S, O, K.)
maSoqaEN A place towards which one tends, repairs, or betakes himself. (TA.)
muSoqaEN: see SaqiEN, last sentence.

xaTiybN miSoqaEN An eloquent speaker or orator or preacher: (S, O, K:) or one loud in voice: (K:) or one who is not impeded in his speech, and who does not reiterate in speech by reason of inability to say what he would, or is not unable to find words to express what he would say: (Katádeh, O, K:) or one who is skilful, and penetrating, or effective, in his speech: (O:) or one who goes into every SuqoE↓, i. e. naAHiyap, [meaning province,] of speech: (TA in this art. and in art. rqE:) [said to be] from AlSRaqoEu meaning “ the raising of the voice; ” (O, TA; *) or from AlSRuqoEu [expl. above]; or, as some say, from SaqaEahu meaning “ he struck him upon his SawoqaEap; ” but this last derivation is far-fetched: (TA:) pl. maSaAqiEu. (O, TA.)
OaroDN maSoquwEapN: see SaqiEN, last sentence.

1. Saqalahu, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) aor.
Saqula
, (M, Msb,) inf. n. SaqolN (S, M, O, Msb) and SiqaAlN, (S, O, Msb,) or the latter is a simple subst., (M, K,) He polished it: (S, M, O, Msb, K;) i. e. a thing, (M,) or a sword, (S, O, Msb,) and the like: (Msb:) and so saqalahu. (S.)

Saqala AlnRaAqapa (assumed tropical:) He (a man, AA, O) made the she-camel lean, or light of flesh: (AA, O, K:) and in like manner it is said of journeying: (AA, O:) and in like manner also, Alfarasa the horse: (Sh, TA:) or this means he tended the horse well, with the coverings for protection from cold, and with fodder, and took good care of him. (TA. [See SiqaAlN, below.])
Saqalahu biAlEaSaA (tropical:) He struck him, or beat him, with the staff, or stick, (Z, O, K, TA,) and disciplined him. (Z, TA.)
And Saqala bihi AlOaroDa (assumed tropical:) He flung him upon the ground (lit. smote the ground with him). (Aboo-Turáb, O, K.)

Saqili, aor.
Saqala
, inf. n. SaqalN, It (a thing, such as iron, and copper,) was smooth, solid, and impenetrable to water. (Msb.)
And Saqila, inf. n. SaqalN, He (a man) differed, or varied, in his gait, or manner of walking. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

SaqolN, (so in a copy of the M,) or SuqolN↓ (K,) [the former, if correct, perhaps a contraction, by poetic license, of SaqilN, for which it is not a mistranscription, as is shown by a verse cited as an ex. of it in the M,] Light, or active; applied to a beast (daAbRap). (M, K.)

SuqolN The xaASirap [or flank]; as also SuqolapN↓: (S, M, O, K: [in the CK, erroneously, Saqolap:]) the former, in this sense, said by AA to be from Saqala AlnRaAqapa: (TA:) seldom is the Suqolap of a horse long except his sides be short, which is a fault: (S, O:) and the SuqolaAni are the qurobaAni [by which may be meant either the two flanks or the two portions between the groin and the armpit on each side] of a daAbRap [i. e. horse or similar beast] &c. (M.) And The janob [or side]. (M, K.) HumurN zaHaAlifu AlSRuqoli means Asses having smooth and fat bellies. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA in art. zHlf.)
And i. q. naAHiyapN [meaning A district, quarter, tract, &c.]: (O, TA:) so in the saying, Oanota fiI SuqolK xaAlK [Thou art in a vacant district &c.]; like SuqoEK xaAlK. (TA.)
See also SaqolN.
SaqalN Length of the flanks; in a horse: (S, O:) or depression (AinohiDaAm) of the flank. (M.)

SaqilN A horse long in the flanks: (S, O:) or long in the flanks and short in the sides: (AO, TA: [see SuqolN:]) and (O) having little flesh, (O, K, TA,) whether long or short, (O, K,) or whether long in the flank or short. (TA.)
Also, applied to a man, (Ibn-'Abbád, O,) Differing, or varying, in his gait; or manner of walking. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
SuqolapN: see SuqolN.
Also Leanness, or lankness in the belly, and slenderness. (TA.)
SiqaAlN an inf. n. of Saqalahu, (S, O, Msb,) or a simple subst. (M, K.) [See 1, first sentence.]

SiqaAlu Alfarasi (assumed tropical:) The tending of the horse well, taking good care of him, supplying him with fodder and fattening him. (S, * M, O, * K.) One says, Alfarasu fiI SiqaAlihi [The horse is in his state of good tending and feeding]. (S, O.) [See also 1, second sentence].
Also The belly. (K.)
SaqiylN A thing, (M,) or a sword, (Msb,) [and the like,] Polished; as also maSoquwlN↓. (M, Msb, K.)
And A thing, such as iron, and copper, smooth, solid, and impenetrable to water. (Msb.)
[Also, as a subst., implying the meaning of an epithet,] A sword. (S, TA.)
SaqRaAlN: see SayoqalN.
SaAqilN Polishing: pl. SaqalapN. (S, M, Msb, K.)

SayoqalN One who practises the art of polishing (S, M, O, Msb, K) and sharpening (M, K) swords (S, M, O, Msb, K) and the like: (Msb:) [commonly called in the present day SaqRaAl↓:] pl. SayaAqilapN (S, M, O, Msb, K) and SayaAqiylu: (so in a copy of the M:) the p in the former pl. is affixed irregularly, as in malaAYikapN and qaXaAEimapN. (M.)
miSoqalN: see the next paragraph.
Also, applied to a speaker, an orator, or a preacher, i. q. miSolaqN, (M, K,) used by a poet in the sense of the latter word, i. e. as meaning Eloquent. (Th, M.)

miSoqalapN (S, M, O, K, KL) and miSoqalN↓ (KL) An instrument, (S, M, O, KL,) or a xarazap [which may here mean either a bead-shaped stone or a shell], (K,) with which one polishes (S, M, O, K, KL) a sword (S, O, KL, TA) and the like, (S, TA,) a knife, (KL,) a mirror, a garment, or piece of cloth, and paper. (TA.)
maSoquwlN: see SaqiylN.
maSoquwlu AlkisaMCi means (assumed tropical:) Milk overspread with a pellicle: (O, * TA:) a rájiz says,

L.foreign: fahowa UicaA maA QhotaAfa Oawo tahayRafaA
Eano kulRi maSoquwli AlkisaMCi qado SafaA

sense.s: [And he, when he thirsts, or experiences the hot south-west wind (Alhayof), leaves only the pellicles when he sucks in with his lips from every quantity of milk overspread with a pellicle, that has become clear]: accord. to As, it means the froth of milk: (TA:) IAar explained it accord. to its apparent signification, as used in a verse of 'Amr Ibn-ElAhtam El-Minkaree, (O, TA,) i. e. as meaning a [glossy] red kisaMC; [a sense not indicated by that verse, and clearly inconsistent with the ex. cited above;] and when told how As had explained it, replied that, when he had said it, he was ashamed to retract it. (TA.)

1. SakRahu, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
Sakuka
, (TA,) inf. n. SakRN, (Mgh, * Msb, TA,) He struck him, or it: (S, Mgh, O:) or he struck him, or it, vehemently, with a broad thing; or in a general sense, (K, TA,) with anything whatever: (TA:) or he slapped him with his hand, i. e. struck him with his expanded hand, (Msb,) like laTamahu, (TA in art. lTv, &c.,) upon the back of his neck, and upon his face. (Msb.) Hence, in the Kur [li. 29], faSakRato wajohahaA (S, TA) And she slapped her face with her hand; syn. laTamatohu. (Jel.) And SakRa AlbaAziI Sayodahu The hawk, or falcon, struck his prey with his foot, and so cast it down. (Ham p. 799.) And [hence, app.,] one says, xuco hecaA OawRala SakRK, meaning OawRala maA OaSukRu bihi [Take thou this on my first striking with it]: and so OawRala SawokK (O, TA.)
Also He pushed him, or thrust him; (As, TA;) like dakRahu and lakRahu. (TA in art. dk.)
And SakRa AlbaAba He shut, or closed the door: (S, O, Msb, K:) or he locked the door. (Lth, O, K.)
And SakRa, aor. and inf. n. as above, He wrote what is termed a SakR [expl. below]. (Msb.)

Sakikota, (S, O, K,) like malilota, (K,) third pers. Sakka, (MA, in which it is mentioned
as said of an ass,) [and it is also implied in the TA that the third pers. is Sakika, like laHiHato said of the eye, and some other instances, which are extr.,] a verb of the class of taEiba, (Msb,) inf. n. SakakN, (S, Mgh, * O, Msb, K, TA,) [in the CK SakiykFA is erroneously put for SakakFA, and it seems from what follows that SakRN is also an inf. n. like SakakN,] Thou wast knock-kneed: (S, O, Msb:) or thou hadst a colliding (AiDoTiraAb) of the knees, and [when used in relation to an ostrich or a horse or the like] of the EuroquwbaAni [which evidently means here, as in many other instances, the hocks]: (K:) [for] the verb is used in relation to a man, (S, O, K, TA,) and to other than man: (TA: [and the same is implied in the S and O, as is shown voce OaSakRu:]) SakakN [sometimes particularly] signifies the colliding of the knees [or of the hocks] in running, so that it makes a mark, or scar, upon each of them: (TA:) [and it is said that] this word, (Mgh,) or SakRN, (TA, [perhaps a mistranscription for SakakN,]) signifies the colliding of the EuroquwbaAni. (Mgh, TA.)
3. SAkRhu [He struck him, or it; or struck him, or it, vehemently, with a broad thing, or with anything; or slapped him with his hand; being struck, &c., by him]. (Ham p. 313.)

8. AiSoTakRaA They (two men, O, TA, and two bodies, TA) struck each other. (O, TA.) One says, taSoTakRu rukobataAhu [His two knees collide, or knock together]. (S, O, Msb. *) And AiSoTakRuwA biAlsRuyuwfi They struck one another with the swords. (TA.)
SakRN inf. n. of SakRa. (Mgh, * Msb, TA.)

Also a Pers. word (S, O) arabicized, (S, Mgh, O, TA,) A certain writing, (S, O, K, *) called in Pers. jak, (O,) or Jako; (TA;) a debenture, or written acknowledgement of a debt (Mgh, Msb) of money or property, or of some other thing: (Mgh:) and a written statement of a commercial transaction, purchase or sale, transfer, bargain, contract, or the like: (Msb, TA:) i. q. sijilRN [in this last sense or in the senses next following]: (S and TA in art. sjl:) a sijilR of a qaADiI [i. e. a sealed, or signed and sealed, statement of a judicial decision; a judicial record; or the record of a judge, in which his sentence is written]: (KL:) and a written order for the payment of subsistence-money, or of a stipend, salary, pension, or allowance; which some persons used to sell, but the selling of which is forbidden: (Msb, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaSukRN and [of mult.] SikaAkN and SukuwkN. (S, O, Msb, K.) [Hence,] layolapu AlSRakRi The night of the middle [of the month] of Shaa- bán; because in it are written the SikaAk of the allowances of subsistence [of individuals]: also called layolapu AlbaraMCapi. (O, TA.) [Hence also] SakRu AlmusaAfiri The traveller's pass, given him to prevent any one's offering opposition to him. (A and Mgh in art. jwz.)

SakRapN The vehemence of the midday-heat in summer: (K:) or the most vehement heat of midday in summer: (S:) and it is prefixed to EumaIR: (K:) one says, laqiyutuh SakRapa EumaIRK, (S, O,) a prov., meaning I met him in the most vehement heat of midday in summer when the heat almost blinded by its vehemence: (Lh, O, TA:) for EumaIR is said to be an abbreviated dim. of OaEomaI: (S, O, TA:) and by it is said to be meant the gazelle, because he is dazzled and confounded in the midday-heats of summer, and knocks against the thing that is before him: some say, SakRapa HumaIRK, from Hamiyati AlXRamosu: and some assert that EumaIR means the heat, itself: (O, TA:) or it is the name of a certain man [as will be found expl. in art. EmI, with variations of this saying]. (S, O, K, TA.)
SukaAkN The air [or atmosphere, between heaven and earth]; like sukaAkN; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K;) a dial. var. of the latter word. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)
SakiykN Weak: (IAmb, Hr, K, TA:) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; [lit.] meaning one who is struck much, or often, because deemed weak. (TA.)
SakRaAkN [A writer of the statements termed SikaAk, pl. of SakRN: or, accord. to Golius, as on the authority of Meyd, an actuary, who commits to writing the sentences of the judge].

OaSakRu Knock-kneed: (S, O, Msb:) or having a colliding (AiDoTiraAb) of the knees, and [when used in relation to an ostrich or a horse or the like] of the EuroquwbaAni [which evidently means here, as in many other instances, the hocks]; as also miSakRN↓; (K;) which latter [in this sense is rare, and is written in the CK maSakRN, but] is with kesr to the m: (TA:) thus applied to a man; (S, O, K, TA;) and to other than man; (TA;) [i. e.] applied also to a horse; (O;) and to an ostrich, because he is long in step, long-legged, and sometimes, or often, his rukobataAni [here improperly used as meaning “ hocks ”] being near together, his legs strike each other: (S, O:) and a man is also said to be OaSakRu AlrRijolayoni: (TA:) the fem. is SakRaMCu: (Mgh, Msb:) and the pl. is SukRN. (TA.)
Also One whose teeth, both the OasonaAn and the OaDoraAs, cleave close together: like OalaSRu. (Az, TA.)
See also the next paragraph.

miSakRN Strong: (S, O, K;) applied to a man; and to other than man; (K;) [i. e.] applied to a camel, and to an ass, (S, O,) as in a verse cited in the last paragraph of art. shr; (O;) and OaSakRu↓ signifies the same: (K:) the fem. of the former is with p; (S, O, TA;) which is held by Sb to be rare; for epithets of the measures mifoEalN and mifoEaAlN seldom have p affixed to denote the fem. (TA.)
One says also raOosN miSakRN lilrRuWuwsi [app. meaning A head strong to butt, or knock, against other heads]. (K in art. rOs.)
See also OaSakRu.
Also A lock; syn. migolaAqN. (K.)
muSakRakN: see what follows.
maSokuwkN and muSakRakN↓ are epithets applied to a camel, [app. as meaning Fleshy;] as though flesh were thrust (SukRa, i. e. XukRa,) into him. (O.)

1. Sakamahu, (S, K,) [aor.
Sakuma
,] inf. n. SakomN, (TA,) He (a man, Fr, S) struck him, or it. (Fr, S, K.) See also SawaAkimu.
And He (a man, Fr, As, S) pushed, thrust, or repelled, him, or it. (Fr, As, S, K.)

And one says of a horse, yaSokumu, (S,) or Sakama EalaI lijaAmihi, (K,) or EalaI faOosi AllRijaAmi, (TA,) The horse champs, (S,) or champed, (K,) his bit, (S, K,) or the fOs of the bit, (TA,) and stretches forth his head, (S,) or then stretched forth his head, as though desiring to contend for superiority [with his rider]. (K.)
SakomapN A vehement shock, collision, impetus, push, or thrust, (Lth, S, K, TA,) with a stone or some other thing. (Lth, TA.)
SukRamN i. q. OaxofaAfN [which means Camels' feet, and boots; probably, here, the former: in the TK it is expl. as meaning the hoofs of camels: and it is there said that the sing. is SaAkimN]. (K.)
SawaAkimu Calamities, misfortunes, or evil accidents. (K.) The Arabs say, SawaAkimu AldRahori Sakamatohu↓ [The calamities of fortune smote him; or may the calamities of fortune smite him]. (S.)

1. SalRa, aor. yaSilRu, inf. n. SaliylN, It sounded; or made, produced, emitted, or sent forth, a sound; (S, M, O, K;) as also SaloSala↓, inf. n. SaloSalapN and muSaloSalN, (M, K, [in the CK SaloSalFA is erroneously put for muSaloSalFA,]) or muSaloSalN may be a n. of place; (M;) and SaloSalapN [sometimes, or always, implies repetition, as will be shown by what follows, or], accord. to Lth, is more intensive, or more vehement, than SaliylN: (TA:) the former verb is said of iron [when struck with iron or the like, (see Ham p. 353, and what here follows,) meaning it made a clashing, or a ringing, sound], as also SaloSala↓; (TA;) of a nail &c., (S, O,) of a nail when struck so that it is forced to enter into a thing, (M, K,) as in a verse of Lebeed cited in art. Hkm, conj. 4; (S, M, O;) of helmets of iron (bayoD) when struck with swords, meaning they made a ringing sound; (M, K; *) [see an ex. of the inf. n. voce raEodN;] also of an empty jar when it is struck; (TA;) and of any dry clay, or baked pottery: (M:) also of a lijaAm [i. e. bit], meaning it made a prolonged sound; (M, K;) and SaloSala↓, (M, K,) inf. n. SaloSalapN, (S,) said of the same, (S, M, * K, *) it made repeated sounds, (S, M, K,) and so taSaloSala↓; (M, K;) which last is also said of a woman's, or other, ornament, meaning it made a [tinkling, or ringing,] sound; (S, K;) and of clay mixed with sand when it has become dry [app. as meaning it made a crackling sound when trodden upon]; (S;) mention is also made, in a trad., of the SaloSalap↓ [i. e. ringing, or tinkling,] or a bell; (K;) and
[its verb] SaloSala is said of anything dry [as meaning it made a sound, or noise, when struck, or put in motion]; (Lth, TA;) and also of thunder, meaning it made a clear sound. (M, K.)

[Hence,] SalRati AlUibilu, (M, K,) aor. taSilRu, (M,) inf. n. SaliylN, The camels made a [rumbling] sound to be heard on the occasion of drinking in consequence of their intestines' having become dry: (M, K:) [and in like manner Alxayolu the horses:] one says, jaMCati Alxayolu taSilRu EaTaXFA The horses came making a [rumbling] sound to be heard from their bellies in consequence of thirst: (S, O:) and samiEotu lijawofihi SaliylFA mina AlEaTaXi [I heard a rumbling sound of his belly in consequence of thirst]. (T, TA.) And SalRa AlsRiqaMCu, inf. n. SaliylN, (tropical:) The water-skin became dry, (M, TA,) not having any water in it, so that it was such as would make a kind of clattering or crackling noise (yataqaEoqaEu) [when struck or shaken or bent]. (TA.) And SaliylN also signifies The sounding of the entering of water into the earth, or ground. (M in art. Sm.)

SalRa, (S, M, O, K,) aor. yaSilRu, (S, M, O,) inf. n. SuluwlN; (S, M, O, K;) and also, sec. pers. Salilota, aor. taSalRu; (O, TA;) and ASlR↓; (S, M, O, K;) or only the latter; (Zj, TA;) or it may be AlSRuluwlu is said, as it occurs in a verse of El-Hotei-ah, and not SalRa; like AlEaTaMCu from OaEoTaI, and AlquluwEu from OaqolaEati AlHumRaI; (IB, TA;) It was, or became, stinking; said of flesh-meat, (S, M, O, K,) whether cooked or raw; (S, O;) said by some to be used only in relation to that which is raw; but OaSalRato↓ occurs, in a verse of Zuheyr, said of a muDogap [or bit of flesh-meat that is chewed], which indicates that it is used in relation to that which is cooked and roasted; or, accord. to some, the verb here means Oavoqalat [which has rendered heavy the eater]: (M:) and one says also AllRiHaAmu SalRalati↓ [the flesh-meats were, or became stinking (in both of my copies of the S AllRijaAmu is erroneously put for AllRiHaAmu, the reading in other copies of the S and in the O)]; the verb in this instance being with teshdeed lilokavorapi [i. e. because of its relation to many subjects, or to a pl.]. (S, O.) In the Kur [xxxii. 9], some read OaUicaA SalalonaA fiI QloOaroDi, (M, O, TA,) [instead of the common reading, which is DalalonaA, with D,] and some read SalilonaA, (O, TA,) which has two meanings: i. e. When we shall have become stinking, in the earth, and altered in ourselves and in our forms? and when we shall have become dried up? from SalRapN meaning “ dry ground. ” (TA.)
And SalRa, (M, K,) inf. n. SuluwlN, (TA,) is also said of water, meaning It became altered for the worse in taste and colour. (M, K.)
SalRatohumu AlSRaAlRapu, (S, M, O, K,) aor. taSulRuhumo, (S, O,) (tropical:) Calamity, or the calamity, befell them. (S, M, O, K, TA.)
SalRa AlXRaraAba, (M, K,) aor. yaSulRuhu, (TA,) inf. n. SalRN, He cleared the wine, or beverage. (M, K.)

And SalalonaA AlHabRa, (O,) or SalalonaA AlHabRa AlmuxotaliTa biAltRuraAbi, (K,) [We cleared the grain that was mixed with dust, or earth, from the dust, or earth, by pouring water upon it; or] we poured water upon the grain that was mixed with earth, or dust, so that each became separated from the other: (O, K:) one says, hecihi SulaAlatuhu↓ [app. meaning This is its water with which it has been washed; like as one says referring to anything that has been washed, hecihi gusaAlatuhu, and muwaASatahu, meaning as above]. (K.)
Salalotu AlxufRa: see the next paragraph.
2. SalRalati AllRiHaAmu: see 1, latter half.

SalRalotu AlxufRa; (so in my copies of the S;) or Salalotu↓ AlxufRa, (so accord. to the O and TA,) inf. n. SalRN; (TA;) [meaning, as is indicated by what immediately precedes in the S and O, He put a piece of skin such as is termed SalRap to the boot, app., to its sole (see SalRapN): or, as is indicated by what immediately precedes in the TA, he put a lining (termed SalaAlap) to the boot: the verb without teshdeed (written in the O Sallotu) I think to be a mistranscription, notwithstanding the inf. n. assigned to it in the TA: general analogy is in favour of its being with teshdeed; and it is said that] taSoliylN signifies The putting skin upon a thing. (KL.)
4: see 1, latter half, in two places.
ASlR AlmaMCa It (oldness) altered the water for the worse in taste and colour. (M, K.)
R. Q. 1. SaloSala: see 1, former half, in four places.
Also He threatened, or menaced; and frightened, or terrified. (IDrd, O, K.)
And He slew the chief man of the army. (IDrd, O, K.)
And SlSl Alkalimapa (tropical:) He uttered the klmp [or sentence] with a feigning, or making a show, of skilfulness. (Z, O, TA.)
R. Q. 2. taSaloSala: see 1, former half.
It is also said of a pool of water left by a torrent, as meaning Its black mud became dry [app. because such dry mud makes a crackling sound when trodden upon]. (IDrd, O, K.)
SalRN: see SalRapN, latter part.
SulRN Flesh-meat, &c., altered [for the worse]. (K.)

SilRN A serpent: (K:) or a serpent against which charming is of no avail: (S, O:) or a serpent that kills at once when it bites: (M:) or a yellow serpent (K) in the case of which charming is of no avail: (TA:) or a yellow serpent that is found in the sand; when a man sees it, he ceases not to tremble until he dies: (Har p. 102:) pl. OaSolaAlN. (S, M, * O, K. *) One says, UinRahaA laSilRu SafFA [lit. Verily it is a deadly serpent of smooth stones; i. e., such as is found among smooth stones;] meaning, an abominable serpent like the viper. (S, O.) And UinRahu laSilRu OaSolaAlK [lit.] (assumed tropical:) Verily he is a serpent of serpents; thus one says of a man, likening him to a serpent; (S, O;) meaning cunning, or crafty, and abominable, (S, M, O, K,) in contention, (M,) or in contention and in other cases: (M, K:) like as one says DilRu OaDolaAlK, and DirRu OaDoraArK. (TA in art. Dr.)
And (tropical:) A calamity, or misfortune; as also SaAlRapN↓. (M, K, TA.) So the former in the saying, muniIa fulaAnN biSilRK (tropical:) [Such a one was tried with a calamity]. (TA.)
And (tropical:) A sharp sword: pl. as above. (A, O, K, TA.)

And (tropical:) An equal, or a match. (Z, K, TA.) One says, hecaA SilRu hecaA (tropical:) This is the equal, or match, of this. (Z, TA.) And humaA SilRaAni (assumed tropical:) They two are likes. (Kr, M.)
See also SalRapN, latter part.
Also A certain plant: (S, O:) or a species of trees. (M, K.)
SalRapN [as an inf. n. of un.] The sound of a nail and the like, when it is struck with force; as also SilRapN↓. (K.) And The sound of the lijaAm [or bit]. (K.)

Also Dry ground: (S, M, O, K:) or ground, or land, not rained upon, between two tracts of ground, or land, that are rained upon; (M, K;) because, being dry, it makes a sound [when trodden upon]: (M:) or accord. to IDrd, ground, or land, rained upon, between two tracts not rained upon; (O:) or simply ground, or land, (M, K,) whatever it be; like saAhirapN: (M:) pl. SilaAlN. (M, O, K.)

And A sole: (K:) [ISd says,] xufRN jayRidu AlSRalRapi means [A boot good] in respect of the sole; which is thus called by the name of the ground, not otherwise; in my opinion because of its dryness, and its making a sound on the occasion of treading. (M. [See also another explanation of this phrase in what follows.])

Also Skin: one says xufRN jayRidu AlSRalRapi [A boot good in respect of the skin; somewhat differently expl. above]: (S, O:) or dry skin, before the tanning. (M, K.) And Stinking skin in the tan. (K.)

Also An extensive rain: (K:) and a scattered, scanty rain: (M, K:) and so SalRN↓ and SilRN↓: thus having two contr. meanings: (K:) pl. as above: (M:) or SilaAlN, its pl., signifies portions of scattered rains, falling by little and little. (S, O.)

And (assumed tropical:) A portion, (K,) or a scattered portion, (M,) of herbage: (M, K:) pl. as above: (M:) or [the pl.] SilaAlN signifies (assumed tropical:) herbage; which is thus called by the name of the rain. (S, O.)
And Moist earth. (O, K.)
See also SulRapN.
Also The Aisot [i. e. podex, or anus]. (TA.)

SulRapN, with damm, (K,) or SalRapN↓, (so in the O,) Remains of water (O, K) in a watering-trough; thus expl. by Fr; (O;) and of other things, (K,) such as [the oils called] duhon and zayot. (TA.) [See also SuloSulapN.]
And A fetid odour. (K.)
And The flabbiness of moist flesh-meat. (K.)
SilRapN: see SalRapN, first sentence.
huwa tiboEu SilRapK, or with D, [i. e. DilRapK,] accord. to different relaters, means He is a very cunning man (daAhiyapN), one in whom is no good. (TA.)
SilaAlN pl. of SalRapN [q. v.]. (S, M, O, K.)
Also The leg of a boot; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K;) and so SilaAlapN↓: (K:) or ↓the latter signifies the lining of a boot: (M, K:) the pl. of the former is OaSilRapN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)
SulaAlapN: see 1, last sentence but one.
SilaAlapN: see SilaAlN, in two places.
SalRaAlN Clay that makes a sound like as does new pottery; as also miSolaAlN↓. (S, O.)
And rajulN SalRaAlN mina AlZRamaOi [A man making a rumbling sound to be heard from his belly in consequence of being thirsty: see 1]. (TA.)
Also, (K,) i. e. like XadRaAdN, (TA,) or SulRaAlN↓, (so in a copy of the M,) Water altered for the worse in taste and colour. (M, K.)
SulRaAlN: see what next precedes.

SilRiyaAnN, of the measure fiEoliyaAnN, (S, O,) or, accord. to some, of the measure fiERilaAnN, (TA in art. SlI,) A certain plant; (K;) a certain herb, or leguminous plant; (baqolapN;) (S, O;) a sort of plants (XajarN [which means thus as well as “ trees ” &c.]), said by AHn to be of the [kind called] Tariyfap, that grows upwards, the thickest portions whereof are the stems (OaEojaAz) and the lower parts, of the size of the HaliIR, and the places of its growth are the plain, or soft, tracts, and the meadows (riyaAD): AA, he adds, says that it is of the [kind called] janobap, because of its thickness and lastingness: (M:) Az says that it is of the best kind of herbage, or pasture, and has a [root such as is termed] jiEovinap, and thin leaves: (TA:) it is called xubozapu AlUibili [the bread of the camels]: (TA in art. SlI:) the n. un. is with p. (S, M, O, K.) It is said in a prov., (S, M, O,) of a man who hastens to swear an oath, (S, O,) or of one who boldly ventures to swear a false oath, (TA,) and has no impediment in his speech (S, O, TA) in doing so, (TA,) jacRahaA jacRa AlEayori AlSRilRiyaAnapa (S, M, O, TA) He hastened to it as the ass hastens to the SlRyAnp: (L in art. jc:) because the ass often plucks out the SlRyAnp by the root when he takes it for pasture. (S, O.)
SaAlRN: see SaloSaAlN, in two places.

Also, [app. a part. n. used as a subst.,] Water that falls upon the ground, which then cracks, (O, K,) or, as in the L, which then dries (fayayobasu fatajifRu [correctly fatayobasu fatajifRu, as referring to AlOaroD, or rather fatayobasu watajifRu]), causing a sound to be heard. (TA.)
SaAlRapN: see SilRN.
SaloSalN: see the next paragraph.
It is [also] said to signify Stinking; from SalRa said of flesh-meat. (O.)
SuloSulN: see SaloSaAlN.

Also A certain bird: (K:) a certain small bird: (M:) or (K) the [collared turtle-dove called] faAxitap; (IAar, S, O, K;) the bird which the Persians (AlEajam) call by this latter name: (Lth, TA:) or a bird resembling the faAxitap: Az says, it is what is called mwXjp [evidently a mistranscription for muwaXRaHap, q. v.]: (TA:) pl. SalaASilu: (IAar, TA:) and SuloSulapN↓ signifies a pigeon, (IAar, O, K, TA,) or a female pigeon. (IAar, TA.)
Also The forelock of a horse; (S, M, O, K;) and so SaloSalN↓: (K:) or a whiteness in a horse's mane. (M, K.)
And Hair of the back of a horse, and of [the part of the breast called] the labRap, that has become white in consequence of the falling-off of the hair. (K.)
And A [drinking-cup, or bowl, such as is called] qadaH: (K:) or a small qadaH; (As, O, K;) [i. e.] a qadaH such as is called gumar. (AHn, M.)
And A skilful pastor. (IAar, O, K.)
See also SuloSulapN.
SaloSalapN: see the next paragraph.
SuloSulapN: see SuloSulN.

Also A portion remaining of water (S, M, O, K) in a pool left by a torrent, (M, K,) and in a vessel, or in the [kind of small skin called] UidaAwap, and in the lower part of a pool left by a torrent, (S, O,) and likewise of [the kinds of oil called] zayot (S, * M, O, * K) and duhon; (M, K;) as also SaloSalapN↓, (Ibn-'Abbád, M, O, K,) and SuloSulN↓: (M, K:) pl. SalaASilu. (S, M, O.) [See also SulRapN.]
And i. q. waforapN (IAar, O, K) and jamRapN (AA, TA) [i. e. Hair collected together upon the head, or hanging down upon the ears, or extending beyond the lobe of the ear, &c.].

SaloSaAlN A noisy ass; as also SuloSulN↓ and SulaASilN↓ and muSaloSilN↓: (M, K:) an ass strong in voice [or bray], vehement therein. (Aboo-Ahmad El-'Askeree, TA.) And A horse sharp and slender [or shrill] in voice [or neigh]. (M, TA.) And A wild ass sharp in voice; as also SaAlRN↓: so says Aboo-Ahmad El-Askeree: and thus is expl. the saying in a trad., OatuHibRuwna Oano takuwnuwA mivola AlHamiyri AlSRaAlRapi↓, app. meaning [Would ye love to be like the asses] sound in bodies, vehement in voices, by reason of their strength and their briskness? (TA.)

Also Clay not made into pottery; (M, K;) so called because of its making a sound (litaSaloSulihi: (M:) or clay mixed with sand; (S, O, K;) which, when it becomes dry, makes a sound; and which, when baked, is faxRaAr: (S, O:) or dry clay, that makes a sound by reason of its dryness: (Z, O, TA:) thus in the Kur lv. 13 [and xv. 26 and 28 and 33]: or, accord. to Mujáhid, i. q. HamaON masonuwnN [which means black mud altered for the worse in odour]. (TA.)
And SaloSaAlapN A land in which is no one. (O, TA.)
SulaASilN: see the next preceding paragraph.
miSalRapN A vessel in which wine, or beverage, is cleared: (M, K:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (M.)
muSalRilN Copious, or abundant, rain. (IAar, O, K.)

Also A generous, or noble, and honourable, chief, pure in respect of parentage; as also muSaloSalN↓, with fet-h: (K:) or one who is pure in respect of generosity, or nobility, and of parentage: (IAar, O:) and rajulN muSaloSilN↓ [thus in the O] a man who is a generous, or noble, chief, pure in respect of parentage, and honourable. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)
And The Oasokaf [or maker of boots]; who is also called by the vulgar [or the people of the towns and village] UisokaAf. (IAar, O, K.)
miSolaAlN: see SalRaAlN.
muSaloSalN may be either an inf. n. of SaloSala or a n. of place. (M. [See 1, first sentence.])
[Also an epithet, if not a mistake for muSaloSilN:] see muSalRilN.
muSaloSilN: see SaloSaAlN:
and see also muSalRilN.

1. Saluba, [aor.
Saluba
,] inf. n. SalaAbapN; (S, M, A, Msb, K, &c.;) and Saliba, aor.
Salaba
; (IKtt, A, K;) and SlRb↓, inf. n. taSoliybN; (K; [but this last, accord. to the TA, is trans. only;]) said of a thing, (S, Msb,) [and of a man,] It [and he] was, or became, hard, firm, rigid, stiff, tough, strong, robust, sturdy, or hardy; syn. AiXotadRa; (S, * A, * Msb, K; *) contr. of laAna. (M, TA.)
[Hence,] Salubati AlOaroDu munocu OaEowaAmK (tropical:) [The land has been hard by lying waste for years]; said of land that has not been sown for a long time. (A, TA.)
And Saluba EalaI AlmaAli, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, tenacious, or avaricious, of property, or the property. (M, L.)
[And Saluba AlXRaraAbu, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) The wine became strong. (HadRu AlXRaraAbi is expl. in the S and L, in art. Hd, as meaning SalaAbatuhu.)]

Salaba AlEiZaAma, (M, K,) aor.
Saliba
, inf. n. SalobN; (M;) and ASTlbhA↓; (M, K;) He cooked, (M,) or collected and cooked, (TA,) the bones, (M, TA,) and extracted their grease, or oily matter, (M, K, TA,) to make use of it as a seasoning: (TA:) or ASTlb↓ [alone] he extracted the grease, or oily matter, of bones, (S,) or he collected bones, and extracted their grease, or oily matter, (Msb,) to make use of it as a seasoning. (S, Msb.)

And in like manner one says of one who roasts, or broils, or fries, flesh-meat and makes its grease to flow: (M:) i. e. one says, Salaba AllRaHoma, (M, * K, TA,) and ASTlb↓ [alone], (M,) He roasted, or broiled, or fried, the flesh-meat, (M, K, TA,) and made its grease to flow. (M, TA.)

And, (K,) as Sh says, (TA,), Salabahu, aor.
Saliba
and
Saluba
, (K, TA,) inf. n. SalobN, (TA,) He, or it, burned him: (K, TA:) and Salabatohu AlXRamosu The sun burned him [app. causing his sweat to flow]. (TA.)

And Salabahu, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
Saliba
, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. SalobN; (S, M, Msb;) and SlRbhu↓, (M, K,) inf. n. taSoliybN, (K,) or the verb with teshdeed is said of a pl. number; (S, A;;) [He crucified him;] he put him to death in a certain well-known manner; (M, L;) he made him to be maSoluwb; (K) namely, one who had slain another; (Msb;) or a thief: (A:) from Salaba AlEiZaAma; because the oily matter, and the ichor mixed with blood, of the person so put to death flows. (M.)

[Hence] AlSRalobu in prayer means The placing the hands upon the flanks, in standing, and separating the arms from the body: a posture forbidden by the Prophet because resembling that of a man when he is crucified (UicaA Suliba), the arms of the man in this case being extended upon the timber. (TA.)

[Hence also,] Salaba AldRalowa, (M, K,) and SalRabahaA↓, (M,) He put upon the dlw [or leathern
bucket] what are called SaliybaAni↓, (M, L, K,) which are two pieces of wood placed cross-wise [to keep it from collapsing], like what are called the EaroquwataAni. (M, L.)

Salabato Ealayohi HumRaAhu, (S, M, A, Msb, * K,) aor.
Saliba
, (S,) His fever was continual, (S, A, Msb, K,) and vehement: (S, A, K:) or was of the kind termed SaAlib [q. v.]. (M, TA.)
2. SlRbhu, (inf. n. taSoliybN, TA,) He, or it, rendered it, or him, hard, firm, rigid, stiff, tough, strong, robust, sturdy, or hardy. (S, M, K, TA.) El-Aashà says,

(S, TA) i. e. [Than the back of the excellent she-camel] which the provender of cities, such as [the trefoil called] qatR, and date-stones, and the pasture of El-Himè, meaning Himè Dareeyeh, the place of pasture of the camels of the kings, and the being long without conceiving, (TA,) have rendered hard, or firm, or strong. (S, TA.)
[Hence] one says, SlRb AlnRabiyca biHabRi AldRaAciIRi (assumed tropical:) [He made the beverage termed nbyc to become strong by means of the grain called HbR AldAcIR]. (Mgh in art. dwc.)
SalRaba AlrRuTabu, (AA, S, K,) inf. n. taSoliybN, (AA, TA,) The ripe dates became dry: (AA, S, K:) and SalRabati AltRamorapu the date became dry. (M, L.)
[Hence, perhaps, SalRaba is said in the K to be syn. with Saluba:] see 1, first sentence.
See also 1, latter half, in two places.

SlRb said of a monk, (M,) or SlRbwA (K, TA) said of monks, (TA,) He, (M,) or they, (K, TA,) made, or took, (M, K, TA,) for himself, (M,) or for themselves, (K, TA,) a Saliyb [or cross], (M, K, TA,) in his church, (M,) or in their churches. (TA.)

AltRaSoliybu also signifies [The making the sign of the cross. And] The figuring of a cross [or crosses] upon a garment; (T, Mgh, TA;) and hence, the figure thereof; the inf. n. being thus used as a subst. properly so termed; (Mgh;) as in a trad. where it is said of the Prophet, qaDaba AltRaSoliyba; meaning qaTaEa mawoDiEa AltRaSoliybi minohu [He cut off the place of the figuring of the cross, or crosses, from it]. (T, Mgh, TA.) And SalRaba bayona Eayonayohi occurs in a trad., meaning He made a mark like the cross between his eyes by a blow. (TA.)

Also A particular mode of wearing, or disposing, the [muffler called] ximaAr, (M, K,) for a woman. (K.) One says of a woman, SalRabato ximaArahaA [She disposed her muffler cross-wise]. (TA.) And a man's praying fiI taSoliybi AlEimaAmapi [with the turban disposed cross-wise] is disapproved: he should wind it so that one part [or fold] thereof is above [not across] another. (TA.)
4. ASlbt, (AA, K,) inf. n. UiSolaAbN, (AA, TA,) She (a camel) stood stretching forth her neck towards the sky, in order to yield her utmost flow of milk to her young one. (AA, K, TA.)

5. tSlRb (tropical:) He acted, or behaved, with forced hardness, firmness, strength, vigour, hardiness, courage, vehemence, severity, strictness, or rigour; he exerted his strength, force, or energy; strained, or strained himself, or tasked himself severely; syn. taXadRada; (A, TA;) which means jahada nafosahu; (L in art. Xd;) licelika [for that]: (A:) said of a man. (TA.)
8: see 1, former half, in three places.

SulobN Hard, firm, rigid, stiff, tough, strong, robust, sturdy, or hardy; syn. XadiydN; (S, A, Msb, * K;) contr. of layRinN; (M, TA;) as also SaliybN↓ and SulRabN↓ (S, M, A, K) and SalabN↓: (M:) pl. of the first or second, [accord. to analogy of the latter, and also of the last,] SilaAbN. (M, A.)

[Hence,] SulobN and SalabN↓, (K,) or makaAnN SulobN and SalabN↓, (M,) A rugged, stony place: (M, K; *) or SulobN signifies a rugged, extending place, of the earth or ground; and SalabN↓, a hard part of the earth or ground: (S:) or this last, a tract of rugged depressed land stretching along between two hills: (Sh, TA:) or the acclivities of hills; and its pl. is OaSolaAbN: (TA:) or OaSolaAbN signifies hard, extending, [tracts of] ground: (As, TA:) or hard and elevated [tracts of] ground: (IAar, TA:) and makaAnN SulobN, a rugged, hard place: (Msb:) the pl. (of SulobN, S) is SilabapN. (S, M, K.) One says of land that has not been sown for a long time, UinRahaA OaSolaAbN↓ munocu OaEowaAmK (tropical:) [Verily it has been hard by lying waste for years]. (A, TA.)

[Hence also,] huwa Sulobu AlmaEaAjimi (tropical:) [lit. He is hard, &c., in respect of the places of biting; meaning he is strong, or resisting, or indomitable, of spirit; (Eaziyzu AlnRafosi;) thus Sulobu AlmaEojami is expl. in the S and K in art.
