Ejm]: and Sulobu AlEuwdi (tropical:) [which means the same]. (A, TA.) And Sulobu AlEaSaA and AlEaSaA Saliybu↓, applied to a tender of camels; [lit. Hard, &c., in respect of the staff;] meaning (assumed tropical:) hard, severe, or rigorous, in his treatment of the camels: Er-Rá'ee says,

L.foreign: EalayohaA UicaA maA Oajodaba AlnRaAsu UiSobaEaA

sense.s: [Hard, &c., having the veins of his limbs appearing: thou wilt see him to have a finger pointing at them, i. e. his camels, because of their good condition, when the people are afflicted with drought]. (M, TA. But in the S, in art. SbE, we find DaEiyf in this verse instead of Saliyb.)
And [in like manner] huwa SulobN fiI diynihi and SulRabN↓ (tropical:) [He is hard, firm, or strong, in his religion]. (A, TA.)
And jaroIN SulobN (Lth, TA) or SaliybN↓ (M, L, TA) (tropical:) A hard, or vehement, running. (Lth, M, L, TA.)
And SahiylN SulobN (assumed tropical:) A vehement neighing. (Lth, TA.) And SawotN SaliybN↓ (tropical:) A vehement sound or cry or voice. (M, L, TA.)

Also, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) and SulubN↓ (Msb, TA) and SalabN↓ (S, M, A, K) and SaAlibN↓, (IAth, L, K,) which last is rarely used, (IAth, TA,) and is said to occur only in one instance, in poetry, but another instance of it in poetry is cited, (TA,) The back-bone; i. e. the bone extending from the kaAhil [or base of the neck] to the Eajob [or rump bone]; (M, A, K;) the bone upon which the neck is set, extending to the root of the tail [in a beast], and in a man to the EuSoEuS [or os coccygis]: (Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán: ”) or a portion of the back: (S:) and any portion of the back containing vertebræ: (S, Msb, TA:) [and particularly the lumbar portion; the lions:] and the back [absolutely]; as is said in an explanation of a verse of 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd cited in what follows: (M, TA:) pl. [of mult.] SilabapN and [of pauc.] OaSolubN and OaSolaAbN, (M, K,) each of which two is used in poetry in a sing. sense, as though every part of the Sulob were regarded as a Sulob in itself, and SilobapN, (M, TA,) of which last ISd says, [but this I do not find in the M,] I do not think it to be of established authority, unless it be a contraction of SilabapN. (TA.) Lh mentions, as a phrase of the Arabs, heWulaMCi OabonaMCu Silabatihimo [These are the sons of their loins: because the sperma of the man is held to proceed from the Sulob of the man, as is said in the Ksh &c. in lxxxvi. 7]. (M. [See also a similar phrase in the Kr iv. 27.])
[Hence SulobN is used as signifying The middle of a page, as distinguished from the haAmiX (or margin): and in like manner, of other things.]
[Hence, likewise,] SulobN signifies also HasabN [meaning (assumed tropical:) Rank or quality, &c.]: (AA, S, M, K:) and power, or strength. (M, K.) A poet says, (M,) namely, 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd, (S, TA,)

(assumed tropical:) [Because God hath made you to have excellence above what I can relate, in rank or quality, or in power, and abstinence from unlawful things]: (S, M, TA:) AA says that Sulob here signifies Hasab; (S;) and UizaAr here signifies EafaAf: (S, M, TA:) but some expl. Sulob here by both Hasab and quwRap: and some relate the latter hemistich otherwise, i. e.

meaning above such as binds the back with an izár. (M, TA.) And it is said in a trad., UinRa AlmugaAliba Suloba QllRehi magoluwbN, meaning (assumed tropical:) [Verily he who strives to overcome] the power of God [is overcome]. (TA.)
Also Coitus (jimaAE): because the sperma [of the man] issues from the part so called. (TA.)
SalabN, and its pl. OaSolaAbN: see SulobN, former half, in six places:
and see also SaliybN, in two places.
SulabN A certain bird, (O, K,) resembling the Saqor [or hawk], but which does not prey, and which is vehement, or loud, in its cry. (O.)
SulubN: see SulobN, near the middle.
SaliybN: see SulobN, former half, in five places.
[Hence,] maMCN SaliybN (tropical:) Water upon which cattle grow fat and strong and hard. (A, TA.)
And EarabiIRN SaliybN (tropical:) An Arabian of pure race: (A, Mgh, TA:) and AimoraOapN SaliybapN (tropical:) A woman of noble, or generous, origin. (A, TA.)

Also Grease, or oily matter, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) of bones; (S,
M, * Msb;) and so SalabN↓; (M, K;) which latter signifies also ichor, or watery humour, mixed with blood, that flows from the dead: (M:) pl. [of the former accord. to analogy, and perhaps of the latter also,] SulubN. (K.) Hence, in a trad., the phrase OaSoHaAbu AlSRulubi [in the CK AlSRalabi↓] Those who collect bones, (K, TA,) when the flesh has been stripped off from them, and cook them with water, (TA,) and extract their grease, or oily matter, and use it as a seasoning. (K, TA.)

Also [A cross;] a certain thing pertaining to the Christians, (Lth, S, M, Msb, K,) which they take as an object to which to direct the face in prayer: (Lth, TA:) pl. [of mult.] SulobaAnN (S, M, A, Msb) and SulubN (Lth, S, M) and [of pauc.] OaSolubN. (Msb.)
[And The figure of a cross upon a garment &c.: see muSalRabN.]

And A certain brand, or mark made with a hot iron, upon camels; (M, K;) which, as Aboo- 'Alee says in the “ Tedhkireh, ” is sometimes large and sometimes small, and may be upon the cheeks, and the neck, and the thighs: (M, TA:) or, as some say, it is upon the temple; and as some say, upon the neck; being two lines, one upon [or across] the other. (TA.)

And i. q. EalamN [as meaning A banner, or standard; properly, in the form of a cross]: (O, K:) En-Nábighah Edh-Dhubyánee is said to have thus called the Ealam because there was upon it a Saliyb [i. e. a cross]; for he was a Christian. (O.)

[And hence, as Freytag says, (referring to the “ Historia Halebi ” and “ Locman. Fabul. ” p. ٤٣ The text is unclear, the number could be 43 or 42.
1. 5. 8,) (assumed tropical:) An army of ten thousand soldiers.]

And AlSRaliybu is the name of The four stars behind AlnRasoru AlTRaAYiru [which is the asterism consisting of the three principal stars of Aquila; whence it seems to be the four principal stars of Delphinus]: inconsiderately said by J to be behind AlnRasoru AlwaAqiEu [which is α Lyræ]. (L, K, and so in the margin of some copies of the S,) [And Freytag says, (referring to Ideler Unters. p. 35,) that AlSlyb AlwAqE is the name of (assumed tropical:) Stars in the head of Draco.]
SaliybaAni of a leathern bucket: see 1, last sentence but one.
See also maSoluwbN.
SalaAbapN inf. n. of Saluba. (S, M, A, &c.)
[Using it as a subst. properly so called,] one says, maXaI fiI SalaAbapK mina AlOaroDi (tropical:) [He walked, or went along, upon hard ground]. (A, TA.)

Saliybapu AlrRajuli He who was, or those who were, in the loins (Sulob) of the father [or ancestor] of the man: hence the family of the Prophet, who are forbidden to receive of the poor-rate, are termed Saliybapu baniI haAXimK wabaniI Eabodi AlmuTRalibi. (Mgh.)
SulRabN: see SulobN, former half, in two places.
Also A hard stone, the hardest of stones. (TA.)
And Whetstones; (S, M, K, TA;) as also SulRabapN↓ (TA) and SulRabiIRN↓ (M, K, TA;) and SulRabiyRapN↓: (S, M, K, TA:) [or a whetstone:] or [a thing] like a whetstone. (A.)
See also SulRabiIRN.
SulRabapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
SulRabiIRN: see SulRabN.

Also A spear-head sharpened; (S, TA;) and so muSalRabN↓, (S,) or SulRabN↓: (TA: [but this last is perhaps a mistranscription for muSalRabN:]) or a thing polished and sharpened with whetstones: (K:) and muSalRabN↓ signifies a spear sharpened with the DulRabiIR, (M, TA,) or a spear-head sharpened upon the SulRab, which is like the whetstone. (A.)
SulRabiyRapN: see SulRabN.
SulobuwbN The mizomaAr [or musical reed, or pipe]: (O, K:) or, as some say, the qaSabap [or tube] that is in the head of the mzmAr [app. meaning its mouth-piece]. (O.)

SaAlibN A hot fever; contr. of naAfiDN [which means “ attended with shivering, or trembling ”]: (S:) or a fever not such as is termed naAfiDN: (M:) or a fever attended with vehement heat, and not attended with cold: (TA:) or a fever attended with tremour (A, K, TA) and quivering of the skin: (TA:) or a continual fever: (Msb:) or a fever attended with SudaAE [or headache]: (Ham p. 345:) it is said by Ibn-Buzurj to be from the SudaAE: (L, TA:) it is masc. and fem.: one says, Oaxacatohu AlHumRaI biSaAlibK [which may be rendered Fever with burning heat, &c., seized him] and Oaxacatohu HumRaI SaAlibN [virtually meaning the same]; the former of which is the more chaste: and one seldom or never makes one of the two nouns to govern the other in the gen. case: (M, TA:) or, accord. to Fr, they said HumRaI SaAlibN and HumRaI SaAlibK and SaAlibu HumRaI. (MF, TA.) SaAlibiI OaXadRu mino naAfiDika [My burning fever, or continual fever, &c., is more severe than thy fever attended with shivering] is a prov., (Meyd, TA,) applied to two things, or events, of which one is more severe than the other. (Meyd.)
See also SulobN, in the middle of the paragraph.

SawolabN and SawoliybN↓, (Lth, O, K, TA,) in some of the lexicons SayoliybN↓, (TA,) Seed that is scattered (Lth, O, K, TA) upon the earth, (Lth, O, TA,) and upon which the earth is then turned with the plough: (Lth, O, K, TA:) Az thinks it to be not Arabic. (TA.)
SawoliybN: see the next preceding paragraph.
SayoliybN: see the next preceding paragraph.

muSalRabN A garment, or piece of cloth, figured with the resemblance of the Saliyb [or cross]: (S, M, TA:) or figured with a Saliyb: (A, Msb:) or figured with the resemblances of SulobaAn [or crosses]. (TA.) [See 2.]
And A camel marked with the brand called the Saliyb; (M, A, TA;)as also maSoluwbN↓: fem. of the latter with p, applied to a she-camel; (M, TA;) as of the former also, applied to camels. (TA.)
And An Abyssinian (HabaXiIRN) marked with the figure of the Saliyb [or cross] upon his face. (A, TA.)
See also SulRabiIRN, in two places.

ruTabN maSalRibN, (S, K,) and tamorapN muSalRibapN, (M,) [Ripe dates, and a date,] becoming, or having become, dry. (S, M, K.) When date-honey (dibos) has been poured on such dates, that they may become soft, they are termed muSaqRarN. (S.)
maTarN muSalRibN Vehement, injurious rain. (L, TA.)
maSolowbN (M, A, Msb, K) and SaliybN↓ (M, A, K) [Crucified;] put to death in a certain wellknown manner: (M:) applied to a slayer of another, (Msb,) or to a thief. (A.) [See 1, latter half.]
See also muSalRabN.
maSoluwbN Ealayohi Affected by a continual and vehement fever; (S, TA;) or by a fever such as is termed SaAlibN. (TA.)

1. Saluta, aor.
Saluta
, inf. n. SuluwtapN, said of the jabiyn [or side of the forehead], It was such as is termed Salot [i. e. conspicuous, or clear, or fair; &c.]: (S, K:) or he (a man) was such as is termed Salot in respect of the jabiyn, (S, * K, * TA,) or of the face, or of the cheek (TA. [Accord. to the S and K, the verb is app. said of the jabiyn: accord. to the TA, of a man.])

Salatahu, (S,) aor.
Saluta
, (TK,) inf. n. SalotN, (K,) He urged him to run, by striking him with his foot, or leg; or struck him with his feet or legs, to urge him; namely, a horse; syn. rakaDahu. (S, K. *)
And He poured it forth; namely, what was in the cup, or bowl. (S.)
jaMCa bilabanK yaSolitu, and bimaraqK yaSolitu, He brought milk, and broth, having much water, (T, S, M,) with little oily, or greasy matter. (T, S.)
3. muSaAlatapN signifies The taking to oneself a verse of another poet without altering anything in it. (Har p. 267. [But this I believe to be postclassical.])
4. ASlt sayofahu He drew his sword from the scabbard. (S, M, A.)

7. AnSlt He advanced with a penetrative energy, and outstripped; syn. maDaI, and sabaqa; (K;) or so AnSlt fiI sayorihi [i. e., in his pace]: (S:) he outstripped; syn. tajarRada: and he was quick, or he hastened, in his pace, or going. (TA.) One says of the eagle (AlEuqaAb), AnoSalatato munoqaDRapF [It was swift in making a stoop]. (A. [This meaning is there indicated by the context.])
AnSlt yaEoduw He hastened in some measure, running: and so Ainokadara yaEoduw. (A'Obeyd, TA.)
AnSltt AlsRaHaAbapu (assumed tropical:) The cloud was going to rain. (TA, from a trad.)

SalotN, applied to the jabiyn [or side of the forehead], Conspicuous, or clear, or fair; syn. waADiHN: (S, A, K:) open, or uncovered, and even: (M, K:) or smooth: (TA:) anything bare; and open, or uncovered: (IAar, TA.) wide, even, and beautiful, or comely. (ISh, TA.) One says rajulN Salotu Aljabiyni A man conspicuous, or clear,
or fair, in respect of the jbyn: (M, TA:) or smooth and shining: (A:) or wide, white, conspicuous, or clear, or fair: (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, TA:) or even: (A'Obeyd, TA:) or hard. (IAar, TA.) And rajulN Salotu Alwajohi waAlxadRi A man conspicuous, or clear, or fair, in respect of the face and of the cheek. (TA.) And fulaAnN yukawRinu AlOasowada SalotFA [Such a one makes the black to be white, or fair]. (TA.)

Also, and munoSalitN↓, (M, K,) and UiSoliytN↓, applied to a sword, (S, M, A, K,) Sharp: (S:) or polished, and sharp, or penetrating: (K:) or unsheathed, and sharp, or penetrating: (M:) or such as penetrates into that which is smitten with it: (A:) but some say that a sword is not termed SalotN unless long: (TA:) or UiSoliytN↓ may have the same meaning as muSolatN↓, i. e. unsheathed: (S:) accord. to AA, SalotN applied to a sword and to a knife and to a needle means having no sheath. (TA.) And one says, Darabahu biAlsRayofi SalotFA (S, M, A) and SulotFA↓ (S, M) He smote him with sword unsheathed. (S, M, A.)

SalotN applied to a man, as also OaSolatiIRN↓ and munoSalitN↓ (S, M, K) and miSolatN↓ and miSolaAtN↓, (S, K,) pl. [of the last] maSaAliytu, (S,) Hard, firm, strong, or hardy, (M,) sharp, or penetrating, (S, M, K,) in affairs, (S,) or in needful affairs, (M, K,) light in clothing: (M:) and [in like manner] SalataAnN↓ signifies sharp, or penetrating, and quick (munoSalitN), in his affair. (Ham p. 536.)
See also SalataAnN below.
And see SulotN.
Oabuw AlSRaloti is a surname of The HidaOap [or kite]. (TA in art. HdO.)
SulotN (S, M, K) and SalotN↓ (M, K) A large knife: (S, M, K:) or an unsheathed knife: (M:) pl. OaSolaAtN. (S, M.)
For the former, see also SalotN.
SilotN A thief, or robber: (K:) formed by transposition from liSotN. (TA.)

SalataAnN, applied to a man, and to an ass, Strong, and hard, firm, or hardy: pl. SilotaAnN: (M:) or, applied to a man, as expl. above voce SalotN, q. v.: (Ham p. 536:) and, applied to an ass, strong: (S: [in some copies of which, for mina AlHimaAri, meaning mina AlHumuri, we find mn AljimaAri, whence an error in the Lexicon of Golius:]) and, applied to a horse, brisk, lively, or sprightly, and sharp of spirit; (S, K;) and so applied to a man; like falataAnN: (T and TA in art. flt:) and, accord. to As, applied to an ass, smooth, having short hair: (TA:) or sometimes it means having no hair upon him; and so SalotN↓. (Ham p. 536.)
[And accord. to ISd, it seems to be an inf. n., of which the verb is not mentioned; for he says that] it signifies also The act of leaping, springing, or bounding. (M.)
OaSolatiIRu: see SalotN.
UiSoliytN: see SalotN, in two places.
muSolatN: see SalotN.
miSolatN: see SalotN.
miSolaAtN: see SalotN.
miSolaAtu AlEunuqi [app. applied to an ass] Having the neck stretching out, and smooth, or with short, or little, hair upon it. (As, TA.)
munoSalitN: see SalotN, in two places.
Also, applied to anything, Quick, or swift. (M, TA.)
Applied to a river, or rivulet, (tropical:) Vehement in its manner of running. (A, TA.)

1. SalaHa, (S, Mgh, Msb, &c.,) aor.
SaluHa
, (S, MA, Mgh, Msb,) the well-known form, though omitted in the K, (TA,) and
SalaHa
, (MA, K, Msb,) [said by some to be] the more chaste, because agreeable with analogy, (TA,) [but the former is the more common,] inf. n. SuluwHN (S, MA, Mgh, Msb, K * [in the CK AlSRaluwH is erroneously put for AlSRuluwH]) and SalaAHN (S, * MA, Mgh, Msb, K *) and maSolaHapN; (MA;) and SaluHa, aor.
SaluHa
, (S, MA, Mgh, Msb, K,) mentioned by Fr, on the authority of his companions, (S, TA,) but said by IDrd to be not well established, (TA,) inf. n. SalaAHN and SalaAHapN, (MA,) or SalaAHiyapN; (TA;) said of a thing, (S, Mgh, Msb,) and of a man, (TA,) It, and he, was, or became, good, incorrupt, right, just, righteous, virtuous, or honest; it was or became, in a good, incorrupt, sound, right, or proper, state, or in a state of order; he, or it, throve; contr. of fsd [i. e. fasada and fasuda]; (MA; [and S and A and Mgh and K by implication; see SalaAHN below;]) in Pers. nyk Xd; (MA;) [and AstSlH↓ signifies the same, for] SalaAHN and AisotiSolaAHN both signify in Pers. nyk Xdn. (KL.) One says, SalaHato HaAlu fulaAnK [The state, or condition, of such a one became good, right, or proper]. (A, TA.)

[Hence,] hecaA OadiymN yaSoluHu lilnRaEoli (tropical:) [This is leather that is suitable for the sandal]. (A.) And hecaA AlXRaIoCu yaSoluHu laka (tropical:) This thing is suitable to thee; or fit, or meet, for thee. (S, K, * TA.) And fulaAnN laA yaSoluHu liSuHobatika (tropical:) [Such a one is not fit for being thy companion]. (A.)

3. SAlHhu, (A, Msb, K,) inf. n. SalaAHN (S, Msb, K) and muSaAlaHapN, (S, K,) the former of which is made fem. in a verse of Bishr Ibn-Abee-Házim, (TA,) [He made peace, or became at peace or reconciled, with him; or he reconciled himself with him: for] muSaAlaHapN is the contr. of muxaASamapN. (Mgh.) And SAlHhu EalaI kacaA He made peace, or reconciliation, [or a compromise,] with him on the condition of such a thing. (MA.) And SAlHhu EalaI baEoDi maA lahu [He compounded with him for part of what was owed to him; he made a compromise with him on the condition of receiving part of what was due to him]; said of a creditor and debtor. (Mgh in art. DgT.) And SaAlaHotu bayona Alqawomi, inf. n. muSaAlaHapN, I made peace, or a reconciliation, between the people, or party; syn. laMCamotu. (Msb in art. lOm. [See also 4.])

4. ASlHhu, (A, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. UiSolaAHN, (S, A,) and quasi-inf. n. SalaAHN, (L in art. lqH,) said of a man, (A, Msb,) and of God, (TA,) [and of a thing,] He, and it, made, or rendered, it, or him, good, incorrupt, right, just, righteous, virtuous, or honest; constituted it, disposed it, arranged it, or qualified it, well, rightly, or properly; rectified, corrected, redressed, or reformed, it; put it into a good, incorrupt, sound, right, or proper, state; or restored it to such a state; put it to rights, or in a state of order; set it right, set it in order, ordered it, managed it well, cultured it; adjusted, dressed, or trimmed, it; prepared it properly for use; repaired, mended, amended, or improved, it; made it, or him, to thrive; contr. of Oafosadahu. (S, * K. [And so by implication in the Mgh &c.]) One says, OaSolaHotu Alqidora biAltRaAbali [I made good, qualified properly, or seasoned, (the contents of) the cooking-pot with the seeds that are used in cooking]. (Msb in art. tbl.) And OaSolaHotu AlsRiqaMCa biAlrRubRi [I seasoned the skin with rob, or inspissated juice]. (S in art. rb.) And OaSolaHotu bayona Alqawomi [in which AlOamora is understood, so that the meaning is I rectified, or reformed, or amended, the circumstances subsisting between the people, or party; or] I made peace, or I effected a rectification of affairs, an agreement, a harmony, a reconciliation, an accomodation, or an adjustment; [or I adjusted the affair;] between the people, or party. (Msb.) And saEaI fiI UiSolAaHi caAti Albayoni [He laboured in rectifying, or improving, the bad, or the good, state of circumstances, or the disunion or union, subsisting between people]. (A.) One says also, ASlH AldRaAbRapa, (TA,) and ASlH UilaI AldRaAbRapi, (T, A, Mgh, TA,) the latter because ASlH implies the meaning of OaHosana, (Mgh,) (tropical:) He acted well to the beast, (T, A, TA,) and put it into a good, or right, or proper, state, or took care of it, or paid frequent attention to it. (A, TA.) And ASlH Uilayohi (tropical:) He acted well to him, did good to him, or benefited him. (K, TA.) And ASlH [alone] (assumed tropical:) He did that which was good, right, or just. (Msb.)
6. tSAlHA AiSRaAlaHaA &c.: see 8, in four places.
7. AnSlH [quasi-pass. of OaSolaHahu; thus signifying It became rectified, &c.: see taXaERaba]. (K in art. XEb.)

8. ASTlHA (S, A, K) and AStlHA, (K,) and tSAlHA↓ (S, A, K) and AiSRaAlaHaA↓, (S, K,) [the last a var. of tSAlHA,] all signify the same, (TA,) and Alqawomu tSAlH↓, and ASTlHwA, (Mgh,) [They two, (i. e. two persons or two parties,) and] the people, or party, made peace, or became at peace or reconciled, [each with the other, and] one with another: (Msb:) [AiSoTilaAHN is the contr. of AixotiSaAmN and] taSaAluHN↓ is the contr. of taxaASumN. (Mgh.)
And ASTlHwA EalaI OamorK They (a particular class of persons) agreed together, or among themselves, respecting a particular thing. (ElKhafájee, MF.)
[Hence,] AiSoTilaAHN signifies also The agreement of a people to name a thing by any name turned from the primary application. (KT.)

And [as an inf. n. used in the sense of
a pass. part. n., for muSoTalaHN Ealayohi,] Conventional [or technical] language: and a conventional [or technical] term: opposed to [lugapN and] tawoqiyfN. (Mz 1st nwE.)
10. AstSlH is the contr. of Astfsd: (S, L, K:) [i. e. it signifies He regarded, or esteemed, a thing good, incorrupt, right, just, or the like; as expl. in the TK; and in like manner, a man.
He wished, or desired, a thing to be good, incorrupt, right, just, &c.; as in the TK; and in like manner, a man.
And He sought to render good, incorrupt, &c.
And hence, He treated in such a manner as to render well affected, or obedient.]
Also He sought to do good or to act well [UilaI fulaAnK to such a one]. (KL.)
And He sought peace, or concord. (KL.)
And It happened well. (KL.)
See also 1.

SuloHN a subst. from muSaAlaHapN, (S, Msb, KT,) syn. with the latter; (Mgh;) masc. and fem.; (S, K;) Peace, reconciliation, or agreement, (Mgh, Msb, K, KT, TA,) after contention: and in the law it means a compact to give over, or relinquish, contention. (KT.) One says, waqaEa bayonahumaA SuloHN (A, TA) Peace, or reconciliation, took place between them two. (TA.) [And Ouxica SuloHFA It (a fortress or the like) was taken peacefully, or by surrender.]
Also That in respect of which there has been made a peaceful compact: or which has been taken in the way of peace. (Mgh.)

And A party at peace with others. (TA.) You say, humo lanaA SuloHN They are [a party] at peace with us. (A, TA.) And you say also qawomN SuluwHN↓ A people, or party, who are at peace: the latter word in this case being app. an inf. n. used as an epithet. (TA. [See also SaAliHN.])
SaloHN: see SaAliHN.

SalaAHN an inf. n. of SalaHa (MA, Mgh, Msb) and of SaluHa: (MA:) [used as a simple subst, it signifies Goodness, incorruptness, rightness or rectitude, justness, righteousness, virtue, honesty; &c.: see 1:] contr. of fasaAdN; (S, A, Mgh, K;) as also SuluwHN↓: (K, TA: [AlSRaluwH in the CK being a mistake for AlSRuluwH:]) accord. to some, it is not used as an attribute of a prophet nor of an apostle, but only of a person inferior to these: accord. to others, however, this restriction is wrong. (MF.)
Also quasi-inf. n. of 4. (L in art. lqH.)
And [hence,] A thing that is good, and right. (Msb.) See also maSolaHapN.
SalaAHi, like qaTaAmi, is a name of Mekkeh; (S, A, K;) either from AlSRuloHu or from AlSRalaAHu; (TA;) and sometimes it is perfectly decl. [pronounced SalaAHN]. (S, K.)
SuluwHN: see SuloHN, and SalaAHN:
and see also SaAliHN.
SaliyHN: see what next follows.

SaAliHN, (MA, L, Msb, K,) from SalaHa; (MA;) and SaliyHN↓, (IAar, L, K,) from SaluHa; (MA;) and SiloHN↓; (K;) applied to a thing, (Msb,) and to a man, (MA,) Good, incorrupt, right, just, righteous, virtuous, or honest; &c.; [see 1; contr. of faAsidN:] (MA, L, K:) pl. SulaHaMCu [accord. to general analogy of SaliyHN, and app. applied only to rational beings, like SaAliHuwna,] and SuluwHN↓ [q. v.; this being said by some to be a pl. of SaAliHN; and by others, to be originally an inf. n.; like as is said of XuhuwdN]. (L.) One says rajulN SaAliHN fiI nafosihi [A man good, incorrupt, &c., in himself], mino qawomK SulaHaMCa [of a people good, incorrupt, &c.]. (L.) And huwa EalaI HaAlapK SaAliHapK [He is in a good, right, or proper, state or condition]. (TA.)
[Hence,] SaAliHN signifies also (assumed tropical:) Suitable, fit, or meet: so in the saying, huwa SaAliHN lilowilaAyapi (assumed tropical:) [He is fit for the office of prefect, or the like]. (Msb.)

And (tropical:) Much, copious, or frequent: one says maTorapN SaAliHapN (tropical:) A copious rain. (Yaakoob, L, TA.) And hence the saying of IJ, Oubodilati AltRaMCu mina AlwaAwi UibodaAlFA SaAliHFA, meaning (tropical:) [t is substituted for w] frequently. (TA.)

The A in SaAliHN is [often] omitted in writing [though not in pronunciation] when it is used as a proper name [so that the name is written SlH, or more properly SeliHN]. (Durrat el-Ghowwás in De Sacy's Anthol. Gram. Ar. p. 66 of the Arabic text.)

SaAliHapN [a subst. from SaAliHN, made so by the affix p; A good deed or action; an act of beneficence; a benefit]. One says, laA tuEadRu SaAliHaAtuhu [His good deeds, or beneficent actions, are not to be numbered]. (A, TA.) And OatatoniI SaAliHapN mino fulaAnK [A benefit came to me from such a one]. (TA.)
AiSoTilaAHN [for muSoTalaHN Ealayohi: see 8, last sentence].
AiSoTilaAHiIRN Conventional [or technical] language: opposed to [lugawiIRN and] tawoqiyfiIRN. (Mz 1st nwE.)
muSoliHN [act. part. n. of 4, q. v.]. One says, rajulN muSoliHN fiI Oumuwrihi waOaEomaAlihi [A man who does well, rightly, justly, or properly, in his affairs and his actions]. (L.)

maSolaHapN A cause, a means, or an occasion, of good; a thing, an affair, or a business, conducive to good, or that is for good; [and hence it may often be rendered simply an affair, when the context shows it to mean what is conducive to good or done for a good purpose;] contr. of mafosadapN; (S and Msb and K in art. fsd;) a good, right, or virtuous, affair; (KL;) a thing that is good and right; syn. SalaAHN↓ [q. v.]: pl. maSaAliHu. (S, A, Msb, K.) One says, naZara fiI maSAliHi AlnRaAsi [He considered the things that were for the good of the people]. (A, TA.) And humo mino Oaholi AlmafaAsidi laA AlmaSaAliHi [They are of the people who occupy themselves in the things conducive to evil, not the things conducive to good]. (A, TA. *) And fiI AlOamori maSolaHapN In the affair is that which is good: (Msb:) [or a cause of good.] And raOaI AlUimaAmu AlmaSolaHapa fiI kacaA The Imám saw what was good and right [or what was conducive to good] in such a thing. (TA.)
It is also an inf. n. of SalaHa. (MA.)
mutaSalRaHN A place, of a garment [&c.], that is to be repaired, or mended; syn. mutaradRamN. (T in art. rdm.)

1. Salixa samoEuhu, [and app. Salixa alone,] aor.
Salaxa
, (L,) inf. n. SalaxN; (S, A, L;) as also Salija; (IAar, L;) [the former of the dial. of El-Koofeh, and the latter of that of El-Basrah; (see OaSolaxu;)] He was, or became, deaf, so as not to hear at all. (S, A, * L.) SalaxFA kaSalaxi AlnRaEaAmi [Mayest thou, or may he, suffer a deafness like the deafness of the ostrich] is a form of imprecation uttered against a man; for all ostriches are [said to be] totally deaf. (L, TA.)
Salaxato jilodahaA is said of a serpent (HayRape) [meaning It cast off its slough: like salaxato]. (TA.)
And Salaxahu, namely, a camel, is said of the mange, or scab, meaning [It excoriated him; like salaxahu; or] it extended over the whole of his body. (TA.)
6. tSAlx EalayonaA He feigned himself totally deaf to us; (K, * TA;) as also tSAlj, with j. (TA.)
9. ASlxR, inf. n. AiSolixaAxN, He (a man, TA) lay upon his side. (K, TA.)
daAhiyapN SaluwxN A destructive calamity. (K.)
Oasowadu SaAlixN i. q. Oasowadu saAlixN [q. v.], A certain species of serpents, that casts off its slough. (AHát, L.)
And jarabN SaAlixN i. q. saAlixN [i. e. Excoriating mange or scab]: (K, TA:) it is such as occurs in the hinder part of the camel, and one doubts not its extending over the whole of his body. (TA.)

OaSolaxu, (S, K, &c.,) so accord. to all the people of El-Koofeh, but the people of El-Basrah and the Arabs of that region say OaSolaju, (IAar, TA,) Deaf: (Fr, A'Obeyd, TA:) or deaf so as not to hear at all: (S, K, TA:) or very deaf: (Mgh:) or OaSamRu OaSolaxu has this last meaning. (IAar, TA.) Fr said, (S,) kaAna Alkumayotu OaSamRa OaSolaxa, meaning El-Kumeyt was deaf so as not to hear at all. (S, A. *)
Also A camel affected with mange, or scab: [or having mange, or scab, by which he is excoriated: like Oasolaxu:] fem. SaloxaMCu: and pl. SaloxaI. (K.)
And Affected with [the malignant species of leprosy termed] baraS. (TA.)

1. SalaAdapN SuluwdapN, [inf. ns. of which the verb is Saluda,] used in relation to a stone [&c.], signify The being hard and smooth. (M.) [And SalodN has a similar meaning.] You say, Saladati AlOaroDu, and OaSoladat↓, The land was, or became, hard:
(K:) or (tropical:) so that it produced no plants, or herbage: (TA:) and Salada AlmakaAnu, and OaSolada↓, (M, TA,) the place was, or became, hard: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) produced no plants, or herbage. (M.) And Salada Ealayohi Aljabalu, aor.
Salida
, inf. n. SalodN; and Saluda, [aor.
Saluda
,] inf. n. SalaAdapN and SuluwdapN and SuluwdN; The mountain, or rock, baffled him, namely, a welldigger, [by its hardness,] and resisted his efforts. (M.)

[Hence,] Salada AlzRanodu, (M, K, and so in some copies of the S,) aor.
Salida
, inf. n. SalodN; (M;) or Salida, with kesr to the l, aor.
Salada
, inf. n. SuluwdN; (AZ, S;) The znd [or piece of stick, or wood, for producing fire] gave a sound without emitting fire; (S, M, K;) and ASld↓ signifies [the same, or] it emitted no fire. (Ham p. 407.)

And [hence,] Saladato zinaAduhu [lit. “ His pieces of stick, or wood, for producing fire, gave a sound without emitting fire ”] means (tropical:) He was, or became, niggardly, tenacious, penurious, or avaricious: (AA, L, TA:) and Saluda, alone, aor.
Saluda
, (M, A, K,) inf. n. SalaAdapN; (M, A;) and Salada, (M, A,) aor.
Salida
, (M,) or
Saluda
, (A,) inf. n. SalodN, (M,) or SuluwdN; (A;) and SlRd↓, inf. n. taSoliydN; (K;) signify the same: (M, K:) or he was, or became, very niggardly &c. (A.)

And Saladato SalaEatuhu, or SaloEatuhu, (accord. to different copies of the K, in the TA the former,) The bald place on the front of his head shone, or glistened. (K, TA.) Salada is also used in the same sense, in a trad., in relation to milk flowing forth. (TA.)
And one says, jaMCa bimaraqK yaSolidu, and bilabanK yaSolidu, meaning He brought broth, and milk, containing little oily, or greasy, matter, and much water: for yaSolitu. (T in art. Slt.)
Saladato OanoyaAbuhu His canine teeth caused a grating sound to be heard. (K, * TA.)
Salada biyadayohi He clapped with his hands. (M.)

Saladati AldRaAbRapu, aor.
Salida
, (K,) inf. n. SalodN, (TA,) The beast beat the ground with its fore feet in its running. (K.)

Salada, (M,) or Salada fiI Aljabali, (K,) aor.
Salida
, inf. n. SalodN, said of a mountain-goat, (M,) He ascended the mountain. (M, K.)

taSoludu, [or probably taSolidu,] said of a wild cow or wild ox (baqarap waHoXiyRap), in a verse ascribed to a Hudhalee, [but not found by SM in the Deewán of the Hudhalees,] is expl. as meaning She, or he, stands erect. (TA.)
Salada AlsRaAYila (assumed tropical:) He gave nothing to the asker, or beggar. (L.)
2: see the preceding paragraph.
4. ASld: see 1, in three places.
Also (tropical:) He (a man) failed to produce fire with his zanod [or piece of stick, or wood, used for that purpose]. (S, A.)

And ASld zanodahu (tropical:) He made his znd to give a sound without emitting fire. (M, TA.) And (tropical:) He (God) caused his znd to emit no fire. (A.) And saOalahu faOaSolada (assumed tropical:) He asked, or begged, of him, and found him niggardly: thus related on the authority of IAar; but by rule it should be faOaSoladahu. (M.)

SalodN Hard and smooth; (S, M, A, K;) as also SilodN↓ (K) and SaluwdN↓ (M) and SaliydN↓ (A) and OaSoladu↓; (M;) applied to a stone; (S, M, A;) and so the first applied to land or ground (OaroD); (S;) and to a solid hoof, as also SilodimN↓ and SulaAdimN↓, which last is of the measure fuEaAlimN accord. to Kh, but fuEaAlilN accord. to others; (M;) and to a side of the forehead, (S, M,) or thus applied meaning smooth and tough; (L;) and to a head, as also SulaAdimN↓, (M,) or thus applied meaning (tropical:) upon which no hair grows: (A:) and SalawodadN↓, (M, K,) which is of an extr. form, (M,) has the first of the significations above, (K,) or signifies [simply] hard: (M:) the pl. of SalodN (M, L) and of SaluwdN↓ (M) is OaSolaAdN. (M, L.)

Also applied to a place, (makaAnN, M,) and SalodapN applied to land, (OaroDN, A,) (tropical:) That produces no plants, or herbage. (M, A.) And OaSolaAdu Aljabiyni (tropical:) The part of the side of the forehead upon which is no hair: likened to smooth stone. (A Heyth.)

[Hence,] HajarN SalodN and SaluwdN↓ (tropical:) A stone that will not emit fire: (L, TA:) and zanodN SaluwdN↓ (M, A) and SaAlidN↓ and SalRaAdN↓ and miSolaAdN↓ (M) [and muSolidN↓] (tropical:) [A piece of stick, or wood, for producing fire] that gives a sound, (M,) not emitting fire: (M, A:) and EuwdN SalRaAdN↓ (tropical:) Wood, or a stick, from which fire cannot be produced. (T, L, K. *)

And farasN SalodN (K) and SaluwdN↓ (S, M, A, K) (tropical:) A horse that does not sweat: (S, A, K:) such a horse is discommended: (K:) or slow to sweat: or having little seminal fluid: and slow in impregnating. (M.)
And rajulN SalodN (M) and SaluwdN↓ (M, A) and OaSoladu↓ (S, M, A, K) (tropical:) A niggardly, tenacious, penurious, or avaricious, man: (S, M, K:) or a man very niggardly &c. (A.)

And naAqapN SalodapN (tropical:) A hardy, strong, enduring she-camel. (K.) And xayolN SilaAdN (tropical:) Hard, hardy, or strong, horses. (A.) [And SilodaAmN↓, also, signifies Robust, or strong. (Freytag, from Jereer.)]
SilodN: see SalodN, first sentence.
SilodaMCN and SilodaMCapN Rugged and hard ground, (ISk, K,) (assumed tropical:) that produces no plants, or herbage. (ISk.)
SilodimN: see SafodN, first sentence.
SilodaAmN: see SalodN, last sentence.
SaluwdN: see SalodN, in six places.
Also, applied to a well, Such that its mountain, or rock, baffles the digger [by its hardness], and resists his efforts. (M.)

(tropical:) A she-camel having little, or no, milk; as also miSolaAdN↓: (S, A, K:) and the latter, [which in the former case is written in some copies of the K with p,] that has brought forth and has no milk. (K. [But this is said in the TA to be a repetition.])
(assumed tropical:) A woman in whom is little, or no, good: or hard, having no compassion in her heart. (M.)
(tropical:) A cooking-pot (qidorN) slow to boil. (S, M, A, K.)
A beast (daAbRapN) that beats the ground with its fore feet in its running. (TA.)
One who ascends a mountain by reason of fear; (K, TA;) as also miSolaAdN↓: (TA:) [or] a mountain-goat that ascends the mountain. (M.)
And Alone, apart from others, or separate; (As, L, K;) as also SaliydN↓. (K.)
SaliydN: see SalodN, first sentence:
and SaluwdN, last sentence.
Also A shining, gleaming, or glistening. (K.)
SalRaAdN: see SalodN, in two places; and muSolidN.
SulaAdimN: see SalodN, first sentence, in two places.
SalawodadN: see SalodN, first sentence.
SaAlidN: see SalodN.
OanoyaAbN SaAlidapN Canine teeth causing a grating sound to be heard; (K, * TA;) as also SawaAlidu, (K, TA,) which is the pl. (TA.)
OaSoladu: see SalodN, first sentence:
and see the same also near the end of the paragraph.
muSolidN: see SalodN.

[Hence,] one says, layosa bimuSolidi AlqadoHi [lit. He is not one whose wood gives only a sound when one endeavours to produce fire from it; meaning (assumed tropical:) he is not one who ungenerously refuses when asked]; an expression of praise; (TA in art. ksr;) and [in like manner] AlqadoHi layosa biSalRaAdi↓. (TA. in art. hX.)
Also Milk milked into a greasy vessel, and therefore without froth. (K.)
miSolaAdN: see SalodN:
and SaluwdN, in two places.
2. SalRaTahu QllRehu Ealayohi, inf. n. taSoliyTN, a dial. var. of salRaTahu, q. v. (Ibn-' Abbád, K.)

1. SaliEa, aor.
SalaEa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. SalaEN, (S, * O, * Msb, K, * TA,) He (a man, S, O, K *) was, or became, bald in the fore part of the head: (S, * O, * Msb, K: * but in the Msb it is said in this sense of the head:) or in the fore part of the head to the kinder part thereof: and likewise in the middle of the head. (TA.) [See also jaliHa The original text has a dot above the jeem. and jalaHN.] Accord. to Ibn-Seenà, the baldness termed SalaEN does not happen to women, because of the abundance of their moisture; nor to eunuchs, because their constitutions are nearly like those of women. (Msb.)
[Hence,] SaliEati AlEurofuTapu, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) The ErfTp [a species of mimosa] dropped the heads of its branches: and had them eaten by the camels. (TA.)
See also 7.
SalaEa raOosahu [perhaps a mistranscription for SalRaEa↓, and primarily signifying He made his head bald in the fore part:] (tropical:) he shaved his head. (Z, TA.)
SalaEa said of such as is termed EicoyawoT, [but the verb in this sense is probably SalRaEa↓, (see this latter,)] He voided his ordure (OaHodava) on the occasion of jimaAE. (TA.)
2. SlRE: see above, last sentence but one.

SlREt AlHayRapu (tropical:) The serpent came forth from concealment (barazat) without any earth, or dust, upon it. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K, TA. [But in the O, the verb in this and the following senses is carelessly written without the sheddeh.])

SlRE, inf. n. taSoliyEN, (said of a man, IAar, TA,) i. q. OaEocara
[meaning He voided his ordure: see taSoliyEN as a subst., below; and what here follows]. (IAar, K, TA.) And SlRE fulaAnN, (inf. n. as above, TA,) Such a one put his hand evenly expanded (K, TA) on the ground (TA) and voided his ordure or his ordure in a thin state (salaHa): (K, TA:) thus expl. by Lth. (TA.) See also 1, last sentence.
5. tSlREt AlsRamaMCu (assumed tropical:) The sky became bared by the disruption of its clouds. (TA.)
See also what next follows.

7. AnSlEt AlXRamosu (tropical:) The sun rose, or began to rise: syn. bazagat: or culminated: or came forth from the clouds, (O, K, TA,) appearing in the time of intense heat, with nothing intervening and concealing it; (TA;) and so tiSlREt↓, (O, K, TA,) and SalaEat↓ [or more probably SaliEat]. (TA.)
8. ASTlE, accord. to Reiske, as stated by Freytag, signifies He, or it, was defiled, or polluted; “ conspurcatus fuit: ” but he names no authority.]

SalaEN Baldness in the fore part of the head: (S, O, Msb, K:) or in the fore part of the head to the hinder part thereof: and likewise in the middle of the head. (TA. [See SaliEa, of which it is the inf. n.: and see also jalaHN.])
Also a dial. var. of SulRaEN, q. v. (TA.)
One says also, laOuqiymanRa SalaEaka meaning [I will assuredly straighten] thy [natural] crookedness; like DalaEaka. (TA in art. DlE, from the T and M.)
SaloEapN: see what next follows.
SuloEapN: see what next follows.

SalaEapN A place of baldness such as is termed SalaEN; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also SuloEapN↓; (S, O, K;) and SaloEapN↓ is said to be a contraction of the first, (O, Msb,) by Lth, (O,) but it is disallowed by the thoroughly learned. (Msb.)
SalaAEN, (O, K,) accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, with kesr, (O,) like kitaAbN, (K,) in the L [written] with damm, (TA,) The heat of the sun. (O, K.)
SaliyEN: see OaSolaEu.
[Hence,] (tropical:) A mountain having upon it no plants, or herbage. (O, K, TA.)
SulayoEaMCu: see OaSolaEu, in six places.
SulRaEN: see SulRaAEN.

Accord. to As, (S, O, TA,) (tropical:) A place that produces no plants, or herbage; (S, O, K, TA;) whether it be a mountain or land; (TA;) from SalaEN in relation to the head; (S, O, TA;) and SalaEN↓ is also syn. with SulRaEN in the sense expl. above. (TA.) And [the n. un.] SulRaEapN signifies A smooth rock. (TA.)

SulRaAEN, (S, O, K,) or SulRaEN↓, (K,) or the latter also, which is app. a contraction of the former, (S, O,) (assumed tropical:) Broad, (S, O, K, TA,) hard, (K, TA,) smooth, (TA,) rock: (S, O, K, TA:) n. un. (of the former, S, O, [and of the latter also,]) with p. (S, O, K.)
SawolaEN: see the next paragraph.

OaSolaEu, applied to a man, (S, O, Msb,) Bald in the fore part of the head; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) denoting more than OajolaHu: (Mgh:) or bald in the fore part of the head to the hinder part thereof: (TA:) and likewise, (TA,) or accord. to As, (O,) bald in the middle of the head: (O, TA:) and applied also to a head, (Msb, TA,) meaning bald in the fore part: (Msb:) and SaliyEN↓ signifies the same, applied to a head, (Msb, TA,) and to a man: (Msb:) fem. SaloEaMCu; (K;) but some disapprove this, and say that the fem. epithet is zaEoraMCu, and qaroEaMCu: (TA:) the pl. is SuloEN (O, Msb, K) and SuloEaAnN: (O, K:) OuSayoliEu↓ is the dim. of the masc., [and SulayoEaMCu↓ is that of the fem.,] meaning as expl. above. (TA.)

[Hence,] the fem., applied to a tree such as is termed EurofuTap, [a species of mimosa,] (tropical:) That has dropped the heads of its branches: (S, TA:) and that has had its branches eaten by the camels. (TA.)

And, applied to a tract of sand, (ramolapN, S, O, K,) and to a land, (OaroDN, K,) (tropical:) In which are no trees: (S, O, TA:) and (TA) in which is no herbage. (O, K, TA.) It also occurs, alone, as meaning (assumed tropical:) A desert (SaHoraMC) that produces nothing; like the head termed OaSolaE. (TA.) And SulayoEaMCu↓, applied to a land, (assumed tropical:) That produces no plants, or herbage. (TA.)
And the masc., applied to a mountain, (assumed tropical:) Open to view, smooth, and glistening. (TA.)
And, applied to a spear-head, (tropical:) Glistening and smooth: (O, TA:) or polished; (K;) and so SawolaEN↓. (O, K.)
[Hence also,] AlOuSayoliEu↓ signifies (tropical:) The penis. (O, K, TA.) And AlOaSolaEu is said to signify (tropical:) The head of the penis. (TA.)

And AlOuSayoliEu↓, (S, O, K, TA,) or AlOaSolaEu, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) A certain serpent, slender in the neck, (S, O, K, TA,) or, accord. to Az, wide in the neck, round in the head, (TA,) its head being like a hazel-nut: (S, O, K, TA:) thought by Az to be so called as being likened to the penis. (TA.)

OaSolaEu applied to an affair, or event, (OamorN,) means (assumed tropical:) Hard, distressing, or calamitous; (TA;) and so applied to a day; as also OajolaHu: (A and TA in art. jlH:) or, applied to a day, (tropical:) intensely hot. (Ibn-'Abbád, Z, O, TA.)

Also, the fem., [used as a subst.,] (tropical:) Any notorious affair or event; or any such affair that is dubious, of great magnitude or moment, to accomplish which, or to perform which, one finds not the way: (O, K, TA:) and (tropical:) a calamity, or misfortune, (S, O, K, TA,) [or] such as is hard to be borne; [as though it were smooth and slippery;] because there is no escape from it: (TA:) and [in like manner] SulayoEaMCu↓ (O, K, TA) and SaloEaMCu, and sawoCapN SaloEaMCu and SulayoEaMCu↓, (TA,) an evil, abominable, or unseemly, action or saying, such as is apparent, manifest, or unconcealed: (O, K, TA:) or a calamity, or misfortune, hard to be borne: (K, TA:) and hence the saying of 'Áïsheh to Mo'áwiyeh, (O, K, TA,) when she reproached him for his having asserted the relationship to him of Ziyád, and he replied that the witnesses gave testimony, (O, K, * TA, [see Abulfedæ Annales, i. 360,]) maA Xahidati AlXRuhuwdu walekino rakibota AlSRulayoEaMCa↓ [The witnesses did not bear witness (in the CK, erroneously, mA Xahidota AlXuhuwda,) but thou committedst that which was an evil, abominable, or unseemly, action, &c.]. (O, K, TA.)
SulayoEaMCu↓ is also said to signify (assumed tropical:) The act of glorying, or boasting; syn. faxorN. (TA.)
OuSayoliEu, dim. of OaSolaEu: (TA:) see the latter, in three places.
taSoliyEN inf. n. of 2 [q. v.]. (K, TA.)
And a subst., like tamotiynN and tanobiytN, signifying Ordure, or dung; or such as is thin; syn. sulaAHN: (TA:) thus expl. by Lth. (O.)

1. Salagati Albaqarapu, and AlXRaApu, (S, O, K,) aor.
Salaga
, (O,) inf. n. SuluwgN, (S, O,) i. q. salagat, (S, O, K,) i. e. The bovine animal, and the sheep or goat, shed the tooth [next] behind that called the sadiys: (S and K in art. slg;) or bred its [tooth called the] naAb: (K in that art. [in which see more]:) or Salaga said of any cloven-hoofed animal, aor. and inf. n. as above, signifies he entered the sixth year: or, as some say, the fifth: this is the utmost of the ages thereof [that have verbs and epithets to denote them]: (Msb:) SuluwgN (Mgh, Msb) in these animals (Msb) or in sheep or goats and animals of the bovine kind (Mgh) is like buzuwlN in camels. (Mgh, Msb.)
SalagN: see SalagapN.
Also A red [hill or mountain, such as is termed] haDobap [q. v.]. (O, K.)
SalogapN A large ship or boat. (Lth, O, K.)

SalagapN [a n. un. of which SalagN↓ is the coll. gen. n., as is indicated in the O and TA,] applied to a she-camel i. q. rabaAEiyapN [i. e. In her seventh year], and fat: or i. q. sadiysN [i. e. in the eighth year]. (AA, O, K.)

SaAligN part. n. of 1 [q. v.], (S, O, Msb, K,) an epithet applied to the male and the female of all cloven-hoofed animals, (Msb,) or to an animal of the bovine kind and to the sheep or goat, (S, O, K,) I. q. saAligN, (IDrd, O, TA,) which latter is said by Sb to be the original, the S being substituted for the s because of the g: (TA:) or, applied to a sheep or goat (Ibn-Abbád, O, K) and to a bovine animal, (K,) it is like qaAriHN [q. v.] applied to a horse: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) or in the fifth year, (As, IF, O, K,) as applied to a sheep: (As, IF, O:) or in the sixth year, (AZ, O, K,) as applied to a sheep or goat: (AZ, O:) or a sheep or goat advanced in age: (IDrd, O:) [see more in art. slg:] the pl. is SulRagN (IAar, S, O, K) and SawaAligu, (IAar, O, K,) both of which are applied to kibaAX, (K,) [or rather] the former pl. is thus applied by Ru-beh, who by kibaAX in this instance means “ heroes, ” or “ brave men. ” (S, O.)

1. Salifa AlsRaHaAbu, [aor.
Salafa
,] inf. n. SalafN, The
clouds had in them no water: (M:) or Salifati AlsRaHaAbapu the cloud had little water. (A, TA. [It is implied in the TA that this is tropical; but I doubt its being so.]) See also its part. n., SalifN.
Salifa said of a man's Harov [or seed-produce], It did not increase, or multiply, or become plentiful or abundant. (TA.)
SalafN as a quality of TaEaAm [or wheat] signifies Its having little increase (nuzol, S, or nazal, L, or namaMC and barakap, K) and little goodness. (L, TA: said in the latter to be tropical.)

[Hence, app., or from the verb as used in the sense expl. in the next sentence below,] mano yabogi, fiI AldRiyni yaSolafo, (S, M, Meyd, &c.,) a prov., (S, Meyd, O, K,) relating to the holding fast to religion, (S,) or used in urging to the mixing in social intercourse with the holding fast to religion, (O, K,) or, accord. to IAth, a trad., (TA,) i. e., accord. to As, He who exceeds the right bounds in religion (Meyd) will not be in favour with men, or beloved by them; (S, Meyd;) or will have little increase therein: (M:) or he who finds fault with men in respect of religion, (O, K,) and regards it as an excellence [that he possesses] above them, will have little goodness in their estimation, and (O) will not be in favour with them, or beloved by them: (O, K:) or the meaning is, he who seeks worldly good by means of religion, his share of the former will be little: (Meyd:) or he who seeks, in respect of religion, more than he has had revealed to him, his share will be little. (IAth.)

Salifato, (S, M, O,) aor.
Salafa
, (S, O,) inf. n. SalafN, said of a woman, means She was not in favour with, or was not beloved by, (S, M, O, K, *) her husband, (S, O, K,) or him by whom she was supported; (M;) and was hated by him. (S, O.)
SalafN, (O, K,) in a man and in a woman, (O,) signifies also The saying that which one's companion dislikes, or hates. (O, K.)

And, (O, K,) likewise in a man and in a woman, (O,) (assumed tropical:) The commending, or praising, oneself for, or the boasting of, or glorying in, that which one does not possess: (O, K:) or, (K,) as Kh asserts, (S, O,) the overpassing the due limits in AlZRarof [here meaning elegance of mind, manners, address, speech, person, attire, and the like], (S, M, O, K,) and in excellence in knowledge or courage or other qualities, (TA,) and arrogating to oneself more than is due, through pride: (S, O, K:) but some say that this is post-classical: (M, TA:) [see an ex. voce MfapN, in art. Awf; mentioned here in the TA as occurring in a trad.:] one says, of a man, Salifa, (M, MA,) inf. n. SalafN, (M,) meaning (assumed tropical:) He commended, or praised, himself [&c.]; (MA;) and tSlRf↓, (S, MA, O,) meaning the same; (MA;) or this latter means takalRafa AlSRalafa, (K, TA,) i. e. [he affected the overpassing of the due limits in AlZRarof (meaning as expl. above); or he took upon himself as a task] the arrogating to himself more than was due, through pride: (TA:) [you say, tSlRf bimaA layosa Einodahu (assumed tropical:) He commended, or praised, himself for, or he boasted of, or gloried in, that which he did not possess:] the epithet from the former verb is SalifN↓, (AZ, S, M, O, K,) applied to a man, (AZ, S, M, O,) and SalifapN applied to a woman; (M;) and the pl. of SalifN is SalaAfaI (AZ, M, K) and SulafaMCu and Salifuwna: (AZ, O, K:) it is said to be from SalifN applied to a vessel, accord. to IAar as meaning “ that takes little water; ” but rather, as others say, as meaning “ thick and heavy: ” the vulgar misapply it [app. by using it in the sense assigned to it by IAar]. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph.
4. ASlf i. q. qalRa xayoruhu [His good things became few; or his wealth, or his goodness or beneficence, became little]: (IAar, O, K:) and (TA) so tSlRf↓. (M, TA.)
And His soul, or spirit, (ruwHuhu,) became heavy; (IAar, O, K;) and he became oppressed as though by the nightmare. (TK.)
And He became one whose wife was not in favour with him, or not beloved by him. (M.)

ASlfhA He hated her, namely, his wife; (M;) as also SalifahaA↓, (so in a copy of the M,) or SalafahaA, aor.
Salifa
; (so in the L and TA;) the latter mentioned by IAmb: (L,TA:) or ASlfhu he hated him, namely, another man. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
And ASlf nisaMCahu He divorced his wives: and he made their share of his favours to be small. (A, TA.)
And one says to a woman, OaSolafa QllRehu rufogaki, meaning May God make thee [or thy faroj or the like] to be hated by thy husband. (EshSheybánee, S, O, K.)

ASlf Alqawomu, (thus in the O, on the authority of Ibn-'Abbád, [like OaHozana, and its contr. Oasohala, &c.,]) or tSlRf↓, (thus in the K, [but the former is preferable on the ground of analogy, and the latter I think a mistake,]) The people, or party, became in the [kind of tract termed] SalofaMC. (O, K.)
5. tSlRf: see 4, first sentence.
And see 1, latter part.
Also He behaved in a loving, or an affectionate, and a blandishing, or coaxing, manner. (O, K.)
And, said of a camel, He loathed, or turned away with disgust from, the [pasturage termed] xulRap, and inclined to the HamoD. (O, K.)
See also 4, last sentence.

AlSRalofu The branches of the heart of the palmtree that are next belong the qilabap: [in the CK, xawACN fI qulobi AlnRaxolapi is erroneously put for xawaAfiI; qlbi AlnRxlpi; and the same mistake was originally made in my MS. copy of the K:] n. un. with p. (IAar, O, K, * TA. [See xaAfiyapN, last sentence.]

SalifN, applied to clouds (saHaAb, S, M, O, K), Containing no water: (M:) or having little water and much thunder. (S, O, K. [Said in the TA to be tropical; but I doubt its being so.]) It is said in a prov., rubRa SalifK taHota AlrRaAEidapi, (S, and so in some copies of the K,) or rubRa SalafK↓, (M, O, and so in some copies of the K, [with an inf. n. in the place of an epithet,]) i. e. Many a cloud is there, [or many clouds are there, lacking rain, or] having much thunder with little rain, [beneath that which thunders:] (A'Obeyd, O:) applied to the wealthy niggard: (A'Obeyd, O, K:) or to him who threatens, and does not perform what he threatens: (S, O, K:) or to him who commends himself much, (M, O, K,) and is loquacious, (M, O,) but is destitute of good. (M, O, K.)

And A vessel that takes little water: (IAar, S, M, O, K:) a small vessel: one that leaks; that will not hold water. (IAar, TA. [This, also, is said in the TA to be tropical.]) And A heavy (K, TA) and thick (TA) vessel. (K, TA.)
Also High ground (qufR), or a hard plain, that produces no plants or herbage: (TA:) and so the fem., with p, applied to land (OaroD). (M, TA.)
Wheat (TaEaAm) having little increase (qaliylu AlnRazali and AlrRayoEi): (M:) or tasteless: (M, O, K:) and SaliyfN↓ signifies the same, in the former sense or in the latter. (M.)

And [A man] heavy in soul, or spirit; syn. vaqiylu AlrRuwHi. (TA. [See 4, second sentence, which shows that muSolifN has this meaning: but the epithet thus expl. in the TA is there said to be like katifN.])

And SalifapN signifies A woman not in favour with, or not beloved by, (S, M, O, K,) her husband, (S, O, K,) or him by whom she is supported; (M;) and hated by him: (S, O:) pl. SalaAYifu, (S, M, O, K,) which is extr. [in respect of analogy], (M,) and SalifaAtN. (O, K.)
See also 1, near the end.
SalofaMC and SilofaMC, and each with p: see OaSolafu, in five places.

SaliyfN The side (EuroD [in one of my copies of the S EaroD, and in the other copy Eirq,]) of the neck; the two being called SaliyfaAni; (S, O, K;) [i. e.] AlSRaliyfaAni signifies the two sides of the neck (jaAnibaA AlEunuqi): or this signifies what are between the liyt [or part beneath the earring] and the qaSarap [or base of the neck, on the two sides]: (M:) or the two heads of the vertebra that is next to the head, in the two sides of the neck. (AZ, O, * K, * TA.) In this last explanation, in the copies of the K, rOs is put for rOsA. (TA. [And in some copies of the K, XiqRayohimaA is there erroneously put for XiqRayohaA, which, as is said in the TA, refers to the neck.]) Oaxaca biSaliyfihi and biSaliyfatihi↓ mean, accord. to As, He took hold of the back of his neck: (O, TA:) and one says also, Oaxacahu biSaliyfatihi↓ meaning He took him, or it, altogether. (TA. [But I think it not improbable that biSaliyfatihi↓ in these two instances may be a mistranscription for biSaliyfayohi.])

AlSRaliyfaAni signifies also Two staves, or pieces of wood, which are placed across [horizontally] upon the [camel's saddle called] gabiyT, by means of which the maHaAmil [pl. of maHomilN, q. v.,] are bound. (S, O, K.) And (TA) SaliyfaA AlUikaAfi signifies The two [similar] pieces of wood that are bound upon the upper part of the [saddle called] UikaAf. (M, TA.)
See also SalifN, latter half.
SaliyfapN: see SaliyfN, in three places.
SalanofFI and SalanofaMCN A loquacious man. (M, TA.)

OaSolafu Hard, applied to a place; and so [the fem.] SalofaMCu↓ applied to land (OaroD): (S, O:) or both signify hard ground (M, K) containing
stones; (M;) or hard and rugged ground; (As, O;) and the pl. is SalaAfK, (M, O, K, * [in the last, erroneously, SalaAfiI, and in the O, correctly, AlSRalaAfiI, being made determinate,]) thus pluralized in the same manner as SaHoraMC because the quality of a subst. is predominant therein, (M,) and [for the same reason] OaSaAlifu also; (O, K;) [the former pl. of SlfMC, and the latter of ASlf:] or SalofaMC↓ (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K) and SilofaMC↓, [each, app., with tenween, the latter because of the measure fiEolaMC, and each because receiving the affix p, for it is added,] and likewise SalofaMCapN↓ (K) and SilofaMCapN↓, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) rugged, hard ground: (K:) or a smooth rock, or a hard, smooth, bare rock, even with the ground. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
muSolifN A man whose wife is not in favour with him or not beloved by him. (IAar, M, O, K.)

1. Salaqa, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) aor.
Saliqa
, (Msb,) inf. n. SaloqN, (As, * S, * M, * TA,) He called out, cried out, or shouted, vehemently; or made a vehement sound; (As, S, M, O, Msb, K;) as also ASlq↓: (S, M, O, K:) he raised his voice on the occasion of a calamity, and of a death: (TA:) and he wailed; (M, TA;) and so ↓the latter verb: (M:) A'Obeyd mentions it as with s [in the place of S]. (TA.)
Also, (S, O, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) said of the tush of a camel; (S, O, TA;) and so ASlq↓; (S, * M, O; *) It made a sound by its being grated against another. (S, * M, O, * TA.)

And Salaqati Alxayolu, (M, * O, TA,) aor.
Saliqa
, or, accord. to Lth,
Saluqa
, inf. n. as above, (O,) The horsemen dashed amid others (fiyhimo) in making a sudden attack or incursion. (M, * O, TA. *)

Salaqa naAbahu, inf. n. SaloqN, He (a camel) grated his tush against another so as to make them produce a sound: and ASlq↓, said of a stallion [camel], he made his tushes to produce a grating sound: (M, TA:) and binaAbihi ASTlq↓, likewise said of a stallion [camel], he made a grating sound with his tush. (S, Msb, TA.)

Salaqahu biAlEaSaA, (AZ, S, M, O, K,) aor.
Saluqa
, inf. n. SaloqN, (M,) He struck him with the staff, or stick, (AZ, S, M, O, K,) namely, another man, (K,) upon any part of his body. (M.) And SaloqN is also said to signify The striking with stone-cutter's picks, or pickaxes. (O.) See also SulaAqapN.
Salaqatohu AlXRamosu The sun smote him with its heat. (O, K.)

Salaqa baniI fulaAnK (aor.
Saliqa
, TA) He attacked the sons of such a one with an abominable onslaught. (IDrd, O, K.)

Salaqahu bilisaAnihi, aor.
Saluqa
, inf. n. SaloqN, (assumed tropical:) He reviled him; syn. Xatamahu. (M.) Fr says that Salaquwkumo is allowable in the sense of salaquwkumo in the Kur xxxiii. 19: (S * and TA in this art.:) but it is not allowable in the reading [of the Kur]. (TA in art. slq, q. v.)
Salaqa jaAriyatahu He spread his girl, or young woman, (K, TA,) upon her back, (TA,) and compressed her. (K, TA.)
Salaqotu AlXRaMpa I roasted the sheep, or goat, upon its sides. (TA.)
Suliqa bisahomihi He was rendered unfortunate by his arrow [in the game called Almayosir]. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)
4: see 1, former half, in four places.

5. tSlRqt AlmaroOapu The woman, being taken with the pains of parturition, screamed, or cried out vehemently: (S, O, K:) or threw herself upon her sides, one time thus and another time thus. (Lth, O.) And tSlRqt AlnRaAqapu, (Lth, O,) or AldRaAbRapu, (K,) The she-camel, (Lth, O,) or the beast, (K,) rolled over, back for belly, by reason of distress: and in like manner the verb is used of any one suffering pain. (Lth, O, K.) And tSlRq EalaI firaAXihi, occurring in a trad., means He writhed about upon his sides on his bed, (O, TA,) and rolled over. (TA.) And tSlRq AlHuwtu fiI AlmaMCi The fish went and came in the water. (O.)
8: see 1, in the middle of the paragraph.
SaloqN, (As, S, M,) an inf. n., (TA, [see 1, first sentence,]) and SalaqN↓ and SaloqapN↓, (M, TA,) A vehement crying or shouting (As, S, M, TA) or sounding: (As, S:) and a wailing. (M, TA.)

And the first, [thus written in a copy of the JK and in a copy of the M, but perhaps correctly SalaqN↓, q. v.,] A round plain: (JK:) or a depressed, soft, round plain: (M:) pl. OaSaAliqu (JK, M) and SuloqaAnN. (M.)
SalaqN: see SaloqN, first sentence.
Also An even plain; (S, O, K;) like salaqN [q. v.]: (S, O:) pl. OaSolaAqN, and pl. pl. OaSaAlqu, (O, K, TA,) in one copy of the K AaSAlyq. (TA.) See also SaloqN, latter sentence.
SaloqapN: see SaloqN.
Also An onslaught, or a shock in battle. (M, TA.)
SalaqaAtu AlUibili The tushes of camels, that make a sound by their being grated, one against another. (S, * O, * TA.)
SaliyqN Smooth. (O, K.)

SulaAqapN Water that has long preserved a still, or motionless, state, (OaTaAla SiyaAmFA, JK, Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, * in which last SyAmA is omitted,) in the place, (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, O,) or in a place, (K,) i. e. in one place, (TA,) and which the beasts have beaten [with their feet], (AldRawaAbRu SalaqahaA↓, [which, accord. to MF, should be Salaqahu AldRawaAbRu, referring to the word maMC, but accord. to the TA it may refer to SulaAqap,]) wherefore it is [said to be] maSoluwqap↓. (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, TA.) In such water the ablution termed AlwuDuwoC should not be performed. (TK.)

SaliyqapN Flesh-meat (Jm, O, K) thoroughly cooked, (Jm, TA,) or spread to dry, (maXoriIRN, O,) or roasted, (maXowiIRN, K,) and thoroughly cooked: (O, K:) or a piece of roasted flesh-meat: (M:) pl. SalaAYiqu: (Jm, M, O, K:) accord. to AA, salaAYiqu, with s, signifies “ roasted lambs, ” from salaqotu AlXRaApa “ I roasted the sheep or goat. ” (TA. See also saliyqapN.)
And A thin cake of bread: (M, TA:) accord. to some, (O,) [the pl.] SalaAYiqu signifies thin bread: (JK, S, O:) but some say that it is SaraAYiqu, with r, that has this meaning. (TA.)
SalanoqFI [said in the copies of the K to be like EalanodaI, but correctly EalanodFI,] and SalanoqaMCN Loquacious: (O, K:) the n is augmentative. (O.)
SulayoqaMCu A species of bird. (M, TA.)

SalRaAqN, applied to a speaker, an orator, or a preacher, (JK, IDrd, O, K,) is like salRaAqN, (JK,) [i. e.] Eloquent; as also miSolaqN↓ [like misolaqN], (IDrd, O, K) and miSolaAqN↓ [like misolaAqN]. (O, K.)
And DarobN SalRaAqN and miSolaAqN↓ A vehement striking or beating. (M, TA.)
miSolaqN: see the next preceding paragraph.
miSolaAqN: see SalRaAqN, in two places.
maSaAliyqu [a pl. of which the sing., if it have one, is not specified,] Large, or bulky, stones. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.)
And Light, or active, camels. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
maSoluwqN: see its fem., with p, voce SulaAqapN.

1. Salama, aor.
Salima
, [in one of my copies of the S
Saluma
,] inf. n. SalomN, (S, M, Msb, K,) He cut off, (K,) or he cut off so as to extirpate, (S, M, Msb,) a thing, (M, K, *) or an ear, (S, M, Msb, K,) and a nose; (M, K;) as also SlRm↓, (M, K, *) inf. n. taSoliymN; (K;) [but] the latter verb is with teshdeed to denote muchness [of the action], or multiplicity [of the objects]: (TA:) and AiSoTalama↓ [likewise] signifies he cut off so as to extirpate (S, * Msb, * K) a nose. (Msb.)

And Salima, aor.
Salama
, inf. n. SalamN, He had his ear extirpated [by amputation]. (Msb.)
2: see the preceding paragraph.
8: see 1.
[Hence,] AuSoTulima Alqawomu The people, or party, were destroyed [or cut off] (M, TA) utterly. (TA.)
SulomapN i. q. migofarN. (K. [See the latter word, which is variously explained.])
SalamapN [written by Golius and Freytag SalamN] Strong men: (K, TA:) as though pl. of SaAlimN. (TA.)
See also SayolamN.

SilaAmapN (S, K) and SulaAmapN and SalaAmapN, (K,) the last on the authority of IAar, (TA,) [all three written in a copy of the M with teshdeed to the l,] A party, or distinct body, of men: (S, M, K:) pl. SlAmAt, signifying companies, and parties, or distinct bodies: (S:) or, as some say, SulaAmapN, with damm, means a party, or company, equals in age and courage and liberality or bounty. (TA.)
SalRaAmN and SulRaAmN The kernel of the stone of the nabiq [or fruit of the lote-tree]; (M, K;) which is also called OulobuwbN; and is eaten: mentioned by Az. (TA.)

SayolamN A difficult, severe, or distressing, event; (M, K;) such as extirpates: you say OamorN SayolamN: and such is termed SayolamiyRapN↓. (M.) And you say also waqoEapN SayolamapN i. e. [An onslaught] that extirpates. (K.)
And A calamity; (S, M, K;) because it [often] extirpates; and so SalamapN↓. (TA.)
And An abominable severing from friendly, or loving, communion or intercourse. (TA.)
And A sword. (S, K.)
Also i. q. wajobapN: like SayoramN [q. v.]: (M, K:) both mentioned by Yaakoob. (M.)
SayolamiyRapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

OaSolamu A man (S) having his ears (S, Mgh) or ear (Msb) extirpated [by amputation]: (S, Mgh, Msb:) or a slave whose ear has been cut off; as also muSalRamN↓: (M:) or a man who is by nature as though his ears had been cut off; and so muSRlRamu↓ AlOucunayoni: (K:) or this last is applied to a man as meaning whose ears have been extirpated by amputation; and to an ostrich as meaning that is naturally as though his ears had been extirpated; (S;) or [small and short in the ears; i. e.] because of the smallness and shortness of his ears; (M;) and it is said that when it is applied to a man, [or rather when a man is likened to an ostrich thus termed,] it means his being contemptible, or despised. (TA.) OucunN SalomaMCu means An ear that cleaves to its lobe, or lobule. (M.) And AlOaSolamu is an appellation applied to The flea. (K.)
muSalRamN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
Q. 4. AiSolahabRati AlOaXoyaMCu i. q. AimotadRato EalaI jihatihaA [The things extended in their proper direction]. (K. [In the O, AiXotadRato is put in the place of AmtdRt. Compare AisolahabRa.])
SalohabN A tall man; (As, IJ, O, K;) and so salohabN [q. v.]; (IJ, TA;) as also muSolahibRN↓ or muSalohabN↓. (K accord. to different copies.)

And A strong camel; (K;) and so SalahobFI↓, (ElUmawee, S, K,) in which the final letter is [not a sign of the fem. gender but] to render the word quasi-coordinate to the quadriliteral-radical class; (S;) fem. SalohabapN (TA) and SalahobaApN↓: (S, K:) pl. SalaAhibu. (AA, O, TA.)
And A large, or great, house or tent. (Lth, O, K.)
And A hard stone; as also SulaAhibN↓. (AA, TA.)
SalahobFI, and its fem.: see the next preceding paragraph.
SulaAhibN: see the next preceding paragraph.
muSolahibRN or muSalohabN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1. Salawotuhu, (K,) or Salawotu AlZRahora, (M,) I struck, or beat, that part, [of him, or] of the back, which is called SalFA: (M:) or I hit that part (M, K) with a thing, or with an arrow or some other thing: on the authority of Lh, who says that it is of the dial. of Hudheyl: and one says also Salayotuhu; which is extr. [with respect to derivation], unless it be an instance of interchangeableness [of w and I]. (M.)
Saliyato and Salato, said of a mare, or she-camel: see 4.

2. SlRI, (S, M, K,) quasi-inf. n. SalaApN or Salewp, for which one should not say taSoliyapN, (S, K,) or the latter is allowable as agreeable with rule and as occurring in old poetry, (MF, TA,) He prayed, supplicated, or petitioned: (S, M, K:) and [particularly] he performed the divinely-appointed act [of prayer commonly] termed SalaAp or Salewp. (S.) Hence, in the Kur [ix. 104], (TA,) waSalRi Ealayohimo And pray thou for them. (Msb, TA.) SalRaI EalaI fulaAnK means He prayed for such a one, and praised him. (TA.) And hence the verse of ElAashà cited in art. rsm, conj. 8. (S, Mgh, * TA.) It is said in a trad., mano duEiIa UilaI waliymapK faloyujibo waUilRaA faloyuSalRi [i. e. Whoso is invited to a banquet, or a marriage-feast, let him comply, or, if not, let him pray for the inviter]. (M.) And the saying, in a verse of El-Aashà, Ealayoki mivola AlRaciI SalRayoti means Keep thou to the like of thy prayer; i. e. he enjoined her to repeat the prayer for him: or, as some relate it, Ealayoki mivolu AlRaciI SalRayoti, meaning upon thee be the like of that for which thou hast prayed: (M:) these words he addressed to his daughter, on the occasion of her saying, “ O my Lord, ward off from my father diseases and pain. ” (Mgh.) The saying Eabiydu fulaAnK yuSalRuwna [The slaves of such a one perform the divinely-appointed act of prayer] means that they have attained to the age of virility. (Mgh.)

SlRI Ealayohi, said of an angel, means He prayed for, or begged, forgiveness, or pardon, for him: and thus the verb sometimes means when said of other than an angel; as in the trad. of Sowdeh, in which it is said, UicaA mitonaA SalRaI lanaA EuvomaAnu bonu maZoEuwnK [When we die, 'Othmán Ibn-Madh'oon will pray for forgiveness for us]; he having then died. (TA.)

[And, said of a man, He blessed him, meaning he invoked God's blessing upon him; namely, the Prophet; or he said, AallRehumRa SalRi Ealayohi (expl. by what here follows) accord. to the rendering of SalRuwA Ealayohi, i. e. EalaI AlnRabiIRi, by Bd and others in the Kur xxxiii. 56.] One says, SalRayotu EalaI AlnRabiIRi [I blessed the Prophet; &c.]. (S.)

And, said of God, He blessed him, meaning He conferred blessing upon him: and He had mercy on him: and He magnified him, or conferred honour upon him: hence the saying, AallRehumRa SalRi EalaI Mli OabiI OawofaI, meaning O God, bless the family of Aboo-Owfà: or have mercy on &c.: but in the saying [in the Kur xxxiii. 56], UinRa QllReha wamalaAYikatahu yuSalRuwna EalaI AlnRabiIRi, the verb does not import two meanings; for it has there only one meaning, which is “ magnification ” [i. e. these words mean Verily God and his angels magnify the Prophet; or rather I would render them, bless the Prophet, as this rendering implies magnification and also a meaning of the quasi-inf. n. given in the M and K, which is “ eulogy, ” or “ commendation, ” bestowed by God upon his apostle, while it imports God's “ conferring of blessing ” and the angels' “ invoking thereof ”]: (Msb, TA:) [it is said that] AllRehumRa SalRi EalaI muHamRadK means O God, magnify Mohammad in the present world by exalting his renown and manifesting his invitation [to ElIslám] and rendering permanent his law, and in the world to come by accepting his intercession for his people and multiplying his reward: and it is disputed whether or not this form of prayer may be used for any but the Prophet [Mohammad]: El-Khattábee says that it may not, though he himself used it for others. (TA.) [SalRaI QllRehu Ealayohi wasalRama is a phrase commonly used by the Muslims after the mention of their prophet: see art. slm. See also SalaApN below.]

SlRI said of a horse, (S, K,) inf. n. taSoliyapN, (TA,) He followed next after the foremost [in a race, at the goal]. (S, K.) Hence the saying [in a trad. of 'Alee], sabaqa rasuwlu QllRehi waSalRaI Oabuw bakorK wavalRava Eumaru [expl. in art. sbq]. (Mgh.)
And SlRI AlHimaAru Outunahu, (Sgh, K,) inf. n. taSoliyapN, (Sgh, TA,) The [wild] ass drove together his she-asses, and made them to take the way [that he would follow]. (Sgh, K, TA.)

4. OaSolato, (T, S, K, TA,) and Saliyato↓, (Fr, K, TA,) and Salato↓, (Zj, TA,) said of a mare, The parts on the right and left of her tail, (SalawaAhaA, S,) or the part on either side of her tail, (SalaAhaA, K, [see SalFA, below,]) became relaxed, she being near to bringing forth: (S, K:) or, said of a she-camel, her young one fell into the part of her called SalFA, and she was near to bringing forth. (T, TA.)

SalFA The middle of the back of a human being and of any quadruped: (M, K:) and, (K,) or as some say, (M,) [app. in a beast,] the part that slopes down from the hips, or haunches: or the space intervening between the jaAEirap [app. meaning the hinder projection of the haunch or rump of a beast] and the tail: (M, K:) or the part on the right and left of the tail; (S, M, K;) the two together being called [the] SalawaAni, (S, K,) which is similarly expl. by Zj in relation to a she-camel; app. properly meaning the two parts bordering upon the tail-bone: (TA:) or the place in which is set the tail of the horse; dual as above: (Msb:) or the bone upon which are the two buttocks: (Mgh: [there thus expl. in relation to a man:]) or the bone in which is the place of setting of the tail-bone; thus expl. by IDrd: or the SalawaAni are the two bones projecting from the two sides of the rump: or, accord. to some of the lexicologists, two veins (EiroqaAni) in the place of the ridof [i. e. in the rump]: (Ham p. 46:) the pl. is SalawaAtN, (M, K,) an instance of a pl. formed by the addition of A and t from a masc. sing., (M,) and OaSolaMCN. (M, K.)
[Hence,] one says, jiYotu fiI OaSolaAYihimo, meaning I came at their rears. (TA.)

SalaApN, or Salewp, [accord. to El-Hareeree, to be written with A when prefixed to a pronoun, and also in the dual number, (see De Sacy's Anthol. Gram. Arabe, p. 67 of the Arabic text,) but this rule I have not found to be generally observed,
even in the best MSS., nor have I in the similar case of HayewpN, (to which it is also applied,) in the best copies of the Kur-án,] is said to be [originally SalawapN,] of the measure faEalapN, (Mgh, MF, TA,) or, accord. to some, [SalowapN,] of the measure faEolapN: (MF, TA:) it is a quasi-inf. n. of SalRaI [q. v.]: (S, K:) and [used as a simple subst.] it signifies Prayer, supplication, or petition: (S, M, Msb, K:) this is said to be its primary signification: and muSalRFI↓ is said to have the same meaning. (Msb, TA.)

Then applied to signify A certain well-known mode, or manner, [of religious service,] because comprising prayer; (Msb;) [the divinelyappointed act of prayer;] one of the divinelyappointed SalawaAt; (S;) a certain religious service in which are rukuwE [or lowering of the head so that the palms of the hands reach the knees] and sujuwd [or prostration of oneself in a particular manner expl. voce sajada]: (M, * K:) and muSalRFI↓ is said to have the same meaning. (TA.) [The performance of this act is fully described in my work on the Modern Egyptians.] It is said to be, in this sense, a proper term of the law, not indicated by the language of the Arabs [before El-Islám] except as importing prayer, which is its primary signification: what Esh-Shiháb says respecting it necessarily implies its being a proper term of the law known to the Arabs [before ElIslám]: in the Mz it is said to be one of the words of El-Islám: but all of these sayings require consideration. (MF, TA, [Much more, which I omit as being unprofitable, is added on this point in the TA, partly from the Msb; as well as several different opinions respecting the derivation of the word as used in this sense, which are fanciful or absurd.]) The saying of the Prophet, laA Salewpa lijaAri Almasojidi UilRaA fiI Almasojidi means There is no Slwp [or divinely-appointed act of prayer] that is excellent or complete [to the neighbour of the mosque unless in the mosque]. (M.) And his saying, to Usámeh, AlSRalewpu OamaAmaka means The time of the Slwp [or divinely-appointed prayer], or the place thereof, [is before thee,] alluding to that of sunset. (Mgh.) And he used the term AlSRalewpu as meaning suwrapu AlSRalewpi, i. e. The faAtiHap [or Opening Chapter of the Kur-án, because it is a form of prayer, or] because the recital thereof is excellent, or satisfactory. (Mgh.) In the Kur xxii. 41, (I' Ab, S, M, Ksh, Bd,) [the pl.] SalawaAtN means Places of worship of the Jews: (I' Ab, S, M, Ksh, Bd, K:) said to be (Ksh, Bd) originally SaluwtaA, a Hebrew word, (Ksh, Bd, K,) arabicized: (Ksh, Bd:) this is the common reading of the word, and the most valid: other readings are SuluwaAtN and SulawaAtN and SilawaAtN; and beside these, some others which are perverted forms. (TA.)
Also Prayer for forgiveness or pardon. (M, Mgh, K.)
[And A blessing, as meaning an invocation of God's blessing upon any one. See 2.]

And i. q. barakapN [as meaning A blessing, such as is bestowed by God]: (Msb:) and mercy (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) of God (S, M) on his apostle: (M:) and magnification; and this is [said to be] specially denoted by its verb when the Prophet is the object: (Msb:) and God's eulogy, or commendation, bestowed upon his apostle. (M, K.)
AlSRalaApu [from SalFA] also means UitoyaAnu AlmaroOapi fiI duburihaA. (TA in art. Swm.)
muSoliyapN part. n. of OaSolato [q. v.] said of a she-camel [or of a mare]. (T, TA.)

muSalRFI A place of AlSRalaAp [as meaning the performance of the divinely-appointed act of prayer]; (Mgh, Msb, K;) or of any prayer or supplication: (Mgh:) [and particularly] a place of the performance of the divinely-appointed prayer on the occasion of the [festival termed] Eiyd: (MA:) [and also such a place at a burial-ground: the place for this purpose is particularly termed muSalRaI AlOamowaAti: see De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., i. 192.]
And A carpet upon which one performs the divinely-appointed act of prayer. (MA.)
See also SalaApN, former half, in two places.
muSalRK Any one praying [in any manner: and particularly performing the divinely-appointed act of prayer]. (TA.)

And AlmuSalRiaI signifies, as applied to a horse, The one that follows next after the foremost [at the goal] (S, M, Mgh, Msb) in a race: (Mgh, Msb:) because his head is next to the part called SalFA, (Lh, S, M, Msb,) or next to the SalawaAni, (Mgh,) of the foremost. (Lh, S, M, Mgh, Msb.)

1. SalaAhu, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor. yaSoliyhi, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. SaloIN, (S, M, K,) He roasted, broiled, or fried, it, namely, flesh-meat, (S, M, Msb, K,) &c.; (S;) and SalaAhu fiI AlnRaAri and EalaI AlnRaAri signify the same; and also he burned it. (TA.) And (so in the M, but in the K “ or ”) SalaAhu (M, K) fiI AlnRaAri (M) He threw it into the fire to be burned; as also ASlAhu↓; and SlRAhu↓, (M, K,) inf. n. taSoliyapN; (TA;) namely, flesh-meat. (M, K. [But see the next sentence.]) And SalaAhu AlnRaAra and fiI AlnRaAri and EalaI AlnRaAri, (M, K,) inf. n. SaloIN and SuliIRN and SiliIRN; (M;) and AlnRaAra ASlAhu↓, and AlnRaAra SlRAhu↓; He made him to enter into the fire, and to remain, stay, dwell, or abide, therein: (M, K:) and fulaAnN AlnRaAra SulRiIa↓ [Such as one was made to enter into the fire, &c.]: (M:) [or] you say, Salayotu AlrRajula naArFA, meaning I made the man to enter fire and to be burned: and OaSolayotuhu↓, with A, when you mean I threw him, or cast him, into the fire, as though intending burning [him]; as also SalRayotuhu↓, inf. n. taSoliyapN. (S.)

And Salayotu fulaAnFA, (T, TA,) or lifulaAnK, (S, TA,) (tropical:) I laboured in a case, or an affair, desiring to calumniate, or slander, such a one therein, and to cause him to fall into destruction: (T, S, TA:) or Salayotuhu and Salayotu lahu both signify I calumniated, or slandered, him, and caused him to fall into destruction, (M, TA,) in consequence thereof: (M:) or, accord. to the K, SalaI fulaAnFA, of which the inf. n. is SaloIN, signifies he soothed, coaxed, wheedled, or cajoled, such a one: or deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him: which meanings are not in any of the three lexicons above mentioned: accord. to the A, Salayotu bifulaAnK [probably a mistranscription for lifulaAnK] means (tropical:) I framed a stratagem, or plot, to cause such a one to fall; there said to be tropical. (TA.)
SalaI yadahu biAlnRaAri [said in the TA to be a mistake]: see 2.

SaliIa AlnRaAra, (S, M, Msb, K,) and biAlnRaAri, (M, Msb, K,) aor. yaSolaI, (S, Msb, * K, *) inf. n. SalFI, (Msb,) or SuliIRN, (S, K, [SaloyFA in the CK being a mistranscription for SuliyRFA,]) or both, (M,) and SiliIRN and SilaMCN, (M, K,) and accord. to the K SalaMCN, but this is a mistake for SalFI, (TA,) He was, or became, burned [by the fire]: (S:) or he endured, or suffered, the heat of the fire; as also AlnRaAra tSlRI↓: (M, K:) or he felt the heat of the fire: (Msb:) and one says tSlRI↓ HarRa AlnRaAri and ASTlAhu↓ [in this last sense or in the sense next preceding]: (Ham p. 792:) and SaliIa AlnRaAra he entered into the fire: (TA in art. blh: see an ex. voce baloha:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib, SaliIa biAlnRaAri means he was tried (buliIa) by fire, or by the fire; and so bikacaA (assumed tropical:) [by such a thing, as though by fire]. (TA.) [In the Kur, in which are many exs. of it, (iv. 11, xiv. 34, xvii. 19, &c.,) it is always trans. by itself, without bi.] And SaliIa biAlOamori, (S, M, *) and biAlHarobi; (S;) and AlOamora tSlRI↓, and AlHaroba; (M;) He endured, or suffered, the heat, and severity, or vehemence, of the affair, or case, and of the war, or fight: (S, M:) Aboo-Zubeyd says,
[And I have suffered the heat and vehemence of their war, like as he who is affected with cold suffers in consequence of coldest and most abundant hoar-frost]. (M.)

[It is said that] SaliIa AlrRajulu signifies also lazima [i. e. The man kept to, or clave to, a thing]; and so ASTlI↓: whence Zj holds SalaApN [expl. in art. Slw] to be derived; because it is a keeping, or cleaving, to that which God has appointed: and hence also, [it is said,] fiI AlnRaAri mano yuSalRaI↓, i. e. ylzm [app. yulozamu, meaning mano yulozamu AlnRaAra He who is made to keep, or cleave, to the fire; nearly agreeing with SalRaAhu AlnRaAra as expl. above from the M and K]. (TA.)
