And Salayotu AlZRahora means I struck, or beat, that part of the back which is called SalFA: or I hit that part: but this is extr.; for by rule it should be Salawotuhu, like as Hudheyl say. (M. [See 1 in art. Slw.])
2: see 1, second sentence; and third sentence in three places; and last sentence but one.

One says also, SlRI yadahu biAlnRaAri, (M, TA,) accord. to the K SalaI↓, [without teshdeed,] but this is wrong, as is shown by a verse cited in the M, (TA,) He warmed his hand with the fire. (M, K, TA.) [And it is said in the TA that SlA Zahorahu bAlnhr means OadofaOahu: but I think that the right reading is SlRI Zahorahu biAlnRamirapi, i. e. He warmed his
back with the woollen garment called namirap.]

And SalRayotu AlEaSaA biAlnRaAri I made the staff supple, and straightened it, by means of fire: (S:) or SlRI AlEaSaA EalaI AlnRaAri, (M, K,) inf. n. taSoliyapN; (K;) and tSlRAhA↓; he parched and darkened the staff upon the fire; syn. lawRaHahaA: (M, K:) or SlRI AlEaSaA he straightened the staff by turning it round over the fire: (T in art. dwm: see an ex. in a verse cited in that art., conj. 10:) and SalRayotu AlqanaApa I straightened the spear-shaft by means of fire: (A, TA:) and SalRayotu AlEuwda biAlnRaAri I rendered supple the stick, or branch, by means of fire. (Msb.)
4: see 1, second sentence; and third sentence in two places.
5: see the next paragraph, in two places:
see also 1, latter half, in five places:
and see 2, last sentence.

8. ASTlI He warmed himself (M, K) biAlnRaAri [by means of the fire]: (M:) one says, AiSoTalayotu biAlnRaAri and bihaA taSalRayotu↓ [app. meaning I warmed myself by means of the fire]: (S:) or ASTlI AlnRaAra and biAlnRaAri mean he became warm by means of the fire: and biAlnRaAri tSlRI↓, he became burnt by the fire. (MA.) Hence, in the Kur [xxvii. 7 and xxviii. 29], laEalRakumo taSoTaluwna [May-be ye will warm yourselves]: (TA:) in relation to which it is said that the time was winter, and therefore AlAiSoTilaMC was needed. (M, TA.)
It is also said of the chameleon, as meaning He repaired to the sun. (M and L in art. Xqc: see an ex. in a verse cited voce XaqacaAnN.)

And one says of a courageous man, with whom one cannot cope, laA yuSoTalaI binaArihi [lit. One cannot warm himself by means of his fire; meaning (assumed tropical:) one cannot approach him when he is inflamed with rage, especially in fight, or battle]. (S.) The phrase may be also used satirically, as meaning (assumed tropical:) One will not seek his hospitality. (Meyd. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 588.])
See also 1, latter half, in two places.
SalFI: see SalaMCN.
SalaMCN: see SalaAyapN.
SilaMCN Roasted, broiled, or fried, flesh-meat. (S, M, K.)

And, as also SalFI↓, (S, M, K,) the former with kesr and the latter with fet-h, (S,) Fuel; (S, * M, K;) syn. waquwdN; (M, K, TA; [in the CK, erroneously, wuquwd;]) i. e. maA tuwqadu bihi AlnRaAru; (TA;) you say SilaMCu AlnRaAri and SalaI AlnRaAri: (S:) or both signify fire: (M, Mgh, K:) or SilaMCN signifies the heat of fire. (Msb.) One says, huwa OaHosanu mina AlSRilaMCi fiI AlXRitaMCi [It, or he, is better than fire in winter]. (TA.)
SaliIRN: see maSoliIRN.
SalaMCapN: see what next follows.

SalaAyapN and SalaMCapN↓, (S, M, Mgh, K,) the latter with C because SalaMCN↓ is used as the pl., [or rather coll. gen. n.,] but not by those who say SalaAyapN, (Sb, M,) [for] the pl. [of this] is SuliIRN and SiliIRN (K) and SalaAyaAtN, (MA,) i. q. fihorN [i. e. A stone such as fills the hand; or of the size of that with which one bruises and breaks walnuts and the like]: (S:) or a thing with which perfume is bruised, brayed, or pounded: (M, K:) or a stone upon which one bruises, or powders, (MA, Mgh,) perfume or some other thing; (Mgh;) that with which [not upon which] one does so being called midowakN. (MA.) Imra-el-Keys [in a verse of his Mo'allakah, (see EM p. 45,) as some relate it,] uses the phrase SalaAyapu HanoZali, because colocynths, when they have become dry, are split therewith. (S. [But there are two other readings, SaraAyap and SaraAbap.])
Also, (K,) as being likened thereto, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The forehead. (K.)
And the former word, A rough, rugged, sariyHap [or long strip] of [high ground such as is termed] qufR. (ISh, Az, TA.)
SilRiyaAnN: see art. Sl.

[SaAlK is expl. by Freytag as meaning Heated or warmed (“ calefactus ”), and burnt: and the pl. is said by him to be SuliIRN: but he names no authority: if this be correct, it must be a possessive epithet from SaliIa.]
SaAliyapN A support for the cooking-pot, such as is termed OuvofiyRapN. (MA.)

maSoliIRN Roasted, broiled, or fried; as also SaliIRN↓. (Ham pp. 13-14. [Both of these words are there without any syll. signs.]) It is said in a trad., OutiIa biXaApK maSoliyRapK i. e. A roasted sheep, or goat, was brought. (S, TA.)
And SayoHaAniyRapN maSoliyRapN means [A date of the sort called SayoHaAniIR] dried in the sun. (A, TA.)
OaroDN maSolaApN A land abounding with the plant called SilRiyaAn. (K.)

miSolaApN A snare that is set up for birds &c.: (S, M: *) pl. maSaAlK. (S, M.) It is said in a trad., UinRa lilXRayoTaAni fuxuwxFA wamaSaAliIa (S) or maSaAliIa wafuxuwxFA i. e. [Verily to the Devil belong snares and traps] with which he catches men. (M.)

muSoTalFI The limbs of a man, or his arms and legs and face and every prominent part, which become cold at the time of death, and which are warmed at the fire: (AHeyth, L in art. brd:) or the face and extremities. (Z, TA.) One says, barada Almawotu EalaI muSoTalaAhu. (AHeyth, L in art. brd: see 1 in that art.)

1. SRmRa, (S, M, Msb, K,) and Samima, which is extr., (M, K,) [first pers. of each Samimotu,] aor. yaSamRu, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. SamamN (S, * M, Msb, K) and SamRN; (M, K;) and OaSamRa↓; (S, M, Msb, K;) He was, or became, deaf; (M, * Msb, K; *) [or] he had a stoppage of the ear, and a heaviness of hearing. (M, K.) And SamRati AlOucunu, aor. as above, inf. n. SamamN, The ear was, or became, deaf. (Msb.)

[And He was, or became, as though he heard not.] One says, SamRa Eanohu (assumed tropical:) [He was as though he heard not him, or it; he was deaf to him, or it]; (M;) and Eanohu OaSamRa↓ [meaning the same]. (S, M.)

[Hence SamRa signifies also (assumed tropical:) He or it, uttered, or made, no sound or noise; like him who, not hearing, returns no reply to a call or question; (assumed tropical:) was dumb, or mute.] One says, SamRato HaSaApN bidamK (tropical:) [A pebble made no sound in falling upon the ground by reason of blood]; i. e. the blood was so copious that if one threw a pebble into it no sound would be heard in consequence thereof, (As, S, M, Meyd, K, TA,) because it would not fall upon the ground: (As, S, Meyd:) the saying is a prov. (Meyd.) And hence the saying of Imra-el-Keys, SmRiI Qbonapa Aljabali, (S, K,) in the following verse:

(assumed tropical:) [I have been given in exchange, for Wáïl and Kindeh,' Adwán and Fahm: make no sound, O pebble: app. meaning that he would shed much blood]: (S, TA: but this verse is omitted in one of my two copies of the S:) or the meaning is, O echo; (S, M, Meyd, K;) so they assert: (AHeyth, TA:) or O calamity; the saying being a prov.; (Meyd, TA;) applied to the case of a severe calamity; as though meaning be dumb, O calamity; said by As to be applied in relation to an event deemed excessively foul or evil: (TA:) or O serpent; (Meyd, TA;) which is said to be the primary meaning: (Meyd:) or O rock. (A Heyth, K, TA. [See also the second of the sentences here following.]) One says also, SamRa SadaAhu (tropical:) [His echo became dumb, or may his echo become dumb;] meaning he perished, or may he perish. (S, K, TA.) And SamRiI SamaAmi↓ [in the CK erroneously written SumRiI] meaning (tropical:) Increase, O calamity: (S, K, TA:) or it is applied to a man who brings to pass a calamity, and means be dumb, O calamity: (TA:) or SamaAmi means calamity, and war; but primarily, the serpent; and this saying, like SamRiI Qbonapa Aljabali, is a prov. said when two parties refuse to make peace, and persist in opposition; meaning answer not the charmer, O serpent, but continue as thou art wont to be. (Meyd.)

SamamN in relation to stones, (Lth, TA,) or stone, (M,) [app. as an inf. n.,] signifies The being hard [and solid (see OaSamRu)]; or [as a simple subst.] hardness [and solidity]: (Lth, M, TA:) and in relation to a spear-shaft, the being compact; or compactness. (M.) One says, SamRa AlHajaru, inf. n. SamamN, The stone was hard [and solid]. (MA.) And SamRati Alfitonapu, meaning [The trial, or civil war, &c.,] was, or became, hard, vehement, or severe. (Msb.)

SamRa AlqaAruwrapa, (S, K,) or SamRN raOosa AlqaAruwrapi, (M,) aor.
Samuma
, (PS, [in a copy of the M
Samima
, contr. to a general rule in the case of a trans. verb of this class, and app. a mistranscription,]) inf. n. SamRN, (M,) He stopped the flask or bottle [app. with a SamaAm]: (S, K:)
or he stopped the head of the flask or bottle, and bound it; as also ASmRhu↓: (K:) or ASmR AlqaAruwrapa signifies he put a SimaAm to the flask or bottle. (S, K.)

And SamRa AljuroHa, aor.
Samuma
, inf. n. SamRN, He bound the wound, and put upon it a bandage with medicament. (M.)

And SamRahu, (S, M, K) inf. n. SamRN, (M,) He struck him, (S, K,) or it, i. e. his head, (M,) with a staff, or stick, (S, M,) and with a stone, (S, M, K,) and with the like thereof. (M.) And SumRa, with damm, He was struck vehemently. (IAar, TA.)

2. SmRm, said of a sword, (S, M, K, TA,) accord. to the K, signifies It struck the joint, and cut, or severed, it: or i. q. TabRaqa: but this is at variance with what is said by J and other leading authorities; which is as follows: (TA:) it penetrated into the bone, and cut, or severed, it; but when it strikes the joint, and cuts, or severs, it, one says TabRaqa; a poet says, describing a sword,

[It penetrates into the bone, &c., sometimes, and at one time it strikes the joint, &c.]: (S, TA:) or it passed into the bones: (M:) and SamoSama↓, said of a sword, signifies the same: (M, TA:) or taSomiymN signifies a sword's penetrating into that which is struck with it without its causing any sound to be heard; from AlSRamamu in the ear. (Ham p. 326.)

And hence taSomiymN signifies also (tropical:) A man's keeping constantly, or perseveringly, to the thing that he purposes, until he attains [it]. (Ham ubi suprà.) One says, SamRama EalaI kacaA (assumed tropical:) He kept constantly, or perseveringly, to his opinion in respect of such a thing, after his desiring to do it. (IDrd, TA.)

And SmRm, (S, Msb, K, TA,) inf. n. taSomiymN, (M, K,) (tropical:) He acted, or went on, with penetrative energy, or with sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness, (S, M, Msb, K, TA,) in an affair, (M, Msb, K, TA,) and in journeying, (S, K, TA,) in this case said of a horse, (Z, TA,) and in other things; (S;) as also SamoSama↓. (K.)
And (tropical:) He bit, and infixed his canine teeth, (S, K, TA,) and did not let go what he bit: (S, TA:) or SmRm fiI EaDRatihi he infixed his teeth [or canine teeth] in his bite. (A, TA.)
And SmRm Alfarasa AlEalafa (tropical:) He (a man) enabled the horse to take of the fodder to such a degree that fat and repletion stuffed him. (K, * TA.)
And SmRm SaAHibahu AlHadiyva (tropical:) He made his companion to retain the narrative, or story, in his memory. (K, * TA.)
See also the next paragraph.
4. ASmR, intrans.: see 1, first and fourth sentences.
ASmRhu He, (God, S, Msb, K,) or it, (a disease, M,) rendered him deaf; (S, * M, * Msb, K; *) [or] caused him to have a stoppage of the ear, and a heaviness of hearing. (M, K.)
[Hence,] OaSamRaniI AlkalaAma (assumed tropical:) He, or it, diverted me from hearing the speech; as though he, or it, rendered me deaf. (TA.)
[Hence, ASmRhu signifies also (assumed tropical:) He, or it, caused him to be as though he heard not.

And hence, (assumed tropical:) He, or it, caused him, or it, to utter, or make, no sound or noise; like him who, not hearing, returns no reply to a call, or question; to be dumb, or mute.] One says, OaSamRa QllRehu SadaAhu (tropical:) [May God make his echo to return no sound;] meaning may God destroy him: (TA:) a prov., said in imprecating death upon a man; the Sdy being that which returns the like of his voice, or cry, from the mountains &c.; and when a man dies, the Sdy hears not from him anything that it should answer him, so that it is as though it were deaf. (Meyd.) [In the vulgar language, SamRama↓ likewise signifies (assumed tropical:) He silenced him, reduced him to silence, or closed his mouth: so says De Sacy, in his Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., iii. 379.]

And ASmRhu [in the CK AaSomamahu] also signifies He found him to be OaSamR [i. e. deaf]. (S, M, K.) One says, naAdaAhu faOaSamRahu [He called him, or called to him, and found him to be deaf]. (TA.) And OaSamRa duEaAWuhu His call found persons deaf to it, (Th, M, K,) who would not hear his censure. (K.)
See also 1, near the end.

6. tSAmR He feigned himself to be OaSamR [i. e. deaf]. (S.) [It is intrans. and trans.] You say, tSAmR Eanohu and tSAmRhu He feigned to him that he was deaf. (M.) And tSAmR Eani AlHadiyvi (M, K) and tSAmRhu (M) He feigned (M, K) to his companion (M) that he was deaf to the narrative, or story. (M, K. *) taSaAmamotuhu means taSaAmamotu minohu [or Eanohu], i. e. I made a show of being deaf [to it], and feigned myself inattentive [to it]. (Ham p. 169.)
R. Q. 1. SamoSama: see 2, in two places.
SamoSamati AlSRimRapu, (TK,) inf. n. SamoSamapN, (K, TK,) The female hedge-hog uttered its cry. (K, * TK.)

AlSRimRu a name for (assumed tropical:) Calamity, or misfortune; (S, TA;) as also AlSRimRapu↓, (TA,) and so SamaAmi↓, like qaTaAmi, in a phrase mentioned in the first paragraph, q. v. (S, K. [See also this last word below.])

And (assumed tropical:) The lion; (S, M, K;) as also AlSRimRapu↓, (M, Msb, K,) thus called because of his courage, [i. e. from the latter word as signifying “ courageous, ” but accord. to the Msb the reverse is the case,] (M,) and so AlSRumaSimu↓ and AlSRumaASimu↓: (K:) the pl. of SimRapN↓ is SimamN. (TA.)
SimRapN Courageous; (S, M, Msb, K;) applied to a man; (S, M;) one who renders deaf him whom he smites. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
See also the next preceding paragraph, in three places.
Also A male serpent: (S, K:) pl. SimamN. (S.)
And A female hedge-hog. (K.)
See also SamaAmN.
SamamN inf. n. of the intrans. verb SamRa [q. v.]. (S, * M, Msb, K.)
See also SimoSimN, in four places.
SamaAmi [an imperative verbal noun, like nazaAli &c.]. One says, SamaAmi SamaAmi, meaning Feign ye deafness, in silence. (S, K.) Also meaning Charge ye upon the enemy. (AHeyth, TA.)

Also (tropical:) Hard, or severe, calamity or misfortune; and so AlSRamRaMCu↓; (K, TA;) [as though] closed up [or obdurate, or deaf to deprecation]: (TA:) or AlSRamRaMCu signifies [simply] calamity, or misfortune: (S:) and daAhiyapN SamRaMCu↓ signifies a calamity, or misfortune, [as though] closed up, and hard. (M.) See also AlSRimRu, above.

SimaAmN The sidaAd [or stopper], (S, M, K,) [i. e.] the thing that is put into the mouth, (Msb,) of a flask, or bottle: (S, M, Msb, K:) and its XidaAd [app. meaning the piece of skin that is tied over the head]: (M:) or accord. to some it signifies the EifaAS [which has the latter meaning]: (Msb:) or it signifies the thing that is put into the head of the flask, or bottle; and EifaAS signifies the “ thing [or piece of skin] that is tied upon it: ” (M:) and SimaAmapN↓ signifies the same as SimaAmN, (IAar, K,) as also SimRapN↓. (K.)

Also The faroj; perhaps for mawoDiEu SimaAmK: (Mgh, TA:) so in a trad., in which it is said that AlwaToCu should be in one SimaAm: but, as some relate it, the word is there with s [i. e. simaAm]. (TA.)

SamiymN The bone that is the [main] stay, or support, of the limb or member or the like; (M, K, and Ham p. 302;) as the Smym [or principal bone] of the shank (M and Ham) of a beast, (M,) and that of the head; (M and Ham;) opposed to waXiyZN, because the latter is smaller than the former: (M:) and the thing that is the [main] stay, or support, of another thing. (Ham p. 359.)
[Hence,] The heart: so in a saying of a poet cited voce dalafa. (Ham p. 678.)

And hence, also, (TA,) (tropical:) The prime, principal, or most essential, part; (M, K, TA;) the choice, best, or most excellent, part; of a thing (S, M, Msb, K, TA) of any kind. (M.) One says, huwa fiI Samiymi qawomihi (tropical:) [He is of the choice, best, or most excellent, of his people or party; of the main stock thereof; or of those that constitute the members, exclusive of such as are followers, or incorporated confederates, thereof]: (S, TA:) contr. of XaZFI (S in art. XZI) [and of XiqRN, q. v.].

And (tropical:) The greatest intenseness or vehemence or violence, or the most intense or vehement or violent degree, of heat, and of cold: (S, K, TA:) or simply the intenseness or vehemence or violence thereof. (M.)
And (assumed tropical:) The middle [or core] of the heart. (Msb.)
And The shell (lit. the dry, or hard, exterior covering) of the egg. (K.)

Also an epithet, applied to a man, (M, K,) and to a woman, and to two persons (M,) and to a pl. number, (M, K,) (tropical:) Pure, unmixed, or genuine, in respect of race, lineage, or parentage. (M, K, TA.)
SimaAmapN: see SimaAmN.

SamRaAnN Hard ground, (M,) [i. e.] any such ground, (K,) containing stones, by the side of sands; as also SamRaAnapN↓: (M, K:) or the latter is a n. un.; and the former signifies hard ground: (Ham p. 285:) or rugged ground, (S, M,) falling short of what is called jabalN: (M:) it is so called because of its hardness. (TA.)
SamRaAnapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

SamoSamN Very niggardly or tenacious: (K:) or niggardly, or tenacious, in the utmost degree.
(IAar, TA.)
See also the next paragraph.
[And see DamoDamN.]

SimoSimN, (S, M, K,) applied to a man, (S, M,) Thick: (A'Obeyd, S:) or short and thick: (M, K:) or it signifies, (S,) or signifies also, (K,) bold, or daring; that acts, or proceeds, with penetrative energy, or with sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness: (S, K:) and applied to a man and to a horse, (M, K,) and to a mare, (M,) [in like manner,] i. q. muSamRimN↓ [and muSamRimapN (in the CK muSamRamN is erroneously put for muSamRimN) i. e. that acts, or proceeds, with penetrative energy, or with sharpness, vigourousness, and effectiveness], (M, K,) as also SamamN↓, (K, TA,) or SamoSamN↓, (so in a copy of the M,) and SamoSaAmN↓, and SamoSaAmapN↓, and SumaSimN↓, and SumaASimN↓, (M, K, the last omitted in the TA,) and SumaASimapN↓: (K:) or strong, robust, or hardy: or compact in make: (M, in relation to all of these epithets:) or SamamN↓, applied to a man, has the former of these two meanings: or the latter of them; as also SimoSimN, and SumaSimN↓: and, accord. to AO, SamamN↓ applied to a horse, and SamamapN↓ to a mare, signify strong, firm, compact in make. (TA.)
See also SimoSimapN.
SumaSimN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places:
and see also AlSRimRu.
SamoSamapN inf. n. of R. Q. 1 [q. v.]
See also the paragraph here following.

SimoSimapN A company, or collection, (M, K,) of men; like zimozimapN; neither of which words is formed by substitution from the other: (M, TA: [in the TA in art. zm, this is said of zimozimapN and DimoDimapN:]) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] SimoSimN↓. (M, K.)
Also The middle of a people or party; and so SamoSamapN↓. (K.)
And A rugged [hill such as is termed] Oakamap, of which the stones are almost erect. (En-Nadr, TA.)

SamoSaAmN, (S, K,) or sayofN SamoSaAmN, (M,) and SamoSaAmapN↓, (S, M, K, [in the CK, erroneously, SimoSaAmap,]) A sword, (K,) or a sharp sword, (S, M,) that will not bend. (S, M, K.) AlSRamoSaAmu, (S, K,) or AlSRamoSaAmapu↓, (M,) was the name of The sword of 'Amr Ibn-Maadee-Kerib. (S, M, K.) And some of the Arabs make SamoSaAmapu↓, thus without tenween, imperfectly decl., to be the name of A particular sword. (IB, TA.)
See also SimoSimN.
SamoSaAmapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places:
and see also SimoSimN.
SumaASimN: see SimoSimN:
and see also AlSRimRu.
SumaASimapN: see SimoSimN.

OaSamRu applied to any animal, (Mgh,) Deaf; (S, * M, * Mgh, Msb, K; *) [or] having a stoppage of the ear, and a heaviness of hearing; (M, K:) fem. SamRaMCu: (Mgh, Msb:) pl. SumRN (M, Msb, K) and SumRaAnN. (M, K.) A poet says,

(TA,) a prov., (Meyd,) meaning Feigning himself deaf to that which displeases him, (Meyd, TA,) i. e. to what is foul, (Meyd,) as though he heard it not, (TA,) but hearing (Meyd, TA) that which pleases him, i. e. what is good; as does the generous man. (Meyd.) And similar is the saying,

[And I have an ear deaf to that which is foul]. (TA.) [See also Ham p. 636, for another similar ex.] One says likewise, daEaAhu daEowapa AlOaSamRi (assumed tropical:) He called him [with the call of the deaf, meaning,] with extraordinary force. (TA.) And Darabahu Daroba AlOaSamRi (tropical:) He beat him [with the beating of the deaf, meaning,] uninterruptedly and excessively; because the deaf, when he does thus, [not hearing any cry,] imagines that he is falling short of what he should do, and therefore will not leave off. (TA.) And lamaEa bivawobihi lamoEa AlOaSamRi (assumed tropical:) He (one warning a people from afar) made a sign by waving his garment continually, as does the deaf; as though he heard not the reply. (TA.) And HayRapN OaSamRu (M, K, TA) and SamRaMCu (TA) (tropical:) A serpent that will not accept charming; (M, K, TA;) as though it heard it not; (M;) that will not obey the charmer: (TA:) and [in like manner] the epithet SumRN is applied to scorpions. (M.) And rajulN OaSamRu (tropical:) A man whom one does not hope to win over, and who will not be turned back from the object of his desire; (M, K, TA;) as though he were called and would not hear. (M, TA.) And dahorN OaSamRu (assumed tropical:) [Inexorable fortune;] as though one complained to it and it would not hear. (M.) And AlSRamRaMCu and daAhiyapN SamRaMCu as expl. voce SamaAmi, q. v. And fitonapN SamRaMCu (assumed tropical:) A sedition, or the like, that is severe, or hard to be borne; (S, Msb;) to the allaying of which there is no way; because of its having gone to the utmost extent. (TA. [See also Oabokamu.]) And OamorN OaSamRu (assumed tropical:) An affair, or event, that is severe, or hard to be borne. (TA.) And SamamN is tropically attributed to AlHilom: (M:) a poet, cited by Th, says,

L.foreign: qulo maA badaA laka mino zuwrK wamino kacibK

sense.s: (tropical:) [the last word I find written thus, app. for the sake of the rhyme: i. e. Say what occurs to thee, of falsehood and of lying: my forbearance is deaf, i. e. insensible, to it, though my ear is not deaf]. (M, TA.) SamRaMCu is applied to a qaTaAp [or bird of the species termed qaTFA, and may in this case be rendered (assumed tropical:) Small-eared, or dull-eared, being applied thereto] because of the sakak [i. e. smallness &c.] of its ear or because it is deaf when thirsting. (M.) And AlOaSamRu [as though meaning (tropical:) The deafmute] is an epithet applied to rajab, (S, M, Msb, K,) the month thus named, (Msb,) which the people of the Time of Ignorance called Xahoru QllRehi AlOaSamRu, (Kh, S,) because the cry of the caller for aid was not heard in it, (Kh, S, M, Msb, K, *) shouting yaA lafulaAnK and yaA SabaAHaAho, (M, K,) nor the commotion of fight, (Kh, S, Msb,) nor the clash of arms, it being one of the sacred months: (Kh, S:) thus applied it is tropical, like naAYimN in the phrase layolN naAYimN; as though, in it, the man were deaf to the sound of arms: (TA:) and in like manner it is also called munoSilu AlOalRi. (M. [See also AlOaSabRu, and muHarRamN, and XahorN.])

And [as that which is without a cavity is generally nonsonorous,] one says HajarN OaSamRu meaning (tropical:) Hard (S, M, Msb, K) and solid (S, Msb, K) stone: (S, &c.:) and SaxorapN SamRaMCu (tropical:) a hard and solid rock: (K, TA:) or this latter signifies (assumed tropical:) a rock in which is no crack nor hole: pl. SumRN. (TA.) And qanaApN SamRaMCu (assumed tropical:) A compact spear-shaft. (M.)
AlSRamRaMCu also signifies (assumed tropical:) The earth, or ground. (M:) And OaroDN SamRaMCu (assumed tropical:) Rugged ground: pl. SumRN. (K.)

Also [app. (assumed tropical:) The vermiform appendage of the cœcum;] the thin, or slender, extremity of the Efjp: (K: [the last word in this explanation is thus, without any syll. signs, in my MS. copy of the K and in the TA: in the CK, Eafijap: but the right reading is evidently Eifajap, which is said in the TA, in art. Efj, to be, like OaEofaAjN, a pl. of EafajN and its dial. vars.: see this last word:] thus called [in my opinion because resembling a meatus auditorius that is closed, and therefore deaf; though said to be so called] because of its hardness. (TA.)
And naAqapN SamRaMCu (tropical:) A fat she-camel: (K, TA:) and, (K,) or as some say, (TA,) one that has just conceived, or become pregnant. (K, TA.)

AiXotimaAlu AlSRamRaMCi, (S, Msb, K, TA,) which is forbidden in a trad., (TA,) is (assumed tropical:) The covering oneself with his garment, like [as is done in the case of] the Ximolap of the Arabs of the desert with their [garments called] Oakosiyap [pl. of kisaMC]; (A'Obeyd, S;) i. e. the turning the kisaMC, from the direction of one's right, upon his left arm and the part between his left shoulderjoint and neck, and then turning it a second time, from behind him, upon his right arm and the part between his right shoulder-joint and neck, so as to cover them both: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) or the wrapping oneself with the garment without making to it a place from which to put forth the hand: (Msb:) or, (K,) as the lawyers explain it, (A'Obeyd, S,) it is the wrapping one's body and arms with one garment, not having upon him another, and then raising it [in the K, as is said in the TA, yaDaEuhu is erroneously put for yarofaEuhu] on one of its sides, and putting it upon his shoulder, so that his pudendum appears from it: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) [but] with the Arabs, libosapu AlSRamRaMCi means the covering one's whole body with his garment, and not raising a side from which to put forth his hand: (Mgh:) when you say, of a man, AiXotamala AlSRamRaMCa, it is as though you said, AiXotamala AlXRimolapa AlSRamRaMCa; for AlSRamRaMC is a sort of AiXotimaAl. (S. [See also AiXotamala, and AlXRimolapu AlSRamRaMCu, in art. Xml.])
jacorN OaSamRu (assumed tropical:) A surd, or an irrational, root, in arithmetic; which is known only to God, accord. to a saying of 'Áïsheh: opposed to jacorN naATiqN. (Mgh in art. jcr.)

[fiEolN OaSamRu A surd verb
is a term sometimes used in grammar, as meaning a triliteral-radical verb of the class commonly called muDaAEafN of which the second and third radicals are the same letter.]
SawotN maSimRN A sound, or noise, or voice, that deafens the ear-hole. (TA.)
OalofN muSamRamN (assumed tropical:) A thousand completed; like muSamRatN and muSomatN. (TA in art. Smt.)
muSamRimN A sword that passes into the bones: (M:) or that penetrates into that which is struck with it. (TA.)
See also SimoSimN.
And (assumed tropical:) A strong camel: so says Aboo-' Amr Esh-Sheybánee: and he cites the saying,
[as meaning I loaded their strong camels with my burdens]: (TA:) or the muSamRimaAt, here mentioned, are the camels that do not utter a grumbling cry; patient of travel. (Ham p. 791.)

1. Samata, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
Samuta
, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. SamotN (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and SumotN (M, L, TA) and SumuwtN and SumaAtN, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) or the first of these is the inf. n. and the rest are simple substs.; (M;) and ASmt↓, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. UiSomaAtN; (K;) and SmRt↓, inf. n. taSomiytN; (S, K; but only the inf. n. is mentioned;) He was, or became, silent, mute, or speechless; syn. sakata: (S, A, Msb, K:) or he was, or became, long silent or mute or speechless: (M, Mgh:) but there is a difference between sakata and Samata; for the former is said of him who has the power, or faculty, of speech, but abstains from making use of it; whereas the latter is sometimes said of that which has not the power, or faculty, of speech. (Er-Rághib, MF and TA in art. skt.) The Arabs say, (Ks, TA,) and it is said in a trad., (TA,) laA Samota yawomFA UilaI AllRayoli, or yawomN, or yawomK, i. e. There shall be no keeping silence a whole day [until night]. (Ks, K, TA. [In the “ Jámi' es-Sagheer, ” we find lA SumaAta instead of lA Samota: and El-Munáwee, in his Commentary on that work, says that the keeping silence for a whole day is forbidden by the words of this trad. because it is an imitation of a Christian custom.]) And UiconuhaA SumaAtuhaA [in another trad., relating to the asking a virgin if she consent to be married, lit. Her permission is her silence,] means her silence is like her permission, i. e. it suffices. (Msb.) One says also, jaMCa bimaA SaMCa waSamata (assumed tropical:) [He brought what was vocal and what was mute]; maA SaMCa meaning sheep, or goats, and camels; and maA Samata, gold and silver: (IAar, TA:) SaMCa in this saying is formed by transposition from SaOaI [q. v.]. (S in art. SOI.)

2. SmRthu, (M, A, K,) inf. n. taSomiytN; (S;) and ASmthu↓; (M, A, Msb, K;) He made him, or rendered him, silent, mute, or speechless: (S, A, Msb, K:) or he made him, or rendered him, long silent or mute or speechless. (M.)
[Hence,] SamRitiI SabiyRaki Feed thy child with that which will silence it [or quiet it]. (A, TA.)
And SmRt AlrRajula He inclined to the man who complained to him by reason of his complaint [and so quieted him; or he cared for the complaint of the man and so quieted him; see muSamRitN]. (M, TA.)
See also 1, first sentence.
4. ASmthu: see 2.
[Hence,] lamo yuSomitohu celika That did not suffice him [so as to quiet him]: said only of what is eaten and drunk. (TA.)
And ASmthu He made it to be solid, not hollow; without a cavity. (A'Obeyd, S, K.) [For that which is without a cavity is generally non-sonorous.]

And OuSomitati AlOaroDu, or OaSomatat, (accord. to different copies of the K, the latter accord. to the O,) The land became altered (OaHaAlat) [so as to be rugged, or hard, app. in consequence of its having been left untilled and unsown,] at the end of two years, (O, K,) and had rugged patches of urine and dung. (O.)
See also 1, first sentence.
OaSomata also signifies He was, or became, tonguetied, (O, TA,) and spoke not; (TA;) said of a sick man. (O, TA.)
SumotapN a subst. from Samata [as such signifying Silence, muteness, or speechlessness; like SamotN used as a subst., and SumotN &c.; and like sukotapN and sikotapN]. (M, TA.)

And (M, TA) A thing, (M, A, K, TA,) i. e. food, (A, K, TA,) or the like, (K, TA,) such as a date, or something pretty, (TA,) with which one silences [or quiets] (M, A, K, TA) a child; (A, K, TA;) as also SimotapN↓; (Lh, M, TA;) like sukotapN [in this sense as well as in the former sense]. (S.) A date is called Sumotapu AlSRabiIRi [The quieter of the child], (M, TA,) and Sumotapu AlSRagiyri [The quieter of the little one], so in a trad., because when the little one cries, or weeps, he is silenced with it. (TA.) One says, maA EinodahaA Sumotapu layolapK She has not as much as would silence [or quiet] her child during one night. (A.) And maA lahu SumotapN liEiyaAlihi and SimotapN↓ He has not what would feed and silence [or quiet] his household, or family. (Lh, M.)
SimotapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
maA cuqotu SamaAtFA [I did not taste, or have not tasted,] anything. (K.)

ramaAhu biSumaAtihi, (AZ, K, A, K, [in a copy of the M bSimaAtih, but this I think a mistranscription,]) or biSumaAtapK↓, (K accord. to the TA, and so in the M in art. skt,) [both probably correct, for] one says also bisukaAtihi (AZ, S) and bisukaAtapK, (S, M, A, K, in art. skt,) He (a man, AZ, S, or God, A) smote him, or afflicted him, with a thing that silenced him. (AZ, S, M, A, K.) [See ramaAhu bisukaAtK, in art. skt.]
SumaAtN signifies also Thirst: (As, TA:) or quickness of thirsting, (M, K, TA,) in men and in beasts. (M, TA.)

fulaAnN EalaI SimaAti AlOamori Such a one is, or was, at the point of accomplishing the affair. (S.) And OanaA EalaI SimaAti HaAjatiI I am at the point of accomplishing my want. (M.) And baAta EalaI SimaAti Oamorihi He passed the night resolved upon his affair. (TA.) And huwa biSimaAtihi He is at the point of [attaining] his purpose: (M, TA:) Aboo-Málik says that SimaAtN signifies qaSodN [i. e. purpose, intention, &c.]. (TA.) And one says, baAta mina Alqawomi EalaI SimaAtK He passed the night in a place where he was seen and heard by the people, near to them. (S, TA.)

diroEN SamuwtN (tropical:) A coat of mail from which no sound is heard to proceed when it is put on, (S, A, L, TA,) it being soft to the feel, not rough nor rusty: (L, TA:) or a heavy coat of mail. (K.) And jaAriyapN Samuwtu AlxaloxaAlayoni (tropical:) A girl, or young woman, having thick legs, form whose pair of anklets no sound is heard to proceed, (K, TA,) by reason of their being depressed in her legs. (TA. [lahA in the CK is erroneously put for lahumaA.]) And sayofN SamuwtN (assumed tropical:) A sword that penetrates deeply into the thing struck with it [so as not to make a sound by its being repelled by a bone]. (K, TA.) And DarobapN SamuwtN (assumed tropical:) A blow [with a sword or the like] passing among the bones, not recoiling from a bone (M, K, TA) so as to make a sound. (TA.)
And XahodapN SamuwtN (tropical:) A honey-comb that is full; not having a cell empty. (A, K.)
SumaAtap: see ramaAhu biSumaAtihi, above.
SimRiytN, applied to a man, (S,) i. q. sikRiytN, (S, K, TA,) [i. e. Much, or often, silent or mute or speechless; or] long silent &c. (TA.)

SaAmitN Silent, mute, or speechless: (Msb:) pl. SaAmituwna (Kur vii. 192) [and SumuwtN, occurring in the K in art. zm]. [Hence,] one says, maA lahu SaAmitN walaA naATiqN (tropical:) [He has not mute nor vocal property; or he has not dead nor live stock]: (S, M, A:) by the former are meant gold and silver; (S, M, Msb, K;) and by the latter, camels, (S, K,) and sheep or goats, (S,) or animals: (M:) i. e. he has not aught. (S.)
Also, of camels, (assumed tropical:) Twenty, (O, K,) and the like. (O.)
And of milk, (assumed tropical:) Such as is thick. (S, O, K.)
OaSomatu: see muSomitN.

laqiytuhu biwaHoXi UiSomita and bibalodapi UiSomita AZ explains as meaning [I met him, or met with him, or found him,] in a desert place, in which was no one to cheer by his company: (S: [and in like manner the latter phrase is expl. in the M:]) accord. to Kr, bibalodapK UiSomita; but the phrase commonly known is bibalodapi UiSomita: (M:) or tarakotuhu bibalodapi UiSomita [I left him] in the desert, or waterless desert: or in such a place that it was not known where he was: (K:) and biSaHoraMCi UiSomita (M, K) meaning as above, (K,) or having the latter of these two meanings: (M:) and biwaHoXi UiSomita and UiSomitapa↓, (M, K,) mentioned, but not expl., by Lh, (M,) meaning as above, (K,) or app. meaning in the desert, or waterless desert: (M:) and some say, biwaHoXi AlUiSomitayoni: (TA:)
ASmt is as above, with the disjunctive alif; and also with the conjunctive [i. e. QSomita]: (O, K:) it is imperfectly decl., (S, MF, TA,) because combining the quality of a proper name with the fem. gender or with the measure of a verb: (MF, TA:) it is said that the desert, or waterless desert, is thus called because in it one fears much; as though everyone [therein] said to his companion, ASmt [i. e. AuSomuto or OaSomito, “ Be thou silent ”]; like as they say of a mahomah that it is so called because a man [therein] says to his companion, maho maho: (MA:) [for] accord. to some the word UiSomit is an imperative changed into a subst., and hence the C is disjunctive, and it may be with kesr accord. to a dial. var. [of the imperative] that has not reached us: accord. to Yákoot, it is the name of a particular desert; but others say that the proper name [of that desert] is waHoXu UiSomita. (TA in art. wHX.)
UiSomitap: see the next preceding paragraph.
muDomatN [primarily signifies Made, or rendered, silent, mute, or speechless.
And hence,] Solid; not hollow; having no cavity. (A 'Obeyd, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K.) [For that which is without a cavity is generally non-sonorous.]
And A door, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and a lock, (M, K,) closed, or locked, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) so that one cannot find the way to open it. (S, M, * K. *) A poet says,
[And in the way to Leylà are what are closed, &c., of chambers to which the owner alone has access: maqaASir being used by poetic license for maqaASayr, pl. of maqoSuwrapN]. (TA.)

Also A garment, or piece of cloth, of one, unmixed, colour. (M, Mgh, K.) The garment thus termed that is disliked is That of which the warp and woof are both of silk: or such as is woven of undressed silk, and then dressed, and dyed of one colour: (Mgh:) [or] such as is termed muSomatN mino xazRK, i. e. consisting entirely of silk, not mixed with cotton nor with other material, was forbidden by the Prophet. (TA.)

[Hence,] farasN muSomatN A horse of one, unmixed, colour; in which is no colour differing from the rest: (S, A, TA:) pl. xayolN muSomataAtN. (TA.) And Oadohamu muSomatN [applied to a horse] (assumed tropical:) Black unmixed with any other colour. (TA.)

[Hence also,] UinaMCN muSomatN (assumed tropical:) A vessel not silvered, or not ornamented with silver. (Mgh.) And bayoDapN muSomatapN (assumed tropical:) A helmet made of one piece. (AO, TA in art. byD.) And HaloIN muSomatN (assumed tropical:) A woman's ornament that is not intermixed with another: or, accord. to Ahmad Ibn- 'Obeyd, that has stuck fast upon its wearer, so that it does not move about; such as the armlet, and the anklet, and the like. (TA.)
The fahod [or lynx, an animal proverbial for much sleeping,] is said to be muSomtu AlnRawomi (tropical:) [app. meaning A heavy sleeper]. (A, TA.)

AlHuruwfu AlmuSomatapu are All the letters [of the Arabic alphabet] except those called Huruwfu AlcRalaAqapi [or AlHuruwfu AlcRuloqu]; (M, TA;) i. e. (TA) all the letters except those comprised in the phrase muro binafolK. (K, TA.) [What is here rendered “ except ” (i. e. maA EadaA) is said by MF to be omitted in most of the copies of the K.]
See also muSamRato.

muSomitN Tongue-tied; (O, TA;) not speaking: (TA:) applied to a sick man [when he is unable to speak]: (O, TA:) and OFSomatu↓ [signifies the same,] i. q. Oabohamu and mubohamN. (So in copies of the K in art. bhm. [In one of the explanations which I have given of mubohamN in consequence of an omission (to be supplied in Book II.), OaSomatu is made syn. with muSomatN.])
OalofN muSamRatN (assumed tropical:) A thousand completed; (M, K;) like muSatRamN; (M;) as also muSomatN↓. (K.)
muSamRitN [A silencer, or quieter: and hence,
] One who cares for another's complaint. (M, * Meyd, TA.) One says, (M, Meyd, TA,) i. e. a rájiz says, addressing a camel belonging to him, (Har p. 642,)

L.foreign: faQSobiro EalaI AlHimoli AlvRaqiyli Oawo muti

sense.s: [Verily thou complainest not to one who cares for thy complaint; therefore endure with patience the bearing of the heavy burden, or die]. (M, Meyd, TA.) taXokuw UilaI gayori muSamRitK, i. e. [Thou complainest] to one who cares not for thy case, is a proverb. (Meyd.)

SamajN [Lamps of the kind called] qanaAdiylu [pl. of qinodiylN]: one of which is called SamajapN: (S, K: [in the K, the former word is called pl. of the latter; but it is a coll. gen. n:]) an Arabic word, an exception to the rule that S and j cannot both occur in a genuine Arabic word: (TA:) or of Greek origin (ruwmiIRN), arabicized: (S:) EshShemmákh says,
[And the asterism, meaning the Pleiades, like the Greek lamps]: (S, MF:) but this does not show the word to be Greek, as the epithet may be added for the purpose of restriction. (MF.)

1. Samaxahu, (S, A, L, K,) aor.
Samuxa
, inf. n. SamoxN, (L,) He hit, or hurt, his SimaAx [i. e. his ear-hole, or his ear]: (S, A, L, K:) and, accord. to Sh, Samaxatohu AlXRamosu The sun smote, or hurt, his SimaAx. (TA.)
Samaxati AlXRamosu wajohahu The sun smote, or hurt, his face: or [in the CK “ and ”] fell vehemently upon it. (A 'Obeyd, K.)
Samaxa Eayonahu, (ISk, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (ISk,) He struck his eye with his fist: (ISk, K:) in some of the lexicons, with his hand. (TA.)
And Samaxa Oanofahu He crushed, or bruised, his nose. (Lh, TA.) [See also what next follows.]
SamoxN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (L.)
Also Any blow that leaves a mark; accord. to AZ, upon the face. (TA.)

SimaAxN The ear-hole: (S, A, Mgh, K:) the hole, (Msb,) or inner hole, (L,) of the ear, that penetrates to [the interior of] the head: (L, Msb:) and OuSomuwxN↓ signifies the same: (L, K:) of the dial. of Temeem: (L:) and simaAxN is a dial. var., (S, L,) as also OusomuwxN: (L:) and, (S, L, Msb, K,) as some say, (S, L, Msb,) the ear itself: (S, L, Msb, K:) pl. OaSomixapN, (L, Msb,) a pl. of pauc., (L,) and OaSomaAxN, (A,) [also a pl. of pauc.,] and SumuxN and SamaAYixu. (L.) One says, Daraba QllRehu EalaI SimaAxihi, and EalaI OaSomixatihimo, meaning God made him, and them, to sleep: phrases similar to DarabonaA EalaI McaAnihimo, in the Kur [xviii. 10: see art. Drb]. (L.) And hecaA kalaAmN yuWolimu OaSomaAxiI [This is speech that pains my ears]. (A.)
SamuwxN [Having merely an ear-hole; as distinguished from OacuwnN, meaning “ having an ear, ” i. e. “ having an external ear ”]. (Msb in art. byD.)
OuSomuwxN: see SimaAxN.

1. Samadahu, (S, M, A, Mgh,) aor.
Samuda
, (S, Mgh,) inf. n. SamodN; (S, M, Mgh, K;) and Samada Uilayohi; (M, A; *) He tended, repaired, betook himself, or directed himself or his course or aim, to, or towards, him, or it; or endeavoured to reach, or attain, or obtain, him, or it; or had recourse to him, or it; syn. qaSadahu: (S, M, A, Mgh, K: *) and so samadahu. (M in art. smd.) One says, Samada Uilayohi fiI AlHawaAYiji He repaired, betook himself, or had recourse, to him in exigencies; syn. qaSada. (M.) And Samada AlOamora, (A,) or Samada Samoda AlOamori, (M,) He betook himself to the thing, or affair; aimed at it; sought it, or endeavoured after it; or intended, or purposed, it; syn. AiEotamadahu; (A;) or qaSada qaSodahu. (M.) And tSmRd↓ lahu biAlEaSaA He betook himself to him or towards him, or aimed at him, with the staff, or stick; syn. qaSada. (M.) And raOosahu biAlEaSaA tSmRd↓ He aimed (Eamada) at the main part of his head with the staff, or stick. (M.)
Hence, Samada lahu He faced it directly; directed his face exactly towards it. (Mgh.)
And He pointed towards it. (Mgh.)

And Samadotu lahu HatRaI OamokanatoniI minohu girRapN I sprang and betook myself towards him, watching until heedlessness on his part made me to have him within my power. (L, from a trad. respecting the slaying of Aboo-Jahl.)
And Samadahu biAlEaSaA, (A,) inf. n. SamodN, (K,) He struck him, or beat him, with the staff, or stick. (A, K. *)
AlSRamodu also signifies AlnRaSobu [The setting up, or erecting, a thing]: (K:) one says Samadahu He set it up, or erected, it. (TK.)
And Samadati AlXRamosu wajohahu, (TK,) inf. n. SamodN, (K,) The sun scorched his face. (K, * TK.)

Samada AlqaAruwrapa, (M, K,) aor.
Samida
, (M,) or
Samada
, (K,) but this is
strange, for there is no faucial letter, nor any other reason for it, (MF,) He put a SimaAd [q. v.] over, or into, the mouth of the flask, or bottle. (M, K.)

2: [SmRdhu, said of a number of persons, signifies the same as Samadahu as first expl. above; or, said of a single person, He tended, repaired, &c., repeatedly, or frequently, to him, or it; see its pass. part. n., below.]
SmRd raOosahu, inf. n. taSomiydN, He wound a piece of cloth, or a kerchief, called SimaAd, round his head. (TA.)
3. SAmdhu, (TA,) inf. n. SimaAdN, (K, TA,) He contended with him in fight; syn. of the inf. n. jilaAdN. (K, * TA. [For jilaAd, Golius appears to have found in his copy of the K jalRaAd.])
4. ASmd Uilayohi AlOamora He rested, or stayed, upon him the affair; syn. Oasonadahu. (M.)
5: see 1, in two places.
SamodN inf. n. of 1. (S, M, &c.) [Hence Samadotu Samodahu, like qaSadotu qaSodahu, q. v.]

Also, (S, L, K,) or SamadN↓, (as in a copy of the S and in one of the M,) Elevated ground: (L:) or elevated and rugged ground, (S, M, L, K,) not so high as to be a mountain: (M, L:) or hard, firm, or tough, ground: (AA:) pl. OaSomaAdN and SimaAdN↓: (M:) or a narrow, rugged, and low part of a mountain, producing trees; as also SimaAdN↓. (Aboo-Kheyreh.)

SamadN (with the article Al an epithet applied to God, M) A lord; because one repairs, betakes himself, or has recourse, to him in exigencies; (S, A, K; *) or, when applied to God, because affairs are stayed, or rested, upon Him, (OuSomidato Uilayohi,) and none but He accomplishes them: (M, A, L:) or a person to whom one repairs, betakes himself, or has recourse, in exigencies: (M, A: *) you say, sayRidN SamadN, meaning a lord, or chief, to whom recourse is had: (A:) or SamadN signifies a lord to whom obedience is rendered, without whom no affair is accomplished: or one to whom lordship ultimately pertains: (M, L:) or a lord whose lordship has attained its utmost point or degree; in which sense it is not applicable to God: (T, L:) or the Being that continues, or continues for ever or is everlasting: (M, K:) or the Being that continues, or continues for ever, after his creatures have perished: (M:) or the Creator of everything, of whom nothing is independent, and whose unity everything indicates: or one who takes no nourishment, or food: (M, L:) also high, or elevated; (L, K;) applied to anything: (L:) a man above whom is no one: (L:) a man who neither thirsts nor hungers in war. (AA, K.)
Also Solid; not hollow; (M, K;) in which sense it may not be applied to God: (M:) and so muSomadN↓, a dial. var. of muSomatN. (S.)
And A people having no trade, or occupation, nor anything by means of which they may live. (K.)
See also SamodN.
SamodapN A rock firmly imbedded in the earth, even with the surface thereof, or, in some instances, somewhat elevated; (M, K; *) as also SumodapN↓. (M.)
And A she-camel that has been covered and has not conceived; (M, K; *) as also SamadapN↓. (Kr, M.)
SumodapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
SamadapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
SimaAdN The sidaAd [or stopper, like SimaAmN], (IAar, K,) or the EifaAS [or piece of skin that is put as a cover over the mouth], (Lth, S, M,) of a flask or bottle. (Lth, IAar, S, M, K.)
And A piece of cloth, or a kerchief, which a man winds round his head, duwna AlEimaAmapi [which may mean either exclusively of the turban or beneath the turban]. (K.)
See also SamodN, in two places.
SamuwdN A certain idol, which belonged to the tribe of 'Ád, who worshipped it. (TA.)
muSomadN: see SamadN, near the end of the paragraph.
muSamRadN applied to a house, or tent, (bayotN, S) repaired to [repeatedly, or frequently, or by many persons, as is indicated by the teshdeed, though only expl. as] syn. with maqoSuwdN. (S, K.)
Also A hard thing; in which is no softness, or fragility. (K, TA.)
miSomaAdN A she-camel that endures cold, and drought, or barrenness of the earth, continuing to yield her milk: pl. maSaAmidu and maSaAmiydu. (K.)
muSawomidN Thick, or rough, (K, TA,) and high, overtopping, or prominent. (TA.)

1. Samara, (M, K,) aor.
Samura
, (M,) inf. n. SamorN and SumuwrN, He was niggardly, or tenacious, and refused; (M, K;) as also ASmr↓, and SmRr↓: (K:) [or] Samara, inf. n. SamorN, signifies he collected, and refused; and so ASmr↓, and SmRr↓: one says, Samara mataAEahu [he collected, and refused, his goods]: (O:) [but ISd says that] the phrase AlSRaAmiriyna↓ mataAEahumo, used by a poet, means, AlSRaAmiriyna bimataAEihimo [i. e., accord. to the context, those who are niggardly with their goods]. (M.)

Samara AlmaMCu, (M, O, K,) aor.
Samura
, inf. n. SumuwrN, (M, O,) The water ran from a declivity into a level place, and then became calm, or tranquil, while [continuing] running. (M, O, K.) And SimorN↓ signifies The resting-place of such water: (M, K:) and Simoru↓ AlwaAdiI the resting-place of such water of the valley. (TA.)

Samara, (O, K,) aor.
Samira
; (K;) and Samira, (O, K,) aor.
Samara
; (K;) said of milk, (O, K,) It was, or became, sour; (O;) or very sour; as also ASmr↓. (O, K.)
2: see above, first sentence, in two places:
and see the paragraph here following.
4: see 1, first sentence, in two places:
and see also the last sentence.
Also ASmrwA, (O, * K,) inf. n. UiSomaArN; (O;) and SmRrwA↓, (K,) inf. n. taSomiyrN; (O;) They entered upon the time of sunset, which is called AlSRumayoru. (O, K.)
5. tSmRr He confined, restricted, or restrained, himself. (O.) [See also its part. n., below.]

SamorN, (M, O, TS, K,) or SamarN↓, (S, A, L,) [the latter probably the correct, or the original, word, and, if so, app. an inf. n. of an unmentioned, and perhaps unused, verb, namely, Samira, whence the part. n. SamirN, q. v.,] Stink, foul odour, or offensive smell: (S, M, K:) and, (K,) accord. to IAar, (O, TA,) the odour of fresh mush, (O, and so in copies of the K,) or of fresh fish: (TA, as from the K:) and, accord. to IAar, (O, TA,) but in this sense more commonly SamarN↓, (O,) the sultry heat, (O,) or foul smell, and sultry heat, and dew, or moisture, accompanying such heat, (TA,) of the sea when it is agitated. (O, TA.)

SumorN i. q. SuborN [i. e. The side of a thing: or a side rising above the rest of a thing: or its upper part, or top: or its edge]: (S, M, K:) the m is said to be substituted for b: (M:) pl. OaSomaArN. (S, M, K.) You say, Oadohaqotu AlkaOosa UilaI OaSomaArihaA, meaning AlI OaSobaArihaA [i. e. I filled the cup to its uppermost parts; or to its edges]. (ISk, S, M, * K: in the M and TA is added, i. e. UilaI OaEaAliyhaA.) And Oaxaca AlXRaIoCa biOaSomaArihi, meaning biOaSobaArihi [i. e. He took the thing altogether: see art. Sbr]. (M, TA.)
SimorN, and Simoru AlwaAdiI: see the first paragraph.
SamarN: see SamorN, in two places.

SamirN: [Stinking; having a foul, or an offensive, odour, or smell]. One says, yadiI mina AlsRamaki SamirapN [My hand is stinking from the fish], (S, O, [in the former of which the meaning is indicated by the context,]) and mina AllRaHomi [from the flesh-meat]. (TA.)
SamorapN Milk devoid of sweetness. (O, K.)
SamiyrN A man whose flesh is dry, or tough, upon his bones, (S, M, A, O, K,) from whom the odour of sweat diffuses itself. (IDrd, S, A, O, K.)
SumayorN The time of sunset. (K, TA.)

SamaAraI, (M, O, K,) and SumaAraI, (O, K,) and SumaAriIRN↓, (S, O, K,) and SimaArI, with kesr, [but whether otherwise like the first and second or the last, is not shown,] (TA, from Az,) The podex, or the anus; syn. duburN, (S,) or AisotN, (M, A,) or saAfilapN: (O:) because of its foul smell. (O, * TA.)
SumaAriIRN: see the next preceding paragraph.
SaAmirN A day in which the wind is still. (O, TA.)
See also 1, first sentence.

SawomarN, a word of the dial. of El-Yemen, (IDrd, O,) The baAcaruwj; (M;) [i. e.] the trees, or plants, (Xajar,) called by the latter name; (K;) or a species of baqol [or herb] called in Pers. by the latter name [which, commonly pronounced with d, is one of the names now applied to basil]: (IDrd, O:) accord. to AHn, a sort of tree, or plant, that does not grow by itself, but twines upon the gaAf, consisting of twigs with leaves like
those of the OaraAk, (M, O,) its twigs being more slender than thorns, (O,) and having a fruit resembling the acorn, (M, O,) in form, but thicker at the base and more slender at the extremity, (O,) which is eaten, and is soft, and very sweet: (M, O:) the stem of the Sawomarap [which is the n. un.] is thicker than the upper half of the arm; and it increases in height with the gaAfap while the latter does so: (O:) 'Alee Ibn-'Abbás, author of the book entitled the “ Kámil, ” says that the baAcaruwj has in it nothing beneficial when a man takes it internally; but when applied externally, it matures, or causes suppuration, [for Anfj in the TA, an evident mistranscription, I read OanoDaja,] and acts as a dissolvent. (TA.)
SaAmuwrapN Very sour milk. (O, K.)

mutaSamRirN i. q. mutaXamRsN [app. as meaning Niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious; agreeably with the first explanation of 1]: (O, K:) and, (K,) or as some say, (TA,) confining, restricting, or restraining, himself. (K, TA.)

1. SamiEati AlOucunu, aor.
SamaEa
, inf. n. SamaEN, (Msb, TA,) The ear was [small: (see OaSomaEu:) or] cleaving [to the head], and small: (Msb:) or was small, and not pointed, or tapering, or slender at the extremity, and had a contraction in the middle, and a cleaving to the head: or clave to the side of the face, from its base, and was short, not pointed, or tapering, or slender at the extremity: or was narrow, or contracted, in its hole, and pointed. (TA.)
2: see the next paragraph.
Q. Q. 1. SawomaEa AlvRariydapa He made the vrydp [or mess of crumbled bread with broth] slender in the head, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) and pointed therein; (Ibn-'Abbád, O;) as also SamRaEahaA↓. (TA.)
And SwmE binaOCahu He made his building high. (Seer, TA.)
And SwmE AlXRaIoCa He collected together the thing. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
SamaEN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Msb, TA.)
Also Courage: because the courageous is described as compact in heart. (TA.)
SamiEN Courageous. (TA.)
And Sharp in intellect. (TA. [See also OaSomaEu.])
SawomaEN: see what next follows.

SawomaEapN A Christian's cell, or chamber, (K, KL,) for retirement, or seclusion, having a high and slender head; (KL;) [the cell of a recluse;] a monk's manaAr [which, as here used, means likewise a cell, or chamber, of the kind described above]: (TA:) the SawomaEap of the Christians is thus called because it is slender in the head; (S, O, K;) or because contracted; (Msb;) or, as As says, from the epithet OaSomaEu, meaning [that it is] pointed at the extremity, [or top,] and contracted: (TA:) and it is also called SawomaEN↓: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) the pl. is SawaAmiEu. (Msb.)
And i. q. miYocanapN [q. v.]. (Lh, M and K and TA in art. Acn.)

And (tropical:) The upper, or uppermost, part of [a mess of] variyd [or crumbled bread moistened with broth]: (K, TA:) and the body thereof: a vrydp [or mess of crumbled bread with broth] is said to be thus called, when it is made pointed in its head, and made even. (TA.)
And (tropical:) A buronus [or garment with a pointed hood]: (K, TA:) Aboo- 'Alee says, (TA,) SawaAmiEu signifies baraAnis; (O, TA;) without mentioning a sing. thereof. (TA.)
And (assumed tropical:) The eagle is thus termed, because always upon the highest place to which it can ascend. (O, * K, * TA.)

OaSomaEu The small in the ear; (S, Mgh, O, K, TA;) of men and of others: (TA:) [see also 1:] fem. SamoEaMCu; (S, Mgh, O, K, TA;) applied in this sense to a woman, and to other than woman; (TA;) thus to a she-goat; and such I'Ab held to be allowable as a victim for sacrifice; (O, TA;) or, applied to a she-goat, whose ear is like that of the gazelle, between such as is termed sakRaMC and such as is termed OaconaMC; or, accord. to Az, applied to a ewe or she-goat, whose ear is little, and cleaving to the head: (TA:) [pl. SumoEN.]
Hence, The ostrich; because of the smallness of his ear, and its cleaving to his head. (TA.)
And the fem., applied to an ear, Small, or little, and contracted towards the head. (O, K.)

Also, the masc., applied to a kaEob [as meaning a joint of the bones, and particularly an anklejoint, and an ankle-bone, and also a joint, or knot, of a cane or reed], Small, or slender, and even. (O, K.) A woman is said to be SamoEaMCu AlkaEobayoni Small, or slender, in the kaboEaAn [i. e. ankle-joints or ankle-bones]. (TA.) And dogs are said to be SumoEu AlkuEuwbi i. e. Small in the kEwb [app. meaning joints of the legs, i. e. tarsal and other joints]: (S, K:) so too the legs of a wild bull, meaning slender, not swollen, in the kuEuwb; even and smooth therein; thus in the saying of En-Nábighah Edh-Dhubyánee, describing dogs and a [wild] bull:

[And he (the owner of the dogs) has dispersed them (the dogs) against him; and legs (qawaAYimu being understood) slender and even and smooth in the joints, free from the disease that would render them unsteady, (such being here meant by AlHarad, which is properly in camels,) have been strong to bear him.] (L, TA. [See also De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., ii. 438-9.]) You say also qanaApN SamoEaMCu AlkuEuwbi i. e. [A spear-shaft] even and smooth [in the knots, or joints]: or, as some say, compact in the interior, hard, and slender in the knots. (TA.) And rumoHN OaSomaEu AlkaEobi i. e. A spear pointed in the kEb [app. meaning the knot that forms its lower extremity]. (TA.)

OaSomaEu applied to a feather means Slender in the Easiyb [or shaft]: (O, TA:) AlEasiybu AllRaTiyfu in the K is a mistake for AllRaTiyfu AlEasiybi: (TA:) or the best of feathers; (K, TA;) such as is used for feathering an arrow, of the kind called ZuhaAr [q. v.]: (TA:) pl. SumoEaAnN, (O, K,) which is said to mean the best of the feathers of a bird. (O.)

Applied to a plant, it means Having fruit come forth that has not yet broken open: (O, K:) or, as some say, saturated with moisture, and compact: and SamoEaMCu is said to have this latter meaning applied to a plant such as is termed baqolap: (TA:) and the same, (i. e. the fem.,) applied to the plant called buhomaI, that has risen high, (Az, S, O, K,) and attained its complete growth, (Az, O, TA,) before the bursting open of its pericarps: (S, O, K:) [and so as applied to any plant: (see busorN:)] or, applied to a plant, smooth and round and slender: (O, K:) or any calyx (buroEuwmap) that has not yet opened: (AHn, O, K:) and, applied to the plant called bhmI, of which the calyxes have not opened, and the awn has not yet appeared: (O:) or, thus applied, fresh, or juicy, and not yet burst open: or having its fruit, or produce, coming forth upon its upper part: accord. to IAar, thus applied, it is an intensive epithet, [app. meaning full-grown and flourishing,] like jaEodN applied to the SilRiyaAn, and OasoHamu applied to the naSiIR: (TA:) the pl. is SumoEN. (O, K.)

OaSomaEu Alqalobi means Vigilant, and sharp, or acute, in mind: (S, O, K:) and qalobN OaSomaEu an intelligent and acute mind: (TA:) and AlOaSomaEaAni the sharp, or acute, (S, O, K,) and vigilant (K) mind, (S, O, K,) and the resolute, (EaAzim, S, and so in the L,) or prudent, or discreet, or intelligent, or firm and sound, (HaAzim, O, K,) judgment, or opinion: (S, O, K:) accord. to As, OaSomaEu applied to the mind (fuWaAd), and to judgment, or opinion, means EaAzimN [expl. above]: and rajulN OaSomaEu Alqalobi means a man of acute intelligence. (TA.) [See also SamiEN.] And one says also EazomapN SamoEaMCu i. e. An effective resolution, or determination. (TA.)

[It is said that] OaSomaEu signifies also A sharp sword: (O, K:) this and the next two significations are related as on the authority of El-Muärrij; but Az says that all that has been related as from him is of the things that are not to be regarded unless the transmission from him prove to be correct. (TA.)
And One that ascends, or rises by degrees, to the most elevated of places. (O, K.)
And i. q. saAdirN [which means In a state of confusion or perplexity, and unable to see his right course: &c.: see this latter word]. (O, K.)

And AlSRamoEaMCu also signifies The saAlifap [meaning the side of the upper part of the neck], (O, K,) and the place of the ear: (O:) this is said to be its meaning as used in a verse of Abu-n-Nejm, (O, TA,) describing a male ostrich. (TA.)
variydapN muSamRaEapN: see what here follows.
variydapN muSawomaEapN (K) and muSamRaEapN↓ (S, O, K) [A mess of crumbled bread with broth] made slender in the head, (S, O, K,) and pointed therein. (S, O.)

2. SmRghu, inf. n. taSomiygN, He put Samog [i. e.
gum] into it; (O, K;) meaning, into ink. (O.)
And SmRg biAlSRamogi, inf. n. as above, He compacted the hair of his head [with gum]. (Msb.)
4. ASmgt AlXRajarapu The tree produced Samog [i. e. gum]. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, Msb, K.)

Hence one says, yuSomigu fuwhu His mouth is discharging like a tree producing gum, and in like manner OucunaAhu his two ears, and EayonaAhu his two eyes, and Oanofuhu his nose. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) And ASmg Xidoquhu The side of his mouth produced much spittle. (O, K.) And ASmg AlrRajulu (tropical:) The man had foam coming forth upon the sides of his mouth. (Har p. 618.) And ASmgt AlXRaApu is said of the sheep or goat when her biestings are fresh (kaAna libaWuhaA TariyRFA, Ibn-'Abbád, O, TA, in the K labanuhaA, but the former is the right, TA) [i. e. The sheep, or goat, yielded fresh biestings] on the first occasion of her being milked. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TA.)

10. AstSmg AlSRaAba He scarified the species of tree that produces SAb [q. v.] (S, O, K) in order that its giraMC [meaning mucilage] might issue, (K, TA,) i. e. (TA) in order that a certain bitter substance might issue from it, and concrete like Sabir [i. e. aloes]: (S, O, TA:) thus expl. by Abu-I-Ghowth. (S.)
And AstSmg He had a Samogap, i. e. a small swelling, or pustule. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.)

SamogN (S, O, Msb, K) and SamagN↓, (K,) the latter mentioned by ISd on the authority of AHn, (TA,) [Gum; i. e.] the fluid that exudes from the trees called EiDaAh and the like of these: (Msb:) it is of many sorts: (S, O:) that which is called AlSRamogu AlEarabiIRu is the Samog of the TaloH, (S, O, Msb,) which is said to be the same [tree] that is called OumRu gayolaAna: (Msb:) or the mucilage (giraMC) of the [tree called] qaraZ [and more commonly sanoT, i. e. the mimosa Nilotica, also called acacia Nilotica]; and this is what is called AlSRamogu AlEarabiIRu; not the Samog of the TaloH; J [and others] having erred [in asserting it to be this]: [but] every tree also has Samog: (K: [this last assertion, however, is questionable; for Samog seems to signify properly gum, or juice that exudes from certain trees and concretes:]) the n. un., (Msb, TA,) or term applied to a portion thereof, (S, O,) is SamogapN (S, O, Msb, TA) and SamagapN: (TA:) and the pl. is SumuwgN: (S, O, Msb, K:) among Sumuwg [i. e. sorts of Samog], the muqol [q. v.] is said to be included; but this is not known. (AHn, TA.) It is said in a prov., tarakotuhu EalaI mivoli maqorifi AlSRamogapi [I left him in a condition like that of the place where the piece of gum has been pared off]: this is when one has left a person nothing; for the Smgp is plucked off from its tree until there remains not upon it what would retain one's life: (S, O:) or, as some relate it, EalaI mivoli maqolaEi AlSRamogapi [in a condition like that of the place where the piece of gum has been plucked off]; (O, and so Meyd;) meaning, without anything remaining to him; because, when the gum is plucked off, there remains not any trace of it. (Meyd.) And in a trad. of El-Hajjáj occurs the saying, laOaqolaEanRaka qaloEa AlSRamogapi [I will assuredly pluck thee away with the plucking away of the piece of gum]; meaning I will assuredly extirpate thee. (TA.) [
Also Resin; see EilokN.]
SimogN: see SimagN:
and see also AlSRaAmigaAni.
SamagN: see SamogN.

SimagN (AZ, O, K) and SimagapN↓, (K,) or the latter is the n. un. of the former, and in like manner SimaxN and SimaxapN, the latter being the n. un., (AZ, O,) or SimogN↓ and SimoxN, of which SimogapN↓ and SimoxapN are the ns. un., (Az, on the authority of A 'Obeyd, TA,) A dry substance which is found upon the teats (AZ, Az, O, K) of a she-camel (AZ, O, K) or of a ewe or she-goat, (Az, TA,) when she is milked on the occasion of her bringing forth: (AZ, Az, O:) when that is rent asunder (UicaA fuTira celika [in the CK quTira]), the milk is clear and sweet. (AZ, O, K.)
SamogapN A small swelling, or pustule; syn. qaroHapN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
SimogapN: see SimagN:
and see also SamogaAn.
SimagapN: see SimagN.
laqiytu SamogaAna, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) and OabaA Simogapa↓, (K,) I met him whose mouth and ears and eyes and nose were discharging like the tree producing gum. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
AlSRimaAgaAni: see what next follows, in two places.

AlSRaAmigaAni, (IDrd, S, O, K,) like AlsRaAmigaAni, [q. v.,] (IDrd, O,) but the former is said by Mtr to be better known, (Har p. 618,) and AlSRimaAgaAni↓, (AO, O, K,) and AlSRimogaAni↓, (Lth, O, K,) The two sides of the mouth, (S, O, K,) where the lips meet [and conjoin], next the XidoqaAni: (O, K:) or the two places where the spittle collects in the two sides of the lip; (IAar, O, K;) called by the vulgar AlSRawaArayon, (O in this art.,) or AlSRawRaArayon, for AlSRiwaAraAni: (O and TA in art. Swr:) or, as some say, [strangely,] the hinder part of the mouth. (TA.) It is said in a trad. that the SimaAgaAni↓ are the two places where sit the two angels [that note and record the actions of a man]: a saying enjoining the use of the siwaAk. (TA.)
labanN muSomigN [app. Milk that is gummy; describing biestings not yet clear]. (TA voce SuEoruwrN, q. v.)

And XaApN muSomigapN bilibaYihaA, (O, TA,) in the copies of the K, erroneously, bilabanihaA, (TA,) A ewe, or she-goat, yielding fresh biestings on the first occasion of her being milked. (O, K, * TA.)
HiborN muSamRagN Ink made with [the addition of] Samog [or gum]: but [J says] I know not from whom I heard this. (S.)

dictScrap.label: Smqr: For words mentioned under this head in the K, see art. Sqr.

sense.s: SimolaAxN The interior of the ear-hole. (K.)

And The dirt (S, A, K) of the ear (S) [i. e.] of the ear-hole; (A, K;) and the scales that come forth therefrom; (TA;) as also SumoluwxN↓; (S, K;) and so simolaAxN and sumoluwxN: (K and TA in art. smlx:) pl. SamaAliyxu. (TA.)
SumoluwxN: see above.

Also sing. of SamaAliyxu (TA) which signifies The thin, or slender, shoots of the OuSuwl [i. e. stems, or lower parts,] of the naSiIR (K, TA) and of the SilRiyaAn: (TA:) or the sing. signifies the OumoSuwx of the naSiIR; which is a kind of thing that is plucked therefrom, resembling a rod. (AHn, TA.)
SumaAlixN Thick milk, (S, K,) of a consistency resembling liver, so that it quivers. (S.)

SumaAlixiIRN and sumaAlixiIRN signify the same; (ISh, K;) i. e. Milk collected in a skin, and buried in a hole dug in the earth, and left until it becomes thick, or coagulates: (ISh, TA:) or food, and milk, having no taste. (IAar, TA.)

1. SamaI, (K,) aor. yaSomiI, (TK,) inf. n. SamayaAnN, He (a man, TK) hastened, made haste, sped, or went quickly; (K, TA;) and was light, active, or agile; this is said by Aboo-Is-hák [i. e. Zj] to be the primary signification; (TA;) as also ASmI↓. (K.)

And SamayaAnN, (S, M, K,) likewise an inf. n. of which the verb is SamaI, aor. as above, said of a man, (TK,) signifies [also] The act of escaping, or getting loose or at liberty, syn. tafalRutN, (M, and so in some copies of the S, in other copies of the S and in the K taqalRubN, [but the latter I regard as a mistake, and so it is said to be in the TK,]) and leaping. (S, M, K.)
SamaI, aor. as above, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. SamoIN, (Msb,) said of an animal that is an object of the chase, means He died (S, Msb, K) in one's sight, (S, Msb,) or on the spot. (K.)
SamaAhu AlOamoru, (Lth, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) The thing, or event, betided him, or befell him. (Lth, K.)
And maASamaAka Ealayohi What incited, urged, induced, or made, thee to do it? (K, TA.)
3. SAmI maniyRatahu He tasted, or experienced, his destiny, or death; as also ASmAhA↓. (M.)
4: see 1, first sentence.
ASmI EalaI lijaAmihi, said of a horse, He champed his bit, (S, M, K,) and went away, or along. (S, M.)

ASmI AlSRayoda He shot the chase, or game, in such a manner that it died (S, Mgh, Msb, K) in his sight, (S, Msb,) before him, (Mgh, Msb,) quickly, (Mgh,) or on the spot: (K:) accord. to Az, he killed it by means of his dog, in his sight; but it applies also to the case of killing with an arrow: (Msb, TA:) OanomaI is said when the chase, or game, goes out of one's sight (Mgh, Msb) after having been [seized by the dog or] hit [by the arrow], (Mgh,) and then dies, (Mgh, Msb,) so that one knows not whether it died by his dog or his arrow
or by some accident. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., kulo maA OaSomayota wadaEo maA Oanomayota [Eat thou what thou hast pursued, or shot, so that it has died in thy sight, and leave what thou hast pursued, or shot, in the case of its dying out of thy sight]. (S, Mgh, Msb.)
And ASmI AlrRamiyRapa He transpierced the animal that he shot at, or shot. (M.) And ASmt Alqawosu AlrRamiyRapa The bow sent its arrow through the animal shot. (TA.)
See also 3.

7. AnSmI Ealayohi He darted down, or rushed, (AinoSabRa, S, K, or AinoqaDRa, M, [both meaning the same,]) upon him, (S, M, K,) and advanced towards him (M,) to which Az adds, like as the hawk, or falcon, darts down (yanoSamiI, i. e. yanoqaDRu). (TA.)

SamayaAnN [an inf. n. used as] an epithet applied to a man, (S, M, A, &c.,) Quick, or swift: (Har p. 93: [see 1, first sentence:]) courageous; (S, M, K;) earnest, not making a false show of bravery, in the charge, or assault: (M, K:) and strong, and mature in age: (M, TA:) or the same word, (accord. to the TA,) or SimiyRaAnN↓, (so in this sense accord. to a copy of the M,) one who rushes (yanoSamiI) upon men injuriously: (M, TA:) accord. to the T, one who seizes upon men unjustly: accord. to IAar, daring in acts of disobedience: accord. to Z, applied to a man, it signifies timoDaMCN EalaI AlOumuwri [i. e. one who executes, performs, or accomplishes, affairs with energy; or who keeps, or applies himself, thereto with much constancy or perseverance: timoDaMCN being an intensive epithet, like tikolaAmN and tiloqaAmN &c.]: (TA:) the pl. of SamayaAnN is SimoyaAnN. (Kr, M, TA.)
SimiyRaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1. SanRa, [aor., accord. to rule,
Sanina
,] said of flesh-meat, i. q. SalRa [i. e. It was, or became, stinking]: either a dial. var. or formed by substitution. (M, TA. [See also the next paragraph.])

4. ASnR He, or it, (a man, S, or a thing, Msb,) had a foul, or fetid, odour, such as is termed SunaAn: (S, Msb, K:) so too said of a he-goat, when excited by lust. (TA.) And said of flesh-meat, [like SanRa,] It stank. (TA.) And ASnRt Albaqolapu The herb, or leguminous plant, when held in the hand, stank. (TA.) And ASnR said of water, It became altered [for the worse]. (K.)
Also He elevated his nose, (S, K,) or his head, (ISk, TA,) from pride. (ISk, S, K.) And hence, (S,) ASnRt said of a she-camel, She, having conceived, behaved disdainfully to the stallion. (S, K.)
And He was, or became, angry. (K.)

ASnRt said of a she-camel, (ISh, M,) or of a mare, (A 'Obeyd, K,) when near to bringing forth, (A 'Obeyd,) Her young one struggled, or was in a state of commotion, (A 'Obeyd, M,) in the part bordering upon her tail [so I render fiI SalaAhaA], (A 'Obeyd,) or its hind leg fell [or happened to come] into that part; (M;) or her young one stuck fast in her belly, and it pushed with its head, (ISh, K,) or with its shank and its nose, (ISh,) in the region of her anus. (ISh, K.) The epithet applied to her in this case is muSinRN↓: (ISh:) and the pl. is muSinRaAtN and maSaAnRu. (Az, TA.)
ASnRt said of a woman, She became old, but having in her some remains [of vigour]: and such is termed muSinRN↓ and muSinRapN. (M.)
ASnR also signifies He spoke in a low, faint, gentle, or soft, manner. (TA.)
And ASnR EalaI AlOamori He persevered, or persisted, in the affair. (K.)

SanRN, (S, M, TA,) with fet-h, (S, TA,) accord. to the K, SinRN, which is wrong, (TA,) [A kind of basket;] a thing like a covered salRap, in which bread is put, (S, K, TA,) and [other] food: (TA:) a large zabiyl, like the salRap. (M.)

SinRN The urine of the wabor [or hyrax Syriacus], (S, M, TA,) in the copies of the K erroneously said to be of camels: (TA:) it is inspissated for medicines; (M, TA;) and is very fetid. (TA.) SinRu Alwabori is also a term applied to Small, round, flattened cakes, (OaqoraAS,) which are brought from El-Yemen to El-Hijáz, found there in caves; having the property of dissolving tumours, applied as a plaster with honey: mentioned by the hakeem Dáwood. (TA.)

Also, (M, TA,) thus, without the art., but written by Az and J with it, i. e. AlSRinRu, as in the K, (TA,) One of the days called OayRaAmu AlEajuwzi; (S, M, K;) said to be the first of those days. (M. [See art. Ejz.])
SunRapN i. q. SubRapN [q. v.] as signifying A suforap, or a thing like the suforap. (M in art. Sb.)
SinRapN: see the next paragraph.

SunaAnN A stink, or stench; (M, Msb;) whether of the armpit or otherwise: (Msb:) or, (S, K,) as also SinRapN↓, (K,) the stink, or stench, of the armpit, (S, K,) and of the creases of the body when they are in a corrupt state: and the former is likewise applied to the odour of the he-goat when excited by lust: (TA:) and it signifies also, (TA,) or as some say, (M,) a sweet odour. (M, TA.)
SanRaAnN A courageous man. (K.)
OaSanRu A man feigning himself unmindful, inadvertent, or heedless. (K.)
muSinRN A man having a foul, or fetid, odour, such as is termed SunaAn; fem. with p: and likewise applied to a he-goat when excited by lust. (TA.)
And Elevating the nose, (S, M, TA,) or the head, (AA, TA,) from pride, (AA, S, M, TA,) or from anger. (M.) So in a verse cited in art. xfD. (S.)
And muSinRN gaDabFA Full of anger. (As, S.)
See also 4, latter part, in two places.
Also Silent. (TA.)

And AlmuSinRu signifies The serpent that, when it bites, kills on the spot: one says, ramaAhu QllRehu biAlmuSinRi Almusokiti [May God smite him with the silencing serpent that kills on the spot whomsoever it bites]. (IKh, TA.)
SinaAbN A sauce made of mustard (S, M, A, K) and raisins. (S, A, K.)
And Long in the back and belly; as also SinaAbapN↓: (IAar, O, K:) and so each with s. (IAar, O.)
SinaAbapN: see what immediately precedes.

SinaAbiIRN, applied to a horse (M, A, TA) or similar beast, (M, TA,) or to a hackney, (TA,) and to a camel, (M, TA,) Of a colour between redness and yellowness, (M, A, K, TA,) with abundance of hair, and of fur: (TA:) or of a bay, or dark bay, or brown, colour; syn. kumayotN: (S, O, K:) or of a sorrel colour; syn. OaXoqaru: (K:) or of this last colour having some white hairs intermixed therewith: (S, O, TA:) so called because his colour resembles the sauce termed SinaAb: (TA:) SinaAbiIRN being a rel. noun from SinaAbN. (S, O, TA.)
miSonabN Addicted to, or fond of, eating the sauce termed SinaAb. (IAar, O, K.)

Q. 1. Sanobarati AlnRaxolapu The palm-tree became solitary, or apart from others: (M:) or became slender in its lower part, and bared of the stumps of its branches, and scanty in its fruit. (M, K.) And Sanobara Oasofalu AlnRaxolapi The lower part of the palm-tree became slender, and stripped of the external parts [or of the stumps of the branches]. (AO, and S in art. Sbr, and TA.)

SanobarN, (K, TA,) or SunobuwrN↓, (O,) [both probably correct,] Anything slender and weak, (O, K, TA,) of animals and of trees [&c.]: (O, TA:) [the reg. pl. of the former is SanaAbiru: and hence, app.,]

SanaAbiru↓ signifies Slender arrows; (T, M;) accord. to IAar: [ISd says,] I have not found it save on his authority; and he has not mentioned a sing. thereof: (M:) [but] accord. to the T, they are so called as being likened to the SanaAbir [a pl. of SunobuwrN] of the palm-tree: (TA:) occurring in this sense in a verse cited voce cilRapN. (IAar, T, M.)
SinobirN, and SinaborN, and AlSRinaboru: see SinRaborN.
SanobarapN Ground that has become rough by reason of urine and of dung, or compacted dung, of oxen or sheep &c., (K, TA,) and the like. (TA.)

Oaxacotu AlXRaIoCa biSanobaratihi and biSinobiratihi and biSanowabirihi [which last is evidently, I think, a mistranscription for biSanawobarihi↓] is a saying mentioned by Ibn- 'Abbád as meaning I took the thing altogether. (O.)

SinRaborN, (S, in art. Sbr, M, O, K,) originally SinaborN↓, (O,) Cold, as a subst.; (M, O;) as also SinRiborN: (O:) or cold clouds: (IDrd, O:) or a cold wind (M, K) with mist or clouds: (M:) occurring in a verse of Tarafeh with kesr to the b: (M:) [see also SunobuwrN:] or SinRabirN, occurring in that verse, signifies the intense cold of winter; (S in art. Sbr;) as also SanaAbiru↓, (S, K,) of which the
sing. is SunobuwrN↓. (TA.) On the expression of Tarafeh, Hiyna haAja AlSRinRabiro, [when the cold wind, with mist, rises,] ending a verse, IJ says that the poet means AlSRinRaboru; but requiring to make the b movent, he transfers to it the final vowel, as in the phrases hecaA bakuro and mararotu bibakiro: he should therefore have said AlSRinRaburo; but regarding the expression as meaning Hiyna hayoji AlSRinRabori, he makes the b to be with kesr, as though he transferred to it the kesreh of the r: this, he adds, is more probable than the opinion that the change is merely one of poetic necessity. (M.) For this last reason, another poet uses the word with teshdeed to the n and r, and with kesr to the b; saying,
[We give to eat fat and the hump of the camel, and we give to drink pure milk, in the time of cold wind and chill mist]. (K.)

Also AlSRinRaboru, (M, K,) or AlSRinaboru↓, (as in two copies of the S in art. Sbr,) and SinRaborN, [without the article Al, occurring in a verse of which the metre requires it to be thus written, with teshdeed to the n,] (TA,) One, (S,) namely, the second, (M, K,) of the days called OayRaAmu AlEajuwzi: (S, M, K: [see EajuwzN:]) AlSRinaboru [or AlSRinRaboru] and AlSRinRabiru may have the same meaning, [or meanings, or may both be applied to the day above mentioned, for the application of SinRaborN to that day is certain;] poetic necessity requiring the b to be movent. (S.)

SinRabirN has also two contr. significations, namely, Hot: and cold: accord. to Th, on the authority of IAar. (M.) You say gadaApN SinRabirN, (M,) or SinRaborN, (K,) and SinobirN↓, (as in a copy of the M,) or SinRiborN, (K,) A cold morning: (M, K:) and a hot morning. (K.)

SunobuwrN A solitary palm-tree, apart from others, (AO, S in art. Sbr, and M, A in art. Sbr, and K,) the lower part of which becomes slender, (S and A in art. Sbr,) and stripped of the external parts [or the stumps of the branches]: (S ubi suprà:) and a palm-tree slender in its lower part, and bared of the stumps of its branches, and scanty in its fruit; (M, K;) as also SunobuwrapN↓: (M:) and a palm-tree that comes forth from the root, or lower part, of another palm-tree, without being planted: (M:) or a little palm-tree that does not grow from its mother-tree: (Ibn-Sim'án:) and the lowest part of a palm-tree, (AHn, Ibn-Sim'án, M, K,) from which the roots branch off: (AHn, M:) and branches that come forth from the lowest part of a palm-tree: (M, K:) or a branch that comes forth from the trunk of a palmtree, not from the ground: this is [said to be] the original signification: (T, TA:) or branches that come forth from the trunk of a palm-tree, not having their roots in the ground: such branches weaken the mother-tree, which is cured by pulling them off: the pl. is SanaAbiyru (IAar) and SanaAbiru↓: (T, TA:) and the SanaAbiyr are also called rawaAkiybu and EiqRaAnN. (Ibn-Sim'án.)

Hence, (A,) applied to a man, Solitary; lonely: (IAar:) or solitary, or lonely, without offspring and without brother: (S, A:) or solitary, weak, vile, or ignominious, having no family nor offspring nor assistant: (M, K:) or having no offspring, nor kinsfolk or near relations, nor assistant, whether of strangers or relations: and weak: (IAar:) and mean, or ignoble. (M, K.) See also SanobarN. And A young, or little, (K,) or weak, (TA,) boy, or child. (K, TA.) It was applied as an epithet to Mohammad, by the unbelievers, as also [its dim.] SunayobiyrN↓, (M, TA,) or they called him SunobuwrN, (O,) meaning that he had no offspring nor brother, so that, when he should die, his name would be lost; (M, TA;) likening him to a [solitary] palm-tree, of which the lower part had become slender, and the branches few, and which had become dry; (AO;) or to a branch growing from the trunk of a palm-tree. (TA.)
