And [hence] one says, (M, Msb,) by way of comparison, (M,) SAn EiroDhu, (M, Msb,) inf. n. SiyaAnapN and SawonN, (M,) (assumed tropical:) [He preserved his honour, or reputation], Eani AldRanasi [from pollution]. (Msb. [See also 6.]) And fulaAnN yaSuwnu diybaAjatayohi i. e. (tropical:) [Such a one preserves from disgrace] his cheeks; (A in art. dbj;) or diybaAjatahu his face. (Har p. 15.)

And SAn Alfarasu Eadowahu (M, TA) and jaroyahu, (TA,) inf. n. SawonN, (tropical:) The horse reserved somewhat of his running for the time of need. (M, TA.) And farasN lahu SawonN wabacolN; and cuw SawonK waQboticaAlK: see 1 in art. bcl.

And SAn Alfarasu, aor. yaSuwnu, inf. n. SawonN, means SafRa bayona rijolayohi [app. the same as SafRa rijolayohi He set his hind legs evenly, side by side]: (M:) or he stood upon the extremity of his hoof, (S, M, K,) by reason of [attenuation, or abrasion, such as is termed] wajFI or HafFA. (S, K.)

And SAn, inf. n. SawonN, He (a horse) limped, or halted, much; (M;) or, as expl. by IB, slightly. (TA.) yaSunRa AlmaXoIa occurs in a verse (S, M, TA) of En-Nábighah, (M, TA,) [referring to horses,] and J says that As knew it not, but that others expl. it as meaning Reserving somewhat of the rate of going, (TA,) or as meaning suffering pain in the hoofs from attenuation, or abrasion: (S:) accord. to IB, it means limping, or halting, and suffering pain in the hoofs, from fatigue. (TA.)
5: see the next paragraph.

6. taSaAwunN is the contr. of AiboticaAlN, (Msb,) or of tabacRulN: (S and Msb in art. bcl:) one says, of a man, taSaAwana and taSawRana↓, the latter on the authority of IJ, (M, TA,) and mentioned also by Z, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He preserved himself, or his honour, or reputation, (M, TA,) mina AlmaEaAyibi [from the things, or actions, for which he should be blamed], (TA. [See also 1, second sentence.])
8: see 1, first sentence.
SawonN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, M, &c.) See also SiynapN, below.
And see maSuwnN.
SawonapN [A receptacle for perfumes &c., such as is commonly called] an Eatiydap. (IAar, K.)

SiynapN [originally SawonapN] i. q. SawonN↓: one says, hecihi viyaAbu AlSRiynapi i. e. AlSRawoni [These are the garments of reservation for wear on extraordinary occasions]: (M, TA:) contr. of bicolapN. (TA.)

SiwaAnN and SuwaAnN (S, M, Msb, K) and SawaAnN (K) and SiyaAnN (S, Msb, K) and SuyaAnN and SayaAnN, (K,) but the third and the last two are extr., (TA,) A thing, (M, Msb, K,) or receptacle, (S,) [or chest or the like,] used as a repository (S, M, Msb, K) for a garment, (S, K,) as also maSaAnN↓, (Skr, cited by Reiske in Abulf. Ann. ii. 614,) [or for clothes,] or for a thing: (M, Msb:) pl.
OSownapN: (MA:) or maSaAnN↓ signifies any place in which one reposits a garment. (TA in art. Drs.)
SawaAniIRu pl. of SiyniIRN. (KL.) See art. Syn.

SawRaAnN [Flint-stone; and flint-stones: thus in the present day:] a sort of stones, (S, Msb,) in which is hardness; (Msb;) hard stones, (M, K,) of a certain sort, (K,) with which fire is struck: or, as some say, certain black stones which are not hard: (M:) or a sort of hard stones, which, when fire smites it, crackles (yufaqRiEu) and cracks, and sometimes fire is struck with it, but it is not fit for [making] time, nor for heating for the purpose of roasting thereon: (Az, TA:) one thereof is called SawRaAnapN↓. (S, M, Msb, K.)
AlSRawRaAnapu The dubur [meaning anus]: (K, TA:) so called because it keeps [from escape] much, or often, what would issue from it. (TA.)
See also SawRaAnN.
SayRinN [thus app., like sayRidN and jayRidN, written in my copy of the Msb Sayn] One who preserves his honour, or reputation. (Msb.)
maSaAnN: see SiwaAnN, in two places.
muSaAnN: see miSowaAnN.

maSuwnN and maSowuwnN↓, (S, M, Msb, K,) like maduwfN and madowuwfN, (S and Msb in art. dwf, q. v.,) the latter of the dial. of Temeem, (M,) Preserved, kept, laid up, taken care of, or reserved; (S, * M, * Msb, K;) applied to a garment [&c.]; (S, M;) as also SawonN↓, which is an inf. n. used. as an epithet: (M:) one should not say muSaAnN, (S, TA,) nor munoSaAnN, as the vulgar say. (TA.)
miSowaAnN A bow-case; (K, TA;) as also muSaAnN↓. (TA.)
maSowuwnN: see maSuwnN.

1. Sawati AlnRaxolapu, (Lth, Az, S, M, K,) aor. taSowiI, (S, K,) inf. n. SuwiIRN; (Lth, Az, S, M, K;) and Sawiyat, (Az, M, K,) which is the form preferred by Az, [aor. taSowaI,] inf. n. SawFI; (TA;) The palm-tree needed irrigation, and became slender: (Az, TA:) or became dry, or dried up; (S, M, K;) as also OaSowat↓, and SawRat↓: (K:) and in like manner one says of other trees: and sometimes, of animals. (M.) And SawiIa AlDRaroEu The udder had no milk remaining in it. (Ham p. 661.)
[Hence,] Sawati AlXRaApu The ewe, or she-goat, became fat, (S, TA,) in consequence of her udder's having been made to dry up. (S.) And SawiIa He became strong. (K.)

2. SwRI, (M,) inf. n. taSowiyapN, (K,) primarily, (M,) is used in relation to females, meaning He abstained from milking her, in order that she might become fat, (M, K,) and not be weak. (M.) You say, SawRayotu AlnRaAqapa I abstained from milking the she-camel for some days in order that the milk might collect in her udder so that she might become fat: or I made her milk to dry up, that she might become fatter. (M.) And SawRayotu AlXRaApa, inf. n. as above, I made the udder of the ewe, or goat, to become dry, that she might become fatter: (S:) or SwRyt Alganama I made the milk of the ewes, or goats, to dry up, purposely, that they might become fatter; like as one says in relation to camels: the subst. from the verb thus used is SawFI↓; and this is said to mean The leaving an animal and not milking her. (M.) Some say that taSowiyapN is like taSoriyapN; and hence the trad., AltRaSowiyapu xilaAbapN [i. e. The causing the milk to collect in the udder of an animal by abstaining from milking her for some days, when one desires to sell her, is an endeavouring to deceive: but I think that the right reading in this instance is probably AltRaSoriyapu, with r]. (TA.)

It is also used in relation to a stallion (S, M, K) of the camels: (S:) thus it is used by El-Fak'asee. (M.) One says, SawRayotu AlfaHola, (M,) inf. n. as above, (S, K,) I put no burden upon the stallion [camel], and did not bind him with a rope, in order that he might become more brisk in covering, and more strong; (S, * M, K; *) thus expl. by El-'Adebbes El-Kinánee: (S:) or I exempted him from work, and fed him, until his spirit returned to him, and he became fat. (M.) And SawRayotu liUibiliI faHolFA I chose for my camels a stallion, and fed and nourished him for the office of the stallion. (S.)
See also 1.
[And see art. Sw.]
4: see 1.
One says also ASwI Alqawomu, meaning The people's cattle became lean, or emaciated; like ADwI Alqwm. (IKtt, TA.)
[See also art. Sw.]
SawFI a subst. from 2, q. v. (M.)
SawK: see its fem., SawiyapN, voce SaAwK.
[Also, app., Empty sunobul (or ears of corn): accord. to the TA (on the authority of Az): the word in this sense, and thus applied, is there written with the article, AlSwI, without any syll. sign.]
SawiyRapN: see the following paragraph.

SaAwK Dry, (S, K, TA,) by reason of thirst, or want of irrigation, or by reason of leanness, or emaciation. (TA.) You say naxolapN SaAwiyapN, (M, K,) and SawiyapN↓, (M, TA,) [agreeably with rule, as part. n. of Sawiyat,] or SawiyRapN↓, (so in copies of the K, [app. a mistranscription,]) A dry, or driedup, palm-tree: (M, K:) and in like manner one terms other trees: and sometimes, animals: thus the poet Sá'ideh applies the epithet SAwyp to wild cows or wild oxen (baqar waHoX). (M.)
And Strong. (TA.)

1. SaAba aor. yaSiybu, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. SayobN, (S, Msb, K,) said of an arrow, (S, M, Msb,) i. q. OaSaAba [expl. in art. Swb]; (S, * M, Msb, K;) like SAb having for its aor. yaSuwbu. (S, M, Msb.)
SayobaAnN: see SawobN, in art. Swb.
SuyaAbN: see SuyRaAbapN.
SayuwbN An arrow going right, or hitting the mark: pl. SuyubN (M, K) and SiyaAbN, (MF, TA,) or the latter is pl. of SaAYibN, which signifies the same. (M, in art. Swb.)
SuyaAbapN: see SuyRaAbapN.
SayRibN: see art. Swb.
SuyRaAbN: see SuyRaAbapN, in four places.
SayRuwbN: see art. Swb.

SubRaAbapN and SuyRaAbN↓ (M, A, K) and SubaAbapN↓ and SuyaAbN↓ (A, K) The OaSol (M, A, K) [as meaning the original stock] of a people, (M,) or [as meaning the original, or the principal, or most essential, part,] of a thing: (A, K:) and the purest, or choice, or best, part or portion, (M, * A, K,) of a thing (M, K) of any kind, (M,) or of a people. (A.) One says, huwa fiI SuyRaAbapi qawomihi and SuyRaAbihimo↓ He is of the OaSol [or original stock] of his people: (Fr, TA:) and mino SuyRaAbapi qawomihi and SuwRaAbapi qwmh (TA) and mino SuyRaAbihimo↓ (A) of the purest in race of his people. (A, * TA.) And qawomN SuyRaAbN↓ A choice, or an excellent, people. (TA.)
Also the first, The collective body of a people; (Kr, M;) and so SuwRaAbapN. (M in art. Swb.)
And A lord, master, or chief. (M, K.)
SiytN and SiytapN: and SayRitN: see art. Swt.

1. SaAHa, (S, A, O, Msb, &c.,) aor. yaSiyHu, (S, O, Msb,) inf. n. SiyaAHN and SayoHapN (S, A, * O, Msb, K *) and SayoHN and SuyaAHN and SayaHaAnN, (S, O, K, *) He raised his voice, voiced, called or called out, cried or cried out: (S, A, O, Msb, K:) or did so vehemently, cried aloud, uttered a loud cry or crying, shouted, exclaimed, or vociferated: (T, S, * A, * O, * Msb, * TA:) or did so with his utmost force or power; (K, TA;) as also SyRH↓: (A, * TA:) it is said of a man, and of other things: (TA:) or of anything: (T, TA:) originally, of an animal, and often of a bird of the crow-kind, but rarely of a bird unrestrictedly, and sometimes of a spear as being likened to an animal. (Ham p. 187.) One says, SaAHa SayoHapF XadiydapF [He called, or cried, &c., with a vehement calling or crying &c., or with a vehement call or cry &c.]. (A.) And SAj bihi He called or cried, or called out or cried out, to it [or to him]. (Msb.) And SiHo liI bifulaAnK Call thou to me such a one. (A, TA.) And bihi SaAyaHa↓ and SaAyaHahu, (A, TA,) and SayRaHa↓ bihi and SayRaHahu, (A,) He called, hailed, or summoned, him; called out, cried out, or shouted, to him. (A, TA.)

And SiyHa bihimo (assumed tropical:) They were
frightened, or terrified. (K.) And SiyHa fiyhimo (assumed tropical:) They perished. (K.)

One says also, laqiytuhu qabola kulRi SayoHK wanaforK I met him before every calling, or crying, and dispersing; meaning (assumed tropical:) I met him before daybreak: (S, TA:) so in the Proverbs of Meyd. (TA.) Or Oatayotuhu qabola SayoHK wanaforK (tropical:) I came to him before everything. (A.) And gaDiba mino gayori SayoHK walaA naforK (tropical:) He was angry for neither little nor much: (ISk, S, K:) or for nothing. (A.)

And SaAHati AlXRajarapu, (A, Msb,) or AlnRaxolapu, (K,) (tropical:) The tree, (A, Msb,) or the palm-tree, (K,) became tall. (A, Msb, K.) And SAH AlEunoquwdu (tropical:) The raceme came forth completely from its envelope, and became long, and in a fresh and tender state. (K.) And SAH AlkaAfuwru (tropical:) [app. meaning The spathe of the palm-tree put forth its spadix, or its raceme, to its full length]. (A.)
2: see 1, in two places.
SyRHt Albaqola said of the sun, (S, K,) and of the wind, (S,) i. q. SawRaHatohu [q. v.]. (S, K.)
And SayRaHotu AlXRaIoCa I broke and split the thing much. (TA in art. SwH.)

3. muSaAyaHapN and taSaAyuHN↓ signify The calling or crying, or calling out or crying out, &c., of people, one to another. (S, K.) One says, SAyH Alqawomu (TK) and tSAyHwA↓ The people, or party, called or cried, &c., one to another. (A, TK.)
See also 1.
5. tSyRH Albaqolu i. q. tSwRH [q. v.]. (S, K.)
And tSyRH AlXRaEaru i. q. tSwRH [q. v.]. (K in art. SwH.)
And tSyRH AlXRaIoCu The thing became much broken and cloven or split or slit. (TA in this art. and art. SwH.) See also 7.
6: see 3, in two places.
tSAyH said of the scabbard, or sheath, of a sword (A, K, TA) (tropical:) It became much split or slit: (K, TA:) it is like the phrase tadaAEaI AlbunoyaAnu [q. v.]. (A, TA.)

7. AnSAH said of a garment, or piece of cloth, It became slit, or rent, or much slit or rent. (A, Msb. [See also 7 in art. SwH.]) And AnSAHt AlEaSaA The staff became much split or cracked; as also tSyRHt↓. (A.)
[Hence,] AnSAH is also said of the dawn and of lightning (tropical:) [meaning It showed its light: originally, became cleft: as expl. in art. SwH]. (A.)

SayoHapN an inf. n. [and also an inf. n. un.] of SaAHa. (S, Msb, &c.) [Hence,] one says, maA yanotaZiruwna UilRaA mivola SayoHapi AlHubolaI [They expect not, or wait not for, aught but the like of the cryingout, or cry, of the pregnant woman]; meaning, evil, or mischief, that shall come upon them suddenly. (TA.)
Hence also (S) Punishment, castigation, or chastisement. (S, A, K.)
And A hostile, or predatory, incursion, by which the tribe are surprised. (TA.)
SayoHaAnN: see what next follows.

SayoHaAniIRN, (T, S, A, Mgh, K,) or SayoHaAnN↓, (Msb,) A sort of dates of El-Medeeneh, (T, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) black, and hard to chew: (T, Mgh, TA:) said to be so called in relation to a certain ram, named SayoHaAnu, that was tied to a palm-tree, (A, Msb, K, *) which was hence called naxolapN SayoHaAniyRapN: (A, Msb:) or the name of the ram was AlSRayRaAHu, and SayoHaAniIRN is a rel. n. changed from its proper form, like SanoEaAniIRN, (K, TA,) from SanoEaMCu. (TA.)
SayRaAHN A clamorous man: and anything noisy, or sounding much. (The Lexicons passim.)
AlSRayRaAHu is another name for AlEawRaMCu [i. e. The constellation Bootes]. (Kzw.)
And (tropical:) A certain perfume, or fragrant substance: (K, TA:) or a wash for the head, (A, K, *) consisting of xaluwq [q. v.], and the like. (A, TA.)
SaAYiHapN The crying, or clamour, of the place of the wailing of women. (K.)

1. SaAdahu, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) like baAEahu, (MF,) [first pers. Sidotu,] aor. yaSiydu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. SayodN; (S, M, Mgh, Msb;) and SaAdahu, (S, &c.,) like haAbahu, (MF,) [first pers. Sidotu, as above, but originally Sayidotu, whereas the first pers. of the former is originally Sayadotu,] aor. yaSaAdu; (IAar, S, Msb, K;) and ASTAdhu↓, (S, M, A, L, Msb, K,) also written and pronounced AiSRaAdahu; (L;) and tSyRdhu↓; (M, A, L;) He took, captured, or caught, it; (Mgh, L;) [made it his prey;] snared, or ensnared, it; trapped, or entrapped, it; (MF;) or sought to take, capture, catch, snare, or trap, it; hunted it, or chased it: namely, [game, i. e.] any kind of wild animals, or the like, (L,) fowl, &c., (Msb,) and fish. (L.) [And SaAda, and ASTAd↓, and tSyRd↓, without the mention of the object, this being understood, He took, captured, caught, snared or ensnared, trapped or entrapped, game, i. e. any kind of wild animals, or the like, fowl, &c., or fish; or he sought to take &c.; he hunted or chased, stalked, or lurked for game; he fowled; or he fished.] You say, xaraja yataSayRadu↓ [&c., meaning He went forth to take &c., or seeking to take &c., game, or wild animals or the like; to hunt or chase, to stalk, or lurk for game; to fowl; or to fish]. (S, K.) And AlwaHoXa xaraja yataSayRadu↓ He went forth [to take &c., or] seeking to take &c., the wild animals. (L.) And Sidotu fulaAnFA SayodFA i. q. Sidotu lahu [I took &c., or sought to take &c., for such a one, game, or a wild animal, or wild animals, or the like]. (M, * K.) And SAd AlmakaAna, and ASTAdhu↓, i. q. SAd fiyhi [He took &c., or sought to take &c., game, or wild animals, or the like, in the place]: Sb mentions, as a phrase of the Arabs, SidonaA qanawayoni meaning SidonaA waHoXa qanawayoni: qanawaAni being the name of a certain land [or of two mountains]. (M.) And AlSRaqoru yaSiydu [The hawk preys]. (Msb and K in art. Sqr.) cawaAtu AlSRayodi is applied to beasts and to birds [That prey upon others; predatory]. (S and K in art. jrj, &c.)
[Hence,] one says, huwa yaSiydu AlnRaAsa biAlmaEoruwfi (tropical:) [He captivates men by goodness, beneficence, or kindness]. (A.)
And AiqotaSido taSido (tropical:) Aim thou at that which is right and just: thou shalt obtain that which thou wantest. (A.)
xarajonaA naSiydu bayoDa AlnRaEaAmi (tropical:) [We went forth to take, or hunt after, the eggs of ostriches]. (T, TA.)

And SidonaA AlkamaOapa, (M, A, TA,) a good phrase of the Arabs, mentioned, but not expl., by IAar; app. meaning (tropical:) We drew forth truffles [from the ground] like as one draws forth wild animals [from their lurking-places]. (M, TA.)
And SidonaA maMCa AlsRamaMCi (tropical:) We took [or caught in vessels or collected] the water of the sky. (Th, M, A. *)

Sayida, (Lth, S, M, L,) of the dial. of El- Hijáz, aor. yaSoyadu, (Lth, L,) inf. n. SayadN; (Lth, S, M, L;) and SaAda, (Lth, M, L,) [aor. yaSiydu;] He (a camel) had the disease termed SayadN [expl. below]: (Lth, S, M, L:) the I in Sayida is preserved unchanged because it is so preserved in the original form, which is AiSoyadRa↓, (S,) though they may not have said AiSoyadRa; (Sb, M;) and the like is the case in Eawira: (Sb, * S, M: *) the augmentative letters are rejected for the purpose of alleviation: hence, one does not say, in the case of verbs of this class, maA OafoEalahu, [i. e. maA OaSoyadahu, and maA OaEuwarahu, and the like,] forming thus verbs of wonder, because the original form is augmented, and a verb of four letters cannot be formed from a verb of four letters, for a measure can only be formed from a measure that is less. (S.) Also, both verbs, (the former accord. to the S and M, and ↓the latter likewise accord. to the M,) (assumed tropical:) He (a man) was unable to look aside, (S, M,) by reason of disease. (S.) And Sayida, inf. n. SayadN, (assumed tropical:) He raised his head, by reason of pride: and (assumed tropical:) he (a king) looked not aside, to the right or left. (S.) And Sayida (K, TA, in the CK [erroneously] SaYida,) (tropical:) He (a man, TA) had an inclining, or a bending, neck. (K, TA.)
And Sidotu fulaAnFA (tropical:) I made such a one to have an inclining, or a bending, neck. (K, TA. [See also 4.])
4. ASAdhu He made him, incited him, or induced him, to take &c., or to seek to take &c., wild animals, or the like, [fowl,] or fish. (L.)
Also He, or it, [app. meaning the vein called SaAd, or the disease termed Sayad,] annoyed, or hurt, him; (K;) namely, a camel. (TK.)
And He cured him (i. e. a camel, TK) of the disease termed Sayad, (K, TA,) by burning with a hot iron. (TA.) Thus it has two contr. significations. (K.)
And OaSoyada baEiyrahu He (God) caused his camel to have the disease termed Sayad. (M.)
5: see 1, in four places.
8: see 1, in three places.
9: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in two places.
SaAdN A certain vein (M, K) between the eyes of a camel, (K,) or between the eye and the nose; (M;) whence the disease termed Sayad: pl. OaSoyaAdN and pl. pl. OaSaAyidu [in the CK OaSAYidu]. (K.)
See also SayadN, in two places.
And see OaSoyadu, likewise in two places.

Also Brass; syn. SuforN:
and copper: (S, M, K:) or a species thereof: (K:) or cooking-pots made of Sufor, (A'Obeyd, TA,) or of copper: (A'Obeyd, M, TA:) pl. SiydaAnN, (M, TA,) like tiyjaAnN pl. of taAjN: and some say that SayodaAnN↓ [q. v., thus written with fet-h to the S,] signifies copper. (TA.)
See also art. Swd.

SayodN an instance of faEolN in the sense of mafoEuwlN, (Msb,) or an inf. n. used as a subst. [properly so called, and therefore used in a sing. and in a pl. sense], (Msb, TA,) [i. e.] an inf. n. used in the place of the objective complement of its verb; (IJ, M;) [Game, chase, or prey; an object, or objects, of the chase or the like;] i. q. maSiydN↓ (S, Mgh, K, TA) used as a subst.; (TA;) meaning what is taken, captured, or caught; or sought to be taken or captured or caught; [by the chase, or by means of a snare or trap, or by artifice of any kind;] of wild animals or the like; (L;) of fowl &c.; (Msb;) and of fish: (L:) or what is repugnant, or difficult of approach, (Mgh, L, K,) wild, or shy, by nature, not to be taken but by means of artifice, whatever it be, (Mgh,) but lawful to be taken, (L,) having no owner: (L, K:) or any wild animal, or wild animals, whether, or not, taken or sought to be taken: (IAar, M:) but this last application of the word is a deviation from general usage: (M:) pl. SuyuwdN. (Mgh, Msb.) [Also The quarry of the hawk; the prey of any beast or bird &c.] Sayoduka laA tuHoramohu (Meyd, A, but in the latter Sayodaka, [for Ailozamo Sayodaka,]) is a prov. (Meyd, A) inciting one to seize an opportunity, (A,) applied to a man who seeks another to execute blood-revenge upon him, and lights upon him when he is inadvertent; meaning Thy prey has become within thy power, therefore be not thou neglectful of him [so as to suffer him to escape, or rather be not thou rendered hopeless of him]. (Meyd. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 712; where tuHoramuhu is put in the place of tuHoramohu.])
See also SayadN.
SiydN: see the next paragraph.

SayadN (S, M, A, L, K) and SiydN↓, with kesr, (K,) or SayodN↓, (L,) and SaAdN↓, (M, * L, K,) A certain disease in a camel's head, in consequence of which he raises it: (S:) a certain disease which causes a camel to raise his head: or a certain disease in a camel's head, which causes his neck to twist: (M:) or a certain disease which attacks camels in the head, in consequence of which there flows from their noses what resembles froth, or foam, and they raise their heads: (ISk, L, K: *) or a certain disease in a camel's neck, in consequence of which he is unable to turn his face aside: it is said that its cure is burning with a hot iron (A, TA) between the eyes: (TA:) [for] it arises from a vein between the eyes, called SaAd. (K.) [Hence,] also SayadN, (M, * A,) and SaAdN↓, (M,) Fixedness of the face of a king, so that it does not turn aside (M, A) to the right or left, by reason of pride. (A. [See also Sayida, of which it is the inf. n.]) [And the former, (tropical:) An inclination, or bending, of the neck: (see Sayida:) hence,] one says, laOuqiymanRa Sayadaka (tropical:) [I will assuredly straighten the bending of thy neck: or I will assuredly rectify thy proud stiffness]. (A.)
SayidN: see OaSoyadu.
SaAdiIRN [Of, or made of, brass or copper:] a rel. n. from SaAdN signifying “ brass ” and “ copper. ” (S.)
SayodaMCu Stones, (S, A, L, K,) or stone, (M,) of a white colour, (M, L,) of which cooking-pots are made; (S, M, A, L, K;) as also SayodaAnN↓. (A, L.) See also SayodaAnN.

And Rugged land or ground, (S, M, K,) containing stones: (M:) or land of which the earth is red, having rough stones even with the ground: (ISh:) or even, or level, ground, in which are pebbles: (AA:) or pebbles [themselves]. (Aboo-Wejreh, L.)

SayodaAnN Copper: (L, K: see also SaAdN:) and gold: (K:) [but this seems to be taken from the following passage in the T:] in the stone-cookingpot (Alburomap) there is sometimes [what is termed] SayodaAnN and SayodaMCu↓, in which is an appearance like the glistening of gold and silver; and the best is that which is like gold: so says AA. (T, L.) See also art. Sdn.
And Stone cookingpots: (S, L, K; and M in art. Sdn:) a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p. (IB, L.)
See also SayodaMCu.
SayodaAnu AlHaSaI Small pebbles. (L. [See also art Sdn.])
SayodaAnapN [as a n. un.: see SayodaAnN, above.
Also] A [demon of the kind called] guwl. (ISk, S, K.)
And A woman of evil disposition, (ISk, S, K,) [and] so SayuwdN↓, (M,) and of much talk. (ISk, S, K.)
See also art. Sdn.
SayuwdN: see SayRaAdN.
[Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A woman who takes, captures, or ensnares, something from her husband. (L, from a trad.) See also SayodaAnapN.

rajulN SayRaAdN [A man accustomed to, or in the habit of, taking, capturing, catching, snaring, or trapping, game, i. e. any kind of wild animals, or the like, fowl, &c., or fish; a sportsman; a hunter, a fowler, or a fisherman: see 1, second sentence]: (Msb:) and SayuwdN↓ signifies the same as SayRaAdN: (K:) you say kalobN SayuwdN [A dog used for hunting]: (S, A:) and SaqorN SayuwdN [A hawk used for catching game]: and the same epithet is applied to a female: (M:) its pl. is SuyudN (S, M, A) and SiydN; (Yoo, Sb, S, M;) the latter of the dial. of those, (S, M,) namely, the tribe of Temeem, (M,) who say rusolN [for rusulN]; (S, M;) the S being with kesr in order that the I may be preserved unchanged. (S.)
See also OaSoyadu, last sentence.

SaAYidN, applied to a man, Practising AlSRayod [i. e. the taking, capturing, or catching, &c., of game, or any kind of wild animals, or the like, fowl, &c., or fish; hunting, fowling, or fishing: see 1, second sentence]. (Mgh, Msb.)
AlSRaAYidu in the dial. of El-Yemen signifies The shank; syn. AlsRaAqu. (M.)
SayRuwdN, like tanRuwrN [in measure], An arrow going right, or hitting the mark. (K.)

OaSoyadu [More, or most, wont, or able, to take, or capture, or catch, game, or prey]. OaSoyadu mino layovi EifirRiyna wamino DayowanK [More wont, or able, to capture prey than the lion of 'Ifirreen and than the he-cat] is a prov. (Meyd.)

Also A camel having the disease termed Sayad; (S, M, A, L;) and so SaAdN↓, for cuw SaAdK, (L, K,) like maAlN for cuw maAlK, (L,) or for SayidN↓: (L:) pl. of the first SiydN. (L.) [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A man unable to look aside, (S, M,) by reason of disease. (S.) (assumed tropical:) A man who raises his head by reason of pride. (S.) (tropical:) A king who looks not aside, (M, A,) to the right or left, by reason of his pride. (A.) (assumed tropical:) A king: (K:) originally used in relation to a camel, and a king is so called because he raises his head by reason of pride, or because he does not look to the right or left. (S.) And A man having an inclining, or a bending, neck. (K, TA.)

AlOaSoyadu (assumed tropical:) The lion; (K;) because he walks proudly, not looking aside, as though he had the disease termed Sayad; (TA;) as also AlmuSoTaAdu↓ [as act. part. n. of 8]; and AlSRaAdu↓; (K, TA;) thus likened to a camel having the disease above mentioned; or, as in some copies of the K, not AlSRaAdu, but AlSayRaAdu↓. (TA.)

maSaAdN and muSoTaAdN↓ and mutaSayRadN↓ [A place of taking, capturing, or catching, &c., of game, or any kind of wild animals, or the like, fowl, &c., or fish; a place of hunting, fowling, or fishing]. (A. [The meaning is there indicated by the context, but not expressed.])
maSaAdN also signifies The upper, or highest, part of a mountain. (MF, from Aboo-'Alee El-Yoosee. [But this, accord. to the S &c., belongs to art. mSd.])
maSoyadN and miSoyadN: see miSoyadapN.
maSiydN pass. part. n. of 1: (Mgh, Msb:) see SayodN.

miSoyadapN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and maSoyadapN (M, and so in the handwriting of Az accord. to the L) and miSoyadN↓ (S, L, Msb, K) and maSoyadN↓ (so in the handwriting of Az accord. to the L) and maSiydapN↓ (M, Msb, K) A thing used for the purpose of AlSRayod [or the taking, capturing, or catching, &c., of game, or any kind of wild animals, or the like, fowl, &c., or fish]; (T, S, M, A, Msb, K;) a snare, trap, gin, or net; (MA in explanation of the first and last;) [the first and third said by Golius, on the authority of Meyd, to be applied peculiarly to a net; but all signify also any kind of trap: see XahomN:] pl. maSaAyidu, without C. (L, Msb.)
maSiydapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
muSoTaAdN: see OaSoyadu:
and see also maSaAdN.
mutaSayRadN: see maSaAdN.

1. SaAra kacaA, (T, S, Msb,) aor. yaSiyru, (S,) inf. n. SayoruwrapN (S, Msb) and SayorN, (S,) He, or it, attained to the state, or condition, of such a thing; (T;) became such a thing; (T, Msb;) in which sense the verb is like kaAna [in meaning, when the latter is non-attributive, and in having its subject
in the nom. case and its predicate in the accus.]. (T.) You say, SaAra zayodN rajulFA Zeyd became a man; or attained to the state, or condition, of a man. (TA.) And SaAra zayodN ganiyRFA Zeyd became rich, not having been so. (Msb.) And SaAra AlEaSiyru xamorFA The expressed juice became wine. (Msb.) [And SaAra laA XaIoCa Einodahu He became in a state, or condition, in which there was not anything in his possession. And SaAra yafoEalu kacaA He became in the state, or condition, of doing such a thing; i. e. he became occupied, or engaged, in doing such a thing; or he set about, began, commenced, took to, or betook himself to, doing such a thing; like jaEala. And SaAra laA yafoEalu XayoYFA He became in the state, or condition, of not doing anything; or he became unoccupied in doing anything. And SaAra laA yatakalRamu He became in the state of not speaking; he became speechless. And SaAra yatafakRaru fiI kacaA He became in a state of reflection upon such a thing; he began to reflect upon such a thing.]

One says also, SaAra AlOamoru UilaI kacaA, (M, A, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. maSiyrN, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) which is anomalous, being regularly maSaArN, like maEaAXN, (S,) and SayorN and SayoruwrapN, (M, A, K,) i. e. rajaEa Uilayohi: (Msb:) [but this is a loose explanation; the meaning being, The thing, or affair, or case, came eventually (see SiyrN) to such a state, or condition:] the difference between maSiyrN and marojiEN is, that the former word necessarily implies a difference [of the latter state or condition] from the former state or condition; but the latter word does not. (Bd in iii. 156.) [In this case, the ulterior state or condition is likened to a place: for]

SaAra also signifies He, or it, attained in respect of place: so in the saying, SaAra zayodN UilaI EamorKw [Zeyd came, or went, or pursued a course that brought him, to 'Amr]. (TA.) Sirotu UilaI fulaAnK [I came, &c., to such a one] is similar to the phrase in the Kur [iii. 27] waUilaI QllRehi QlomaSiyru [And to God, as the ultimate object, is the transition, or course, of every human being]. (S.) [Hence, OFlaA UilaI QllRehi taSiyru QloOumuwru, in the Kur xlii. last verse, which Bd explains by adding the words biQrotifaAEi AlwasaAYiTi waAltRaEalRuqaAti; the meaning being, Verily to God are things, or events, referrible, mediately and dependently: in the Expos. of the Jel expl. as meaning tarojiEu.]
[And in like manner one says, SaAra lahu kacaA Such a thing came to, betided, or befell, him, or it: and hence, he, or it, came to have, or became possessed of, such a thing.]

And SaAra fiI OaroDi falaApK [He became, or came to be, meaning he found himself, in a desert, or waterless, land]; i. q. waqaEa fiyhaA. (Msb in art. wqE.) And SaAra fiI AlrRabiyEi [He entered, lit. became in, the season called rbyE]; i. q. OarobaEa [which is expl. in the S as signifying daxala fiI AlrRabiyEi]. (K in art. rbE.)

SayorN signifies also The returning of seekers after herbage to the watering-places. (O, K.) And one says, SaAra AlrRajulu, aor. yaSiyru, [inf. n. SayorN,] The man stayed, or abode, at the water. (TA.) And SaAra AlnRaAsu AlmaMCa The people stayed, or abode, at the water. (M, K, TA.)

SaArahu, (S,) first pers. Sirotuhu, (M,) aor. as above, (S,) inf. n. SayorN, (K,) a dial. var. of SaArahu having for its aor. yaSuwruhu, [q. v.,] (S,) He cut it; (S, M, K;) and clave it, or split it. (M.)

And in like manner, [i. e. as a dial. var. of SaArahu having for its aor. yaSuwruhu,] He made it to incline, or lean. (S.) You say, SaAra wajohahu, aor. yaSiyru, (M,) as also yaSuwru, (M and K in art. Swr,) He turned his face towards a person or thing. (M.) And Sirotu Eunuqahu I twisted his neck. (M.) [Respecting the phrase faSirohunRa Uilayoka in the Kur ii. 262, accord. to one reading, see 1 in art. Swr.]
SaArahu, aor. yaSiyru, inf. n. SayorN, signifies also Habasahu [He confined, restricted, &c., him, or it]. (Msb.)

2. SyRrhu kacaA He made him, or it, to be in such a state, or condition; or he made him, or it, to be such a thing; [as also OaSaArahu↓;] syn. jaEalahu. (S.) You say, SayRaraniI lahu EabodFA and OFSaAraniI↓ [He made me to be to him a slave]. (A.)

[And SayRarahu UilaI kacaA and OaSaArahu↓ He, or it, made, or caused, him, or it, to come, or to pursue a course that led, to such a state, or condition; brought, or reduced, him, or it, thereto.] 'Omeyleh El-Fezáree said to his paternal uncle Ibn-'Ankà, maA AlRaciI OaSaAraka↓ UilaI maA OaraI yaA EamRi [What hath made thee to come, or brought thee, or reduced thee, to the state, or condition, that I see, O my paternal uncle?]. (M.) [In this case, the ulterior state or condition is likened to a place: for] you say, SayRarahu Uilayohi and OaSaArahu↓ [meaning He, or it, made him to come, or brought him, to him, or it; i. e., to a person, or place, or to a state, or condition:] (M, K:) and SayRaratoniI Uilayohi AlHaAjapu and OaSaAratoniI↓ [Want, or need, or necessity, made me to come, or brought me, to him, or it]. (A.) And [hence,] SayRara Uilayohi AlOamora He committed to him the thing, or affair; syn. fawRaDahu Alyh. (M in art. fwD.) [And SayRara lahu kacaA He made such a thing to come to, betide, or befall, him, or it: and consequently, he made him, or it, to have, or become possessed of, such a thing.]

taSoyiyrN is also by word, or covenant, as well as by deed. (Bd in ii. 20.) [You say, SayRarahu kacaA meaning He asserted, or pronounced, him, or it, to be in such a state, or condition; or to be such a thing: in which case, also, it is syn. with jaEalahu, whereby it is expl. in the S. And SayRara lahu kacaA He asserted, or pronounced, such a thing to belong to him, or it; asserted, or pronounced, him, or it, to have such a thing; attributed to him, or it, such a thing: and appointed or assigned, to him, or it, such a thing.]
4: see 2, in six places.
5. tSyRr OabaAhu He became like his father. (S, M, K.)
SayorN: see what next follows.

SiyrN The ulterior or ultimate, latter or last, state, or condition; the end, conclusion, event, issue, or result; of a thing, an affair, or a case; (S, M, O, Msb, K;) as also SayorN↓ (O, K) and maSiyrN↓ (S, O, Msb, TA) and maSiyrapN↓ (TA) and SayRuwrN↓, (S, M, K,) of the measure fayoEuwlN, (S,) and SayRuwrapN↓. (K.)

The verge, brink, or point, of an affair, or event. (M, K.) You say, OanaA EalaI SiyrK mino Oamori kacaA I am on the verge of such an affair, or event. (M.) And OanaA EalaI SiyrK mino HaAjatiI I am at the point of [attaining] the object of my want. (M.) And OanaA EalaI SiyrK mino qaDaMCi HaAjatiI I am at the point of accomplishing my want. (A.) And fulaAnN EalaI Siyri OamorK Such a one is at the point of accomplishing an affair. (S.)
A water at which people stay, or abide; (M, O, K;) as also SiyrapN↓. (TA.)

A crevice of a door. (S, M, A, Msb, K.) It is said in a trad., mano naZara fiI Siyri baAbK fafuqiYato Eayonuhu fahiIa hadarN [Whosoever looks into the crevice of a door and has his eye put out, it is a thing for which no mulct is to be exacted]: (S, M:) A'Obeyd says that this is the only instance in which the word [in this sense] has been heard. (S.)

[The condiment, made of small fish, called] SiHonaAp: (S, M, K:) or [a condiment, or the like,] resembling SHnAp: (M, K:) or what is called in Pers. maAhiI Mwaho [jelly of salted fish]; as also SiHonaApN: (Mgh voce SHnAp:) and the small salted fish of which SHnAp is made: (Kr, M, K:) or the young ones of fish: [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p: (Msb:) thought by IDrd to be Syriac; (TA;) by IAth, to be Pers., as also SHnAp. (TA in art. SHn.)
Also The OusofufR [properly bishop] of the Jews. (O, K.)
See also the next paragraph.

SiyrapN, (S, M, Msb, K,) accord. to A'Obeyd SiyorapN, with fet-h, but Az says that this is a mistake, (TA,) An enclosure (HaZiyrap) for sheep or goats (S, M, Msb, K) and for cows or bulls, (M, K,) constructed of wood and stones (M, TA) and of branches of trees; (TA;) as also SiyaArapN↓, (M, K,) which latter is said by IDrd to be of the dial. of the people of Baghdád: (TA:) pl. of the former SiyarN (S, M, Msb, K) and [coll. gen. n.] SiyrN↓. (M, K.)
See also SiyrN.

SiyaArN The Sanoj; (O and TA in this art., and TS and K and TA in art. Sbr;) i. e. the stringed instrument thus called: (TS and TA in that art., and O and TA in the present art.:) [this is the right meaning, as is shown by the latter of the two verses cited voce SubaArapN: but,] accord. to AHeyth, (O,) the sound of the Sanoj. (O and K in the present art.)
See also art. Swr.
SiyaArapN: see SiyrapN.
Also i. q. SubaArapN [q. v., signifying Stones, &c.]. (M in art. Sbr.)
SayRirN A grave. (AA, O, K. [Perhaps so called as being the ulterior abode.]) One says, hecaA SayRiru fulaAnK This is the grave of such a one. (O.)
And A company (jamaAEap). (O, K.)
See also art. Swr.

SayRirapN A thing, upon the head of a qaArap [or small isolated mountain or the like], resembling the [heap of stones, piled up as a sign of the way, called] Oamarap, except that it is cased, and the Amrp is
taller than it, and larger; or [in my originals “ and ”] they are both cased, but the Amrp is peaked and tall, and the SyRrh is round and wide, and has angles [app. at the base]; and sometimes it is excavated, and gold and silver are found in it: it is of the work of 'Ád and Irem. (O, TA.)
SaAYirN Staying, or abiding, at a water. (TA.) And SaAYirapN↓ A party, or people, staying, or abiding, at a water. (O, TA.)
Also A twister of men's necks. (TA.)
[And The pivot at the top, and that at the heel, of a door; the former of which turns in a socket in the lintel, and the latter in a socket in the threshold:] see saAkifN.
SaAYirapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Also Rain. (M, TA.)
And Herbage, or pasture. (M.) See the next paragraph.
Also The state of dryness to which herbage comes. (M.)
SayRuwrN: see SiyrN.

Also Judgment, or opinion, (S,) and understanding, or intellect, or intelligence; (S, M, K;) as in the saying, maA lahu SayRuwrN [He has not judgment nor understanding]: (S, M:) or a judgment, or an opinion, to which one eventually comes; as in the saying, maA lahu badoCN walaA SayRuwrN [He has not a first, nor a final, idea, thought, judgment, or opinion]. (A.)

Also, (O, K;) as AHn says, on the authority of Aboo-Ziyád, (O;) and SaAYirapN↓, (K,) Dry herbage or pasture, that is eaten long after its being green: (O, K:) and he adds that no herbs have SayRuwr except such as are of the kinds called AlvRagor and AlOafaAniI. (O, TA.)

OumRu SayRuwrK signifies A confused and dubious affair, (M, K,) through which there is no way of passing; as in the phrase waqaEa fiI OumRi SayRuwrK, mentioned by Yaakoob [ISk] in the “ Alfádh ” [accord. to some of the copies of that work]: originally meaning a [mountain, or hill, such as is termed] haDobap without a pass: but it is more probably SabRuwr [q. v., in art. Sbr]. (M.)
SayRuwrapN: see SiyrN, first sentence.
maSiyrN an inf. n. of SaAra [q. v.]. (S, M, &c.)
[Also A place, and hence a state or condition, to which a person, or thing, eventually comes: a place of destination.] See SiyrN.
A place where people alight and abide: a good place where people alight and abide. (TA.)

A place to which waters come, or take their course: (M, K:) [or a place of herbage, or pasture, and of water: pl. maSaAyiru: so in the saying,] xarajuwA UilaI maSaAyirihimo They went forth to their places of herbage, or pasture, and of water. (A.)
See also art. mSr.
maSiyrapN: see SiyrN, first sentence.

1. SaASati AlnRaxolapu, [aor. taSiySu,] The palm-tree bore dates which had become such as are termed SiyS, i. e., XiyS; (K, * TA;) as also SyRSt↓, (K,) inf. n. taSoyiySN; (TA;) and ASASt↓, (K,) inf. n. UiSaASapN; (TA;) all three on the authority of IAar, and the first mentioned by Sgh, in the O; and SaOoSaOat, from SiYoSaMCN [a dial. var. of SiySaMCN, i. q. SiySN]. (TA.)
2: see the preceding paragraph.
4: see the preceding paragraph.
SiySN, in the dial. of Belhárith Ibn-Kaab, The [bad] kind of dates called HaXafN; (S;) i. q. XiySN; as also SiySaMCN↓; (K;) SiySN and SiySaMCN being dial. vars. of XiySN and XiySaMCN. (S.)
SiySapN: see SiySiyapN, throughout.
SiySaMCN: see SiySN. [It is also said to signify] Dates without stones. (L in art. lqH.)

Also The pips of a colocynth that have no hearts, (AHn, S, K,) being husks only; (AHn;) to which a poet likens ticks that have been long left in a desolate place: (AHn, S: *) and so, accord. to some, of anything, such as the melon and the cucumber and the like. (AHn.)

SiySiyapN, (S, IB, O,) or SiySapN↓, (K,) thus in all the copies of the K, but it is a mistake, or a contracted form, (TA,) The weaver's [implement called] Xawokap, with which he makes the warp and the woof even: (S, IB, K:) but IB says that its last radical letter is I, not S; so that it should be mentioned among the class of infirm words: (TA;) pl. SayaASK. (S.)
Hence, (S,) The spur of the cock. (S, K.)

[Hence also,] The horn of the bull or cow, and of the gazelle: (K:) pl. as above, (TA,) signifying the horns of bulls or cows; which were sometimes fixed upon spears, instead of the iron heads: (S:) and to such horns, called by this name, conflict and faction, or sedition, (fitonap,) is likened in a trad., because of its grievousness: some say that the sing. is SiySapN, [as in the K,] contracted. (TA.)

And hence, (TA,) A wooden pin, or peg, with which dates are plucked out [when they are compacted in a mass, closely adhering together, in the receptacle of woven palm-leaves, or the like, in which they are packed]: (K:) likened to the horn of a bull or cow: in this sense, the word is written SiySapN: and a certain poet changes it to SiySajR. (TA.)

[Hence also,] Anything with which one defends himself: pl. as above, (K,) [in the CK erroneously written SayaASiI, as though it had the article Al prefixed to it, or were itself prefixed to another noun, for otherwise it is written and pronounced] with the [final] I elided. (TA.)
[Hence also,] A fortress: (K:) pl. in this sense as above. (S, TA.)
[Hence also,] A pastor who manages [and protects] well his herds or flocks: (AA, K:) in this sense also written SiySapN. (AA, as in the TA.)
1. SiEotu, aor. OaSiyEu, inf. n. SayoEN: see 1 in art. SwE, in three places.
4. ASAE Alganama: see 1, in art. SwE, latter half.
5. tSyRE: see 5 in art. SwE, last sentence.

Also, said of water, It was, or became, in a state of commotion upon the surface of the ground: (IDrd, O, K, * TA:) but tsyRE is more approved [in this sense, or as meaning “ it ran upon the surface of the ground, ” as expl. in art. syE]. (TA.)
7. AnSAE: see art. SwE. It belongs to this art. and to art. SwE. (K.)

OaSoyaEu [an epithet mentioned, but not expl., in the O and TA: it seems to be from SiEotuhu “ I dispersed it, or scattered it; ” and hence to be syn. with OasoyaEu, signifying In a state of commotion, or of exceeding commotion]. Rubeh says,
[app. meaning And he passed the day enveloping her, or it, or them, in the dust in a state of commotion, or of exceeding commotion]. (O, TA.)

2. SyRg TaEaAmahu, (ISh, O, K,) inf. n. taSoyiygN (K,) He soaked his food in sauce, or seasoning: (ISh, O, K:) and SyRghu biAlsRamoni He soaked it with clarified butter. (ISh, O.) [Sabagahu has a similar meaning, and is better known.]
SiygapN and other words in which I is substituted for w, see in art. Swg.

1. SaAfa, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) aor. yaSiyfu, inf. n. SayofN, (TA,) He, or it, (a company of men, M, Msb,) remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) during the [season called] Sayof, (S, O,) or during his, or their, Sayof, (O, Msb,) or during a Sayof, (K,) bihi in it, (S, M, O, K,) i. e. in a place; (S, M, O;) as also ASTAf↓, (S, O, * K, * TA,) and tSyRf↓; (S, * O, * K, * TA;) and biAlmakaAni AiSRayRafa↓ is like SayRafa↓ [probably a mistranscription for taSayRafa, of which AiSRayRafa is a var., and of which, together with one of this var., an ex. will be found in what follows]: (TA:) you say, Sifotu bimakaAni kacaA [I remained during the Sayof in such a place], and in like manner Sifotuhu, and taSayRafotuhu↓, and SayRafotuhu↓ [probably a mistranscription for AiSRayRafotuhu↓, as seems to be indicated by what here follows]: (M:) a Hudhalee says,
[I remained during the Sayof in Noamán, and she remained during the Sayof]. (M, TA.)

And Siyfati AlOaroDu, (S, M, O, K,) a verb of the class of EuniIa, (K,) originally Suyifat, (TA,) The land was rained upon by the rain of the [season called] Sayof. (S, M, O. *) And SifonaA, of the measure fuEilonaA, like xurifonaA and rubiEonaA, We were rained upon by the rain of the Sayof: (S:) and in like manner SuyRifonaA↓. (M, TA. *)

SAf AlsRahomu Eani Alhadafi, (S, M, O, Msb, * K, *) aor. yaSiyfu, (S, O, K,) inf. n. SayofN (S, M, O, Msb, K) and SanyofuwfapN (S, M, O) and maSiyfN, (M,) The arrow turned aside from the butt: (S, M, O, Msb, K:) a dial. var. of SAf having for its aor. yaSuwfu and
inf. n. SawofN. (O, Msb, * K.)
And SAf AlfaHolu Eano Taruwqatihi The stallion-camel turned away from covering the female that he had covered. (M.)

2. SayRafaniI It (a thing, S, O, K) sufficed me for my [season termed] Sayofap, (S, O, K,) or for my Sayof: (Msb:) by the “ thing ” here spoken of is meant food, or a garment, or some other thing. (TA.)
See also 1, in three places.

3. EaAmalahu muSaAyafapF (S, M, O, Msb, K) and SiyaAfFA (Lh, M) is from AlSRayofu, (M, O, Msb,) like muXaAharapF (S, O, Msb, K) from AlXRahoru, (O, Msb,) and muEaAwamapF (S, O) from AlEaAmu, (O,) i. e. [He made an engagement, or a contract, with him for work or the like] for the days of the Sayof. (S.) And in like manner, AisotaOojarahu muSaAyafapF and SiyaAfFA [He hired him, or took him as a hired man or hireling, for the period of the Sayof]. (M.)
4. ASAfwA They entered the [season called] Sayof: (S, M, O, Msb, K:) like OaXotawoA meaning “ They entered the [season called] XitaMC. ” (TA.)
And ASAft She (a camel) brought forth in the Sayof. (M.)

[Hence,] ASAf said of a man, (tropical:) He had offspring born to him [in the summer of his age, i. e.] when he was old, or advanced in age: (S, M, O, K, TA:) or he had no offspring born to him until he was advanced in age, or old. (L, TA.) And (tropical:) He abstained from women while a young man, and then married when old, or advanced in age. (M, TA.)
ASAf QllRehu EanRiI XarRa fulaAnK God turned away, or may God turn away, from me the evil, or mischief, of such a one: (S, O, K: *) belonging to this art. and to art. Swf. (O, TA.)
5. taSayRafa, and its var. AiSRayRafa: see 1, first sentence, in four places.
8: see 1, first sentence.
SaAfN: see SaAYifN:
and see also art. Swf.

SayofN as signifying A certain portion of the year is said by ISk to be fem.: (TA, voce XitaMCN; q. v.:) [but by others I find it treated as masc.:] the Sayof as meaning one of the seasons is well known: (M:) Lth says, it is one of the quarters of the year; and is applied by the vulgar to a half of the year [i. e. to the half-year commencing at the vernal equinox; the other half-year being called by them the XitaMC]: Az says, it is, with the Arabs, the division which the vulgar in El-'Irák and Khurásán call the rabiyE [i. e. the spring]; it consists of three months; and the division that next follows it is with the Arabs the qayoZ; and in it is the jamorap [q. v.] of the qiyoZ; then, after this, is the division called the xariyf; and then, after this, the division called the XitaMC: (TA:) [i. e.] it is the quarter of the year vulgarly called the rabiyE, commencing when the sun enters Aries: but is applied by the vulgar to the qayoZ, which is the [summer, i. e.] the quarter commencing when the sun enters Cancer: (Msb in art. zmn; q. v.:) [F says,] the Sayof is the qayoZ [i. e. summer, or the hot season]; or [the season] after the rabiyE: (K:) and [Sgh says,] the Sayof is one of the divisions of the year; which is after the rabiyE: (O:) [but unless this explanation in the O denote only a vulgar meaning, and the latter of the two explanations in the K be virtually a repetition, we must suppose that, in each of them, by the rbyE is meant the season of rain thus termed, which ends in March: (see the latter of the two tables which I have inserted voce zamanN:) most probably, I think, both have been faultily transcribed from what here follows; for the S is largely copied in the O, and the S and O are among the principal sources of the K, which generally follows the O when it differs (rightly or wrongly) from the S:] the Sayof is one of the divisions of the year; which is after [that called] AlrRabiyEu AlOawRalu and before [that called] AlqayoZu: (S:) [this admits of two renderings, both of which are correct; namely, the quarter after the season of two months called AlrbyE AlAwRl (which ends in March) and before the quarter called AlqyZ (which is summer); and also the season of two months after that called AlrbyE AlAwRl and before the similar season called AlqyZ: (see the former of the two tables to which I have referred above:) but probably the latter only was meant by him who first gave. this explanation:] the pl. is OaSoyaAfN (M, O, K) and SuyuwfN: (M, Msb:) SayofapN↓ is a more particular term [app. meaning A single Sayof; (see 2;)]; it is like XatowapN [q. v.]; (O, K;) and its pl. is SiyafN, like bidarN pl. of badorapN. (Fr, O, K.) AlSRayofa DayRaEoti AllRabana is a saying expl. in art. DyE [q. v.]. (O, K.)

AlSRayofu also signifies The rain that comes in the [season called] Sayof; (S, O, Msb, K;) [see, again, the second of the tables to which I have referred above, and see also nawoN;] and (O, K) so AlSRayRifu↓; (M, O, K;) also signifying the herbage thereof: (M:) or, (K,) accord. to Lth, (O,) the latter signifies the rain that falls after the division [a mistake for the rain] called the rabiyE; (O, K;) and so the former; (K;) and it is also called AlSRayofiIRu↓; (O, K;) which likewise signifies the herbage thereof. (TA.) Hence the prov., relating to the completing of the performance of a needful affair, tamaAmu AlrRabiyEi AlSRayofu [The completion of the rain called the rbyE is that called the Syf]: for the rain called the rbyE is the first rain, and the Syf is that which is [next] after it. (TA.)
Myapu AlSRayofi is [A verse] in the end (Mxir) of suwrapu AlnRisaMCi [the 4th chapter of the Kur-án, but which verse I know not], mentioned in a tradition. (TA.)
Also The female of the buwm [or owl]. (Kr, M.)
SayofapN: see the next preceding paragraph, latter half.
SayofiIRN A thing of, or belonging to, the [season called] Sayof. (S, O.)
A young camel born in the Sayof. (M.) [And in like manner a sheep or goat: see SafariIRN.]
And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) A son born to a father [in the summer of his age, i. e.] old, or advanced in age. (S, M, O.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce riboEiIRN.]
See also SayofN, near the end of the paragraph.

SayofiyRapN [used as a subst., or as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, for miyrapN SayofiyRapN,] and SaAYifapN↓ signify The miyrap [or provision of corn &c.] in the first part of the Sayof [here meaning spring]; i. e. the second myrp; for the first of the miyra is the riboEiyRap, then the SayofiyRap, then the dafaYiyRap, and then the ramaDiyRap: (M:) or the SaAYifap↓ of a people is their miyrap in the Sayof. (S, O, K.) [See miyrapN.]
[SayofiyRapN is also applied to The latter, or last, season of the bringing forth of camels; so in an explanation of hubaEN in the S and TA.]
SayofiyRapN [fem. of SayofiIRN: and also used as a subst., or as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant: see the latter word].

SaAYifN is used as an imitative sequent in the phrase SayofN SaAYifN, (S, O, K,) meaning A warm, or hot, [spring or] summer: (PS:) a phrase like layolN laAYilN &c. (S, O.) And one says yawomN SaAYifN, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) meaning A hot day; (O, K;) and yawomN SaAfN↓ (S, O, K) was sometimes said, meaning SaAYifN; like yawomN raAHN [as meaning raAYiHN]: (S:) and layolapN SaAYifapN [a hot night]. (S, O, Msb.)
And maTarN SaAYifN [app. Rain coming in the Sayof, meaning spring; as also muSiyfN↓, occurring in a verse cited voce rasama, q. v.]. (M.) See also SaAfK in art. Sfw.
SaAYifapN [fem. of SaAYfN, q. v.

Also, as a subst.,] A warring, or warring and plundering, expedition in the Sayof [i. e. either spring or summer]: (M, Mgh, and Ham p. 239:) pl. SawaAYifu. (Mgh, and Ham ib.) And [particularly] (Mgh) A warring, or warring and plundering, expedition against the Greeks (AlrRuwm): because they [i. e. the Arabs] used to go on expeditions of this kind in the Syf, (S, Mgh, O, K,) and to return in the winter, (Mgh,) on account of the cold and snow. (S, O, K.) And they said, waliIa fulaAnN AlSRaAYifapa, meaning Such a one was commander of the army going on a warring, or warring and plundering, expedition in the Sayof: (Ham ubi suprà:) [but Mtr says,] he who explains SaAYifapN as meaning the place [of], or the army [engaged in, such an expedition], errs: [adding that the Hanafee Imám] Mohammad has used the phrase AlSRawaAYifu wanaHowuhaA mina AlEasaAkiri AlEiZaAmi either by surmise or by extension of the [proper] meaning. (Mgh.)
See also SayofiIRN, in two places.
Also The time, or season of the Sayof. (M, TA.)
AlSRayRifu: see SayofN, last quarter of the paragraph.
SayRifapN, originally SayowifapN: see art. Swf.

maSiyfN A place of remaining, staying, dwelling, or abiding, during the [season called] Sayof; (S, O, TA;) as also muSoTaAfN↓ (S, K, TA) and mutaSayRafN↓: (TA:) and a time thereof: (Sb, M, TA:) pl. maSaAyifu. (Msb.)

And A place in which dates are dried in the [season called] Sayof.
(Har p. 165.)
[Also part. n. of the verb in the phrase Siyfati AlOaroDu:] you say OaroDN maSiyfapN and maSoyuwfapN↓ Land rained upon by the rain of the [season called] Sayof. (S, M, O, K.)
Also, applied to a channel in which water flows, Winding, or tortuous: (S, M:) from SaAfa, like maDiyqN from DaAqa. (S.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce karabapN: and see also maDiyfN.]
muSiyfN: see SAYifN.

Also, (M, O, K,) and muSiyfapN, (O, K,) [in the CK, erroneously, maSiyfN and maSiyfapN,] and miSoyaAfN↓, (M, O, K,) applied to a she-camel, (M, O, K,) That has brought forth in the [season called] Sayof: (M, L, TA:) or having with her her young one: (O, K, TA:) pl. of the last maSaAyiyfu. (TA in art. jr.)
And [hence,] the first, (tropical:) A man having a child born to him [in the summer of his age, i. e.] when he is old, or advanced in age. (TA.)
miSoyaAfN, applied to land (OaroDN), Having in it abundance of the rain of the [season called] Sayof. (O, K.)
And, so applied, Late in producing herbage. (O, K.)
See also muSiyfN.
[Hence,] (tropical:) A man who does not take a wife until he has whiteness in the hair of his head mixed with the blackness thereof. (O, K.)
maSoyuwfap: see maSiyfN.
muSoTaAfN: see maSiyfN.
mataSayRafN: see maSiyfN.
1. SaAka bihi, aor. yaSiyku, inf. n. SayokN: see 1 in art. Swk.
3. ZalRa yuSaAyikuniI munocu Alyawomi a dial. var. of yuSaAYikuniI. (TA in art. Swk. See 3 in art. SOk.)
1. SaAla, aor. yaSiylu, i. q. SAl having for its aor. yaSuwlu, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) i. e. He (a man) leaped or sprang [&c.]. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

Siyla lahumo kacaA, (S and K in art. Swl,) or lahu, (Ibn- 'Abbád and O and K in the present art.,) Such a thing was appointed, or ordained, or prepared, for them, or for him. (Ibn-'Abbád, S, O, K.) This is its proper place. (TA.)
SiylapN The knot of the Eacabap [i. e. of the end, or of the suspensory thong, of a whip]. (S and K in art. Swl, and O in the present art.)
SiyaAlN and SiyaAlapN: see art. Swl.
SuyRamN and SiyRamN and SuyRaAmN and SayaAmaI pls. of SaAYimN, expl. in art. Swm.
SiynapN [originally SiwonapN]: see art. Swn.

SiyniIRN Of, or relating to, AlSRiyn [i. e. China]. (TA.) [Hence,] OawaAnK SiyniyRapN, (K, TA,) and [the pl.] SawaAniIRu, (S,) Vessels of AlSRiyn, (S, K, TA,) made in the country thus called [i. e. China]. (TA.)
SiyniynN A certain drug, [said to be] well known. (TA. [But what it is I have been unable to learn.])
SiyaAnN and SiyaAnapN inf. n. of SaAna expl. in art. Swn.
The former, of which SuyaAnN and SayaAnN are said to be vars., is also syn. with SiwaAnN, likewise expl. in art. Swn.
SayRinN: see art. Swn.
